claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines don’t cause immunodeficiency syndrome - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is based on incorrectly using Covid-19 case rates to claim being vaccinated increases a person’s risk of being infected with Covid-19.

claims.text: Bill Gates has called for the withdrawal of all Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates didn’t say all Covid-19 vaccines should be withdrawn - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He didn’t. These ‘quotes’ were taken from a satirical article.

claims.text: An ITV News article has the headline “Shaking the duvet too vigorously while making your bed can increase your chances of a heart attack, scientists warn”.

claimReview.title: Warning that vigorous duvet-shaking can raise risk of heart attack is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The screenshot showing this has been doctored and no such article exists.

claims.text: The BBC said there is HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Potential Covid-19 vaccine which used HIV protein was never rolled out - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The BBC was talking about a vaccine which was trialled but never rolled out, which contained a small piece of HIV protein. None of the Covid-19 vaccines in use contain HIV material.

claims.text: There’s no extra money for Wales or Scotland to deliver the same council tax rebate scheme that was announced in England.

claimReview.title: Wales and Scotland are getting money to fund a council tax rebate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Welsh and Scottish governments are receiving money from the UK government as a result of the council tax rebate scheme, but other areas of its estimated budget have been revised downwards as a result of England’s provisional budget for those areas being revised downwards too.

claims.text: A BBC News article reports that breathing too many times a day could raise your risk of a heart attack.

claimReview.title: ‘BBC article’ claiming shallow breathing increases risk of heart attack is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The article is fake.

claims.text: US military data shows a huge increase in rates of cancer, as well as other medical conditions, following the Covid-19 vaccine rollout.

claimReview.title: US data doesn’t prove increase in cancer following vaccine rollout - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data supporting this claim is flawed, and has been withdrawn by officials.

claims.text: The UK government now admits that vaccines have damaged the natural immune system of those who have been double-vaccinated.

claimReview.title: The government hasn’t admitted Covid-19 vaccines damage your natural immune system - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government hasn’t said this and there’s no evidence it’s true.

claims.text: UK residents now have to pay dozens of different taxes, none of which existed 100 years ago.

claimReview.title: Income tax, fuel tax and inheritance tax all existed 100 years ago - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t true. Income tax, which is listed in the post, was first introduced in 1799. And there are a number of other taxes mentioned that aren’t in place in the UK.

claims.text: 136 children in the UK have died of Covid since the pandemic began.

claimReview.title: NHS video overstates the risk of Covid-19 to children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The number of deaths that we know were caused by Covid in people aged under 18 in England and Wales is 50, although this figure doesn’t include 2022 deaths, and it would rise slightly with the inclusion of data from Scotland and Northern Ireland.

claims.text: A picture of tractors blocking a motorway in Holland was taken yesterday and is part of a global protest movement.

claimReview.title: Picture of tractors in the Netherlands has nothing to do with Canada ‘freedom convoy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The picture is from 2019, and the protest shown was against climate change policies in the Netherlands.

claims.text: A video from the news shows a ‘crisis actor’ moving in a body bag.

claimReview.title: Moving ‘crisis actor’ in body bag is actually climate change protester - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. The video shows climate policy protesters.

claims.text: Anyone facing financial hardship with less than £4 on a prepaid energy meter can call and ask for a £49 fuel voucher twice a year.

claimReview.title: Viral posts about £49 fuel vouchers are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not an established scheme across the UK. Financial support with energy bills is available but the claim that everyone is entitled to a £49 voucher twice a year is incorrect.

claims.text: People who share then comment on a Facebook post will be given the chance to win a holiday.

claimReview.title: Offer of Santorini holiday ‘reward’ returns to Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears not to be true. A scam with the same words appeared two years ago.

claims.text: There is a link between Covid-19 vaccines and a new strain of HIV identified in the Netherlands.

claimReview.title: No link between Covid-19 vaccines and new HIV strain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. The HIV strain identified is thought to have arisen around 30 years ago.

claims.text: Families could suffer a £2,000-a-year average hit from the cost of living crisis.

claimReview.title: Mirror’s claim that households will be £2,000 a year poorer overstates impact of inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is based on a calculation which overstates the impact of inflation, by factoring in both how much prices will rise and how much ‘real wages’—which already allow for inflation—will fall.

claims.text: Germ theory is a scientifically proven lie.

claimReview.title: Germ theory is not ‘a lie’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Germ theory is an established scientific fact.

claims.text: McDonald’s uses mechanically separated chicken.

claimReview.title: McDonald’s doesn’t use mechanically separated chicken - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False.

claims.text: A tornado of rain is pictured over the sea.

claimReview.title: Rain tornado off Jersey is CGI - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tornado was created with CGI and is not real.

claims.text: A photograph shows Meryl Streep on the New York subway shortly after an unsuccessful audition for a role in King Kong.

claimReview.title: Photo of Meryl Streep on the subway is not after King Kong audition - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The photograph was taken years later, when Ms Streep was a successful actress.

claims.text: Keanu Reeves said that “humanity is showing signs of breaking free from the matrix”.

claimReview.title: Keanu Reeves did not say ‘humanity is showing signs of breaking free from the matrix’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence the actor ever actually said this.

claims.text: One in 100 children who catch Covid-19 get sick enough with the disease to be admitted to hospital.

claimReview.title: NHS video overstates the risk of Covid-19 to children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It reflects the approximate proportion of children who tested positive for Covid-19, who were admitted to hospital. This rate has roughly halved recently. A child’s real risk of admission due to Covid is also much lower than this rate suggests, because many infections are not detected as cases, and some admissions are not due to Covid.

claims.text: Arrest warrants for Australia PM Scott Morrison, state premiers and other government officials have now been served to New South Wales police with a deadline for arrest of 31 January.

claimReview.title: Australian police taking no action over politician ‘arrest warrants’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New South Wales police said they had received documentation from a protest group but that no further police action was expected. No such arrests were made by that date.

claims.text: West Yorkshire Police is investigating the Covid-19 vaccine programme.

claimReview.title: West Yorkshire Police is not investigating the Covid-19 vaccine programme - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. A reference number was created following reports of alleged criminality but West Yorkshire Police has confirmed that  no crimes have been recorded, no criminal enquiries are ongoing and there are no investigations relating to this report or any other alleged criminality relating to the vaccine program.

claims.text: Fifty percent of children who acquire myocarditis caused by Covid-19 vaccines will die within five years of diagnosis.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated Brits won’t have AIDS by the end of February 2022 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. It is based on misquoted data from 26 years ago. The study featured a group of largely middle-aged patients with histories of heart failure. More recent research suggests lower mortality rates.

claims.text: Research has found that a massive amount of the population has a deadly heart condition after a year of Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Estimates of heart condition prevalence in the UK isn’t linked to vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We could find no evidence that aortic stenosis has anything to do with Covid-19 vaccines. There’s no evidence the vaccines cause the condition, which is due to a congenital heart defect, or damage to the heart that occurs with age.

claims.text: The morning after pill is an abortifacient, so induces an abortion.

claimReview.title: Jacob Rees-Mogg wrong to suggest morning after pill is ‘abortifacient’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The morning after pill doesn’t induce an abortion, but rather prevents ovulation so no egg is fertilised, preventing pregnancy, in the manner of contraception.

claims.text: Between 80,000 and 100,000 children are not on any school rolls at all.

claimReview.title: We don’t know how many children aren’t on school rolls - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Children's Commissioner misspoke when she made this claim. There is no current data to support this.

claims.text: Government data shows the fully vaccinated will develop AIDS by the end of February.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated Brits won’t have AIDS by the end of February 2022 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that vaccines cause a type of AIDS, that declining efficacy from a Covid-19 vaccine would cause AIDS or that being vaccinated reduces your protection against Covid-19.

claims.text: At least 133 children have died of Covid-19 in the UK.

claimReview.title: GP’s article overstates the number of Covid-19 deaths in children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is the number of deaths in England following a positive Covid-19 test in people aged under 20. The number of deaths that we know were caused by Covid in people aged under 18 in England and Wales is 50, although this figure is slightly less recent.

claims.text: Incidences of heart attacks, Bell’s palsy, congenital malformations, female infertility, pulmonary embolisms, neurological abnormalities and cancers have increased dramatically, according to NHS data.

claimReview.title: False US military health data misrepresented as NHS figures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures published in the social media post are based on false US military data, not NHS data.

claims.text: We have had a colder than usual winter.

claimReview.title: Rishi Sunak wrong to say we’ve had a ‘colder than usual’ winter - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have had a warmer than usual winter, in the UK at least.

claims.text: There was a large rise in the number of Covid deaths on 2 February 2022.

claimReview.title: Higher number of reported Covid-19 deaths down to backlog - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A large number of deaths were reported on this day, because of a delay in the system. At the beginning of February 2022, the number of deaths happening each day was falling.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines are not safe because people are dying and getting seriously ill as a result of receiving them.

claimReview.title: A surgeon made several incorrect claims about Covid-19 vaccine on GB News - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Although there have been some extremely rare cases of death or serious illness caused by the Covid-19 vaccines, it is much safer to be vaccinated.

claims.text: UKHSA data shows that people who receive a booster dose of the Covid-19 vaccine are more likely to be infected with the disease.

claimReview.title: A surgeon made several incorrect claims about Covid-19 vaccine on GB News - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The UKHSA data does not show this. Indeed the UKHSA warns against misinterpreting its data in this way.

claims.text: While the media talks a lot of the 150,000 deaths, perhaps they should have been talking about the number of people who died 'of Covid' not 'with Covid'. That was just 17,371 up to the end of quarter three 2021

claimReview.title: Dan Wootton and David Davis make incorrect claims about Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is the number of people who died of Covid and had no pre-existing conditions in England and Wales.

claims.text: Sky News tweeted: “BREAKING NEWS: New photos show Boris Johnson drinking with the Berkeley Hunt at get together during first lockdown. More to follow….#PartyGate”.

claimReview.title: Fake Sky News tweet claims PM drank with foxhound pack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This tweet wasn’t tweeted by an official Sky News account. No such story has been reported.

claims.text: The founder of the World Economic Forum Klaus Schwab is related to the Rothschild family.

claimReview.title: Klaus Schwab is not related to the Rothschild family - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The post suggests Mr Schwab is related to a woman whose surname before marriage was Rothschild but is not directly related to the House of Rothschild. Mr Schwab has said they are not related.

claims.text: There are 420,000 more people in work now than at the start of the pandemic.

claimReview.title: Nadine Dorries wrong to claim employment higher than pre-pandemic level - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There are 420,000 more employees now than in March 2020, but the total number of people in work, including the self-employed, is 600,000 lower than it was before the start of the pandemic.

claims.text: The spike proteins generated by the body in response to the Covid-19 vaccines make people a ticking time bomb for cancer, blood clots and other ailments.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines don’t make you a ‘ticking time bomb’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Some health problems have been linked to vaccination in very rare cases, but the risk from not being vaccinated is much higher.

claims.text: The CDC said that immunity from a prior Covid-19 infection is “paramount”.

claimReview.title: A surgeon made several incorrect claims about Covid-19 vaccine on GB News - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not what the CDC said. It recommends vaccination against Covid-19.

claims.text: The ONS has admitted only 6,183 people died of Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The ONS has not said only 6,183 people have died of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This figure is the number of people in England and Wales who, up to the end of 2021, died of Covid-19 where only Covid-19 was listed on their death certificate. In most cases Covid-19 will lead to another disease or condition before death.

claims.text: Kary Mullis said: “Anyone can test positive for practically anything with a PCR test, if you run it long enough with PCR if you do it well, you can find almost anything in anybody. It doesn’t tell you that you’re sick.”

claimReview.title: PCR inventor Kary Mullis quote doesn’t prove the tests are useless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Kary Mullis did not say these words exactly but statements to that effect at an event discussing HIV and AIDS in 1997. It’s not true that you can find ‘anything in anybody’ using PCR tests. Covid-19 PCR tests are very specific.

claims.text: 97% of the PPE secured was ready, fit-for-purpose and there on the front line

claimReview.title: Michael Gove incorrect to say 97% of PPE procured 'fit-for-purpose' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While this PPE may have been usable, it was not all fit for use in the health and care sector, nor on the front line.

claims.text: Data from 145 countries shows that deployment of Covid-19 vaccines causes an increase in Covid-19 cases and deaths.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines haven’t caused an increase in cases and deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Medical statisticians have explained that the analysis, which is not peer reviewed or published in an academic journal, is deeply flawed. 

Lots of data is available that shows the contrary.

claims.text: PCR tests which use 40 or 45 cycles give false positives which amounts to medical fraud.

claimReview.title: PCR inventor Kary Mullis quote doesn’t prove the tests are useless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Laboratories in the UK typically do 40 cycles to PCR test samples for the virus that causes Covid-19, and some do 45. But these rarely give false positives and do not amount to medical fraud.

claims.text: Drivers should give five feet when overtaking cyclists.

claimReview.title: Highway Code changes infographic needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for speeds up to 30 miles per hour. At higher speeds, the Highway Code says drivers should give cyclists more space.

claims.text: An Israeli study showed that vaccinated people were 27 times more likely to catch Covid-19 than unvaccinated people.

claimReview.title: A surgeon made several incorrect claims about Covid-19 vaccine on GB News - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is very misleading. The study compared vaccinated people with unvaccinated people who had been previously infected. It did not show that vaccinated people were more likely to catch Covid-19 than unvaccinated people in general.

claims.text: The Spanish Flu wasn’t a flu virus, it was a bacteria that caused severe and lethal pneumonia.

claimReview.title: Spanish Flu pandemic wasn’t caused by a meningitis vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The 1918 flu pandemic, also known as Spanish Flu, was caused by the influenza A H1N1 virus. There is evidence that many of the people who died in the pandemic may have had an additional bacterial pneumonia.

claims.text: The Spanish Flu did not originate in Spain. It actually originated in Fort Riley, Kansas due to an experimental bacterial meningitis.

claimReview.title: Spanish Flu pandemic wasn’t caused by a meningitis vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There continues to be a debate about where geographically the 1918 pandemic began, and there were some early cases documented in Fort Riley, Kansas. However, experts say there is “no way” that a meningitis vaccine could have contributed to starting a flu epidemic.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines could cause neurodegenerative diseases in young people.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines are not associated with developing neurodegenerative diseases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA has told Full Fact there is “no credible evidence” of an association between the Covid-19 vaccines and neurodegenerative diseases.

claims.text: The International Criminal Court in The Hague has acknowledged documents associated with a campaign to end the Covid-19 vaccine rollout.

claimReview.title: Video filmed at police station is filled with Covid-19 vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but this is only a standard acknowledgement of a complaint and not proof of an investigation or wrongdoing.

claims.text: Cyclists should cycle in the centre of the lane.

claimReview.title: Highway Code changes infographic needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true for quiet roads, but on busy roads they should stay at least 0.5 metres from the kerb.

claims.text: National Insurance contributions will increase by 1.25% from 6 April 2022.

claimReview.title: Government website makes percentage error on National Insurance rise - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not a percentage increase on existing National Insurance rates, it is a 1.25 percentage point increase applied to existing National Insurance rates. For many, this will mean a tax rise of more than 10%

claims.text: Only 17,500 people have died of Covid in England and Wales.

claimReview.title: Alex Belfield is wrong to say that only 17,500 people died of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The true number is more than 140,000. 17,500 is roughly how many of these people did not have other pre-existing conditions.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines can change your DNA.

claimReview.title: Facebook video on unvaccinated people makes incorrect claims about DNA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. mRNA vaccines do not alter DNA.

claims.text: Cyclists are not obliged to use cycle lanes.

claimReview.title: Highway Code changes infographic needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, though this was the case already.

claims.text: The BBC did not report on these queues.

claimReview.title: Dover lorry queues can be seen from space, like most UK traffic can - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The BBC News website did publish a local report on the queues that day. We don’t know if the stories appeared on BBC televised news.

claims.text: Cyclists on either side of a vehicle have priority when cars are turning.

claimReview.title: Highway Code changes infographic needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The police have the evidence and authority under the Criminal Law Act 1967 to confiscate Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video filmed at police station is filled with Covid-19 vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Police have some powers to close public premises but there is almost no likelihood they would close down a Covid-19 vaccine facility, particularly if there is no evidence those facilities are involved in the perpetration of crime.

claims.text: You can save someone’s life if they’re having a stroke using a needle. If someone is having a stroke, sterilise a needle then use it to prick the tips of all 10 fingers of that person. After their fingers start to bleed, prick the soft parts of their ear. Then send them to a hospital.

claimReview.title: A needle cannot save the life of someone having a stroke - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You absolutely should not do this. If you suspect someone is having a stroke, call 999.

claims.text: Klaus Schwab wrote that four billion people would die through planned epidemics, war and starvation by 2050.

claimReview.title: Klaus Schwab is not related to the Rothschild family - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He didn’t write this. It’s a passage from a 1992 conspiratorial text which also seems to wrongly attribute it to novelist H.G. Wells.

claims.text: Rubbing hydrogen peroxide on the body “once, preferably twice a day” treats cancer.

claimReview.title: Rubbing hydrogen peroxide over your body every day does not treat cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that hydrogen peroxide applied to the skin, as described in the video, treats cancer. Depending on the strength of application, it can cause burning, blistering and permanent scarring.

claims.text: Pfizer’s CEO Albert Bourla hasn’t been vaccinated against Covid-19 because he is “healthy” and doesn’t want to “cut the line”.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s CEO has had Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Bourla said this in December 2020. He has since publicly shared pictures of him being vaccinated against Covid-19.

claims.text: A recent poll by parent voice charity Parentkind found that nearly two thirds of parents of secondary school children are not in favour of masks in the classroom.

claimReview.title: Parents mostly against face masks in classrooms - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The survey was not necessarily representative of parents in general. However, other data supports the finding that most parents are opposed to face masks in classrooms.

claims.text: There were continuous lorry queues at Dover on 22 January 2022, that were longer than the Channel itself, and could be seen from space.

claimReview.title: Dover lorry queues can be seen from space, like most UK traffic can - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long exactly the queues were on that date. They likely could be seen from satellite images, as most road queues can be. We haven’t seen evidence the queues were longer than the English Channel.

claims.text: If you challenge someone not wearing a face mask you can be held personally liable for a summary offence under equality laws and could be subject to a fine of up to £9,000.

claimReview.title: Fake government guidance is wrong about face masks and equality laws - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While the government advises that members of the public should not challenge someone who is not wearing a face covering, doing so does not constitute a criminal offence.

claims.text: Photos of a swimming pool with visitors placed between social distancing screens in the water are not real.

claimReview.title: Photos of swimming pool with social distancing screens is genuine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is genuine footage taken at the reopening of a spa in France.

claims.text: There is a live criminal investigation into the Covid-19 vaccine programme.

claimReview.title: Video filmed at police station is filled with Covid-19 vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t. A crime reference number was created after campaigners visited a London police station in December 2021. The Metropolitan Police has confirmed there is no investigation.

claims.text: Cyclists should ride two abreast.

claimReview.title: Highway Code changes infographic needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Cyclists can ride two abreast but the Highway Code does not say they should.

claims.text: There have been three deaths linked to Covid-19 vaccines among children in Australia.

claimReview.title: Tweet claiming three child deaths from vaccines in Australia is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. The tweet claiming this is fake, purporting to be from an Australian health official. The New South Wales health ministry has said the information in the tweet is incorrect.

claims.text: The UK has recorded five times more deaths “due to” the Covid-19 vaccines than all other vaccines over the past five years

claimReview.title: Claims Covid-19 vaccines have led to five times more deaths than other vaccines are based on false assumptions - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These refer to the number of deaths reported after vaccination though may not have been due to vaccination.

claims.text: Receiving a Covid-19 vaccine makes you more likely to be admitted to hospital with the disease.

claimReview.title: A surgeon made several incorrect claims about Covid-19 vaccine on GB News - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Receiving a Covid-19 vaccine makes you much less likely to be admitted to hospital with the disease.

claims.text: Samuel L. Jackson, a student at Morehouse College, can be seen in the background of a photo of Dr Martin Luther King Jr. playing pool in 1966.

claimReview.title: Samuel L. Jackson is not in photo of Martin Luther King playing pool - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although Mr Jackson was a student at Morehouse College, he confirmed on Twitter he wasn’t in the photo. The picture was not taken at the College.

claims.text: An official NHS poster warns that Covid-19 vaccines cause Bell’s palsy.

claimReview.title: NHS poster about Bell’s palsy and vaccines is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a genuine NHS or UK government poster, and the MHRA says there’s currently no evidence of higher rates of Bell’s palsy following vaccination.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccination has resulted in “catastrophic death and injury figures”.

claimReview.title: Video filmed at police station is filled with Covid-19 vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: With 52 million people currently vaccinated in the UK, there have been 439,578 reports of adverse reactions and 1,972 reports of death following vaccination. However, these reports are not evidence vaccines caused those reactions or deaths. All Covid-19 vaccines are licensed as safe for use in the UK and continuously monitored.

claims.text: 94% of small and medium-size businesses say the Government is ignoring their concerns about how the UK leaves the EU.

claimReview.title: Small businesses and Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 94% of 649 owner-managed firms told a survey the Government wasn't listening to their concerns about Brexit negotiations, or only occasionally listening. The survey wasn’t designed to be representative of all SMEs though.

claims.text: In August, Serco were given £108 million to run the test and trace system.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Serco was awarded this contract for running some contact tracing call centres.

claims.text: One estimate of the “economic cost” of Brexit, £130 billion, now exceeds what we’ve paid in to the EU over 47 years.

claimReview.title: Has the “cost of Brexit” amounted to more than the UK’s total net contributions over 47 years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no definitive figure for the economic impact of Brexit. The analysis this is based on estimates the UK’s GDP is £130 billion lower in 2019 than it would have been had it followed pre-EU referendum trends. Between 1973 and 2018 the UK’s net contribution to the EU was £216 billion in real terms.

claims.text: A major clean-up of an Indian beach led to hundreds of thousands sea turtles hatching along its coast this week.

claimReview.title: Thousands of sea turtles did not hatch on Indian beach this week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The clean-up happened over three years ago. At least 80 turtles were spotted there afterwards, not hundreds of thousands. A photo claiming to show the beach after the clean-up, covered in turtles,  was taken on the other side of India.

claims.text: Smoking ban credited for 74% drop in heart attacks in Scotland.

claimReview.title: Herald suggests Scotland’s 2006 smoking ban behind drop in heart attacks since 1990 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research reported shows the 74% drop in heart attacks since 1990 is due to a reduction in the risk from smoking, cholesterol and high blood pressure. It only mentions the ban in passing.

claims.text: The USA and India are keen to do trade deals with the UK.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The gender pay gap is at the lowest on record.

claimReview.title: Women in work: the female employment rate, company boards and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct across a range of measures, although there’s still a significant gap overall.

claims.text: About 92% of our land mass is not built on.

claimReview.title: Has 92% of the country not been built on? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's estimated that between 88% and 99.9% of the UK isn’t ‘developed’ or built on. But that doesn’t mean all of the remainder is available for development.

claims.text: Conservative councils recycle more of their waste than Labour councils.

claimReview.title: Do Conservative councils recycle more than Labour ones? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2017/18 Conservative councils in England recycled, reused or composted around 49% of their waste, compared to 36% in Labour councils, based on the best available data.  Research suggest that variation in recycling rates can’t solely be put down to which party runs your council, though.

claims.text: Deaths in fires increased by 20% last year.

claimReview.title: What’s happened to fire services since 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Because of inflation, pay rises for public sector workers are actually pay cuts.

claimReview.title: Is the government’s pay rise for public sector workers a real-terms pay cut? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is effectively correct for some workers (in the police force and some doctors, dentists and teachers) and incorrect for others like those in the armed forces, prison officers, and other teachers, doctors and dentists.

claims.text: British youngsters are the “most illiterate” in the developed world.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: Are British youngsters the most illiterate in the developed world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report this is based on didn’t say that British youngsters were the most “illiterate” as such. It said the proportion of 16-19 year olds in England who have “low literacy” is the highest of 23 countries and regions in the OECD. Having low literacy skills involved having difficulty with simple written information, such as not being able to fully understand instructions on a bottle of aspirin.

claims.text: 5G technology is dangerous for human health.

claimReview.title: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: There has been a steep decline in the number of student nurses following bursary cuts.

claimReview.title: Have university applicant numbers fallen in 2017? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of applicants to nursing courses in the UK is down by 19% this year compared to 2016. Students starting on nursing, midwifery and most allied health courses from August will no longer be able to access the NHS bursary scheme in England.

claims.text: The UK received 24,000 asylum applications last year, far fewer than other EU countries.

claimReview.title: UN wrong on asylum seekers in Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's 31,000 including family members, the sixth highest number in the EU. Adjusting for population size, the UK is 18th out of 30 European countries.

claims.text: 11 million people don’t have a passport or driving license.

claimReview.title: Voter ID scheme: far more turned away than convicted of electoral fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for Great Britain according to research from 2015 – there isn’t a more up-to-date figure.

claims.text: In the 2016 EU referendum, 148 Labour constituencies voted to leave, 84 to remain. 247 Conservative constituencies voted to leave, 80 to remain.

claimReview.title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Best estimates are that 249 Conservative constituencies probably voted to leave, and 81 to remain (based on the 2015 general election seat distribution). For Labour it was 148 for leave, and 84 for remain.

claims.text: Children won’t be allowed back to school unless they’ve been tested.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Testing in schools is voluntary.

claims.text: The Supreme Court is a member of the network of the Presidents of the Supreme Judicial Courts of the EU.

claimReview.title: That claim you’ve seen about Supreme Court judges getting paid £175,000 by the EU is totally made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct.

claims.text: Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine is designed to change people’s DNA.

claimReview.title: Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine will not change your DNA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. mRNA vaccines like Moderna’s instruct cells in the body to make proteins. They do not change their DNA.

claims.text: An increasing proportion of people will die as the Covid-19 vaccines are rolled out to younger people

claimReview.title: Deaths from vaccines have not overtaken Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not clear what data the article draws on to reach this conclusion. However, it appears to use information from the Yellow Card scheme, which cannot provide a definitive link between vaccines and reported side effects, and misleadingly extrapolates this to the younger population.

claims.text: The C-17 aircraft filmed leaving Kabul airport was inflatable.

claimReview.title: Kabul plane was not inflatable decoy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence this is true. The post compares a video with a still image. Other footage of the aircraft does not show it moving in the same way an inflatable would.

claims.text: On 8 May 2021 the Genocide Act was repealed. Genocide is now legal.

claimReview.title: The Genocide Act of 1969 has not just been repealed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The law was repealed in 2001 and replaced by the International Criminal Court Act that also made genocide illegal.

claims.text: It was wrong for a BBC Question Time audience member to say Vote Leave are accused of breaking electoral law.

claimReview.title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong; the audience member was right. The Metropolitan Police are still investigating Vote Leave, and the Electoral Commission also found Vote Leave had broken electoral law, and fined them.

claims.text: Two men were sent to prison for defacing a mosque with a poppy, while two others only received fines for burning poppies and defacing a memorial.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about poppy graffiti on mosque is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The two men sent to prison also admitted to a number of other racially motivated offences.

claims.text: The UK could change its mind about withdrawing from the EU even after triggering the formal process of leaving under Article 50.

claimReview.title: Can the UK change its mind about leaving the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Article 50 doesn’t say whether or not a country can change its mind, so it’s arguable either way. Some eminent lawyers think that it can, but there are also those – especially within the EU itself – who argue that once a country has triggered Article 50 it can’t then abort the process without permission.

claims.text: Asylum seekers in the UK can choose whether they want a flat, house, hostel or bed and breakfast.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The government specifies that those eligible for support can’t choose where they live and may be placed in any of these types of housing. They are only eligible if they are homeless or don’t have money to buy food.

claims.text: In the UK we get 52 weeks of maternity pay. The EU sets maternity pay at 14 weeks.

claimReview.title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect for the UK. Maternity pay can be for up to 39 weeks. The EU minimum standard is 14 weeks of paid maternity leave.

claims.text: The UK recorded just three deaths from respiratory conditions besides Covid-19 in October 2020.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. In four weeks of October, 1,239 deaths were recorded just from flu or pneumonia in England and Wales alone.

claims.text: 11 million people are financially at risk from the cladding crisis.

claimReview.title: Labour’s figures on the cladding crisis are far too high - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This estimate is much too high. The true number of residents affected is probably more like 760,000. Landlords of another 600,000 properties will also be affected. The total will be much less than 11 million, which seems to be more than all the people living in flats in the UK.

claims.text: Mark Francois has denied the existence of a gender pay gap.

claimReview.title: Mark Francois did not deny that there is a gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Mr Francois did not say this. It seems the quote was fabricated.

claims.text: Cases of food poisoning have more than doubled from one million in 2009 to 2.4 million in 2019.

claimReview.title: FSA estimates takeaways and restaurants are responsible for 8% of norovirus cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures do not indicate an increase but are simply a “better estimation” of the amount of illness caused by food.

claims.text: Magnets can stick to your arm after a Covid-19 jab because they contain a microchip or other metals.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines do not make you magnetic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. The vaccines do not contain a microchip and there is nothing in a vaccine that could cause a magnet to stick to your skin after getting it.

claims.text: The presidents of Haiti, Tanzania and Zambia died ‘unexpectedly’, and this is linked to the fact they refused the Covid-19 vaccines for their nations.

claimReview.title: No evidence three presidents died because they refused vaccines for their nations - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The president of Zambia did not refuse the vaccines, and died at age 97 of pneumonia. The president of Tanzania died of a heart condition. The president of Haiti was assassinated, but did not refuse the vaccinations.

claims.text: Government asset sales are a form of saving.
claims.claimant: George Osborne MP, Chancellor of the Exchequer

claimReview.title: Do asset sales save the government money? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While asset sales can reduce the reported deficit in the short run, they won't have a significant effect in the longer term: the government can only sell an asset once.

claims.text: Emmanuel Macron said the UK will only be allowed to stay in the EU if they fully adopt all EU rules and regulations including adopting the Euro within six months of stopping Brexit.

claimReview.title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He hasn’t said this. If the UK remained in the EU we would have to continue following EU law, but not in areas where we have opt-outs. This means we wouldn’t have to join the Euro.

claims.text: The government’s no deal Brexit preparations are costing £171,000 per hour.

claimReview.title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is the total additional funding per hour the government has allocated for Brexit preparations in 2018/19 for several different scenarios including those where the UK leaves with a deal. The government hasn’t said how much of the funding is going to no deal preparations specifically.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines weaken your immune system.

claimReview.title: Godfrey Bloom video makes false claims about vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that Covid-19 vaccines weaken the immune system.

claims.text: The number of new cases in South Korea is declining.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct when the viral post began to appear. Reported new cases declined from their peak in late February, and have been roughly level since mid-March

claims.text: A Lisbon court found only 152 deaths have been caused by Covid in Portugal.

claimReview.title: A Portuguese court hasn’t said there have only been 152 Covid deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. A Lisbon court found doctors from the Ministry of Justice recorded 152 deaths have been caused by Covid in Portugal. Most deaths are recorded by doctors from the Ministry of Health. In total over 17,000 people have died of Covid-19 in Portugal.

claims.text: Student nurses of the 2017 cohort were asked to join the NHS workforce early this year, due to Covid-19.

claimReview.title: This is what has happened with student nurses who volunteered to work for the NHS early - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, final year nursing students were given the option to join the workforce early and be paid for this work, due to Covid-19.

claims.text: The pound is now undervalued, based on the IMF’s recommendations in February and June 2016.

claimReview.title: Was the pound overvalued before the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is uncertain. When IMF said the pound was overvalued, they based their recommendations on the assumption that the UK would vote to remain in the EU. It's open to debate what value the pound should be at now that we've voted to leave.

claims.text: Bus fares have gone up by 60% since 2010.

claimReview.title: Bus fares have risen faster than wages since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at one measure which includes coach fares too. However, this increase doesn’t factor in the rise in wages over the same period.

claims.text: Under Labour the tax gap was falling by £1.5bn/year. Under the Conservatives it has been increasing by £1bn/year.

claimReview.title: What's been happening to the tax gap? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers are accurate but very uncertain. The proportion of tax due but unpaid is lower under Labour but no longer falling.

claims.text: It has become convention that Parliament authorises military action when the UK is not in imminent danger of an attack.

claimReview.title: Does parliament get a vote on military intervention? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly—this has been argued by governments since 2011. But there’s still some question over which circumstances the convention applies under, and it’s not legally binding.

claims.text: 10,000 fewer places on nursing courses have been filled because there are fewer applications.

claimReview.title: Nursing training places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This figure refers to applications rather than places. There are still more applicants than places.

claims.text: A picture shows women in burkas voting, saying that’s how Sadiq Khan became London mayor.

claimReview.title: A picture of a woman voting was taken in Pakistan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture was taken in Pakistan in 2013.

claims.text: The gender pay gap increases after women become mothers.

claimReview.title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s evidence that the pay gap increases significantly after parents have children.

claims.text: 66% of coronavirus deaths in Spain are from care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC.

claims.text: Members of the House of Lords get £300 a day.

claimReview.title: How much money do members of the House of Lords get? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Generally, members of the Lords can claim £300 a day for attendance or choose to claim a lower rate, or not at all. They can also claim for some expenses.

claims.text: Since 2000, almost as many British military personnel have died in training or exercises as were killed in Iraq.

claimReview.title: Deaths during military training: worse than Iraq? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although some deaths may not have been directly related to the training.

claims.text: In 1918 Philadelphia ended quarantine to throw a parade for the war effort.

claimReview.title: The 1918 Philadelphia parade fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Philadelphia wasn’t in quarantine to start with when it held this parade.

claims.text: A legal judgment over Article 50 doesn’t stop us from leaving the EU.

claimReview.title: What does the High Court’s Article 50 ruling mean for Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The judges didn’t, and couldn’t, block Brexit. But they said that the government can’t leave the EU without Parliament passing a law.

claims.text: The UK was the only G7 nation to reduce aid spending in 2020.

claimReview.title: The UK will cut aid this year, but barely did last year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but misses out the wider picture. The UK reduced spending by 0.006 percentage points of national income in 2020, but was still the second-highest spender on aid in the G7 that year.

claims.text: 1,400 more people are accessing mental health services every day, compared to 2010/11.

claimReview.title: Has the number of people using mental health services increased? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS figures suggest the number using mental health services is increasing but changes to the way these figures are gathered means we can’t say for sure or put an exact figure on it.

claims.text: There are 2.1 million A&E visits a year for self-treatable conditions.

claimReview.title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 2.1 million A&E visits in England received no treatment in 2016/17. It’s not possible to say from this how many could have been self-treated.

claims.text: Viruses are dead material expelled from healing cells.

claimReview.title: Almost all of these claims about viruses are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear what this claim means, but there is debate about whether or not viruses are technically alive. When viruses leave host cells after replicating in them, the cells can’t really be said to have healed.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines offer no protection against transmission of or infection from the virus.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines do offer some protection against transmission and infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While they don’t reduce the risk completely, multiple studies have shown vaccines do have a meaningful impact on your chances of catching or passing on the virus once you’ve been vaccinated. Early evidence suggests a booster vaccine will strengthen this effect even more.

claims.text: The number of white people arrested for terror offences outstrips any other single ethnic group.

claimReview.title: What do we know about which ethnic groups get arrested for terrorism charges? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for the year to June 2018, although this is based on ethnicity as recorded by the arresting officer. The margin is small—38% were perceived to be white and 37% were thought to be Asian. 9% were recorded as black and 16% as ‘other’.

claims.text: A 14 year-old girl is missing after being pulled into a car.

claimReview.title: Viral posts about missing girl are false, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. There are no reports of this happening. The picture is of a 15 year-old girl who briefly went missing in different circumstances in 2019.

claims.text: The UK is the only EU country with no time limit on immigration detention.

claimReview.title: Limits on immigration detention - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, although the courts have said that the government can’t hold people for ‘unreasonable’ periods of time.

claims.text: The government's impact assessment showed that we would be £100 million worse off because of the early closure of the Renewables Obligation.

claimReview.title: Would early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind cost £100 million? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government's best estimate is that the net present value of the early closure is about £160 million, a positive figure. The £100 million worse off estimate comes from making different assumptions about how the UK would generate electricity.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has said that processed meat is as big a cancer threat as cigarettes.

claimReview.title: Processed meat isn't as big a cause of cancer as smoking - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Inaccurate. The WHO has said processed meat is proven to cause cancer, just as cigarettes are. But the cancer risk attached to eating processed meat is far smaller than smoking.

claims.text: Vaccines pose a risk of death to the elderly.

claimReview.title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Vaccine side effects are rarely serious, and the risk of death from the vaccine is much lower than the risk of Covid-19 infection.

claims.text: In the last eight years, university tuition fees have trebled.

claimReview.title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, they went from a maximum of £3,000 to £9,000 for students beginning higher education in England in 2011/12. They’re now at £9,250.

claims.text: The Covid-19 virus has not been isolated as per Koch’s postulates, and this means PCR tests do not work.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 virus has been isolated many times - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. Covid-19 has been isolated many times. It does not need to adhere to Koch’s postulates as it is a virus, and Koch’s rules have been widely disregarded now. Covid-19 PCR tests are generally very accurate.

claims.text: McDonald’s is reopening in the UK from Monday 27 April.

claimReview.title: UK branches of McDonald’s did not reopen on 27 April - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. McDonald’s has said it has no plans to reopen at this stage.

claims.text: If we vote ‘remain’... The EU will continue to control… trade

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on trade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Trade policies for EU members are decided at EU level, so the UK can’t negotiate its own trade deals.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine makes you magnetic at the injection site.

claimReview.title: Getting a Covid-19 vaccine doesn’t mean you can connect to Bluetooth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The vaccine does not make any part of you magnetic.

claims.text: NASA data shows that global temperatures dropped sharply over the past two years.

claimReview.title: No, we are not experiencing “global cooling” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The average global temperature was slightly lower in 2017 and 2018 than in 2016. But global temperatures tend to fluctuate from one year to the next and the clear overall trend is that the planet is getting hotter over time: 2016 was the hottest year on record, 2017 was the second-hottest, and 2018 was the fourth-hottest.

claims.text: 6.5 million migrants have registered with UK GPs in the last 10 years.

claimReview.title: We can’t be sure how many migrants registered with GPs in the last decade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to the ONS, that’s how many new GP registrations there were in England and Wales between 2007 and 2017 where the person’s previous address was abroad. But migrants who moved between homes in the UK may have been double counted and we don’t know how many were only here short-term.

claims.text: Antidepressants may cause hair loss

claimReview.title: It’s not clear if antidepressants cause hair loss - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Hair loss is listed as an uncommon side effect by NICE, but the evidence is uncertain, and the research in this article does not compare the risk of hair loss in people who take antidepressants with the risk in people who don’t.

claims.text: After 18 September, the government is going to say that because there were no objections, they will roll out unlicensed vaccines.

claimReview.title: Unlicensed vaccines are not untested - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Unlicensed (rather than untested) vaccines are already allowed to be rolled out by the government in circumstances such as a pandemic. The government is consulting on whether to clarify the rules around this.

claims.text: A police officer appears to be taking drugs while on duty in a viral video.

claimReview.title: Viral video of police officer taking drugs doesn’t feature a real officer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video was made as a prank. Police Scotland told us that it wasn’t a real police officer.

claims.text: Less than 29,000 homes for social rent were built under Labour in Scotland.

claimReview.title: The state of social renting in Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around that many homes for social rent (and funded by the government) were built between 2000/01 to 2006/07. But the data doesn’t include those homes for social rent that didn’t receive any government funding.

claims.text: Scotland’s bill for HS2 is £17 billion.

claimReview.title: HS2 will not cost Scotland £17 billion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no evidence for this claim. In effect, all money spent by Scotland on HS2 is returned through the Barnett formula.

claims.text: Charles Bronson has taken Wayne Couzens hostage in his cell and has been beating him up.

claimReview.title: No evidence Charles Bronson attacked Wayne Couzens in jail - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Charles Bronson is at HMP Woodhill and Wayne Couzens is likely still in Belmarsh.

claims.text: If there is no new deputy First Minister in Northern Ireland within a week, the law requires an election there.

claimReview.title: Elections on the horizon in Northern Ireland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Three quarters of hospitals in England are unsafe.
claims.claimant: David Behan, Chief Executive, Care Quality Commission

claimReview.title: Are three-quarters of hospitals in England 'unsafe'? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the sum of hospitals rated inadequate or requiring improvements in safety by the Care Quality Commission. It doesn't define all these as unsafe. The inspected hospitals aren't known to be representative of all hospitals in England.

claims.text: Those who fought on the beaches of Northern France now have to pay for their TV licence.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that migrants get a free TV licence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The free TV licence for most over 75s ended on 1 August 2020.

claims.text: Only 8% of schools have received air monitors that were promised by the government.

claimReview.title: Observer Twitter poll data on air monitors is meaningless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This data comes from a Twitter poll which means it is meaningless, as we can’t be sure who answered it or whether they were representative of schools.

claims.text: Under this government half a million more disabled people are in work.

claimReview.title: How many disabled people are in work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since 2013 the number of disabled people in work has increased by just under half a million. Under the current government the number of disabled people in the UK in work has increased by around 100,000 since 2015.

claims.text: Adoption without parental consent is unusual outside England and Wales.
claims.claimant: Sir Nicholas Mostyn, High Court judge

claimReview.title: Are we unusual in permitting non-consensual adoption? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research suggests that all or most other European countries do allow non-consensual adoption in some circumstances. But it seems much rarer in practice than in England and Wales.

claims.text: Figures published ahead of the Irish referendum on abortion show only 43 women came from Ireland to have an abortion in England last year.

claimReview.title: How many women leave Northern Ireland to have an abortion in Britain? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 3,265 women living in Ireland came to England and Wales for an abortion in 2016. 43 refers to the reported number of women from one hospital who came to the UK so far in 2017.

claims.text: The EU imposes taxes or “tariffs” on rice, oranges, coffee, wine, children’s clothes and other non-EU imports.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, though not all non-EU trade is subject to tariffs. The EU has arrangements—including trade deals—with non-EU countries that reduce or remove these tariffs.

claims.text: The cost of the UK Test and Trace system has been £32 billion.

claimReview.title: Germany has spent far more than £48m on test and trace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The budget for the first two years of NHS Test and Trace is £37 billion. Spending up to the beginning of April 2021 is estimated at around £20 billion, but we don’t have clear figures yet.

claims.text: In 2010 the budget deficit was running at over 10% of the UK’s GDP.

claimReview.title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's correct.

claims.text: It’s free to watch TV in prison.

claimReview.title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In-cell TVs costs £1 per week for prisoners to rent, but they can be removed as a disciplinary measure.

claims.text: Two thirds of people with mental health conditions claiming PIP receive the higher daily living allowance compared to less than a quarter under DLA.

claimReview.title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures are correct, 66% compared to 22%, but fewer people are claiming PIP, and only 39% of those who have moved from DLA to PIP have been awarded more money than they were receiving under DLA.

claims.text: The UK will pay a net £20 billion into the EU budget while it negotiates the terms of exit under Article 50.

claimReview.title: Article 50 and EU budget payments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t replicate the exact figure, but it’s plausible. The UK is set to pay over £9 billion per annum net into the EU budget in the next few years.

claims.text: Germany has sent a bill to China for “coronavirus damages”.

claimReview.title: The German government hasn’t billed China for “coronavirus damages” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A German newspaper drew up a mock bill but the German government has not sent a bill, as suggested.

claims.text: An estimated 0.5% of people arriving into the UK have Covid-19.

claimReview.title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These were remarks by the Home Office’s Chief Scientific Advisor, which were later clarified to be wrong. 0.5% is an estimate for the proportion of reported Covid-19 cases in the UK believed to have been “imported” from abroad as of 23 March.

claims.text: Half of the shadow cabinet members are women.

claimReview.title: Women in the Commons - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct then and now. 16 out of 32 members of the current Labour shadow cabinet are women.

claims.text: People who receive the NHS Covid-19 vaccination card must keep it with them all the time.

claimReview.title: The new vaccination card is not a ‘Covid passport’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. People are not required to carry the card.

claims.text: The government will raise the state pension age from 67 to 75 by 2035.

claimReview.title: It’s not government policy to raise the pension age to 75 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was recommended in a report by the Centre for Social Justice think tank. The Department for Work and Pensions told us it is not government policy to do this.

claims.text: Sir John Curtice has said there is absolutely no evidence of a swing in favour of a second referendum.

claimReview.title: Has public opinion swung in favour of a second EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite right - Professor Curtice has said that there is some evidence of a swing, but that the evidence is not consistent.

claims.text: The effects of the vaccines are not reversible.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is unclear how long the protection given by Covid-19 vaccines lasts against the disease. Most side effects observed are mild and pass within a few days.

claims.text: The number of poor and non-white students at Oxford and Cambridge is decreasing.

claimReview.title: Is Oxbridge still a rich white student's world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of Oxbridge students from a BME background has increased. The proportion from disadvantaged areas is low - with different trends from Oxford and Cambridge.

claims.text: Event 201 was a complete rehearsal of the Covid-19 pandemic.

claimReview.title: US rapper Pitbull wrong to claim Event 201 was ‘rehearsal’ for coronavirus pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Event 201 was a real exercise to simulate how those in government, business and public health might respond to a global pandemic. It was not based on Covid-19 and does not mean the organisers had prior knowledge of the pandemic.

claims.text: Mobile coverage in the UK is worse than Romania.

claimReview.title: Mobile phone coverage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 4G availability is slightly worse on average in the UK than Romania, according to data from OpenSignal.

claims.text: Labour’s poll support is at a record low.

claimReview.title: It’s correct that Labour’s support is at a record low in polling history - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour polled 18% in a YouGov poll asking people how they’d vote in a UK-wide election. This is a record low, based on data going back to 1970.

claims.text: 60 ambulance stations have closed since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how many ambulance stations have closed since 2010 as national figures on this aren’t regularly published.

claims.text: 24,300 people died from preventable causes over winter last year.

claimReview.title: How many excess deaths are there in winter? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 24,300 more people died during the winter in 2015/16 than the average over the months before and after. These deaths are known as excess winter deaths and are largely attributed to respiratory diseases, circulatory conditions or dementia.

claims.text: Data from the World Integrated Trade Solutions website shows that Covid-19 testing kits were being bought and sold by countries long before the pandemic.

claimReview.title: This data does not show tests for coronavirus being ordered pre-2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data shows imports and exports of general testing kits which have since been classified as for Covid-19 during the pandemic.

claims.text: Leave.EU was cleared of a number of things and no criminal charges were brought against them.

claimReview.title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Both the Metropolitan Police and the National Crime Agency closed investigations into Leave.EU with no charges brought. However Leave.EU was found by the Electoral Commission to have broken electoral law, and paid a fine.

claims.text: The BBC decided not to broadcast the funeral of Dame Vera Lynn live, but did broadcast the funeral of George Floyd in America.

claimReview.title: It’s not true the BBC decided against showing Dame Vera Lynn’s funeral live - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Dame Vera’s funeral was a private event. The BBC did broadcast live the funeral procession, which was public.

claims.text: Political parties can’t accept money from people who are not British citizens or businesses.

claimReview.title: Most non-UK citizens can’t donate to UK political parties - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Parties can accept money from people on the electoral register - a wider group than just British citizens. Irish, EU and Commonwealth citizens living in the UK can be eligible as well. Generally only UK and Irish businesses can donate.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we have to give up our nationality.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There are no developed plans to change the nationalities of member states in any year.

claims.text: The Conservative manifesto promised that per-pupil schools funding would be protected, and it’s now being cut.

claimReview.title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending on English schools overall is increasing but per-pupil funding is set to fall in the next few years, once inflation is factored in. The Conservative manifesto promised to protect funding per pupil, but not necessarily in real terms.

claims.text: If more money is spent in Northern Ireland then the Barnett formula means Scotland and Wales will also receive more.

claimReview.title: Northern Ireland and the Barnett formula - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It will depend on political negotiations. The Barnett formula isn’t set out in law.

claims.text: The last time a police officer was successfully prosecuted in the UK concerning the death of somebody in custody was in 1969.

claimReview.title: We know of one successful conviction of a police officer for the killing of someone in police custody since 1971 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is at least one more recent case of a successful prosecution: a police sergeant was convicted of manslaughter in 1986. There have also been successful prosecutions for offences other than manslaughter and homicide.

claims.text: At regional Covid-19 test centres, 98% of results are delivered within 24 hours.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The most recent figure is about 72%.

claims.text: You don’t have to follow the government’s rules after being vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Children should still follow Covid-19 rules after vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was a mistake in an ‘easy read’ consent form for 12-15 year olds. The form has now been updated to make it clear that you should still follow rules and advice to prevent the spread of Covid-19 after being vaccinated.

claims.text: 61% of acute hospitals are in deficit at the moment.

claimReview.title: How much is spent on health and social care in the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the proportion of acute hospital trusts in in NHS England in deficit by the end of 2016/17. So far in 2017/18 the figure is 83%.

claims.text: Lipid nanoparticles used to deliver the mRNA vaccine attack the heart.

claimReview.title: Evidence suggests myocarditis risk after Covid-19 vaccination is lower compared to Covid infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this. Nanoparticles, which protect the delivery of mRNA vaccines, break down in circulation.

claims.text: Most people who own a house, own one house.

claimReview.title: Do most people own one house? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England, we haven’t yet sourced this for the rest of the UK.

claims.text: An image of a highly patterned room is a picture from the Downing Street flat refurbishment.

claimReview.title: Images of decorated room are not the Downing Street refurbishment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image has been around since at least 2017, and seems to be a picture from interior designer and Soane co-founder Lulu Lytle’s previous work on her own home.

claims.text: You can get a £3,000 fine for not wearing a face covering and a £10,000 fine for a group gathering.

claimReview.title: Punishments for not wearing face coverings, not social distancing and for possessing indecent images of children vary depending on the exact offence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In England, you can get fined up to £6,400 for repeatedly not wearing a mask without a valid exemption. People organising large gatherings can be fined up to £10,000.

claims.text: The number of patients having to wait over four hours for a bed in A&E increased from 83,743 in 2010 to 641,963 in 2018.

claimReview.title: How many emergency patients are waiting over four hours for a bed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are broadly correct looking at the number of patients in England waiting over four hours between a decision being taken to admit them to hospital for an emergency and them actually being admitted.

claims.text: The woke culture war is the biggest dividing line among voters.

claimReview.title: No, ‘woke’ culture war isn’t the biggest dividing line in Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not, according to the survey being reported on in this article.

claims.text: School funding has increased by a minimum of £5,150 per pupil.

claimReview.title: School funding hasn’t increased by £5k per pupil - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. £5,150 is the minimum amount secondary schools will receive per pupil, not the level of increase.

claims.text: Pancreatitis, Diabetes Mellitus (Type 2), anaphylaxis, arthritis, encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, pneumonia, deafness, retinitis and epididymitis are also listed as side effects.

claimReview.title: Measles is not the “number one side effect” of the MMR vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. All of these (except aseptic meningitis) are listed under “adverse reactions” of the MMR II vaccine used in the US. That’s not the same as a side effect. Adverse reactions can refer to anything developed by chance after someone is vaccinated, but these aren’t necessarily caused by the vaccine. The two UK MMR vaccines list some of these as adverse reactions.

claims.text: The new UK-Japan trade deal will deliver a £1.5 billion boost to the UK economy.

claimReview.title: Is the UK's trade deal with Japan better than the EU's? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the estimate of annual GDP growth after 15 years, relative to 2018, before the existing EU-Japan trade deal took effect.

claims.text: A video shows what may be synthetic fibres inside a cupcake.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, the “fibres” shown in the video are gluten strands, a common protein found in things like wheat.

claims.text: Covid-19’s infection fatality rate is 0.1%

claimReview.title: The infection fatality rate for Covid-19 is higher than 0.1% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Most research places the virus’s infection fatality rate between 0.5% and 1%.

claims.text: A photo shows Nigel Farage accompanying National Front member Martin Webster.

claimReview.title: There is no evidence to suggest Nigel Farage was a member of the National Front. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know who the person next to Mr Webster is, but it almost certainly isn’t Mr Farage. There is no evidence to suggest Mr Farage was ever a National Front member.

claims.text: Being vegan for a year saves 6,670kg of grain.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear where these facts about veganism are from - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is unclear where this figure comes from.

claims.text: CDC document confirms that SARS-CoV-2 has never been isolated.

claimReview.title: CDC has not said SARS-CoV-2 has never been isolated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The document was talking about a process used to understand the ‘lower limit of detection’ during the creation of PCR tests. SARS-CoV-2 has been isolated many times.

claims.text: You cannot catch Covid-19 from your pets.

claimReview.title: The RSPCA has said that they are worried people will abandon pets because the economic effects of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is currently no known evidence of Covid-19 being transmitted from pets to humans.

claims.text: An early poll shows 80% of people on the Isle of Wight want to download the government’s new coronavirus tracing app.

claimReview.title: Health Secretary uses Facebook poll to estimate coronavirus tracing app take-up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a Facebook poll which is not representative of Isle of Wight residents.

claims.text: Self-employed people aren’t eligible for shared parental leave.

claimReview.title: Shared parental leave: self-employed people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: 26,383 people die of cancer each day.

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct.

claims.text: Last year, 91% of school places created were in good or outstanding schools.

claimReview.title: Ofsted hasn’t inspected 300 schools for a decade or more - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Between 2015/16 and 2016/17, 91% of new primary and secondary school places were created in schools that were last rated good or outstanding.

claims.text: If the UK leaves the EU single market and relies only on its membership of the World Trade Organisation, there would be 80,000 jobs lost in Scotland.

claimReview.title: Scottish jobs after Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers aren’t certain, but a forecast for the Scottish government suggests that in 10 years there would be 80,000 fewer jobs in Scotland if the UK leaves the single market, compared to the number there would be if it stays in the EU. The report expects every scenario outside the EU to mean fewer jobs.

claims.text: The EU did not help Britain during the Falklands War, and instead sent weapons to Argentina.

claimReview.title: The European Community supported Britain during the Falklands War - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The EC (the predecessor of the EU) applied an arms embargo and an import ban on Argentina.

claims.text: Coronavirus lives on the hands for 10 minutes, but can be prevented with alcohol hand sanitiser.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear how long the virus can ‘survive’ on hands, but hand sanitiser with at least 60% alcohol is a good second choice to washing your hands with soap and water.

claims.text: 93% of positive tests are false.
