claimReview.title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No test is 100% accurate, and it’s hard to know the precise false positive rate for Covid-19 tests, but all the evidence suggests that the number is extremely low.

claims.text: “Tens of thousands” of vaccinations are being administered in Bolton “every single day”.

claimReview.title: Matt Hancock wrong about number of Bolton vaccinations - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. Official figures show that the highest number of people vaccinated in Bolton in a single day is 5,465.

claims.text: Of all the positive Covid tests of the 9,000+ students at Cambridge University tested in the week to 6 December, every single one was found to be a false positive after a second test.

claimReview.title: Cambridge Covid-19 test results don’t mean PCR tests are inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for one week of testing. Of the ten group swabs which initially tested positive, none tested positive after a second test carried out later. In previous weeks, most positive tests were confirmed by later tests.

claims.text: The population of Britain is 51 million.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The population of the UK in mid-2018 was 66.4 million.

claims.text: A report by the Social Mobility Commission says there isn’t a north/south divide on social mobility, it says the picture is more mixed than this.

claimReview.title: Is social mobility in England still all about the North/South divide? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. The report said the strongest divide was between London and the rest of the country.

claims.text: You should also gargle as a prevention. A simple solution of salt in warm water will suffice.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this works as a preventative or a cure for the virus.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this works as a preventative or a cure for the virus.

claims.text: 44.2% of Southern Mainline and Coast trains were not at terminus on time.

claimReview.title: Are Southern trains running on time? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is accurate according to one definition of ‘on time’: trains arriving within five minutes. According to another definition—within one minute—an estimated 70% of trains during this period were late.

claims.text: Police officers suffered broken bones at a Bristol protest.

claimReview.title: Police confirm officers did not suffer broken bones at Bristol protest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Avon and Somerset police initially said two police officers had broken bones, but have since retracted this.

claims.text: There is a lot more damage being done to UK citizens as a result of Covid-19 vaccinations than in any other vaccination programme in history.

claimReview.title: MP makes unevidenced claims about vaccine damage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no reliable, publicly-available data to substantiate this claim. No source was provided to evidence his statement.

claims.text: Recovering the costs of health tourism won’t plug the funding gap the NHS is facing.

claimReview.title: Health tourism savings won't plug the hole in NHS funding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. These costs are relatively small compared to the amounts the NHS will need to find to maintain current services.

claims.text: Dominic Cummings appears in a photograph of the Bullingdon Club alongside Boris Johnson and David Cameron.

claimReview.title: Dominic Cummings is not in this picture of the Bullingdon Club - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The man identified as Mr Cummings in the photograph is called Harry Eastwood.

claims.text: Female wolf is acting as part of a ‘fighting unit’ and showing trickery and loyalty by protecting her partner’s neck in a fight.

claimReview.title: Image shows a retreating wolf, not a protector - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. None of the wolves in the image are female, and the wolf which appears to be ‘protecting’ a partner's neck was likely just to be turning away.

claims.text: A Public Health England document shows that ethylene oxide, the sterilising solution used on PCR tests, may be harmful to the unborn child.

claimReview.title: Ethylene oxide-sterilised swabs won’t cause harm during pregnancy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Prolonged exposure to ethylene oxide can be unsafe and may be harmful to the unborn child. But when it is used to sterilise test swabs it does not pose this risk even if you are tested often.

claims.text: England kept £452.5 billion of Scottish taxes. Without Scotland’s money England would be bankrupt.

claimReview.title: England hasn’t ‘kept’ £450 billion of Scottish taxes since 2001 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This ignores the fact that the UK government has some responsibilities for spending in Scotland directly and for areas of spending in or for Scotland. Since 2001/02 more money has been spent in or for Scotland than raised there.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP has use of a House of Commons bar where purchases are subsidised by £7 to every £10 spent.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although not directly subsidised, the catering services run at a loss, so public money is effectively spent subsidising the catering overall.

claims.text: 14 million GP appointments are missed every year.

claimReview.title: The total number of missed GP appointments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s one estimate, based on a survey of 500 GPs in 2015. No-one routinely collects information about the total number of missed GP appointments in England.

claims.text: The government advice is not to challenge someone who is not wearing a face covering.

claimReview.title: Challenging someone for not wearing a face mask isn’t against the Equality Act - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government says members of the public should not challenge people for not wearing a face covering, but people who work in premises where face coverings are required can. They should be “mindful and respectful” of those who are exempt.

claims.text: The Institute for Public Policy Research found household bills will rise by between £245 and £1,961 a year after Brexit.

claimReview.title: This claim about the £2,000 cost of a hard Brexit comes from a typo - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Consultancy Oliver Wyman (not the IPPR) estimate household bills will rise by between £245 and £961 (not £1,961) a year after Brexit. The figure of £1,961 was a typo in a newspaper.

claims.text: An image shows a woman wearing a protest sign that says “my legs are open for refugees”.

claimReview.title: This picture of a sign about refugees has been digitally altered - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been digitally altered. It is a pre-made Amnesty International sign saying “my door is open for refugees”.

claims.text: Some recovered Covid-19 patients catch the disease again

claimReview.title: It's very rare to catch Covid-19 twice - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There may have been some rare cases of reinfection with Covid-19, but most people seem to be immune afterwards, at least in the short term

claims.text: Scotland subsidises England.

claimReview.title: Scottish taxes don’t subsidise English spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Public spending per person is higher in Scotland than across the UK as a whole. Scotland receives more public spending than it raises in tax.

claims.text: The government has announced an unprecedented £84 billion real-terms increase in funding for the NHS.

claimReview.title: Is £84 billion being spent on the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The increase is £20.5 billion in real-terms for the NHS in England between 2018/19 and 2023/24. There is a way of calculating the figures that gets £84 billion, but it’s unhelpful and contains some potentially misleading figures.

claims.text: Asking what’s in the vaccine before having it is classed as an offence.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no specific law about this.

claims.text: Giving dogs ice in hot weather causes them to overheat.

claimReview.title: It is generally fine to give your dog small amounts of ice - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is generally fine to give your dog ice. If they appear to have heat stroke, cool them slowly without using ice and call the vet.

claims.text: The Queen and her children do not have passports to travel.

claimReview.title: No, the ‘P’ on your passport does not stand for ‘peasant’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Queen doesn’t need a passport, as she is the issuer of these documents, but all other members of the Royal Family have them.

claims.text: Lower prices for families — competition between businesses across Europe means lower prices in UK shops, cheaper flights and lower energy bills

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on prices - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The studies cited emphasise how trade competition in the EU might lower prices but don’t look at how other factors such as EU regulation and agricultural policy might raise prices. It’s difficult to say overall what the impact of being in the EU has had on prices in the UK.

claims.text: Up to 650,000 people die a year from the flu.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the top-end estimate of a  modelled global total which is still fewer than the number of people who died from Covid-19 last year. At least 3 million people across the world died of Covid-19 in 2020.

claims.text: An image shows Greta Thunberg with George Soros.

claimReview.title: A photo of Greta Thunberg and Al Gore has been edited to replace him with George Soros - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been edited. It actually shows her with Al Gore.

claims.text: 125,000 care home staff had been tested for Covid-19 as of mid-May.

claimReview.title: The government was wrong on its own data on Covid-19 tests for care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Government data shows 125,000 tests on staff in care settings had been processed. It is not possible to tell the number of staff tested but it is likely much lower. The figure also includes tests on other people including family members, social care workers and care home CEOs.

claims.text: You don’t have to be a member of the EU to trade with it. Switzerland is not in the EU, and it exports more per person to the EU than we do.

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exports - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Switzerland has some access to the EU’s single market. It pays financially for this and takes on certain EU laws.

claims.text: The High Court ruled that Northern Ireland’s abortion law was contrary to international human rights law, though this has since been successfully appealed.

claimReview.title: Abortions in court in Northern Ireland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The case is now being appealed to the Supreme Court.

claims.text: The EU admits its budget will collapse without financial contribution from the UK.

claimReview.title: The EU hasn’t said Brexit will collapse the EU budget - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The EU is preparing a draft budget for 2021-2027, involving increased contributions and decreased spending in some areas to account for the UK’s departure.

claims.text: “Real scientists” are trying to stop the rollout of the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Radio 4 programme featured Covid vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that several scientists have argued that the vaccine rollout should be halted. However, their claims have been widely fact checked during the pandemic, and have been associated with dangerous misinformation about Covid-19 and vaccines.

claims.text: Poland lowered its retirement age using money from the EU.

claimReview.title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. Poland gets back more from the EU budget than it pays in, but none of this is spent directly on pensions.

claims.text: As part of the Coronavirus Act, children can be detained for 14 days without their parents’ consent, and their parents don’t have to be informed, only a teacher, according to a letter from the Children’s Commissioner.

claimReview.title: Can children be detained without their parents’ consent if the authorities think they have coronavirus? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although the government had since said a child could not be detained without their parents’ knowledge or consent under the powers in the Coronavirus Act, the law itself seems ambiguous enough that this theoretically could happen. The law says steps should be taken to avoid this, and says a parent or guardian should be contacted, so this scenario seems unlikely.

claims.text: Matt Hancock used the phrase “protective ring” to describe the government’s winter Covid-19 plan, and claims to the contrary misinterpret his comments.

claimReview.title: Matt Hancock used the phrase ‘protective ring’ about care homes long before he claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Hancock appears to have first used this phrase about care homes on 15 May 2020 to describe action taken during the first wave of the pandemic.

claims.text: The IMF says that the UK will be the fastest growing economy in the G7 in 2016, whereas it had predicted that a Brexit vote would be immediately bad for the economy.

claimReview.title: The IMF on Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that the IMF puts the UK at the top of the G7 for growth in 2016. It had envisaged scenarios where the UK economy suffered soon after a vote to leave the EU. That hasn’t happened, although the IMF still thinks there’s trouble coming.

claims.text: Any woman who needs to travel to find refuge from domestic violence can do so for free on any UK train at the moment. The cost of the ticket will be covered by the relevant rail operator.

claimReview.title: It’s true that women escaping domestic abuse can get a free train ticket in Great Britain if they are travelling to refuge accommodation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Women with a confirmed place at a Women’s Aid member refuge can have a free train ticket to that refuge accommodation. This scheme operates in England, Wales and Scotland. The cost is either covered by the Rail Delivery Group or the train network, depending on where the journey is. A man with a confirmed place in a Women’s Aid partner refuge could also use the scheme.

claims.text: Recent changes to the law mean killers could avoid whole life terms by pleading guilty.

claimReview.title: Can killers now avoid life in prison with a guilty plea? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The new sentencing guidelines don’t change the law. If a whole life order is made in court, a guilty plea will not reduce the sentence. However, a judge will factor a guilty plea into the decision about whether to make a whole life order in the first place.

claims.text: Bill Gates has bought messaging service Telegram.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates has not bought Telegram - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Neither Bill Gates nor the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation have bought Telegram.

claims.text: It is clear the people of Scotland don’t want a second independence referendum.

claimReview.title: How likely is a second Scottish independence referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Recent opinion polls suggest people in Scotland don’t want a second referendum, but pollsters don’t ask the question consistently.

claims.text: Self-harming by teenage girls has doubled in the last 20 years.

claimReview.title: Has the number of teenage girls self-harming doubled? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of hospital admissions in England for girls under the age of 18 because of self-harm has doubled in that time. We don’t know how much of that is down to improved recording or to an actual increase in self-harm.

claims.text: Norway has free movement with the EU, despite not being in the single market.

claimReview.title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Norway does have free movement, but it is in the single market.

claims.text: An Iraqi refugee in Austria had his conviction for raping a 10-year-old overturned because he didn’t realise the victim was saying no.

claimReview.title: Was a refugee acquitted of rape because he didn't speak German? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The conviction was set aside by an appeal court, citing concerns about whether force had been used, which is a requirement for a rape conviction in Austria. But a conviction for serious sexual assault of a minor stands, and there will be a re-trial on the rape charge.

claims.text: People in Leicester are being forcibly tested for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Leicester residents are not being forcibly tested for coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Both Leicester City Council and Leicestershire Police told Full Fact that no such methods are being used in the city. Testing across the UK is optional.

claims.text: There are 1,000 fewer GPs now than there were when Theresa May became Prime Minister.

claimReview.title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This uses figures that aren’t comparable, but it’s still almost certain that the number of GPs in England has fallen since last year, and could have fallen by over 1,000.

claims.text: Life expectancy in the UK is falling.

claimReview.title: Life expectancy in the UK isn’t falling - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Growth in overall life expectancy has slowed down and almost stopped after over a century of increases. Life expectancies are falling in certain local authorities within the UK.

claims.text: GPs should be the first to be vaccinated when a Covid-19 vaccine becomes available.

claimReview.title: GPs and other frontline medical workers will be among the first to receive a Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has published plans indicating that health workers will be among the first to receive a vaccine when available.

claims.text: 12 million people are on waiting lists for operations and treatment because the NHS is too busy testing healthy people with no symptoms for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Covid testing hasn't left 12 million on NHS waiting lists - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The current waiting list is 5.5 million, and this is anticipated to rise, with some estimates up to 12.2 million. There are a number of factors contributing to the size of the waiting list. 

Much of the Covid-19 testing happens outside of the NHS.

claims.text: The number of registered nurses in the UK fell by 1,783 to 690,773 in the year to March 2017.

claimReview.title: What’s happening to nursing numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, according to figures from the Nursing and Midwifery Council.

claims.text: Normal seasonal colds and flu infections are being mistaken for a Covid-19 “second wave”.

claimReview.title: Ordinary colds and flu aren’t the reason for rising Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The symptoms are similar in some cases, but Covid-19 can be clearly identified with a positive test. Recent monitoring also shows low levels of influenza-like illnesses in the UK at the moment.

claims.text: A new Covid-19 vaccine was tested on fit young military men. Of the 15 tested, 8 went to intensive care, 3 on ventilators and 5 people, four of them servicemen, are dead.

claimReview.title: Ukrainian soldiers have not died after having an American Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: Londoners are set to get six times more funding for transport infrastructure per head than the North East and North West regions, and eight times that on offer in Yorkshire & the Humber.

claimReview.title: Regional investment in transport: we don’t know exactly who gets what - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These estimates are correct, using rough information from a government list of planned infrastructure projects. That information isn’t complete, and the comparison ignores funding which isn’t allocated to specific regions. If general funding was included, the regional differences are likely to be smaller.

claims.text: Reversing recent cuts to Capital Gains Tax will save £2.7 billion.

claimReview.title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to official estimates, although the true amount could vary a bit either way.

claims.text: US patent number CA2741523 is for swine flu.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the application number for a patent for the Ebola virus made to the Canadian Intellectual Property Office. This patent has not been granted, and doesn’t mean the Ebola virus was created by someone.

claims.text: Homelessness reached its peak in 2008 under the last Labour government. Since then it’s down by almost a half.

claimReview.title: Sajid Javid claims 50% fall in homelessness under Conservatives—homelessness is up since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’re not aware of any data showing this. Statutory homelessness in England fell between 2003 and 2009. It has risen around 39% since then.

claims.text: We’re seeing fewer families in absolute poverty in the UK.

claimReview.title: Poverty: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends how you look at it and what time period you pick. If you take the claim to be referring to the period since 2010, that could still be correct or incorrect. The number of individuals in households that are in absolute poverty appears to have fallen, but the number of children has remained broadly the same.

claims.text: 118,000 care home residents had been tested for Covid-19 as of mid-May.
claims.claimant: Department of Health and Social Care

claimReview.title: The government was wrong on its own data on Covid-19 tests for care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. When the Prime Minister made this comment, 57,000 residents had been tested in public labs, and 61,074 tests were processed in commercial labs. Adding these together gets to 118,000 but that’s not appropriate as this would lead to residents being double counted.

claims.text: There are 4,000 abortions a week in Britain.

claimReview.title: Factchecking campaigning leaflets on abortion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were around 202,000 recorded abortions in Britain in 2016. That’s around 4,000 a week on average.

claims.text: MPs earn a starting salary of £81,932, higher than the starting salaries for nurses, midwives, paramedics and radiographers (£25,655) and junior doctors (£28,808).

claimReview.title: MPs cannot claim for alcohol from expenses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The starting salaries quoted are correct for 2021.

claims.text: Prisoners becoming eligible for early release halfway through their sentences was a Labour policy.

claimReview.title: How long do child killers serve in prison? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It actually first became law in 1991, under a Conservative government. Labour continued it in a major revamp of the law in 2003.

claims.text: Smokers will be able to get e-cigarettes on NHS prescription.

claimReview.title: E-cigarettes on the NHS? Not so fast - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Public Health England has put this idea on the agenda in a new report, but doesn't have the power to decide. The idea might be taken up, but it'll be a while.

claims.text: More children have died since Covid-19 vaccines were given to 12 to 15-year-olds, compared with the five year average of mortality stats from 2015 to 2019.

claimReview.title: No evidence linking deaths among children to vaccine rollout - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While statistics show the deaths of children, sadly, did increase compared to the five year average, there is no evidence that these deaths are linked to Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: About 80-90% of those hospitalised with Covid-19 are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Most people admitted to hospital with Covid-19 are vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This used to be true. The figure now is more like 35%.

claims.text: The Resolution Foundation brought out a report this week saying we were on course for the biggest increase in inequality since Thatcher.

claimReview.title: Income inequality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was its bottom-line judgement about income inequality. As the report itself says, this is only a projection. It’s based on assumptions about current trends in the economy, and the future of the economy is especially uncertain now the UK is leaving the EU.

claims.text: Ketchup tested positive for Covid-19 using a lateral flow test.

claimReview.title: Ketchup did not ‘test positive’ for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is inaccurate. The ketchup appears to have broken the test, which doesn’t mean tests are inaccurate when used correctly in people. Evidence shows you are more likely to get a false negative result than a false positive using this type of test.

claims.text: Cocaine use in Britain has doubled in the last five years.

claimReview.title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t enough available evidence to say this. These figures are based on an analysis of wastewater in parts of London and Bristol, which can’t tell us very much about the picture across Britain.

claims.text: At mobile Covid-19 testing units, 97% of results are delivered within 24 hours.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 testing is not as fast as Matt Hancock claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The most recent figure is about 61%.

claims.text: Drinking a glass of water before taking a bath helps lower blood pressure.

claimReview.title: Drinking water at set times does not provide certain health benefits - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.

claims.text: Government spending on flood defences until 2021 has heavily favoured London and the South East.

claimReview.title: We don’t know if there’s a north/south divide in flood defence spending because the data was taken offline - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t enough data available to prove this, and previous estimates  don’t clearly show this divide. Figures from the Environment Agency that could have helped shed light seem to have been taken offline.

claims.text: Wearing masks causes dementia, hypoxia and hypercapnia, bacterial pneumonia, and will “make children stupid”.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for any of these claims. Tight-fitting masks can cause harm in rare instances but this is not the case for typical cloth masks.

claims.text: The Covid-19 virus cannot be detected with tests.

claimReview.title: Tests can detect the Covid-19 virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. PCR tests can detect it very accurately.

claims.text: The vaccine is causing new daily cases of Covid-19 in the UK, or at least isn’t stopping them.

claimReview.title: Vaccines have not caused daily cases to increase - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have real world evidence and data from trials showing that the vaccines do reduce your chances of catching Covid-19, and vastly decrease your chances of getting seriously ill and dying from it.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means no more ECJ or ECHR.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that no deal would remove the jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice. But it’s incorrect to say it would remove the jurisdiction of the European Court of Human Rights (which has nothing to do with the EU).

claims.text: There are eight vaccine deaths per day.

claimReview.title: 1,102 people haven’t died ‘of’ the Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since we started vaccinating people in the UK, about eight people a day or 1,102 overall have died a short while after getting the vaccine. These are not “vaccine deaths” and the number is in line with how many we would expect from other causes in that time period.

claims.text: Participants in a remote video meeting are being required to wear masks.

claimReview.title: TikTok joke about masks in Zoom meetings is taken seriously on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t true. It comes from a joke video on TikTok.

claims.text: The number of GP training places is rising.

claimReview.title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct in England, although not all the places are being filled.

claims.text: MPs get free housing.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim for rent or hotel accommodation as well as expenses for a second home if they are not already receiving rent free London accommodation through any ministerial post, and provided that their constituency is outside London.

claims.text: Over 500 churches have been closed in London.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an estimate for the number of churches converted into homes between 2001 and 2006, so doesn’t tell us how many churches have closed in recent years.

claims.text: US food standards allow for rat hairs in paprika.

claimReview.title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US food standards set limits above zero for rat hair in paprika, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation states that there are up to 650,000 deaths per year associated with respiratory illnesses linked to seasonal flu.

claimReview.title: It's incorrect to say flu vaccines don't work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Between 290,000 and 650,000 respiratory deaths per year globally are attributed to the flu.

claims.text: The Federation of Small Businesses said the UK small business community sees the potential wins of an independent global trade policy. It wants trade with the EU 27 kept as easy as possible and is pushing to export to new growth areas in the US and Commonwealth.

claimReview.title: Small businesses and Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The FSB also said its top priority is to secure a full, time-limited transition period. Other organisations say that businesses are optimistic but apprehensive, want clarity about the transition, and suggest a full or partial customs union with the EU, or for tariffs to be kept to a minimum.

claims.text: 58% think the Chequers deal disrespects the result of the referendum.

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 39%.

claims.text: Low-paid workers are trapped in poverty.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: Measuring low pay isn't the same as measuring poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This muddles definitions. The report in question didn't discuss poverty. Although the issues are related, not all low-paid workers are in poverty.

claims.text: Masks do more harm than good and they’re considered ineffective by surgeons.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are rare instances of harm caused by tight-fitting masks but not ordinary masks. While the efficacy of masks in surgery is debated there is some evidence of their benefit.

claims.text: Positive and negative control swabs are included in Covid-19 testing kits.

claimReview.title: Control swabs aren’t meant to be used for patient testing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Control swabs are included in some testing kits. These are used to check that the tests are working properly and are not for use in patient testing.

claims.text: 1.1 million food parcels are given out — 1.1 million people who would starve otherwise.

claimReview.title: Over a million food parcels given by Trussell Trust last year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Trussell Trust did give out 1.1 million parcels last year, but this isn’t the same as the number of people, as people can use food bank vouchers more than once. We don't know how many people nationwide received parcels, but this may be in the right ballpark.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, local government funding is down 50%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Government funding for local authorities in England fell by 49% between 2010/11 and 2017/18 in real terms, under coalition and Conservative governments. Councils have other revenue sources, and total “spending power” fell 29% in real terms in the same period.

claims.text: Lawyers are complaining about legal aid reductions despite making more money.

claimReview.title: Not all of Britain’s lawyers are “raking it in” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Turnover in the legal sector overall has been rising, but legal aid is a relatively small and falling proportion of that.

claims.text: Iceland has declared all religions are mental disorders.

claimReview.title: Iceland has not declared that all religions are mental disorders - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false and originated from satirical article online. The Evangelical Lutheran Church is the official state church of Iceland.

claims.text: The Covid-19 virus is not spread asymptomatically. Only sick people give it to other people.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The virus can be spread by asymptomatic and presymptomatic people.

claims.text: It’s illegal to sue those behind covid vaccines.

claimReview.title: A post about coronavirus vaccines gets facts about their safety, ingredients, and legality wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Current UK law says that if the government decided to authorise a vaccine for emergency use, manufacturers and healthcare professionals would not take responsibility for most civil liability claims. However if the product is not found to have met safety standards or is defective, this immunity is lost.

claims.text: PTFE in masks can lead to symptoms such as fever, chest tightness, shortness of breath, headache, cough, chills, sore throat.

claimReview.title: PTFE in masks does not pose a health risk, unless you get it very hot - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears to be describing polymer fume fever, which only happens if someone is exposed to PTFE heated to high temperatures.

claims.text: All of the animals used in vaccine trials died.

claimReview.title: Influencer video full of untrue vaccine claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. If animals had died after being vaccinated, human trials would have been stopped, which they weren’t. It is common practice in animal trials to euthanize the subjects so they can be examined.

claims.text: A recent Daily Mail headline bears an uncanny resemblance to the front page of a Nazi newspaper from 1933. Both papers branded particular judges as ‘Enemies of the People’.

claimReview.title: The Daily Mail, “enemies of the people”, and a Nazi newspaper - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The German headline reads "traitors of the people". The men depicted in the 1933 newspaper weren’t judges, and the translation in the caption is wrong. They were people who had their citizenship revoked by the Nazi regime.

claims.text: The UK delivers 69% of the EU’s world trade surplus.

claimReview.title: Is the UK really the EU’s ‘Treasure Island’? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for trade in goods but does not include trade in services. It’s also a figure which could be misleading unless you understand exactly how it’s calculated.

claims.text: The UK has gone from being one of the top economic performers in terms of growth in the G7, Europe and the world to being bottom of the league in the last year.

claimReview.title: Is the UK economy in the relegation zone? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct the UK had the fastest growing economy in the G7 in 2014 and was faster growing than the EU average in 2015. Various experts have said it is near the bottom of the G7 countries in 2017 and its growth is now lower the the EU average.

claims.text: A study has concluded that there have been no cases of children transmitting the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: A scientific review did not conclude that there are no cases of children transmitting the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is taken out of context. It is the finding of one study among a review that found contradictory evidence about transmission of the new coronavirus in children. The review concluded that “the role of children in passing the disease to others is unknown”.

claims.text: Diluted cordial poured onto a lateral flow test appears to test positive, meaning the tests are a farce.

claimReview.title: Pouring diluted cordial onto a Covid-19 test won’t give an accurate result - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tests are not designed to have acidic substances, like drinks, poured on them. This will break the test.

claims.text: The CDC has ‘dropped’ the RT-PCR Test.

claimReview.title: The CDC has not ‘dropped’ all PCR tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The CDC has withdrawn its request for emergency use authorisation for one particular type of PCR test. This is because more efficient PCR tests are now available.

claims.text: Jo Swinson said she couldn’t forgive David Cameron for calling the 2016 EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Jo Swinson said the Liberal Democrats supported an EU referendum in 2008 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, she said this at the Liberal Democrats’ 2019 party conference.

claims.text: Covid-19 has a survival rate of 99.998%.

claimReview.title: Instagram post gets it wrong about Covid-19 vaccines and animal testing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While there is no completely accurate statistic, based on the sheer number of people who died from Covid-19 we know the survival rate is lower than this.

claims.text: Until 2004, immigration was around 50,000 a year and it’s risen since then.

claimReview.title: Immigration to the UK has been rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 50,000 is wrong, although immigration did increase considerably after 2004 as new countries joined the EU.

claims.text: Many nurses have to go to food banks.

claimReview.title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Media reports show that at least some individual nurses and trainees have visited food banks. We do not have solid evidence of the scale of use.

claims.text: Remain campaigners predicted that house prices would fall by 10% after a vote to leave.

claimReview.title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. The UK Treasury expected house prices to be 10-18% lower than they would otherwise have been in 2017/18.

claims.text: Patients are now waiting over two weeks on average to see a GP.

claimReview.title: We can’t say patients are waiting over two weeks to see a GP on average - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are no reliable figures that prove this. This refers to non-urgent appointments at GP practices, but the figure isn’t necessarily representative of GP practices nor patients across the UK.

claims.text: The government is giving the NHS 1%. Under Labour it was 4% every year.

claimReview.title: How much money does the NHS need and how much is it actually getting? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending on the NHS in England has increased in real terms by an average of around 1% a year since 2010. Since the NHS was established spending increases have averaged 4% per year.

claims.text: The maximum weekly state pension is £141 in the UK, £507 in Germany, £304 in France, and £513 in Spain.
claims.claimant: The People Vs The Government, DWP and Atos

claimReview.title: Do pensioners in the rest of the EU get more cash than the elderly in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures for the UK, Spain and France are in the right ballpark, but differences between their pension systems means it’s not a fair comparison. Germany doesn’t have a maximum amount for its state pension.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, child poverty is up 50%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There’s no single measure of child poverty, but depending on which you use it has risen by up to 5% or fallen by up to 3% between 2009/10 and 2017/18, under coalition and Conservative governments.

claims.text: Germany owes £3.7 trillion of WWII debt.

claimReview.title: Germany doesn’t “owe” the UK £3.7 trillion of war debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Germany’s war debt was written off decades ago. We also haven’t seen evidence that Germany’s debt to the UK, or the cost of war damage incurred by the UK, was worth £3.7 trillion.

claims.text: MPs would need to approve British military action in Syria.

claimReview.title: MPs don't have to approve military action in Syria - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Legally, the government doesn't need the permission of Parliament to use military force. But there is a convention that it will consult MPs before doing so, where possible, and abide by the outcome of their vote.

claims.text: A post by the Royal British Legion said it will offer poppies in every community in the UK.

claimReview.title: The Royal British Legion will offer poppies in all UK communities - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, it’s a screenshot of a post from 2016. The charity regularly says this.

claims.text: The MHRA put out a tender for Artificial Intelligence (AI) to handle reports of adverse Covid-19 vaccine reactions.

claimReview.title: Influencer video full of untrue vaccine claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. In November 2020 it was reported that GenPact, a professional services firm, had been awarded a £1.5m contract to build an AI tool that could process “the expected high volume” of reports of adverse reactions occurring after, though not necessarily caused by,  Covid-19 vaccination.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 survival rate is less than 99.8% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All the Covid-19 vaccines being used in the UK have been safety tested and approved for use by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency.

claims.text: Only 22 per cent of homes already granted planning permission in the Green Belt are affordable.

claimReview.title: Are there plans to build on the Green Belt? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Correct according to analysis by the Campaign to Protect Rural England. Not all homes with planning permission get built, though some of these already have been. 

Last year in England 19% of all new homes (within and outside the Green Belt) were “affordable”.

claims.text: The Home Office set a target to cut immigration down to the tens of thousands.

claimReview.title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, referring to net migration rather than just immigration. Governments since 2010 have continually mentioned this figure, though it’s not clear if it is still in place.

claims.text: A CDC study on 12 to 17 year-olds who got the Pfizer vaccine found 397 reports of heart inflammation.

claimReview.title: The Pfizer vaccine, teenagers and myocarditis - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true 397 cases of myocarditis were reported after around 8.9 million adolescents who got the vaccine.

claims.text: Halting changes to the Personal Independence Payment will create a £4.4 billion “black hole” in the budget.

claimReview.title: Does George Osborne have a £4.4bn black hole in his budget? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £4.4 billion isn’t a helpful way to describe the budget’s “black hole” caused by the withdrawal of the changes—it adds up all the spending over the five years to 2020/21. Dropping the policy will make public finances £1.3 billion worse off than they would have been by the end of the Parliament. And the government was already relying on £3.5 billion other savings that have yet to be identified.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine is a “device” and does not fulfil the legal definition of a vaccine.

claimReview.title: Hecklers at Twickenham Stadium vaccine drive spout false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: None of the Covid-19 vaccines available in the UK are “devices” and all have been authorised for use as vaccines by the MHRA.

claims.text: A poster from the MHRA makes various claims about the vaccines and importance of Yellow Card reports.

claimReview.title: Poster about Yellow Card scheme is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This poster is not actually from the MHRA.

claims.text: A 103 year-old Chinese grandmother has made a full recovery from Covid-19 after being treated for 6 days in Wuhan, China

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This has been widely reported in the media.

claims.text: At the windiest times onshore wind turbines generate 7% of the UK's electricity.

claimReview.title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was right in the first quarter of 2015.

claims.text: The UK will spend £36 million on efforts to close the Calais “Jungle” camp

claimReview.title: We aren't spending £36m just to close the Calais 'jungle' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has committed £36 million and some of this money will be used to close the camp, but it’s also being spent on border security and keeping child migrants safe.

claims.text: Basic rate taxpayers under this government have seen a tax cut equivalent of £1,000.

claimReview.title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct using Treasury analysis comparing a basic rate taxpayer in 2017/18 to 2010/11.

claims.text: The rise in deaths is the largest for almost fifty years, prompting concerns about a crisis in elderly care.

claimReview.title: What’s behind the rise in deaths? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Provisional data suggests the increase in deaths in England and Wales from 2014 to 2015 was the largest annual rise since 1968. The rate of death—the number of deaths per 1,000 population—is also thought to be up. The ONS told us the higher number of deaths was due to the flu.

claims.text: The mandatory Covid-19 vaccine has been passed through the House of Lords without an impact assessment having been carried out.

claimReview.title: Mandatory Covid-19 vaccine is only for care home workers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but applies only to the amendment to the Health and Social Care Act, which mandates that all care home workers must be fully vaccinated against Covid-19 from November.

claims.text: The present government has spent more on foreign aid than any previous Labour government.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson was broadly right about aid spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, at least from the data that goes back to 1970. It has also spent more than any previous Conservative government in that period.

claims.text: The pound has fallen by 15%.

claimReview.title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite, the exact fall depends which currency you compare it to. It’s fallen by 12% against the Euro and 5% against the US Dollar since May 2016.

claims.text: Fares across all operators are 20% higher in real terms than they were in January 1995.

claimReview.title: How much does the government subsidise the railways by? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This is for the average price across all regions and ticket types.

claims.text: Boris Johnson announced an extra £14.4 billion in funding for schools over three years.

claimReview.title: The government’s education funding figures need context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £14.4 billion is the cumulative amount schools in England will receive over three years. By the third year (2022/23), school funding will be £7.1 billion higher than it was in 2019/20, or £4.3 billion once inflation is accounted for.

claims.text: Lowering the state pension age for women back to 60 would create four million jobs for the younger generation.

claimReview.title: Lowering the state pension age for women won't create four million jobs for young people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not accurate. There is no evidence that four million women over the age of 60 are currently employed nor that they would all retire given the opportunity.

claims.text: The reported numbers of cases of Covid-19 are misleading because asymptomatic people with a positive test would not normally be counted as a “case”.

claimReview.title: Viral video contains several false pandemic claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is a common practice to count a “case” without symptoms for many infectious diseases.

claims.text: CCGs increased their spending on mental health by 6.3% last year while their overall funding increased by 3.7%.

claimReview.title: NHS spending on mental health - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the increase in spending by CCGs on mental health compared to their overall core services budget allocation. The figures don’t account for inflation. Factoring that in, mental health spending went up by 3.9% over that time and overall CCG budgets went up by 1.5%.

claims.text: Daily dementia deaths in England in October were at 192.

claimReview.title: A comparison of daily deaths from Covid-19 and non-Covid causes is incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2019 there were around 172 deaths from dementia and Alzheimer’s daily in England.

claims.text: The government spent £100 billion on Trident.

claimReview.title: How much of this meme on government spending is true? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s hard to tell. The government expects replacing the current Trident nuclear submarine missile system will eventually cost around £31 billion, and it has committed to spending at least that. Suggestions for the future in-service costs of the system range from £70 billion to £150 billion over 30 years.

claims.text: Theresa May paid around £2,400 to “MP Services” on a regular basis.

claimReview.title: Parliamentary expenses: is this meme about Theresa May correct? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Expenses of between £500 and £3,000 were claimed by Mrs May for payments to a company called MP Services between 2005 and 2007. The payments are usually for the printing of annual reports, newsletters, and outdoor banners.

claims.text: Bill Gates created the new coronavirus and a vaccine for it.

claimReview.title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The Bill Gates and Melinda Gates Foundation has funded a research institute that has a patent to a different coronavirus.  Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold, SARS and the new virus that causes Covid-19.

claims.text: The £20 note shows a 5G tower giving off emissions and a coronavirus symbol.

claimReview.title: £20 notes don’t have a secret message about 5G and coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The ‘5G tower’ is Margate Lighthouse and the ‘coronavirus’ is based on a famous staircase at the Tate Britain art gallery.

claims.text: 670,000 people marched for a People’s Vote in London on Saturday 20 October

claimReview.title: Did 670,000 march for a People’s Vote on Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an estimate by the organisers of the march. We can’t say for sure if it’s accurate or not, but it may be on the high side.

claims.text: A court ruled that more people are entitled to the PIP benefit because they were suffering from “overwhelming psychological distress”.

claimReview.title: What did the courts rule on PIP? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Upper Tribunal’s decision was based on the interpretation and application of the language of the complicated PIP regulations, which include the phrase “overwhelming psychological distress”. It decided that - in relation to the case assessed - the individual’s “overwhelming psychological distress” made them satisfy additional parts of the criteria for assessing PIP eligibility.

claims.text: An image shows a parasitic worm in a child’s heart, caught from a dog due to close contact.

claimReview.title: This picture doesn’t show a child's heart infected with a dog parasite - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The picture is of an infected dog’s heart. The parasite can only be passed from an infected dog to a human via mosquito, not direct contact.

claims.text: There were 25% cuts to local government spending between 2010 and 2015.

claimReview.title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England, looking at a comparable measure of council funding which includes central government grants, council tax and business rates, called “core spending power”.

claims.text: There are more doctors.

claimReview.title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It was 109,000 in September 2017, an increase of 11,900 since the same month in 2010.

claims.text: Covid-19 is not classed as a ‘high consequence infectious disease’.

claimReview.title: Results of Covid-19 vaccine trials have been published and peer-reviewed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, because it no longer meets the criteria for an HCID. This doesn’t mean that it is no longer considered dangerous or significant.

claims.text: A picture shows a horse that was found living in a flat in Preston, Lancashire.
claims.claimant: The City of Preston News Network

claimReview.title: This picture doesn’t show a horse found living in a flat in Preston - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s a picture of a model horse in a window in Illinois, USA that’s been there since at least 2006.

claims.text: The UK has introduced a special scheme for taking in vulnerable Syrian refugees, and 10,000 Syrian refugees have come to the UK since the conflict began.

claimReview.title: The UK, the USA, and Syrian refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that over 10,000 Syrian refugees are now in the UK, although not all were brought over under this scheme. More than half made their own way to the UK.

claims.text: Israel is in Africa.

claimReview.title: This arrow is pointing at Egypt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Israel is in Asia.

claims.text: Zoflora causes infertility in young boys and men.

claimReview.title: No evidence Zoflora cleaner harms fertility - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no direct evidence this is the case.

claims.text: A debate in parliament about teenage mental health was attended by only 11 MPs.

claimReview.title: Did only 11 MPs turn up to a debate on adolescent mental health? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The sparsely-attended debate was an adjournment debate. These are not usually attended by many MPs as they do not involve voting and occur at the end of the day.

claims.text: The Department for Work and Pensions is or isn't carrying out a review of 60 suicides linked to benefits.

claimReview.title: Is the DWP reviewing a link between suicides and welfare reform? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The DWP has carried out internal 'Peer Reviews' in 40 individual cases since February 2012 after the suicide or apparent suicide of a customer.

claims.text: Two and a half thousand more people every day are being treated within four hours in A&E departments.

claimReview.title: A&E waiting times: better or worse? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, measuring patient attendances from 2009/10 to 2015/16.

claims.text: Hate preacher Anjem Choudary received benefits and faced no action for his crimes.

claimReview.title: These claims about radical Muslim preachers and Tommy Robinson are mostly incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Choudary received benefits and was imprisoned under the terrorism act.

claims.text: A global survey from around 2014 found that 24% of people thought the USA was the country that posed the greatest danger to world peace.

claimReview.title: America: seen as the number one threat to world peace, says one survey - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Universal Credit is working because over 3.3 million more people are in work since 2010.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit isn’t the reason there are 1,000 more people a day in work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misleading link to draw. There are 3.3 million more people in work since 2010, but there is no clear evidence on how many people Universal Credit has got into work.

claims.text: A former active IRA member is now serving as a Conservative party councillor.

claimReview.title: It’s true that a Conservative councillor in Croydon is a former member of the IRA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. She defected from the IRA in 1972 and became a Conservative councillor in 2002.

claims.text: Over 200,000 UK businesses trade with the EU, helping them create jobs here in the UK.

claimReview.title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: business - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: HMRC figures from 2012 found almost 200,000 VAT-registered traders in the UK which traded goods with other EU member states. They said that the figure could be “significantly higher” if it included companies that traded in services.

claims.text: The UK could not bring in safer lorry designs until the EU legislated on the matter.

claimReview.title: Do EU rules prevent safer lorries? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU sets rules on permitted lorry dimensions, which we have to follow. But the EU voted to allow safer lorry designs in 2014, a plan which the UK government initially opposed.

claims.text: Parts of London have the highest productivity in Europe.

claimReview.title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct by one measure, but it isn't based on a fair comparison.

claims.text: A popular online quote about love, which ends with “because if I have to ask you, I don’t want it anymore”, was said by Frida Kahlo.

claimReview.title: Quote about love does not appear to come from Frida Kahlo - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Full Fact could not find any evidence that Frida Kahlo said this.

claims.text: The civil servant responsible for increasing the state pension age to 67 is retiring at 61 with a £1.8 million pension pot.

claimReview.title: This post about the decision to increase the state pension age needs some context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The former-permanent secretary to the Department for Work and Pensions, who oversaw part of the process of increasing the state pension age to 68, did retire at 61 with this pension pot. But civil servants don’t make policy decisions, meaning he didn’t decide to raise the age himself.

claims.text: Six people were stabbed in London on Saturday 6 July 2019, including three 12 year-olds.

claimReview.title: Metropolitan police taking part in London Pride were on duty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. We don’t know their exact ages, but the three children stabbed were reportedly all younger than 12.

claims.text: You’re more likely to drown than die from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a valid comparison to make, and the figures it’s based on aren’t accurate.

claims.text: Real wages have been growing faster recently than at any time in the past decade.

claimReview.title: Real wages aren’t growing at their fastest rate in a decade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Across Great Britain real wages are growing by about 1% annually—the fastest rate in around two years.

claims.text: The government committed over £1 billion to reduce the impact of changes and limit them to 18 months.

claimReview.title: Increasing the state pension age - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The government limited the increase in the state pension age from the new 2011 timetable so that no-one would face an increase of more than 18 months. That reduced the savings it would otherwise have made by £1.1 billion. Overall, changes since 1995 mean some women will retire three to six years later planned.

claims.text: Masks decrease oxygen intake, increase carbon dioxide intake, increase toxin intake, increase stress levels which directly impacts the immune system in a negative way making us more susceptible to illness.

claimReview.title: Mask graphic contains a number of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Fabric and medical face masks should not affect breathing and the NHS says they are safe for anyone over the age of three who can manage them correctly. Certain types of masks called respirators can affect gas exchange, but can still be safely worn for several hours in a row in healthcare environments. There’s no evidence masks harm the immune system.

claims.text: Asylum seekers get £37.75 for every person in their household, loaded onto a debit card each week.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If asylum seekers are homeless or don’t have money to buy food, they can apply for asylum support, which can include a cash allowance of this amount.

claims.text: Last year we saw 217,000 more homes being built in this country. That is a record—apart from one year—for the last 30 years.

claimReview.title: Is house building at record levels? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 217,000 is how many more homes there were in England in 2016/17 than the year before. That’s the second highest increase on record over the last 26 years. 184,000 of these were newly built in 2016/17.

claims.text: The government has broken a manifesto pledge by removing drugs from the Cancer Drugs Fund.
claims.claimant: Heidi Alexander MP, Shadow Health Secretary, quoted in the Guardian

claimReview.title: Did the government keep its promise on the Cancer Drugs Fund? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In its manifesto the Conservative Party promised to continue to invest in the Fund, which has seen spending rise. But drugs have been removed from the list. And beyond 2016 it could be replaced by a new system.

claims.text: A photo of Remain supporters holding a burning Union Flag has been edited.

claimReview.title: This image was edited to make it appear that Remain supporters burnt a Union Flag - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is correct that the image has been edited.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation said that women of childbearing age should be banned from drinking alcohol.

claimReview.title: The WHO hasn’t said women should be banned from drinking - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t accurate. The WHO have said that “appropriate attention should be given to prevention of [...] drinking among pregnant women and women of childbearing age”. The WHO told Full Fact that it does not recommend abstinence for all women of childbearing age.

claims.text: More than 10,991 people have died from Covid-19 vaccines in the US so far.

claimReview.title: Comparisons between deaths reported after swine flu and Covid-19 vaccines are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. According to the CDC there have been 6,207 reports of death among people who received a Covid-19 vaccine in the US, although this figure is much higher when including people based outside the US or in an unknown location. Deaths reported after a Covid-19 vaccine are not necessarily caused by the vaccine.

claims.text: People who share a Facebook post commenting “Love Cadbury” will receive a free chocolate hamper.

claimReview.title: Cadbury World ‘promotion’ is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This post comes from a fake page, not from Cadbury itself.

claims.text: Torbay and North Yorkshire councils approve the highest percentage of term-time holidays in England.

claimReview.title: The end of holiday fines? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These two councils had the highest percentage of authorised term-time holidays in England for 2014/15. There are big differences between councils.

claims.text: UK carbon dioxide emissions have fallen 42% since 1990.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson gets his numbers muddled on economic growth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. UK carbon dioxide emissions fell 39% between 1990 and 2018, though this data isn’t perfect and may overstate the fall.

claims.text: Anticoagulants should be used to fight Covid-19.

claimReview.title: This post about Covid-19 and blood clotting conditions contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is evidence supporting the use of anticoagulants in some Covid-19 patients.

claims.text: Certain fizzy drinks are full of colouring and chemicals.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, and artificial colours have been linked to hyperactivity among children.

claims.text: No deal is consistently the preferred option of the British public.

claimReview.title: Does the public want no deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is misleading to suggest. While some polls have found this, others have found more support for remaining in the EU. It all depends on how the question is asked and the options respondents are presented with.

claims.text: If it drops on a metal surface it will live for at least 12 hours - so if you come into contact with any metal surface - wash your hands as soon as you can with a bacterial soap.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not yet known exactly how long the virus survives on surfaces.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus survives on surfaces yet—it may be between hours and days.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus survives on surfaces yet—it may be between hours and days.

claims.text: New antibody tests are 100% accurate.

claimReview.title: New antibody tests are not 100% accurate on all measures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Although Public Health England found the Roche test had 100% specificity, it did not have 100% sensitivity.

claims.text: Flu and heart attacks went away this year.

claimReview.title: US rapper Pitbull wrong to claim Event 201 was ‘rehearsal’ for coronavirus pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A drop in flu cases in both the US and UK was likely down to measures brought in to stop Covid-19. Heart attacks have not gone away.

claims.text: The Italian Prime Minister has said his country has exhausted all options to fight against the coronavirus pandemic and pleads to God to “rescue your people.”

claimReview.title: This “quote” from the Italian Prime Minister about coronavirus is made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This quote is made up.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we would have to give up our currency.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, nothing is due to change in 2022 and the UK has an opt-out of the euro.

claims.text: Eat Out to Help Out led to an increase in Covid-19 infection rates

claimReview.title: Did Eat Out to Help Out cause Covid to spread? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We cannot reliably say whether this is true. One study estimates that it did cause extra Covid cases, but it is uncertain, and often misunderstood

claims.text: An image shows a new self-contained diesel-powered electric vehicle charging point in Lancashire.

claimReview.title: Photo of diesel-powered electric vehicle charging point is at least two years old - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence the image is from Lancashire and the county council says none of its charging points are diesel-powered. The image has been circulating since at least 2019.

claims.text: Pensioner poverty has fallen considerably since the 1970s and 80s.

claimReview.title: Pensioners in poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. On the relative measure, pensioner poverty has fallen from peaks of 40% in those decades to about 16% now. Absolute poverty has also fallen long term.

claims.text: Households can still meet with another household in a pub, bar or restaurant, up to six people from a number of households can meet outside, social distancing hasn’t changed, and businesses like gyms and hotels can remain open.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on lockdown rule changes are right for certain parts of England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You cannot socialise with people outside your household in pubs, bars or restaurants, in Greater Manchester and parts of Lancashire and West Yorkshire as of 31 July 2020. Up to six people can meet outside from a number of households and social distancing hasn’t changed. Gyms and other indoor sporting facilities in Bradford must also close.

claims.text: The Conservatives broke a manifesto promise by raising national insurance rates in the 2017 budget.

claimReview.title: Did the Conservatives break a manifesto promise on national insurance? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The 2015 Conservative election manifesto promised not to raise national insurance rates this parliament. The government has now announced plans to raise national insurance rates for some self-employed people.

claims.text: According to NHS data, as of 21st January there have been 4,717 Covid-19 deaths of people between the ages of 0-59 in the UK.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 survival rate is not 99.991% for under 60s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The NHS data used in this video is just for England, not the whole UK, and only includes hospital deaths after a positive test.

claims.text: People who die within 28 days of a positive Covid-19 test have Covid put on their death certificate automatically.

claimReview.title: Letter to MHRA is filled with false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Medical professionals filling out death certificates are not required to note a Covid-19 test result if they don’t think it was relevant to the cause of death.

claims.text: The Covid vaccine will make you infertile.

claimReview.title: A post about coronavirus vaccines gets facts about their safety, ingredients, and legality wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim has no basis. Experts say that the risk of the Covid vaccine affecting a woman’s fertility is “vanishingly small.”

claims.text: Cutting the distance between people from 2m to 1m might double their risk of catching Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Two metres is a little better than one - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, based on new research in the Lancet.

claims.text: A book published in 1981 said that in 2020 a severe pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world, and calling it “Wuhan-400”.

claimReview.title: These quotes “predicting” coronavirus are from two different books - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These lines are from two different books: one is from a book of predictions by a psychic published in 2008 that predicted a pneumonia-like illness, and “Wuhan-400” is a fictional disease from a sci-fi book published in 1981 that bears little similarity to the new Wuhan coronavirus.

claims.text: MPs get free breakfast and dinner.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim for food expenses if they are travelling away from London or their constituency. Also, MPs can eat in parliamentary bars and restaurants which are effectively subsidised with public money.

claims.text: Hand sanitiser is toxic.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 can be fatal and tests for it aren’t rigged - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Hand sanitiser shouldn’t be ingested or used incorrectly. However, when used appropriately, it is not poisonous.

claims.text: There will be 50,000 more nurses going into the NHS.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s first interview of 2020: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has committed to do this by 2024/25. Not all of these nurses will be ‘new’.

claims.text: There is a risk of autoimmune disease, strokes, seizures, convulsions and other side effects from the vaccines.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccines cause mild, transient side effects such as arm pain or fatigue for most people. There isn’t much evidence linking the vaccines directly to more severe side effects. Possible reported side effects are continually monitored to detect such links.

claims.text: The BBC lost £50 million through non-payment of the licence fee this year.

claimReview.title: Facebook post makes incorrect claims about TV licence fee non-payment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There's no official data yet on how much the BBC lost in 2020/21. The £50 million figure is likely to be based on an estimate from Julian Knight MP, but this is an estimate of the extra amount lost due to the BBC being above its target for licence fee evasion, not the overall amount lost due to non-payment.

claims.text: Phenol / phenoxyethanol is in vaccines and is used as antifreeze. It is toxic to all cells and can destroy the immune system.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These chemicals have been used in vaccines as preservatives. They are not in antifreeze.

claims.text: A study from India showed people eating cucumber every day had a 71% less risk for lung cancer.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that eating cucumbers stops lung cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No studies show this. One study showed people who ate green vegetables were less likely to get lung cancer but the paper’s authors said this couldn’t be narrowed down to one vegetable’s effect.

claims.text: The BMA misled junior doctors on whether their pay would be cut.

claimReview.title: Why is the government accusing the BMA of lying? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Ministers dispute suggestions that some doctors might get a 30% pay cut, which they blame on a pay calculator that was withdrawn by the BMA. The union hasn’t responded to our request for comment. There’s also a broader disagreement about what the government intended to do about pay at the time.

claims.text: Getting rid of EU customs union tariffs when we leave will help the worst off.

claimReview.title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If we set lower tariffs this may bring down costs for lowest-earning households, but tariffs are just one part of a bigger economic picture.

claims.text: The word “robot” means “slave” in Greek.

claimReview.title: The word “robot” comes from Czech, not Greek like GPT-3 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: “Robot” comes from Czech, not Greek, although it is derived from a term for forced labour.

claims.text: The label on a box of face masks says “will not protect against Covid-19”. Therefore it’s “anti-science” to wear one.

claimReview.title: It’s not ‘anti-science’ to wear a face mask - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The main role of this type of face mask is to reduce the spread of Covid-19 droplets from an infected wearer, to help protect others, rather than to protect the wearer from infection.

claims.text: A 2019 blogpost authored by Dominic Cummings was recently edited to include a warning about coronavirus.

claimReview.title: A 2019 Dominic Cummings blog post was recently edited to explicitly mention a coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The edit appears to have been made on 14 April 2020.

claims.text: On average there are less than 10 deaths a week from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: More than 10 people are dying of Covid-19 each week in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. At the time this claim was made, there was a seven-day average of 8.6 Covid-19 deaths each day. In the seven days before this was claimed, 57 Covid-19 deaths were reported in the UK.

claims.text: At the SNP party conference, the SNP voted to increase the state pension in an independent Scotland to match the EU average.
