claimReview.title: SNP members voted to commission a plan for pension increases in an independent Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The conference voted in favour of a resolution supporting the commissioning of a plan looking at how pension levels could be increased. It also mentioned that the OECD average should be set as a target.

claims.text: Leicester is going back into lockdown soon after 5G was rolled out there.

claimReview.title: Leicester going back into lockdown has nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 5G coverage was available in Leicester by November 2019, months before Covid-19 was detected in the UK. 5G is not linked to cases of Covid-19. Leicester had some lockdown restrictions re-imposed because the number of cases there was increasing.

claims.text: Punishment for breaking lockdown is harsher than for possessing images of child abuse.

claimReview.title: Punishment for breaking social distancing and possessing indecent images of children can vary - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sentencing for both crimes varies greatly. The fine cited for breaking lockdown (£3,400) is roughly correct after numerous breaches, and punishment for possession of indecent images of children can vary depending on the exact offence.

claims.text: Fluoride was first used by the Nazis to keep prisoners docile and submissive.

claimReview.title: No evidence to back up these claims about fluoride - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that the Nazi Party used fluoride on their prisoners.

claims.text: There are 13 deaths by suicide every day in England.

claimReview.title: Are there 13 deaths by suicide every day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct for 2015.

claims.text: The tests conducted at the 199 testing centres, as well as the mobile test centres, are all done within 24 hours.

claimReview.title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. When this was said, on 3 June, 19% of tests at regional testing sites and 5% of tests at mobile test centres were done within 24 hours.

claims.text: The death rate in Andalucía almost halved between November and December following the introduction of their vitamin D policy.

claimReview.title: The link between vitamin D and Covid-19 is complex - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The death rate in Andalucía did drop, but numbers increased again in January. There are also other reasons that may explain the drop in cases in Andalucía, and the difference between Andalucía and the UK case numbers.

claims.text: Overseas aid spending will increase by £1 billion over two years because of new EU rules.

claimReview.title: Is the EU behind a £1 billion increase in aid spending? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU rules in question are about how to measure the UK's wealth, which is the basis of the government's aid target. The EU doesn't set that target - we do.

claims.text: It defies logic that Joe Biden secured more votes that Barack Obama. If only valid votes are counted, Donald Trump and Joe Biden share the popular vote.

claimReview.title: Express opinion piece wrong to allege evidence of widespread voter fraud in US elections - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is logical that Mr Biden received so many votes because turnout was relatively high. There is no evidence of widespread invalid votes. There is no evidence that Mr Trump and Mr Biden received the same popular vote. Mr Biden currently leads by around 4.5 million.

claims.text: A photo shows two children who have decapitated their mother.

claimReview.title: This is not a real photo of a family murder - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s a doctored photo, the original is just a family portrait.

claims.text: The 17.4 million votes to leave the EU in 2016 was the largest mandate for anything in British political history.

claimReview.title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No single electoral option has received more votes in UK history than the vote to leave the EU in 2016. But a handful of referendum options and political parties have received a higher percentage share of a national vote.

claims.text: Thomas Hughes has been attacked in prison.

claimReview.title: Father of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes has not been attacked in prison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence this is true.

claims.text: BBC News reported that 350 people attended the anti-lockdown protest in London on 29 May 2021.

claimReview.title: The BBC did not claim 350 people attended anti-lockdown protests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: BBC News did not say this. The claim is based on a screenshot from a year earlier with an altered caption.

claims.text: The government’s own research says that Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to a 6.4% drop in real wages.

claimReview.title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government estimated a free trade agreement Brexit could lead to real wages being 6.4% lower after 15 years than if the UK remained in the EU. That’s not the same as saying this form of Brexit will lead to a drop in real wages compared to now.

claims.text: Ethylene oxide, used to sterilise lateral flow tests, is deadly and turns into antifreeze upon use.

claimReview.title: Chemical used to sterilise Covid-19 tests won’t turn into deadly antifreeze - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While large amounts of ethylene oxide can be dangerous, the amount used to sterilise tests is tiny and assessed against strict safety standards. No ethylene oxide is left once tests are packaged.

claims.text: The NHS is getting an extra £34 billion, that’s the biggest increase in modern memory.

claimReview.title: The £20.5 billion NHS England spending increase is the largest five year increase since the mid-2000s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The £34 billion is a spending increase in real terms of £20.5 billion between 2018/19 and 2023/24. The last time spending increased by at least that amount was between 2004/05 and 2009/10.

claims.text: In October, Test and Trace was reducing R by between 0.3 and 0.6.

claimReview.title: We don’t know how much Test and Trace affects the spread of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know this for sure. A small part of the reduction certainly came from Test and Trace. Some of the rest came from people with symptoms self-isolating anyway.

claims.text: In 1955, Crest became the first fluoride toothpaste.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Crest began testing its first fluoride toothpaste in 1955. It wasn’t the first fluoride toothpaste but fluoride became a standard additive around this time.

claims.text: An electric car can self-charge as it drives by attaching a generator to the wheel to harness the energy as it spins.

claimReview.title: You can’t recharge an electric car by attaching a generator to the wheel - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true, and breaks two major laws of physics. An electric car battery would deplete whether or not you attach a generator to the wheel.

claims.text: Scotland Yard has logged 22,025 motorcycle muggings in 12 months – a rise of 50 per cent.

claimReview.title: Is moped crime rising in London? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Metropolitan Police have recorded 22,025 crimes enabled by scooters, mopeds and motorcycles from June 2017 to May 2018, 50% more than the same period in 2016/17, but this does mask a recent falling trend month-by-month.

claims.text: SARS-CoV-2 variants don’t exist.

claimReview.title: Covid virus variants are real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All viruses mutate over time, and SARS-CoV-2 is no exception. We know they exist because of genomic sequencing, and there are a number of  Variants of Concern currently identified as such by the UK government.

claims.text: Being vegan for a year saves 365 animals.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear where these facts about veganism are from - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen the evidence for this. Estimates we’ve seen range between 37 and 200 animals a year.

claims.text: Chief executives at particular Welsh councils get paid about three times as much as MPs.

claimReview.title: Public sector pay - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They get paid more, but not three times as much. The Chief Executive of Isle of Anglesey County Council gets paid £113,000 a year, compared to £76,000 for an MP. At Gwynedd it’s between £103,000 and £110,000.

claims.text: The 2016 EU referendum was the largest democratic vote in British history.

claimReview.title: Was the vote to leave the “largest democratic vote” in British history? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: More people voted to leave the EU in 2016 than have voted for any other single electoral option in British political history. Options in other votes have received a higher percentage share of the vote, and the 1992 general election had a higher number of total voters.

claims.text: The Coalition's original debt target has been met.

claimReview.title: Why is net debt falling as a share of GDP? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It has, but the IFS says this is "not a genuine reduction in government indebtedness". The fall in 2015/16 is only because the government is selling assts.

claims.text: 55% of people in poverty are in working households.

claimReview.title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 55% of working age people in poverty were in a working family, according to estimates from 2015/16.

claims.text: The British Medical Association advises that without immigrants “many NHS services would struggle to provide effective care”.

claimReview.title: More context is needed for these “facts about immigration” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is an accurate quote from the BMA from 2014. It has made similar comments since.

claims.text: The UK is the second largest economy in the EU.

claimReview.title: The UK is one of the three largest economies in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK is either the second or third largest economy in the EU, depending on the measure used.

claims.text: Early findings show that of 74,405 Covid-19 cases admitted to hospitals between September and March, just 32 had received a vaccine at least three weeks before.

claimReview.title: There’s more to the claim only 32 vaccinated people were hospitalised with Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are correct, but comparing them is misleading, as vaccinations didn’t start until December, so this doesn’t show how effective the vaccine is at stopping hospitalisations.

claims.text: 20-30% of the population is going to die with each vaccine.

claimReview.title: There is no HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: From the roll-outs so far, there is no evidence to support this.

claims.text: Adidas, Puma and Nike use kangaroo leather in their football boots.

claimReview.title: Adidas, Nike and Puma use kangaroo leather in some products - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. All these companies currently sell football boots made using kangaroo leather.

claims.text: Research shows that people do not follow self-isolation rules because they cannot afford to.

claimReview.title: Why are people not self-isolating? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Based on the available evidence, this is not a major factor reported by people who do not self-isolate correctly. Just 8.9% said that they broke the rules in order to go to work.

claims.text: The UK has taken in 41,000 unaccompanied children since 2010.

claimReview.title: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to around 41,000 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since 2010, the UK has granted protection to 41,396 asylum seekers and refugees under the age of 18. However, at least 40% of these young people were accompanied by parents or carers.

claims.text: The average cost of a child’s funeral is £3,675.

claimReview.title: The cost of children's funerals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the cost of an average funeral in 2016 according to a survey by insurers Royal London. Another firm puts the cost slightly higher. The cost of burying a child may be lower in some areas, as councils often waive or discount burial fees for under-16s.

claims.text: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has revoked a PCR Covid-19 test.

claimReview.title: PCR tests have not been revoked by the FDA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The CDC has withdrawn a request for emergency authorisation for one type of PCR test, but not because of any fault. The FDA has recalled one brand of lateral flow test.

claims.text: An image shows members of the Nazi party turning their backs in the German parliament.

claimReview.title: An image on social media does show Nazi party members turning their backs during a speech - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is what the picture shows, although some descriptions have details wrong.

claims.text: There are 400 people a year who drown

claimReview.title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2018, 263 people died in accidental drownings in the UK.

claims.text: Black workers face a widening pay gap the more qualifications they earn.

claimReview.title: Do black workers face a widening pay gap the more qualifications they earn? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s evidence of an overall pay gap, but the relationship between qualifications and pay is complicated. The claim is based on analysis comparing the average earnings of black and white workers over an annual period. It doesn’t take account of things like the grades obtained in each qualification, where graduates have studied and what types of jobs they end up in. Nor does it mean that this will be the experience that individual workers have—it tells us what the gap looks like overall.

claims.text: One person was convicted for voter impersonation at the last election.

claimReview.title: Voter ID scheme: far more turned away than convicted of electoral fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This refers to the year 2017.

claims.text: You are twice as likely to get into university if you are poor and English as if you are poor and Scottish.

claimReview.title: Are poor Scots half as likely to get into university as poor English pupils? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is probably a reasonable claim, though the comparison is a bit tricky. It also doesn’t account for the substantial amount of higher education provided by further education colleges in Scotland.

claims.text: The deficit has come down under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Is the government getting the deficit down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, the deficit has fallen from 10% of GDP to 2.3% between 2010 and 2017, but the government is far off its original plans for a reaching a surplus.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine doesn’t stop you transmitting it.

claimReview.title: This Morning guest makes misleading claims on vaccine efficacy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Data has shown that even one dose can reduce the chances of you passing it to your household.

claims.text: The rise in “platform work” shows that UK workers are increasingly likely to patch together a living from multiple different sources.

claimReview.title: Has the gig economy doubled in size in three years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t enough evidence to say this.

claims.text: There are 80 courts in the UK enforcing Sharia law.

claimReview.title: Are there 80 Sharia courts in Britain? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People can agree to ask a Sharia council to make a legally binding decision, but this must be in line with English law. No-one knows how many councils exist.

claims.text: Larch trees planted in a Douglas fir forest in Oregon create a smiley face among the woodland every autumn.

claimReview.title: Photo of smiley face in forest is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true. They were deliberately planted by the owners of a lumber forest. The needles of the larch trees planted there turn yellow every autumn and create an image of a smiley face.

claims.text: On 9/11 the World Trade Center Building 7 collapsed for no apparent reason.

claimReview.title: World Trade Center 7 didn’t collapse for ‘no apparent reason' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Years of investigation have concluded that the building collapsed because of fires ignited by debris falling from the North Tower’s collapse.

claims.text: Rigevidon can cause blood clots, strokes, and burst aneurysms.

claimReview.title: What are the possible side effects of the contraceptive pill Rigevidon? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Rigevidon, along with other combined contraceptive pill brands, can sometimes cause these issues, although rarely.

claims.text: Local authority budgets have been cut by 40% since 2010.

claimReview.title: Local authorities' budgets are roughly 26% lower since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly the reduction in the money English local authorities get from central government, since 2010. Overall, their budgets are 26% lower, because they also raise money locally.

claims.text: The government reduced payments for people with disabilities by £30 a week.

claimReview.title: How much of this meme on government spending is true? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: From April 2017, new Employment and Support Allowance claimants in the group who must attend interviews with an adviser started getting £30 a week less (down to £73.10) than they would have previously. In 2016, this was projected to save between £30 million and £450 million a year between 2017/18 and 2020/21.

claims.text: Filling up your car in hot weather could cause the fuel tank to explode.

claimReview.title: Your fuel tank won’t explode if you fill it during a heatwave - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Fuel systems in cars are designed to cope with summer heat. The auto-combustion point of fuel is much, much higher than a car’s fuel tank could feasibly reach.

claims.text: Under Boris Johnson’s deal, Scotland’s economy would be 6% weaker than if we remained.

claimReview.title: Claim that Brexit will cost every Scot £1,600 is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a dated estimate and isn’t definitive. 6% is roughly how much smaller the Scottish government estimated the country’s GDP would be in 2030 in the case of a free trade agreement where the UK leaves the EU customs union and single market, compared to if the UK had not left the EU.

claims.text: A three month extension to Brexit will cost £1 billion a month.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson repeats his false claim that extending Brexit costs £1 billion a month - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it won’t. The UK would still pay that amount if it left in October under Boris Johnson’s deal.

claims.text: Social distancing doesn’t work because air droplets can travel up to 25 feet.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Evidence shows sneezing can propel air droplets up to 25 feet but infectivity significantly increases at distances less than two metres.

claims.text: One in five people are drinking too much alcohol.

claimReview.title: Booze telling the truth? Is Britain sobering up or not? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 21% of adults aged 16+ in England reported to an NHS Digital survey that they usually drank more than the recommended 14 units of alcohol a week in 2017.

claims.text: The Covid-19 spike protein which the Pfizer vaccine causes an immune response against also trains the body to attack syncytin-1, a protein in the placenta, which could lead to infertility in women.

claimReview.title: No evidence Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine affects women’s fertility - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim has no basis. The spike protein on the Covid-19 virus and a protein that makes up the placenta have only a small amount in common, almost certainly not enough for the immune system to attack the placenta.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, financial centres will all be moved to Strasbourg.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: Figures from the Office for National Statistics show the number of suicides during the peak of the coronavirus pandemic was down from 10.3 per 100,000 to 6.9 per 100,000.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence the number of people taking their own life fell during the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. These figures show deaths registered during this period, not deaths occurring. Most of these suicides took place before 2020, and the ONS has said lower registrations are likely due to the impact of the pandemic on the coroner’s service.

claims.text: Cambridge University banned poppies.

claimReview.title: Cambridge University has not banned poppies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue.

claims.text: If you have a runny nose and sputum, you have a common cold.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are the symptoms for the common cold, but they don’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: Higher education in this country is blindingly white.

claimReview.title: Higher education: a white, middle-class affair? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the UK in 2016/17, 74% of UK students in their first year of an undergraduate degree were white. Among 18 year-olds in England, white pupils are the least likely of any ethnic group to take up a place in UK higher education.

claims.text: The state is removing more children from their families than at any time since the 1980s.

claimReview.title: Are more children being taken from their families? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct as far as available figures show. More children are becoming ‘looked after’ by a local authority than at any time since the mid-1980s, and increasing numbers are being adopted or placed with a special guardian. These figures don’t perfectly reflect the numbers of children who are away from their original parents.

claims.text: A photo shows that hand sanitiser is poison because it degrades metal.

claimReview.title: Rusty hand sanitiser stand doesn’t prove hand gel is poison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo shows a metal hand sanitiser stand that has probably rusted due to the water contained in hand sanitiser dripping on it over time. Water isn’t harmful to human skin in the same way, and neither is alcohol.

claims.text: Nearly 5 billion plastic straws are currently used in the UK each year.

claimReview.title: How many plastic straws do we use? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest government estimate for the number used in England alone is around 4.7 billion. The estimate itself is very uncertain.

claims.text: A study on the effects of Covid vaccines during pregnancy shows 82% of respondents miscarried, contrary to what its authors claimed.

claimReview.title: Study did not show 82% of pregnancies end in miscarriage after Covid vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is misleading and based on an incorrect calculation. The study it is based on found the rates of miscarriage were no different to those before Covid-19, although it concedes that further research is needed.

claims.text: Vaccines are incompatible with human life, and being vaccinated while pregnant or breastfeeding may be unsafe.

claimReview.title: No evidence you shouldn’t breastfeed after Covid-19 vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Being vaccinated while pregnant or breastfeeding is recommended as safe.

claims.text: The NHS Pay Review Body reports that 80% of of the midwives who left the profession would’ve stayed if they were valued more highly.

claimReview.title: Midwives leaving the profession - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. The NHS Pay Review Body says that according to the Royal College of Midwives 80% of the midwives who were intending to leave midwifery in the next two years said that increased pay would encourage them to stay in midwifery. But the same survey found the biggest concern  was staffing levels.

claims.text: 4.7 million unpaid carers fear getting sacked over caring commitments.

claimReview.title: An Express headline on how many working carers fear for their job is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is based on the results of a survey question answered by 280 working carers meaning there is some uncertainty about how accurate the figure is. It asked whether they thought they would ever have no option but to leave their existing job to help care for a dependent or relative due to lack of support and flexibility from their employer.

claims.text: It was this Conservative government that tackled the debt.

claimReview.title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s debt has risen from £1 trillion (or 64% of GDP) in May 2010 to £1.8 trillion (or 81% of GDP) now.

claims.text: Covid-19 can be transmitted between humans and pets.

claimReview.title: Your pets almost certainly won’t give you Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is one reported case of a pet dog in Hong Kong testing ‘weak positive’ for Covid-19. However, the dog is showing no symptoms and there is some question to whether the positive test is valid. The WHO and NHS says there is no evidence that pets can become infected or pass the virus to people.

claims.text: This text message shows the government is monitoring people leaving the house during coronavirus lockdown.

claimReview.title: This text message is not an official government communication - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not an official government text.

claims.text: Daily deaths from heart disease in England were at 174 in October.

claimReview.title: A comparison of daily deaths from Covid-19 and non-Covid causes is incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Heart disease is an imprecise term, and based on 2019 data, up to 330 daily deaths could be attributed to it.

claims.text: The UK was able to approve the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine more quickly because of Brexit.

claimReview.title: Vaccine approval isn’t quicker because of Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Under European law, the UK was permitted to act independently to approve the vaccine in an emergency.

claims.text: George Osborne promised to eliminate the deficit by 2015.

claimReview.title: Did George Osborne promise to eliminate the deficit by this year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2010 he said that the government's aim was for the deficit to be eliminated by 2015. While an aim isn't a promise, the government's performance on the deficit has been worse than was aimed for.

claims.text: The mayor of Calgary said that Covid-19 was a hoax.

claimReview.title: The mayor of Calgary didn't say that Covid-19 was a hoax - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No, he didn’t. This seems to come from a fake transcript of a nonexistent court hearing. The mayor of Calgary says it never happened.

claims.text: 100,000 people have arrived into the UK since the lockdown began.

claimReview.title: It’s likely that over 100,000 people have entered the UK since the lockdown began - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s estimates on this subject are opaque, but the latest figures it has been using suggest well over 100,000 people will have entered the country since mid- to late March.

claims.text: Heathrow Airport is used primarily by people on expensive flights.

claimReview.title: Is Heathrow just for high flyers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A survey found flyers from Heathrow say they have higher incomes than those flying from most other London airports, but we don’t know how much their flights cost.

claims.text: The alkaline diet has benefits based on its combatting of acidic conditions in the body.

claimReview.title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this

claims.text: Formaldehyde is in vaccines and causes cancer in humans among other issues and is banned from vaccines in most European countries.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not banned in Europe. There are only trace amounts in certain vaccines and not enough to be carcinogenic.

claims.text: There are more than 1,000 fewer armed police officers since 2010.

claimReview.title: Have armed police numbers been cut? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are about 700 fewer now than in 2010. Labour's claim accurately quotes the latest published Home Office figures, but newer figures from the National Police Chiefs' Council have changed the picture. The numbers are expected to return to 2010 levels over the next few years.

claims.text: MPs’ salaries have increased from £66,000 in 2010 to £77,000 in 2018.

claimReview.title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures don’t take account of inflation since 2010. In 2018 prices MPs’ pay has remained stable compared with 2010 at around £77,400.

claims.text: Taxpayers faced a bill of more than £140 million last year for criminals from other EU countries in British jails.

claimReview.title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on the average yearly cost per prisoner in England and Wales, and the number of prisoners from other EU countries in prison in England and Wales at the end of December 2017. The estimate is very rough and spending on prisoners can vary depending on the prison they’re in.

claims.text: The government spends around £50 billion a year to support people with disabilities and health conditions.

claimReview.title: Does the government spend £50 billion a year on disabled people? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government spends around £50 billion on benefits which go to disabled people and people with health conditions and their carers. This includes payments that aren’t directly to do with people’s health condition such as housing benefit and income support. This figure doesn’t tell us about how individual people’s entitlements have changed due to recent changes to the benefits system.

claims.text: £300 million could put 10,000 police officers on the streets.

claimReview.title: Can £300 million pay for 10,000 police officers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Probably not. There aren’t published estimates for the cost of training and recruiting police officers and Labour hasn’t substantiated its claim publicly. £300 million would cover those officers’ salaries for one year, but it wouldn’t cover the costs of training, equipment, and overheads at the same time.

claims.text: The number of doctors in specialist psychiatry training fell from 3,187 in 2009 to 2,588 in the first quarter of this year.

claimReview.title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This 20% drop was between September 2009 and March 2018, which isn’t a fair comparison. Comparing September 2009 and 2017 there was a 15% decrease.

claims.text: In recent weeks the government has allowed water companies to discharge sewage into rivers due to Brexit disrupting deliveries of water treatment chemicals.

claimReview.title: Murky claims about sewage bill fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Environment Agency has cited the UK’s relationship with the EU as one of the factors affecting the supply of water treatment chemicals to the UK.

claims.text: The sudden deaths of 10 teenagers may be linked to Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: No available evidence that vaccines caused teen deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no available evidence that shows vaccines were responsible for any of these deaths.

claims.text: Since Omicron was first detected on 27 November there have been seven deaths from it, with an average age of 83.

claimReview.title: We don’t know how many suicides there have been since Omicron arrived in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were 7 deaths in England from the Omicron variant up to 16 December 2021. The average age of Covid-19 deaths in general is 83—we don’t know what it was for these Omicron deaths.

claims.text: Frank Lampard said FIFA is “corrupted” and that it hates Cristiano Ronaldo.

claimReview.title: No evidence Frank Lampard made these comments about Ronaldo and FIFA corruption - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no legitimate source for this quote.

claims.text: Viruses are dead material expelled from healing cells. Everyone has thousands of viruses inside their body.

claimReview.title: Mask graphic contains a number of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is debate about whether viruses are technically alive. The human body does contain a number of viruses that don’t do harm. Covid-19 is caused by a virus that is potentially very harmful though.

claims.text: Half of maternity units don’t have consultants at the weekends.

claimReview.title: Do we have enough maternity consultants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 43% of maternity units don’t have a consultant present during the day at weekends, according to a survey by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

claims.text: Trading with the EU under World Trade Organisation rules alone would cost the UK £45 billion in lost GDP.

claimReview.title: How much would a hard Brexit cost? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s quoting the Treasury’s forecast incorrectly. £45 billion was the Treasury’s estimate for the cost to tax revenues after 15 years, rather than the size of the economy. It's not unorthodox to say that trading with the EU under terms set by the WTO would be bad from an economic perspective. Even so, no forecast is certain.

claims.text: Young people are finding it harder than ever to own their own home.

claimReview.title: It's harder for young people to own their own home - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Young people are less likely to own their own home, and the gap in affordability has grown since a decade ago.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines have caused 1,213 deaths.

claimReview.title: Piers Corbyn makes misleading claims about vaccine deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is the number of deaths within seven days of vaccination reported through the Yellow Card scheme, but this does not mean the vaccines caused these deaths.

claims.text: Drinking a glass of water before going to bed helps prevent stroke and heart attacks.

claimReview.title: Drinking water at set times does not provide certain health benefits - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s some evidence that keeping hydrated can help prevent coronary heart disease and help improve stroke outcomes. But we found no evidence specifying that drinking water before bed was particularly beneficial.

claims.text: £6.3 billion has been cut from social care.

claimReview.title: How much is spent on health and social care in the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A survey of councils providing social care in England said they reported or planned to make savings of £6.3 billion on adult social care services between 2010 and the end of 2017/18. Over this time spending on adult social care by councils has fallen by £1.3 billion in real terms.

claims.text: We were promised a ‘punishment budget’ before the referendum.

claimReview.title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sort of. Remain campaigners published a 7-page ‘Brexit Budget’ which gave rough, hypothetical figures for the kind of cuts that would be needed if the UK voted to leave the EU, the pre-referendum economic forecasts were correct and the government still wanted to run a balanced budget in 2020/21. It was presented by George Osborne, then Chancellor of the Exchequer.

claims.text: Cut onions promote the growth of bacteria and quickly become dangerous to eat.

claimReview.title: Pre-cut onions are not dangerous - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Cut onions are safe to eat for about a week, if kept in the fridge.

claims.text: Warburtons has decided to stop sourcing the majority of its flour from British farmers and will now source its flour through a Canadian and American deal with Frontier.

claimReview.title: Claims that Warburtons now gets its wheat from the USA are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Warburtons have changed their grain trader contract but they will still get their wheat from Canada and the UK, as they did previously. They don’t buy any wheat from the USA.

claims.text: Immigrants are 60% less likely to claim benefits than a British-born person.

claimReview.title: More context is needed for these “facts about immigration” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s based on a decade-old report and only looked at immigrants from a few EU countries. Immigrants are probably less likely to be receiving out of work benefits than UK nationals, based on the best available evidence.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation (WHO) have advised people to use contactless payments instead of cash to reduce the risk of Covid-19 transmission.

claimReview.title: The WHO has clarified that they aren't warning people against using paper money due to coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The WHO advises the public to wash their hands after handling money, especially if handling or eating food. But they haven’t issued a warning about using banknotes.

claims.text: Prolonged exposure to radiofrequency radiation from a mobile phone antenna may exceed the recommended guidelines.

claimReview.title: Mobile phone base stations like this do not pose a radiation risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that this is the case.

claims.text: More than four million calls to the taxman are going unanswered, new figures show.

claimReview.title: HMRC: how many unanswered calls? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the case in 2016/17, according to analysis from the National Audit Office. This year the figure is higher. Around 5.6 million customer calls to HMRC (13%) were unanswered between April 2017 and February 2018.

claims.text: The use of stop and search has fallen by almost two thirds since reforms to the system.

claimReview.title: Stops and searches are becoming less common - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The symptoms of Covid-19 are a sore throat lasting 3 or 4 days. The virus then blends into nasal fluid, enters the trachea and then the lungs causing pneumonia. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing. The nasal congestion feels like you're drowning

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia, and the symptoms may not come in this exact order or at these times. The NHS does not mention nasal congestion that ‘feels like drowning’ as a specific symptom for Covid-19.

claims.text: 79.7% of contacts of people who test positive for Covid-19 are reached.

claimReview.title: Matt Hancock misstates the proportion of Test and Trace contacts being reached - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Incorrect. This is the proportion of people who tested positive in the first place who are reached by the system. 

In the week to 5 August 79.7% of people who were referred to the service after testing positive were reached. Close contacts were identified for 78.6% of those cases. Of those close contacts, 74.2% were reached and asked to self-isolate.

claims.text: Nationally, only 69.4% of contacts are now reached and asked to self-isolate.

claimReview.title: Matt Hancock gets test and trace figures wrong again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The latest data from NHS Test and Trace shows that of all positive cases referred to the system, 81.4% were reached. Close contacts were identified for 80.2% of those cases. Of those identified close contacts, 69.4% were reached.

claims.text: Mandatory vaccines became law from Wednesday 6 January 2021.

claimReview.title: The laws introducing a third English lockdown do not make the Covid-19 vaccine mandatory - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Vaccines are not mandatory in the UK, and the changes to the law introducing a third lockdown in England on Wednesday don’t change that.

claims.text: Photograph of people filling the streets of Paris was taken during protests against Covid-19 regulations on 17 July 2021.

claimReview.title: Photo doesn’t show Covid protest in Paris - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Although there were protests in Paris on this day, this photograph was taken during celebrations after France won the World Cup in 2018.

claims.text: Our Tory government gives itself a £3,300 pay rise.

claimReview.title: MPs haven’t given themselves a £3,300 pay rise - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s been proposed that the salary of all UK MPs will rise by around £3,300, but the government does not set pay.

claims.text: This photo of people waving Palestinian flags was taken at 2018’s Labour party conference.

claimReview.title: Labour members did vote to debate Palestine over the NHS and Brexit at the 2018 party Conference - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct.

claims.text: The AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine causes more side effects than the Pfizer vaccine.

claimReview.title: Side effects from the Oxford and Pfizer vaccines are about the same - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This misunderstands a summary of the evidence from the MHRA. Clinical trial data suggests that the two vaccines’ side effects are about the same.

claims.text: You can send your old or unwanted LEGO bricks to LEGO’s Replay scheme, which donates the toys to charities that work with children.

claimReview.title: Official LEGO donation service not yet available in UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The scheme is not yet available in the UK. There are other UK-based charitable organisations that will accept second hand LEGO.

claims.text: Prisoners in the UK can watch TV all day for free.

claimReview.title: Prisoners don’t have to pay the TV licence whereas most pensioners will soon have to - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Prisoners rewarded for good behaviour can have a TV in their prison cell. Prisoners are exempt from the TV licence fee, but a rental charge of £1 per cell per week applies.

claims.text: 62,000 people a day are tested for Covid-19 in the UK.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner’s testing numbers are not quite right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how many people are being tested, but it is more than 62,000, which only includes people newly tested in England.

claims.text: Bill Gates owns the patent and vaccine for coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates doesn’t own the vaccine for or patent of the Covid-19 virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no patent for the virus that causes Covid-19, and there is not yet an effective vaccine.

claims.text: 3.5 million don’t have access to any photo ID.

claimReview.title: Voter ID scheme: far more turned away than convicted of electoral fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for Great Britain according to research from 2015 – there isn’t a more up-to-date figure. It refers to types of ID that would be valid as part of the government’s proposed voter ID scheme.

claims.text: US food standards allow for insect fragments in peanut butter.

claimReview.title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US food standards set limits above zero for insect fragments in peanut butter, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claims.text: Wages are lower today than they were 10 years ago.

claimReview.title: Are pay packets growing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, on several measures weekly wages are lower than they were 10 years ago.

claims.text: All non-EU trade through the port of Southampton is ‘WTO’.

claimReview.title: Southampton MP gets trade figures wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is misleading. Much non-EU trade through Southampton happens under preferential terms negotiated between the EU and other countries, not on basic WTO terms.

claims.text: Various social media posts claim to show “the world’s tiniest poisonous snake” or a killer worm in a green pepper.

claimReview.title: You don’t need to worry about that video claiming to show a snake in a pepper - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It doesn’t show this. The creature is probably a nematode parasite that is unlikely to be harmful to humans.

claims.text: The Control of Diseases Act in the UK changed on 27 April.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Public Health (Control of Disease) Act 1984 was not changed on this date. The last time the law was changed was 25 March when the Coronavirus Act meant a section, saying local authorities could not cremate a body against the wishes of the person, was removed temporarily. It’s possible this might happen under the new law, but it also says the person’s wishes must be taken into account as far as possible.

claims.text: More than 60 frontline UK healthcare workers took their own life at the beginning of the pandemic.

claimReview.title: New figures on healthcare workers' suicides should be treated with caution - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This data was on deaths by suicide registered in England and Wales in the first half of 2020, we don’t know how many happened in that year.. The majority of all deaths by suicides registered in the first half of 2020 actually happened before the year began.

claims.text: Under the Conservative government 4 million people have been taken out of income tax altogether.

claimReview.title: 4 million people taken out of income tax - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Increases to the personal allowance mean about 4 million fewer people had to pay income tax in 2015/16 than did in 2010/11. Changes to the threshold in 2017 are expected to further reduce the number of people paying income tax.

claims.text: 52% of police officers have been found guilty of sexual misconduct while wearing uniform.

claimReview.title: Most police have not been found guilty of sexual misconduct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It comes from confusion over a Byline Times report, which claimed that 42 out of 83 (52%) of Metropolitan Police officers kept their jobs after being found to have committed sexual misconduct.

claims.text: How many who have no other morbidities under the age of 60 have died from this Covid-19? 350

claimReview.title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest NHS figures for England show that 253 people under the age of 60 with no underlying health conditions have died from Covid-19 in hospitals.

claims.text: People in Poland retire at 60.

claimReview.title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The retirement age for women in Poland is 60—the lowest level in the EU. For men it’s 65 (which is the most common retirement age for men and women in EU countries).

claims.text: The survival rate of Covid-19 without vaccination is 99.8%.

claimReview.title: Catching Covid-19 is not less risky than vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While recent data shows the UK death rate from Covid-19 is 0.2%, this was reported after those most vulnerable to Covid-19 had been vaccinated and doesn’t tell us what the survival rate in an unvaccinated population is. There is evidence that vaccines offer significant protection from serious illness and death.

claims.text: HS2 will cost £150 billion.

claimReview.title: HS2 isn’t expected to cost as much as this post claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is much higher than the latest independent estimate, which puts it at £106 billion. That cost is significantly higher than initital estimates.

claims.text: Austerity has caused the death of 130,000 people in Britain.

claimReview.title: These 130,000 deaths cannot be explicitly linked to austerity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report that the 130,000 figure comes from does not explicitly link this number to austerity, and there’s no way to know how much this was a factor.

claims.text: The UK is the second largest bilateral humanitarian aid donor to Syria.

claimReview.title: The UK is now the second or third largest donor of aid to Syria - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK used to be the second largest aid donor to Syria since 2012, but it is now third behind Germany, according to the United Nations.

claims.text: Graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines helps these parasites grow faster.

claimReview.title: There are no parasites in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: Japan stopped its vaccine rollout, treated people with ivermectin and ended Covid-19 almost overnight.

claimReview.title: Japan is not using ivermectin instead of vaccines to treat Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. Japan is continuing its vaccine rollout. Ivermectin is not an approved treatment for Covid-19 in the country.

claims.text: There is a distinct likelihood children will develop myocarditis if they receive a Covid-19 vaccination.

claimReview.title: Critical report on BBC Newsround story is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is some evidence linking Covid-19 vaccines to myocarditis, and the symptoms that have been reported are “very rare” and “typically mild”.

claims.text: Union Jack flags have replaced EU flags outside parliament ahead of the opening of parliament by the Queen.

claimReview.title: EU Flags were not replaced by Union Jacks outside of parliament - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. There were no flags in parliament square prior to the Union Jack ones being put up for the ceremony.

claims.text: Rapid Covid-19 tests are unreliable because fruit and Coca-Cola can give “positive” results.

claimReview.title: A kiwi fruit did not test “positive” for Covid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Rapid Covid tests very rarely give false positive results when used on humans, as intended. They more often give false negatives.

claims.text: The UK paid out £674 million in health costs to European countries, but received only £49 million in return. Addressing this could “transform the financial situation of the NHS”.

claimReview.title: How much does the UK recover in health costs from the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures are broadly correct for 2015, although addressing this situation would in itself only have a marginal impact on the financial situation of the NHS.

claims.text: Around half of free schools are in the 30% most deprived communities in the country.

claimReview.title: How many free schools are in deprived communities? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Based on the available data (including deprivation data from 2008), just under 45% of open mainstream free schools are.


Around half of free schools are in the 30% most deprived communities in the country.

claims.text: New gates and QR scanners in a Sainsbury’s store are for vaccine passports.

claimReview.title: QR scanners in Sainsbury’s are not for vaccine passes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The gates and scanners have been installed as part of a trial checkout-free store in London, which is currently only open to Sainsbury’s employees.

claims.text: Sub-standard care and staffing at weekends is responsible for thousands of deaths.

claimReview.title: Nobody knows how many lives could be saved by a seven-day NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There's no way to be sure. Research suggests thousands of "excess deaths" for patients admitted at weekends, but not that this is due to poor care.

claims.text: 6,000 UK veterans sleep on the streets.

claimReview.title: Figures for people seeking asylum in hotels and veterans sleeping rough are both wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A report two years ago claimed that 6,000 veterans were homeless, but homelessness includes those in temporary accommodation. The number sleeping rough is probably much lower.

claims.text: Brexit will lead to a cut to GDP of between 3%, 5% and 8%. However you look at it, that’s a recession.

claimReview.title: Estimates of lower GDP growth post-Brexit don’t mean a recession - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on government figures which were actually saying that economic growth is likely to slow down, not that a recession is likely.

claims.text: The Foreign Secretary’s claim that the UK can leave the EU customs union but still trade freely was described as “impossible” by his Dutch counterpart.

claimReview.title: Free trade outside the EU customs union - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct, although Jeroen Dijsselbloem assumed that Boris Johnson was referring to staying in the EU single market when he talked about maintaining “free trade”. That may not have been the case.

claims.text: Ventilators and intensive care units were never used in Russia.

claimReview.title: Claims about Russia, Covid-19 and 5G are almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. For example, one study in Russia looked at more than 1,500 Covid-19 patients in ICU, many of whom were given respiratory support via ventilation.

claims.text: One million ‘legal migrants’ moved to Britain in 2020/21.

claimReview.title: No evidence one million people legally moved to Britain in 2020/2021 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no data to prove this claim. It relies on information about immigration from the previous year, and makes assumptions about the number of people who would migrate to Britain over the course of 2020 and 2021—despite the pandemic.

claims.text: Theresa May claimed expenses for a £1.59 paper clip.

claimReview.title: Parliamentary expenses: is this meme about Theresa May correct? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We couldn’t find a claim for this exact amount  or for a single paperclip, though Mrs May did claim expenses for paperclips along with other items of office stationery.

claims.text: People required to self-isolate will receive a support payment of £500 per week.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson makes an error about quarantine payments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. People who are eligible for the payment will receive £500 in total, not for each week that they self-isolate.

claims.text: A Lee Rigby charity football page was removed from Facebook due to “left wing pressure.”

claimReview.title: A Lee Rigby charity football Facebook page was taken down due to a hacking attempt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The page was removed from Facebook, but the company says this was due to a hacking attempt. It has since been reinstated.

claims.text: Unemployment is the lowest it has been since 1975.

claimReview.title: Is unemployment the lowest it has been since 1975? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct looking at unemployed people as a percentage of all adults either working or looking for a job across the UK.

claims.text: All patients over the age of 16 attending a doctor or hospital appointment in England must now be asked about their sexual orientation.

claimReview.title: Are doctors going to be forced to ask about your sexual orientation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not quite right, these new guidelines aren’t compulsory and it’s up to individual organisations whether they collect it. It’s still predicted to be introduced widely.

claims.text: There has not been a recession, or 500,000 to 800,000 job losses since the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Has there been a recession since the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The United Kingdom has won the second-most number of Nobel Prizes after the United States.

claimReview.title: How many Nobel Prizes has the UK won? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. There are lots of different ways to count it too. If we look at Nobel Prizes per person, the UK is down to 10th.

claims.text: Videos show a four legged monster climbing over buildings in Russia.

claimReview.title: Video of monster climbing buildings appears to be a hoax - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
One of the videos has previously been reported as a hoax, and was created by a graphic designer.

Nobody has publicly admitted to creating the other video from 2013.

claims.text: A police officer’s starting salary was £24,000 in 2010 and £23,000 in 2018.

claimReview.title: This tweet on public sector pay doesn’t factor in inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t factor in inflation. In 2018 prices, the starting salary fell from £27,400 in 2010 to £23,100 in 2018.

claims.text: Mark Carney said there would be a recession in the case of a vote in favour of Brexit.

claimReview.title: Has there been a recession since the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He said before the referendum vote that it was a possibility. He expected a “material slowing in growth”, and that a recession was one of “a range of possible scenarios”.

claims.text: PCR tests are contaminated with a dangerous gas called ethylene oxide.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Swabs are sterilised with ethylene oxide, which can be unsafe in large quantities, but not in the amounts used in this way.

claims.text: A safe, and easy way to remove ticks is to apply a small amount of liquid soap on a cotton ball and blot it onto the tick.

claimReview.title: Don’t use washing up liquid to remove ticks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although this technique may sometimes work, the NHS recommends an alternative method which could help to reduce the risk of contracting a disease from a tick.

claims.text: Older people are more likely to become ill with Covid-19 if they are vaccinated than if they are not.

claimReview.title: The Joe Rogan podcast misused English Covid-19 data - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is based on a misreading of PHE data, which cannot be used to measure the effects of Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: Wages are growing.

claimReview.title: Marr wrong to claim PM wasn’t telling the truth on wages - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wages are up, in real terms, over the past year.

claims.text: A report suggests an independent Scotland would have to make public expenditure reductions.

claimReview.title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report, commissioned by the Scottish National Party, actually says that public spending could continue to grow. This does depend on sufficient growth in the economy after independence.

claims.text: If you’re in a situation where you can’t speak, ring 999 and when they answer press 55. This tells them you need help but can’t speak. They will dispatch police to you.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on how to make a silent 999 call is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you call 999 from a mobile and the operator can’t hear anything suspicious, you will be prompted to press 55 if you need the police. This will not necessarily mean the police will be dispatched. The police call handler will decide what to do.

claims.text: The UK and France are the predominant defence countries in terms of investment and spend across Europe.

claimReview.title: The UK and France are the biggest defence spenders in Europe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Whether the UK or France spends the most depends on exactly how you count it.

claims.text: The OECD says that the UK has the most efficient, accessible healthcare system.

claimReview.title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The OECD says that the UK’s healthcare efficiency is weak.

claims.text: You cannot give blood after you’ve been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Hecklers at Twickenham Stadium vaccine drive spout false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You can, but you have to wait seven days. If you have side effects after vaccination you have to wait 28 days from after they pass.

claims.text: The UK Statistics Authority say A&E performance figures have been fiddled.

claimReview.title: Fiddled A&E statistics? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Authority hasn't said that the figures have been fiddled. It hasn't said that they haven't yet, either. It has demanded that NHS England explain the impact of emails sent to NHS Trusts about counting A&E performance last October and how that might have affected the figures since then.

claims.text: 18 people died of Covid-19 in one day in England.

claimReview.title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true.

claims.text: Millennials are on track to become the first generation to suffer worse health than their parents when they reach middle age, a study has warned.

claimReview.title: Millennial malaise: unhealthier than their parents? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A report by the Health Foundation says “The gains made as a society in improving the health of previous generations may well be eroded by the precariousness and instability of the lives some young people are facing.” We’ve asked it for more information.

claims.text: Suicide is the cause of death for around 3,000 people per day

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Suicide is the cause of death for around 2,000 people per day.

claims.text: Various multinational food and drink companies use artificial flavourings made by Senomyx which are made from aborted foetal cells.

claimReview.title: There aren’t human foetal cells in lots of popular snacks and drinks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
All but one company confirmed they didn’t use the flavouring product made by the company in question. 

The cells are not flavourings themselves but used in flavouring development. They are clones of cells taken from the kidney of aborted foetus in 1973.

claims.text: Faster pay rises for those at the bottom are one of the reasons inequality has fallen in recent years.

claimReview.title: Has the National Living Wage reduced inequality? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Income inequality has fallen by some measures in recent years, but pay rises aren’t considered to be the main reason. These inequality trends are expected to reverse as a result of wider policy changes to taxes and benefits.

claims.text: The price to buy back hospital PFI contracts is £1 trillion.

claimReview.title: Labour hospital and acute care PFI contracts in England cost £1.4 billion in 2017/18 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Although we don’t know the precise figure, the cost to buy back the PFI contracts would likely be close to the existing values of the contracts – over ten times lower than the £1 trillion claimed.

claims.text: David Davis said last month that people overstaying their visa is the biggest problem the UK has.

claimReview.title: How many people overstay their visas? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know which comments by Mr Davis are being referred to. But this generally reflects the views of researchers that most people who live illegally in the UK have expired visas rather than because they snuck in illegally in the first place.

claims.text: The BBC published a travel piece saying that there will be microchips in the upcoming vaccines funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation so they can track who has been vaccinated for coronavirus.

claimReview.title: The BBC did not say that the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation is planning to put microchips in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The BBC article is a speculative piece on the future of travel following the Covid-19 pandemic. There is no mention of microchips being used in vaccines.

claims.text: Covid-19 kills roughly the same number of people as flu.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The death toll from Covid-19 far exceeds that from seasonal flu.

claims.text: Germany’s biggest export market is America.

claimReview.title: Trading places: Who are the UK and Germany’s biggest trade partners? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, Germany exported €111 billion worth of goods and services to the USA in 2017.

claims.text: An image shows a police officer in France pepper spraying a woman recently.

claimReview.title: This photo does not show a French police officer pepper spraying a protester - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was actually taken in Washington state in 2007.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. All of the Covid-19 vaccines have been approved for safety and effectiveness through clinical trials.

claims.text: The Scottish Parliament hasn’t debated education for two years.

claimReview.title: Scotland’s maths and science scores are falling in international tests but rising in national tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There have been several education debates.

claims.text: Greece owes 367 Billion.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Greece’s national debt is worth €337 billion.

claims.text: There were no new daily Covid-19 cases reported in several UK nations and regions on April 29.

claimReview.title: This map in the Daily Express uses all the wrong numbers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Every nation and region listed on the map reported many Covid cases on that day.

claims.text: On duty police officers participated in the London Pride parade.

claimReview.title: Metropolitan police taking part in London Pride were on duty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The Metropolitan police taking part in the Pride parade were on duty.

claims.text: The amendment the government rejected would have cost the taxpayer hundreds of billions of pounds to replace the sewage system in order to eliminate sewage discharge.

claimReview.title: Murky claims about sewage bill fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The amendment itself did not explicitly require sewage discharge to be reduced completely, although its explanatory notes did say this. The amendment called for progressive reduction in harm. Details of the cost of replacing the sewage network are yet to be fully published.

claims.text: Since 2010, we’ve created more jobs than France, Spain, Ireland, The Netherlands, Austria, Sweden and Norway combined.

claimReview.title: Doing a sterling job? How the UK’s employment record compares to the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was correct for the first quarter of 2018, but based on the available data for the second quarter it’s not likely to be correct anymore. It refers to overall changes in employment, including people who move into and out of work.

claims.text: Emergency services will know where you are exactly if you quote the numbers painted on street lamps.

claimReview.title: Emergency services can’t use the numbers on street lamps to find you - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Emergency services cannot use this information to identify your location instantly. The numbers are there for councils to locate street lamps for repairs.

claims.text: 3.9 million kangaroos are killed for leather.

claimReview.title: Adidas, Nike and Puma use kangaroo leather in some products - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an overestimate, based on the most recent data. Just under 1.5 million kangaroos and wallabies killed commercially in 2017 in Australia. We don’t know how many of those 1.5 million are used for leather.

claims.text: The proposal to introduce a points-based system could put up immigration, based on Australia's experience.

claimReview.title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Australia's immigration levels don't tell us anything about what might happen in the UK. Whether or not immigration went up would depend, in part, on how the points-based system was designed by the UK.

claims.text: One in seven workers are self-employed, and the number is growing.

claimReview.title: Are more people self-employed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One in seven is right, and the number and proportion of workers that are self-employed has been rising since the early 2000s, although it has fluctuated.

claims.text: Transport for London issued a tube sign advising passengers to wear deodorant in hot weather and saying the tube smelt like “someone left a ham behind a radiator” in summer.

claimReview.title: This sign saying the tube in summer smells like 16-year-old ham is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is a fake sign.

claims.text: Covid-19 is no longer classified as a high consequence infectious disease.

claimReview.title: Mask wearing doesn’t cause bacterial pneumonia - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. That doesn’t mean it’s not dangerous.

claims.text: The roads in north Wales are better than in Buckinghamshire.

claimReview.title: England v Wales: how bad are the roads? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In Buckinghamshire, 4% of A roads, and 5% of B and C roads are in poor condition. In Gwynedd in North Wales, 11% of A, B and C roads are in poor condition. We don’t know if these figures are directly comparable.

claims.text: There are 11,000 fewer firefighters in England than there were in 2010.

claimReview.title: What’s happened to fire services since 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure seems to refer to the reduction in all staff working for fire and rescue services in England. There are 6,800 fewer firefighters in England than there were in 2010.

claims.text: Muslim women are three times as likely to be unemployed, and twice as likely not to be in the jobs market in the first place, compared to women generally.

claimReview.title: Are Muslim women more likely to be unemployed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct.

claims.text: The UK has £9 billion invested in the European Investment Bank.

claimReview.title: The UK's stake in the European Investment Bank - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This is the value of the UK’s shares in the EIB, based on its finances in 2016.

claims.text: Every time the Labour party has been in government, it has left unemployment higher than when it came in.

claimReview.title: Labour’s record on unemployment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only two of Labour’s periods in government are covered by the most recent comparable data, but this is not quite correct looking at the data we have over all times Labour was in government. Unemployment fell during Ramsay MacDonald’s first term in 1924. Labour was also part of a war time coalition during which unemployment fell.

claims.text: There were over 44,000 new doctors in the NHS and 80,000 more nurses between 1997 and 2010.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The total number of FTE qualified nurses working in general practice and NHS hospitals increased by 79,000 and the number of doctors by 48,000.

claims.text: The Express used a photo from before coronavirus lockdown to suggest people in Brighton were breaking social distancing rules.

claimReview.title: This photo of Brighton was taken during the coronavirus lockdown - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Metadata from the photo shows it was taken during lockdown.

claims.text: A video shows protests at the Rothschild Castle, Switzerland.

claimReview.title: A video does not show anti-Rothschild protests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. It shows protests outside the federal parliament building in Bern.

claims.text: Bombardier is worth 10% of Northern Ireland’s GDP.

claimReview.title: How valuable is Bombardier to the economy of Northern Ireland? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence for this. Bombardier claims it makes up 10% of Northern Ireland’s manufacturing exports, which is about 2% of its GDP.

claims.text: We’ve got 39 billion that we’re going to send to the EU.

claimReview.title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s the estimated size of our “divorce bill” which settles outstanding budget contributions, and other financial commitments and liabilities we have towards EU, up to the end of 2020.

claims.text: Mark Carney said households are £900 a year worse off because of Brexit.

claimReview.title: Are families £900 worse off since Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He said that “some of it” was “arguably” down to Brexit. The figures are based on the difference between the Bank of England’s projections for individuals’ real wage growth between 2016 and 2018 and what actually happened.

claims.text: Recent flooding would have been prevented by dredging.

claimReview.title: EU regulations on dredging did not cause recent flooding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Experts say dredging is part of flooding prevention, but only one part, and would not have prevented the recent floods.

claims.text: Two patients every day die of thirst or starvation in NHS hospitals.

claimReview.title: How many patients die from thirst or starvation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly one patient every three or four days died as a direct result of malnutrition or dehydration in NHS and non-NHS hospitals in England and Wales across 2015. This can’t be directly linked to the quality of care, though.

claims.text: 4,500 people died of the flu within a matter of days.

claimReview.title: The 1918 Philadelphia parade fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A reported 12,000 died in Philadelphia of the flu within four weeks.

claims.text: One of Nicola Sturgeon’s Covid advisors claimed Covid-19 vaccines were 100% safe for children.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The advisor said the Pfizer vaccine was 100% effective in an interview. This was later corrected.

claims.text: There’s been an increase in the number of EU staff in the NHS since the referendum.

claimReview.title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around 4,400 more EU nationals worked for the NHS in England in June 2018, compared to June 2016. But some of the increase could be down to more staff reporting their nationality. The proportion of staff who report they are EU nationals is about the same in 2018 as in 2016.

claims.text: The 5G radiation is bad for humans.

claimReview.title: Hundreds of birds were found dead in the Netherlands but it had nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Public Health England says it has not found evidence that 5G is a risk to human health.

claims.text: Help to Buy ISAs won’t help you buy a home, because you still need to provide an initial exchange deposit when the contracts are signed and you haven’t been given the government bonus at that point.

claimReview.title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since initial exchange deposits are negotiated between the buyer and the seller, it’s possible to negotiate them down. The seller can agree to receive the rest of the money when the purchase completes.

claims.text: The government has been "peddling misinformation" by claiming that business rates will fall in the majority of English council areas next year.

claimReview.title: Business rates: how many council areas will face rate rises? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government's figures aren't the only way to look at the impact of the revaluation, but it’s not necessarily been "peddling misinformation". Its estimates ignore regular rate rises that match inflation, and assume that some businesses will successfully appeal against the revaluation of their property.  If you factor in inflation and look at the picture before appeals, then most English council areas will see average rates rise from next year.

claims.text: Nine in 10 girls experience sexist name-calling or are sent explicit photos or videos.

claimReview.title: How common is sexual abuse in schools? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from a survey that asked girls what they thought was happening among people their age—not what had happened to them personally. Sexual harassment and abuse of girls appears to be common, but the nine in 10 figure is not reliable.

claims.text: Government figures say that a hard Brexit will mean £100 billion is added to the UK’s public sector debt.

claimReview.title: Will a hard Brexit cost £100 billion? - Full Fact
