claimReview.textualRating: The most recent forecast put public sector net debt at over £160 billion higher in 2020/21 compared with the previous year’s forecast. But the forecasters, from the Office for Budget Responsibility, told us that there are a lot of factors behind this change. In November 2016 it said that voting to leave the EU would add £15.2 billion to the debt by 2020/21.

claims.text: Sweden is abolishing cash.

claimReview.title: Sweden is not abolishing cash - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Cashless transactions are common in Sweden, but the government told us it has no plans to stop issuing notes and coins.

claims.text: 8% of stop and searches are knife crime related

claimReview.title: How many stop and searches are knife crime related? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t say for certain. The claim refers to London, where in the first three months of 2018, 9% of stop and searches that led to a “positive outcome”, were for “weapons, points and blades”. This category includes things like acid and screwdrivers as well as knives. We don’t have the same figure for England and Wales.

claims.text: Over half of Britons would ignore Christmas Covid rules.

claimReview.title: Daily Express is wrong to say most people would ignore a Christmas lockdown - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no good evidence for this. It comes from a poll on the Express website, which does not represent the views of British people as a whole.

claims.text: No more than 100,000 people have died of Covid in the UK.

claimReview.title: Lord Sumption made several errors about Covid on Today - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. So far, 124,082 deaths have been recorded in England and Wales alone, where Covid itself was the underlying cause.

claims.text: 17,410,742 people voted to leave in the 2016 EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Was the vote to leave the “largest democratic vote” in British history? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The Covid vaccination programme is a medical experiment.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccine programme isn’t a medical experiment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it isn’t. The vaccines have been approved for use after clinical trials.

claims.text: Research says that nearly half of people who catch Covid develop depression afterwards.

claimReview.title: A Bangladesh study doesn’t show that depression follows Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not what the research says. It measured rates of depression among Covid survivors—but not whether they developed depression after catching the disease.

claims.text: You can't have the Pfizer vaccine if you're allergic to penicillin.

claimReview.title: Penicillin allergies don’t rule out Pfizer vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Official advice in the UK is that having penicillin allergies doesn’t rule out having any of the approved Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: Theresa May blocked NHS funding for a brand of glucose sensor which is a lifeline to diabetics.

claimReview.title: Has NHS funding been blocked for glucose sensors? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The sensor has been available for funding on the NHS across the UK since November 2017, but not all areas have chosen to make it available yet. Since this claim was first made, it's been announced that from April 2019 it will be available to all patients in England who meet certain criteria.

claims.text: A majority of voters say violence against MPs is “worth it” to get their way in Brexit.

claimReview.title: Poll about support for violence against MPs is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A majority said the “risk of violence” is “a price worth paying”. There’s a big distinction between the two, and survey it’s based on suffers from a number of flaws.

claims.text: Glyphosate is in vaccines.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about glyphosate, vaccines and cancer are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Tests by a campaign group and a research scientist/consultant claimed to have detected glyphosate in some vaccines in the US, but the reliability of these tests have been called into question.

claims.text: Three in four academy chains contain secondary schools which could be seen as 'coasting' under the government's definition.

claimReview.title: Coasting schools: three strikes and you're out - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's impossible to know yet how many schools will be labelled 'coasting', as it depends on performance in 2015 and 2016.

claims.text: There are 5,240 fewer mental health nurses since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to be looking at different months in 2010 and 2017, which isn’t the best comparison. Comparing the number of full-time equivalent mental health nurses between January 2010 and January 2018 (the latest figures), the drop is closer to 4,500.

claims.text: 11,000 of 13,000 knife attacks in London were carried out by Muslim migrants.

claimReview.title: Muslim knife attacker claim is unfounded and implausible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is baseless as information on offenders’ religion and nationality is not held by the authorities. Regardless, the claim is implausible.

claims.text: 15% of world trade is conducted through the EU.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU members are responsible for an estimated 15% of the global trade in goods (so excluding services). But only trade between two EU member states would count as being conducted through the EU—so the actual figure for goods will be lower than this.

claims.text: The BBC receives £5 billion of public money.

claimReview.title: How the BBC makes money - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the BBC’s total income, not just that from the licence fee (£3.5 billion) or public money. Much of the rest is generated from its commercial operations.

claims.text: Premier League footballer Marcus Rashford tweeted at Katie Hopkins telling her to “f*** off”.

claimReview.title: Marcus Rashford did not tweet this at Katie Hopkins - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Twitter account that tweeted this is not Marcus Rashford’s verified account.

claims.text: There were 32 deaths from suicide in Ireland in August.

claimReview.title: People did die of Covid-19 in Ireland in August - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s too soon to know this figure as only a coroner can officially rule a death as a suicide, but this figure is realistic looking at past data.

claims.text: It’s not true that until 12 March, the government’s advice said it was ‘very unlikely’ people in care homes will become infected.

claimReview.title: Government guidance withdrawn in March did say it was ‘very unlikely’ people in care homes would be infected with Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The guidance did say this. It was withdrawn on 13 March.

claims.text: Three tablespoons of organic coconut oil morning and night will cause cancer to disappear.

claimReview.title: Lemon juice, coconut oil and stopping all sugar intake won’t cure cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence that coconut oil has any cancer curing properties.

claims.text: The US is the UK’s second largest trading partner.

claimReview.title: The UK’s trade with the USA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Neomycin sulphate, an antibiotic, is in vaccines and can lead to epilepsy, brain damage and allergic reactions.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Trace amounts of this antibiotic may end up in certain vaccines. If you are allergic to it could cause an allergic reaction.

claims.text: UK is testing more people for Covid-19 than any country other than China and Italy.

claimReview.title: There’s limited data on how many Covid-19 tests are being done globally, but the UK doesn’t rank third in the world - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. As at 13 March, the latest data available when this claim was made, the UK ranked fifth (behind China, South Korea, Italy and Russia) for the number of Covid-19 tests carried out. These statistics only included the 38 countries and regions with official data on Covid-19 tests at that time.

claims.text: Matt Hancock is the shareholder of Genomics England which is a conflict of interest.

claimReview.title: All health secretaries become a shareholder of Genomics England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Anybody who becomes the  Secretary of State for Health and Social Care automatically becomes the sole shareholder of Genomics England. This is not unique to Matt Hancock, and he will lose this role when he is no longer in office.

claims.text: Bovine TB blood tests detect bovine TB protein itself, not the immune response.

claimReview.title: Why it’s unlikely Geronimo the alpaca’s TB test gave a false positive - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False.

claims.text: People have to pay the NHS for delivery of a new Omicron-specific Covid-19 test.

claimReview.title: Email asking people to pay for Omicron Covid-19 tests is a scam - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS have confirmed this is a scam. There is no Omicron-specific PCR test.

claims.text: This video shows Cristiano Ronaldo visiting a mosque and reading the Qur’an.

claimReview.title: Ronaldo didn’t visit a mosque in Birmingham - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it doesn’t. This is a Ronaldo lookalike.

claims.text: Being vegan for a year saves 3,320kg of CO2.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear where these facts about veganism are from - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An academic study, which is cited as the evidence for this figure, shows the number is actually closer to half of this.

claims.text: 100 companies are responsible for 71% of global emissions.

claimReview.title: Are 100 companies causing 71% of carbon emissions? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Of the estimated greenhouse gas emissions from human activity (excluding certain sources like agricultural methane) between 1988 and 2015, 71% originated from 100 fossil fuel producers. This includes the emissions released when the fossil fuels they sold were subsequently used by their customers.

claims.text: British old age pensioners get a weekly hardship allowance of £0.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, insofar as the “weekly hardship allowance” doesn’t exist. Pensioners can claim additional benefits to help with their income.

claims.text: Keir Starmer voted against a 2.1% NHS staff pay rise.

claimReview.title: Clearing up the NHS pay debate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There has never been a vote specifically on raising NHS pay by 2.1%. The NHS Funding Bill which committed to minimum total levels of NHS funding was passed unopposed.

claims.text: The proportion of people with a job who live in poverty has risen for the last three years.

claimReview.title: Poverty hasn’t skyrocketed in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. In 2017/18, 13% of households with at least one person in work lived in poverty. This was a slight fall from the year before.

claims.text: Higher education in this country is blindingly middle class.

claimReview.title: Higher education: a white, middle-class affair? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Across several different measures, the more disadvantaged your background, the less likely you are to go into higher education. The gap has been narrowing over time, but is bigger at the most selective universities.

claims.text: 30,000 EU nationals live in the UK.

claimReview.title: About 3.2 million citizens of other EU countries live in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong, about 3.2 million nationals of other EU countries live in the UK.

claims.text: The UK has the fastest growing economy in the G7.

claimReview.title: UK is fastest growing G7 economy by one measure, and fifth by another - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s true if you look at change over the most recent 12 months of data. If you look at growth over the last quarter of data (Q2 to Q3 2021), the UK places fifth.

claims.text: The Bank of England has said the economy will shrink 14% - the equivalent of two recessions.

claimReview.title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Bank has predicted this could happen. If it does, the recession would be more than twice as big as in 2008.

claims.text: Theresa May claimed the entirety of her monthly mortgage payments—between around £1,700 per month and £2,700 per month.

claimReview.title: Parliamentary expenses: is this meme about Theresa May correct? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These aren’t monthly figures and Mrs May didn’t claim expenses for her entire mortgage. She claimed expenses on the interest payments for her mortgage on her second home, as MPs were allowed to do before 2010. She consistently claimed around £450-500 a month between June 2006 and January 2008.

claims.text: There is little evidence that falling wages are being caused by migration, aside from in construction.

claimReview.title: What does immigration do to wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Studies find that immigration affects low-waged workers the most, in low-skilled and semi-skilled jobs generally not just in construction.

claims.text: Israel has banned the entry of vaccinated tourists.

claimReview.title: Israel’s travel policy doesn’t view vaccinated passengers as higher risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Israel has postponed plans to relax restrictions on vaccinated foreign tourists, who it considers to be less of a risk than unvaccinated tourists. Vaccinated tourists are not subject to more restrictions than unvaccinated tourists.

claims.text: There’s a record level of investment going into schools.

claimReview.title: Spending on schools up to 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve asked the government for the source of this. The cash amount going to schools in England is rising and ahead of inflation, but spending per pupil is set to fall in real terms, by 8% between 2014 and 2020, taking school-specific inflation into account.

claims.text: Ethylene oxide is the main ingredient used in antifreeze.

claimReview.title: Chemical used to sterilise Covid-19 tests won’t turn into deadly antifreeze - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is used as an intermediate agent to produce other chemicals.

claims.text: Apple has reopened all 42 China stores.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. On 13 March 2020, Apple announced that it had reopened all 42 stores in mainland China after a closure of almost six weeks.

claims.text: The chance of getting a blood clot after the AstraZeneca vaccine is almost the same as being killed by a cow.

claimReview.title: The chance of being killed by a cow and other AstraZeneca vaccine risk comparisons explained - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The risk of getting a blood clot after vaccination is higher than the risk of being killed by a cow, but the risk of dying from a blood clot after vaccination is about the same as being killed by a cow.

claims.text: A police bulletin warns scammers are going door to door handing out face masks doused in chemicals that cause the wearer to fall unconscious, allowing them to rob the property.

claimReview.title: Police have not warned the public about face masks doused in chemicals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this police warning or of this crime taking place. This claim has been debunked around the world.

claims.text: The Conservatives are levelling up per pupil funding.

claimReview.title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Per pupil spending on schools in England is set to increase over the next three years to roughly the level it was at in 2009/10.

claims.text: There were 6,507 suicides registered by coroners in 2018 - a rise of 11.8% on the previous year.

claimReview.title: Is the suicide rate up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Technically correct, but some of this rise may be due to legal changes making it easier for coroners to record suicide as cause of death.

claims.text: British old age pensioners who have worked for 45 years get a total yearly benefit of £6,000.

claimReview.title: Who gets more, pensioners or refugees? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A British pensioner with 45 years’ worth of national insurance contributions is likely to earn at least £500 a year more than this, and be eligible for more benefits on top.

claims.text: The Treasury said there would be 500,000 to 800,000 jobs lost in the case of a vote in favour of Brexit.

claimReview.title: Has there been a recession since the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Sainsbury’s has stopped selling fireworks due to animal welfare concerns.

claimReview.title: Concerns about animal welfare are just one reason Sainsbury’s stopped selling fireworks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A Sainsbury's spokesperson said the supermarket has not sold fireworks since 2019. They said the decision to stop selling them was based on a number of different factors, including animal welfare.

claims.text: We make one of the biggest contributions to the EU budget.

claimReview.title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.  The UK contributes roughly the third largest sum of money into the EU budget behind Germany and France, and a similar amount to Italy.

claims.text: Yellow Card data will allow the vaccines to move out of the phase 3 clinical trials and be granted full approval.

claimReview.title: Poster about Yellow Card scheme is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Yellow Card data isn’t required for the vaccines to “move out of” phase 3 trials. Phase 3 trials for the vaccines have reported their main findings, and participants will be followed up for several years.

claims.text: The Delta variant doesn’t exist and is a media-fabricated scam.

claimReview.title: There are ways to identify the Delta variant - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Delta variant is real. It has affected many countries across the world, including the UK, and is a recognised variant of concern designated by bodies such as Public Health England and the World Health Organisation.

claims.text: Both female Prime Ministers have been Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Women in the Commons - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The UK has had two female Prime Ministers, both Conservative MPs.

claims.text: The UK has nine out of the 10 poorest regions in northern Europe.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have the poorest regions in northern Europe? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, this is out of date. In 2016, the UK had six of the 10 regions with the lowest GDP per person, from a group of nearby countries. This isn’t a good measure of how rich or poor people in those regions are.

claims.text: Esther McVey’s record is of 1,000 more jobs per day.

claimReview.title: Counting Esther McVey’s record on employment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at the increase in employment during her time as Work and Pensions secretary, since her first stint at DWP, and since the Conservatives entered government. But the employment increase can’t necessarily be attributed to any specific government policies.

claims.text: The survival rate for Covid-19 is 98.54% in the UK.

claimReview.title: We don’t know the true Covid-19 survival rate yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know what the survival rate is yet, as we don’t know how many people have had the disease. This figure comes from a claim about the US which is a slight over-estimate based on available figures.

claims.text: China was the first place to have over 100,000 5G towers.

claimReview.title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While it is true that China has over 100,000 towers, it is unclear if it was the first place to pass this number.

claims.text: The mRNA vaccines from BioNTech/Pfizer contain polyethylene glycol (PEG). 70% of people develop antibodies against this substance—this means many people can develop allergic, potentially fatal reactions to the vaccination.

claimReview.title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that the vaccine contains this, but in very small amounts. In some rare cases people are allergic to PEG and one study found 72% of samples were found to contain mostly low levels of antibodies against it, but that doesn’t necessarily mean that many will have an allergic reaction.

claims.text: This is an image of Jeremy Corbyn at an IRA funeral.

claimReview.title: This is not an image of Jeremy Corbyn at an IRA funeral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The man in the photo is not Jeremy Corbyn.

claims.text: Local authorities are bringing in less money in council tax at the moment than they're spending out just in vulnerable adult and children care alone.

claimReview.title: Councils aren’t getting enough funding to meet demand for social care - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Council tax revenues raised in England in 2017/18 were £500 million less than the adult and children’s social care budget for councils in the same year, according to the Local Government Association. Government data suggests council tax revenue was £5 billion higher. The main source of council budgets is money from central government, which has been falling in recent years.

claims.text: Under the Labour party 1.4 million people spent most of the last decade on out-of-work benefits.

claimReview.title: Were 1.4 million stuck on out-of-work benefits under Labour? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to 2010 research by the Department for Work and Pensions, 1.4 million people were on out of work benefits in nine of the last ten years.

claims.text: The government minimum wage so that people can live reasonably is £8.72 an hour x 36 hours equals £1,256 per month, x 12 months equals £15,070 per year.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post compares the national living wage with the state pension - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct for workers over the age of 25.

claims.text: There is a shortage of 40,000 nurses across the UK.

claimReview.title: Are we short of 40,000 nurses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to an estimate of full-time equivalent nursing vacancies in December 2016 done by the Royal College of Nursing, though it only refers to England. That isn’t the same as the number of nurses NHS England needs.

claims.text: US patents 7897744 and 8506968 are for SARS.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The first number is the US patent number for the SARS virus. The patent application was made by the CDC, but after the outbreak in 2002. The second number is a patent for a SARS vaccine which has now expired.

claims.text: As of 2 November, case numbers are spiking.

claimReview.title: Why are media outlets reporting the Covid epidemic is escalating? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At this point, new infections in the UK were falling. The total number of people with Covid-19, as opposed to newly diagnosed people, may have still been increasing.

claims.text: Deaths have risen in the UK since 2011.

claimReview.title: UK death rates have stayed the same since 2011 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but after accounting for the changing size and age structure of the UK, rates of death have stayed about the same since 2011. This represents a stalling of death rates following decades of falling death rates.

claims.text: The “corona vaccine” is not safe or effective.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Clinical trials have shown that vaccines for Covid-19 work and are safe.

claims.text: Natural immunity is robust, complete, and durable. It cannot be improved upon by vaccination, or any other method.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Studies have shown natural immunity to Covid-19 can wane, and that, among people who have been infected, those who have been vaccinated are less likely to be reinfected.

claims.text: EU Membership costs 34p per person per day.

claimReview.title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct, based on the UK’s net payment into the EU budget in 2018.

claims.text: 118,000 care home workers have been tested for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The government says 125,000 workers in care settings and 118,000 care home residents have been tested for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. 118,000 care home residents have been tested for Covid-19 since the start of the pandemic.

claims.text: Lord Kerr, who sits on the UK Supreme Court, wrote Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union.

claimReview.title: The Lord Kerr who wrote Article 50 isn’t the Lord Kerr who sits on the Supreme Court - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wrong. There are two Lord Kerrs. John Kerr, who was one of the authors of Article 50, does not sit on the Supreme Court. That’s Brian Kerr.

claims.text: The “vast majority” of those dying from Covid-19 in the UK now are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Guardian wrong to suggest unvaccinated deaths are the majority currently - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The most recent report from the UKHSA, including data from England, shows that there are currently more deaths in vaccinated, rather than unvaccinated, people. This is due to the high proportion of the population who are now vaccinated.

claims.text: Labour’s manifesto would have cost half of HS2.

claimReview.title: HS2 isn’t expected to cost as much as this post claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour’s 2019 manifesto set aside £83 billion of additional day-to-day spending by 2023, and there were other costs not included in the manifesto. This is much more than half the current estimated cost of HS2, which is the sum of many years' spending anyway.

claims.text: South Korean Police use purple dye cannons to mark protesters

claimReview.title: South Korean police don’t use purple dye cannons on protesters - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: South Korean police have historically used yellow dye cannons of protesters, but have reportedly begun to reconsider the user of water cannons.

claims.text: The railways are owned by the Dutch and German government.

claimReview.title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Governments in Germany, the Netherlands and France are shareholders in the companies and parent companies running around a dozen UK rail franchises.

claims.text: The official UK death toll from the coronavirus pandemic now equals the death toll from the Blitz.

claimReview.title: More people have probably been killed by coronavirus than were killed during the Blitz - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At the time this claim was made, the government’s “official” published count of Covid-19 deaths was slightly under the number of deaths during the Blitz, although the numbers are very similar. The true number of deaths related to Covid-19 is likely to be higher than the toll during the Blitz.

claims.text: The UK spends 0.7% of its GDP on aid, which is more than any other G7 country.

claimReview.title: How much money does the UK spend on aid compared to the rest of the G7? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for the UK in 2017, though it’s based on a slightly different figure that includes overseas income. Germany spends just under 0.7%, but slightly less than the UK.

claims.text: Men in Teesside have the same life expectancy as those in Ethiopia.

claimReview.title: Alex Cunningham and Boris Johnson both used the wrong figures about health inequality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Men in one very deprived ward of Stockton have the same life expectancy as men in Ethiopia, according to figures from the World Bank in 2017. This isn’t the case for Teesside as a whole.

claims.text: Heathrow Airport is used by businessmen and women.

claimReview.title: Is Heathrow just for high flyers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An estimated 24% of flyers from Heathrow are travelling for business, more than most other major airports. Only City airport has a higher proportion of business travellers in London (50%).

claims.text: Irish GDP per head was lower than the UK before they cut corporation tax, and it’s now 50% higher.

claimReview.title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. We’ve seen no measures of GDP per head which placed Ireland below the UK before they cut corporation tax in 2015, and some measures show the difference is now is more than 50%.

claims.text: Italy fielded a player in the Euro 2020 final who shouldn’t have been playing due to receiving a yellow card in the quarter-final.

claimReview.title: Italy aren’t going to be disqualified from Euro 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. No Italian player received two yellow cards to warrant suspension before the final, and yellow cards expired after the quarter-finals anyway.

claims.text: One in 50 Londoners snorts cocaine on a daily basis.

claimReview.title: Has cocaine use really doubled in five years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t enough available evidence to say this and we don’t know enough detail about the methodology behind this claim to assess its accuracy.

claims.text: You are allowed to register to vote twice—once at home and once at university.

claimReview.title: You can register to vote in two places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: You can now be forcibly vaccinated.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You cannot be forcibly vaccinated.

claims.text: The vaccines are inadequately tested and somewhat dangerous.

claimReview.title: Mike Yeadon wrong again on lockdowns and face masks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Covid-19 vaccines are tested thoroughly like any other vaccine and are safe.

claims.text: Labour will borrow £500 billion more in government.

claimReview.title: Will there be half a trillion pounds of borrowing under Labour? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know yet what all of Labour’s policies will cost or raise. This figure refers to planned investment spending, not all of which the party says will come from public borrowing.

claims.text: Clementine Churchill told her husband Winston Churchill that she could have made a former love interest, a street sweeper, prime minister.

claimReview.title: Churchill street sweeper quote has been attributed to many politicians - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This anecdote has appeared in many different forms across the internet, with attribution to a number of famous political couples. There is no evidence that this conversation between the Churchills ever actually took place.

claims.text: 11.5 million Brits, or one in four, were prescribed addictive drugs last year.

claimReview.title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for adults in England in 2017/18. This is the number of people who had received at least one prescription for one of five specific types of potentially addictive drug.

claims.text: Nearly 99% of Covid-19 patients who are vitamin D deficient die, according to a research study.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 study that links deaths to low vitamin D levels is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A study from Indonesia did claim to show this, but there are problems with the study methods that mean it doesn’t prove this is the case. The paper has now been removed by the authors from the online research library it appeared on.

claims.text: London overtook New York in murders in February for the first time in modern history as the capital endured a dramatic surge in knife crime.

claimReview.title: Has the number of murders in London overtaken New York? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly correct. More homicides (not just murders) were recorded in London than New York over the past two months. Looking over the longer term the figure is generally higher in New York. There has been a surge in knife crime.

claims.text: If an unlicensed COVID-19 vaccine is rushed into use by the British government, then the vaccine’s manufacturers would be exempt from civil liability.

claimReview.title: Unlicensed vaccine manufacturers are immune from some, but not all, civil liability - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is generally correct. EU law, which has been adopted by the UK, protects manufacturers from liability if the government decides to supply their vaccines without licensing. However, they are not exempt from all liabilities.

claims.text: Menachem Begin killed World War Two veterans and then booby trapped their bodies to kill those who found them.

claimReview.title: This is a real photo of Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Begin ordered the killing of the two British soldiers and their bodies were booby trapped.

claims.text: Walking your pet dog may raise your risk of catching coronavirus by 78 per cent.

claimReview.title: Research suggesting increased Covid-19 risk for dog-owners may be barking up the wrong tree - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on research which has many flaws. In particular, suggestions this is down to dogs acting as a Covid-19 vector are based on limited evidence.

claims.text: EU laws prevent the UK from dredging rivers.

claimReview.title: EU regulations on dredging did not cause recent flooding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Dredging happens in the UK. Some elements of it are affecting by EU directives, but not prevented.

claims.text: Half of all council tenants on Universal Credit are at least a month in arrears in their rent.

claimReview.title: Is Universal Credit leading to rent arrears? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to 105 councils who responded to freedom of information requests. We haven’t seen the data behind it and don’t know what the picture is in the rest of the UK.

claims.text: A requirement for doctors to have a Hepatitis B vaccine sets a clear precedent for requiring care home workers to have the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Is there a precedent for mandatory vaccines for care home workers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Guidance states that healthcare staff doing certain exposure prone procedures do need to have had the Hepatitis B vaccine, but this is not law.

claims.text: GPs are treating 200,000 fewer patients on Fridays with appointment availability getting progressively worse during the week.

claimReview.title: Daily Mail report on GPs seeing fewer patients on Fridays needs more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is correct for July 2021 in England, but comes with important caveats. The drop in appointments on Friday is more marked when compared with Monday, when GPs are busiest, rather than the rest of the week. The Friday drop is also a longstanding one, and the figures can’t tell us about “availability” or how appointment supply compares with demand.

claims.text: The latest data from the UKHSA appears to show Covid-19 vaccines do not prevent hospitalisation or death from the disease.

claimReview.title: UKHSA data reaffirms that vaccines work against Omicron - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. No vaccine is 100% effective, but the Covid-19 vaccines are highly effective against hospitalisation and death. The data from the UKHSA cannot be used to estimate vaccine effectiveness.

claims.text: More than one in 10 callers to HMRC fails to get through to anyone, compared with just over one in 20 a year ago.

claimReview.title: HMRC: how many unanswered calls? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 13% of calls to HMRC went unanswered from April 2017 to February 2018, compared to 8% in 2016/17 as a whole.

claims.text: A peer-reviewed research paper says that the new coronavirus has been artificially engineered.

claimReview.title: A Norwegian-British research paper doesn’t claim the virus causing Covid-19 was man-made - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A Norwegian virologist has made claims about the non-natural origins of the new coronavirus. But this claim is not in a new peer-reviewed paper he co-authored. The scientific community widely agrees that the virus was not artificially engineered.

claims.text: Covid-19 death statistics have been manipulated.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 victims cannot be cremated against their wishes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that deaths shortly after a positive test may include some people who died for other reasons. However, it also does not include people who did die of Covid later on. Information from death certificates reliably shows that, so far, there have been 152,397 fatalities where Covid-19 was mentioned as a cause of death on the death certificate.

claims.text: Last month MPs voted against removing the "tampon tax".

claimReview.title: Did MPs vote against removing the "tampon tax"? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs didn't vote on whether to remove the tax (which can't be done without changing EU law). The amendment they voted against was on whether the government should have to set out a "road map" for how it will negotiate with the EU to get sanitary products exempt from VAT.

claims.text: Not one politician has lost a penny.

claimReview.title: This viral UK Facebook post claiming 31 million job losses probably refers to the USA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not possible to analyse the financial situation of every MP. However, it is correct that UK MPs have not taken any pay cuts during the pandemic.

claims.text: AstraZeneca translates to ‘weapon that kills’.

claimReview.title: AstraZeneca does not translate to ‘weapon that kills’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It doesn’t. This claim is made by selectively choosing definitions from different languages and cultures. AstraZeneca’s name was created from a merger, with ‘Astra’ coming from the Greek for ‘star’.

claims.text: The removal of cremation form 5 means that people are being cremated against their family’s wishes.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 victims cannot be cremated against their wishes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that cremation form 5 has been suspended, but this does not mean people are being cremated against their wishes or the wishes of their family. In fact, the Coronavirus Act specifically prevents this.

claims.text: Judges are going to decide on whether the UK will leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Are judges deciding whether the UK will leave the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The courts will decide whether Parliament has to have a say or not, rather than the government going ahead with Brexit by itself. It’s not directly a question about whether the vote should be upheld, which isn’t a legal matter.

claims.text: The UK has led the world by committing to “net zero” greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.

claimReview.title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK’s stated ambition to reduce emissions goes further than most other countries, and the UK is generally considered to be a world-leader in setting targets into law. A few other countries have set similar or more ambitious targets.

claims.text: We will retake our seats on international bodies. […] We will have more international influence and use it to encourage more friendly international cooperation.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on international influence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK already sits on many international bodies individually, as do representatives of the EU as a whole.

claims.text: Sadiq Khan was the consultant lawyer for the captured 9/11 Al Qaeda terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui.

claimReview.title: Sadiq Khan’s former law firm did consult on the defence of someone convicted in relation to 9/11 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sadiq Khan did consult for the defence of Zacarias Moussaoui, although Mr Khan never represented the man in court and has never met him.

claims.text: The NHS has issued a letter saying that some children infected with coronavirus have been exhibiting symptoms similar to toxic shock syndrome.

claimReview.title: This letter about inflammation in children is real but only refers to a handful of cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a real letter issued to NHS primary care medical professionals. This letter was intended for medical professionals and refers to only a small number of cases.

claims.text: Theresa May u-turned on a pre-election promise to cap energy bills.

claimReview.title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The government did introduce a bill that would allow for energy price caps as promised. At the moment it’s progressing through parliament.

claims.text: One in ten patients admitted to hospital are suffering from a form of diabetes linked to being overweight and inactive

claimReview.title: The Mail’s diabetes front page needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This needs context. One in ten patients admitted to English hospitals in 2018/19 had type 2 diabetes, but a small fraction of those were admitted for their diabetes specifically.

claims.text: UK universities get 15% extra money in funding from the EU, on top of what the government gives them.

claimReview.title: How much money do British universities get from the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 15%, or a little higher, is a rough estimate of additional EU research and development funding; this isn't only for universities. British higher education providers get at least 2.6% of their total income from the EU, or around 16% of their research income.

claims.text: The trains don’t run on time.

claimReview.title: Are rail fares out of control? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around 87% of trains in Britain arrived at their destination within five or 10 minutes of their schedule, in the year to May 2018. Around 62% arrived within a minute of their schedule.

claims.text: The UK government killing British nationals fighting for Islamic State in Syria is lawful under international law.

claimReview.title: Is it legal to kill people fighting for Islamic State in Syria? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends on how you interpret international law. Different states interpret it differently. The UK government believes it can be lawful in some circumstances.

claims.text: Covid-19 is not a virus, but a bacterium being amplified by 5G which causes inflammation and hypoxia.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid-19 patients can get secondary infections from bacteria. Hypoxia and types of inflammation can be symptoms of Covid-19. There’s no proof Covid-19 is in any way related to 5G.

claims.text: Real wages are rising.

claimReview.title: Are pay packets growing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Average weekly earnings before bonus payments were higher in March 2018 (and in January-March) than they were in the same periods in 2017. After bonus payments they were either lower or had not changed.

claims.text: If a wound was not caused by a rusty nail where farm animals graze you most likely don’t have to worry about tetanus.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on tetanus jabs gets a lot wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some wounds carry a higher risk of tetanus than others. However, it is not true to say that a wound caused by a rusty nail where farm animals graze is the only type of injury that could lead to tetanus infection.

claims.text: £22 billion was taken out of welfare between 2010 and 2015.

claimReview.title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is how much more would have been spent in real terms on social security payments across the UK between 2010/11 and 2015/16, had changes introduced between 2010 and 2015 not taken place.

claims.text: The four-hour accident and emergency target has not been hit in over two years.

claimReview.title: When was the four-hour A&E target last hit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The four hour A&E target hasn’t been met in England since July 2015, and the last time it was met over a full year was in 2013/14. The target hasn't been met at “major” A&E departments since June 2013 and hasn’t been above 95% annually since 2010/11.

claims.text: If you want to marry and bring in someone from a country outside of the EU, you have to have a salary of over £18,600.

claimReview.title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, this has been the minimum income requirement before tax since 2012, although in some circumstances you can include your partner’s income in meeting the threshold.

claims.text: A higher proportion of the public say that they are dissatisfied with the NHS than satisfied.

claimReview.title: Can't get no NHS satisfaction? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s difficult to say: this is according to one survey commissioned by the BMA. But there are often differences from survey to survey driven by multiple factors. A similar question asked by the British Social Attitudes survey found a majority were satisfied last year.

claims.text: Government ministers broke their own Covid rules at a recent ‘Cobra’ meeting.

claimReview.title: Photos of ministers together weren’t taken at a ‘Cobra’ meeting - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It can be hard to tell from photographs, but there’s no clear evidence ministers were not following current workplace guidance at the Cabinet meeting. Some rules that apply to social activity do not currently apply in workplaces.

claims.text: This image shows a naked child trying to “escape” Buckingham Palace.

claimReview.title: This is not an image of a naked child “escaping” from Buckingham Palace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is an image from a viral hoax created to promote a TV drama.

claims.text: A quarter of Oxford colleges did not admit a single black student in a whole year group at least once between 2015 and 2017.

claimReview.title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place between 2015 and 2017.

claims.text: If you do challenge someone, you could be fined under the Equality Act 2010.

claimReview.title: Challenging someone for not wearing a face mask isn’t against the Equality Act - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Asking someone to wear a face covering is unlikely to be discrimination, as long as you follow government guidance.

claims.text: Wind turbines can never generate as much energy as the energy invested in building them.

claimReview.title: Overblown: Wind turbines don’t take more energy to build than they will ever produce - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect—this is based on a selective quotation. It could, in theory, be the case for turbines placed in poor locations. But studies show turbines pay their energy cost back quickly.

claims.text: Pay rises have been fastest for people at the bottom because of the new National Living Wage.

claimReview.title: Has the National Living Wage reduced inequality? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Earnings have increased faster for people on lower incomes in recent years, although the National Living Wage doesn’t target those at the very bottom.

claims.text: Alcohol hand sanitiser can catch fire in a hot car.

claimReview.title: Can hand sanitiser catch fire in a hot car? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At temperatures below several hundred degrees celsius, there would need to be a spark for alcoholic hand sanitisers to catch fire.

claims.text: The Kray twins were never let out.

claimReview.title: Claim about the Kray Twins and great train robbers’ prison releases are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Reggie Kray was released early on compassionate grounds after being diagnosed with terminal cancer. His brother Ronnie died in hospital after collapsing in prison.

claims.text: Full-fibre has low maintenance costs once rolled out, which can be estimated at around £230 million a year.

claimReview.title: Labour corrects broadband cost figure - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a miscalculation. Data from the infrastructure agency suggests costs would be two to four times this amount.

claims.text: NHS staff do 11 hours a week unpaid overtime on average.

claimReview.title: Mirror claims NHS staff work 11 hours unpaid overtime on average but it’s probably more like two hours - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The NHS staff survey suggests NHS staff in England do around two hours unpaid overtime on average, but even this figure should be taken with a pinch of salt.

claims.text: The UK is lobbying to reduce EU duties on Chinese steel.

claimReview.title: Is the UK calling for EU duties for Chinese steel? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has objected to raising duties on Chinese steel in the past, and is thought to be a supporter of China being granted ‘Market Economy Status’ which may result in lower duties in the future. At present it backs the duties currently imposed by the EU.

claims.text: You can get side effects of Covid-19 vaccines simply by being in close proximity to someone who has had the vaccine.

claimReview.title: Being near to people vaccinated against Covid-19 won’t give you side effects - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. There is nothing in the Covid-19 vaccines used in the UK that could cause vaccine shedding.

claims.text: Surgical masks offer no protection against Covid-19 and are “no good”.

claimReview.title: The evidence shows surgical masks do offer protection from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While surgical masks won’t remove the chance of contracting Covid-19, there is evidence which suggests they reduce the chance of infection, the severity of infection and the spread of the disease.

claims.text: North Wales doesn’t get its fair share of infrastructure spending compared to the rest of the UK.

claimReview.title: Infrastructure spending: does North Wales get its fair share? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not possible to say from available data. Specifying who benefits from infrastructure projects is often neither fair nor possible to do.

claims.text: PCR tests insert nanoparticles into your brain and cause Morgellons disease.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims PCR tests insert ‘nanoparticles’ into brain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is entirely false. There is no evidence PCR tests insert anything into your brain, and there is debate about whether Morgellons is a real disease.

claims.text: FIFA doesn't allow poppies to be worn on international football jerseys.

claimReview.title: FIFA has restrictions on England footballers wearing poppies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but in 2011 they allowed armbands embroidered with poppies to be worn.

claims.text: The number of people entering teacher training has increased in the last year.

claimReview.title: Are we recruiting enough trainee teachers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of people entering postgraduate teacher training increased in the last year, but is below target. The overall number of people entering at undergraduate and postgraduate level has fallen.

claims.text: The UK has the lowest unemployment since 1975.

claimReview.title: Unemployment in the UK since 1975 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It was at 4.3% between May and July 2017.

claims.text: Japan is not taking in refugees.

claimReview.title: Japan does accept a small number of official refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Japan does accept a small number of officially recognised refugees, but more people are able to stay in Japan under humanitarian grounds.

claims.text: The Conservative election manifesto gave no indication that the party would stop new onshore wind generators from accessing an existing subsidy.
claims.claimant: Amber Rudd, Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change

claimReview.title: The Conservative manifesto's onshore wind pledge - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The reference to ending "new public subsidy" for onshore wind is ambiguous. It doesn't, on the face of it, reference existing schemes, but has to be seen in the context of the clear aim to stop the construction of new wind farms.

claims.text: Scotland has the highest rate of workers in the UK earning the real living wage, at 81.6%.

claimReview.title: SNP manifesto claim on living wage is slight underestimate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to be based on slightly out of date figures, the most up to date figures we could find suggest this is a slight underestimate and that the figure is closer to 83%

claims.text: Boris Johnson said a variety of outrageous things about Scotland and its resources.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson didn’t say this quote about Scotland – it’s a parody - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. These “quotes” come from a parody article.

claims.text: A&E admissions for alcohol poisoning have doubled.

claimReview.title: Have A&E admissions for alcohol poisoning doubled? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The attendance rate to A&E for alcohol poisoning has doubled over six years, according to research. This counts people regardless of what treatment they get and isn't the same as being admitted to a ward. Emergency admissions to a hospital ward due to alcohol have increased by over a half over a period of nine years.

claims.text: Every week in prisons there are 600 incidents of self-harm, at least one suicide, and 350 assaults, including 90 on staff.

claimReview.title: Self-harm and suicides in jail - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although suicides aren't measured precisely. 2015 was the worst year on record for these incidents.

claims.text: Over 70% of Covid-19 deaths are now in vaccinated people in the UK.

claimReview.title: Joe Rogan podcast uses Covid-19 death data out of context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for deaths in England, and comes from UKHSA data in its week 38 vaccine surveillance report. However, the UKHSA explains that this is expected because a larger proportion of the population are vaccinated than unvaccinated, particularly among vulnerable groups

claims.text: New changes in wine import regulation will save British wine drinkers £130 million a year

claimReview.title: The government’s numbers on savings for wine drinkers don’t add up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most of this isn’t a “saving” but a maintenance of the status quo. It is only a saving compared to the government’s abandoned policy which would have introduced regulatory costs.

claims.text: The UK Vaccine Damage Payment has paid out over £74 million since 1978.

claimReview.title: This FOI about vaccines is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, between 1978 and April 2017. Just over 900 payments were made in total.

claims.text: Kobe Bryant’s daughter Natalia has died by suicide.

claimReview.title: Kobe Bryant’s daughter has not died by suicide - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false, and the website making the claim is impersonating BBC News.

claims.text: A new trial drug being tested by Pfizer is actually ivermectin being rebranded.

claimReview.title: Pfizer’s new trial drug is not ivermectin in disguise - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There may be similarities in how they work, but the two drugs are structurally very different.

claims.text: The NAO found there was never a national shortage of PPE.

claimReview.title: The NAO didn’t claim there was never a national PPE shortage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NAO did not find this. It wrote that while trusts told it that they were able to get what they needed in the spring of 2020, healthcare workers reported widespread shortages.

claims.text: The EU wants the UK to pay £60 billion before they negotiate a post-Brexit trade deal.

claimReview.title: How much will the UK have to pay the EU once Brexit is negotiated? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t verify this yet. Experts and a number of media reports have suggested that the final bill to the EU once Brexit is negotiated could be anywhere between €20 and €70 billion. We asked the EU who told us it couldn’t comment.

claims.text: 58% of votes cast in the recent EU parliamentary elections were votes to leave, and 41.5% were votes to remain.

claimReview.title: What do the EU election results tell us about public support for leave and remain? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This assumes that all Labour voters supported leave, which is far from clear. It’s also not the case that all people voted for a party based on their Brexit policy.

claims.text: The leaked UK-US trade documents contain the quote: “The USA reserves the right to withdraw all trade, aid and communication upon the non-compliance of the UK to allow open discussions about the sale of all assets within and partnered with the National Health Service”.

claimReview.title: This quote about selling NHS assets does not appear in the leaked UK-US trade documents - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This quote is false. The documents do not contain this.

claims.text: A 5G mast next to a school was removed after four young elementary school students develop cancer.

claimReview.title: A mobile phone mast was relocated due to local concerns about school cancer cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A mobile phone mast was removed from the grounds of an elementary school following local concern over several cases of cancer. However, there is no evidence linking the cancers to the mast. The mast did not use 5G technology.

claims.text: When the UK leaves the EU, we can set our own tariffs.

claimReview.title: Will getting rid of EU tariffs help the worst off? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although we won’t have a completely free hand to set what we want due to World Trade Organisation rules.

claims.text: Italian politician Maria Elena Boschi exposed her underwear during her swearing-in ceremony.

claimReview.title: An Italian politician did not expose her underwear during her swearing-in ceremony - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The image which supposedly shows this is an edited version of a real photo.

claims.text: The UK economy is growing more quickly than any of the other G7 countries.

claimReview.title: Is the UK still the fastest growing G7 economy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2016, the UK economy seems to have grown faster than any G7 country bar Germany, which grew at essentially the same rate.

claims.text: The total number of deaths in the first three months of 2020 is lower than in any of the previous five years.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post is wrong on deaths in first three months of 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is based on data that stops a week short. The real total is higher than it was in 2016 or 2019.

claims.text: Germany has accepted 800,00 Syrian refugees.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: Germany hasn't accepted 800,000 Syrian refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Germany will end up accepting hundreds of thousands of refugees, both from Syria and the wider world, but 800,000 Syrians accepted to date is way off.

claims.text: Luxembourg benefits the most from being in the EU, getting back 3,304% of what it pays in.

claimReview.title: Is Luxembourg the biggest beneficiary of the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The amount that Luxembourg received in EU spending in 2018 was roughly 105% of what it paid in to the EU budget. 16 other EU countries received a higher level of spending—relative to what they paid in—than Luxembourg.

claims.text: Under the Conservatives, the state pension has risen by over £1,450.

claimReview.title: Prime Minister’s pension claims don’t adjust for inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In cash terms yes, the state pension has increased by £1,470 since 2010/11. But after accounting for inflation the increase is around £550.

claims.text: Doubling of teenage depression rates is linked to social media use.

claimReview.title: Telegraph headline linking depression and social media isn't backed up by article - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study referred to in the article does not show this, and the expert quoted in the article said that there could be a number of factors at play.

claims.text: The UK’s most popular book is The Modern Kama Sutra.

claimReview.title: The Kama Sutra is not the UK’s most popular book - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong and based on data from one online marketplace. Other bestseller compilations from Amazon and Nielsen do not include the Modern Kama Sutra.

claims.text: Clint Eastwood is dead.

claimReview.title: Despite reports to the contrary, Clint Eastwood is alive - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, Clint Eastwood is alive.

claims.text: Some reports suggest Covid-19 vaccines have caused a 2,000% increase in miscarriages.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence miscarriages are being caused by the vaccine. You would expect the number of miscarriages following vaccination to increase as more younger people of childbearing age, a proportion of whom may have a miscarriage, become eligible to get vaccinated.

claims.text: In the six years from 2010 rail fares have risen 25% on average.
claims.claimant: Lilian Greenwood MP, Shadow Transport Secretary

claimReview.title: Rail fares: up 25% in six years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right in cash terms - consumer prices have gone up by about 14% over the same period. The 25% increase is for 'regulated' fares, which make up about half of all fares.

claims.text: £37 billion has been spent on NHS Test and Trace so far.

claimReview.title: NHS Test and Trace has not spent £37bn so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. £37 billion is the budget for the project’s first two years. We don’t know exactly how much was spent by early March, but it will be much less.

claims.text: The BBC made donations to the Conservative party.

claimReview.title: The BBC did not “donate” money to the Conservative party - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These weren’t donations, they were appearance fees paid to individual MPs. Many media outlets pay fees to politicians from across the political spectrum.

claims.text: While Boris Johnson was mayor, the murder rate fell.

claimReview.title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at homicides overall, rather than just murders. The homicide rate fell from roughly 21 per million people in 2007/08 to 13 per million in 2015/16.

claims.text: City of London police are warning people about a mobile network provider scam.

claimReview.title: City Of London Police are not warning people about this scam claiming to involve banks and mobile network providers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a real scam.

claims.text: A sign at a vaccine clinic urges parents to donate their children’s organs.

claimReview.title: Parents aren’t being urged to donate their children’s organs at vaccine appointments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true, and the picture being shared has been manipulated to change the text on the sign, which originally read “Covid vaccines here” in Spanish.

claims.text: London has the highest proportion of babies with at least one parent born outside the UK.

claimReview.title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. More babies born in London have at least one parent born outside the UK than anywhere else in England and Wales.

claims.text: There were no Covid-19 deaths in Ireland in August.

claimReview.title: People did die of Covid-19 in Ireland in August - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There were 14 confirmed Covid-19 deaths in Ireland in August.

claims.text: In Wales you cannot use your car to visit places other than shopping for essentials, helping someone who is shielding, or to work.

claimReview.title: It’s true that recent changes to lockdown rules are slightly different throughout the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are some of the main reasonable excuses for leaving the house according to Welsh law as of 11 May. There is nothing to say you cannot use a car to do these things.

claims.text: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla said he doesn’t need the vaccine because he’s healthy.

claimReview.title: Chris Preddie wrong about Pfizer CEO not taking Covid vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misquote from an interview from December. Albert Bourla said he didn’t want to take the vaccine ahead of more vulnerable recipients. He has since been double vaccinated.

claims.text: There are 10 times more staff dealing with benefits abuse than with tax evasion by the super-rich.

claimReview.title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber tax inspectors 10:1? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are more people working on benefit fraud, but not 10 times more. 3,765 staff currently work at the DWP investigating benefit fraud and error, compared to 700 at HMRC who focus on the wealthiest individuals. Over 26,000 people at HMRC work on all tax enforcement and compliance.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, EU courts have jurisdiction over the UK.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Nothing has changed on this compared to Theresa May’s withdrawal agreement, but the European Court of Justice would have jurisdiction on some rules in Northern Ireland.

claims.text: The government hasn’t delivered even a quarter of the childcare places they claimed they would.

claimReview.title: 30 hours free childcare: only a quarter of places delivered? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This would have been correct based on old government policy, but the number of planned places has been reduced since then. The latest figures show the government has delivered just over half of the places it expects to.

claims.text: 17.4 million people voted to leave and 16.1 million voted to remain in the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: £785 million was allocated to local council public health teams.

claimReview.title: Putting outsourced contact tracing spend in context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has given £785 million in grants to local authorities in England to support the Covid-19 response, which is expected to be mostly spent on contact tracing.

claims.text: Rishi Sunak said someone on an income of £24,000 pays income tax of £180.

claimReview.title: Viral tweet on Rishi Sunak’s tax claims got it wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Rishi Sunak was referring to the increase in national insurance someone on £24,000 would have to pay when he mentioned £180, not their total income tax bill.

claims.text: ONS data shows huge falls in non-Covid causes of death in December 2020.

claimReview.title: ONS death figures not averaged correctly - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data was wrong. It claimed to show a huge fall in 2020 against the previous five-year average. But that five-year “average” hadn’t in fact been divided by five, meaning it was five times too high.

claims.text: Being vegan for a year saves 1,000 square metres of forest.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear where these facts about veganism are from - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is unclear where this figure comes from.

claims.text: People knew about Covid-19 in 2018.

claimReview.title: Trade data doesn’t show we knew about Covid in 2018 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Confusion arose due to the fact that a trade export website changed the name of a number of medical diagnostic test exports to “COVID-19 Diagnostic Test”.

claims.text: The number of infants in large classes in Wales has increased by 18% over the last three years.

claimReview.title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Spending on disability benefits will be higher every year up to 2020 than it was in 2010.

claimReview.title: Disability benefits: spending on the rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in cash terms. Taking inflation into account, there will still be a rise in spending, although not in each consecutive year.

claims.text: The risks of myocarditis in children after vaccination are more serious and more prominent than post-Covid.

claimReview.title: Evidence suggests myocarditis risk after Covid-19 vaccination is lower compared to Covid infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Evidence suggests the risk of myocarditis is higher following Covid-19 infection and the clinical outcomes may be worse.

claims.text: PCR tests are useless.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 victims cannot be cremated against their wishes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. While the tests aren’t perfect, they are very accurate.

claims.text: In the last five years, we have seen literally hundreds of convicted rapists who have come out of prison commit another sexual offence.

claimReview.title: How many rapists reoffend? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It shows that each year, in England and Wales, roughly 40-60 people are convicted of rape who had previous rape convictions. From 2013 to 2017, there were 263 such convictions.

claims.text: Only half the UN's appeal for Syrian aid was funded last year.

claimReview.title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's about right—in 2015 the appeal received $4 billion (56%) out of the $7.2 billion it wanted.

claims.text: There are record numbers of young people going to university, including from disadvantaged backgrounds.
claims.claimant: Jo Johnson MP, Universities and Science Minister

claimReview.title: Are there record numbers of young people going to university? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Accurate based on numbers and rates of young people accepted onto full-time places at university in England. Advantaged students are still substantially more likely to go to university.

claims.text: No healthy child has died from Covid-19 in the UK.

claimReview.title: Daily Mail understates the risks of Covid-19 to children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Six under 18s with no underlying health conditions died from Covid-19 in England before the end of February 2021.

claims.text: No one who sat in a restaurant without a mask to eat their meal died.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence for how many people took part in ‘Eat Out To Help Out’ or later died from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to say that no one who took part in Eat Out to Help Out did not contract Covid-19 and later die.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, all gas, oil and minerals will become owned by the EU.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Individual governments decide who can mine and produce these products, and where. The licensing rules for oil and gas are decided by the EU, but the UK is keeping these in place in the case of a no deal Brexit.

claims.text: £20 a week is about two hours extra work every week for Universal Credit claimants.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit: Do politicians' claims about working more hours add up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only true in very specific circumstances, and does not mention the fact that many people who work and claim Universal Credit are affected by a 63% taper rate, which means they receive 37p for every pound they earn. It’s true that some people could make back the £20 a week by working two extra hours, but this can’t be applied to everyone.

claims.text: Nine out of the 11 judges who made the ruling on the suspension of parliament, receive stipends of £175,000+ from the EU.

claimReview.title: That claim you’ve seen about Supreme Court judges getting paid £175,000 by the EU is totally made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not the case. Two supreme court judges are ad hoc judges for the European Court of Human Rights, which is separate from the EU. Only one of the two has come to the court, and that has only been twice in the last four years. They get paid around £444 per day for this.

claims.text: 1% of the population owns 50% of the wealth of the country

claimReview.title: UK wealth: how much is owned by the 1%? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That seems likely to be an overestimate. It may be a reference to estimates for the whole world rather than just the UK.

claims.text: When we joined the EU, there were 9 member states.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were 9 member states when we joined.

claims.text: One third of those who have won a case against the UK at the European human right court were terrorists, criminals or prisoners.

claimReview.title: The human rights victories won by criminals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around half of successful cases involved someone convicted or suspected of a criminal offence at some point. The answer depends on how you define "criminal".

claims.text: Campaigners on both sides of the EU referendum made false claims.

claimReview.title: False claims, forecasts, and the EU Referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Sometimes they even made false claims about the false claims made by each other.

claims.text: Covid-19 nasal swabs contain nanobots.

claimReview.title: No evidence of ‘nanobots’ in Covid-19 test swabs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.

claims.text: The government's claim to have spent more on flood defence schemes misrepresents its record.

claimReview.title: The government defence on flood defences - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Funding for flood defences have increased overall, although it was originally set to fall. There do seem to have been cuts made in particular areas, such as staff at the Environment Agency.

claims.text: Elderly people were ‘culled’ in care homes, hospices and other places using a drug called midazolam.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is real and not a government euthanasia policy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People have died in care homes during the Covid-19 pandemic. While midazolam is often used in end of life care, there is no evidence to suggest that this has been used with the intention of killing people, or as part of a euthanasia policy.

claims.text: An image shows a World War Two veteran crying during a parade because he is the last survivor of his battle group.

claimReview.title: There is no evidence to say why this veteran is crying - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a picture of man taken during a military parade in Russia in 2007. His identity and the reason for his tears is unknown and has been the subject of much online debate.

claims.text: It is estimated that a single Google search could power a low-energy light bulb for an hour.

claimReview.title: How energy intensive is a Google search? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Google’s own estimate which is a decade old shows that the energy required to power a Google search could power a low energy (10 watt) light bulb for 108 seconds. Each search will vary slightly and Google searches may have become more efficient in the last decade.

claims.text: While western countries have been busy fighting the new coronavirus, international terrorism has stopped.

claimReview.title: It is not true that worldwide terrorism has stopped while western countries fight Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. There have been multiple terror attacks around the world in March and April this year, leaving hundreds of people dead.

claims.text: 19 million people in the UK have already been infected with the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: It is not clear that 19 million people have already had the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is according to a new piece of statistical research, but this research has been challenged by other scientists and is highly uncertain. Other early estimates have estimated the prevalence to be lower, but it’s impossible to tell how accurate these will turn out to be.

claims.text: The number of unlawfully large infant classes has fallen.

claimReview.title: Is the number of unlawfully large infant classes falling? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is accurate, but taking into account large infant classes counted as lawful (because of the circumstances in which extra pupils were admitted) the number that are large is growing.

claims.text: There is an order to incinerate or immediately bury Covid-19 bodies without autopsy.
