claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no such order.

claims.text: The main cause of breast cancer is the use of antiperspirant.

claimReview.title: The role of antiperspirant in causing breast cancer is not proven - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Cancer Research UK says that at present there’s no convincing evidence that using deodorants or antiperspirants affects breast cancer risk.

claims.text: Domestic abuse rates increase by 38% when England loses football matches.

claimReview.title: World Cup: does domestic abuse spike when England lose? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A 2014 study found the number of domestic abuse incidents reported to police in Lancashire increased by 38% when England lost a match compared to when they weren’t playing. It was 26% higher if England won or there was a draw.

claims.text: Half of British businesses are struggling to recruit the skilled labour they need.

claimReview.title: Are British businesses struggling with recruitment? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 52% of businesses surveyed by Lloyds Bank in June were struggling to recruit skilled labour, although we don't know the reasons why. We haven't been able to check the methods behind the survey directly.

claims.text: 400,000 people in the UK are living with long Covid.

claimReview.title: Evidence doesn’t show 400,000 people have long Covid ‘right now’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not accurate. This estimate is based on a small sample size, and assumes everyone who has ever had long Covid still does.

claims.text: The Covid-19 death rate as a percentage of the population is 0.0024%.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims on pre-existing conditions and Covid-19 deaths go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is not correct. The figure is calculated by dividing the number of deaths of those without pre-existing conditions by the whole population including those with existing conditions. 
This isn’t a “death rate” and shouldn’t be described as one. It excludes many people who have died outside hospitals. It’s also wrong to suggest that people with pre-existing conditions do not die of Covid-19, but just with it. Over 90% of people who die with Covid-19 have Covid-19 as an underlying cause of death.

claims.text: The living wage is £18,000 a year.

claimReview.title: Post comparing the living wage and pensions needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct for someone working full time.

claims.text: British citizens can make more than £7,000 a day by investing in oil through a specific scheme.

claimReview.title: Fake Mirror article about oil investors on Dragons’ Den looks suspicious - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is highly suspicious. The company mentioned in the article is not a registered business in the UK, the article is not a genuine Mirror article and the methods used in the post are similar to those used in scams in the past.

claims.text: PHE released a report revealing 62% of Covid-19 deaths are people who have been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated people sometimes die of Covid-19—but very rarely - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: PHE’s report suggests 61% of Covid-19 deaths with the Delta variant are in people who have received at least one vaccine dose. But this is not unexpected when no vaccine is 100% effective and so many vulnerable people have been vaccinated.

claims.text: You can receive no fine and a 12 month suspended sentence for possessing 10,000 indecent images of children.

claimReview.title: Punishments for not wearing face coverings, not social distancing and for possessing indecent images of children vary depending on the exact offence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t find a specific case this is referring to, but it is a possibility depending on the nature of the offences.

claims.text: There is grotesque inequality in the UK.

claimReview.title: What’s happening to inequality? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's up to you what you count as grotesque, and there are a lot of different ways to measure and illustrate inequality.

claims.text: Mass migration pushes down wages.

claimReview.title: Does "uncontrolled mass migration" push down wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: UK research suggests that immigration has a small impact on average wages of existing workers but more significant effects for certain groups: low-wage workers lose while medium and high-paid workers gain.

claims.text: Labour is pushing Theresa May for a UK-wide Customs Union.

claimReview.title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour says it wants to whole of the UK to be outside the EU customs union after Brexit, but in a new customs union with similar levels of access, and the ability to strike free trade deals. This, like the government’s Chequers proposal, is likely to be unpalatable to the EU. It’s hard to judge how feasible this would be as a negotiating position, but it seems to fall foul of the EU’s red lines.

claims.text: A post suggests that all Nando’s chicken in the UK is now halal.

claimReview.title: Not every Nando’s UK restaurant is halal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. Nando’s serves only halal chicken in 76 of its 434 UK branches. The ad shared in the post was from Nando’s in Singapore.

claims.text: A majority of the public is against extending the transition period between the UK and the EU.

claimReview.title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The poll found more people are opposed to extension than in favour of it, but less than 50% so it’s not a majority opinion. Many other recent polls have shown the opposite.

claims.text: Sir Alex Ferguson said the European Super League sells supporters “down the river”.

claimReview.title: Fake football quotes go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence Sir Alex said exactly this in relation to the Super League, although he has said the Super League represents a move away from 70 years of club football history.

claims.text: A government review warns it is almost as easy to buy some drugs as it is to buy pizza.

claimReview.title: There’s not enough evidence to say it’s as easy to buy drugs as pizza in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is not enough evidence for this claim, which does not appear in the review itself. The Global Drug Survey compared delivery times of cocaine and pizza internationally in 2018 and found 30% of people could get cocaine in under 30 minutes while only 16.5% of people said they could get a pizza delivered in that time. Figures to make this comparison for the UK aren’t available.

claims.text: An un-edited photo shows a skull-shaped cloud seen in California.

claimReview.title: That viral photo of a cloud that looks like a skull was taken from a heavy metal album cover - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image is fake and the skull comes from an Iron Maiden album cover.

claims.text: There is a two-year time limit for Brexit negotiations under Article 50, which the UK has no power to extend.

claimReview.title: Article 50: a two-year limit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The UK will be out of the EU two years after triggering Article 50, unless it reaches an agreement within that time or agrees with all other EU members to extend the negotiation period.

claims.text: The total number of deaths from Covid-19 in Italy rose from 233 to 4,032 over about two weeks.

claimReview.title: These numbers about Covid-19 deaths in the UK and Italy are broadly accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. As reported by the Italian government, the number of deaths from Covid-19 rose from 233 on 7 March to 4,032 on 20 March.

claims.text: There are 16,481 fewer beds in hospitals since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is in the right ballpark, but it doesn’t seem to be the best comparison. It seems to compare the number of beds at different times of the year, but the number available fluctuates seasonally. Comparing July-September in 2010 and 2017, the decrease in beds available overnight in England is closer to 13,200.

claims.text: Italy has concluded Covid-19 is not a virus, and people are actually dying of amplified global 5G electromagnetic radiation poisoning.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Covid-19 is caused by a virus, called SARS-CoV-2, not 5G.

claims.text: 5G isn’t safe.

claimReview.title: Mobile phone base stations like this do not pose a radiation risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t convincing evidence that this is the case.

claims.text: The UK gets a one-third reduction on the fee we pay for being in the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK gets a rebate on its EU budget contribution, which averaged 24% from 2013-2017. The EU has signalled that it proposes to scrap rebates (for all EU countries that receive one) over the next decade.

claims.text: The estimated cost of a no deal Brexit is £5.81 per person per day.

claimReview.title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to be based on an estimate of how much lower UK GDP could be in 2030 if we leave with no deal, compared to if we remained in the EU. This is a hypothetical model for comparing possible paths: it cannot be used to accurately predict the size of the economy in 2030, or to translate the “cost” of Brexit into a definitive cash sum.

claims.text: A man was arrested for putting down fake social distancing arrows in an Ikea to confuse customers.

claimReview.title: No-one was arrested for creating a labyrinth in Ikea using fake social distancing signs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The story is a joke and has been circulating in a similar form since 2018.

claims.text: A picture shows Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin shaking hands.

claimReview.title: This is a real photo of Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. He was the prime minister of Israel at the time, and it was taken during a visit to Downing Street in 1979.

claims.text: People who die of Covid would probably have died within a year.

claimReview.title: Lord Sumption made several errors about Covid on Today - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not supported by the evidence. Research suggests people who die of Covid lose about a decade of life, on average.

claims.text: Last year, Tory MPs promised, budgeted and voted into law a 2.1% pay rise for NHS staff.

claimReview.title: Clearing up the NHS pay debate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite right. Parliament passed a law which committed the government to providing a minimum level of funding for the NHS each year until 2023/24. But it didn’t specify how exactly that money would be spent.

claims.text: You should gargle as a prevention with salt in warm water.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence this will prevent or cure the virus.

claims.text: Ending tariffs means lower prices in shops and pubs.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not necessarily. The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates that a reduction in consumer prices from reducing tariffs would be wiped out by extra costs imposed by the UK leaving the EU customs union.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, only the backstop changed so all the other flaws of May's deal continue.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The biggest change was to the Irish backstop, but the non-binding political declaration changed too.

claims.text: A post suggests video footage showing a camera crew filming people in hazmat suits is evidence the pandemic is staged by the media.

claimReview.title: Video thanking Hungarian key workers doesn’t show pandemic is staged - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The footage was almost certainly taken of a film crew recording part of an advert where the Hungarian Prime Minister thanks key workers.

claims.text: The EU army will call up all 16 to 25 year olds to serve in an army for the European Union.

claimReview.title: UK citizens can’t be conscripted into an ‘EU army’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no EU army. There are no formal plans for an EU army. The UK has a veto on EU security and defence policy so couldn’t be forced to participate in an EU army.

claims.text: The Daily Mail front page on 11/11/2019 said “An official report finds that Boris Johnson’s Conservative party received donations from nine Russian donors with suspected links to the Kremlin. Does our Prime Minister choose to publsh [sic] it? No, Johnson PERSONALLY blocks publication of the report.”

claimReview.title: The Daily Mail front page did not call Boris Johnson a traitor - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a real front page.

claims.text: Knife crime is at record levels.

claimReview.title: Violent crime is not at record levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Police and hospital figures show knife crimes at or near their highest recorded levels. Knife crime is almost certainly rising at the moment, but no source is strong enough for us to be certain that it’s at record levels.

claims.text: US food standards allow for rat droppings in ginger.

claimReview.title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US food standards set limits above zero for rat droppings in ginger, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claims.text: The London Challenge for schools saw the most dramatic improvement in any major capital city anywhere in the world.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The London Challenge scheme did see an improvement in schools in the capital, but we don’t know of any way to benchmark this against schools in other major cities.

claims.text: For every gram of cocaine consumed, four square kilometres of rainforest are destroyed

claimReview.title: Are more young people taking cocaine? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is a typo from a claim made in 2008 which said 4 square metres not kilometres of rainforest are destroyed for every gram of cocaine. This estimate doesn’t appear to be true in 2016.

claims.text: Vaccine manufacturers are not liable for injuries or deaths caused by the vaccines.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True, mostly. In the UK, Covid-19 vaccine manufacturers are protected from much, but not all, civil liability that arises as a result of the vaccines.

claims.text: We built more homes in 2017 than in all but one of the last 30 years.

claimReview.title: There are 1.1 million more homes in England since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for the last 26 years, looking at the total number of homes added to the overall stock including things like conversions, minus demolitions. There were 217,000 homes added in 2016/17.

claims.text: 30,000 British pensioners freeze to death each year.

claimReview.title: There were 25,260 excess winter deaths across all ages in Great Britain last year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About 25,260 excess deaths occurred in GB over winter 2018/19—a lower number than in recent years—and most were in people of pension age. Cold weather is a major contributor to these deaths, but there are a number of causes.

claims.text: There was no “pandemic death rate” in 2020.

claimReview.title: False claims from funeral director about facemasks, vaccines and the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 73,766 deaths were registered as being due to Covid-19 from March to December 2020 in England and Wales.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines have caused 859,481 adverse reactions.

claimReview.title: Piers Corbyn makes misleading claims about vaccine deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Slightly fewer adverse reactions have been reported but it doesn’t mean they have been caused by the vaccine. The vast majority are normal and clear up within a few days.

claims.text: The flu kills up to 650,000 people worldwide each year.

claimReview.title: Estimates of 650,000 annual flu deaths can’t be compared to Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the WHO’s upper estimate of annual worldwide flu-related deaths, with a lower estimate of 290,000.

claims.text: Covid-19 can be cured by antibiotic tablets, anti-inflammatory and taking anticoagulants such as aspirin.

claimReview.title: Claims about Russia, Covid-19 and 5G are almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While the anti-inflammatory drug ibuprofen has been tested in Covid-19 patients and the anticoagulant heparin has been used to treat some patients, it is misleading to say they “cure” the disease. Antibiotics are not used to directly treat viruses and aspirin can be used as pain relief in adults but not as a cure for Covid-19.

claims.text: Within 72 hours Philadelphia’s hospitals were filled.

claimReview.title: The 1918 Philadelphia parade fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We know emergency hospitals opened in Philadelphia during this time suggesting the regular hospitals were working at, or close to capacity.

claims.text: The UK is short of skilled electricians, plasterers, joiners, chefs and nurses.

claimReview.title: What skills are we short of in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no simple definition of a shortage skilled profession in the UK, but nurses and chefs are on the official Shortage Occupation List, because they’re considered to need workers from overseas. The other professions mentioned aren’t currently on that list, but some employers still report difficulties in recruiting them, especially joiners.

claims.text: Over 26 million workers are entitled to paid leave because of the EU, so there are almost 750 million days of paid holiday taken.

claimReview.title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s the correct number of employees in the UK, but multiplying them by the number of paid holidays they’re entitled to doesn’t work and doesn’t produce a number that the EU alone can take credit for.

claims.text: Between 13,000 and 125,000 operations will be cancelled as a result of upcoming junior doctors’ strikes.

claimReview.title: Are 125,000 operations predicted to be cancelled? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The current estimate is 125,000 operations cancelled, this figure is based on the number of operations which were cancelled over two days during the last strike in April. However, these figures were calculated before the specific dates were announced and before the September strike was suspended

claims.text: Just 748.6 people per 100,000 died in England in May.

claimReview.title: Telegraph suggests 9% of England dies each year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. If May’s death rate was replicated over the course of a year, then 748.6 people per 100,000 would die. But about a twelfth as many people died in May alone.

claims.text: A memo from Imperial College London sets out plans for a permanent lockdown of the UK.

claimReview.title: Fake memo circulating claiming to be from Imperial College - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The memo is a fake.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets free use of a gym.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The gym is not free for MPs, who have to pay between £25 and £35 a month for membership.

claims.text: It was this Conservative government that tackled the deficit.

claimReview.title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The deficit (how much the government borrows each year) fell from £158 billion (or 10% of GDP) in 2009/10 to £41 billion (2% of GDP) in 2018/19.

claims.text: The official Leave campaign is getting a similar amount of money as the Remain campaign.

claimReview.title: Who’s getting taxpayers’ money in the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is spending an estimated £9 million sending pro-Remain leaflets to all UK households. This is on top of what the official campaign groups on either side of the debate will get in public money, which includes a free mailout.

claims.text: Four times as many black people are being detained as white people.

claimReview.title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you're black, you're about four times as likely to be detained than if you're white. Overall, more white people are detained, since they make up a larger portion of the population.

claims.text: Pregnant women are 22 times more likely to die from Covid-19 than other women.

claimReview.title: The Express muddles up the dangers of Covid-19 in pregnancy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This muddles the results of a study, which in fact found that Covid increases the risk of death in women who are pregnant.

claims.text: This year alone, MPs have cost the British taxpayer £92,993,748 in expenses.

claimReview.title: This post about MPs is untrue and around 20 years old - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In 2017/18 MPs’ expenses totalled £35 million. The total cost of MPs’ and MPs’ staff pay and expenses that year came to £182 million.

claims.text: You cannot have more than one person in a car unless in an emergency.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. No guidance on car passengers has been issued although you are meant to keep 2m from people not in your household.

claims.text: Japan has dropped Covid-19 vaccine mandates.

claimReview.title: Japan has never enforced a Covid-19 vaccine mandate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Japan never enforced a Covid-19 vaccine mandate. Its government websites clearly state vaccination is encouraged but optional.

claims.text: Hydroxychloroquine is used to treat radiation sickness.

claimReview.title: Hydroxychloroquine is not used as a treatment for radiation sickness - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The medicines regulator in the UK says the drug is not used for this.

claims.text: The WTO has 625 staff.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It was 627 at the end of 2018.

claims.text: The ONS have estimated that the restrictions across 2020 will have resulted in 200,000 non-Covid excess deaths.

claimReview.title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The ONS and other public bodies estimated there may be 12,500 non-Covid early deaths due to delays in treatment in the long term. The 200,000 figure was from an earlier estimate.

claims.text: The increase in the number number of talking therapies staff is closer to 3,000 than 2,700.

claimReview.title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One estimate says at least 2,850 more people worked in IAPT services (a flagship talking therapy programme for those with anxiety and depression) from August 2012 to April 2015. This does not include other NHS talking therapies.

claims.text: Newly qualified NHS nurses, paramedics, midwives, radiographers, care assistants, physiotherapists and occupational therapists are considered unskilled workers under a new set of immigration rules.

claimReview.title: Most of these NHS jobs are classed as “skilled” under new immigration rules - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. All of the listed jobs apart from care assistants meet the skills threshold under new immigration rules.

claims.text: Stronger leadership on the world stage — shaping our future by sitting at the top table

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on global influence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK already sits on many international “top tables” individually, as do representatives of the EU as a whole.

claims.text: Matt Hancock said there would be 25000 tests a day by mid-April. We’re currently at under 15,000 as of yesterday, so we’re missing that target. He said 100,000 by the end of April.

claimReview.title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Feeding bread to ducks is safe and doesn't make them sick.

claimReview.title: Poster claiming bread is healthy for ducks gets its facts in a flap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Many wildlife charities say bread should only be fed to ducks in small amounts. It should form part of a much wider, nutrient-rich diet and is less important during spring and summer.

claims.text: A £22 billion Test and Trace contract was given to a company which has been prosecuted twice by the Serious Fraud Office.

claimReview.title: Test and Trace money didn’t all go to one company - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £22 billion was the entire budget for Test and Trace during 2020/21, of which around £13.5 billion was spent. The money went to a range of public and private organisations, not just one company.

claims.text: Costa Coffee is demanding customers show proof of medical status before you can sit in.

claimReview.title: Costa sign demanding vaccine proof to sit in wasn’t taken in UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A photo shows a sign outside a Costa Coffee in Ireland explaining that adults who want to dine indoors need to show proof of full vaccination or that they have recovered from Covid-19 in the last six months. These are the rules for indoor dining in Ireland.

claims.text: Young people could save up to £1,000 a year in bus fares under Labour’s plans for free bus travel for the under 25s.

claimReview.title: Would free bus travel save young people £1,000 a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Assuming they took 520 bus journeys a year (a national travel survey says that figure is 101 for under 21s), and the bus fare is around £2, they could save £1,000.

claims.text: 400,000 more people are employed in the UK since the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: More people are in work since the Brexit vote - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Employment has increased by around 450,000 since May to July 2016.

claims.text: The number of deaths in the UK from Covid-19 is just shy of the capacity of the Manchester arena.

claimReview.title: Figure comparing arena capacity to Covid-19 deaths needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of people who died in hospital in the UK having tested positive for Covid-19, by 25 April, is around the same as the capacity of Manchester arena: about 21,000.

claims.text: State expenditure is at a record high.

claimReview.title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The amount of money spent by the state is the highest it’s ever been in real and cash terms. But is not at a record high when compared to the size of the economy—the most useful measure.

claims.text: The survival rate from Covid-19 is 99.8%.

claimReview.title: This Morning guest makes misleading claims on vaccine efficacy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s almost certainly not as high as that in the UK.

claims.text: There were 2.7 million more patients every year using good and outstanding hospitals at the end of Jeremy Hunt’s tenure as Health Secretary than at the beginning.

claimReview.title: Are three million more patients using good or outstanding hospitals? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is how many more admissions there were in 2017/18 to hospital trusts that had improved their rating to good or outstanding (between 2013 and 2019) than admissions to trusts that had dropped their rating to requires improvement or inadequate.

claims.text: Lockdowns will end when healthy people stop getting tested.

claimReview.title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People not getting tested will not stop lockdowns from happening. The number of tests, positive cases and things like test positivity are all used to measure the outbreak. A lack of testing might lead to an extended pandemic.

claims.text: Doctor patient confidentiality no longer exists.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Doctors can tell the authorities if they suspect you have a notifiable infectious disease.

claims.text: The EU currently represents 15% of the world's economy and it’s forecast to go down to 12% by 2030.

claimReview.title: Is the EU becoming less important to the world economy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no single estimate, but two separate IMF figures say the EU’s share (including the UK) of the global economy is around either 16% or 22% in 2017. That share has been decreasing and is expected to continue doing so. One estimate for 2030 says it could fall to around 12% (assuming the UK is no longer part of the EU).

claims.text: MPs get free iPads.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs are able to loan an iPad from the House of Commons. They can also claim computing expenses for their constituency office on expenses.

claims.text: Homeopathic nosodes could help with vaccine side effects.

claimReview.title: No evidence homeopathic nosodes can help side effects from vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to indicate that this is true. A 2010 House of Commons Science and Technology Committee report on homeopathy said that homeopathic remedies perform no better than placebos.

claims.text: £72 million is going towards specific areas of the country, including Scarborough, to help improve the quality of education.

claimReview.title: Is social mobility in England still all about the North/South divide? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The “Opportunity Areas” programme will provide £72 million for 12 areas of the country ranked low for social mobility. North Yorkshire, including Scarborough, will seek to improve early years education, maths and literacy skills and secondary school places through the programme.

claims.text: Housing Benefit spending has risen by £4 billion.

claimReview.title: Spending on Housing Benefit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The rise was £4.3 billion between 2009/10 and 2014/15 according to the Department for Work and Pensions, or £2.3 billion adjusted for inflation.

claims.text: Asymptomatic transmission is quackery.

claimReview.title: Soft drinks shouldn’t be ‘tested’ with lateral flow tests and asymptomatic transmission is not ‘quackery’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Asymptomatic transmission of Covid-19 has been shown to be an important factor in how  Covid-19 can spread.

claims.text: A photo of a lorry which fell into Bristol harbour, backside first, demonstrates why the government should not have taken reversing out of the HGV driving test.

claimReview.title: Photo of lorry stuck in Bristol harbour used to spread misinformation about HGV tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government hasn’t taken reversing out of the test. It was recently announced that a third party will carry out parts of the test, including reversing,  for certain types of vehicles, instead of the DVSA. The photo of the lorry is from a genuine incident in Bristol.

claims.text: The vaccination programme has overwhelmed the NHS.

claimReview.title: No evidence Covid-19 vaccines are 'overwhelming' NHS services - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have seen no evidence to suggest this is the case. Both the Royal College of GPs and NHS Providers say the concerns in the article have not been reflected by their members, although they are dealing with significant operational pressures for other reasons.

claims.text: Young British people would be called up to serve in an EU army.

claimReview.title: UK citizens can’t be conscripted into an ‘EU army’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU has no formal plans for an EU army, or for military conscription. The UK has a veto on EU security and defence policy so couldn’t be forced to participate in an EU army.

claims.text: Some charities are spending less than half of the money raised by members of the public on good works.

claimReview.title: How much are charities spending on good works? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Looking at the ratio of charitable spending on total income doesn't tell us about how well-run a charity is. Charities sometimes have to spend money to make money, and may choose not to spend all of their income at once.

claims.text: A leaked letter shows the government has a deliberate plan to damage the economy with the help of a public health campaign.

claimReview.title: Fake letter from Cabinet Office spreads on social media - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The letter is fake.

claims.text: Pictures show Boris Johnson has received a Covid-19 vaccine three times.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson hasn’t had three Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. One of the pictures shows the Prime Minister receiving an annual flu vaccine.

claims.text: The food and drinks industry say they face significant disruption and economic damage if EU nationals continue to leave the UK.

claimReview.title: The food and drinks industry after the EU referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK's Food and Drink Federation has warned of this disruption, although we don’t know yet how many EU nationals in the industry will end up leaving the UK.

claims.text: The UK’s police commissioner said that police have no power to enforce rules on people wearing masks in shops.

claimReview.title: Police do have legal powers to enforce face covering laws - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no “UK police commissioner”. One police group has said the new rules will be difficult to enforce in practice, but not that they have no legal power to enforce them. Police do have these powers.

claims.text: A report shows the poorest 10% of households gained around 13% in their incomes due to tax and benefit changes under Labour, while the richest lost almost 9%.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Mask-wearing cuts Covid incidence by 53%, says global study.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t show masks cause 53% drop in Covid risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t what the study says. The study says that mask-wearing was “associated with” a reduction in risk, but that, due to the limitations of the research, “it was difficult for our review to draw a one directional or causal conclusion.”

claims.text: Promises of investment in Wales for electrification and a tidal lagoon have now been withdrawn.

claimReview.title: Electric railways and tidal lagoons: has Wales lost out? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The planned electrification of the Great Western main line between Swansea and Cardiff has been cancelled, as has a planned tidal lagoon in Swansea Bay.

claims.text: Not a single one of the four nominees to key EU positions was voted on by MEPs.

claimReview.title: Do MEPs get to vote for the new President of the European Commission? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MEPs don’t nominate any of the four candidates, but two of the roles (President of the European Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs) do still need to be approved by MEPs and they are consulted on a third.

claims.text: People who were undergoing chemotherapy have been told that they should not receive vaccines, and should stay away from people who had received vaccines, and now because of Covid-19 this has all changed.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccines have not only been tested on healthy people as claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People who are immunosuppressed are advised not to have live vaccinations and not to be in close contact with people who have received certain live vaccinations, but the Covid-19 vaccines in use in the UK are not live vaccines and people undergoing chemotherapy have been prioritised to receive them.

claims.text: Red Bull and Monster energy drinks contain bull semen.

claimReview.title: Red Bull and Monster don’t contain bull semen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. They contain taurine, which is present in bull semen, but the drinks use synthetically produced taurine.

claims.text: There will be no cap on the amount people pay towards their social care under the Conservatives’ plans.

claimReview.title: What might people have to pay for their social care? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct at the time. Plans announced in the Conservative manifesto included no limit to the amount people pay for adult social care, although councils will pay when people have less than £100,000 left. However, since then the Prime Minister has said there will be a cap on the amount people will have to pay.

claims.text: When the five new countries in the process of joining the EU join, they will have the same rights as other members.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They would end up with the same rights. There might be some restrictions on workers from new countries at first.

claims.text: Wuhan is where 5G was rolled out first.

claimReview.title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wuhan was one of the first places with 5G trials, as well as several other large Chinese cities, like Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou but we don’t know if it was the first.

claims.text: Many migrants contribute to society.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Studies suggest recently-arrived EU immigrants contribute more to the public finances than they receive, although the effect is small.

claims.text: The UK unemployment rate is about half the Eurozone average.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have lower unemployment than the Eurozone? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The UK rate is 4.4% compared to the Eurozone average of 9.1%, using the latest comparable figures for April to June 2017. Some countries like Germany still have lower rates.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine trials have not yet been completed and therefore the results cannot be peer-reviewed.

claimReview.title: Results of Covid-19 vaccine trials have been published and peer-reviewed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Covid-19 vaccine trials have been published in peer reviewed journals. The data collection and analysis are ongoing, in order to allow up to two years of follow up on participants.

claims.text: A picture shows private jets in a Scottish airport for COP26.

claimReview.title: Picture of parked up private jets isn’t from COP26 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture first appeared online in 2013 and seems to have been taken of jets parked in a New Orleans airport when the Super Bowl was held there.

claims.text: 10,000 jobs have already moved out of the financial services sector following the EU referendum vote.

claimReview.title: 10,000 finance jobs lost since Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence for this. A survey predicts 10,000 jobs might be moved from the UK if we leave the single market. We don’t know what kind of Brexit deal will be made and the survey has additional limitations.

claims.text: Three million people work in local counties and boroughs.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Two million people were recorded as working in local government across the UK in September 2019.

claims.text: The European Union makes two thirds of UK law.

claimReview.title: Is two thirds of UK law made by the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's about right if you count EU regulations as part of 'UK law'. The EU influence on UK-only laws is about 13%. But this counting exercise doesn't tell us very much.

claims.text: The head of the EU law enforcement agency says that 5,000 terrorists have come into the EU because of its migration policy.

claimReview.title: Have 5,000 jihadis come into the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Rob Wainwright denies that he said any such thing. Europol’s official position is that up to 5,000 EU citizens may have been radicalised and travelled to fight in the Middle East, but perhaps a third of those have returned to Europe, of which a majority aren’t considered a threat.

claims.text: 54% of hospital trusts are good or outstanding.

claimReview.title: Hospitals: safety versus quality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 56% of core hospital services were rated good or outstanding as of July 2016. That falls to 32% when you look at the individual ratings for acute trusts and all services provided by them. We’re checking with the Department of Health which figures the Prime Minister was referring to.

claims.text: In 2017 Labour said a 2.2% increase in NHS funding would make it the envy of the world.

claimReview.title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour’s 2017 manifesto pledged roughly 2.2% annual funding increases for the NHS in England for the rest of the decade. In the same manifesto they said they wanted to “restore the NHS to its place as the envy of the world”. They didn’t directly connect this to their specific pledges.

claims.text: A video claims there is a space in instant noodle cups.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This space is designed by manufacturers to assist with the transportation and cooking of the noodles.

claims.text: The vast majority of the public strongly objects to the government’s plan to pay £39 billion to Brussels.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A poll found that 75% of respondents said paying an EU exit fee of up to £40 billion was unacceptable. But responses to these questions depend on how the question is framed.

claims.text: Covid-19 is a flu and nothing more.

claimReview.title: Results of Covid-19 vaccine trials have been published and peer-reviewed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Covid-19 has killed more people than flu in a given season and is caused by a different organism.

claims.text: Three people have been killed and 127 injured in a plane crash at Gatwick Airport on Wednesday.

claimReview.title: Instagram post falsely claims there was a plane crash at Gatwick Airport - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This has not happened.

claims.text: Covid-19 is no more dangerous than seasonal flu.

claimReview.title: Luminescent enzymes not in Covid-19 vaccine and other myths debunked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Covid-19 has killed far more people than seasonal flu does over a similar period.

claims.text: National Child Mortality Database identified deaths in under 18s increased dramatically in the first lockdown.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The NCMD said there had been a slight increase but the numbers were too small to draw definite conclusions.

claims.text: The UK could pay £500 million more per week for drugs following a post-Brexit trade deal with the USA.

claimReview.title: Paying £500 million more a week for drugs post-Brexit is based on a fairly extreme scenario - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s certainly possible that drug prices could increase following a trade deal as this fits with US priorities from past negotiations. But the £500 million figure is a rough calculation based on a scenario that the Nuffield Trust has said is fairly extreme.

claims.text: The Royal College of Nursing (RCN) has told nurses not to use the term “ladies” or “lady.”

claimReview.title: The Royal College of Nursing hasn’t told nurses to call women by gender-neutral terms - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The RCN internal style guide recommended using “women” or “woman” instead of “ladies” or “lady” in written documentation.  This was not guidance to nurses on how to speak to patients.

claims.text: Thirty-two deaths from the swine flu vaccine in 1976 halted the programme.

claimReview.title: Comparisons between deaths reported after swine flu and Covid-19 vaccines are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Full Fact could not find a confirmed number of deaths reported after a swine flu vaccine in 1976, but reports suggest that a number of the deaths could not be directly linked with the vaccine. The rollout was halted because of a number of reports of Guillain-Barré syndrome, and the fact the swine flu cases never reached pandemic levels.

claims.text: EU law means that the UK will be covered by human rights laws even if we scrap the Human Rights Act.

claimReview.title: Does dropping human rights laws require leaving the EU too? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The EU now has a stand-alone system of human rights law, which would remain in place even if we scrapped the older, separate system set up by the Human Rights Act and European Convention on Human Rights.

claims.text: Due to changes in validity since leaving the EU, your passport is now only valid for 10 years from the issue date on your passport.

claimReview.title: Why the government recommends having 6 months left on passports to visit Europe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the case when travelling to many European countries. Other countries have different passport requirements.

claims.text: The WTO’s founding principle is to ensure that free trade flows as smoothly, predictably and freely as possible.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Its founding and guiding principles “remain the pursuit of open borders, the guarantee of most-favoured-nation principle and non-discriminatory treatment by and among members, and a commitment to transparency in the conduct of its activities.”

claims.text: China has closed down its last coronavirus hospital. Not enough new cases to support them.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The last hospitals closed at the start of March 2020.

claims.text: UK sick pay is 28 weeks. The EU does not set a minimum sick pay.

claimReview.title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Child poverty and pensioner poverty are up since 2010.

claimReview.title: Is child and pensioner poverty rising? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Relative poverty has increased or stayed flat among children and pensioners, depending on how you measure it, but absolute poverty has fallen in some cases. We’ve asked the Department for Work and Pensions whether any of these changes are statistically significant.

claims.text: The government’s Social Mobility Commission concluded there are 600,000 more children living in relative poverty than in 2012.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct - this refers to the number of children living in low income households as defined by the government.

claims.text: One in four of the most disadvantaged children leave primary school obese, twice the rate for the most advantaged.

claimReview.title: Are disadvantaged children twice as likely to be obese? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right. Of year 6 pupils who go to school in the most deprived tenth of areas, 25% are classed as obese, compared to 13% for children in the least deprived tenth.

claims.text: People with no recourse to public funds are not yet able to claim free school meal vouchers.

claimReview.title: Some children with no recourse to public funds are eligible for free school meals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has extended free school meal eligibility in England to some but not all people with no recourse to public funds, temporarily, during the pandemic.

claims.text: The National Crime Agency says that one in 35 UK men have a sexual interest in children.

claimReview.title: How many men have a sexual interest in children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The National Crime Agency told us this estimate came from “various pieces of academic research” but it wasn’t able to point us directly to a specific piece. The estimates that we’ve seen are very uncertain and—whatever the exact figure—experts on the topic stressed to us that thoughts often don’t turn into actions.

claims.text: We just had two years (2016-2018) of record-breaking Global Cooling.

claimReview.title: No, we are not experiencing “global cooling” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. “Global cooling” describes a long term period during which the earth’s average temperature is cooling. Although the average global temperature was slightly lower in 2017 and 2018 than in 2016, these drops were not record breaking. Global temperatures tend to fluctuate from one year to the next and NASA data shows that overall global warming is occurring: the planet is getting hotter and hotter over time, and at a faster and faster pace.

claims.text: The Universal Credit helpline costs 55p per minute.

claimReview.title: How much does the Universal Credit helpline cost? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was roughly the maximum amount someone could be charged for a call from their mobile. The government has now announced that the helpline will be made a freephone number.

claims.text: Bacterial pneumonia is caused by people wearing masks and is massively on the rise.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that wearing a mask can cause bacterial pneumonia, or that deaths from pneumonia have increased.

claims.text: The Chief Medical Officer, Chris Whitty, plans for the current rate of Covid-19 infections and deaths to continue.

claimReview.title: Independent SAGE’s estimated death rate is too high - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misunderstanding of what Professor Whitty said. He was talking about hygiene rules continuing, not levels of infection staying the same.

claims.text: A coronavirus vaccine for cows shows that the virus behind the current outbreak is not new.

claimReview.title: This is not a vaccine for the 2019 coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a different coronavirus from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes Covid-19. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses that can affect a range of species.

claims.text: Asylum seekers may see a doctor or get hospital treatment for free, and free prescriptions for medicine, free eye tests and free glasses.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Asylum seekers aren’t charged for GP visits, hospital treatment, or prescriptions. They may be eligible for free eye tests and vouchers for glasses.

claims.text: Children should not return to school after a positive lateral flow test, even if they receive a negative follow-up PCR test result.

claimReview.title: What happens when pupils test positive for Covid-19? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not what the guidance for testing states. Pupils should only have a follow-up PCR test if they get a positive lateral flow result at home. If the follow-up comes back negative they can go back to school.

claims.text: The NHS has warned people should not shake hands to prevent the spread of the Wuhan coronavirus

claimReview.title: The NHS hasn’t advised people to stop shaking hands to avoid the Wuhan coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Although some doctors have suggested this may be a good idea, no advice around shaking hands has been issued by the government

claims.text: Contact tracers have been told not to trace contacts of Covid-19 cases connected to educational settings.

claimReview.title: Contact tracing has not stopped in schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Contact tracers have been told to not escalate these cases to local health teams, but their contacts will still be traced nationally.

claims.text: An estimated 1 million people marched for a People’s Vote on Saturday 23rd March.

claimReview.title: There almost certainly weren’t a million people on the People’s Vote march - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s impossible to say with precision how many people attended the march. However experts in crowd estimation put the number at between 312,000 and 400,000.

claims.text: Supermarket prices for bacon have gone up, partly because of the UK’s vote to leave the EU.

claimReview.title: What have bacon butties got to do with Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Wholesale prices for bacon products have risen in the past few months, partly due to a fall in the exchange rate after the UK voted to leave the EU. But the price paid in shops has fallen this year.

claims.text: Health tourism costs 0.3% of NHS spending.

claimReview.title: Health tourism: what's the cost? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s estimate of how much "deliberate health tourism" and those taking advantage of free NHS services cost the NHS every year was around 0.3% of NHS spending allocated to specific services in 2012/13. It’s still roughly around 0.3% of total health spending.

claims.text: Labour did not triple tuition fees.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner is wrong on tuition fees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Labour tripled fees from £1,000 per year to £3,000 per year in 2006 in England and Northern Ireland and in Wales the following year.

claims.text: The prime minister’s Chequers deal is more unpopular than the Poll Tax.

claimReview.title: Is the Chequers deal on Brexit more unpopular than the Poll Tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. Recent polling suggests that the Chequers deal is supported by fewer people than the Poll Tax was at its least popular, but fewer people also oppose it outright.

claims.text: The Conservatives have found homes for the 8.8 million immigrants, illegal immigrants, and asylum seekers living here.

claimReview.title: This viral image on immigration and homelessness has a fundamental flaw - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UN estimates that there were 8.8 million people in the UK in 2017 who were not born here, but that doesn’t mean the government has found homes for them.

claims.text: All seven patients who were getting treated for Covid-19 at Safdarjung hospital in New Delhi have recovered.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is a news story reporting that seven patients in this hospital in New Delhi had recovered. However, these were not the only Covid-19 patients in the city.

claims.text: Since the mid-1990s the incomes of people in their twenties have gone up by 20%.

claimReview.title: How much more difficult is it to buy a home? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Median weekly earnings for all employees aged 22-29 increased by 14% from 1997 to 2018 in real terms. If you don’t adjust for inflation—which is more appropriate when comparing to changes in house prices over the same period—the increase is 72%.

claims.text: Public satisfaction with the NHS is higher after seven years of Conservative government than after the first five years of the last Labour government.

claimReview.title: Public satisfaction with the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that NHS satisfaction was higher in 2015 than 2002. Satisfaction went up significantly during the whole length of Labour’s last stint in power between 1997 and 2010, and has levelled off since the Conservatives entered office.

claims.text: The Pirbright Institute was responsible for foot and mouth.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A pipe connected to the Pirbright Insitute’s Surrey facility was found to be the likely source of a 2007 foot and mouth outbreak.

claims.text: A pilot scheme where people had to show ID before voting was a success.

claimReview.title: Has the government’s voter ID scheme been a success? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The scheme was piloted in five councils in May 2018, and the government said it was a “success”, as the “overwhelming majority” of voters had the right documents. Around twice as many people were blocked from voting in this pilot than there have been cases of voter fraud from 2010 to 2017 in the UK.

claims.text: Nebulized hydrogen peroxide “helps against ALL respiratory infections like colds/flu, sore throat, pneumonia, chest infections”.

claimReview.title: Nebulised hydrogen peroxide shouldn’t be used to treat all respiratory illnesses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA told Full Fact that it was not aware of any evidence that shows that inhalation of hydrogen peroxide would be effective in treating respiratory disease, and has “significant concerns” that this practice is not safe.

claims.text: The gender pay gap is lower than it's ever been before.

claimReview.title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. The pay gap is at a record low for full-time employees and for employees overall.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines put people who have received them in danger if 5G is ‘cranked up’.

claimReview.title: There is no graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this claim.

claims.text: The Department of Health and Social Care gave private firms a record £9.2 billion in 2018.

claimReview.title: Was a record amount spent on private providers by the Department of Health? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The department spent £9.2 billion on purchasing health care from private providers in 2018/19. That’s a record amount of spending in cash terms, but not in real terms or as a proportion of the department’s budget.

claims.text: At the 2019 Labour conference, the union flag was banned.

claimReview.title: These claims about the 2019 Labour conference are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence this happened.

claims.text: Pensioners only receive £8,000 a year and still have to pay for a TV license.

claimReview.title: Post comparing the living wage and pensions needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The amount pensioners receive varies depending on a number of factors. Over 75s do now have to pay for a TV license, with some exceptions.

claims.text: South Africa has not vaccinated its elderly due to a lack of data.

claimReview.title: Letter to MHRA is filled with false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this is the case, at least with regard to data about the vaccines. South Africa is due to start vaccinating the elderly this month.

claims.text: One in 10 children aged between five and 16 have a mental health problem.

claimReview.title: How many children have mental health disorders? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct according to a survey conducted in 2004. More up-to-date research is due to be published in 2018.

claims.text: In the United States there are acceptable levels of rat hair in paprika and maggots in orange juice.

claimReview.title: The USA doesn’t “allow” maggots in orange juice—it sets levels at which enforcement is mandatory - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The US Food and Drug Administration sets levels of natural contaminants in food (like maggots in orange juice) above which it takes automatic enforcement action.

claims.text: The Bank of England governor says that post-Brexit trade deals could lead to “a golden age of trade”.

claimReview.title: Mark Carney didn’t say Brexit could usher in “a golden age of trade” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Carney’s speech yesterday did not use these words. It did discuss both opportunities and risks from Brexit, but to describe his comments as suggesting a “golden age of trade” is misleading.

claims.text: The vaccines won’t stop me getting Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They most likely will. All the vaccines available are highly effective at preventing Covid-19 development.

claims.text: Fluoride calcifies the pineal gland.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The pineal gland can take on calcium deposits over time and fluoride can attach to calcium.  Studies on the effects of fluoride on the pineal gland have proved inconclusive.

claims.text: The oil and gas industry supports more than 400,000 jobs.

claimReview.title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over 400,000 was an older estimate. These figures are uncertain, and don't just include people directly employed by the industry.

claims.text: Today's budget increases total departmental spending over this Parliament by £150 billion. That’s the largest increase this century, with spending growing by 3.8% a year in real terms.

claimReview.title: Was the Chancellor right on the Budget increasing departmental spending by the most this century? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Departmental budgets (which cover about half of all public spending) are forecast to increase by more over this parliament, in real terms, than any other parliament this century. But they increased more on average each year during the 2001-2005 parliament.

claims.text: The government has introduced new rules allowing passengers to claim compensation if a train is delayed by 15 minutes.

claimReview.title: Rail delay compensation: what’s new? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The scheme will be introduced on some rail services from 11 December and the government has said it will become a requirement for all rail franchises.

claims.text: Tax on Scottish whisky amounts to £20 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Scottish taxes don’t subsidise English spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. A reliable figure for this isn’t available, but the economic output of the entire industry is far less than this.

claims.text: The Greek letter 'Delta' is pyramid shaped and the Phoenician letter for 'Omicron' is 'Ayin, the symbol for which just happens to be an eye. Putting these together creates the ‘Eye of Providence’, a symbol of the Illuminati.

claimReview.title: Why conspiracists are linking the Omicron variant to the Illuminati - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Greek letter Delta is pyramid shaped. The Phoenician alphabet equivalent for Omicron is, like Omicron, a circle, but does derive from an older letter shaped like an eye. The Illuminati isn’t real.

claims.text: From 21 July to 25 July, 12 people died from Covid-19 in Spain.

claimReview.title: You were more likely to catch Covid-19 in Spain than the UK in late July. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. Around 10 people in Spain died after testing positive with Covid-19, so this figure will miss out some Covid-19 deaths.Correct.

claims.text: Black Caribbean students are three times more likely to be permanently excluded than other children.

claimReview.title: Black Caribbean pupils three times more likely to be excluded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, although gypsy/Roma students and travellers of Irish heritage were most likely to be excluded.

claims.text: A picture shows a woman holding a protest sign saying “stop killing volcanoes to make lava lamps”, from the People’s Vote march.

claimReview.title: This isn’t a real sign at a protest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture has been edited. The sign originally said “I’m not very happy about this” and the picture was taken in 2011.

claims.text: The NHS is free for all 500 million EU citizens.

claimReview.title: Which NHS treatments are free for EU citizens? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People normally need to be “ordinarily resident” in the UK get free healthcare, and EU visitors are entitled to free NHS treatment for unplanned illnesses. Similarly UK citizens are entitled to free (or discounted) state healthcare when visiting other EU countries.

claims.text: One million people are in the armed forces.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are around 193,000 UK armed forces personnel, of which 132,000 are full-time trained personnel.

claims.text: A World Health Organisation representative said that as long as people eat meat, there is going to be some risk of infection.

claimReview.title: Animals and the origins of the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Dr Gauden Galea, the WHO representative in China, did say this. It was aired by CNN during a news story about the role of wild animals in the new coronavirus outbreak.

claims.text: The Conservatives are planning to sell off NHS property by implementing the Naylor Review.

claimReview.title: Naylor Review: will the Conservatives sell NHS property to developers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Naylor Review is about how efficiently the NHS uses its land and property. It says some should be sold to fund improvements to the rest. The Conservatives are backing the review's proposals.

claims.text: Government investment in flood defences will be £2.3 billion in the next six years, higher than in previous parliaments.

claimReview.title: Flood defences: what's happening to funding? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over the next five years capital spending on flood defences will be £1.9 billion, which is a fairer way to compare spending with previous parliaments. Either way, it's an above-inflation increase compared to the previous two parliaments.

claims.text: In 2008, US children got 36 vaccines and the autism rate was 1 in 150.

claimReview.title: Autism prevalence is up but scientists have consistently found that vaccines don’t cause it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US children were recommended to get around 13 vaccines, which involved about 39 doses, in 2008. It was estimated that about 1 in 88 children has autism disorders.

claims.text: One offender carried out 93 crimes last year before going to jail for the first time.

claimReview.title: Context is needed in this article about offences committed prior to prison sentences - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One person sent to prison for the first time had 93 offences recorded, however there is no data on the time period these offences were committed over. One conviction may include several offences.

claims.text: There’s £460m extra funding for the police this year, including the local precept.

claimReview.title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, there’s an extra £460m in cash terms for police in England and Wales. The majority of that rise comes from about £280 million raised in council tax, rather than central government.

claims.text: The percentage of the UK population who have received a booster vaccine is double that of any other European country.

claimReview.title: UK booster roll out level twice the EU average - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. As of 12-14 December, 35% of the UK population had received a booster, below Iceland (54%) and only just ahead of Austria and Hungary.

claims.text: Tax credits originally cost £1.1bn. Now they've reached £30bn.

claimReview.title: Tax credits: how much has spending increased in 16 years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure only covers half a year, when the first tax credits were introduced in 1999. They cost over £4bn in their first full year compared to £28bn today.

claims.text: Make sure you and your family all dig out your NHS number and have a copy of it immediately to hand for the Covid jab. NHS staff on the front line say this is the biggest bottleneck when it comes to administering the vaccine to as many people as quickly as possible.

claimReview.title: You don’t need your NHS number to get a Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You do not need to have your NHS number with you in order to receive the vaccine. A name and date of birth is all that is required, although some trusts have asked patients to bring their NHS numbers if possible.

claims.text: There is a toy for children called “my first vape”.

claimReview.title: ‘My First Vape’ toy is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t. This “toy” is a joke.

claims.text: The XMRV virus is in vaccines.

claimReview.title: There are no mouse brains in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that this virus is present in any vaccines or that it is linked to disease in humans.

claims.text: Extending the Brexit transition period would cost an estimated 15 billion.

claimReview.title: Would extending the Brexit transition period cost £15 billion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t know for sure—much will depend on the size of the EU’s next budget and the sum would probably have to be negotiated. But £15 billion a year seems a reasonable estimate for now.

claims.text: A picture shows the Queen as a young girl doing a Nazi salute.

claimReview.title: This footage of the Queen doing the Nazi salute is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The pictures are real, and show the Queen doing what appears to be a Nazi salute aged about seven.

claims.text: This screenshot shows an empty NHS funding bill debate.

claimReview.title: This is an image of one debate about the NHS Funding Bill - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that this is a debate for the NHS Funding Bill, however, bills go through many readings in parliament and the House of Lords.

claims.text: Labour’s universal basic income policy would cost £504 billion.

claimReview.title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on the assumption that the Labour Party introduces universal basic income for all adults at a certain level. It has so far only said it will trial such a scheme if it gets into government and not released much detail on how such a scheme would work.

claims.text: The NHS internal market, created in the 1990s, costs around £10 billion a year.

claimReview.title: No-one knows the exact cost or benefit of the NHS internal market in England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence to prove this. Research that arrives at this figure just estimates increases in admin costs over time, rather than trying to single out what impact the internal market has had.

claims.text: A letter sent by a Liverpool school claimed consent wasn’t needed to test children for Covid-19 during a city-wide testing scheme.

claimReview.title: Viral letter on Covid-19 testing in Liverpool school was real but has been withdrawn - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While the letter was genuine, it was withdrawn days after being sent by the school and replaced by a new letter saying consent was required. The council says the first letter was drafted without input from its public health teams.

claims.text: MPs get £25 per day food allowance. That adds up to £845,000 per year for all MPs.

claimReview.title: MPs can only claim £25 a day for food if they stay overnight outside London or their constituency - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can only claim this allowance for food if they stay overnight outside their constituency or London for parliamentary work. This is not what they can claim for every day of working in parliament, so this larger figure is meaningless.

claims.text: Tommy Robinson was prosecuted for causing distress to defendants in a grooming trial.

claimReview.title: Tommy Robinson was not prosecuted for causing distress to men on trial for grooming - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Mr Robinson was prosecuted and found guilty of contempt of court for breaking a reporting ban.

claims.text: A majority are in favour of Thailand’s policy of admitting vaccinated travellers.

claimReview.title: Twitter poll results don’t show ‘wide support’ for Thailand’s travel policy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on results from a self-selected Twitter poll, so it is meaningless.

claims.text: This is a photo of Gerry Adams, Martin McGuinness and Jeremy Corbyn together.

claimReview.title: This is a photo from Tony Benn’s funeral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True, all three were attendees of Tony Benn’s funeral in 2014, along with many other politicians.

claims.text: There is no Delta variant test.

claimReview.title: There are ways of testing for the Delta variant - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Genetic analysis of positive tests allow scientists to identify different variants of Covid-19, including the Delta variant.

claims.text: South West Yorkshire NHS partnership has not recorded any deaths due to Covid-19 between February and September 2020.
claims.claimant: South West Yorkshire NHS Partnership Foundation Trust

claimReview.title: This is a real letter from an NHS trust that dealt with no Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true and comes from a real freedom of information request. However, this NHS trust would be unlikely to treat people seriously ill with Covid-19 because it provides disability, mental health and community services.

claims.text: The Conservative government raised the armed services budget to 2% of GDP.

claimReview.title: Government defence spending is 2% of GDP - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Defence spending has never been below 2% of GDP in the years we have data for. In July 2015, the Conservative government pledged to spend 2% of GDP on defence in every year to the end of the decade.

claims.text: French president Emmanuel Macron gave a speech saying he will no longer sacrifice “my life, my time, my freedom and the adolescence of my daughters” for people who refuse the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Macron didn’t say he would no longer sacrifice his life for people who refuse Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Macron did not say this. These comments were made by Italian journalist Selvaggia Lucarelli on social media, and have been wrongly attributed to Mr Macron.

claims.text: Tanks were seen in Paris’ Champs Élysées, around the same time as protests against France’s introduction of vaccine or immunity certification.

claimReview.title: Tanks in Paris were almost certainly there for Bastille Day - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo was almost certainly taken on Bastille Day, a national French holiday, on which military vehicles parade the Champs Élysées. The same vehicles were seen in news reports and on social media.

claims.text: Over 200,000 nurses have quit the NHS since 2010.

claimReview.title: Have 200,000 nurses quit the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure covers all nurses and health visitors who have left the NHS in England in the last eight years, including those with an unknown reason for leaving as well as those who have retired or died in service. Overall the number of nurses working in the NHS is slightly higher than in 2010.

claims.text: A positive pregnancy test result for men could indicate high levels of hormones linked to testicular cancer.

claimReview.title: Pregnancy tests can’t reliably diagnose testicular cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true in some cases, but pregnancy tests are not a reliable form of diagnosis for testicular cancer.

claims.text: A quarter of nurses need a second job.

claimReview.title: Are nurses taking a second job to survive? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 23% of respondents to a survey of Royal College of Nursing members said they had taken an “additional paid job”, such as agency nursing, to help pay everyday bills and living expenses. We don’t know how representative this is of all nurses and this is based on a low response rate (8%).

claims.text: Any speed over 90mph is an instant ban and possible court order and custodial sentence.

claimReview.title: These claims about speed cameras on the M1 and M25 aren’t true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only a court can impose a driving ban, and whether they decide do depends on the circumstances. Police guidance suggests that speeds over 96mph are likely to result in someone being summoned to court.

claims.text: The number of drug-related deaths is the highest it’s ever been in this country since the 90s.

claimReview.title: Drug poisoning deaths are the highest they’ve been in 25 years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of drug poisoning deaths registered in 2016 was the highest since comparable records began in 1993. This includes deaths involving both legal and illegal substances, drug misuse and suicides.

claims.text: Norway and Switzerland have to accept EU laws despite not being members in order to trade with it.

claimReview.title: Norway, Switzerland and EU laws - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is about right. Both Norway and Switzerland keep out of some EU activities, such as the Common Agricultural Policy. But they bring many of their laws into line with EU rules, on the single market in particular.
