Norway incorporates single market rules as they’re made, while Switzerland accepts EU law from time to time in return for more market access.

claims.text: This photo shows women working for the Red Cross arriving at Normandy beach in 1944 to assist injured troops.

claimReview.title: This is not a photo of women of the Red Cross landing at Normandy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is a photo of women working for the Red Cross arriving in Southern France in 1945 to “keep high the spirits” of American soldiers.

claims.text: The SNP was wrong to say that Scotland currently has a lower prevalence of Covid than England.

claimReview.title: A Guido Fawkes ‘fact check’ incorrectly claims the SNP is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The SNP was correct about this, citing reliable recent data from the ONS. Data from the Coronavirus dashboard shows a different picture, but is less reliable for this purpose.

claims.text: Angela Merkel, Theresa May and the Lithuanian President were pictured together at a party in their youth.

claimReview.title: No, this image doesn’t show Merkel, May and the Lithuanian president hanging out as teenagers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False.

claims.text: A survey found 11% of workers who report having taken a financial hit from the coronavirus pandemic have been evicted.

claimReview.title: How many people have been evicted as a result of coronavirus? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Housing charity Shelter says there has been a spike in evictions, though not nearly as large a spike as this survey found.

claims.text: A turtle was deformed because of plastic waste in the water.

claimReview.title: A turtle was deformed by a plastic ring in the water - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True - a plastic ring became lodged around the animal, and the turtle grew around the ring.

claims.text: Labour’s planned welfare spending will cost £520 billion.

claimReview.title: Claim about cost of Labour’s welfare policy is unsubstantiated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on the assumption that the Labour Party introduces universal basic income for all adults at a certain level. It has so far only said it will trial such a scheme if it gets into government and not released much detail on how such a scheme would work.

claims.text: The Metropolitan Police is investigating the Covid-19 vaccine programme.

claimReview.title: Met Police has not launched an investigation into the Covid-19 vaccine programme - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The force confirmed to Full Fact there is no criminal investigation and no indication any crime has been committed.

claims.text: Going to bed between 10pm and 11pm every night cuts your risk of getting heart disease by up to 25%, according to a new study

claimReview.title: Study linking sleep time and heart disease risk shows correlation not causation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study did find there was a correlation between going to bed at that time and a lower risk of heart disease. But it didn’t prove that one caused the other, as suggested.

claims.text: Henry Kissinger told the WHO “Council on Eugenics” that vaccines could be used to control the human population

claimReview.title: Henry Kissinger has never given a speech about exterminating people with vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Dr Kissinger never said this. The meeting never happened. The Council on Eugenics does not exist.

claims.text: Nearly two-thirds of British businesses do not make a profit of over £10,000 but are subjected to corporation tax.

claimReview.title: It's not correct to say two-thirds of businesses make less than £10,000 profit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Two-thirds of limited companies have corporation tax liabilities of up to £10,000, but fewer than half of British businesses make a profit of less than £10,000.

claims.text: The Covid-19 death rate for “most of us” is 0.05%.

claimReview.title: Facebook post makes misleading claims about Covid-19 passports and death rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The terms here are poorly defined and seem to be based on disputed research. The 0.05% death rate figure, for younger people, is disputed.

claims.text: The government spent £2 million on a royal wedding.

claimReview.title: How much of this meme on government spending is true? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know exactly, but £2 million is probably in the right ballpark in terms of the policing costs for Princess Eugenie’s upcoming wedding.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, public sector pay is down 15%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Between May 2010 and July 2019 in Great Britain, , under coalition and Conservative governments, average weekly earnings in the public sector (excluding financial services) decreased by 1-2% in real terms.

claims.text: According to the OECD, the United Kingdom has the slowest growth in the developed world.

claimReview.title: Is the UK’s economy growing slower than any other country in the developed world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has one of the slowest real GDP growth rates, but not the slowest, of a number of countries analysed by the OECD, but these don’t include all developed countries.

claims.text: If you’ve taken an mRNA Covid-19 vaccine, your genetic make-up has been changed, and this is confirmed in a video of World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab.

claimReview.title: mRNA vaccines aren’t gene editing and don’t alter your DNA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The mRNA in certain vaccines, like Pfizer and Moderna, has no way of altering your DNA.

claims.text: The amount of income tax paid by the super-rich has fallen from £4.4 billion to £3.5 billion since 2009.

claimReview.title: Are the super-rich paying less income tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers are correct—up to 2014/15—but it's not a fair comparison. Tax rates changed in 2010 and some rich people moved their income around to avoid tax, which distorts the figures.

claims.text: 50% of delayed discharges accounted for by social care are in 24 local authorities.

claimReview.title: Social care and hospital delays - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around 24 councils accounted for roughly half of delayed discharges from hospital in November 2016, but the majority of these delays were due to the NHS, not social care. Looking just at social care 20 councils accounted for 50% of the delayed discharges. These councils also tend to have more people, and the disparity is lower when you take population size into account.

claims.text: BME students make up 17.9% of all British Oxford undergraduates. That’s pretty close to the percentage of BME people among 17-24-year-olds in England and Wales – 18.3%.

claimReview.title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place in 2017, and looking at those in the 2011 census who would be between 17 and 24 today.

claims.text: Labour policies would save the average family £6,700.

claimReview.title: Labour claims about savings under their policies are not credible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is not credible and does not represent what an average family would save.

claims.text: A study on vitamin D and Covid-19 shows an 80% reduction in need for ICU and a 60% reduction in deaths. The study demonstrates that the clear relationship between vitamin D and Covid mortality is causal.

claimReview.title: The link between vitamin D and Covid-19 is complex - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was a pre print of a study, which has now been removed from the Lancet website, and is being investigated.

claims.text: World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab wrote in “Covid-19: The Great Reset” that four billion people would die through planned epidemics, war and starvation by 2050.

claimReview.title: World Economic Forum founder did not write book about ‘organised epidemics’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He didn’t say that. It’s a passage from a 1992 conspiratorial text which seems to wrongly attribute it to novelist H.G. Wells.

claims.text: Currently, there are at least two or three women per week who are killed by their ex-partners or current partners.

claimReview.title: Women killed by men - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Official statistics, and separate figures from Women’s Aid, show around 80 women were killed by their partner or ex-partner in the latest year they cover.

claims.text: Death is listed as a side effect of the MMR vaccine.

claimReview.title: Measles is not the “number one side effect” of the MMR vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The US MMR vaccine package insert, under “adverse reactions”, says death from various and sometimes unknown causes has been reported after vaccination but a causal relationship hasn’t been found in healthy individuals. Death isn’t listed under adverse reactions on either MMR vaccine used in the UK.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, our fishing rights become owned by EU.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Being in the EU does mean the amount each country can fish per species is limited. Current policy says countries can limit who fishes in their waters to those who have traditionally done so. The Lisbon Treaty isn’t set to change any of this in 2022.

claims.text: If you get stabbed, open a tampon and whack it in the wound. The tampon will swell, which creates pressure and stops the bleeding.

claimReview.title: You shouldn’t put a tampon in a stab wound - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Several first aid experts told us not to do this, as it may not work and could risk further harm. You should put pressure on the wound with something like a bandage, towel, or even a piece of clothing, and call 999.

claims.text: The Grenadier Guards’ band played the ‘Imperial March’ during Donald Trump’s state visit.

claimReview.title: The ‘Imperial March’ was not played to Donald Trump during his UK state visit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They did not play the song. It was edited over actual footage of the band playing a selection of US military anthems.

claims.text: Care workers in France are being rewarded with a £1,500 tax-free lump sum.

claimReview.title: Many French care workers will get a tax-free bonus of up to £1,340 for working during the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Care home workers in France will get a tax-free bonus of up to €1,500 (£1,340) if they worked during the pandemic in the most affected areas. Those in less affected regions will get up to €1,000 (£890).

claimReview.title: Viral claim about France’s tax-free health care workers bonus needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Care workers in nursing homes will get a bonus, but it’s not yet clear how much. Healthcare staff fighting Covid-19 will get €1,500 (£1,300). Other hospital staff will get €500 (£440).

claims.text: Waving the British flag will result in arrest for breach of the peace.

claimReview.title: You almost certainly won’t get arrested for flying a British flag - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is unlikely outside of some very particular circumstances.

claims.text: 58% of coronavirus deaths in Scotland are from care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The report from the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC), which this figure comes from, says that in May 45% of Covid-19 deaths were in care homes.

claims.text: In three months we fell from being the fastest growing economy in the G7 to the slowest growing in the group.

claimReview.title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK was the fastest growing economy in the G7 in the last three months of 2016. It dropped to one of the three slowest in the first three months of this year, sitting alongside Italy and the USA at the bottom of the pile.

claims.text: A scam is asking people to input the personal details, including bank details, to receive “Covid-19 Relieve.”

claimReview.title: This is a scam and is not from the government - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. This is a scam and should not be interacted with.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, homelessness is up 170%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The estimated number of rough sleepers is up 165% in England between 2010 and 2018, under coalition and Conservative governments. But this data is known to undercount rough sleeping so those figures are not definitive. Also many people who aren’t sleeping rough are also defined as homeless. The number of households that were homeless for any reason increased by 41% between 2009/10 and 2017/18 in England.

claims.text: MPs get free travel.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim expenses for official travel. For example, MPs with constituencies outside London can claim for travel between their constituency and Westminster.

claims.text: The number of elderly people being rushed into A&E from care homes has risen by 62% since the Conservatives took power.

claimReview.title: Emergency admissions to hospitals from care homes are up 62% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the increase in the number of emergency admissions from care homes in England from 2010/11 to 2016/17. Roughly 90% of these admissions were people aged 60 plus in both 2010/11 and 2016/17.

claims.text: Poland has lowered its retirement age from 67 to 60.

claimReview.title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In October 2017, the retirement age in Poland was set at 65 for men and 60 for women. This reversed a 2013 policy which set about gradually raising the retirement age to 67 for both men and women.

claims.text: The UK is the USA’s largest European export market.

claimReview.title: UK-US trading and investment: a special relationship - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 6% of all US exports came to the UK in 2018, making it the top export market in Europe and behind only Canada, Mexico and China globally.

claims.text: The UK has the highest death rate in the EU from drugs.

claimReview.title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estonia had the highest rate of drug-related deaths per million people aged 15 to 64 in the EU, based on research using data from 2015 and 2016. The UK placed joint-third alongside Ireland.

claims.text: Cancer survival rates are at a record high.

claimReview.title: Cancer survival rates at record levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to an index of one-year and five-year survival rates for all cancers.

claims.text: The UK is one of the three countries that puts the most money into the EU budget.

claimReview.title: The UK is one of the biggest contributors to the EU budget - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: British exports are up while EU imports are down.

claimReview.title: April’s trade figures fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for goods. Data on services for April 2021 is not yet available.

claims.text: £1 billion was given to 13 companies for PPE but no PPE has been supplied.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post incorrectly claims that a list of PPE contracts are all unfulfilled - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These contracts appear to be real contracts for PPE, but there is no evidence that the contracts were all unfulfilled.

claims.text: Spain owes 1 Trillion.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spain’s national debt is worth €1.2 trillion.

claims.text: There is no reduction in viral transmission with the use of face masks.

claimReview.title: Video shares falsehoods about face masks and asymptomatic spread of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Face masks can help to reduce transmission of SARS-Cov-2, and are recommended in many scenarios by the WHO and the UK government.

claims.text: Covid-19 has a survival rate of 99.8%.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 victims cannot be cremated against their wishes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. About 0.23% of the entire UK population has already died with Covid-19.

claims.text: Scotland will have to leave the EU whether or not it becomes independent.

claimReview.title: Could Scotland stay in the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s very likely that Scotland would have to re-apply to join the EU on independence, although in theory it could stay in without a hiatus if all member countries agreed to write it into the EU treaties.

claims.text: The justice budget has fallen by 40% since 2010.

claimReview.title: Justice spending is down 25% since 2010, not 40% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was a proposal, but is now out of date. The government announced a 40% real terms reduction in the Ministry of Justice budget between 2010/11 and 2019/20, but in the end the reduction was 25%.

claims.text: Bill Gates and the UK government are contributing £400 million each to a new fund designed to boost green investment.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates’ £400m claim about green investment was wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The new fund is worth £400 million in total, with each party contributing £200 million.

claims.text: 80% of selective schools are rated as outstanding compared to 20% of all state schools. 99% of selective schools are rated good or outstanding.

claimReview.title: How do selective school ratings compare? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. 82% of selective schools were rated outstanding as of August 2016, compared to just over 20% of all state schools. 99% of selective schools received the top two ratings compared to 88% of all schools.

claims.text: 53 people have died in Gibraltar in 10 days after vaccinations with the Pfizer Covid-19 started.

claimReview.title: 53 people have not died in Gibraltar because of the Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As of 27 January, out of more than 11,000 vaccinated, six have died after receiving the vaccine, but there’s no evidence these deaths were related to the vaccine. 54 have died with or of Covid-19 in Gibraltar since vaccinations started on 10 January.

claims.text: Predictions of negative economic consequences immediately after a vote to leave the EU haven’t come to pass.

claimReview.title: Brexit and economic apocalypse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Predicted lower growth and an emergency budget didn’t happen, although sterling has fallen significantly. Economists still expect there to be an impact on growth in the coming years, not least after we actually leave the EU.

claims.text: Tax avoidance costs £90 billion per year.

claimReview.title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an unofficial estimate of the total tax gap. The figures are disputed and do not just cover tax avoidance.

claims.text: The NHS Long Term Plan will save 500,000 lives.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear exactly how NHS England plans to save 500,000 lives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s unclear how this will happen. NHS England hasn’t published much detail on how it calculated this figure. We’ve asked them for more information.

claims.text: Around 90,000 unaccompanied children claimed asylum in Europe in 2015.

claimReview.title: Unaccompanied refugee children in Europe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Official figures show this. There's some uncertainty over the age of some applicants, where the authorities have to assess what age they think a person is.

claims.text: The vaccine could cause women and girls to become infertile.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this.

claims.text: There are now 1.9 million more children in good or outstanding schools compared with 2010.

claimReview.title: It’s still misleading to say 1.9 million more children are in good or outstanding schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t acknowledge that there were 560,000 more pupils in state-funded schools in England in 2017 compared to 2010, and changes to inspection practices. 580,000 pupils are in schools that haven’t been inspected since 2010.

claims.text: In the UK we get 5.6 weeks of paid holiday. The EU sets paid holiday at four weeks.

claimReview.title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Those are minimum standards.

claims.text: Pfizer CEO Dr Albert Bourla was arrested on 5 November and held in custody for deceiving customers on the effectiveness of the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla has not been arrested for vaccine data fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this. Dr Bourla has been seen on television multiple times since, and a Pfizer spokesperson told Full Fact  he has not been arrested.

claims.text: The UK takes part in free trade agreements with 50 countries because of our EU membership.

claimReview.title: How many free trade deals has the EU done? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU lists 50 countries with which it currently has a trade agreement of one kind or another.

claims.text: An auto ticket generating system will issue you with a six point penalty.

claimReview.title: These claims about speed cameras on the M1 and M25 aren’t true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Highways England said they weren’t aware of any new systems on these roads. Breaking the speed limit can result in a fine of at least £100 and three points on your licence. Speed cameras can’t automatically issue points, but can trigger the process to issuing these fines and points.

claims.text: The government spent £200 million stopping benefit appeals.

claimReview.title: How much of this meme on government spending is true? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Department for Work and Pensions’ direct operating costs for mandatory reconsiderations and appeal tribunals for certain disability and illness benefits was £199 million between 2013/14 and 2017/18. That’s not the same as ‘stopping’ the appeals.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, police numbers are down 20%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The total police workforce in England and Wales fell by 17% between March 2010 and March 2019, under coalition and Conservative governments. Police officer numbers fell by 14% in the same period.

claims.text: There is no constitutional requirement for a Parliamentary recall or vote before military intervention.

claimReview.title: Does parliament get a vote on military intervention? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. There’s no legal requirement that parliament is involved in these decisions, the power rests with the Prime Minister, through the Crown.

claims.text: Only 32 vaccinated people have been hospitalised with Covid.

claimReview.title: There’s more to the claim only 32 vaccinated people were hospitalised with Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This needs context. A study looking at some people who were hospitalised for Covid between 8 December and 5 March, found only 32 people were hospitalised three weeks after vaccination.

claims.text: A little girl has gone missing in your area and police need help to find her.

claimReview.title: This little girl called Alice is not missing from your area - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a real missing person case. This is an ongoing scam. Do not click on it.

claims.text: Every four minutes a young person in England is diagnosed with gonorrhoea or chlamydia.

claimReview.title: Is a young person diagnosed with an STI in England every four minutes? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2017, there were 144,000 diagnoses for those aged 15-24 in England or the equivalent of one every four minutes. That’s not the same as the number of people diagnosed, someone might get diagnosed more than once, or with several STIs.

claims.text: This is a photo of a giant eagle in Scotland.

claimReview.title: This post does not show photo of a giant eagle in Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This photo was not taken in Scotland, it was taken in the USA.

claims.text: The government hasn’t protected the police budget.

claimReview.title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The England and Wales police budget has been protected since 2015 with increased local taxation making up for reductions in central government funding. If local taxation for the police is maximised in future, police funding overall will be protected. From 2010 to 2015 the police budget wasn’t protected and fell.

claims.text: One in six people in the US get food poisoning each year and one in 66 people in the UK get food poisoning each year.

claimReview.title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These estimates are both correct based on government figures, but they’re not      comparable due to differences in methodology and how the data was collected.

claims.text: The withdrawal agreement does not create any form of separation for Northern Ireland.

claimReview.title: Does the Brexit withdrawal agreement mean Northern Irish separation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not strictly correct. The withdrawal agreement includes a backstop arrangement. If that kicks in Northern Ireland will operate under different rules to the rest of the UK.

claims.text: A photo of Mike Tyson shows him wearing a ‘Plan-Demic’ t-shirt.

claimReview.title: Photo of Mike Tyson in ‘Plan-Demic’ t-shirt has been edited - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo has been altered to add  a Plan-Demic logo.

claims.text: 6 months ago the DWP promised a review of Universal Credit for the terminally ill.

claimReview.title: This claim that 2,000 people have died waiting for benefits since a Universal Credit review was announced needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The Department for Work and Pensions said in July 2019 that it would evaluate how the benefits system worked for those nearing the end of their life and those with severe conditions.

claims.text: In-work poverty is at record levels.

claimReview.title: Six million jobs pay less than the living wage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The proportion of individuals in poverty where at least one member of their family is in work is the highest recorded.

claims.text: The number of people detained under the Mental Health Act has increased by 47% in ten years.

claimReview.title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in England between 2005/06 and 2015/16.

claims.text: We spend nearly £50 billion on debt interest in the UK.

claimReview.title: Does the government spend £50 billion on debt interest payments? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s debt interest bill was £48 billion in 2016/17, although it effectively paid some of that back to itself through the Bank of England. The government actually spent about £39 billion.

claims.text: Professor Jonathan Van-Tam said that when Covid-19 is low in the community the risk of developing a blood clot for the under-30s increases.

claimReview.title: The risk of vaccination does not rise when Covid-19 becomes scarcer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not what Professor Van-Tam said, nor is it quite right. What changes is the balance of risk. When Covid is extremely scarce, the risk of young people suffering a rare blood clot after having the AstraZeneca vaccine might outweigh the benefit of the vaccine.

claims.text: Officers from the EU law enforcement agency, Europol, are immune from prosecution.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: Europol and diplomatic immunity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn't correct. Europol staff working on an investigation in a member state are in the same position as ordinary officers when it comes to criminal prosecution.

claims.text: Between 27 November to now there have been 239 deaths by suicide and the average age of those who died was between 25 and 44.

claimReview.title: We don’t know how many suicides there have been since Omicron arrived in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know exactly how many people died by suicide in the month long period since 27 November.

claims.text: Once the UK leaves the single market, freedom of movement no longer applies.

claimReview.title: You can have freedom of movement outside the EU if you’re in the single market - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Freedom of movement is one of the rules of the single market.

claims.text: Fibres from face masks and test swabs are evidence that nanoparticles are being inserted into us.

claimReview.title: Fibres from masks and swabs aren’t 'Morgellons' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Nanoparticles are not part of masks and swabs, and are too small to be seen with the naked eye.

claims.text: There’s a £2.5 billion shortfall in social care funding.

claimReview.title: A £2.5 billion shortfall in social care funding? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Local Government Association estimates a £2.6 billion gap in funding for adult social care by 2020. Other experts agree there’s a gap.

claims.text: 406 constituencies voted to leave, 242 voted to remain in the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Best estimates show it was probably about 410 to 240.

claims.text: 0070031450 A1 is a US patent for BSE (mad cow disease).

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is a patent application number one digit away from this that mentions BSE, but is not a patent for BSE itself.

claims.text: Tens of thousands of doctors and nurses in the NHS are from other EU countries.

claimReview.title: Lib Dem claims about EU health workers and the NHS are generally true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is correct. The number of reported other EU nationals working for the NHS in March 2019 was 65,000, of whom around 31,000 were doctors and nurses.

claims.text: 91% of lone parents are women.

claimReview.title: Do new Universal Credit requirements affect women more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, 90% of single parents with dependent children were women in 2017 in the UK.

claims.text: The overall teacher vacancy rate is 0.3% and has remained under 1% for the past 15 years.

claimReview.title: There's only so much the data can tell us about teacher vacancies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's correct, but the rate has been rising, albeit from a very low level. The data is thought not to fully reflect difficulties in teacher recruitment.

claims.text: The present government is continuing to spend more on foreign aid than any previous Labour government.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson was broadly right about aid spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is essentially true. Spending was briefly slightly higher than the present government’s planned target in 2006 and 2009, but no previous government has sustained it at or above that level.

claims.text: The public won’t be able to claim compensation if unlicensed vaccines damage our health.

claimReview.title: Unlicensed vaccines are not untested - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
They will in some cases. If the product doesn’t meet safety standards or is defective, then the manufacturer is liable. 
The consultation aside, it’s already true that if the government recommends the roll-out of an unlicensed product, manufacturers can’t usually be sued in civil court for the consequences.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets free transport.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim for certain types of travel, including within their constituency and between Westminster and their constituency.

claims.text: There were more suicide deaths than coronavirus deaths in the last two months.

claimReview.title: It’s too early to say how many suicides have happened during the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. Due to the time taken to formally register a suicide death, official figures on recent suicides do not yet exist.

claims.text: Funding for pensions has increased significantly in recent years.

claimReview.title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The state pension has increased in recent years, but because the pension age has increased, fewer people are now eligible for the pension. So while state spending on pensioner benefits has risen since 2010 it has remained stable in the last few years.

claims.text: 70% of all flights / all international flights by UK residents are taken by just 15% of the population.

claimReview.title: Do 15% of people take 70% of flights? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 70% of all flights in Great Britain were taken by 15% of adults according to analysis of a 2014 government survey.

claims.text: 7,000 prison officers have been lost from the prison service in recent years due to austerity measures.

claimReview.title: Fewer prison officers in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are 7,000 fewer prison officers now than there were in 2010 on one definition. This fall followed on from the 2010 spending review which reduced funding for the Ministry of Justice.

claims.text: Vaccination causes the immune system to start attacking the body when the person comes into contact with coronaviruses.

claimReview.title: Hecklers at Twickenham Stadium vaccine drive spout false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that any of the Covid-19 vaccines cause autoimmune diseases.

claims.text: Of the 635 MPs in the House of Commons some have been accused of spousal abuse or writing bad cheques, or have been arrested for fraud, drug-related charges, shoplifting or drink driving, or have bankrupted at least two businesses, have bad credit, or are defendants in lawsuits.

claimReview.title: This post about MPs is untrue and around 20 years old - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The post was originally circulated online around 20 years ago making claims about members of the US Congress and using almost exactly the same figures. Even back then the claims it made were unverifiable.

claims.text: Under Boris Johnson’s tenure as Mayor of London, the number of murders was under 100 a year for multiple years.

claimReview.title: What happened to violent crime in London since 2008? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen figures to back this up. Available figures are for homicides, which include more than just murders. They only show one year when there were fewer than 100 murders.

claims.text: Interest payments on the national debt are the fifth biggest item of government expenditure.

claimReview.title: Interest payments on the national debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The government spends more on health, benefits, pensions and education (broadly defined) but debt interest takes up about 5% of all government spending (excluding payments to the Bank of England).

claims.text: This image shows an elephant carrying a sick lion cub to water.

claimReview.title: This photo of an elephant carrying a lion cub is an April Fools' joke - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image was an April Fools' Joke digitally edited by a South African game reserve.

claims.text: Homeless deaths soar by 24% as 597 people die in a single year.

claimReview.title: Deaths of homeless people in England and Wales up 24% since 2013 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to new estimates for England and Wales. The Office for National Statistics says this is a conservative estimate and the real number may still be higher.

claims.text: The attainment gap between rich and poor pupils in grammar schools is virtually zero.

claimReview.title: Poor children at grammar schools seem to do well - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The gap between disadvantaged pupils and their peers at GCSE level is around three percentage points on average in grammar schools, compared to around 23 in other mainstream state schools. This might reflect more about the types of children that go to grammar schools rather than the effectiveness of the schools themselves.

claims.text: Grenfell Tower was built by a Labour Council under Labour government in 2007-2008, when Sadiq Khan was the Housing Minister.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Grenfell Tower was built in 1974 under a Conservative council. There was a Labour government at this time, but Sadiq Khan was not a minster: he was a young child in 1974.

claims.text: If you come to the UK illegally, you are an illegal migrant, and I’m afraid the law will treat you as such.

claimReview.title: Can refugees enter the UK illegally? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not in all cases. Specifically, refugees seeking asylum in the UK can’t be penalised for entering illegally if they are claiming asylum and coming from a place where their life or freedom are threatened. They may also stop over in other “safe” countries en route to the UK.

claims.text: The EU budgeted up to €3.9 billion in 2014 for spending that could be used to promote itself.

claimReview.title: How much does the EU spend on promoting itself? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU did spend money on promoting itself, and some EU publications certainly appear biased. But we can't put a precise figure on "propaganda" spending.

claims.text: We built 1.1 million homes in 2017.

claimReview.title: There are 1.1 million more homes in England since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is the total number of homes added to the overall housing stock since 2010/11, or the number of new homes built since 2009/10.

claims.text: Ursula von der Leyen decides on EU laws, which national leaders and MEPs can’t do.

claimReview.title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: She is the nominee to become President of the European Commission, which proposes new EU laws. But elected politicians—MEPs in the European Parliament and government ministers from all EU member states—get to review, amend and approve EU laws.

claims.text: GP numbers are experiencing their first sustained fall for 50 years.

claimReview.title: GP numbers: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at the number of GPs (excluding registrars, retainers and locums) per 100,000 people across the UK since 1964.

claims.text: 55% of the NHS budget is spent on the over 85s.

claimReview.title: How much of the NHS budget is spent on people over 85? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can't find any data to support this. Analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies suggests that by 2021/22 around 10% of health spending across the UK will go on those aged 85 plus.

claims.text: This image of two boats surrounding a third shows Australian warships turning away a ship of people trying to enter the country illegally.

claimReview.title: A post incorrectly claims to show Australian warships turning away people trying to enter the country illegally - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The image is from a territorial row between China and Japan in 2012. However, Australia does have a policy of turning back boats.

claims.text: Asylum seekers are offered a £300 maternity payment for having a baby.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Claiming to be living alone is one of the most common types of benefit fraud.

claimReview.title: Falsely claiming to live alone accounts for around 9% of benefit fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was probably the fourth most common type of benefit fraud in 2016/17 where the specific reason was known, accounting for an estimated 9% of overpayments relating to fraud.

claims.text: A new lung cancer drug has been authorised under an international scheme that the UK has been able to join post Brexit.

claimReview.title: Conflicting claims about ‘new’ cancer drug thanks to Brexit are both misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The medication has had EU authorisation since 2016 but the recent authorisation has allowed a new use of the medication, earlier in the disease. This has not yet been authorised in the EU.

claims.text: Maths and science has fallen to a record low in Scottish schools

claimReview.title: Scotland’s maths and science scores are falling in international tests but rising in national tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Scotland’s maths and science ranking has fallen to a record low in international league tables but attainment in national qualifications has risen

claims.text: Pre-eclampsia occurs between 26 and 32 weeks into pregnancy.

claimReview.title: Pre-eclampsia doesn’t only occur 26 to 32 weeks into pregnancy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was actually the timing for recruitment for the study the Mirror was reporting on. The NHS says that pre-eclampsia can occur from 20 weeks into pregnancy until a few weeks after delivery.

claims.text: More than a quarter of a million people came to the UK from the EU in the 12 months to September 2015 - the equivalent of a city the size of Plymouth or Newcastle in just one year

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: migration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over a quarter of a million is correct according to official estimates, around the same as Plymouth’s population but not quite as much as Newcastle’s.

claims.text: Fighting cross-border crime — the EAW allows us to deport criminals from the UK and catch those fleeing justice across Europe

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on cross-border crime - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The European Arrest Warrant does allow the government to remove criminals from the UK to other EU countries, but a similar arrangement might be negotiated if we voted to leave.

claims.text: One in seven children aged seven to nine gets less than 15 minutes a week reading time with their parents.

claimReview.title: One in seven parents don’t read to their 7-9 year-old for more than 15 minutes per week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A survey found one in seven parents reads to their child aged seven to nine for less than 15 minutes per week. That doesn’t necessarily mean the child’s other parent isn’t reading to them as well.

claims.text: The Germans want a £40 billion Brexit payout.

claimReview.title: Germany doesn’t “owe” the UK £3.7 trillion of war debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK will have to pay an estimated £39 billion to the EU (not specifically Germany), as part of the proposed withdrawal agreement. If we leave with no deal, it’s highly uncertain whether or not we’d legally have to pay that bill.

claims.text: Primary school children are being used to carry drugs.

claimReview.title: Are children being used to carry drugs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Reports from police in England and Wales to the National Crime Agency suggest in 42% of forces children as young as 12 are being used, but we can’t confirm yet if there are younger children involved as well.

claims.text: Romanian workers are being brought in to do seasonal British farm work, despite huge interest in these roles by British people.

claimReview.title: Some context for the claims that Romanian seasonal workers are taking UK workers’ jobs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Farmers and produce companies say although there has been high interest and some roles are filled, experienced farmworkers are still needed to train and supervise new recruits and volunteers.

claims.text: Diane Abbott said an Iraqi migrant’s body was found off the coast of Luxembourg, a landlocked country.

claimReview.title: Diane Abbott did not say an Iraqi migrant was found off the coast of a landlocked country - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Her original tweet about a body found off the coast of Belgium was edited to say this.

claims.text: There was more ice than ever before at the polar ice caps in 2015.

claimReview.title: There wasn’t more polar ice “than ever” in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The extent of Antarctic sea ice did peak in 2015, before hitting a low in 2016, but Arctic sea ice and the land ice sheets at both poles have been steadily shrinking for decades.

claims.text: Labour’s freedom of movement plan could increase net migration to 840,000 a year.

claimReview.title: Conservative claim about immigration under Labour is not credible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour hasn’t published its manifesto yet, and the methods used to reach this number are not credible.

claims.text: A photo shows Jeremy Corbyn with the IRA.

claimReview.title: This is not a picture of Jeremy Corbyn with the IRA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The man in the photo is not Jeremy Corbyn.

claims.text: FFP3 respirators provide 99% protection against Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The evidence shows surgical masks do offer protection from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: FFP3 respirators will filter out 99% of particles and are recommended as personal protective equipment for people working with Covid-19 patients.

claims.text: 5G WiFi networks could be responsible for the rapid spread of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: 5G is not accelerating the spread of the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. There is no evidence that 5G WiFi networks are linked to the new coronavirus.

claims.text: Six million people earn below the national living wage.

claimReview.title: How many earn below the living wage? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research this appears to be based on refers to jobs, rather than people. In 2014 5.4 million people with one job earned below the national living wage.

claims.text: The survival rate of Covid-19 without the vaccine is greater than the effectiveness of the vaccine itself.

claimReview.title: It’s misleading to compare the effectiveness of Covid-19 vaccines and the death rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The comparison with the reported effectiveness of the Moderna vaccine is misleading, as that’s looking at how many people get infected, not how many die.

claims.text: The Centre for Social Justice recently produced figures which show that pupil absence grew by 55% during the previous lockdown, with more than 90,000 pupils now absent from school.

claimReview.title: Iain Duncan Smith’s figures on school absence are out of date - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are not recent figures. The CSJ published them in June 2021, and they describe pupil attendance more than a year ago. Therefore, they do not accurately tell us anything about the current picture of persistent pupil absence.

claims.text: 1 in 100 children in this country are homeless.

claimReview.title: How many children are homeless in England, Scotland and Wales? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly this many children are in temporary accommodation in Great Britain.

claims.text: The government will spend half a trillion pounds on the NHS this parliament.

claimReview.title: The half-a-trillion NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but adding up five years’ worth of spending into one big figure isn’t particularly meaningful.

claims.text: Under Margaret Thatcher the corporation rate was 52%. It fell to 34% while she was Prime Minister.

claimReview.title: Corporation tax: could we have raised more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct.

claims.text: The EU’s founding principle is free trade among its members.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was one of the EU’s founding principles. Since 1992, it is also committed to European citizenship; a common foreign and security policy; and cooperation between EU governments on justice and home affairs.

claims.text: 4,717 Covid-19 deaths out of the 0-59 year-old UK population means a 0.009% fatality rate.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 survival rate is not 99.991% for under 60s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong on a few levels. The death data is for England alone, and only for those dying in hospital after a positive test, and this calculation only works if every single person aged 0-59 has been infected with Covid.

claims.text: Italy is hit hard, experts say, only because they have the oldest population in Europe.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Whilst it is true that an older population has contributed to a high number of deaths in Italy, it may not be the sole reason.

claims.text: A small animal centre stopped new adoptions because people were buying them for food.

claimReview.title: An adoption centre did pause adoptions of rabbits for fear they’d be used as food, but there’s no evidence it’s widespread - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The West Berkshire small animal centre was concerned that people might use it’s rabbits for food and so paused adoptions. The RSPCA said it hasn’t received any reports of these animals being killed for food.

claims.text: The UK provided 20% of the new cases of coronavirus in the world on Sunday, 17 October 2021.

claimReview.title: Viral tweet overstates UK’s lead in Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s more like 15% of reported cases, and that may be influenced by different reporting times between countries and delays caused by the weekend. The seven day average is a better measure to compare and on 18 October this showed the UK had 10% of new cases.

claims.text: 58.8% of graduates are in non-graduate jobs.

claimReview.title: Are graduates settling for non-graduate jobs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is based on a survey from 2010. Separate figures from earlier this year paint a different picture.

claims.text: A picture showing people unwell on the streets of India was taken during a gas leak in 2020, not during the Covid-19 pandemic in 2021. This suggests that casualties from the current wave of Covid-19 in India are being exaggerated, and that Covid-19 is a conspiracy.

claimReview.title: A mistake in the New York Post has been misconstrued as a sign of Covid-19 conspiracy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image was incorrectly used in a New York Post article about the Covid-19 pandemic, but it actually comes from a video taken in 2020 after a gas leak in Visakhapatnam, India. The outlet has since corrected the mistake, and there is nothing to suggest it is evidence of a conspiracy.

claims.text: 1.9 million more children are in good and outstanding schools.

claimReview.title: It’s time to stop saying there are “1.9million more children in good or outstanding schools” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t acknowledge that there were 630,000 more pupils in state-funded schools in England in 2018 compared to 2010. We also don’t know how a lot of schools rated good or outstanding are doing today, as many haven’t been re-inspected for several years. Evidence from recent Ofsted inspections suggest some may now lose their high ratings.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines were not tested on animals before they were approved.

claimReview.title: Instagram post gets it wrong about Covid-19 vaccines and animal testing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All of the vaccines approved for use in the UK were tested on animals.

claims.text: British companies sold £12.9 billion worth of goods to the EU, ten per cent up on pre-Brexit figures.

claimReview.title: April’s trade figures fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £12.9 billion is correct, but the 10% rise claim is against summer 2020 and doesn’t reflect the wider trend. Exports to the EU are down compared to the period before Brexit.

claims.text: The last Labour government once raised the basic state pension by 75p.

claimReview.title: Pensions under Labour and the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but this was an outlier. That was the rise in the full basic state pension in April 2000. Looking at the increase in this payment after inflation, it was higher on average under Labour between 1997 and 2010 than under the Coalition and Conservatives since 2010.

claims.text: Average UK household income rose from £20,448 in 1990 to £37,100 in 2020.

claimReview.title: House price growth has outstripped income growth—but not by much - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is close to correct, if you adjust the 1990 figure for inflation. This is the disposable income (i.e. after taxes and benefits).

claims.text: On 16 February 2021, the front page of the Metro newspaper reported on concerns about Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: A fake Metro cover shares false vaccine information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a fake front page. The Metro did not say this.

claims.text: The prosecution service introduced laws making it illegal to use "hoverboards" on public paths.

claimReview.title: "Hoverboards" and the law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is illegal, but not because prosecutors say so. The law making it illegal to ride on the path dates from 1835, and judges confirmed in 2011 that it applies to devices like hoverboards.

claims.text: Hundreds of thousands of children are in overcrowded classrooms.

claimReview.title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Hundreds of thousands of children were in classes of more than 30 last year. That’s been true for at least the last decade, although it’s become more common to have large primary school classes recently.

claims.text: Nigel Farage once flirted with the idea of there being a second EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Deja-EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: During interviews earlier this year Mr Farage said that he might be starting to think we should have a second referendum as he felt the proportion voting to leave would be larger than in 2016. He also said he feared we may have to have a second referendum if Parliament rejects the final deal with the EU.

claims.text: 20,000 people a day who are sick with Covid-19 are not isolating.

claimReview.title: Evidence doesn’t show 20,000 people ‘sick with Covid’ fail to self-isolate every day - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misunderstanding of figures which roughly estimated that 20,000 people a day who are asked to isolate by NHS Test and Trace (having either tested positive or come into contact with someone who has) do not do so fully.

claims.text: Identical comments under Boris Johnson’s post are bots.

claimReview.title: It’s unlikely that these are bots commenting on Boris Johnson’s post - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is most likely that these are genuine commenters posting similar messages on purpose.

claims.text: If you request gift aid, the charity organisers take 5% of the gift aid before passing it on.

claimReview.title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If a donor adds Gift Aid onto their donation, JustGiving deducts a 5% Gift Aid processing service fee. This is collected separately from the donations made.

claims.text: Benefit fraud and error costs the UK taxpayer £3 billion per year.

claimReview.title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s estimated that £3.9 billion is overpaid to claimants due to fraud or claimant error, and £1.3 billion is underpaid to claimants due to claimant error. That gives a balance of £2.6 billion.

claims.text: Ketchup, orange squash, tomatoes, strawberries and grapes all deliver positive Covid-19 lateral flow test results.

claimReview.title: Ketchup, squash and fruit do not deliver positive Covid-19 results - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We know that foods high in acid can break lateral flow tests and cause it to appear “positive”. However, research has shown that they very rarely deliver a false positive result when used properly, on people.

claims.text: Fact checkers are funded by pharmaceutical companies.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Full Fact has never received funding from a pharmaceutical company, and a full list of major donors who gave over £5,000 is available online.

claims.text: There is a scam involving Santander customers being sent fake bank cards.

claimReview.title: Santander bank card ‘scam’ probably doesn’t exist - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t find any evidence that this scam exists.

claims.text: Corporation tax rates are higher in the USA than the UK

claimReview.title: Corporation tax: UK vs USA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. US companies pay about twice the rate of tax on their profits as UK companies.

claims.text: This is a photo taken of Boris Johnson since he has been Prime Minister.

claimReview.title: This picture of Boris Johnson isn’t from this week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was taken in April 2019 as part of a programme on Brexit.

claims.text: The UK’s EU budget rebate lasts until 2020/22

claimReview.title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no fixed end-date for the UK’s rebate. But the EU wants to get rid of rebates for all countries that have one over the course of the next EU budget (2021-27). The UK could potentially block moves to remove its rebate.

claims.text: British OAPs who have worked for 45 years get a total yearly benefit of £6,000.

claimReview.title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A British pensioner with 45 years’ worth of national insurance contributions is likely to get at least £700 a year more than this, and be eligible for more benefits on top.

claims.text: A picture shows a tasselled wobbegong shark.

claimReview.title: Viral ‘shark’ picture isn’t a shark at all - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It doesn’t. The picture shows a goosefish, although tasselled wobbegong sharks are real.

claims.text: Virus levels are now 50x higher among secondary school pupils than they were in September.

claimReview.title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to ONS data, this is correct.

claims.text: School standards in Scotland are falling.

claimReview.title: Scottish schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to various sets of pupil tests, although international tests suggest that standards are improving in some subjects.

claims.text: Universal Credit will make work pay.
claims.claimant: Department for Work and Pensions spokesperson

claimReview.title: Universal Credit: will it "make work pay"? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Overall, Universal Credit will strengthen work incentives for people claiming the benefit, the Institute for Fiscal Studies has said. But certain groups, such as single parents, will see their work incentives weakened.

claims.text: Boris Johnson’s dad Stanley wrote a novel called ‘The Virus’ in 1982.

claimReview.title: Stanley Johnson did write a novel called ‘The Virus’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct.

claims.text: There are 13,100 more nurses on our wards.

claimReview.title: What’s happening to nursing numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have figures specifically for the numbers of nurses working on our wards. This figure refers to the increase in the number of nurses working in acute, elderly and general wards for adults. It misses out nurses who work in other types of wards – for example mental health, or those who work in the private sector, but are commissioned to work for the NHS.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means UK fishing waters are back in our control.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is largely correct. The UK will become an independent coastal state though there will still be other international obligations on fisheries the UK needs to abide by.

claims.text: A woman in her twenties will earn 95p for every pound that young men of their age earn.

claimReview.title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s what you’d expect on average. If you knew nothing about two people apart from the fact that one was a woman, one was a man, and both were working and in their twenties, you’d expect the woman to earn about 5% less than the man.

claims.text: Drink plenty of water

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Staying hydrated is good for you, but doesn't prevent or cure Covid-19

claims.text: A three-page trade agreement would mean little obvious would change in terms of our trade when we leave the EU.
claims.claimant: Iain Duncan Smith, David Campbell Bannerman, Martin Howe, Jon Moynihan, Rebecca Ryan

claimReview.title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This would be the most basic possible trade agreement. The UK and EU would lose alignment on regulation of goods, with significant non-tariff barriers to trade, and tariffs on trade in services.

claims.text: An asteroid bigger than Big Ben is due to crash into the Earth’s atmosphere on 11 January.

claimReview.title: A giant asteroid isn’t about to ‘crash into the Earth’s atmosphere’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It’s expected to come within 3.5 million miles of the Earth’s surface, far beyond the reaches of our atmosphere.

claims.text: The number of people dying today is the same as it would be in any other year.

claimReview.title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. Deaths in the week to 6 November were 14% higher than the average across the past five years, and higher than the maximum across the past five years.

claims.text: NHS Test and Trace cost £22 billion in just a few months.

claimReview.title: We can’t say if Test and Trace has cost more than the Channel Tunnel—yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not quite right. £22 billion is the budget allocated by the government for the first year of Test and Trace. £4 billion was spent up to the end of October. We don’t yet know how much the whole first year will cost.

claims.text: The share of jobs that are high-skilled is falling.

claimReview.title: What's happening to high-skilled jobs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was true in 2014, but over the longer run the share of high-skilled jobs in the economy has been increasing.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we would have to give up our sovereignty.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU law does has supremacy over domestic law in some areas. The UK has some veto power and several opt-outs. If no EU law is applicable, UK parliament and courts are supreme. The Lisbon Treaty, which came into force in 2009, doesn’t mention anything about this changing in 2022.

claims.text: There was a £38 billion black hole in the defence budget in 2010.

claimReview.title: Prime Minister repeats uncertain £38 billion defence budget 'black hole' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim has never been properly justified, even when the National Audit Office and MPs have tried to check it.

claims.text: The CDC is removing its request for emergency use authorisation of PCR tests. This is evidence that PCR tests don’t work, are fraudulent and cannot distinguish between influenza and Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The CDC has not said PCR tests don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The CDC has given laboratories advance warning that they will stop requesting approval for one type of PCR test. This is because there are now other, more efficient PCR tests available. Some of these can simultaneously test for influenza viruses as well as SARS-CoV-2 to avoid having to take multiple samples or run multiple tests on the same sample if it is negative for SARS-CoV-2.

claims.text: Refugees are predominantly male.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: are asylum seekers mostly men? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the EU, 57% of new asylum applicants in the first six months of 2015 were men, 26% were children of both genders, and 18% were women.

claims.text: The EU parliament elections this year will be proportional.
claims.claimant: Green Party of England and Wales

claimReview.title: What will happen to your vote in the upcoming EU parliament elections? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The system is designed to deliver a broadly proportional result, but in practice the outcome won’t be perfectly proportional.

claims.text: A San Diego biotech company is developing a Covid-19 vaccine in collaboration with Duke University and National University of Singapore.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The company, Arcturus Therapeutics, announced on 4 March 2020 that it would be working on a vaccine with DukeNUS Medical School in Singapore.

claims.text: Vapers with Covid-19 are up to 17% more likely to transmit the virus.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t say most vapers are 17% more likely to transmit Covid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study found this may be the case in a small minority of vapers. However, in most vapers the increased risk is 1%. Even the higher 17% risk is lower than the risk from coughing or talking.

claims.text: Wages are rising at their fastest rate for a decade.

claimReview.title: Wage growth is only the fastest in a decade if you ignore inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct but it doesn’t account for inflation. When you factor in rising prices, real wage growth is at its highest in two years.

claims.text: These children live in families struggling to put food on the table.

claimReview.title: Poverty is not the same as food insecurity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data shows 74% of these children live in ‘food secure’ households.

claims.text: A Swedish woman was savagely beaten by a Muslim migrant after she asked him to stop groping her.

claimReview.title: We don’t know who attacked this Swedish woman - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A woman was physically attacked in a nightclub in Sweden after she tried to stop a man sexually assaulting her. Her description of the attacker did not mention his religion or if he was a migrant, and his identity remains unknown, so there is no basis for the claim that he was a Muslim migrant.

claims.text: The risk of a blood clot following a Covid-19 vaccine is worse than the cold or flu symptoms you may experience if infected.

claimReview.title: Social media post appears to overstate risk of vaccine blood clots - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This overstates the risk of blood clots caused by the vaccine. Furthermore, evidence suggests the risk of clotting and other arterial conditions is much higher following infection than vaccination.

claims.text: Computers are getting better than humans at reading.

claimReview.title: Are computers getting better than humans at reading? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They’re not. “Even elementary school reading comprehensions are harder” than the test computers passed, says the test’s creator. It’s an academic milestone not a practical one.

claims.text: The EU wants to force the UK to take a share of refugees.

claimReview.title: The UK can't be forced to accept more refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Unlike most other EU member states there would be no legal requirement for the UK to take a "quota" of refugees if such a scheme were passed.

claims.text: Over 2.5 million people now officially live in energy poverty.

claimReview.title: The government hasn’t u-turned on energy price caps - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an underestimate: almost 3.7 million households may be living in some form of fuel poverty across the UK, although the data is not directly comparable due to differences in how it is measured.

claims.text: Covid-19 is easily treatable at home. About 85% of hospitalisation and death is completely avoidable with early treatment.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The studies on which this claim is made have limits. Some new, expensive Covid-19 treatments can reduce the risk of hospitalisation and death.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation confirmed that the PCR test is flawed and all tests with a high cycle threshold (Ct) are invalid.

claimReview.title: What’s a PCR test cycle threshold and why it matters - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. It reiterated guidance that tests with a high Ct may need to be retested. There are lots of different reasons for high Ct value results. Interpreting them requires clinical context.

claims.text: The DWP employs 3,300 staff to investigate welfare fraud.

claimReview.title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As of July 2018 the DWP employed 1,405 full-time equivalent specialists to investigate benefit fraud, and data suggests there may be another 2,000 or so doing related work.

claims.text: Labour pledged to scrap all controls on immigration

claimReview.title: Labour didn’t vote to scrap all immigration controls - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Labour passed a motion at its party conference to extend free movement and ruling out certain forms of immigration systems. This doesn’t mean scrapping all immigration controls.

claims.text: The number of people using food banks since 2010 has gone from the tens of thousands to the millions.

claimReview.title: How many people use food banks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of uses of Trussell Trust food banks has increased over this period from 41,000 to 1.2 million, but we don’t know how many individual people use food banks in total. The Trust estimates it had 560,000 users in 2016/17, but this won’t reflect the total number of people using food banks in the UK.

claims.text: A photograph shows a young Angela Merkel posing with Adolf Hitler.

claimReview.title: This isn’t a picture of Angela Merkel and Adolf Hitler - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This picture shows Hitler with an anonymous girl. Mrs Merkel was born nine years after Hitler died.

claims.text: Microsoft and Bill Gates have filed a patent numbered 060606 for a microchip which is inserted into the body and which rewards activity with cryptocurrency.

claimReview.title: Patent application 060606 does not mention inserting microchips into the body - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Microsoft's 060606 patent doesn't reference injectable microchips. It is true that Microsoft has a patent application with the numbers 060606 in it, but it's for a system which rewards physical activity with cryptocurrency.

claims.text: Covid-19 deaths in care homes are rising.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 deaths in care homes have started to fall - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was true at the time, by one measure. By another measure it was probably not true. Now it seems clearer that deaths in care homes from suspected Covid-19 are falling.

claims.text: Four million people have diabetes.

claimReview.title: Four million people have diabetes—probably - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems about right. We can only be sure about the three and a half million people diagnosed with diabetes. Another half a million may be undiagnosed, according to estimates.

claims.text: Most of the refugees in the EU have come from Syria.

claimReview.title: More refugees in the EU are Syrian than any other nationality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct in terms of people granted refugee status, although Syrians aren’t the majority of migrants crossing the Mediterranean or applying for asylum.

claims.text: Business rates are set to rise for more than 500 businesses from 1st April 2017.

claimReview.title: Business rates: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct, although rates are set to fall for many others.

claims.text: If women in the UK reached their full economic potential it would be worth £23 billion.

claimReview.title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is from 2006. Some of the gains may have increased with the size of the economy, and higher prices mean that the cash figures would be larger. Some of the gains may already  have been achieved.

claims.text: Shamima Begum is back in the UK.

claimReview.title: Shamima Begum is not back in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As of October 2020 this is not true.

claims.text: Boris Johnson has died.

claimReview.title: A tweet claiming the Prime Minister has died is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This was claimed by a Twitter account masquerading as the BBC.

claims.text: UK GDP growth in the second quarter of 2018 was 0.4%. In the Eurozone it was 0.3%.

claimReview.title: Is UK economic growth higher than in Europe? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This was correct when the claim was made earlier in August, but the figures have since been revised, with both the UK and Eurozone growing at 0.4% in the second quarter. 


Growth in the EU and the Eurozone is higher in the previous 12 months than the UK. It’s projected to stay that way.

claims.text: Bumblebees have been recently listed as endangered.

claimReview.title: Not all bumblebees are endangered - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s Red List of Threatened Species, there are 13 species of either endangered or critically endangered bumblebee. None of the species recorded in the UK are classified as endangered by the IUCN.

claims.text: The vaccines only have temporary approval by the MHRA.

claimReview.title: Poster about Yellow Card scheme is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is essentially correct. The Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccines have received temporary authorisations, while the Moderna and Janssen vaccines have received temporary licenses which offer the possibility of being converted into permanent licenses in future.

claims.text: It can survive for 6-12 hours on fabric and will be killed by normal laundry detergent .

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way.

claims.text: At the 2019 Labour conference, working class white members were charged more to attend than ethnic minorities.

claimReview.title: These claims about the 2019 Labour conference are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was a planned discount for ethnic minority members for a 2018 regional party conference. These plans were scrapped after the UK’s equalities watchdog intervened.

claims.text: You and your family members can be detained.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You can be isolated if it’s suspected you have an infectious disease, and your family members, if it’s suspected you’ve infected them, can also be subjected to these measures.

claims.text: A government document showing that 60-70% of Covid deaths over the summer will be among the vaccinated is proof that vaccines are intended for genocide.

claimReview.title: Government modelling not proof of vaccine ‘genocide’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This reflects the fact that the majority of elderly and vulnerable people will have been vaccinated, and the number of those for whom the vaccine was ineffective will be larger than the number who are not vaccinated.

claims.text: The average forecast for UK GDP growth this year was the same September as in June, despite the UK voting to leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Post-referendum predictions: have forecasts for the economy changed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but it isn’t the whole picture. Yes, the average forecast for UK GDP growth in 2016 was the same in September as it was in June. But the types of goods and services predicted to make up that growth was different.

claims.text: Shamima Begum has been flown back or is due to be flown back to the UK.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence Shamima Begum has been flown back to the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this and it’s circling online with known false claims.
