claims.text: A voice recording on WhatsApp claims there will be 900 deaths a day at the peak of the new coronavirus outbreak, one third will be children with no underlying health conditions, ambulances won’t be sent to people struggling to breathe, and all ice rinks are now being used as mortuaries.

claimReview.title: This viral voice message about ambulances shared on WhatsApp is inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust, where the person in the recording suggests they work, and Public Health England have confirmed the information is inaccurate.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines have killed 18,928 people in the EU, more than 11,405 people in the US, 1,470 people in the UK and 5,522 people in Scotland.

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Half of these figures are incorrect and none of the reports they come from link the total number of reported deaths to vaccines.

claims.text: In January 2020, the economy had grown by 73% under the Conservative government.

claimReview.title: Was Dawn Butler right about Boris Johnson ‘lying’ to Parliament? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The economy grew 73% between 1990 and 2017, under both Labour and Conservative-led governments. In January 2020, the economy had grown by around 20% since the Conservatives took office in 2010.

claims.text: The EU will continue to control migration, trade, VAT, and vital security policies such as counter-terrorism. EU law will carry on having ultimate authority over British law

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU law does override UK law, and has mostly taken over control of trade, immigration from other EU countries, and VAT. The EU doesn’t control counter-terrorism or the intelligence services.

claims.text: Various spellings of the name Muhammad combined rank number one for most popular boys name in England and Wales in 2018.

claimReview.title: The ranking of most popular baby names depends on how you count them - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This all depends on how you count the various spellings of Muhammad and other boys’ names and abbreviations of names. If you count Henry and Harry variations together, they come higher.

claims.text: 2.6 million WASPI women are affected by the changes to the state pension age.

claimReview.title: Increasing the state pension age - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 2.6 million women (and 2.3 million men) are affected by the changes made in 2011. Other women are affected by earlier changes.

claims.text: 31 million people have lost their jobs in the last five weeks.

claimReview.title: This viral UK Facebook post claiming 31 million job losses probably refers to the USA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is far too high for the UK. 31 million is closer to the job losses reported in America.

claims.text: Free movement of people across the EU means that migrants now fill one in nine jobs in Britain.

claimReview.title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About one in nine UK workers were estimated to be foreign nationals in 2016, including nationals from outside the EU.  This proportion has been increasing, which the ONS has said is mostly down to EU immigration.

claims.text: A video shows the last moments of an Ethiopian Airlines flight that crashed in March.

claimReview.title: This video doesn’t show the final moments of the Ethiopian Airlines flight that crashed in March - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video doesn’t come from the Ethiopian Airlines flight that crashed in March. It’s from a different plane.

claims.text: Department for Education research shows missing school for even a day can impact pupil attainment.

claimReview.title: Mixed evidence on the link between term time holidays and attainment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This research finds as pupil absence rates increase, they do worse in tests at ages 10/11 and 15/16. Missing a single day doesn’t always show this for some pupils though, if the absence is an authorised holiday. Either way, the findings can’t prove that missing school is the cause of worse performance, or at least that if it is a cause, it's the main one. The evidence is more mixed looking specifically at holidays as a reason for absence.

claims.text: Suicide is the main cause of death among new mothers.

claimReview.title: Deaths following childbirth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Suicide was the main cause of death between six weeks and one year after pregnancy in the period 2012-2014. Other causes of death were more common in the six weeks after giving birth.

claims.text: On fabric it can survive for 6-12 hours. normal laundry detergent will kill it.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence yet that the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way. Any soiled clothing should be thoroughly washed.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence yet that the virus can survive in clothing and be transmitted this way. Any soiled clothing should be thoroughly washed.

claims.text: The UK and USA invest $1 trillion between them in each other’s economies.

claimReview.title: UK-US trading and investment: a special relationship - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. UK-based companies invested around $541 billion in the USA in 2017 while US-based companies invested around $748 billion in the UK, according to official US figures. That totals around $1.3 trillion.

claims.text: Between 17,000 and 20,000 Royal Navy sailors died fighting illegal slave traders.

claimReview.title: Royal Navy sailors died while preventing the slave trade, but not tens of thousands - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While it is true that sailors died as part of British efforts to combat illegal slave trading, it is unlikely to be this high a number.

claims.text: Amazon sprays all its packaging with toxic pesticides that can be harmful to cats.

claimReview.title: Amazon parcels do not pose widespread risk to cats - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. This claim originates from another social media post which has since been deleted. Amazon says it doesn’t spray its packaging with toxic pesticides and that its boxes are no different than most other card packaging.

claims.text: Coronaviruses can live on surfaces for up to 28 days, so you should be careful if you receive a package from China.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that the new coronavirus can survive on packages for 28 days - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is currently no evidence that this virus can survive on surfaces that long. Most other coronaviruses do not. Current health advice suggests the risk of contracting the virus from a package is very low.

claims.text: A HMRC boss, Edward Troup, once said that taxation is “legalised extortion”.

claimReview.title: "Taxation is legalised extortion": a quote out of context? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He did write this, but says it should be seen in context. The words appeared in a 1997 opinion piece in the Financial Times, in which Mr Troup argued against a particular approach to preventing tax avoidance.

claims.text: There are more hospital beds.

claimReview.title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The number of beds available in NHS hospitals in England has been falling for the last thirty years, something experts put down to medical innovations. 1,300 fewer beds were used by patients fit to be discharged in November 2017 compared to the year before.

claims.text: A man gave his girlfriend jewellery made from his own teeth.

claimReview.title: Egyptian man did not give partner jewellery made from his teeth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo was posted as a joke. An accompanying picture of the jewellery appeared in a Buzzfeed article five years ago.

claims.text: There is no test that can identify the Delta variant.

claimReview.title: There are ways to identify the Delta variant - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The Delta variant can be identified through analysis of viral genetic material from positive PCR tests. 

The Delta variant is the main strain of Covid-19 in the UK currently.

claims.text: There are more teachers with first class degrees.

claimReview.title: Teachers with first class degrees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of postgraduate trainee teachers with first class degrees did increase between 2012 and 2014. In 2015 and 2016 it seems to be static. These more recent figures aren’t fully comparable with those from earlier because of a change in the data.

claims.text: Finland, South Korea and Canada, which all have the most comprehensive systems, have been repeatedly shown to have the best educated children in the world.

claimReview.title: Finland, Canada and South Korea rank highly for education - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Finland, South Korea and Canada have done consistently well in tests that compare 15 year-olds internationally, although these tests aren’t a perfect guide to the relative performance of different education systems. We haven’t seen definitive evidence that the success of these systems is due to the fact they’re comprehensive.

claims.text: The UK and US have exported no vaccines.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccine exports and the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seemed to be the case when the claim was made, though it has since been reported that the UK sent over 700,000 doses to Australia in February/March though this has not been confirmed. The US also sent 2.7 million doses to Mexico in late March.

claims.text: Fruit Shoot and oranges can test positive for Covid-19 using a lateral flow test.

claimReview.title: Fruit Shoot and oranges can’t test positive for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No, they can’t. What looks like a positive test result is actually just the test breaking as a result of it being used incorrectly.

claims.text: British workers put in longer hours for lower pay than German workers.

claimReview.title: Germans are more productive than us, work less, and earn more - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines breach the Nuremberg Code.

claimReview.title: Video in a car shares misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Multiple medical ethicists have told us that this is an inappropriate and unsubstantiated claim.

claims.text: We are short by 100,000 lorry drivers.

claimReview.title: How many more HGV drivers does the UK need? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure hasn’t been fully evidenced. It is based on the assumption that there was already a shortage of 60,000 before the pandemic. There are 30,000 fewer lorry drivers now than in the year before the pandemic.

claims.text: The delays in cancer care waiting times are the longest since targets were first introduced.

claimReview.title: Cancer care waiting times - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are a number of cancer care waiting times. Targets for the proportion of patients being treated within 62 days of being urgently referred by a GP are being missed. In January 2017 the proportion meeting the target was the lowest since targets were set in 2009. The rest of the targets were all hit.

claims.text: Support for Welsh independence is up to 30%.

claimReview.title: Latest poll puts support for Welsh independence at 24% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A recent poll put support for Welsh independence at 24%.

claims.text: 66% of coronavirus deaths in France are from care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The ECDC report says 66% of cases reported by long term care facilities were in nursing homes for the elderly. Around 50% of all deaths were in long term care facilities for all age groups.

claims.text: Instagram is changing its rules so that any posts or messages on the platform will be public, can be used in court cases against you, and Instagram is now a public entity. If you share a certain image, Instagram will not be able to share your images or messages.

claimReview.title: The meme you’ve seen about Instagram privacy settings is not true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: None of this is true.

claims.text: A video shows the Taliban throwing people from a plane.

claimReview.title: Video of people falling from plane in Kabul shows a US aircraft - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The footage actually shows a number of people falling from a US aircraft after clinging to the outside. The US Air Force, which owns and operates the aircraft, has since confirmed it is reviewing the incident.

claims.text: Ireland’s test and trace system cost £775,000.

claimReview.title: Flawed comparisons between test and trace systems go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This was the cost of developing its contact tracing app. The whole test and trace programme is estimated to cost €700 million per year in Ireland.

claims.text: Parliament will have to change the Terrorism Act after judges declared that parts of it are incompatible with human rights.

claimReview.title: Miranda’s rights: will the Terrorism Act be changed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The ruling doesn't mean that the law is no longer in force or that Parliament has to revise it. A declaration of incompatibility is a formal signal from judges that an Act should be changed. It generally is, but doesn't have to be.

claims.text: The EU gives British workers the entitlement to 28 days' paid holiday.

claimReview.title: How much of your paid holiday is down to the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU minimum is 20 days. The British government increased it to 28 to cover bank holidays.

claims.text: It takes a German worker four days to produce what a UK worker makes in five.

claimReview.title: Germans are more productive than us, work less, and earn more - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct in 2015. On average, it took a German worker under four hours to make what a UK worker made in five hours. Since they worked fewer hours each week, they took about four and a half days to produce what a UK worker produced in five.

claims.text: Lots of scientists think vaccines kill more people than they save.

claimReview.title: Radio 4 programme featured Covid vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know which scientists are being referred to, but Covid-19 vaccines have saved vastly more lives than they have cost.

claims.text: Per head, Norway pays almost the same amount into the EU budget as the UK.

claimReview.title: Norway's EU payments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Norway’s payments linked to its relationship with the EU are around two thirds of what the UK pays per head of population, before money comes back. Comparing payments after money comes back is difficult, but seems to narrow the gap still further.

claims.text: Re-offending costs up to £13 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Does re-offending cost £13 billion a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This estimate is uncertain and old. It originated in 2000 and has been inflated since then to account for price increases and changes in levels of crime. The researchers themselves say estimating these costs is "inevitably imprecise".

claims.text: Poor British adults are less healthy than they were a generation before.

claimReview.title: The poorest in UK are living longer, but it seems they feel worse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from research on how people feel about their health, which is not necessarily the same as how healthy they are. Life expectancy in low income households has risen, which suggests  that their general health may not be worse.

claims.text: 400,000 people are being paid to be tested every week.

claimReview.title: This post telling healthy people to stop getting tested is full of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to be based on target figures for the ONS infection survey, which measures how many people currently have or have already had the virus. Participants are given vouchers. This is a different program to tests conducted under the Test & Trace scheme.

claims.text: The number of NHS overnight hospital beds has fallen by 15,000 since 2010.

claimReview.title: The number of NHS hospital beds has fallen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is in the right ballpark but isn’t the best comparison. It’s fairer to say the number of beds has fallen by about 12,000.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine doesn’t stop you catching the disease.

claimReview.title: This Morning guest makes misleading claims on vaccine efficacy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Data shows that even one dose can significantly reduce your chances of getting infected, even without symptoms.

claims.text: 50% of mental health problems develop by the age of 14 and 75% by the age of 18.

claimReview.title: What age do mental health conditions develop at? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the finding of a study of New Zealanders born in the early 1970s that followed them throughout their lives. The study’s authors caution that it might not apply to all countries, particularly as around 90% of those who took part in the study were white.

claims.text: The UK is best at cycling, rowing and track and field.

claimReview.title: The Olympic Games, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over a quarter of all UK Olympic medals have been for athletics. The other sports UK athletes have won most medals in are rowing, sailing, cycling and swimming.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means we would have free trade with the world.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK could import goods and services freely following a no-deal Brexit. But its exports would still be subject to other countries’ import regulations.

claims.text: Latex rubber is in vaccines and causes life-threatening allergic reactions.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Latex is used in the packaging of some vaccines, which could potentially cause harm if someone’s strongly allergic to it.

claims.text: 800,000 of the "2 million jobs created" are zero hour contracts.

claimReview.title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have no way of knowing how much of the increase in employment (the "2 million jobs") over last Parliament came from zero hour contracts.

claims.text: Coronavirus killed 9 people out of 66.6 million yesterday.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 has killed more people than obesity in the UK this year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the death toll on 9 September, but it has risen since then. At its peak, more than 1,000 people were dying daily in the UK.

claims.text: Over the past 43 years, the EU has taken control over more and more areas which don’t have anything to do with trade—such as our borders, our public services, and whether prisoners have the right to vote.

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: Taking control? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The scope of the EU has expanded, partly due to treaties that the UK has signed up to. It covers aspects of borders and public services but not total control. It covers prisoners voting only when it comes to European elections.

claims.text: The number of mental health nurses has fallen from 46,155 to 39,358 [since 2009].

claimReview.title: Mental health: there are fewer beds, nurses and psychiatry trainees than in 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the difference in the number of mental health and learning disabilities nurses between two different months which isn’t the best way to compare the figures. Comparing the figures in September 2009 and 2017 shows the drop has been larger.

claims.text: A PHE report shows the Covid-19 vaccines have negative effectiveness in the over-40s.

claimReview.title: Vaccines do not raise your risk of catching Covid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The report contains data that it warns could be misinterpreted in this way. It also says that the vaccines are positively effective.

claims.text: The French Prime Minister wrote to the President of the European Commission asking the EU to punish the UK for Brexit.

claimReview.title: Did the French PM really ask for the EU to ‘punish’ the UK over Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The letter did not use the word “punish”. But it did call on the EU to take action against the UK with respect to the latest fishing row, which some could interpret as punishment for Brexit.

claims.text: UK growth is currently the slowest among the 10 largest EU economies.

claimReview.title: Is the UK economy in the slow lane? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: UK growth is the slowest among all EU economies over the last quarter. Over the last year, of the ten largest EU economies the UK has grown the 8th fastest.

claims.text: Most of the world trades with the EU on WTO terms.

claimReview.title: Who trades with the EU under WTO rules? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Of 135 non-EU full members of the World Trade Organisation, 58 currently trade with the EU under negotiated trade terms, and another 47 have preferential access to EU markets.

claims.text: British 90 year-olds knew Panzers.

claimReview.title: These claims about people of certain ages remembering parts of World War Two are generally incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, today’s 90 year-olds would have remembered panzers though are unlikely to have seen them in combat.

claims.text: The government has given the NHS the money that it asked for.

claimReview.title: Has the NHS got the money it asked for? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The head of NHS England says this is not the case.

claims.text: Vaccinated people account for a higher proportion of Covid-19 deaths than infections. This suggests that the vaccines are actually making the recipients worse once exposed to the alleged Covid-19 virus.

claimReview.title: Why might vaccinated people account for a bigger share of Covid-19 deaths than infections? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence vaccines make infections more severe. There are other reasons why vaccinated people account for a higher proportion of deaths than infections.

claims.text: Vaccine risks for children outweigh benefits.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The JCVI has said that the benefits from vaccination for healthy 12 to 15-year-olds are marginally greater than the potential known harms.

claims.text: A senior judge has said that Muslim women should be allowed to wear a veil in court.

claimReview.title: Lord Neuberger unveiled? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Lord Neuberger said that judges should understand why people wear a veil. He didn't call for a specific change to the law which allows veils to be restricted.

claims.text: Christian Eriksen had a Covid-19 vaccine days before collapsing on the football pitch.

claimReview.title: Christian Eriksen did not have Covid-19 vaccine before collapse, says Inter Milan CEO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The head of his club team, Inter Milan, has said Mr Eriksen had not been vaccinated.

claims.text: Irish people were forced into slavery in British Colonies for hundreds of years.

claimReview.title: The “Irish slave” myth has been widely discredited - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Claiming the Irish experience of indentured servitude was chattel slavery is a misrepresentation of history.

claims.text: The government can introduce restrictions on Universal Credit where you can’t get it unless you get tested and unless you get a vaccine.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has confirmed this is untrue and there are no plans to do this.

claims.text: More Londoners voted for Brexit than for Sadiq Khan as mayor.

claimReview.title: Did more people in London vote to leave the EU than for Sadiq Khan? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In Greater London, there were around 200,000 more votes for Brexit than first and counted second votes for Sadiq Khan in the London mayor elections. Counting all votes for him (including those that didn’t contribute to his final win) he got 20,000 more votes.

claims.text: Student ‘loans’ don’t actually work like loans.

claimReview.title: Student ‘debts’ aren’t really debts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s right. What you pay for your student ‘loan’ depends on what you earn, not how much you borrowed, and it doesn’t appear on your credit file.

claims.text: Most German cars are sold in Britain.

claimReview.title: About 1 in 7 German cars are sold in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s wrong. About one in seven cars made in Germany are sold in Britain. It is true that more German cars are exported to the UK than anywhere else.

claims.text: There’s a do not resuscitate across the UK on the elderly, on the disabled.

claimReview.title: Viral video includes lots of false claims and half truths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Guidance from regulatory bodies explicitly says that do not resuscitate orders should not use a ‘blanket approach’. 

The preliminary report from a Care Quality Commission investigation into the use of DNACPRs during the Covid-19 pandemic found examples of unacceptable and inappropriate DNACPRs being made at the start of the pandemic, but stated that there was no evidence to suggest it continued as a widespread problem.

claims.text: Hydrogen boilers could cause four times as many explosions and injuries than conventional boilers.

claimReview.title: Headlines exaggerate danger of hydrogen boilers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A model estimated that hydrogen boilers would cause more explosions and injuries if used without safety valves. With the valves, the risk from the two systems was about the same.

claims.text: The police don't normally look back and investigate things that have taken place a year ago.

claimReview.title: Do police normally investigate things that happened a year ago? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Police often investigate alleged offences which took place years before. This is less clear cut in the context of breaches of Covid-19 regulations, which police say they do not routinely investigate retrospectively.

claims.text: The IFS found average working families will be £1,400 worse off because of the 2017 Budget.

claimReview.title: “Average working families” and the Budget - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not correct. Figures on this scale don’t refer to the recent budget, they cover all changes to tax and benefits from 2015 to 2020. The average one-earner couple with children stands to lose £1,400 over this period and households with children overall are expected to be £1,300 worse off.

claims.text: The UK has a huge trade deficit with the EU.

claimReview.title: The UK’s trade deficit with the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK imported around £60 billion more goods and services from the rest of the EU than it exported there in the 12 months to September 2016, although it has a trade surplus in services alone.

claims.text: Grammar schools benefit some pupils.

claimReview.title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The evidence suggests pupils who get into grammar schools do better than they would under comprehensive education, but the majority who don’t get in do worse.

claims.text: We can only sell lamb to Japan because of the EU-Japan trade deal.

claimReview.title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We sell lamb to Japan as a result of Japan agreeing to drop an import ban. Japan charges no tariffs on lamb, so farmers will continue to export lamb to Japan tariff free post-Brexit.

claims.text: London's most miserable boroughs revealed to be Greenwich and Lambeth. Redbridge was ranked happiest.

claimReview.title: The most miserable borough in London? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Don't send flowers yet. The order is right but the difference between the happiness levels in these boroughs, and Redbridge at the top of the scale, is minimal. On average people across all London boroughs rate their happiness at around seven or eight out of 10.

claims.text: Up to 93% of PCR tests are false positives.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. It has been estimated that the false positive rate is very low.

claims.text: Videos show flucloxacillin medication contains something that makes it magnetic.

claimReview.title: Flucloxacillin capsules contain iron oxide which may make them magnetic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We cannot verify the provenance of the videos, but the MHRA told Full Fact that the magnet is most likely attracting the iron oxide food colouring used in the capsule shell.

claims.text: The average term of a government since the Second World War is 3.7 years.

claimReview.title: How long does the average government last? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct if you count the current government, which is still in office. Looking only at completed governments, the mean average is 3.8 years and the median is 4.1 years.

claims.text: A little girl has vanished from a local area and the police need help to identify those responsible.

claimReview.title: This little girl has not vanished from your local area - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The story is false and appears to be an attempt to gain access to your Facebook account.

claims.text: An “Australian terms” trade deal could be called a deal on Mongolian or Afghan terms.

claimReview.title: What does an "Australia style" Brexit deal really mean? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mongolia and Afghanistan actually have more favourable trade terms with the EU, at least as far as tariffs are concerned, than Australia.

claims.text: There have been 1,400 deaths and one million injured from Covid-19 vaccinations in the UK.

claimReview.title: Free paper repeats falsehoods on deaths following vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are deaths and potential side effects reported following the vaccine, not necessarily because of it.

claims.text: More than one million people are not receiving the social care they need.

claimReview.title: Are one million people without social care? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research behind this isn’t published yet, so we can’t say how accurate it is. Age UK has previously produced similar estimates, based on asking people whether they need help with at least one daily task every time they need it.

claims.text: Pensioners are getting £1,250 more a year than they did when the Conservatives entered government.

claimReview.title: £1,250 more a year for pensioners - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Pensioners who receive the full basic state pension in 2017/18 are getting £1,250 more in cash per year than those receiving it in 2010/11. However, in real terms the increase is only £558.82 extra per year, and only for pensioners receiving the full basic state pension.

claims.text: If more than 250,000 people write ‘FREEDOM’ in response to a question about religion on the 2021 census it will become a recognised belief system.

claimReview.title: Saying your religion is ‘Freedom’ on the census won’t make it a recognised belief - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. There is no specific number people have to reach to get a census output. To add a new protected characteristic to the Equality Act 2010 you have to bring a legal claim and win in a court of employment tribunal.

claims.text: The government never committed to taking 3,000 child refugees from Europe under the Dubs Amendment.

claimReview.title: The Dubs Amendment: 3,000 refugee children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was never an official target, although 3,000 was the number mentioned by campaigners, some of whom say they believed that to be the figure. The government only accepted the Dubs Amendment after the 3,000 target was taken out of it.

claims.text: Plasma from newly recovered patients from Covid -19 can treat others infected by Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is being used as a treatment in some countries, but clinical trials have not yet proved that this is effective.

claims.text: Pupils who both attend grammar schools and are entitled to free school meals represent one out of every thousand pupils generally.

claimReview.title: Few pupils are both at grammar schools and on free school meals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Since the Conservatives came to power, the number of bus trips taken by young people has declined by 40%.

claimReview.title: Would free bus travel save young people £1,000 a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for 21 to 29 year-olds. According to the National Travel Survey, the number of bus journeys taken by people in England between 21 and 29 dropped by 40% between 2010 and 2016.

claims.text: The lab from which the coronavirus originated has a similar symbol as the lab responsible for a mass outbreak in the Resident Evil games.

claimReview.title: This company is based in Shanghai, not Wuhan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The source of the new coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan has not yet been identified. The lab is based in Shanghai, not Wuhan and there is no reason to think it has anything to do with the new coronavirus.

claims.text: Since 1987 more than 200,000 UK students have studied or worked in Europe on the Erasmus exchange programme, 15,000 in 2012 alone.

claimReview.title: British students and the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The local Government Association said the spending review would allow some councils to go some of the way to raise the money they need for social care.

claimReview.title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right, although how far the measures will go varies by area. Experts have estimated the funding gap for adult social care at between £2.8 billion and £3.5 billion by 2020.

claims.text: There’s been a reduction in the quantity of business rates across the board in total.

claimReview.title: Business rates: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. In the past few years a combination of increased reliefs, threshold changes and caps on business rate increases have reduced the amount businesses are paying overall.

claims.text: The increase in net migration under the Conservative government is the highest it has ever been.

claimReview.title: The Conservatives’ migration record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The greatest annual increase in estimated net migration in the last 20 years was under the Labour government in 1998. Levels of net migration under this government are thought to be the highest ever recorded.

claims.text: There are 1.8 million more children in good or outstanding schools.

claimReview.title: 1.8m more pupils in good or outstanding schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 1.8 million more pupils were in good or outstanding schools in 2016 than in 2010. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice.

claims.text: Theresa May knew about the Windrush issue in 2014 - there was a report in 2014 which reported on these stories.

claimReview.title: What was known about Windrush in 2014? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report included stories of individuals of the Windrush generation facing difficulties proving their immigration status. We don’t know whether Theresa May saw the report first-hand, though the Home Office was made aware of the findings.

claims.text: The government is spending £14 billion on primary and secondary education between now and 2022/23.

claimReview.title: Is £14 billion being spent on education? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The increase is £4.3 billion by 2022/23 once you account for inflation. The £14 billion figure is unhelpful as it is the figure you get if you add up all the extra money spent on education in each year to 2022/23 compared to 2019/20 and doesn’t account for inflation.

claims.text: This man holding a “The UK Invented Racism” sign is the same that tried to burn the Cenotaph’s Union Jack.

claimReview.title: This person isn’t the one from viral footage of someone trying to burn the Cenotaph’s Union Jack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. They are two different people.

claims.text: 53 cyclists were killed in 2014 due to bad road conditions, up 77% since 2010.

claimReview.title: How many cyclists are hurt and killed on poor roads? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The figures refer to the number of cyclists killed or seriously injured (KSI) in this kind of road accident.

claims.text: The ‘CDC 2019-Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCoV) Real-Time RT-PCR Diagnostic Panel’ cannot differentiate between Covid-19 and flu.

claimReview.title: The CDC has not ‘dropped’ all PCR tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This test can only detect SARS-CoV-2. It will not confuse Covid-19 and flu, and can ‘differentiate’ between them. But it cannot test for both at the same time.

claims.text: Raising public sector pay in line with inflation will cost £4 billion.

claimReview.title: The cost of lifting the public sector pay cap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's correct that it will cost £4 billion a year according to one estimate, although it's uncertain how accurate this will turn out to be.

claims.text: Mental health is an exemption of Tier 4 and Tier 5 -- you can go out and see a friend, you can leave your house.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You can leave your house during lockdown for specific reasons, regardless of mental health, for example, to meet one local friend for exercise.

claims.text: About 3-4% of reported rapes are based on false allegations.

claimReview.title: Allegations of rape - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no way to know the true figure, and it depends which types of case you include in your definition. Evidence from England and Wales suggests that 3-4% is a reasonable estimate for the number based on malicious complaints.

claims.text: A photograph shows Prince Philip dressed up in guardsman’s uniform as a prank to amuse the Queen.

claimReview.title: Prince Philip did not dress up in a bearskin for a prank - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This photograph does show Prince Philip in the uniform of the Grenadier Guards, but it was not a prank. He was the Colonel of the Regiment.

claims.text: By 2020 the government will have borrowed more than all Labour governments put together.

claimReview.title: Government borrowing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s true if you add up borrowing under Labour governments since 1945, whether or not you adjust for inflation. But it isn’t a fair comparison because the UK economy and the government have both got bigger.

claims.text: Drinking lemon mixed with hot water for one to three months will cause cancer to disappear.

claimReview.title: Lemon juice, coconut oil and stopping all sugar intake won’t cure cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no scientific evidence to show lemons or lemon juice can cure cancer.

claims.text: £37 billion was found to pay Serco for a failed track and trace system.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims about Serco’s role in Test and Trace resurface - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £37 billion is the two-year budget for Test and Trace. The vast majority is spent on testing not tracing and does not go to Serco.

claims.text: We have more households because of social change and people living longer for any given level of population than we had a generation ago.

claimReview.title: What’s driving our increasing population and household numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Immigration has been the largest driver of the increasing population, according to the Office for National Statistics. Life expectancy has also been steadily increasing over the last few decades.

claims.text: To test for the new coronavirus, take a deep breath and hold for more than 10 seconds. If you complete it successfully without coughing, discomfort, stuffiness or tightness it proves there is no fibrosis in the lungs, basically indicating no infection.

claimReview.title: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this test can show if you have the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this test can show if you have the new coronavirus.

claims.text: There's a "massive gap" of 100,000 units a year between what housing is needed and what is being built.

claimReview.title: How large is the housing gap? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There's a few different ways of looking at it but 100,000 seems to be a pretty reasonable estimate of the gap (for 2014).

claims.text: Greenwich council is set to remove a memorial stone to Lee Rigby.

claimReview.title: Greenwich Council have removed a Lee Rigby memorial - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: When this article was originally written, Greenwich council told us they didn’t have plans to remove the stone. It has since been removed and replaced with an official memorial.

claims.text: Being on this pill is associated with depression.

claimReview.title: What are the possible side effects of the contraceptive pill Rigevidon? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This brand’s advice leaflet says Rigevidon is associated with “mood swings including depression”. Guidance on whether the combined contraceptive pill can cause depression is unclear.

claims.text: Antivirals should be used to fight Covid-19.

claimReview.title: This post about Covid-19 and blood clotting conditions contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Antiviral drugs can be used to treat viral infections, but no specific antiviral drug has been conclusively shown to be effective against Covid-19 so far.

claims.text: Taxpayers are subsidising low paid workers at Asda, Tesco, Sainsbury’s and Morrisons by almost £1 billion a year via working tax credits and housing benefits.

claimReview.title: Supermarket pay image—where do the figures come from? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t verify these figures, but we know they’re out of date. Citizens UK—which produced a report that the figures have been taken from—says they should not be used as a reflection of the situation today.

claims.text: Private renting is making millions of people ill.

claimReview.title: Quarter of private renters experience sickness over housing worries—but we don’t know if private renting is the cause - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
A survey found almost a quarter of private renters agree that housing worries have made them ill in the past year. 
This doesn’t mean the sickness was specifically caused by renting privately as opposed to any other type of housing situation.

claims.text: 5G kills trees.

claimReview.title: These trees weren’t cut down because of 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have found no evidence that’s the case.

claims.text: Labour’s plans to nationalise certain industries would cost at least £196billion and savers and pensioners could suffer further losses of £9 billion.

claimReview.title: There are some problems with this estimate of Labour’s nationalisation plans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The analysis this is based on says either one or the other of these things happens, not both.  Regardless its method is disputed and doesn’t factor in the potential economic benefits of nationalisation.

claims.text: Infrared thermometers harm the pineal gland.

claimReview.title: Infrared thermometers do not affect the pineal gland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Infrared thermometers do not emit infrared radiation, they measure it.

claims.text: The number of homicides in London was around 250 in 2006, 110 in 2016 and 150 last year.

claimReview.title: The number of homicides in London has fallen over the last decade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These aren’t all correct. The Metropolitan Police told us it recorded 172 homicides in 2006, 109 in 2016, and 134 in 2017 (of which 12 were terrorism related).

claims.text: There are 9 million more visits to A&E since 2000.

claimReview.title: Are patients going to A&E instead of GPs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but walk-in centres have been introduced since then, and this type of A&E has seen the biggest rise in attendances. Major A&E departments have seen their attendances increase by around 3 million between 2002/03 and 2015/16.

claims.text: The population has grown by a third since the start of the NHS.

claimReview.title: More people, more (NHS) problems? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, comparing data from 1951 and 2016.

claims.text: £1.2 billion is lost to benefit fraud.

claimReview.title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is out of date and newer estimates put this much higher at £2.3 billion for 2018/19.

claims.text: Options for post-Brexit trade deals with the EU will lead to between £39 billion and £158 billion less per year.

claimReview.title: This viral image showing the cost of different Brexit deals is wrong in a lot of ways - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on government analysis comparing 3 hypothetical deals to existing GDP projections, which explicitly can’t be used as economic forecasts and are very uncertain. Were they to be used anyway, these are figures for a 15 year period, not one year.

claims.text: 86% of children suffered an adverse reaction to the Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in clinical trials.

claimReview.title: Figures about Pfizer side effects for children need more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is correct, but ignores vital context. The adverse reaction in question was pain at the injection site, an extremely common side effect for many vaccines. Most of the study participants (aged 12 to 15 years old) reported only mild or moderate pain.

claims.text: 26% of NHS doctors are foreign-born.

claimReview.title: More context is needed for these “facts about immigration” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 26% of doctors in England (excluding GPs) were nationalities other than British as of September 2017. The latest figure is 27% (September 2018). We don’t know where they were born as this data isn’t collected.

claims.text: Workers coming to the UK on very low salaries can claim over £10,000 in benefits.

claimReview.title: Can working immigrants claim over £10,000 in benefits? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is possible for low-paid workers to claim this much in benefits currently. Migrants from the EU who work here have the same right to benefits as UK nationals, which may be difficult to change under EU law.

claims.text: The EU is the only place where free ports don’t really exist.

claimReview.title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Free ports do exist within the EU, although in a more limited form than elsewhere in the world.

claims.text: The vaccine doesn’t work.

claimReview.title: The government hasn’t said the vaccine will cause a third wave of deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is lots of evidence that proves this is wrong.

claims.text: Trade with the EU is more than double that with Australia, Canada, India, New Zealand and the USA combined.

claimReview.title: Trade with the English-speaking world - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Vitamin D, Ivermectin, zinc and hydroxychloroquine are safe and effective treatments for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Freedom March video littered with false claims about Covid-19 cures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no robust evidence yet that any of these can treat or prevent Covid-19.

claims.text: No one needs refuge from France.

claimReview.title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although France is generally considered a “safe” potential country for asylum seekers, there is legal precedent to suggest France could potentially be considered a risk to an asylum seeker if the authorities fail to offer them the treatment they are entitled to.

claims.text: A woman was hospitalised with suspected Covid-19, only for her illness to be shown to be Legionnaires’ disease caught from a mask.

claimReview.title: You cannot catch Legionnaires’ disease from a mask - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You cannot catch Legionnaires’ disease from a mask.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines cause vaccine enhancement syndrome which makes you even more vulnerable to the disease.

claimReview.title: Having a Covid-19 vaccine doesn’t make you more vulnerable to the disease - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is based on a misreading of a MailOnline article about Covid-19 variants. There is no such thing as vaccine enhancement syndrome. The Covid vaccines do not cause antibody dependent enhancement, which may be what the post had in mind.

claims.text: If you do catch Covid-19, you have a “one in a 100 percent” chance of dying.

claimReview.title: This viral post understates the risk of Covid-19 infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid-19’s fatality rate is still being determined, but somewhere between 0.5% and 1% is a reasonable estimate. However, this varies depending on a person’s health and background.

claims.text: There is a discrepancy between information on Pfizer’s website and patient information leaflet and official government advice for pregnant women thinking about getting the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: What is the advice on getting the Pfizer vaccine during pregnancy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that the advice given by Pfizer and the advice given by health authorities differs. Pfizer said this is because it is not within the company’s remit to say there is sufficient clinical evidence to support pregnant women getting their Covid-19 vaccine safely. This decision is down to each individual country’s regulatory body.

claims.text: Millions of people who voted Leave did not vote for Theresa May’s hard Brexit.

claimReview.title: Public support for a "hard Brexit" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t know for certain. More recent polling could be used to show this—if being against a “hard Brexit” is defined as prioritising free trade over immigration control.

claims.text: Sadiq Khan faked getting the flu jab as the plastic cap was still on the needle.

claimReview.title: A picture of Sadiq Khan just before his flu jab doesn’t show he didn’t get it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cap is still on the needle, because the image was taken before the mayor had the vaccination.

claims.text: The UK gives the EU £12 billion per year.

claimReview.title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Last year the UK made a net contribution of up to £9 billion (not counting any money that goes to the UK private sector).

claims.text: The WHO now says a child’s presence in school counts as “informed consent” for a vaccination and parental presence is not required.

claimReview.title: The WHO has not decided attending school implies consent for vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The evidence for this claim was taken from a document written by the WHO which described types of vaccine consent around the world, including written, verbal and implied consent. In the UK, sending your child to school doesn’t automatically imply you’ve consented for them to get a vaccine.

claims.text: All animals used in Covid-19 vaccine trials died months later from immune disorders, sepsis and/or cardiac failure.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccine did not kill every animal it was tested on - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.. The claim is based on a 2012 study looking at different vaccines. The animals, in this case mice, were euthanized as is standard procedure in this sort of trial. They did not die “months later” as claimed.

claims.text: Inheritance tax has been cut

claimReview.title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Government policies since 2010 have tended to push down inheritance tax, mainly because of an increased allowance for passing on “the family home”.

claims.text: Household savings are the lowest in 50 years.

claimReview.title: Are household savings at their lowest in 50 years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, looking at total household savings as a percentage of total household incomes, although these figures don’t give the fullest picture.

claims.text: The Conservatives are cutting income tax for 32 million people.

claimReview.title: Is income tax being cut for 32 million people? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is the number of people who will be paying less income tax in real terms in 2019/20 than in 2015/16.  

We haven’t been able to exactly replicate the figure as some of the underlying data isn’t publicly accessible – but it seems in the right ballpark.

claims.text: By the end of January 2022, all vaccinated Germans will have AIDS and be 100% more vulnerable to Covid infections.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated Germans won’t have AIDS by the end of January 2022 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures this article is based on have since been corrected. There is no evidence that vaccines cause AIDS, that declining efficacy from a Covid vaccine would cause AIDS or that being vaccinated reduces your protection against Covid.

claims.text: The Covid-19 variants have planned release dates, as shown by a document from the WHO, John Hopkins University, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the World Economic forum.

claimReview.title: Grant Shapps misspoke about double vaccinated people on BBC Breakfast - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This document appears to be fake. There is no evidence that the Covid-19 variants are being planned.

claims.text: One in three nurses are over 50.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly correct according to NHS figures from 2014.

claims.text: Finland is going to have a four-day working week and six-hour days.

claimReview.title: Finland is not going to have a four-day working week. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not Finnish government policy. The Finnish Prime Minister did suggest the idea on a panel in 2019 while she was Minister for Transport.

claims.text: Government debt has doubled under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Labour and Conservative records on the national debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. Public sector net debt, adjusted for inflation, rose by 53% between 2009/10 and 2016/17.

claims.text: Standing next to a mobile phone antenna or staying too long in its vicinity is a radiation risk.

claimReview.title: Mobile phone base stations like this do not pose a radiation risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not true. Masts like the one in the image are safe to stand near.

claims.text: We hit 10,000 tests a day by the end of March.

claimReview.title: Government misses one of its Covid-19 test targets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know. Fewer than 10,000 people were tested on each day in March, but that could have involved more than 10,000 tests. Data on the number of tests only started to be published in full on 6 April.

claims.text: Top universities make offers to 55% of white applicants, but only to 23% of black ones.

claimReview.title: Are white applicants more likely to receive offers to top universities than black applicants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are correct, according to research looking at offers made by Russell Group universities, although they relate to applications rather than applicants. The reasons for the difference are complex - research has had conflicting findings on whether there is underlying discrimination.

claims.text: Last week Sir Patrick Vallance and Prof Chris Whitty presented a graph which cherry-picked several hospitals on course to run out of beds, despite falling or flat rates of Covid-19 bed occupancy across the country.

claimReview.title: Telegraph wrong on Whitty and Vallance statements - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sir Patrick and Professor Whitty did not present any data on individual hospital bed occupancy figures last week. This may refer to data they presented at the end of October. On 26 November Sir Patrick said the number of Covid-19 patients in hospital was flattening.

claims.text: A man was fined £50 for burning poppies.

claimReview.title: Two men did go to prison for throwing bacon at a mosque, while a man was fined for burning poppies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. Emdadur Choudhury was fined after burning poppies in 2011.

claims.text: The Conservatives are polling 38% in North East Somerset, the Liberal Democrats are on 32%, and Labour are on 8%.

claimReview.title: You need to read the small print on this Lib Dem voting intention graph - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are the results of a poll asking how people in the area would vote if only the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives were competitive.

claims.text: Boris Johnson wrote a letter asking the public for their thoughts on mandatory RFID microchips.

claimReview.title: No, the government is not proposing to inject the public with tracking microchips - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This letter is fake. No such policy is being proposed.

claims.text: By 2010, 76% of pupils in England were achieving five good GCSEs, compared to 45% in 1997.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: A little girl called Alice has been kidnapped from various areas in the UK.

claimReview.title: This little girl called Alice has not been kidnapped from your area - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a legitimate missing person case. It is a phishing scam.

claims.text: 915 children were admitted with malnutrition in Cambridge hospitals between 2015 and 2020. There were 656 similar admissions at Newcastle hospitals, and 656 at the Royal Free London hospitals.

claimReview.title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These numbers seem to refer to all admissions, not children only. The correct figures for children are 33, 71 and 11.

claims.text: A photo of dozens of lightning strikes was taken recently in Caldbeck, the Lake District.

claimReview.title: Claims that a 2011 lightning composite picture were taken in the Lake District are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture was taken in 2011 on the Greek Island of Ikaria.

claims.text: A famous photo of Earth published in 2002 is a composite image or “photoshop”. It also pastes copies of clouds across the surface.

claimReview.title: NASA didn’t paste a picture of the Earth into photos from the moon - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image from 2002 is a composite image but made up of thousands of files worth of real data. The image’s creator said clouds in some places were duplicated but it is not a cover-up or hoax.

claims.text: The English countryside is too white and needs more ethnic minorities, says government report.

claimReview.title: A government report didn’t say the countryside was “too white” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report didn’t say the countryside was “too white”. It said ethnic minorities should be encouraged to visit national parks and other areas of outstanding natural beauty. It also said minorities should have better representation on these organisations’ boards.

claims.text: £350 million has been invested in projects that will fall on the wrong side of the cut-off deadline for the Renewables Obligation (RO) subsidy.

claimReview.title: Onshore wind: how much investment would be affected by early closure of the subsidy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This much has been invested in some of the projects expected to qualify for the RO before the early closure was announced, according to an industry body. It’s not known how many of those projects will miss out on funding due to the early closure.

claims.text: MPs get £5,435 to feed each of their own children, on top of their salary.

claimReview.title: What extra expenses can MPs claim if they have children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If MPs are outside of London they can claim the cost of rent on a home either in London or their constituency. As part of this rental budget, they can claim an extra £5,500 per child under 18, up to three children.

claims.text: A quarter of the energy we use in Britain today comes from wind.

claimReview.title: About 15% of the UK’s electricity comes from wind - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s a snapshot picture when wind is generating an unusually high amount of electricity. Over the course of a year, about 15% of the UK’s electricity comes from wind power.

claims.text: England’s test and trace service reaches contacts at a cost of approximately £10,000 each.

claimReview.title: No, contact tracing doesn’t cost £10,000 per contact - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misleading calculation based on the total cost of the test and trace service, which is mainly spent on testing and not tracing.

claims.text: Mosquitoes kill 2,740 people every day.

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears to be an overestimate. Mosquitoes are responsible for no more than around 700,000 deaths per year, or 1,900 a day.

claims.text: The saving to the public purse from closing the Renewables Obligation (RO) to onshore wind a year early is up to £270 million a year.
claims.claimant: Amber Rudd, Secretary of State for Energy and Climate Change

claimReview.title: What effect on the public purse would closing the Renewables Obligation early have? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government won't improve its finances by closing the RO early, as the scheme is paid for by energy suppliers and their consumers. £270 million is the government's upper estimate of how much the closure could save them.

claims.text: Giving all children a daily free meal at school improves their results.

claimReview.title: Free school meals and educational performance - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s the conclusion of a prominent study of a pilot programme carried out a few years ago, although some of its authors have cautioned against it being used to justify the roll-out of this policy nationwide. Older studies have pointed in the same direction.

claims.text: Nine regions voted to leave and three voted to remain in the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The UK has lost its measles free status just three years after the virus was eliminated.
claims.claimant: Department of Health and Social Care

claimReview.title: Being ‘measles free’ doesn’t mean there are no cases of measles - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The World Health Organisation no longer judges measles to have been eliminated in the UK – but that doesn’t mean there was ever a year when there were no cases of the disease.

claims.text: You should stay at home for two weeks after receiving the flu vaccine.

claimReview.title: You do not need to stay home for two weeks after getting the flu vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is exaggerated. Only children who have been vaccinated with the flu vaccine nasal spray should avoid close contact with people who have severely weakened immune systems for two weeks.

claims.text: The government will be putting more money into the NHS over the next five years, £394 million more a week.

claimReview.title: NHS England: £394 million more a week? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending increases announced for NHS England’s budget mean that £20.5 billion more will be spent on it in 2023/24 than in 2018/19. That’s £394 million more a week by 2023/24. This money doesn’t cover all health spending.

claims.text: There is more money going into our schools than ever before—a record £43.5 billion by 2020.

claimReview.title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not a helpful figure as it doesn’t account for inflation or pupil numbers.  Spending per pupil in England fell by 8% in real terms from 2009/10 to 2017/18, and will be held constant from 2017/18 to 2019/20.

claims.text: Refugees or illegal immigrants living in Britain get a total yearly benefit of £29,900.

claimReview.title: This image on benefits for pensioners and refugees is not correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Illegal immigrants cannot collect benefits. Refugees can on the same basis as UK nationals once their request for asylum is granted—but this figure is unusually high.

claims.text: The government’s own research says that Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to a 6.7% drop in GDP.

claimReview.title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government estimated a free trade agreement Brexit could lead to GDP being 6.7% lower after 15 years than if the UK remained in the EU. That’s not the same as saying this form of Brexit will lead to a drop in GDP compared to now.

claims.text: Vaccines contain ingredients known to cause cancer.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that any current vaccines cause cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No vaccines given in the UK contain enough of any chemical to be carcinogenic.

claims.text: Asylum seekers have to live on just £37.75 per week.

claimReview.title: Comparing tax dodging and benefits for people seeking asylum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People seeking asylum who are homeless or can’t afford food typically receive £37.75 per week. The level is slightly higher for young children and pregnant women or new mothers. This is in addition to furnished housing and utilities which are provided for no cost.

claims.text: Licensed gambling has grown 57% over the last decade.

claimReview.title: Gambling spend down since 2008 on average - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Gambling yield has grown 57% over the last decade if you exclude the National Lottery. Including the National Lottery it has grown 40%. However, this growth is largely due to the changes in how online gambling is classified. This growth doesn’t necessarily mean people are gambling more.

claims.text: The government has taken millions of people out of paying income tax.

claimReview.title: Income tax cuts for basic rate payers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Increases in the personal allowance since 2010 mean four million additional people now below the threshold don’t pay income tax.

claims.text: 27% of Conservative voters say they will ditch Boris Johnson over bike lanes.

claimReview.title: Survey doesn’t show voters ditching Conservatives over bike lanes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are too many problems with this survey to draw this conclusion.

claims.text: Images online show the rubbish left behind after the 2019 Glastonbury festival.

claimReview.title: These are photos of rubbish left after various Glastonbury festivals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The images are of Glastonbury Festival; some of the images are of this year’s festival, although others are older.

claims.text: Wales has a fiscal deficit worth just under 25% of its GDP, compared to the UK deficit of 5%.

claimReview.title: Wales’s fiscal deficit: the gap between tax and spend - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was correct in 2014/15, according to estimates from Cardiff University. This is the most recent year we’ve seen estimates for. The scale of the difference seems likely to be similar now, even if the figures are smaller.

claims.text: One in four pregnancies in England and Wales ends in abortion.

claimReview.title: Abortion rate lower than claimed as miscarriages not factored in - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This data does not include pregnancies which end in miscarriage. If the data factored these in, the proportion of all pregnancies which end in abortion would likely be considerably lower.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines offer very little protection against the disease.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines are very effective - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The claim is based on a misinterpretation of a Lancet comment article, which compared different ways of measuring effectiveness. It did not refute the headline figures that have already been reported.

claims.text: The death rate from heart disease has increased for the first time in 50 years.

claimReview.title: The heart disease death rate isn’t increasing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The death rate continues to fall.

claims.text: The studies into Covid-19 vaccines are too short to see if there are late effects. There were narcolepsy cases after the swine flu vaccination, and similarly this vaccine could put millions at risk.

claimReview.title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that the swine flu vaccine was associated with a small increase in the risk of narcolepsy in children and young people. But the vaccine’s effects will continue to be monitored as it is rolled out, and so far it is not being given to children.

claims.text: There are 1.9 million more children studying in good or outstanding schools since 2010.

claimReview.title: Nearly 2 million more children are in good or outstanding schools since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, comparing Ofsted ratings between 2010 and 2017. This progress has been influenced by Ofsted’s changing inspection practices—which refined what was expected of schools and placed a greater emphasis on inspecting schools which fell below this expectation.

claims.text: The UK has created more jobs than the rest of the EU put together.

claimReview.title: Has the UK created more jobs than the rest of the EU combined? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has seen a larger rise in employment than the rest of the EU combined. Some countries have seen employment fall since 2010, so the comparison isn't that useful.

claims.text: The last government repatriated 100 powers from Brussels.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: have 100 EU 'powers' been returned to the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Lisbon Treaty, negotiated under the previous Labour government, allowed the Coalition to reclaim around 100 'powers' (specific legislative acts).

claims.text: The UK is the only G7 country to be reducing aid spending in 2021.

claimReview.title: The UK will cut aid this year, but barely did last year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This may be true, but we don’t yet have enough evidence to be sure. The UK certainly plans to reduce aid spending significantly in 2021. Most other G7 countries plan to increase it. We don’t yet know whether they all will, on all measures.

claims.text: Net migration to the UK could be 100,000 higher after Brexit under the government’s plans.

claimReview.title: Here’s why Migration Watch got their study on post-Brexit immigration wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study this is based on is inaccurate and has been withdrawn.

claims.text: The AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson vaccines contain aborted human and monkey cells.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Partly false. Both vaccines use cell lines derived from aborted foetal cells but those cells do not make it into the final vaccine. Neither contain or use monkey cells.

claims.text: Japanese-owned companies have made it clear that their investment in the UK depends on access to the Single Market.

claimReview.title: Japanese-owned companies in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Japanese government has sent a formal statement to the EU and UK, outlining what Japanese businesses would like a future trade agreement to look like. It raises the possibility that Japanese firms will relocate their European base from the UK to mainland Europe if barriers to investment are too high.

claims.text: Many graduates will not pay back their student debt.

claimReview.title: About 17% of students are forecast to fully pay back their loans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to forecasts. Estimates from the Institute for Fiscal Studies in October last year show about 83% of graduates are forecast to have some of their debt written off under the current system.

claims.text: Teachers at a school which Boris Johnson visited spelled out the words “Fuck Boris” on a wall which the Prime Minister was interviewed in front of.

claimReview.title: This image of the Prime Minister has been altered - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They did not. These words have been added digitally.

claims.text: There was no extra money announced for social care this week.

claimReview.title: Social care: what’s the situation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The Prime Minister announced more money would be given to the NHS in England and has said that the budget for social care will be announced at a detailed review of public spending planned in 2019.

claims.text: That the donkey in an image was being carried to prevent it causing harm by exploding landmines.

claimReview.title: Donkey being carried out of compassion, not self-preservation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The donkey was actually being carried out of compassion, and later became a mascot for the French Foreign Legion.

claims.text: 95% of applicants received an offer at one of their top three preferred schools last year.

claimReview.title: What's happening to secondary school places? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: An overwhelming majority of the public would support renationalising the railways, according to a poll.

claimReview.title: Do the public want the railways renationalised? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 64% of the 1,500 adults polled in June 2018 said they would support renationalising the railways. 19% said they would oppose it, and 17% said they didn’t know. The results are similar to other polls done on the question.

claims.text: The proportion of BAME young offenders in custody rose from 25% to 41% between 2006 and 2016.

claimReview.title: Young people and race in the criminal justice system - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England and Wales.

claims.text: The government is only reconfiguring six new hospitals rather than building 40.

claimReview.title: The government has given six hospitals money to upgrade buildings - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In its latest announcement the government has committed the money to upgrade six hospitals by 2025. Up to 38 other hospitals have received money to plan for building work between 2025 and 2030, but not to actually begin any work.

claims.text: Deaths from flu and pneumonia have been replaced with Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While the figures point towards a decrease in the number of deaths caused by flu and pneumonia, this has not just been replaced with deaths from Covid-19, which far exceed that possible shortfall.

claims.text: Kary B Mullis said that his PCR test was not made to detect any type of infectious disease. It’s designed to pick up a signature of DNA and RNA of the person being tested.

claimReview.title: The inventor of PCR never said it wasn’t designed to detect infectious diseases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He never said this. This is a misunderstanding of a quote from him about the limitations of PCR testing in general, to find out about the exact levels of a virus in a sample, not whether or not the sample contained the virus.

claims.text: There has been a 22% drop in ambulances meeting their 15 minute transfer target since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The decrease is actually greater—28%. In 2010/11 in England 80% of ambulance transfers were done in 15 minutes, in 2015/16 it was 58%.

claims.text: MPs can claim £50 for breakfast.

claimReview.title: MPs cannot claim £50 for breakfast as viral post claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. MPs can claim £25 for food bought during the day if they stay overnight outside their constituency and London.

claims.text: We let convicted terrorists out.

claimReview.title: Claim about the Kray Twins and great train robbers’ prison releases are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People convicted of terrorism related offences can be let out of prison, though they can also be sentenced to life in prison.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives British businesses the right to buy and sell across Europe without tariffs or checks.
