claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: A £20 billion funding increase to the NHS will be paid for in part through the ‘Brexit dividend’.

claimReview.title: Does the ‘Brexit dividend’ exist? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no guaranteed extra money to pay for increased NHS funding from stopping our payments to the EU budget. Other costs associated with Brexit are expected to outweigh the savings.

claims.text: The top 1% of earners in the UK are paying 28% of the tax burden.

claimReview.title: Do the top 1% of earners pay 28% of the tax burden? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t correct.  The highest earning 1% in the UK pay an estimated 28% of all income tax – not the total “tax burden”. This is close to a record level, but it isn’t quite the highest percentage ever.

claims.text: Bill Gates is a eugenicist who wants to reduce the population of the world.

claimReview.title: Viral video contains several false pandemic claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Mr Gates has promoted improved healthcare, which he has said may cause the world population to grow more slowly.

claims.text: The price of oil has fallen from $100 a barrel during the Scottish independence referendum to $50 a barrel. Scottish people now have twice as much reason to reject independence.

claimReview.title: The oil price and Scotland’s independence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The price of oil has fallen from around $90 a barrel to $50. But there isn’t much evidence this has had an impact on the proportion of people saying they would vote for independence.

claims.text: The number of children in poverty has risen since 2010, and now stands at 4 million.

claimReview.title: Poverty: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct, if you look at the number of children living in relative poverty and don’t include housing costs. This hasn’t been a statistically significant rise, and there’s more than one measure of poverty.

claims.text: 423 mosques have opened in London.

claimReview.title: Don’t trust claims about the change in the number of churches and mosques in London - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have an exact number for how many mosques there are and over what period they opened. There are 478 mosques, Islamic centres, prayer rooms and halls for hire in London according to an unofficial estimate. Some of these opened many decades ago.

claims.text: US food standards allow for maggots in orange juice.

claimReview.title: You can’t really compare rates of food poisoning between the US and UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US food standards set limits above zero for maggots in orange juice, beyond which enforcement action is mandatory.

claims.text: The number of deaths in England and Wales is below average for this time of year.

claimReview.title: More people are dying than usual at the moment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Over the final four weeks of 2020, the number of deaths was 16% above the 27-year average and 20% above the five-year average.

claims.text: Price inflation is “soaring” at a two year high of 1%.

claimReview.title: Adjective inflation: are prices “soaring”? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that consumer price inflation is at a two year high. But that’s far from a “soaring” rate of inflation.

claims.text: The Gates Foundation has 200,000 shares in Serco.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Gates Foundation bought 200,000 shares in 2019, bringing its total ownership to 3.74 million shares.

claims.text: Real household incomes are about £900 lower than forecast before the Brexit referendum.

claimReview.title: Are families £900 worse off since Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not possible to get this exact figure using publicly available data and the Bank of England told us its calculation was based on unpublished data.

claims.text: In 2016 and 2017 the number of students applying from lower waged families has fallen.

claimReview.title: Are university applications falling in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Application rates by disadvantaged young students and entry rates by young pupils from lower waged families haven’t fallen, according to UCAS.

claims.text: There was no Marshall Plan for Britain, only for Germany.

claimReview.title: This MP is very wrong about the Marshall Plan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s incorrect. The UK received more funding from the Marshall Plan than any other country. We received around $3bn, and West Germany received around $1.5 billion.

claims.text: The SNP has delivered 9,799 council homes.

claimReview.title: The state of social renting in Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This doesn’t include homes completed by councils without any government funding.

claims.text: The cost of mental ill health to the economy, the NHS and society as a whole is £105 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Does mental ill health cost £105 billion a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £105 billion is an estimate of the annual economic and social costs of mental ill health from health charity Centre for Mental Health. It doesn’t just count public costs though: about half of it is made up of an estimate of the cost to individuals from the lower quality of life due to having mental health difficulties. It’s an uncertain estimate.

claims.text: A million more pupils are in good or outstanding schools in England than five years ago.

claimReview.title: A million more pupils in good or outstanding schools? Not just a simple story of school improvement - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This progress is partly due to Ofsted's changing inspection practice - which refined what was expected of schools and placed a greater emphasis on inspecting schools which fell below this expectation.

claims.text: The NHS track and trace app is being automatically downloaded onto phones.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 track and trace app has not been automatically downloaded onto people’s phones - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. What has been added is an API, which can help Covid-19 tracking apps function. The official tracking app is not available in the UK yet, outside of testing in the Isle of Wight.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine was only tested on completely healthy people.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccines have not only been tested on healthy people as claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The trials of the Covid-19 vaccines did include groups of people with certain medical conditions. We are also finding out more about this through post authorisation monitoring.

claims.text: The Channel Tunnel cost £12 billion to build in today’s money.

claimReview.title: NHS Test and Trace cost £13.5 billion in its first year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen varying estimates but this is probably about correct.

claims.text: A video shows a theme park ride where riders are lifted to a height and swung from cables, before being dropped back down to earth.

claimReview.title: The ride shown in this video has been edited to make it appear more complex - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The swing part of the ride is not real, and the ride does not extend to the same height as shown in the video.

claims.text: The CEO of Pfizer said he doesn’t need to get vaccinated for Covid-19 because he’s healthy.

claimReview.title: Pfizer CEO didn’t say he doesn’t need to be vaccinated because he’s healthy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is a misquote from an interview in December where the head of Pfizer said he didn’t want to get the vaccine ahead of more vulnerable recipients. At the time, rollout had just begun. He has since had both doses of the vaccine.

claims.text: 66% think Theresa May is aiming for a Brexit that is too "soft".

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 40%.

claims.text: Half of nightclubs in London / nationwide have shut in the past eight or ten years.

claimReview.title: No longer partying all night - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An industry database covering Great Britain recorded 45% fewer nightclubs in 2015 compared to 2005. There’s no specific figure for London.

claims.text: Footage shows Boris Johnson being booed and pelted with plastic balls in Manchester.

claimReview.title: This video of a crowd booing Boris Johnson is not from the 2019 Conservative party conference - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The footage is genuine, but it’s from the 2015 Conservative party conference—not this year’s conference.

claims.text: A police car pictured has an expired MOT.

claimReview.title: Police cars don’t need MOT registration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vehicle in question did, but it doesn’t matter, as police vehicles are exempt.

claims.text: 3,250 people investigate benefit fraud compared to 300 who investigate tax evasion.

claimReview.title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber tax inspectors 10:1? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t comparing like-with-like and the DWP figure is out of date. The staff mentioned work on all benefit fraud and error and tax evasion and avoidance, not just the illegal activities.

claims.text: Crime levels on the London Underground are reminiscent of crime in New York at its worst in the 1990s.

claimReview.title: The London Underground isn’t as dangerous as New York’s in the 1990s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Riders of the New York City Subway in 1990—when crime peaked in the 1990s—were considerably more likely to experience a serious crime than riders of the London Underground are to experience any crime at the moment.

claims.text: GPs will be given £12.58 per Covid vaccine dose.

claimReview.title: The figure for a dose of a potential Covid-19 vaccine covers the cost of delivering the treatment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. This is an “item of service fee”, that covers the cost of providing this treatment.

claims.text: The UK is going through the biggest squeeze on its living standards since the Napoleonic Wars.

claimReview.title: Is wage growth at the same level as during the Napoleonic wars? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wage growth between 2010 and 2020 will be the lowest it’s been over any ten year period in peacetime since the Napoleonic Wars. Experts say it was lower around both the First and Second World Wars. There’s more than one way to measure living standards too.

claims.text: The latest government reshuffle means the government looks more like the country as a whole.

claimReview.title: How diverse is the government? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Following the January 2018 reshuffle, the government can appear more or less diverse depending on how you look at it. In any case, women and ethnic minorities are underrepresented compared to the UK population, and people educated at private school are overrepresented.

claims.text: Introducing a Land Value Tax would force homeowners with gardens to sell them.

claimReview.title: Labour’s Land Value Tax: will you have to sell your garden? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It would depend on how the policy was actually designed. Labour has only committed to considering the idea, as have the Green and Liberal Democrat parties.

claims.text: Adidas are the biggest user of kangaroo leather.

claimReview.title: Adidas, Nike and Puma use kangaroo leather in some products - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Adidas did not tell us how much kangaroo leather they use. Nike and Puma did not respond to our questions.

claims.text: Stopping all sugar intake will cause all cancer cells in your body to die.

claimReview.title: Lemon juice, coconut oil and stopping all sugar intake won’t cure cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this will lower the risk of getting cancer, or boost the chances of surviving if you are diagnosed.

claims.text: Pretty Little Thing products may contain chemicals that can cause cancer, birth defects or other reproductive harm.

claimReview.title: Pretty Little Thing products can contain lead, but probably not dangerous amounts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Pretty Little Thing states in its terms and conditions that some of their products may contain lead. However, it is unlikely the amount present could cause harm.

claims.text: More jobs — over 3 million jobs are linked to our trade with the EU, that's one in ten jobs (Source: HMT)

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on jobs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estimates show around three million jobs are linked to our trade with other EU countries, but don’t tell us anything about the number of jobs linked to British membership of the EU. Nobody is forecasting that these three million jobs would be lost if we left the EU.

claims.text: The vaccines won’t allow me to stop wearing a mask.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: From 19 July, the legal requirement to wear a face mask in indoor settings or public transport in England ended regardless of vaccination status. Businesses, including transport operators, can still ask their employees and customers to wear face coverings.

claims.text: Daily Covid deaths in the UK soared on 9 November 2021.

claimReview.title: Be wary of claims Covid-19 deaths “soar” on Tuesdays - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is missing key context. The number reported on that day was higher than the day before, but this happens almost every Tuesday, which usually includes the backlog from the weekend. The weekly average number of daily reported Covid-19 deaths actually fell on 9 November 2021.

claims.text: Life expectancy has stopped increasing in some areas and fallen in others.

claimReview.title: Do pension changes mean 37 million people working longer? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that the life expectancy figures in some areas of the UK have stopped increasing. Figures have slightly decreased in other areas, but it's premature to say that life expectancy is falling in reality due to the margin of error.

claims.text: Last year some nurses starting their career got a pay rise of over 15%.

claimReview.title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know exactly what Mr Hancock is referring to here but it doesn’t seem right. Nurses towards the lower end of the pay scale may have seen a cash terms salary increase of 3% to 12% between 2019/20 and 2020/21. These figures are lower when you factor inflation in.

claims.text: The gap in UK life expectancies is falling.

claimReview.title: Alex Cunningham and Boris Johnson both used the wrong figures about health inequality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not true. The life expectancy gap between rich and poor, and between the northeast and London, is rising.

claims.text: Many NHS staff will actually get a 1.7% increase to their wages.

claimReview.title: What’s the deal with NHS pay rises? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The government has proposed increasing NHS salaries by 1%. Additionally it will spend 0.7% more on increasing the salaries of around 10% of staff significantly while the majority of staff will not benefit from this funding.

claims.text: Migration has amounted to 80% of UK population growth.

claimReview.title: Migration drives the majority of UK population growth—exactly how much is debatable - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This combines a rough estimate of both migration to and from the UK and children born to immigrant parents. Without counting children, migration directly accounts for 60% of UK population growth since 2000.

claims.text: The EU says chlorine-washed chicken is safe.

claimReview.title: Does the EU say it's safe to eat chicken rinsed in chlorine? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The European Food Safety Authority has said that there are “no safety concerns” with the chlorination of chicken, but it has also said this practice might not be sufficient for maintaining good hygiene standards throughout the slaughter process.

claims.text: The flu jab contains formaldehyde, which is a human carcinogen and has been known to cause infertility and hormone imbalance.

claimReview.title: Image on flu jab ingredients is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Traces of formaldehyde may be in some flu vaccines if it’s used in the manufacturing process. But there’s not enough for it to be carcinogenic or affect fertility—studies linking these things look at people who handle it regularly as part of their jobs.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines in use are poorly tested experimental vaccines.

claimReview.title: Viral video contains several false pandemic claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The currently approved Covid-19 vaccines have all been through testing in multiple stages of clinical trials.

claims.text: People in the UK want to see lower levels of immigration.

claimReview.title: The UK’s views on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Polls suggest that immigration is currently the biggest issue for people in the UK and that a majority of people think it should be reduced.

claims.text: The UK-US trading relationship is worth over £190 billion per year.

claimReview.title: UK-US trading and investment: a special relationship - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at the value of what each country exports in goods and services to the other. The total value of this in 2018 came to around £191 billion.

claims.text: The Conservatives have scrapped the nursing bursary.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: 90% of people in hospital with Covid-19 are unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Lorraine Kelly and her guests were wrong about Covid-19 patients - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The true figure is more like 36%. However there are signs that unvaccinated people are the majority in intensive care.

claims.text: If the UK were in a customs union with the EU, we’ll be reliant on the European Union to protect our steel industry.

claimReview.title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Being in a customs union with the EU means we have to apply the same tariffs on steel imports as the rest of the EU does.

claims.text: Almost all European countries have a trade surplus with us, apart from five.

claimReview.title: Where does the EU export to? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over the last ten years all EU countries other than three sold more to us than they bought—Ireland, Luxembourg, and Malta.

claims.text: A High Court judgment legalised abortion in Northern Ireland in some circumstances.

claimReview.title: High Court decides on Northern Ireland abortion law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. The judge said that the current restrictions are a breach of women's human rights, but has deferred the decision on what exactly to do about it.

claims.text: An actor was hired to pretend that she had been hospitalised with Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Actor pretended to have Covid-19 for hospital training exercise, not for propaganda - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The person in the video was part of a training exercise in a German hospital. It was not done to create Covid propaganda.

claims.text: There was a major increase in the number of “short” positions taken by UK hedge funds when Boris Johnson ran for Conservative leader.

claimReview.title: We think there's a big error in that viral article about hedge funds and Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We cannot identify any such increase; this seems to be an error caused by looking at incomplete data.

claims.text: There are fewer police officers.

claimReview.title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of police officers in England and Wales has fallen by just under 20,000 since 2010.

claims.text: A video called “Dance of the Pope” shared on WhatsApp is a virus that will format your phone.

claimReview.title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a hoax. There is no evidence the Dance of the Pope video or virus exists.

claims.text: Airports have been built with foreign aid money where planes can’t take off and land because of winds.

claimReview.title: Was foreign aid money spent on an airport that doesn’t run flights? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: St Helena airport, which was built with £285 million of foreign aid, was unable to run commercial flights when it first opened due to wind shear on the island. But since October 2017 it has run commercial flights.

claims.text: Only 3,000 people have died of Covid-19 in England.

claimReview.title: Many more than 3,000 people have died of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Covid was the underlying cause of over 71,000 deaths in England in 2020 alone.

claims.text: A post claims influenza has been eradicated and seems to suggest this is suspicious.

claimReview.title: Flu deaths aren’t being miscategorised as Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While there appears to be very few flu infections due to various reasons, the flu has not been eradicated. Covid-19 deaths are not miscategorised flu deaths.

claims.text: Channel 4 is in receipt of taxpayers’ money.

claimReview.title: Misleading for Nadine Dorries to say Channel 4 is ‘in receipt of taxpayers’ money’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true in the usual meaning of that phrase. Channel 4 funds itself with commercial operations. Its debt appears on public accounts, but it also pays tax.

claims.text: There was more ice than ever before in 2015.

claimReview.title: There wasn’t more polar ice “than ever” in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The extent of Antarctic sea ice did peak in 2015, before hitting a low in 2016, but Arctic sea ice and the land ice sheets at both poles have been steadily shrinking for decades.

claims.text: NHS Trusts are in the worst financial crisis of their history, according to NHS Providers, with 80% of acute hospitals in deficit, although the NHS was in surplus in 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS trusts in deficit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 75% of acute hospitals are in deficit, according to the latest figures.

claims.text: New figures show the serious crime rate in England and Wales is rising.

claimReview.title: Why homicide is now 2,700 times more serious than cannabis - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New figures suggest recorded crimes are getting more severe, but they can’t prove that crime is rising.

claims.text: There are more homeless UK citizens than the entire population of Iceland.

claimReview.title: The estimated number of homeless people in Britain is broadly comparable to the population of Iceland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have definitive numbers but these figures are broadly comparable. The charity Shelter calculated that an estimated 320,000 people in Great Britain were homeless at the start of 2018. We don’t know how many are UK citizens. The population of Iceland at the end of 2018 was around 360,000.

claims.text: 1,000 GP practices have closed since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are around 1,000 fewer GP practices in England in 2017 than in 2010. Some practices may have merged together, rather than closing completely, but we don’t know how many have done so.

claims.text: The UK is the EU's single largest export market.

claimReview.title: Where does the EU export to? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right for the goods market. If you treated the UK as if it were out of the EU it would have made up 16% of the EU's goods exports in 2014. That's just ahead of the United States.

claims.text: A casting call looking for actors to play “hospital patients” suggests there aren’t enough genuine patients in hospitals.

claimReview.title: Casting call for ‘hospital patients’ was for NHS recruitment advert - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS has confirmed that the job advert was for actors to feature in an NHS staff recruitment campaign.

claims.text: Analysis by the King’s Fund suggests that 40% of mental health trusts saw budget reductions last year.

claimReview.title: 40% of mental health trusts have seen their incomes fall - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Prisons are filling up with foreigners.

claimReview.title: Are our prisons "filling up with foreigners"? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About one in eight prisoners in England and Wales is a foreign citizen. The percentage has been falling over the last few years.

claims.text: Since 2015, the UK has resettled more refugees than any other country in Europe.

claimReview.title: Resettlement figures don’t give us the full picture on refugee numbers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but “resettlement” only applies to a small percentage of the number of refugees a country might accept. Other countries in Europe have accepted far more people for protection as a whole than the UK.

claims.text: There was a decrease in Sudden Infant Death Syndrome in the USA in 2020 as a result of scheduled vaccinations being cancelled.

claimReview.title: No evidence for drop in US sudden infant death syndrome cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was a decrease in reports of SIDS to the US Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System but these represent a tiny proportion of SIDS cases. There’s no evidence childhood vaccinations are linked to SIDS.

claims.text: Increasing numbers of people are being referred to the Channel "deradicalisation" scheme, including a large proportion under 18.

claimReview.title: "Deradicalisation" referrals: young and increasing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct.

claims.text: In the USA there have been 387,087 reports of adverse events after the Covid-19 vaccination.

claimReview.title: Adverse event reports after vaccines are not necessarily due to vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Adverse event reports after vaccination are not proof that the vaccine was the cause.

claims.text: No country currently has a functioning track and trace app.

claimReview.title: Does any country have 'a functioning track and trace app'? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Multiple countries have launched apps, including Germany, France, Australia, Singapore and Latvia. However uptake has been fairly low, and it’s too early to say whether they will be effective in helping combat Covid-19.

claims.text: The UK is 15th in the international educational league tables, behind Vietnam.

claimReview.title: The UK's international education ranking - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2015, the UK ranked 15th in the world for the performance of 15 year olds in science, behind Vietnam in 8th place. But we’re not necessarily as far behind Vietnam as this might suggest.

claims.text: Gargling water mixed with salt or vinegar eliminates the new coronavirus from your throat.

claimReview.title: Drinking and gargling water will not cure the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.

claims.text: Greenhouse gas emissions fell by 8% in 2014, the largest fall in a single year.

claimReview.title: UK carbon emissions are falling - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s right for carbon dioxide emissions. Looking at all greenhouse gases, the reduction was slightly higher in 2009.

claims.text: There is a crisis in teacher recruitment and retention.

claimReview.title: The number of teachers in English schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of new trainees is falling, but more full time equivalent teachers are joining state schools than leaving them.

claims.text: MPs were forced out of hospital and their sick beds to vote in Commons.

claimReview.title: Did some MPs have to leave their sickbeds to vote on Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A convention allowing unwell or pregnant MPs who are on parliamentary grounds to vote without entering the division lobby wasn’t applied to a vote on the Brexit bill last week. This meant one sick MP, and two heavily pregnant MPs who wanted to vote were obliged to physically enter the lobby.

claims.text: When travel to Spain resumes, you will not need to have been vaccinated, you will only need a negative Covid-19 test taken in the 72 hours before arrival.

claimReview.title: Travel to Spain requires negative Covid test - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, based on the current rules, which may change. Spain has indicated that it may introduce vaccine passports but that these will not be compulsory. A negative Covid test is required.

claims.text: Ipsos MORI translates to ‘they die’ in Latin.

claimReview.title: AstraZeneca does not translate to ‘weapon that kills’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not really. This is what online translators translate 'Ipsos mori' to, but in reality it is garbled ungrammatical Latin. Ipsos MORI says its name doesn’t mean anything.

claims.text: Unvaccinated people are not dying from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Vaccines reduce the risk of death but don’t eliminate it altogether - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue, unvaccinated people are dying from Covid-19.

claims.text: Your belongings can be seized.

claimReview.title: The Control of Diseases Act was not changed in April to say you can be forcibly vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Objects can be seized if it’s suspected they are infected or contaminated.

claims.text: A group of 43 European countries and territories have far more people than the UK, but fewer Covid-19 deaths.

claimReview.title: The UK has had one of Europe’s worst Covid-19 outbreaks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. Although the list excludes other European countries with high death tolls, such as France, Italy, Spain and Belgium.

claims.text: £1.8 billion of money announced for the NHS over the next five years isn’t all new money.

claimReview.title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This depends on how you define ‘new money’. The Treasury will have to increase spending by this amount—but it is money that NHS trusts had already earned, but were subsequently told they couldn’t spend.

claims.text: Spending on schools is being cut by 8%.

claimReview.title: Spending on schools up to 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cash amount going to schools in England is rising and ahead of inflation, but spending per pupil is set to fall by 8% between 2014 and 2020, taking school-specific inflation into account.

claims.text: Citric acid is a poison derived from black mould and is deliberately being used to harm the population.

claimReview.title: Citric acid is not being used by ‘evil forces’ to harm population - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that manufactured citric acid is made from a type of mould, but it is generally recognised as safe. There is no evidence it is being used in a plot to harm the population.

claims.text: Half of everything we sell to the rest of the world goes to the EU.

claimReview.title: Do half the UK's exports go to Europe? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of all goods and services exported going to the EU was 44% last year.

claims.text: Since 2010 there has been a considerable increase in homebuilding.

claimReview.title: The housing supply has increased by a million in the past five years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, the number of new homes is up since 2010.

claims.text: The EU’s accounts haven’t been signed off for years.

claimReview.title: Is the EU’s budget ‘signed off’ by auditors? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Auditors say the accounts have been accurate since 2007. But they have historically recorded significant errors in how money is paid since their first audit in 1995. In the most recent year, they found a significant part of the EU’s spending was largely error-free for the first time.

claims.text: The NHS test and trace app was created by Serco, not the NHS.

claimReview.title: Serco didn’t build and does not run the NHS Test and Trace app - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Serco did not build and does not operate the NHS test and trace app.

claims.text: Two thirds of manufacturing jobs, and 50,000 manufacturing apprenticeships, are reliant on Britain’s membership of the EU.

claimReview.title: Manufacturing jobs and the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. Roughly 15% of manufacturing jobs can be said to be directly linked to demand from other EU countries. That doesn’t mean these jobs are dependent on the UK being an EU member. Both claims are based on older inaccurate figures, and use flawed comparisons.

claims.text: The average age of death from Covid-19 is 82.

claimReview.title: This Morning guest makes misleading claims on vaccine efficacy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true for deaths involving Covid-19 registered in England and Wales between October 2020 and January 2021.

claims.text: In January 2020 a new EU law means anyone who has an offshore bank account will have to “come clean so we can see how much they are hiding”.

claimReview.title: Claim Brexit is about concealing offshore accounts is baseless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no such EU law coming into place.

claims.text: Because of this, the healthcare workers administering vaccines will be tried as war criminals because they are breaking the Nuremberg code when it comes to consenting to being part of an experiment.

claimReview.title: People giving Covid-19 vaccines won’t be tried as war criminals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Those getting the vaccine in the national roll-out are not being experimented on. They must give consent to get the vaccine which includes being given information on potential risks of both getting it and not getting it.

claims.text: HS2 will only take a few minutes off the current journey time.

claimReview.title: HS2: is it faster? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Current government figures suggest that anything from 13 to 102 minutes could be taken off journey times from the north to London and Birmingham. This is comparing the current fastest times to the fastest times once HS2 is fully running in 2033.

claims.text: There are 400,000 people who don’t get the social care they used to following cuts over the last eight years.

claimReview.title: Social care: what’s the situation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of people in England receiving adult social care from their local council fell by around 425,000 between 2009/10 and 2013/14. Because of changes in the way the figures are collected we can’t compare this with more recent numbers.

claims.text: Coronavirus lives for 12 hours on metal surfaces.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on surfaces yet, it could be between hours and days.

claims.text: A video of Michael Gove dancing in a crowded room shows a Downing Street party.

claimReview.title: Video of Michael Gove dancing is from Conservative conference not Christmas party - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video was taken at Conservative Party conference in 2021.

claims.text: You’re far more likely to die in a car crash this year.

claimReview.title: The chance of being killed by a cow and other AstraZeneca vaccine risk comparisons explained - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Around one in 35,720 people in Britain die in a road accident each year.

claims.text: 50 schools in France have closed since mass reopenings last week due to new coronavirus outbreaks.

claimReview.title: 50 French schools have closed due to coronavirus cases, but it is likely these infections happened before schools reopened - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true but it’s unlikely children were infected at schools.

claims.text: Contaminated food from takeaways and restaurants is spreading norovirus.

claimReview.title: FSA estimates takeaways and restaurants are responsible for 8% of norovirus cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New research estimates that restaurants and takeaways are responsible for around 8% of UK norovirus cases.

claims.text: The new conditionality requirements for lone parents under Universal Credit will have a hugely disproportionate impact on women.

claimReview.title: Do new Universal Credit requirements affect women more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since April 2017, the “lead parent” of a child has been required to work, or be looking for work, for up to 16 hours a week once the child turns three. Some research suggests this could be more challenging for single parents—the vast majority of whom are women.

claims.text: Last year almost half of maternity units in England were forced to close their doors.

claimReview.title: This claim about maternity units closing is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
41 of the 89 NHS trusts in England that responded to an FOI request were forced to close at least one of their units temporarily in 2017. 

46 trusts didn’t provide any information and we don’t know how many individual maternity units had to close.

claims.text: Patients diagnosed with lung cancer after visiting A&E are five times more likely to die within a year compared to diagnoses after a GP referral.

claimReview.title: There are some mistakes in these figures about lung cancer diagnoses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. A diagnosis following a GP referral was associated with a three      times higher likelihood of survival after 12-months compared to diagnosis following an emergency presentation route.

claims.text: 68% of Wales’s exports go to the EU.

claimReview.title: Do two thirds of Welsh exports go to the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although this is counting goods exports only.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, we have to pay the £39bn Brexit bill we don't legally owe.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The divorce bill is now more like £33 billion, and the UK would be legally obliged to pay it under the terms of newly revised withdrawal agreement.

claims.text: As Mayor, Sadiq Khan produced a report to say that the Fire Services did not need further funding.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2016 a report commissioned by Mayor Khan recommended that the London Fire Brigade did not need its budget increased.

claims.text: Six council homes were built under Labour in Scotland.

claimReview.title: The state of social renting in Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This reflects a single year under the Labour-Lib Dem coalition in Scotland. Almost all social housing new-builds (several thousand each year) were started by housing associations during that time.

claims.text: Over 6,000 elderly people a month are kept in hospital beds in England when they are fit to discharge and it costs the NHS £6 billion a year.

claimReview.title: No source yet for £6bn cost of 'bed blocking' claim - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 6,000 was the number of people of all ages fit to discharge and still in hospital on one day in June. There were over 170,000 delayed bed days over the month, these are the number of full days each bed could have been used by another patient. The estimates for how much this costs vary, but none seem to be higher than £900 million a year.

claims.text: Aluminium is in vaccines and is linked to Alzheimer’s, dementia, seizures, autoimmune diseases, SIDs and cancer. Aluminium can accumulate in the brain and cause more damage with each dose.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that aluminium build up in the brain causes the disease. Studies show that the amount of aluminium we can get from vaccines (and food) is not enough to be unsafe.

claims.text: The rate of extra investment in the NHS has fallen by 68% since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although this refers to growth in all UK health spending, rather than just for the NHS. It compares the periods 1955/56 to 2015/16 (when health spending grew by an average of 4% in real terms each year) and 2009/10 to 2015/16 (when it grew by an average of 1.3% a year).

claims.text: Labour’s plan to introduce four extra public holidays could cost Britain almost £10 billion.

claimReview.title: Will four extra bank holidays cost us £10 billion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s difficult to say exactly how much bank holidays affect the economy, but most research seems to agree that they reduce GDP. The £10 billion estimate is based on research from 2012 and the consultancy that produced it says it's out of date.

claims.text: The National Health Institute in Italy has recalculated the Covid-19 death toll from 130,468 down to 3,783 directly due to Covid-19, or 2.9% of the total.

claimReview.title: Italy hasn’t changed its Covid-19 death toll from 130,000 to under 4,000 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Research from the Italian health authorities looking at a sample of around 8,000 people who’d died in hospital with Covid-19 found 2.9% didn’t have any previous underlying conditions, not that they didn’t die of Covid-19.

claims.text: NHS England estimates that 30% of A&E visits don’t need to be made.

claimReview.title: Are patients going to A&E instead of GPs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Primary Care Foundation estimated in 2010 that between 10% and 30% of cases attending A&E were of a type that could be seen by a GP.

claims.text: It costs £8 per day to watch TV in hospital if you’re 82.

claimReview.title: Does it cost more to watch TV in hospital than in prison? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Costs vary by hospital. In some hospitals in England some TV channels are free for a limited number of hours, or free in children’s wards during the day. In others it can cost £8 per day for the cheapest TV package outside of these set hours, and in some hospitals it is free at all times. We’ve not seen any differences in the cost for adults based on their age.

claims.text: Inhaling steam can cure Covid-19 by killing the virus that causes it when it is in the sinuses, before it reaches the lungs.

claimReview.title: There’s no proof steam inhalation cures Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that this is the case.

claims.text: 2 nurses who were in ITU in Swansea have died today. 3 more still ventilated. All from the same unit.

claimReview.title: Claims about Swansea nurses dying in intensive care were false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: The EU is asking for a 100 billion Brexit divorce bill.

claimReview.title: The EU "divorce bill" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU says that the UK should pay a share of money that’s already been committed to various projects. There is no official bill from them yet—and any bill will be a matter for negotiations. €100 billion is much higher than other estimates.

claims.text: New grammar schools may be required to set up feeder primary schools in poorer areas.

claimReview.title: The government’s proposals could change what we know about selection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is proposing and consulting on this option. Pupils' backgrounds are part of what makes current grammar school different from other schools, so proposals like this could mean that research about current grammar schools won't be a perfect guide to the impact that new grammar schools would have on social mobility.

claims.text: People who haven’t had the Covid-19 vaccine are not dying.

claimReview.title: Unvaccinated people are among those dying of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sadly they are. In the UK, hundreds of unvaccinated people died with Covid-19 in the last few weeks of 2021 alone. They are also more likely to die of Covid-19 than vaccinated people.

claims.text: London has a Muslim mayor.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Sadiq Khan is a practising Muslim.

claims.text: The new coronavirus is actually the impact of 5G exposure.

claimReview.title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect, the new coronavirus is a virus and there is no evidence that 5G is harmful to people’s health.

claims.text: If the new coronavirus is exposed to a temperature of 26-27ºC it will be killed, as it does not live in hot regions. Also drinking hot water and sun exposure will do the trick and staying away from ice cream and cold food is advised.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There have been cases of Covid-19 in areas with warmer temperatures than this, and we don’t know what temperatures the virus can withstand. There’s no evidence that hot water and the sun will cure it or that staying away from cold food can prevent it.

claims.text: Unapproved vaccine trials don’t end until 2023.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Pfizer and AstraZeneca vaccine trials have an estimated completion date of April 2023, in order to take into account samples from participants collected up to two years after their final vaccine. This doesn’t mean they are unsafe for use now.

claims.text: The UK has the worst Covid death toll in Europe.

claimReview.title: The UK does not have the worst death toll in Europe, when you account for population - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As of 25 May 2021, the UK had the 14th worst death toll in Europe when you factor in the size of the country. It has recorded more deaths than any other country, but it also has a much larger population than most.

claims.text: A patent for coronavirus was granted in 2018 to the Pirbright Institute UK, founded by Bill and Melinda Gates.

claimReview.title: A patent for the coronavirus spreading in Wuhan was not applied for in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A patent for a different virus in the same family as the Wuhan virus was applied for by the Pirbright Institute, which receives part of its funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

claims.text: The Conservatives got 3.5 million more people back to work, or 1,000 a day.

claimReview.title: Counting Esther McVey’s record on employment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since 2010, when the Conservatives entered government, employment levels have increased by 3.7 million, over 1,000 people per day on average. That can’t necessarily be attributed to any specific government policies.

claims.text: Kobe Bryant’s wife Vanessa has died by suicide.

claimReview.title: Kobe Bryant’s wife Vanessa has not died by suicide - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false, and the website making the claim is impersonating BBC News.

claims.text: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) has increased at twice the rate in the North as in the rest of the country.

claimReview.title: Foreign Direct Investment in the North - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It's correct that the number of deals has increased at twice the rate. We don’t know how much each of these investment deals was worth.

claims.text: Austerity is to blame for 130,000 preventable deaths in the UK.

claimReview.title: We can’t explicitly link 130,000 preventable deaths to austerity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A think tank estimated that 130,000 deaths due to preventable risk factors wouldn’t have occurred in England if pre-2012 trends had continued between 2012 and 2017. It didn’t directly attribute this to austerity. It said that while spending reductions to public services were part of the reason for this, wider policy issues were also important.

claims.text: Hydroxychloroquine cures Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Hydroxychloroquine is not used as a treatment for radiation sickness - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is some limited evidence that it can work for some patients. It is not licensed as a treatment for Covid-19 in the UK outside of clinical trials.

claims.text: Those administering the Covid vaccines will get £12.58.

claimReview.title: A post about coronavirus vaccines gets facts about their safety, ingredients, and legality wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an “item of service” fee, and covers the cost to GPs of providing the treatment. Similar payments are made to GPs for providing a range of services.

claims.text: Jo Johnson became a director at Dyson a week after his brother Boris Johnson said in a series of texts that he would fix a tax issue that might have affected the company’s staff.

claimReview.title: The PM’s brother did not join Dyson days after tax texts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Jo Johnson became a director of the Dyson Institute for Engineering and Technology which is not the same as the Dyson engineering company itself, on 18 February, before his brother’s text exchange.

claims.text: The court found there was no actual bias in the awarding of a contract to Public First.

claimReview.title: Was Michael Gove right about court ruling over bias in contracts? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The question the court was asked to determine was whether the award of the contract was unlawful because of “apparent bias”. The judgment explicitly states that there was no suggestion of actual bias (it was not an issue that the court was asked to address). The court ruled there was apparent bias and therefore the award of the contract was unlawful.

claims.text: The gap between productivity in London and the UK’s 2nd, 3rd and 4th cities is greater than in any other major economy in the world.

claimReview.title: Productivity in the UK workplace: London vs. the rest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is a significant ‘productivity gap’ between London and other cities in the UK; and it does seem to be relatively large compared to the largest European economies. We haven’t seen an analysis wide-ranging enough to claim that it’s greater than all other major economies.

claims.text: Researchers at the Erasmus Medical Center claim to have found an antibody against coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Researchers in the Netherlands have released research, which has not yet been peer-reviewed, on an antibody against the new coronavirus.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, the NHS waiting list has increased by 70%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In May 2019 there were 4.4 million referrals for treatment on the NHS in England, where the treatment had not yet begun. That’s an increase of 70% compared to May 2010. The period covers coalition and Conservative governments.

claims.text: Postal ballots date of birth section is being pre-filled with the year starting “19”, and this could suppress young voter turnout.

claimReview.title: Councils aren’t using pre-filled postal ballots to suppress the youth vote - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Postal voters should receive a ballot with the correct first two digits of their year of birth prefilled; this is to prevent people from erroneously writing the wrong date.

If they do receive a ballot with the wrong first two digits, they should just cross them out and write the correct ones.

claims.text: 86% of austerity has fallen on women.

claimReview.title: Has 86% of austerity fallen on women? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The House of Commons Library estimates that, looking at all changes to taxes and benefits from 2010-2017, 86% of the reduction in government spending is in spending on women. This is based on which person in a household receives a benefit or is taxed, so doesn’t factor in the “indirect” impact on partners and household budgets.

claims.text: A 12 year-old was taken by strangers and attacked.

claimReview.title: Avoid this report about a child attack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This article is highly suspicious and steals content from a number of unrelated stories.

claims.text: People over six foot tall are twice as likely to get coronavirus.

claimReview.title: There is no proof you’re more likely to get Covid-19 if you’re tall - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no proof of this. In the UK, taller men were more likely to report having had coronavirus, but this trend was the opposite in the US.

claims.text: 51% of journalists were public school educated compared to 7% of the total population.

claimReview.title: How many journalists went to public school? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 51% of the UK’s ‘top 100’ journalists educated and working in the UK in 2015 attended a private school, according to the Sutton Trust. 7% of pupils in England attend a private school—that’s been the case for at least the last 15 years. Elsewhere in the UK the proportion is lower.

claims.text: Italy owes 1 Trillion.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Italy’s national debt is worth €2.4 trillion.

claims.text: The Rockefeller Foundation planned the Covid-19 pandemic under the name ‘Operation Lockstep’.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 pandemic was not planned by Rockefeller Foundation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is entirely false. ‘Lock Step’ was the name of a scenario planning exercise that examined what might happen in a future pandemic, but differs considerably from the current pandemic.

claims.text: Schools in the UK could reopen and the lockdown could be lifted in the next two days.

claimReview.title: Ignore these pranks on Facebook saying lockdown will be lifted in the next few days - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s incorrect.

claims.text: The NHS budget will rise by £22 billion over the next few years.

claimReview.title: NHS spending is going up, but other health spending isn’t - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct, but it’s less when adjusted for inflation, and non-NHS health spending is going down. The real rise in overall health spending in England is expected to be around £5 billion.

claims.text: The Mu variant of Covid-19 is “immune to vaccines”.

claimReview.title: Evidence so far does not show the Mu variant is ‘immune to vaccines’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Mu variant possesses a number of mutations, some of which may make it more likely to evade the immune system. However, it is incorrect to say that the evidence so far suggests the variant is entirely “immune” to vaccines, or that they won’t work at all.

claims.text: Everyone is going to be issued a digital health or vaccine passport. If you allow them to vaccinate you and test you regularly, you will be given more personal freedoms.

claimReview.title: The government has awarded a contract to develop technology that proves you’ve recently had a negative Covid-19 test - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A government contract has been awarded to create a Covid-19 negative test result certification app. This is not a vaccine passport.

claims.text: The UK is the best country for education in 2019.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have the best education system in the world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on data that measures public perception of different educational systems. It is not good data for objectively ranking education systems. Objective measures suggest the UK has a good public education system, but not the world’s best.

claims.text: Scientists believe that coronavirus may have come from bats in a Chinese research facility.

claimReview.title: There's no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus originated in a Chinese government laboratory - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Two Chinese scientists have published an article suggesting that the 2019 coronavirus outbreak could have originated from bats in a laboratory in Wuhan. However, apart from maps showing the proximity of laboratories, they offer no evidence to prove this.

claims.text: People can get up to £24,000 a year in benefits while working 16 hours a week.

claimReview.title: £24,000 doesn’t represent what most Universal Credit claimants receive - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This can happen. However, this amount is considerably higher than the average amount received.

claimReview.title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. These are the numbers of deaths registered in the UK for each year.

claims.text: Captain Tom and his charity walk has raised 15.5 million with over 750,000 people donating.

claimReview.title: The Maytrix Group receives no money from Captain Tom’s fundraiser - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The fundraiser was at around £15 million on 16 April. It is now at over £31 million. This doesn’t include Gift Aid.

claims.text: The EU plans to ban British kettles, toasters and hairdryers.

claimReview.title: First they came for the vacuum cleaners: will it be kettles next? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At best this is a stretch. It's not a ban: the EU is considering regulation which would limit the amount of energy appliances such as kettles and hairdryers use. A study into the proposals has been drafted, but no legislation has been brought forward yet.

claims.text: The UK pays nearly a fifth of all VAT going into the EU budget.

claimReview.title: Does the UK pay a fifth of the VAT going into the EU budget? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK is behind a significant share of the VAT revenue flowing into the EU budget. But it makes more sense to look at all contributions rather than a small part; VAT was only 12% of EU revenue in 2014.

claims.text: Bill Gates is a partner in the lab in Wuhan, China.

claimReview.title: Bill Gates doesn’t own the vaccine for or patent of the Covid-19 virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence the new coronavirus comes from a laboratory or is man-made. Bill Gates is not a partner in any of these labs.

claims.text: Scotland’s public finances haven’t always benefited from being part of the UK.

claimReview.title: Scotland's public finances - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Scotland’s was a net contributor to the rest of the UK in 2005/6, and for four years from 2007/8 until 2011/12.

claims.text: 160 MPs are for leave and 486 are for remain.

claimReview.title: How did different constituencies vote in the 2016 EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s pretty close to survey results of all the MPs just before the 2016 referendum. There has since been a general election and some MPs could have changed their view.

claims.text: 1.8 million people had to wait longer than four hours for treatment in A&E departments last year.

claimReview.title: A&E waiting times: better or worse? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for A&E attendances rather than individual patients.

claims.text: A poll shows that UKIP’s Paul Nuttall is set to win in the Stoke Central by-election.

claimReview.title: Don’t trust this Stoke by-election poll until we know more about it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know if this was a reliable poll. The information we need to assess the poll hasn’t been published.

claims.text: 87 people are dying a day waiting for care.

claimReview.title: It’s not certain that 87 people a day are dying waiting for care - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS data shows the equivalent of 88 requests a day for social care support from councils in England did not reach a conclusion as the requester died. There are a number of limitations to this data so we can’t be sure how true this figure is.

claims.text: If you have been recently vaccinated you need to stay away from babies, young children, pregnant women, immunocompromised people, the elderly, and terminally ill people for at least two weeks minimum.

claimReview.title: This post greatly exaggerates the risks of infection from people who have just been vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you’ve recently had a live vaccine, Public Health England doesn’t generally caution against close contact with any of these groups. Experts say that the risk of transmitting a virus like this is tiny and that in general people in close contact with these groups getting vaccinated is a major benefit to them.

claims.text: London tube workers wrote a humorous message in solidarity with Manchester.

claimReview.title: A tube sign expressing solidarity between London and Manchester is not a real sign - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t a real London Underground tube sign.

claims.text: There is a rising problem of mental stress among children because of exams.

claimReview.title: Exam stress for school children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s evidence to support this from children’s counselling services and the views of school leaders in England, but we don’t yet know much more about how common exam stress is across the UK more generally.

claims.text: Covid-19 patients have been misdiagnosed as having pneumonia when they actually have a blood clotting condition called disseminated intravascular coagulation.

claimReview.title: This post about Covid-19 and blood clotting conditions contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is incorrect to say that Covid-19 patients have been misdiagnosed with pneumonia when they have disseminated intravascular coagulation. Severe Covid-19 can cause pneumonia as well as blood clotting problems.

claims.text: If an asylum seeker is refused asylum, they get somewhere to live and £35.39 per person on a payment card.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, if they are homeless, unable to buy food and there’s a reason they can’t leave the UK yet. They can only get the payment card if they take the offer of somewhere to live.

claims.text: The Liberal Democrats were the first mainstream party to call for an in/out referendum on the UK’s EU membership.

claimReview.title: Were the Lib Dems the first party to campaign for an EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct to the best of our knowledge. The Liberal Democrats campaigned for this from at least 2007.

claims.text: The government has changed the definition of child poverty, meaning that figures showing no significant change since 2010 can’t be trusted.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: have the Conservatives redefined child poverty? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They haven’t changed what’s counted or how it’s counted. They did change the target. We can still use the original measures of child poverty to see whether the numbers are going up or down.

claims.text: The woman arrested at the Clapham vigil for Sarah Everard is the same woman who was injured in the 2017 Parsons Green Tube attack.

claimReview.title: Clapham protester is not same woman injured in Parsons Green Tube attack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. They are different women.

claims.text: Wash your hands frequently as the virus can only live on your hands for 5-10 minutes.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence yet on how long the virus can survive on the skin. But it is important to regularly wash your hands.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can last on the skin, especially not down to the minute. But you should regularly wash your hands.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can last on the skin, especially not down to the minute. But you should regularly wash your hands.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means the UK has its own justice system again.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
If we leave the EU with no deal, EU courts will no longer have jurisdiction over the UK.

However the UK will still follow certain international rules and regulations, such as trading rules determined by the WTO and the European Convention of Human Rights.

claims.text: The death rate in 2020 was lower than in the early 2000s.

claimReview.title: Death rate back to early 2000s levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The death rate fell considerably over the past two decades, as life expectancy improved. 2020 saw these improvements reversed.

claims.text: Wealthy professionals are most likely to drink regularly.

claimReview.title: The Pro-sesh-ional classes: Do wealthy people drink more regularly? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. We don’t have the exact data to confirm this, but high earners and people in professional jobs are more likely to say that they drink weekly than other people.

claims.text: Doctors in India have been successful in treating coronavirus with a combination of drugs (Lopinavir, Retonovir, Oseltamivir along with Chlorphenamine) and are going to suggest the same medicine globally.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: India’s ministry of health has advised that the anti-HIV drugs, Lopinavir and Retonovir, are used in some groups of Covid-19 patients. But it is unclear how successful this treatment has been. The other two drugs from the claim are not mentioned in their guidance.

claims.text: Sixth forms and further education colleges are better funded.

claimReview.title: Are sixth forms and further education colleges better funded? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends how you interpret “better”.

claims.text: People with Covid-19 should take aspirin 100mg and Apronax or paracetamol.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Trials into both of these drugs’ effectiveness in treating Covid-19 are ongoing, but haven’t concluded yet. Paracetamol can ease symptoms but isn’t a specific treatment.

claims.text: While Boris Johnson was mayor of London, crime fell by 20%.

claimReview.title: Did crime fall while Boris Johnson was Mayor of London? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a fair estimate using the best available data. The crime rate fell by 23% between 2007/08 and 2015/16, though this only looks at crime recorded by the police and there are other caveats to this data.

claims.text: A post claims that the 1918 influenza bout had a deadly second wave after quarantine restrictions were lifted.

claimReview.title: The 1918 pandemic did have a deadly second wave, but not due to quarantine being lifted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true the second wave of the pandemic was the most deadly, but it did not happen due to lifting of quarantine.

claims.text: Far more people have died of Covid-19 in the UK than in Japan

claimReview.title: Far more people have died of Covid-19 in the UK than in Japan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. At the time this post appeared there had been 31,855 Covid-19 deaths reported in the UK, compared with 628 in Japan.

claims.text: Scotland’s youth unemployment rate fell by 0.3 percentage points over the last year.

claimReview.title: Scottish government uses non-official data on youth unemployment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on experimental data so isn’t a “national statistic”. The most reliable data shows that youth unemployment in Scotland increased by 0.8 percentage points (from 8.9% to 9.8%) in the year to July 2019, compared to the year before.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means no more uncontrolled immigration.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK already controls immigration from outside the EU. If we left with no deal, the UK would have more control over immigration from the EU—as we would not have to follow EU rules on freedom of movement.

claims.text: Lockdown and the tier systems are deadlier than Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Letter to MHRA is filled with false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this is true. Official estimates suggest that the lockdown in the spring of 2020 saved many thousands of lives.

claims.text: More people are eligible for support under PIP than DLA.

claimReview.title: Are people with mental health conditions now receiving higher disability benefit payments? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s unlikely. PIP was designed so that fewer people would be eligible than would be the case under DLA. A quarter of people claiming DLA for mental health conditions did not qualify for PIP when reassessed.

claims.text: We now have 420,000 more people in employment than there were before the pandemic began.

claimReview.title: PM misleads on employment figures, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The total number of people in employment, including the self-employed, is 600,000 lower than before the pandemic began.

claims.text: No law is decided until Parliament votes on it.

claimReview.title: Laws can be made without a parliamentary vote, contrary to the health secretary’s claim - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some laws are created without or before a parliamentary vote, through secondary, or delegated, legislation.

claims.text: The current withdrawal agreement effectively keeps us in the single market and customs union.

claimReview.title: The withdrawal agreement is not a trade deal with the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The withdrawal agreement doesn’t set out the terms of the UK’s future trading relationship with the EU. That would have to be negotiated after Brexit. If the withdrawal agreement passed but no trade deal was then negotiated, the Irish backstop would kick in—keeping Northern Ireland aligned to some of the rules of the single market, but not the rest of the UK. The UK would be in a customs union.

claims.text: The Mayor of London has cancelled New Year’s Eve celebrations and will not allow fireworks but will allow fireworks for Diwali.

claimReview.title: Fireworks are not banned in London on New Year’s Eve - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Mayor’s New Year’s Eve fireworks on the banks of the Thames are not happening because of the pandemic, but fireworks in general are allowed up until 1am on New Year’s Eve, as they always are. This is also the case for Diwali.

claims.text: The UK can sign a three-page trade agreement with the EU and then trade tariff-free under GATT 24.
claims.claimant: Iain Duncan Smith, David Campbell Bannerman, Martin Howe, Jon Moynihan, Rebecca Ryan

claimReview.title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In theory such an agreement could satisfy GATT 24, allowing tariff-free trade on most goods with the EU. It would lead to significant wider barriers to trade, and the EU is unlikely to sign up to it.

claims.text: Bovine TB blood tests can give a false positive result if the animal has previously been tested with a skin test.

claimReview.title: Why it’s unlikely Geronimo the alpaca’s TB test gave a false positive - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems very unlikely.

claims.text: More testing for Covid-19 equals more cases and therefore equals more restrictions.

claimReview.title: Soft drinks shouldn’t be ‘tested’ with lateral flow tests and asymptomatic transmission is not ‘quackery’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Testing identifies new cases. The number of positive cases isn’t the only measure used to understand the spread of the virus. The number of tests and things like the proportion of positive tests are also used.

claims.text: Dominic Cummings said “Poor people are poor because they have inferior genes and brains. Rich people are rich because they are superior.”

claimReview.title: Dominic Cummings did not say this phrase about genetics and poor people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no record of him having written or having said this phrase.

claims.text: Fluoride is the same ingredient used in rat poison and Prozac.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sodium fluoride has been used as a rat poison in the past but the fluoride in that is at much higher concentrations than is found in tap water or toothpaste. Prozac’s main ingredient is fluoxetine hydrochloride – which contains fluoride but also consists of other elements in a very different structure.

claims.text: This pill can cause infertility.

claimReview.title: What are the possible side effects of the contraceptive pill Rigevidon? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS says it’s unlikely that combined contraceptive pill use leads to fertility problems.

claims.text: Jeremy Corbyn has voted against the installation of sprinkler systems in tower blocks and high-rise buildings.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no such vote that we are aware of.

claims.text: Dementia and Alzheimer’s disease are now the leading causes of death.

claimReview.title: The biggest cause of death depends on how you count them - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends how you categorise illnesses. More people died of dementia and Alzheimer’s disease than any other single cause in 2015 but, as a group, cancers were the most common cause of deaths.

claims.text: Two million people are unemployed.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 1.3 million people are unemployed in the UK.

claims.text: Taxpayers contribute about £4 million to subsidise food at the Houses of Parliament.

claimReview.title: Parliament’s food outlets ran at a loss of £9 million in 2020/21 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Catering services at the Houses of Parliament run at a loss so they are effectively subsidised. When the claim was first made in 2019, the latest data for 2017/18 for this cost was about £3.1 million. In 2020/21, the cost was £9.1 million, mainly due to reduced sales because of Covid-19 lockdowns.

claims.text: New data shows zero increase in suicide figures since lockdown.

claimReview.title: New data doesn’t definitively show zero increase in suicides across England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data, which covers an area of around 9 million people shows, on average, 84 suicides a month before lockdown (in January, February and March), and 85.4 a month in June, July and August. The researchers say this appears to show no rise in suicide "post-lockdown".

claims.text: Even the Government’s proposed new EU deal can be overturned after the referendum; it is not legally binding”

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: European law makers are expected to pass the laws necessary to sign off on the deal later this year. Once that happens, each part of the deal will be legally binding in one way or another. Many parts of it could still be challenged at the EU court in future.

claims.text: The UK’s gig economy workforce has doubled since 2016.

claimReview.title: Has the gig economy doubled in size in three years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although there is no fixed definition of the gig economy. This is looking at “platform work”—jobs that are found via a website or app and accessed using a laptop, smartphone or other internet-connected device.

claims.text: The UK paid £674 million in health costs to European countries, but received only £49 million in return. Addressing this could “transform the financial situation of the NHS”.

claimReview.title: Figures about EU health costs need more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures are broadly correct, using figures for 2015, although addressing this situation would in itself only have a marginal impact on the financial situation of the NHS.

claims.text: 650,000 jobs in London are dependent on the single market.

claimReview.title: How many jobs are dependent on the single market? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. Treasury estimates suggest this many jobs in London are associated with exports to the EU.

claims.text: A third of teachers leave state education within five years of qualifying according to new figures.

claimReview.title: A third of teachers leave after five years - that's nothing new - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is correct, but the figures haven’t changed a great deal for the last 15 years.

claims.text: Tommy Robinson filmed Asian men involved in a grooming case and went to jail

claimReview.title: These claims about radical Muslim preachers and Tommy Robinson are mostly incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Tommy Robinson reported on a trial in which defendants were accused of grooming young women. The trial had a ban on reporting until all linked cases were tried. He was imprisoned for breaking the ban.

claims.text: A study shows that drinking lots of tea and coffee reduces the risk of stroke and dementia.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t show tea and coffee cause lower dementia and stroke risk - Full Fact
