claims.text: According to German TV, there were 2.2 million at the People’s Vote march in London on Saturday 19 October.

claimReview.title: Unevidenced tweet about People’s Vote crowd size spreads to Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence any German TV station said this. Best estimates suggest the number was in the low hundreds of thousands. Two million is an implausible estimate.

claims.text: No-one is going to see a reduction in their benefits because of the recent amendment to PIP legislation.

claimReview.title: Amendments to PIP legislation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No-one who was assessed before the two recent tribunal decisions will see a cut in their payments. If the legislation hadn’t been amended then some of them might have seen their payments increase on reassessment. People who were assessed after 28 November may see their payments drop as a consequence of the amendment, as and when they are reassessed.

claims.text: Income tax and tax on whisky go to England to be spent on English priorities.

claimReview.title: Scottish taxes don’t subsidise English spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most income tax is kept by the Scottish government. Tax on whisky and other taxes go to the UK Treasury but when money is spent on England-only policy areas, the Scottish government receives money back.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines have been authorised on an emergency licence, because they are still in clinical trials.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccines have not only been tested on healthy people as claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Two of the vaccines have received temporary authorisation, and the Moderna vaccine has been issued conditional marketing authorisation.

These classifications are regulatory tools to allow approval at the earliest time possible during an emergency situation, as soon as there is robust data to show that the benefits outweigh the risks.

claims.text: 45% of young trans people in this country, modern Britain, have attempted suicide.

claimReview.title: Young trans people in Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t say how representative this is of the young trans community in Britain as a whole—the overall sample was not adjusted to try and be representative. It’s based on a survey of LGBT people aged 11 to 19, with 594 young trans respondents.

claims.text: Government spending on mental health services is now £11.7 billion.

claimReview.title: Total spending on mental health - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the right figure, but it’s only an estimate.

claims.text: The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine contains viruses from chimpanzees.

claimReview.title: There are no human cells in the AstraZeneca vaccine, and it won’t give you a chimpanzee virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccine uses a modified virus which was originally created from a virus found in chimpanzees.

claims.text: Theresa May refuses to allow the very best international doctors to come here to care for our sick.

claimReview.title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government limits the number of Tier 2 visas it grants each month. These are what non-EEA medical staff need to work in the UK. Nurses get priority access to these visas, but there are reports of some doctors being refused them due to government caps.

claims.text: German TV said there were 2.2 million people at the People’s Vote march on Saturday 19 October.

claimReview.title: No evidence that People’s Vote march had over two million people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence any German TV station said this. All the reporting we’ve seen from German TV and other news media outlets put the number in the tens or hundreds of thousands.

claims.text: There are 26,911 words in the EU regulations on the sale of cabbages.

claimReview.title: The cabbage myth returns: EU cabbage regulations don’t have 26,911 words - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. It’s a long-running myth that has been around since the 1951, and was originally about a USA government agency.

claims.text: Face masks can cause low oxygen levels in the body.

claimReview.title: Video shares falsehoods about face masks and asymptomatic spread of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The WHO has explicitly said that surgical masks do not cause low oxygen levels.

claims.text: Wages are lower in 2015 than they were before the crisis.

claimReview.title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Average weekly earnings (including bonuses) were lower in July 2015 than they were just before the 2008 recession, after accounting for inflation and seasonal movements in pay.

claims.text: Theresa May has increased subsidies for grouse shooting from £45 million to £84 million a year.
claims.claimant: The People Vs The Government, DWP and Atos

claimReview.title: Does the government subsidise grouse shooting? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Moorland in England used for grouse shooting is eligible for agricultural subsidy, though the act of shooting itself isn’t subsidised.

Data on the total subsidy paid to grouse moors isn’t published, though the £45 and £84 million figures are likely to be overestimates.

claims.text: One in four mothers-to-be have mental health issues before they give birth.

claimReview.title: Mental health during pregnancy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around one in four pregnant mothers included in a study by King’s College London had a mental health disorder when interviewed, but the study wasn’t designed to be representative of all pregnant women in the UK.

claims.text: Hundreds of convicted killers could be released from prison after a recent change to the law on 'joint enterprise'.

claimReview.title: Could killers convicted under 'joint enterprise' walk free from jail? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: People convicted of a 'joint enterprise' killing can appeal but the Supreme Court stressed when changing the law that it wouldn't automatically overturn all such cases. It depends whether the change would be relevant to a particular case and on there being a "substantial injustice".

claims.text: In 2013, US children got 46 vaccines and the autism rate was 1 in 88.

claimReview.title: Autism prevalence is up but scientists have consistently found that vaccines don’t cause it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US children were recommended to get around 13 vaccines, which involved about 53 doses, in 2013. In 2012, 1 in 69 were estimated to have autism disorders and in 2014, it was 1 in 59 (we found no figures for 2013).

claims.text: In 1999 the Labour government agreed a £2 billion settlement for miners suffering from bronchitis and emphysema. By 2005, 350,000 had received compensation.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government did agree this settlement, as part of the liability they took on for British Coal. By January 2005, 172,000 claims had been settled and another 180,000 had received a final offer. In total the government expected payouts to miners for industrial injuries (not only from COPD) to total around £7.5 billion.

claims.text: 53% of coronavirus deaths in Sweden are in care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The ECDC report says 53% of care homes in Stockholm county reported Covid-19 cases. 50% of all Covid-19 related deaths in Sweden amongst over-70s were in long term care facilities.

claims.text: People with Covid-19 should not take ibuprofen

claimReview.title: There’s mixed evidence on whether people with Covid-19 should avoid ibuprofen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are concerns ibuprofen can aggravate underlying health issues. There is no strong evidence on how ibuprofen affects Covid-19 sufferers yet, but some experts suggest taking paracetamol is preferable.The NHS has changed its guidance on the new coronavirus to reflect this.

claims.text: A third of the Carillion contracts with the Government were led by the Labour government.

claimReview.title: How many PFI contracts did the last Labour government sign with Carillion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. 38% of PFI contracts with Carillion in the published data were awarded during the Labour government. But published data only include deals up to the end of 2015.

claims.text: The government is bringing in a law that means unlicensed, untested vaccines can be given to people and no one is liable if they go wrong.

claimReview.title: The government is not planning to roll out an untested Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is not correct. The government was holding a consultation on whether it should change rules around unlicensed vaccines. Unlicensed is not the same as untested, and the manufacturer would still be liable if the product didn’t meet safety standards or is defective. 
Any vaccine given to the public will have to go through several stages of testing, regardless of this consultation.

claims.text: In the last year there has been an 8% increase in murders

claimReview.title: Have murders in London increased in the last year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Murder is down by 24.1% in 12 months of Feb 2012 when compared to 12 months previously. [17]

claims.text: £4.6 billion was cut from the adult social care budget in the last parliament.

claimReview.title: Social care funding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The report behind the figure says the actual budget fell by £1.6 billion, with the rest of the £4.6 billion attributed to more people needing social care and the cost of social care having risen. We don’t know how accurate these figures are, though social care spending did fall overall during the last parliament. We’re checking the figures.

claims.text: “Smart dust”, invented by Hitachi, has GPS capabilities and can be absorbed after being sprayed onto people, taken in food or drink or even injected.

claimReview.title: No evidence GPS ‘smart dust’ is being implanted in humans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While Hitachi did unveil a tiny chip in 2006, there is no indication it has GPS capabilities or that it would work after being implanted in the human body.

claims.text: You cannot catch Covid-19 person to person.

claimReview.title: Mask graphic contains a number of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Like other coronaviruses, Covid-19 is spread via respiratory droplets from an infected person to an uninfected person.

claims.text: A video shows an Uber driver throwing a disrespectful passenger into a fountain in Manhattan.

claimReview.title: Video of Uber driver throwing passenger into a fountain is a prank - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video is a staged prank altercation.

claims.text: At the time of the Energy Bill’s second reading debate, 1% of the UK’s electricity was being generated by wind.

claimReview.title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right.

claims.text: People from black and minority ethnic populations are most affected by detentions under the Mental Health Act.

claimReview.title: The number of detentions under the Mental Health Act is rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you're black and minority ethnic, you're more likely to be detained than if you're white. Overall, more white people are detained, since they make up a larger portion of the population.

claims.text: Shamima Begum has secretly returned to the UK.

claimReview.title: Shamima Begum has not secretly returned to Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true—we know Ms Begum was in Syria on 14 February 2020. She is banned from returning to the UK, and there is no evidence to suggest she has.

claims.text: Labour tripled the amount of help to the poorest countries and the UK became the first major developed nation to achieve the 0.7% of GDP aid target.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct the amount of foreign aid from the UK roughly tripled between 1997 and 2010. The UK was the first country in the G7 or G20 to spend 0.7% of GNI on foreign aid, but this only happened in 2013 - after Labour left office - and several other European countries achieved this earlier.

claims.text: We get less than half of this back and have no control over how it’s spent.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Based on the money actually paid to the EU less than half comes back as funding in the UK, which is ultimately controlled at EU level and mainly spent on farmers and poorer areas.

claims.text: Total travel and accommodation costs for Scottish Conservative MPs were £250,427 in the last 12 months.

claimReview.title: These figures on MP expenses are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This most likely refers to 2017/18 when Scottish Conservative MPs’ travel and accommodation expenses totalled £389,000, or £30,000 on average per MP.

claims.text: The UK gets £66 million of investment every day from EU countries - that’s more than we pay to be a member of the EU.

claimReview.title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: investment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £66m a day is the average for the past ten years. Our membership fee was £23m a day in 2015. Investment was £14m a day in 2014.

claims.text: The government’s Social Mobility Commission said the number of children in poverty is expected to increase to 5.2 million by 2022.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on an estimate made in 2017 which estimated child poverty would be considerably higher by this point than it is. For that reason it shouldn’t be considered relevant today.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets a £77 lunch allowance.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. MPs can claim £25 per night for food expenses if they stay overnight outside of their constituency and the London area.

claims.text: Staying at least 1m away from people cuts your risk of catching Covid-19 by 80%.

claimReview.title: Two metres is a little better than one - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, based on new research in the Lancet.

claims.text: Muslims failing to understand government messaging were responsible for Leicester’s local outbreak.

claimReview.title: Claims that Muslims caused Leicester’s Covid-19 outbreak are baseless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A failure to understand government messaging has been suggested as one factor contributing to Leicester’s outbreak, but it is not proven, far from the only possible factor and not limited to Muslims over any other community.

claims.text: Suicides have increased during lockdown.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is too soon to know what impact the pandemic has had on the suicide rate. There is currently no evidence of a dramatic increase.

claims.text: An earlier version of the Dubs Amendment specified that the government should accept 3,000 child refugees from Europe.

claimReview.title: The Dubs Amendment: 3,000 refugee children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: We have not heard of one police officer dying from Covid-19 across the world.

claimReview.title: Police officers around the world have died from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Many Covid-19 deaths among police officers have been reported worldwide, including at least one such death in the UK.

claims.text: Energy bills will rise by £500 million a year if the UK leaves the EU.

claimReview.title: Energy bills and Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. This is one estimate of the cost of leaving the EU’s ‘internal energy market’—but leaving the EU won’t necessarily mean leaving the market. And the estimate doesn’t make any attempt to count effects of Brexit on bills.

claims.text: Officers are being injured on duty at a rate of 28 assaults a day.

claimReview.title: Are assaults on police officers rising? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the year to March 2019, there were 10,399 assaults with injury on a constable, which equates to a daily average of 28. These numbers do not give the complete picture, however.

claims.text: The US is the largest economy in the world.

claimReview.title: The UK’s trade with the USA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s the first or second largest, depending on how you measure it.

claims.text: Mark Field MP tweeted in 2011 about threatening a girl on the tube and in 2014 in favour of beating women and children.

claimReview.title: These Mark Field tweets are fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tweets are fake.

claims.text: The VAERS website shows a list of damage and death caused by vaccines.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccine programme isn’t a medical experiment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it doesn’t. It shows a list of events reported after vaccination, not necessarily caused by it. Reports in the UK so far show no deaths caused by Covid vaccines.

claims.text: Since 2001, Scotland has sent £900 billion in tax to Westminster.

claimReview.title: England hasn’t ‘kept’ £450 billion of Scottish taxes since 2001 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The NHS has had its lowest financial settlement than any time going back to 1948.

claimReview.title: NHS spending: the lowest financial settlement ever? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The decade from 2010 to 2020 will see the smallest annual increases in UK healthcare spending than any previous period, according to experts at The King’s Fund and Health Foundation.

claims.text: Seventeen countries have banned the AstraZeneca vaccine outside of the UK.

claimReview.title: 17 countries haven’t ‘banned’ the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not the case. At the time of writing, 17 countries in Europe have temporarily stopped giving it out whilst waiting for a review from the European Medicines Agency. They have not “banned” it.

claims.text: England’s test and trace system cost £22 billion.

claimReview.title: Flawed comparisons between test and trace systems go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the amount allocated to Test and Trace for 2020/21 by the UK government but the actual level of spending has been lower than this. Also some of this money is spent in the other three UK nations.

claims.text: Six million adults were abused as children in England and Wales.

claimReview.title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct according to estimates from the Crime Survey.

claims.text: Prisoner Charles Bronson is due to be released from prison on 21 December.

claimReview.title: No plans to release Charles Bronson in December - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. A Ministry of Justice spokesperson confirmed to Full Fact that there is no planned release date for Bronson.

claims.text: You face hefty fines if you break these rules.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Businesses could face unlimited fines if they break government rules. Police can also fine people.

claims.text: Childcare costs in England have risen up to seven times faster than wages.

claimReview.title: Have childcare costs risen up to seven times faster than wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly the case for parents of children under two in London from 2008 to 2016, according to research by the TUC. The exact changes are unclear. In England overall it is three to four times faster.

claims.text: 330,000 people a day are being tested for Covid-19 under the Test and Trace programme.

claimReview.title: We do not test 330,000 people a day for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The real number, in England, is around 52,000. It will be slightly higher for the whole UK and if antibody and surveillance tests are included.

claims.text: The UK gets more in EU research funding than it puts in.

claimReview.title: EU research funding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although the UK pays more into the EU budget overall than it gets out.

claims.text: The average family are now paying £1,500 more per year for nursery fees than in 2010.
claims.claimant: Harriet Harman MP, then Leader of the Opposition

claimReview.title: Are childcare costs soaring? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The average price of part-time nursery for a child under the age of two has risen by this amount. Accounting for inflation, the figure is more like £890.

claims.text: Boris Johnson has said that climate change is a primitive fear without foundation.

claimReview.title: Corbyn claim about Boris Johnson’s climate change scepticism needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Johnson did not say that climate change in general is a primitive fear without foundation, but has expressed views sceptical of the scale of the human impact on the climate.

claims.text: There have been 1,517 deaths and 1,102,228 adverse reactions caused by the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Yellow Card data isn't proof of Covid-19 vaccine deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
These figures relate to Yellow Card reports. This is a mechanism to allow individuals to report any suspected reactions or side effects even if the reporter isn’t sure that it was caused by the vaccine. 

The MHRA says “It is very important to note that a Yellow Card report does not necessarily mean the vaccine caused that reaction or event”.

claims.text: The percentage of judges that are from ethnic minorities has fallen in the past year.

claimReview.title: Diversity among judges: a mixed picture - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is what the official statistics appear to show, but in fact there has been a slight rise in the proportion of ethnic minority judges compared to 2015. It's now 6.5% of those whose ethnicity is recorded, up from 5.9%. The apparent fall is due to a change in methodology.

claims.text: The case of Bell v Tavistock means it’s illegal to give teenagers the Covid vaccination without parental consent or a court order.

claimReview.title: Viral video makes incorrect claims about teenagers and vaccine consent - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not true. The case of Bell v Tavistock is only about treating children with gender dysphoria and doesn't change the law about when teenagers can give informed consent to medical treatment generally.

claims.text: The UK minimum wage is £8.21, and is soon to be £10.50. The EU hasn’t set a minimum wage.

claimReview.title: UK workers’ rights: what are the rules on sick pay, maternity and annual leave? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s the minimum wage for people over 25 in the UK. The Conservatives have pledged to raise the minimum for every over 21 to £10.50 by 2024 but it’s not yet law. It’s correct that the EU doesn’t set a minimum wage.

claims.text: Some government buildings in London are operating under sharia law.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Three government buildings underpinned a government-issued Islamic financial bond. The buildings are still governed by English law though, and haven’t changed use. Because they underpinned the bond they had to be sharia compliant.

claims.text: 1.8 million migrants entered the EU illegally in 2015.

claimReview.title: Did 1.8 million migrants enter the EU illegally last year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect as far as available figures show. 1.8 million illegal border crossings were detected by EU member states in 2015, but this isn’t 1.8 million unique people as some are counted multiple times. It’s thought around one million migrants came over the same period.

claims.text: A British navy captain tried to order an Irish lighthouse to move out of the way.

claimReview.title: Don’t believe the funny story about the navy and the lighthouse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is a version of a famous old myth.

claims.text: An image shows a young Palestinian girl who grew up to be a lecturer in Canada.

claimReview.title: Facebook post claiming to show Palestinian girl who grew up to be a lecturer not what it seems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The woman pictured is Iraqi, not Palestinian, and the ages of the girl and woman don’t match.

claims.text: Funding for schools has increased significantly in recent years.

claimReview.title: State spending isn’t at a record high when you consider the size of the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending on schools was around £50 billion in 2018/19. Spending per-pupil in England has fallen 8% since 2009/10.

claims.text: Under new government plans, murderers of pre-school children will be subject to whole-life sentences for the first time.

claimReview.title: How long do child killers serve in prison? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s already possible for people who murder children to be given whole-life sentences, but usually only in certain cases.

claims.text: Gargling with warm and salt water kills germs on the tonsils and prevents them from leaking into the lungs.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence gargling with saline will cure or prevent Covid-19.

claims.text: There has been an increase in far-right referrals under the Prevent strategy and in some areas of the country these are outnumbering other referrals.

claimReview.title: Far right extremism: a growing problem? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Home Office told us that "in some areas of the country, far right referrals under the strategy account for more than other types", but the data isn't routinely published so we don't know the exact figures. Across the UK the number of far right referrals has increased, but it is lower as a proportion of all referrals.

claims.text: Crime has been falling and not just because of the lockdowns.

claimReview.title: Falling crime is related to pandemic lockdowns - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There has been a small drop in police-recorded crime, not including fraud. This was mostly driven by reductions in theft. Crime levels over the last year have been significantly impacted by Covid-19 lockdowns.

claims.text: A majority of people want a new Covid-19 lockdown.

claimReview.title: Poll didn’t indicate the majority want a new Covid-19 lockdown - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is unsupported by the poll it was based on. 39% of respondents to the Independent poll were in favour of new lockdown measures. We don’t know how representative of Independent readers or the wider public those polled are.

claims.text: The cost of living for young people is made more expensive by government intervention and taxes.

claimReview.title: How much are young people taxed? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Under 25s paid about 19% of their income in taxes in 2016/17. Other government interventions may have had indirect effects on the cost of living.

claims.text: A report suggests an independent Scotland would have to keep the pound.

claimReview.title: Would an independent Scotland have to keep the pound and cut public spending? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A report commissioned by the Scottish National Party recommends that an independent Scotland' should keep "the pound sterling for a possibly extended transition period”, although it does not rule out Scotland moving to its own currency in the longer term.

claims.text: There were 3,700 drug-related deaths in England and Wales last year.

claimReview.title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct, there were 3,756 registered in 2017. Around half of these will have happened in 2016 because of the time it takes to hold an inquest and then register the death.

claims.text: Britain will be forced to join an EU army unless we leave the EU.

claimReview.title: The UK can’t be forced into an “EU Army” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The UK has a veto on EU military policy so couldn’t be forced to participate in an EU army.

claims.text: There is a 0.42% chance of an asteroid hitting Earth on 2 November.

claimReview.title: The asteroid which might enter Earth’s atmosphere on 2 November will not “hit” Earth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NASA says there is a 0.41% chance of an asteroid entering Earth’s atmosphere but, if so, it is so small it would burn up in the atmosphere before “hitting Earth.”

claims.text: House building starts fell by 45% under Labour, but have increased by over two thirds since the Conservatives were in government.

claimReview.title: House building: counting the government's record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but also reflects the impact of the financial crisis on house building. The exact time period you look at and the measure of building can have a big impact on how the figures are interpreted.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, the UK can't sign trade deals until at least 2021.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK can sign trade deals during the transition period but they wouldn’t be able to come into force until the transition period ends on 31 December 2020.

claims.text: Andy Murray is the first person ever to win two Olympic tennis gold medals.

claimReview.title: Murray wins a second gold, but he’s not the first - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Murray is the first to win two Olympic gold medals in singles tennis, but 19 other men and women have won multiple gold medals in all forms of Olympic tennis. He’s also the first man to successfully defend an Olympic title; a number of women have done so in doubles.

claims.text: Dr Elisa Granato, one of the first participants in a UK Covid-19 vaccine trial, has died.

claimReview.title: Fake stories wrongly claim Elisa Granato, one of the UK's first Covid-19 vaccine trial participants, has died - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. She is not dead.

claims.text: Four volunteers developed Bell's palsy after receiving Pfizer's Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Some on the Pfizer vaccine trials did get Bell’s palsy, but not more than we’d expect by chance - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but that’s about how many people in a group the size of the trial would be expected to develop it in that period of time. There’s no evidence it’s linked to the vaccine.

claims.text: A quarter of primary school leavers are unable to read or write properly.

claimReview.title: Are a quarter of 11 year-olds in England unable to read? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 25% of 10 and 11 year-old students in England did not reach the expected level of reading in their SATs and 22% when tested on grammar, punctuation and spelling. There are other measures of literacy which show similar or slightly lower proportions failing to meet the standards.

claims.text: A photo of a wolf pack shows how they are separated in formation based on strength, with an alpha wolf that pulls up the rear and controls the whole group.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about wolves makes howling errors - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image, taken from a documentary, actually shows a wolf at the front of the group, leading the rest of them. One wolf leads to conserve energy for the rest of the pack.

claims.text: Lateral flow tests could cause cancer or damage DNA because the swabs used to collect a sample from the user are sterilised with ethylene oxide.

claimReview.title: Viral video spreads misinformation about ethylene oxide and Ivermectin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Overexposure to ethylene oxide itself can cause health problems such as cancer, but there is no suggestion that using something that has been sterilised by ethylene oxide is harmful. It is routinely used to sterilise medical equipment.

claims.text: The percentage of state school students applying to university has fallen.

claimReview.title: Are university applications falling in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: UCAS don't publish figures on this. The figures we do have may be affected by local authority led schools becoming academies.

claims.text: A photograph shows a weasel on the back of a woodpecker in flight.

claimReview.title: A weasel did take a ride on a woodpecker - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image appears to be real.

claims.text: Disposable incomes of ordinary working people have collapsed over the last 15 years.

claimReview.title: Disposable incomes have broadly stagnated over the last decade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear what this is referring to, but over the last 15 years, disposable incomes have risen across all income groups. They’ve broadly stagnated over the last decade.

claims.text: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle’s home renovations cost £2.4 million in taxpayer funds.

claimReview.title: Was Harry and Meghan’s home renovated with taxpayer money? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The renovations did cost this much, and the money came directly out of public funds. But taxpayers aren’t financially worse off because these renovations happened.

claims.text: Ian Huntley has been found dead in his cell.

claimReview.title: Ian Huntley has not been found dead in his cell - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: The draft law that will start the process of leaving the EU has 133 words. The law enabling women to become MPs only has 70.

claimReview.title: The Article 50 bill - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Close: the 1918 law on women MPs had 95 words. The general point that the length of a law has nothing to do with its importance is correct.

claims.text: The fatality rate in Scotland is 13.9%, the same as in Italy.

claimReview.title: Be wary of social media posts comparing fatality rates in confirmed Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the fatality rate of cases of Covid-19 confirmed by NHS labs in Scotland, which is about the same in Italy.

claims.text: Ivermectin is a safe and effective treatment for Covid-19 symptoms.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Department of Health and Social Care previously told Full Fact that, based on available data, there is not sufficient evidence to prove that ivermectin is a safe and effective treatment for Covid-19.

claims.text: The government invested an extra £34 billion in the NHS, which was a record increase.

claimReview.title: Was Dawn Butler right about Boris Johnson ‘lying’ to Parliament? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the cash value of the announced increase between 2018/19 and 2023/24, but the real-terms value, which includes the effects of inflation, was £20.5 billion. There was an increase at least this large between 2004/5 and 2009/10.

claims.text: You might not be able to have children if you have the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Viral video spreads misinformation about ethylene oxide and Ivermectin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that any Covid-19 vaccines can impact fertility. The NHS is currently advising that it is preferable for pregnant people in the UK to have the Pfizer/BioTech or Moderna vaccines as they have been given in pregnancy worldwide to more people without issue.

claims.text: Serco runs the enforcement of the UK’s test and trace system, including the app.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Serco has had no involvement in the app. Its contracted work for England’s Test and Trace system involves running call centres and testing facilities.

claims.text: 21.2% of newborns in 2000 had at least one parent born abroad.

claimReview.title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About 21% did, although we haven’t been able to find a source for this exact figure yet.

claims.text: By the end of the last Labour government we had the highest NHS satisfaction levels since it was founded.

claimReview.title: Satisfaction with the NHS peaked in 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Satisfaction with the NHS in Great Britain was 70% in 2010, just after the Coalition government took office, the highest since records began in 1983.

claims.text: Breastfeeding reduces the mother’s risk of dying from heart disease.

claimReview.title: Breastfeeding linked to reduced risk of heart disease - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study in question found a link between the two, but not that one necessarily caused the other.

claims.text: Remain supporters burnt Union Flags.

claimReview.title: Some images of Union Flags burning have been edited - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At least one image of a Union Flag burning was faked.

claims.text: 5G wrecks immune systems and that is why people in Wuhan are suffering with this illness.

claimReview.title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that 5G can harm humans, or their immune systems.

claims.text: In Scotland, the fully vaccinated account for nine in every 10 Covid-19 deaths over the past four months.

claimReview.title: Why might vaccinated people account for a bigger share of Covid-19 deaths than infections? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. It’s more like eight in 10. People who have been vaccinated at least once account for around nine in 10 Covid-19 deaths.

claims.text: There are 10,000 people with Covid-19 in hospital in Wales, and 200 in critical care.

claimReview.title: There aren’t 10,000 patients in hospital with Covid in Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Welsh government figures show that in the week up to 9 December there were an average of 526 general and acute beds in hospital occupied for Covid-19 related reasons, and 39 invasively ventilated beds.

claims.text: Our hospitals have a large number of in-patients who are there only because they took the vaccine.

claimReview.title: MP makes unevidenced claims about vaccine damage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this.

claims.text: Covid-19 and influenza reports are being combined.

claimReview.title: Flu and Covid-19 statistics are being published in one report, but not added together - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but it will have no effect on the numbers, which will still be shown separately in the document.

claims.text: Four million people are on the waiting list for NHS treatment.

claimReview.title: Four million on hospital waiting lists - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, although the figure refers to each referral rather than individual patients. Around 3.7 million referrals in England were waiting to receive non-emergency treatment as of November 2016. Including those hospital trusts that didn’t submit information, the NHS thinks that there may be 3.9 million on the waiting list.

claims.text: The Wuhan coronavirus is a more virulent version of the normal cold.

claimReview.title: The Wuhan coronavirus has nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The new coronavirus observed in Wuhan is a virus in the same family of viruses as the common cold, but is a different illness.

claims.text: The government has secured almost £160 billion extra since 2010 as a result of tax compliance activities.

claimReview.title: How much has the government recouped from tax evasion and avoidance? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to HMRC estimates, but a large part of this figure covers money the government thinks it will get in future as a result of actions already taken, rather than money actually saved so far.

claims.text: The National Audit Office has said that 420,000 new school places are needed.

claimReview.title: Are there enough school places being created? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 420,000 places will be needed in primary and secondary schools between 2016 and 2021, according to the National Audit Office.

claims.text: One in eight refugees who claimed to be children arriving in the UK were in fact adults.

claimReview.title: How many child asylum seekers are found to be adults? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for unaccompanied child refugees, but is an overestimate of the proportion of all child refugees found to be adults.

claims.text: The EU parliament has 705 members, all elected.

claimReview.title: These figures for the size of House Of Commons, House of Lords, and the EU parliament are all correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct.

claims.text: The government are lifting the living wage by the biggest ever amount, up to £8.72, and it will go up to £10.50.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s first interview of 2020: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The national living wage set by the government is set to rise to £8.72 in April, the largest rise since it was put in place in 2016. It was also announced at last year’s Conservative party conference that it would rise to £10.50 within the next five years.

claims.text: There are 23,000 Syrian refugees coming to the UK.

claimReview.title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s a target for 2020, based on two government resettlement schemes. Of that target, 20,000 are specifically from the Syrian conflict. These schemes aren’t the only way for refugees to enter the UK.

claims.text: People working in restaurants and bars in Bolton that were closed because of local Covid-19 restrictions could not access any support.

claimReview.title: Andy Burnham was wrong about furlough on Question Time - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. During the local restrictions in Bolton, businesses were still able to make claims through the furlough scheme on behalf of employees who had already been furloughed for at least three consecutive weeks before July.

claims.text: Most people made homeless by the Grenfell Tower fire are not in permanent accommodation.

claimReview.title: Two thirds of former Grenfell households are not in permanent homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Just under two-thirds of the 210 households who were residents of Grenfell Tower or Grenfell Walk are not in permanent accommodation.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines weaken your immune system and make it harder for your body to fight the disease.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccines do protect against severe disease - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Covid-19 vaccines help your body to fight the disease, and are highly effective at preventing hospitalisation and death.

claims.text: If you are in a car accident when you have your feet on the dashboard, you may send your knees through your eye sockets if the airbag is deployed.

claimReview.title: You are at risk of serious facial injuries if your feet are on the dashboard during a car crash - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Car accident victims who had their feet on the dashboard have suffered serious facial injuries.

claims.text: The number of people going to Accident and Emergency is rising every year.

claimReview.title: An ageing population and A&E - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: A typical taxpayer pays £1,075 less income tax than they did in 2010.

claimReview.title: Are taxpayers paying less income tax than in 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, a typical taxpayer pays £1,075 less in income tax now than in 2010/11 but this calculation doesn’t account for inflation. It's around £850 less in income tax once this is factored in.

claims.text: Health and social care will account for 40% of all public spending by next year.

claimReview.title: No, health won’t account for 40% of all public spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s been estimated that health and social care will account for around 40% of the planned public sector budget by 2024/25, but this is only about half of day-to-day spending as it doesn’t include things like welfare and pension payments.

claims.text: Imports from the rest of the world rose to £20.1 billion, their highest since records began in 1997.

claimReview.title: April’s trade figures fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £20.1 billion is the highest cash amount of imports from the rest of the world in any given month, but imports were higher than this, when adjusted for inflation, for large parts of the late 2010s.

claims.text: The government is spending ‘record levels’ on mental health overall

claimReview.title: Spending on mental health services - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems plausible, but the government no longer publishes the survey that would show it for certain.

claims.text: More than 2,000 more fully qualified staff working in mental health trusts since 2013.

claimReview.title: Mental health staff in the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Working for a mental health trust doesn’t mean you work on mental health. This figure hides the detail: mental health nurse numbers in England are down, while staff in the scientific, therapeutic and technical group has gone up.

claims.text: Some grammar schools get less than £4,500 per pupil. Other state schools can receive as much as £8,000.

claimReview.title: Are grammar schools facing a crisis of funding? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2016/17 English grammars received on average £4,500 per pupil while other state schools received £5,200.

claims.text: In the UK on 1 July 2020, no one had been vaccinated against Covid-19 and there were 63 new daily cases.

claimReview.title: Vaccines have not caused daily cases to increase - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccines hadn’t been rolled out at this point, and there were 658 new infections on this date in 2020.

claims.text: Eating plenty of colourful foods could reduce the risk of Alzheimer's disease according to research.

claimReview.title: Reported study doesn’t talk about Alzheimer’s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This research did not assess the risk of developing Alzheimer’s.

claims.text: An image shows a battalion of the Cameron Highlanders in 1914, prior to being despatched to the front line, the next image is the same battalion upon their return in 1918 after the armistice.

claimReview.title: 'Fake' WW1 photo contains kernel of truth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The 1914 image is real, but the 1918 image appears to have been constructed to reflect the casualties suffered by the battalion in the first months of the war.

claims.text: Queen Elizabeth II has ordered 80 Manchester United shirts and asked for Cristiano Ronaldo’s signature.

claimReview.title: No evidence the Queen ordered 80 Manchester United shirts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to suggest this is true, and the account which appeared to first announce the rumour has since deleted the tweet, citing their inability to verify it.

claims.text: The NHS recommends washing your underwear and towels at 60C or 40C with a bleach-based laundry product to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: We fact checked claims about avoiding social contact and how you wash clothes in the face of the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not NHS advice on limiting the spread of the new coronavirus. It comes from advice on stopping the spread of germs generally.

claims.text: mRNA vaccines cause a variable response in amounts of spike protein expressed and therefore some people will produce dangerous amounts and could die, while for others there will be no harm.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims that you cannot refuse the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There may be variation in the amount of spike protein that different people produce after vaccination. But this does not appear to be an ‘uncontrolled’ amount, and there is no evidence to suggest people have died because of this.

claims.text: Labour are planning to raise corporation tax to a rate that’s lower than it was in 2010.

claimReview.title: Corporation tax: could we have raised more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct.

claims.text: Fibres from face masks and test swabs can cause Morgellons disease.

claimReview.title: Fibres from masks and swabs aren’t 'Morgellons' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is nothing sinister about these fibres and there is some debate as to whether Morgellons is a real disease.

claims.text: Each month 22 NHS patients with glaucoma unnecessarily lose their sight due to NHS treatment delays.

claimReview.title: Up to 260 UK patients per year experience vision loss because of healthcare delays - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Researchers estimate up to 22 patients per month in the UK experience vision deterioration due to health service delays, but not all from glaucoma.

claims.text: The latest figures show 28% of students who applied to Oxford University from the North East got in. 24% of people from London who applied got in. But only about 700 people applied from the North East, and over 9,000 applied from London.

claimReview.title: Where do UK applicants to Oxford University come from? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at applications from, and offers to, UK-domiciled potential undergraduates between 2015 and 2017.

claims.text: The Treasury expects the UK economy to shrink by 4.9% under a Canada-style deal with the EU.

claimReview.title: No, the Treasury doesn’t expect the economy to shrink if we sign a Canada-style deal with the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Treasury estimated that a free-trade agreement similar to Canada’s would mean the UK economy grows between 4.9% and 6.7% less over 15 years, than it would have if we had remained in the EU. But that doesn’t mean the economy will shrink.

claims.text: Nine in ten London newborns had at least one parent born overseas in 2015.

claimReview.title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About seven in ten did.

claims.text: Ten years ago no child had type 2 diabetes.

claimReview.title: This claim about children with diabetes is completely wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. At least 328 under 18s in England were found to have type 2 diabetes in 2009, though that study was not comprehensive.

claims.text: Britain has the highest rate of cocaine use among young adults in Europe.

claimReview.title: Are more young people taking cocaine? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have recent data for all European countries, but it’s likely – the percentage of 16-24 year olds in England and Wales who had taken cocaine in the past year exceeds all other countries we have data for.

claims.text: A group of puppies transported more than 100 miles died with Covid-19.

claimReview.title: BBC wrong to say puppies died of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. These puppies had canine coronavirus. It is not the same as Covid-19.

claims.text: You can’t leave your house unless to buy food, medicine or in an emergency.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not right. You can also leave to exercise, travel to work, take children to school or care for a vulnerable person.

claims.text: The monthly allowance for a single person over 25 on Universal Credit is £317.82.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit monthly allowance is more than House of Lords daily allowance – for now - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct until April 2020, when the rate was set to rise to £323.22. However, it has temporarily risen to £409.89 during the Covid-19 pandemic.

claims.text: They’re removing the reversing element from HGV tests to make them easier to pass.

claimReview.title: Reversing is not being removed from HGV driving tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The reversing part of certain medium and large vehicle tests will be assessed by an authorised third party instead of a DVSA examiner.

claims.text: The symptoms of Covid-19 are that it first infects the throat, so you’ll have a sore throat lasting 3 or 4 days. The virus then blends into nasal fluid that enters the trachea and then the lungs causing pneumonia. This takes about 5 or 6 days. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia, and the symptoms may not come in this exact order or at these times.

claims.text: Three British Airways pilots have died of the Covid-19 vaccine in the last seven days.

claimReview.title: British Airways is not in ‘crisis talks’ with the government about vaccinated pilots - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Four British Airways pilots have recently died but the company says the deaths are not “linked”. The MHRA says it hasn’t been told about any deaths of pilots after vaccination, and has not had discussions with any airline about preventing vaccinated pilots from flying.

claims.text: The Scottish government’s budget has been cut dramatically since 2010/11.

claimReview.title: Has the Scottish Government budget increased or decreased since 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It fell on any measure between 2010-11 and 2013-14. Since then it’s either flatlined, risen slightly, or returned to roughly the same value—it depends on what you include.

claims.text: The UK’s net EU contribution is larger than 26 EU nations combined (all but Germany).

claimReview.title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Technically correct, but this statistic is meaningless. In 2017 the UK’s net contribution to the EU was 18% of all net contributors.

claims.text: Tax evasion and tax avoidance costs the government £34 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Tax: evasion and avoidance in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong, according to the estimates it's using. HMRC estimates that £2.7 billion was lost through tax avoidance and £4.4 billion through tax evasion in 2013/14. £34 billion is the total value of tax that goes uncollected.

claims.text: A "cracked" trial is one that's dropped because a witness doesn't turn up or withdraws their evidence.

claimReview.title: When criminal trials are "cracked" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A criminal trial can be "cracked", or closed unexpectedly, for lots of reasons. Problems with witnesses aren't the main cause.

claims.text: Leaving the EU means there would have to be border controls between Ireland and Northern Ireland.

claimReview.title: The Irish border and Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s a matter of speculation at the moment. Some sort of customs checks on goods crossing the border would be needed, but not necessarily passport checks or stopping everyone.

claims.text: Despite pledging to meet net zero emissions by 2050, on current track the government will only meet their target by 2099.

claimReview.title: There’s not enough evidence to say the net zero emissions target will be missed by 49 years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour’s analysis is based on unfounded assumptions and the claim can’t be proved. That said, there is evidence the government is not on track to hit net zero by 2050.

claims.text: Six million people earn less than the living wage.

claimReview.title: Six million jobs pay less than the living wage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Six million jobs pay less than the living wage. That’s not the same as people. An estimated 5.4 million people earned below this level, according to earlier data.

claims.text: Mandatory vaccine certificates are being introduced.

claimReview.title: Facebook post makes misleading claims about Covid-19 passports and death rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There has been no suggestion certificates will be mandatory across all settings, although plans are under discussion.

claims.text: The UK's Syrian refugee programme is slightly ahead of schedule.

claimReview.title: Two UK schemes have resettled 11,000 Syrian refugees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct. Just over 10,000 refugees from the Syrian conflict have come to the UK via a government scheme from September 2015 to December 2017. The target for the scheme is 20,000 by May 2020. Individuals arriving before July 2017 had Humanitarian Protection, rather than refugee status.

claims.text: New Covid-19 vaccines contain levels of mercury that cause brain damage.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that mercury-based chemicals in a Covid-19 vaccine would cause harm - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most commonly given vaccines in the UK do not contain the mercury-based chemical thiomersal. We don’t know if future Covid-19 vaccines will contain it, but even if they do, there is no evidence that it causes harm in the amount contained in vaccines.

claims.text: Absolute poverty and relative poverty have both declined under this government.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Government figures show that relative low income was at the same level in 2018/19 as in 2009/10 while absolute low income fell by one percentage point. Another measure of poverty, produced by the Social Metrics Commission, does show a fall under this government.

claimReview.title: Child poverty: Boris Johnson's claims fact-checked
claimReview.textualRating: Relative poverty has increased since 2009-10 while absolute poverty has declined. But Boris Johnson has only been PM since July 2019 and we do not have figures to compare since his government began.

claims.text: Half of NHS staff will see an average pay increase of 4%.

claimReview.title: Are NHS workers getting a 4% pay rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for 2016/17 according to the NHS Pay Review Body, although we haven’t seen the figures in full. Pay levels have been frozen at 1%, but individuals will be entitled to more money as they move up pay bands.

claims.text: An image shows Gogglebox’s Mary Killen in an earlier life as a model.

claimReview.title: False picture of Gogglebox's Mary goes viral again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is a picture of glamour model Susan Shaw, not Mary Killen.

claims.text: Testing creates some revealing anomalies: the virus seems to understand the soft border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland, for example, crediting those to the north with a far higher rate of infection.

claimReview.title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that the UK is testing more than the Republic of Ireland. The Republic of Ireland had the world’s highest infection rate at the time of the claim.

claims.text: Fluoride is now being used against you in the water supply, toothpaste and medications.

claimReview.title: No evidence to back up these claims about fluoride - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Fluoride is added to the UK water supply and some toothpastes, and can be prescribed as a medication, to prevent tooth decay. The only potential negative effect of fluoride at levels recommended in the UK is discolouration of the enamel of teeth.

claims.text: Conservative councils save families around £100 a year more than Labour and Liberal Democrat councils.

claimReview.title: Do Conservative councils charge £100 less tax than Labour or Liberal Democrat councils? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The method the Conservatives have used to make their comparison is flawed in several ways and therefore pretty meaningless.

claims.text: A paramedic’s salary is £21,909.

claimReview.title: How much do firefighters, paramedics and police officers earn? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was a newly qualified paramedic’s salary in 2016. It’s now £25,655 outside of London.

claims.text: 1.9 million more children are now in good and outstanding schools, compared with 2010.

claimReview.title: The government should stop saying there are 1.9 million more children in good or outstanding schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t acknowledge that there were 560,000 more pupils in state-funded schools in England in 2017 compared to 2010, and changes to inspection practices. 580,000 pupils are in schools that haven’t been inspected since 2010.

claims.text: The UK has the lowest literacy rates in its history

claimReview.title: Telegraph columnist wrongly claims literacy at the lowest level in UK history - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Literacy is currently about 99%. In the past, it has been as low as about 5%. Adult and child literacy appear to have either stayed stable or improved over recent decades.

claims.text: The bank levy has been cut

claimReview.title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It has, but it’s been replaced by a surcharge on bank profits, which is expected to increase taxes on banking.

claims.text: The German government does not recommend the use of Covid-19 vaccines and has frozen licensing of vaccines.

claimReview.title: Germany has not stopped using Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The government suspended the use of the AstraZeneca vaccines to under 60s in March but it has not prohibited Covid-19 vaccinations or licensing.

claims.text: New Zealand’s MPs took a 20% pay cut during this pandemic

claimReview.title: MPs haven’t given themselves a £3,300 pay rise - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New Zealand’s Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern gave herself, government ministers and public service chief executives a 20% pay cut. Other MPs had a 10% pay cut.

claims.text: The masks they give to hospital staff and in schools say they do not protect against Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Surgical masks may offer some protection to the wearer from Covid-19 and may stop them from infecting others - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The masks pictured may offer some limited protection to the wearer, and can stop them spreading it if they are infected. Hospital staff are required to wear these masks, but they may also wear respirators that do protect the wearer. Face coverings and masks are not recommended for use at schools in England except in some circumstances.

claims.text: In London, stop and searches have similar ‘success rates’ for white people and black people.

claimReview.title: Stops and searches are becoming less common - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The rates are similar, but white people are slightly more likely to have some action taken against them as a result of a stop and search.

claims.text: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation was kicked out of India.

claimReview.title: Was the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation Kicked Out of India?
claimReview.textualRating: False

claimReview.title: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation wasn’t kicked out of India - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect.

claims.text: A photo of William Shatner in uniform for the Blue Origin space mission was clearly photoshopped using an image of Jeff Bezos in the same uniform. This is proof the mission didn’t happen.

claimReview.title: Fake photo of William Shatner does not prove he didn’t go into space - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This one photo does not prove anything. The image is faked, but that doesn’t mean the space mission was. There is extensive footage of Shatner before the launch, in space and after landing.

claims.text: There are more women in the UK in work than ever before.

claimReview.title: The pay gap, record employment and an extra £23 billion to GDP: women and the workplace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but it's almost always true: employment grows as the population grows. The employment rate for women aged 16-64 was also at a record high.

claims.text: The UK government/NHS have put posters on buses saying “Kids have strokes too, know the warning signs”.

claimReview.title: This picture of a bus warning about childhood strokes wasn’t taken in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo was taken in Canada, not the UK. It is part of an awareness campaign by a Canadian charity about strokes in children.

claims.text: The number of deaths so far this year in the UK (up to week 39) has been 454,000.

claimReview.title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is the figure for England and Wales only. For the UK as a whole it is 513,987.

claims.text: The coronavirus vaccine will be mandatory.

claimReview.title: There is no indication that a Covid-19 vaccine will be mandatory or that those who don’t get it will have their movements restricted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no suggestion the coronavirus vaccine will be mandatory. No vaccines are mandatory in the UK.

claims.text: Betty White died three days after she received her Covid booster vaccine.

claimReview.title: Betty White did not get a Covid-19 booster vaccine three days before she died - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this. Her agent confirmed she died of natural causes and did not receive her booster three days before her death.

claims.text: The UK’s aid budget is set to have more than doubled from 2010 to 2020.

claimReview.title: UK development aid spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite correct, even though there’s a few ways to look at it. The UK spent £8.5 billion on aid in 2010 and is on course to spend £15.3 in 2020, or £13.1 billion after inflation.

claims.text: You can text a crisis counsellor from Samaritans.

claimReview.title: Samaritans doesn't have a text number anymore - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is no longer true. The charity does not have a text number, but can be contacted by phone, email and letter. Mental health support by text can be accessed using the SHOUT text service.

claims.text: A tube advert purporting to be from the Conservatives says “We plan to cut all homeless people in half by 2025”.

claimReview.title: This advert on the tube was not made by the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The advert is fake. It was made by an artist.

claims.text: People with white-sounding names are nearly twice as likely to get call backs for jobs than people with ethnic sounding names.

claimReview.title: Job applicants with ethnic minority sounding names are less likely to be called for interview - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In a 2009 experimental study, 10.7% of applicants with a white sounding name received a positive response, compared with 6.2% of applicants with an ethnic minority sounding name - making them 74% more likely to get a positive response.

claims.text: We don’t have data on people who died of Covid-19 as the primary infection.

claimReview.title: 73,444 deaths registered in 2020 in England and Wales had Covid-19 as the underlying cause - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We do know how many deaths were registered in England and Wales with Covid-19 as the underlying cause. In 2020 it was 73,444.

claims.text: The Lib Dems quadrupled renewable power in government.

claimReview.title: Did the Lib Dems quadruple renewable energy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was slightly closer to tripling than quadrupling, under the Conservative Lib Dem Coalition. But it’s difficult to attribute energy generation to any one party in government as some generators can take years to commission and build.

claims.text: Leeds City Council have not signed a contract with Carillion.

claimReview.title: Did a Labour-run council sign a PFI contract with Carillion in December? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Carillion was signed off as Leeds City Council's preferred bidder for a contract on 20 December 2017, but they did not sign the actual contract.

claims.text: You can sign the Revoke Article 50 petition repeatedly using the same email address.

claimReview.title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s possible to use the same email address twice but no more than that.

claims.text: A picture shows Jeremy Corbyn shaking hands with Tariq Mahmood, who has served a prison sentence for ballot rigging.

claimReview.title: Photo shows Jeremy Corbyn shaking hands with man previously jailed for electoral fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo is genuine and shows the two shaking hands during 2019 the Peterborough by-election. Mr Mahmood was jailed in 2008 for electoral fraud. Police found no electoral fraud offences were committed in the 2019 by-election.

claims.text: The government has cut police spending by 25% over the last five years.

claimReview.title: What's happened to police budgets? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Direct government grants to police forces have fallen by 25% over the last five years. Funding fell by 18% overall because forces were able to raise more money locally.

claims.text: The British workforce is two people.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 32 million people were estimated to be in work in 2019.

claims.text: Omar Salem, the man with a sick daughter who confronted Boris Johnson at Whipps Cross hospital, was wearing a microphone.

claimReview.title: There’s absolutely no evidence the man who confronted Boris Johnson in a hospital was wearing a microphone - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He wasn’t, according to eye witnesses, photographs and audio of the exchange.

claims.text: The new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claims.text: Honey, pepper and ginger can ‘100%’ eliminate the effect of Covid-19 and has been approved by the WHO.

claimReview.title: Honey, ginger and pepper isn’t approved treatment for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This treatment for Covid-19 has not been approved by the WHO. The WHO says that although some spices may be beneficial for health, there is no evidence that this particular mix can protect from Covid-19 infection.

claims.text: The proportion of lung cancer cases only diagnosed after a visit to an A&E ranges from 15% in Guildford and Waverley in Surrey to 56% in Tower Hamlets and Manchester.

claimReview.title: There are some mistakes in these figures about lung cancer diagnoses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This range is too large and not all of those will be after a visit to A&E. The correct range is from 26% in Harrogate and Rural District to 47% in Tower Hamlets.

claims.text: There are 1,800 more midwives in the English NHS since 2010.

claimReview.title: A shortage of midwives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s about right, although it depends when you measure from.

claims.text: It isn’t necessary for parties to form tactical alliances in the EU parliament elections.
claims.claimant: Green Party of England and Wales

claimReview.title: What will happen to your vote in the upcoming EU parliament elections? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Smaller parties are disadvantaged by the voting system in Great Britain, so it’s harder to win as many seats as larger, unified voting blocs.

claims.text: A screenshot shows a tweet from Jeremy Corbyn saying the London Bridge attacker was “murdered by British Police”.

claimReview.title: Fake Jeremy Corbyn tweet spreads after the London Bridge attack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tweet is fake. Mr Corbyn did not say this.

claims.text: The percentage of the UK population who have received a booster vaccine is double that of the EU.

claimReview.title: UK booster roll out level twice the EU average - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. As of 12-14 December, 35% of the UK population and 19% of the EU population had been boosted.

claims.text: Covid-19 tests are rigged.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 can be fatal and tests for it aren’t rigged - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are different types of tests for Covid-19 which should be used in different scenarios. PCR tests are considered to be highly accurate and reliable, particularly in symptomatic people.

claims.text: 74,000 children are living with ‘long Covid’.

claimReview.title: Extrapolating figures around long Covid in kids is not the way to go - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The ONS figures that these estimates are based on are ‘experimental statistics’ which have measured prevalence of some long Covid symptoms in children at five weeks after infection. They shouldn’t be used as an absolute measure from which to extrapolate population levels of long Covid in children.

claims.text: Driving in flip flops could land you a £5,000 fine, 9 points and a driving ban.

claimReview.title: Driving in flip flops isn’t an offence, but driving carelessly is - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Driving in flip flops doesn’t carry any penalties by itself, but if it led to careless driving or endangered other road users then these penalties could apply.

claims.text: People won’t have to sell their homes under the Conservatives’ social care plans.

claimReview.title: What might people have to pay for their social care? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most people will be able to defer selling their homes until after they die in order to pay for any kind of social care - although some may not be eligible.

claims.text: Leeds City Council announced that Carillion was its preferred bidder for a contract last week.

claimReview.title: Did a Labour-run council sign a PFI contract with Carillion in December? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Leeds City Council authorised the award of a contract worth £14 million to Carillion on 20 December 2017, although they did not sign the actual contract.

claims.text: We’re seeing fewer families in relative poverty in the UK.

claimReview.title: Poverty: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends how you look at it and what time period you pick. If you take the claim to be referring to the period since 2010, that’s incorrect. The number of children or people living in relative poverty has risen since then, whether or not you include housing costs.

claims.text: Responding to new laws banning handguns in the wake of the Dunblane Massacre, Boris Johnson wrote “Nanny is confiscating their toys. It is like one of those vast Indian programmes of compulsory vasectomy.”

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson handgun quote is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True.

claims.text: You no longer have to quarantine if you have returned to England from an exempt country before July 10.
claims.claimant: Foreign and Commonwealth Office travel advice

claimReview.title: Government issues contradictory advice on travel quarantine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This has been claimed by the Foreign and Commonwealth Office as well as a government minister. However, advice from the Department for Transport on the government’s official website says you must follow the rules that were in place when you arrived in England.

claims.text: Everybody who’s self-isolating is entitled, in addition to the equivalent of the living wage and statutory sick pay, to help in extreme circumstances from their local councils and also to a £500 payment to help them with self-isolation.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson was wrong to say that “everybody” is entitled to extra self-isolation support - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Employees who are self-isolating are entitled to statutory sick pay which is not equivalent to the living wage. Support from councils in extreme circumstances is an alternative, not additional, to the £500 payment, and only available to those on benefits or in hardship.

claims.text: Scotland has the highest taxes anywhere in Europe.

claimReview.title: Scotland doesn’t have the highest taxes in Europe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, a number of European countries have higher income tax rates than Scotland.

claims.text: All alleged victims of adult sexual offences tried in the Crown Court will be able to have their evidence recorded in advance from September 2017.

claimReview.title: What changes are being made to pre-recorded evidence from alleged rape victims? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only a small number of alleged victims in three particular courts are likely to be affected by these proposals from September.

claims.text: A third of stops and searches in London results in something being found.

claimReview.title: Stops and searches are becoming less common - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The government is protecting police budgets.

claimReview.title: Police funding: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Central government funding is being cut in real terms over the course of this parliament, but police funding overall will stay the same if local taxation for the police is maximised.

claims.text: “Our boys” didn’t change the handball and VAR rules in association football.
