claimReview.title: Did “our boys” change the handball rule? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Changes to the VAR rules were made unanimously by IFAB. British football associations had the ability to veto this change, but all four voted in favour. Details of the vote to change the handball rule have not yet been released, but at least two of the four British FAs would have had to vote in favour of it.

claims.text: We have an ageing population.

claimReview.title: An ageing population and A&E - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct

claims.text: An app will be placed on your phone without your consent and a QR code on the app will show your vaccine status. Shops and businesses will have a QR scanner that will indicate whether you are allowed to enter based on your vaccine status.

claimReview.title: There is no indication that a Covid-19 vaccine will be mandatory or that those who don’t get it will have their movements restricted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have found no evidence to suggest any tracking apps will be automatically downloaded onto phones or used to trace vaccinations. There is no suggestion that people who don’t get the vaccination will have their movements limited.

claims.text: 51% think the Chequers deal is not good for Britain.

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 42%.

claims.text: Under the current system, people on a work, study or family visa incur average NHS costs of £625 per year.

claimReview.title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s unclear how the Conservatives have calculated this new figure and we’ve asked them for more information.

claims.text: Children aren’t affected by Covid-19 and don’t transmit the virus.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Children are less affected but some can still become seriously ill or die. They do transmit the virus.

claims.text: Lebanon, a country the size of Devon and Cornwall, shelters 1.5 million refugees compared to 150,000 in the UK.

claimReview.title: Refugees in Lebanon and the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Lebanon is the size of those counties combined, and the figures are in the right ballpark, although Lebanon’s refugee population is unusual in that many have been “refugees” for decades or from birth, which isn’t possible in the UK.

claims.text: The vaccine has luciferase.

claimReview.title: Luminescent enzymes not in Covid-19 vaccine and other myths debunked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Luciferase is the name given to the bioluminescent natural enzyme which makes glow worms glow. Regardless, it isn't in any of the vaccines.

claims.text: The 2021 Budget reduced day-to-day health and social care spending by £30 billion.

claimReview.title: Has the NHS had its budget reduced by £30 billion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS and the Department of Health will receive less Covid-19 specific funding in 2021 but its core budgets will increase.

claims.text: 61% of coronavirus deaths in Norway are in care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct up to May.This was reported by the ECDC.

claims.text: People with cancer have a pH that is too acidic.

claimReview.title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is unfounded.

claims.text: US-Patent 5676977 is for AIDS.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This number is for a now-expired patent for an ineffective AIDS cure.

claims.text: The attainment gap in schools is narrowing.

claimReview.title: What's happening to social mobility? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct according to the Social Mobility Commission, but it also says there is still a “clear and strong” link between income and attainment and that the gap widens as a pupil goes through school.

claims.text: The FDA recalls 1,270 drugs every year that were previously approved but are then subsequently deemed unsuitable.

claimReview.title: The FDA recalls drugs for a wide range of reasons - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The FDA recalls medications for a wide variety of reasons. These include lots of different manufacturing, storage, or labelling concerns. Just under 1,000 have been recalled in 2021.

claims.text: The Chilcot Inquiry cost £13 million and the Leveson Inquiry cost £5 million.

claimReview.title: The cost of public inquiries - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The royal family brings in £400m a year in private revenue, of which £360m is kept by government under the Sovereign Act 2011.

claimReview.title: How does the royal family make money? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The Crown Estate brought in £330 million in 2017/18, this money goes to the government who then give the Queen a grant based on 25% of the Crown Estate’s income two years previously.But the Crown Estate isn’t the royal family’s private property. The Queen pays tax to government on her other private incomes.

claims.text: 6% of students don’t make it from their first year of university to their second year.

claimReview.title: 6% of young first-time students drop out of university after their first year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for UK young undergraduate students at university for the first time in 2014/15. These figures are dated now, but still the latest available.

claims.text: The daily number of Covid-19 cases seriously understates the real total because it does not count reinfections.

claimReview.title: Robert Peston overstated the importance of reinfections - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that reinfections are not currently counted as cases in the data, but the evidence suggests that it would only add about 1% to the total if they were.

claims.text: Martin Lewis, the founder of Money Saving Expert, recommends ignoring parking charge notices.

claimReview.title: This advice on how to fight a parking ticket is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Martin Lewis has said he does not recommend this.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us the power to stop the creation of a European army.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct—each EU member has a veto on common defence policies.

claims.text: EU regulation means kipper sellers must package their kippers in ice.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s kipper claim is a red herring - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The EU does not set any requirements on the temperature at which smoked fish must be transported. The temperature requirement is a UK regulation.

claims.text: Statistics show that Serco is much worse at contact tracing than local councils.

claimReview.title: Labour’s tweet about Serco is missing some important context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comparison needs context. Public and private contact tracers do different jobs, and there’s reason to believe it may be easier for local teams to reach a higher proportion of their contacts.

claims.text: Immigrants/refugees living in the UK get a weekly allowance of £250.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. People given refugee status in the UK are not entitled to any special allowances, but can claim the same benefits as any UK citizen. Asylum seekers are entitled to £37.75 per week and accommodation if they are homeless and can’t afford food.

claims.text: We have a £100 billion trade deficit with Europe.

claimReview.title: What is a trade deficit and do we have one with the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK was sold just under £70 billion more in goods and services by the rest of the EU than it sold to them in 2017.

claims.text: Vaccinated people over 30 have higher rates of Covid-19 infection than unvaccinated ones.

claimReview.title: Lionel Shriver is wrong to say that Covid-19 vaccines can’t stop the virus spreading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is based on very unreliable estimates of the case rate among unvaccinated people. The opposite may well be true.

claims.text: Labour are proposing stopping the 25% discount on council tax for single householders.

claimReview.title: It is not Labour policy to scrap the single occupant council tax discount - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not Labour policy.

claims.text: Corporation tax revenues have increased since the government reduced the tax rate.

claimReview.title: Corporation tax: rates down, receipts up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are both correct. Official forecasts say that receipts could well have been higher if the rates hadn’t been cut.

claims.text: The total number of deaths from Covid-19 in the UK is now at 233, the same number of deaths reported in Italy about two weeks ago.

claimReview.title: These numbers about Covid-19 deaths in the UK and Italy are broadly accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. On 21 March, Public Health England reported a total of 233 deaths in the UK from Covid-19. However, not enough is known to say whether the number of deaths will grow at the same rate in the UK as in Italy.

claims.text: Government proposals on raising the state pension age will see 36.9 million people having to work longer.

claimReview.title: Do pension changes mean 37 million people working longer? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only around six million people are affected by the government’s most recent proposals. 32 million people already have a pensionable age higher than 66 years as things stand. The government’s proposals to bring the rise forward by seven years would bring this up to 38 million (based on 2016 population figures).

claims.text: 650 of these are elected, 808 are unelected, and 36 were just appointed and include the Prime Minister’s brother and friends.

claimReview.title: These figures for the size of House Of Commons, House of Lords, and the EU parliament are all correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The 650 members of The House of Commons were elected to their positions by members of the public. 

Members of the House of Lords are elected by the Prime Minister, the Lords Appointment Commission, or other peers. A recent announcement of new peers did include Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s brother.

claims.text: The NHS has published its very first price lists for treatments.

claimReview.title: Is the NHS introducing price lists for treatments? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The list in question was published last year and offers patients who do not qualify for NHS funding for certain treatments the option to “self-fund”. Some hospitals have been offering similar schemes since at least 2013.

claims.text: On 2 November it was reported that 293 Covid-19 fatalities were recorded in just 24 hours.

claimReview.title: 293 ‘daily’ Covid deaths likely cover more than one day after technical issue - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 293 Covid-19 deaths were reported on 2 November, but the government says that due to a technical fault affecting death recording, and more general delays in reporting deaths over the weekend, this data likely covers more than one day.

claims.text: The Guardian deactivated its 2021 “Person of the Year” poll after J.K. Rowling took the lead.

claimReview.title: Guardian didn’t deactivate ‘Person of the Year’ poll because J.K. Rowling took the lead - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The article was not a poll but a request for readers to nominate their “Person of the Year”. The responses were reported on 30 December, including Ms Rowling as a nominee. The Guardian regularly runs similar articles and deactivates submissions after a period of time. It did not publish a tally of the results.

claims.text: The OECD says that important steps have been taken in the UK to improve educational outcomes.

claimReview.title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: David Davis has never said the government had impact assessments of the effect Brexit on different parts of the economy.

claimReview.title: Brexit impact assessments: did the government bluff about their existence? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although David Davis has never directly said “impact assessments”, as far as we can tell, he did confirm the existence of 57 impact assessments to a select committee.

claims.text: An illustration shows that the Covid-19 test involves a swab going all the way to the back of the nose.

claimReview.title: Viral illustration shows one type of Covid-19 sampling method - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This illustration is from a medical imaging company showing a nasopharyngeal swab Covid-19 test. Not all tests are done this way.

claims.text: The richest 1% of people in the UK own more than twenty times the wealth of the poorest 20% in the UK.

claimReview.title: Wealth in the UK: The richest 1% and the poorest 20% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Finding out what the wealthiest own is harder than you might expect, but this is a reasonable claim that’s based on a well-regarded set of estimates. It’s important not to confused inequalities of wealth with inequalities of income, which are much lower.

claims.text: Young people are not at risk from Covid-19 at all.

claimReview.title: Young people do face a small risk from Covid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Both children and young adults face a very low risk of death or serious illness if they catch Covid-19.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, food bank use is up 1,000%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The increase is over 1000%, looking at the number of three-day food packages handed out by the Trussell Trust, which runs a network of food banks in the UK. This does not cover all food banks in the UK though. The period covers coalition and Conservative governments.

claims.text: Lawyers have repeatedly said that there is no legal obligation for the UK to pay to leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some lawyers have said this, but there are differing legal views on the matter.

claims.text: Theresa May leads Jeremy Corbyn in the opinion polls.

claimReview.title: How are Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn doing in the polls? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that Theresa May is more favoured as Prime Minister than Jeremy Corbyn in polls generally, though the Express poll only compares the two leaders on their economic credibility.

claims.text: EU immigrants pay £1.34 in taxes for every £1 they receive in state assistance

claimReview.title: Do EU immigrants contribute £1.34 for every £1 received from the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research has found this for recent immigrants from other EU countries, but counting those who came before 2000 reduces this figure. This is a difficult thing to measure, and other research has different findings.

claims.text: If you live in an area where the council is run by the Labour party, you pay £100 more than under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t been able to replicate this calculation, and in general it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single party.

claims.text: 90% of people in ICU with Covid-19 have not been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson misspoke about unvaccinated people in ICU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not supported by the latest evidence, which shows that 61% of admissions in the first half of December 2021 were unvaccinated people. Around 90% had not received a booster dose.

claims.text: Between weeks 23 and 37 in 2021 there have been 252 deaths among 15 to 19-year-olds in England and Wales. This compares to 162 in the same period in 2020, an increase of 90 (or 56%).

claimReview.title: Teen deaths up since last year, but no evidence vaccines responsible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are correct but this period in 2020 saw lower than average teen deaths, so is not a normal year to compare 2021 against. The ONS, which produced the data, also says: “There is no evidence [from the data] to suggest a link with the COVID-19 vaccines”

claims.text: US patent 2006257852 is for the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: These patents are not for the new coronavirus or its vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not. It is an abandoned patent from 2006 for chemical mixtures related to the SARS virus, which is another type of coronavirus.

claims.text: Nigel Farage has earned £541.10 per day from TV and radio since 2016.

claimReview.title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is a based on the outside income Mr Farage declared as an MEP between 2014 and 2018. Half of that period was before Brexit. His estimated outside earnings over that period equate to an average of £359.90-£479.50 per day, and we don’t know if all that was from broadcast deals.

claims.text: The number of deaths in police custody is at the highest level in five years.

claimReview.title: How many deaths occur in police custody? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were 17 deaths in 2014/15, according to official figures; the highest in four years, rather than five.

claims.text: There are now more deaths from the Covid-19 vaccine per day than there are with Covid-19 within 28 days of a positive test.

claimReview.title: 1,102 people haven’t died ‘of’ the Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The vaccine has not caused any deaths per day. That is how many people have died after a vaccine.

claims.text: The UK can stay in the single market and control immigration.

claimReview.title: Can we be part of the single market and control immigration? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This depends on the deal struck between the UK and the EU. The UK is unlikely to be able to control the level of immigration from the rest of the EU while staying in the single market, and EU leaders are saying they won’t compromise on this issue.

claims.text: Crime is starting to rise.

claimReview.title: Is crime now starting to rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Crime is falling in England and Wales according to the Crime Survey. Police are recording more violent and sexual offences but these may not reflect genuine rises in the crimes.

claims.text: Options for post-Brexit trade deals with the EU will lead to between 700,000 and 2,800,000 fewer jobs.

claimReview.title: This viral image showing the cost of different Brexit deals is wrong in a lot of ways - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this in the report cited by the claimant, nor elsewhere.

claims.text: The German federal government only expects the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine to have an effectiveness of eight percent among the over 65s.

claimReview.title: Report of 8% vaccine efficacy for elderly is unreliable - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The German government said it couldn’t confirm the report. Public data shows older adults had a similar immune response to the vaccine as younger adults, though there is limited data for over 65s.

claims.text: 0.5% of pedestrian deaths are people killed by people on a bike.

claimReview.title: How many cyclists are killed each year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct, for Britain.

claims.text: Official data shows that incidents of bovine TB increased dramatically in areas of Gloucestershire despite the badger cull.

claimReview.title: Does badger culling work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of new TB incidents increased by 130% in one area of Gloucestershire from 2017 to 2018. However, you cannot judge the effectiveness of badger culling based on a one-year change in one part of the country. Wider evidence suggests the effect of culling on the spread of bovine TB is limited.

claims.text: The photo shows the latest migrants taken into England.

claimReview.title: This is not a photo of people seeking asylum in England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This photo was not taken in England, it was taken in Germany.

claims.text: Record numbers of teachers are quitting the profession, more than entered the profession.

claimReview.title: Are more teachers quitting the profession than entering it? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Slightly more people left teaching roles in state-funded schools in 2014 than entered them. Those that left include over one in four who retired, so not all of these people are "quitting" teaching in favour of a different job. The numbers of teachers leaving and entering state-funded schools in England in 2014 were the highest since 2011 (when records began).

claims.text: Five more countries are in the process of joining, including Turkey.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The UK has a veto, but officially supports Turkey joining.

claims.text: After leaving the EU and replacing EU funding, the UK will have additional savings to spend on priorities such as the NHS.

claimReview.title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most economists forecast that savings on the EU membership fee would be outweighed by slower economic growth. Without raising taxes or borrowing more, the government would have less money to spend on public services.

claims.text: One in five over-65s in the UK is classified as a millionaire

claimReview.title: Golden oldies: Are one in five pensioners millionaires? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One in five households in Great Britain, headed by an over-65, has a total wealth of over a million pounds.

claims.text: Mental health problems are on the rise.

claimReview.title: Healthcheck: cancer, diabetes and mental health conditions on the rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know of any figures that consistently measure the change in the number of people with mental health conditions over time. One in four people in England had a mental health condition at some point in the previous year, according to a 2007 study. Another study estimated one in six people had a common mental health condition in the past week in 2014.

claims.text: Dose range finding studies were not performed for the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims that you cannot refuse the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Dose ranging studies were performed for the vaccines currently in use.

claims.text: Funding for rail companies today is four times what British Rail got in the 1970s and 80s.

claimReview.title: Government funding for the rail industry - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Government support to the rail industry is roughly three times what it was at the end of the 1980s, varying year to year. We haven’t seen earlier figures.

claims.text: High-quality butter is made from cream or milk. Margarine made from palm oil doesn’t melt.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We could not find a clear answer as to why the butter broke up and the margarine didn’t.

claims.text: Theresa May hasn’t really increased the housing supply.

claimReview.title: Housing: supply and demand - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of houses being built has increased over the last decade, although it is difficult to attribute this to any one government. Overall house building isn’t keeping up with demand.

claims.text: Police spending has been protected.

claimReview.title: What's happened to police budgets? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Direct funding from government for police in England and Wales will continue to fall until 2020. Most local forces have the power to raise enough money to keep their budgets flat - but only if they raise the maximum amount they're allowed to.

claims.text: Boris Johnson said in 2007 that Gordon Brown should not have become Prime Minister after Tony Blair with no public vote.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson did say this about Gordon Brown becoming Prime Minister without an election - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is true.

claims.text: British pupils are suffering because teachers are struggling to cope with an influx of foreign students speaking different languages.

claimReview.title: Is immigration affecting the performance of native English speakers in schools? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of pupils with English as an additional language has been rising. But research suggests the performance of pupils with English as their first language isn't affected by this.

claims.text: Health visitor numbers peaked in October 2015 at 10,309. Numbers have fallen by 2,065 or 20% since then.

claimReview.title: Health visitor numbers in England down by a fifth since 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for the NHS in England.

claims.text: The coronavirus patent was applied for in 2015.

claimReview.title: A patent for the coronavirus spreading in Wuhan was not applied for in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A company applied for a patent on a weakened version of a virus in the same family as the new Wuhan virus.

claims.text: The NHS Confederation says cuts to social care will put pressure on hospitals.

claimReview.title: Social care funding: how did the sector react to the latest plans? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right.

claims.text: Funding for some early help services in England has fallen by £1.8 billion from 2010 to 2015

claimReview.title: Early help for children—uncertain definition leads to uncertain estimates - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research by charities backs this up but only counts funding allocated directly to local authorities. Counting other funding can show a smaller fall.

claims.text: We put up nurse pay last month.

claimReview.title: Nurse pay up over the past few years but down on 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2018 the government and the NHS staff council agreed a three year pay deal which saw pay for nurses increase annually in April between 2018/19 and 2020/21.

claims.text: More than a quarter of all evening meals in the UK are vegan or vegetarian, research shows.

claimReview.title: How much meat do we eat? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An estimated 29% of evening meals contained no meat or fish in 2017, according to market research designed to be representative of Britain. We don’t know how many evening meals were vegan, though.

claims.text: In the UK there’s a huge difference in wealth per person between the poorest and richest regions, compared to other countries.

claimReview.title: One measure of inequality makes the UK look far less equal than other countries—it’s not - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is because of the way the data is collected, rather than real world effects. Using other measures the UK’s income inequality is about average compared to similar countries.

claims.text: Diabetes is linked to a quarter of pandemic deaths in England according to NHS statistics.

claimReview.title: Daily Express diabetes and coronavirus deaths headline is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About a quarter of Covid-19 patients who died in England hospital also had diabetes, but this does not mean that diabetes was definitely linked to all these deaths. This cannot be concluded from these NHS statistics.

claims.text: Roughly 40% of people on welfare are pensioners, and 10% or 20% are taking in-work benefits.

claimReview.title: Are 40% of welfare claimants pensioners? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t found figures to back this up. Around 56% of all welfare spending in Great Britain went to pensioners in 2016/17, counting pensions as part of the welfare bill.

claims.text: Text on NHSX website is proof that vaccine passports will definitely be introduced in December 2021.

claimReview.title: NHSX website doesn’t reveal vaccine passport roll out - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The text refers to the way exemptions will be viewed on the NHS COVID app. 

The Department of Health and Social Care have confirmed that vaccine passports are an “option” but there are no firm plans.

claims.text: A video shows an emergency alert siren playing in public in London.

claimReview.title: This video does not show an official alert siren playing in London - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is very unlikely this happened. The UK’s civil defence siren has been retired since 1992, and most of the actual siren systems removed. We could find no other coverage of a siren playing in the area shown in the clip.

claims.text: The party with the most MPs gets to form the government.

claimReview.title: Does the largest political party form the government? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In a hung Parliament, there's no rule that the largest party forms a government. It might get the first chance to try, but the incumbent can also claim this.

claims.text: The name ‘Ipsos MORI’ is Latin for ‘they die’.

claimReview.title: Ipsos MORI isn’t trying to kill you with Covid tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not really. This is what online translators translate 'Ipsos mori' to, but in reality it is garbled ungrammatical Latin. Ipsos MORI says its name was created from the merger of two companies and doesn’t mean anything.

claims.text: The largest peacetime investment in public services happened between 1997 and 2010.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Total government spending as a share of the economy increased by 9.6 percentage points, a record compared to any other 13 year period since 1955 (the earliest we have data for).

claims.text: The vaccine makes you detectable via Bluetooth.

claimReview.title: Getting a Covid-19 vaccine doesn’t mean you can connect to Bluetooth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There’s nothing in the vaccine that does this, or makes it possible.

claims.text: Wales’s test and trace system cost £102 million.

claimReview.title: Flawed comparisons between test and trace systems go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This was the amount allocated by the Welsh government, but the system in Wales is also part-funded by the UK government.

claims.text: The mRNA Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The mRNA vaccines have been tested for safety and effectiveness like any other vaccine. While this is the first time mRNA vaccines have become available to the public, they have been researched for many years.

claims.text: There is no general age limit for competing in the Olympics.

claimReview.title: The Olympic Games, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The age limits are set by the international governing body for each sport.

claims.text: The defence budget was cut by nearly 20% between 2010 and 2015.

claimReview.title: Government defence spending is 2% of GDP - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Defence spending fell by 18% in real terms between 2010/11 and 2014/15, or by 22% comparing since 2009/10.

claims.text: You need to be 18 to get married on your own.

claimReview.title: What rights do you get at 18? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England and Wales. You can get married or enter a civil partnership at 16 and 17 but you still need parental consent.

claims.text: One in six secondary schools are at or over capacity.

claimReview.title: What's happening to secondary school places? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 15% of state-funded secondary schools in England were at or over capacity in 2014—one in seven.

claims.text: Drinking lots of water will eliminate the new coronavirus from your throat.

claimReview.title: Drinking and gargling water will not cure the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. It is a common myth.

claims.text: Millions of women have been plunged into poverty because of changes to the pension age made in 2011.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner uses exaggerated figure for number of WASPI women in poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an exaggeration. We don’t know the exact number but it is likely substantially lower.

claims.text: Nearly one in five British Muslims has some sympathy with those who have fled the UK to fight for IS in Syria.

claimReview.title: Do one in five UK Muslims sympathise with Britons fighting for IS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The survey asked about sympathy with "young Muslims who leave the UK to join fighters in Syria", not just those fighting in the conflict, and not just those fighting for IS.

claims.text: The Moderna vaccine contains SM-102 which could cause health complaints such as cancer, fertility damage and damage to the nervous system, kidneys or respiratory system.

claimReview.title: The Moderna vaccine contains SM-102 not chloroform - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These claims about SM-102 are from a product safety leaflet when it is in a mixed solution with a toxic substance called chloroform. The Moderna vaccine does contain SM-102, but not chloroform.

claims.text: We can leave the EU with no deal and negotiate a free trade agreement during the transition period.

claimReview.title: Brexit withdrawal deal and future trade deal—what’s the difference? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The transition period is part of the withdrawal agreement. Leaving the EU with no deal means there’s no transition period – though we could still try and negotiate a free trade agreement following a no-deal Brexit.

claims.text: The EU spends £8 billion on overhead each year.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU spent £8.5 billion on administrative costs in 2018. That’s 6% of its total budget.

claims.text: Labour would borrow one trillion to cover their promises.

claimReview.title: Would Labour borrow a trillion pounds? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The original claim is actually that Labour would spend (not borrow) a trillion pounds to cover their manifesto commitments. The figure hasn't been confirmed, and we don't know what time period it covers, and whether it refers to spending increases compared to now, or total spending.

claims.text: At least a large part of growth in employment has been driven by an increase in insecure, precarious work.

claimReview.title: Has employment growth been driven by a rise in insecure, precarious work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That doesn’t seem to be the case for the UK jobs market overall. The picture for specific industries, regions and groups might be different and statistics will only ever give a limited insight into questions about job quality.

claims.text: Vets say that all cats should be kept indoors during the coronavirus outbreak.

claimReview.title: Most people do not need to keep their cats indoors during the new coronavirus outbreak - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This advice only applies to cats from infected or self-isolating households. The article saying it applied to all cats has now been changed.

claims.text: Luc Montagnier has said there is no chance for survival for people who receive a Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: No evidence Nobel Laureate said vaccinated people will die in two years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence he said this.

claims.text: A report this week found 120,000 unnecessary deaths are happening every year because of austerity.

claimReview.title: Is austerity linked to 120,000 unnecessary deaths? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An academic paper has estimated there were around 120,000 more deaths in total between 2010 and 2017 than there would have been had the mortality rate between 2001 and 2010 continued. Restrictions on health and social care spending is one of a number of possible explanations for this, and the findings need to be treated with a bit of caution.

claims.text: Covid vaccines can’t stop people spreading the virus.

claimReview.title: Lionel Shriver is wrong to say that Covid-19 vaccines can’t stop the virus spreading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is misleading. Covid vaccines have prevented millions of infections—and the subsequent infections that would have come from them. They also reduce the risk of transmission in ‘breakthrough’ infections.

claims.text: Deaths in care homes are up 81% since the start of the Covid-19 vaccination rollout.

claimReview.title: Covid vaccine hasn't caused increase in care home deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Deaths in care homes are up about that much since before the vaccination rollout, although we haven’t been able to replicate the 81% figure exactly.

These are not deaths due to the vaccine. They are largely due to Covid-19 itself and reporting delays.

claims.text: If you appeal against a Work Capability Assessment you are almost certain to win.

claimReview.title: Appealing a ‘Fit for Work’ decision - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About three-fifths of appeal cases are successful. Decisions that are challenged but don’t make it to appeal have a lower success rate.

claims.text: There were 17,000 fewer police officers in 2015 than in 2010.

claimReview.title: What happened to council funding, welfare spending and police numbers under the Coalition? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England and Wales.

claims.text: A decision of the European Court of Human Rights means that the police have to warn criminals about serious threats to their life.

claimReview.title: Human rights law means police warnings for people at risk of being killed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: ‘Threat to life warnings’ are a police response to the human rights court’s requirement that the state sometimes has to be proactive in protecting people from threats. That decision dates from 1998, and wasn’t about criminals in particular.

claims.text: There have been over 8.7 million abortions since 1967.

claimReview.title: Factchecking campaigning leaflets on abortion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Since mid-1968, when the Abortion Act was first introduced in Britain, there have been around 8.7 million recorded abortions.

claims.text: Most students who immigrate to the UK return home after study.

claimReview.title: How many international students leave after studying in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The available evidence is contradictory. Most student immigrants come from outside the EU on a temporary visa and a minority still have the right to remain after a few years. But emigration figures suggest the number staying in the UK may be higher than this.

claims.text: Grammar schools don’t benefit most pupils.

claimReview.title: Grammar schools benefit some pupils but the majority do worse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The advantage for pupils who attend grammar schools is outweighed by the disadvantage for those who don’t.

claims.text: These images were taken at a ‘Cobra’ meeting.

claimReview.title: Photos of ministers together weren’t taken at a ‘Cobra’ meeting - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. They appear to have been taken at a cabinet meeting.

claims.text: Mercury (aka thimerosal or thiomersal) is in vaccines and can damage brain, gut, liver, bone marrow, nervous system and kidneys, is linked to autoimmune disorder, autism.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Thiomersal isn’t in any UK vaccines any more. This is down to concern around a slightly different mercury-based chemical.

claims.text: If you removed medical students from the NHS workforce statistics, the number of doctors has actually fallen.

claimReview.title: The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased in the past year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased if these final year students are excluded, although to a lesser extent.

claims.text: The EU imposes 50% tariffs on rice, maize and other cereals and 300% tariffs on processed sugar imported from African countries.

claimReview.title: Out of Africa: the facts about EU tariffs on African exports - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The EU does charge tariffs on imports of all these goods, but most African countries aren’t subject to them

claims.text: In 2017 the UK resettled more refugees from outside Europe than any other EU member state.

claimReview.title: How many refugees does the UK take in? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Technically correct, but resettled refugees are only a subset of all refugees a country might take in. Overall, Germany, France, Austria and Sweden all granted asylum to more refugees than the UK did in 2017.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Facebook post makes misleading claims about Covid-19 passports and death rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All UK Covid-19 vaccines have been shown to be effective and safe through clinical trials.

claims.text: The government supports 2.2 million households with a £140-a-week discount on energy bills.

claimReview.title: The Warm Home Discount is £140 for the entire winter, not a week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The Warm Home Discount is actually £140 for the entire winter.

claims.text: There are 400,000 fewer families living in poverty now than there were in 2010.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know where this data comes from and have asked the government.

claims.text: The new benefit cap will affect 40,000 single mothers.

claimReview.title: How does the new benefit cap affect single mothers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Department for Work and Pensions has estimated that up to 54,000 families with single mothers could be affected by the benefit cap in 2016/17. Of those, it’s likely that around 40,000 were newly affected as a result of the recent lowering of the cap.

claims.text: An independent review of the vaccines advises that all vaccination should be halted.

claimReview.title: Critical report on BBC Newsround story is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The “independent review” claims all reports of side effects after vaccination were caused by vaccination which is unproven.

claims.text: Covid-19 starts with a sore throat lasting 3-4 days. It then blends into a nasal fluid that enters the trachea and the lungs, causing pneumonia, which takes about 5 or 6 days. With pneumonia comes high fever and difficulty breathing. The nasal congestion makes you feel like you’re drowning.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a roughly accurate description of the most common symptoms, although not everyone with Covid-19 gets pneumonia. The symptoms may not come in this order or at these times. There have been no reports of sufferers experiencing nasal congestion that makes them feel they are drowning.

claims.text: Covid-19 kills no more than 0.1% of the people who catch it

claimReview.title: Covid-19 kills far more than 0.1% of the people who catch it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The real death rate is probably about five or ten times higher.

claims.text: David Davis and Theresa May said on nine separate occasions in the House of Commons that they'd done, or were doing... around 58 sectoral analyses

claimReview.title: Brexit impact assessments: did the government bluff about their existence? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have found ten cases where Mr Davis, one of his ministers, or Theresa May referred to or acknowledged the existence of 50+ sectoral analyses or assessments in the House of Commons or at a select committee.

claims.text: Sajid Javid claimed to be opening one of 48 new hospitals in August 2021, but it was actually a new cancer centre at an existing hospital in the pipeline years before Boris Johnson pledged to build 40 and later 48 new hospitals.
claims.claimant: People's Chancellor - Economics For The Many

claimReview.title: Did Sajid Javid open a ‘new hospital’ in Carlisle? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The new building is on the site of an old part of Carlisle Infirmary, which was planned before Boris Johnson pledged to build 40 new hospitals during the 2019 election.

claims.text: The cost of the German Test and Trace system has been £48 million.

claimReview.title: Germany has spent far more than £48m on test and trace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Funding for the German system is complicated, but available figures suggest that far more than the £48 million has been spent.

claims.text: Less than 4% of board members in FTSE 150 companies are from black and minority ethnic backgrounds. (That’s the 150 largest companies, by value, on the London Stock Exchange.)

claimReview.title: Ethnic diversity on company boards - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About 5% of directors on FTSE 150 boards which are headquartered or mainly operational in the UK, western Europe, the US, or Australia are from black and minority ethnic backgrounds. Only 1.6% are British too, compared to about 13% of the UK population as a whole.

claims.text: If someone with the new coronavirus sneezes, it travels about 10 feet before it drops to the ground and is no longer airborne.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Environmental factors impact how far droplets from a sneeze can travel, but it is likely to be several metres.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: How far the droplets spread from a sneeze depends on environmental factors, but it is likely to be several metres.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: How far the droplets spread from a sneeze depends on environmental factors, but it is likely to be several metres.

claims.text: The working week in Germany is 28 hours.

claimReview.title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only for some workers. In 2018, Germany’s largest trade union won a two-year deal for its 900,000 members to work a 28-hour week. German employees can work up to 40 hours a week. If they work longer than this, they must be compensated through additional holiday.

claims.text: A poll showed a fall in Conservative support following several recent news reports about lobbying and leaks.

claimReview.title: Conservative support may have fallen—but not when the Guardian says it did - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some of the stories could have affected opinions in this poll, but the disagreement between Boris Johnson and Dominic Cummings only became public after the poll was conducted.

claims.text: The ONS has registered 4,122 deaths in 2020 due to Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post is wrong on deaths in first three months of 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was broadly correct for the first 14 weeks of the year, including a few days in April and in December 2019.

claims.text: HMRC employs 300 people to investigate tax fraud.

claimReview.title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In February 2018 HMRC employed around 26,000 people “tackling all forms of non-compliance in the tax system”.

claims.text: A photo shows two bags of donated blood, one lighter red and one almost black, and says the redder one is from a non-vaccinated person and the darker one is from a vaccinated person.

claimReview.title: No evidence Covid-19 vaccine makes blood look different - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS Blood and Transplant says it has observed no difference between vaccinated and unvaccinated people’s blood.

claims.text: England has been named second worst nation for child happiness.

claimReview.title: England not named world's second worst nation for child happiness - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research only shows England's performance compared to 14 other countries, not worldwide. Other surveys tell a different story.

claims.text: The schools budget has been increased over the past few years.

claimReview.title: School spending: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cash amount has risen, but that doesn’t take into account inflation or rising pupil numbers.

claims.text: More NHS patient are waiting 18 weeks for treatment in England, says the Guardian. Fewer are, says the government.

claimReview.title: Have NHS waiting times got better or worse? Pick your measure - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are two different measures of waiting times, which often move in different directions.

claims.text: The number of apprenticeship starts has fallen by 70% over the last quarter.

claimReview.title: Has the number of people starting apprenticeships fallen? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, apprenticeship starts in England in May to July this year were 72% lower than in February to April. Comparing neighbouring quarters isn’t always appropriate because differences can be due to the time of year. The fall is 59% comparing to May to July last year.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines can render you infertile.

claimReview.title: Hecklers at Twickenham Stadium vaccine drive spout false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. If anything, the vaccines may protect against fertility damage that the virus might cause.

claims.text: The Treasury forecast a recession if the UK voted to leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit: is the UK economy growing or slowing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct.

claims.text: More than a quarter of a million people came to the UK from the EU in the last 12 months – the equivalent of a city the size of Newcastle. If this continues for a decade, there will be over two million extra people.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over a quarter of a million is correct according to official estimates, not quite as much as Newcastle’s population.

claims.text: To minimise the risk of catching the new coronavirus, you should use public transport only when necessary, avoid kissing and shaking hands, and make visitors wash their hands as soon as they enter your house.

claimReview.title: We fact checked claims about avoiding social contact and how you wash clothes in the face of the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Official Public Health England advice does not recommend any of these things.

claims.text: Manchester City Council commissioned a mural of George Floyd over one of Lee Rigby.

claimReview.title: A George Floyd mural in Manchester was not chosen over a Lee Rigby memorial - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Manchester City Council said they made no decision about the George Floyd mural in the city’s Northern Quarter.

claims.text: A camera with photographs of the Titanic sinking has been discovered in the ocean.

claimReview.title: A picture of the Titanic sinking is not a newly discovered photograph - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can find no evidence to support this. The image on this post is a recent painting, not a photograph.

claims.text: Many people are buying online and not going to the shops.

claimReview.title: How much shopping gets done online? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of retail sales made online is steadily increasing, but at around 17%, doesn’t account for the majority of purchases.

claims.text: Pressing the cancel button twice before using a cash machine prevents fraudsters from stealing your PIN.

claimReview.title: Pressing ‘cancel’ does not prevent cash machine fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. LINK, which operates the UK’s largest cash machine network, calls it an “urban myth”.

claims.text: A 5G tower powered by a “Delta” power system, suggests a link between 5G and Covid-19.

claimReview.title: 5G tower with ‘Delta’ power system is not related to Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The power system is supplied by Delta Group, an infrastructure business founded in 1971. The name is coincidental, and has no link to Covid-19.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines didn’t make it past animal trials.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines passed animal trials - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. All four vaccines approved for use in the UK passed animal trials.

claims.text: The EU proposes to abolish freedom to publish pictures of public buildings.

claimReview.title: The EU, the Gherkin and 'freedom of panorama' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The suggestion is to apply copyright protection to images of public buildings for commercial use. It's at an early stage, and may not be taken up by EU legislators.

claims.text: Self-employed mothers take on the burden of childcare and fathers don’t get financial support or bonding time with their child as they aren’t eligible for shared parental leave.

claimReview.title: Shared parental leave: self-employed people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Self-employed mothers can exchange their maternity allowance for shared parental leave and pay for their partner, if he is employed—but they have to give up the maternity allowance. Self-employed fathers aren’t eligible for any time off or pay after having a child.

claims.text: Hundreds of birds found dead on the deck of a ship were killed by 5G.

claimReview.title: No evidence birds found dead on ship were killed by 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that 5G kills birds. They are thought to have died during migration.

claims.text: One third of women in the UK report having been harassed in the workplace and 70% said they didn’t feel able to report it.

claimReview.title: Sexual harassment in the workplace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s difficult to put a figure on this because of differing definitions of harassment. The one third figure comes from a survey that isn’t necessarily representative of adults across the UK, and is about in the middle compared to other survey estimates we’ve seen.

claims.text: Only self-employed people with incomes over £16,000 will lose out from the changes to NICs.

claimReview.title: Taxes, national insurance and the self-employed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s about right. It’s roughly in the middle of two estimates we’ve seen, both of which were done in a reasonable way.

claims.text: Twice as many children were admitted to English hospitals with malnutrition in the first six months of 2020, compared to the same period the year before.

claimReview.title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on data that is not reliable. We cannot say this with any confidence.

claims.text: Football players will display Black Lives Matter on their shirts but weren’t allowed to display the poppy symbol.

claimReview.title: Footballers aren’t banned from wearing the poppy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Footballers in the Premier League have displayed the words Black Lives Matter on their shirts recently, and have always been allowed to wear the poppy. Home nations teams were fined in 2016 for wearing the poppy in an international fixture, but this rule has since been changed.

claims.text: Spending on adult social care has been given a £2 billion boost.

claimReview.title: Trade-offs: local councils face choices about adult social care funding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Whether adult social care funding goes up or down depends on how councils use that funding boost. They could put it all into adult social care. Or they might use some of it to free up money for other services.

claims.text: A&E waiting times in England hit worst-ever level.

claimReview.title: A&E waiting times have hit their worst levels on record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at data which goes back to 2010.

claims.text: The spike protein in some Covid-19 vaccines is toxic to humans.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s some evidence that the spike protein generated by vaccines may travel from the injection site, but we don’t have evidence that it’s harmful.

claims.text: There are only about 50 large companies that trade across the Irish border.

claimReview.title: Irish border: how much trade? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Roughly 100 large companies (with 250+ employees) in Northern Ireland made export deliveries to the Republic in 2016, making up 11% of deliveries to Ireland. We don’t have data for those exports going to the North from the Republic.

claims.text: The Conservatives gave shareholders the power to veto pay policies.

claimReview.title: Executive pay: power to the shareholders? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Coalition government did this in 2013, although these powers didn’t extend to actually setting directors’ pay packets for the preceding year.

claims.text: An image shows a woman in Iran being fed a spoonful of water before she is stoned to death under Sharia law.

claimReview.title: This image does not show a woman about to be stoned to death under Sharia law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture was taken at a protest in Colombia, where the woman allowed herself to be buried in the ground.

claims.text: A little girl gets a dollar towards her kidney transplant every time her picture is shared.

claimReview.title: Posts claiming ‘every share earns money’ for sick children tend to be fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The picture is from 2017, of a girl with leukemia, whose family was encouraging people to donate blood.

claims.text: A picture shows the world's oldest living land animal, a tortoise named Jonathan.

claimReview.title: Viral social media picture doesn’t show world’s oldest living land animal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that the oldest known land animal is a tortoise named Jonathan, but this is a picture of a different tortoise.

claims.text: The UK’s test and trace system has cost £12 billion.

claimReview.title: This comparison of the cost of the Irish and UK contact tracing systems is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £12 billion has been provided for the test and trace programme in England by the UK government. The cost of the app in England and Wales is estimated to be £35 million for development and first-year running costs.

claims.text: Writing off current student loans would cost £100 billion.

claimReview.title: £100 billion: the cost of writing off student debt? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly the value of current student loans in the UK, including maintenance loans. But the true ‘additional’ cost of a policy to write off current student loans, compared to the amount the government already ‘writes off’ from unpaid loans, would be lower than this.

claims.text: An MP’s salary was £66,000 in 2010 and £77,000 in 2018.

claimReview.title: This tweet on public sector pay doesn’t factor in inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t factor in inflation. In 2018 prices, MPs' pay remained stable between 2010 and 2018 at around £77,400.

claims.text: The Australian government has admitted Covid-19 vaccines are a poison.

claimReview.title: Australian government hasn’t admitted vaccines are a dangerous poison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Under Western Australian legislation, vaccines (alongside medicines such as paracetamol) are classed as poisons. This is just a legal definition, and does not mean the government is saying they are dangerous or planning to poison people.

claims.text: Private hospitals can register as a charity saving them up to 80% on their business rates.

claimReview.title: NHS and private hospitals: who pays business rates? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Human and animal cells from sources like aborted foetuses are in vaccines and are linked to childhood leukaemia and diabetes.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They may be used in certain vaccines’ production, but are unlikely to make it to the final product.

claims.text: Independent experts have suggested that Google is paying an effective tax rate on its UK profits of around 3%.

claimReview.title: Is Google paying 3% tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This all comes down to how people think Google’s “economic activity” in the UK should be defined. Several experts have said that the amount of tax that Google is paying over the last decade represents only around 3-5% of the profits that they think Google should be taxed on. HMRC says that Google will be paying the full tax due. Without the full details, we don’t know to what extent this agreement accounts for the concerns that people have about Google’s tax arrangements.

claims.text: Data from a new app which tracks symptoms of Covid-19 claims that up to 6.6 million people in the UK have the disease.

claimReview.title: We don’t know how many people in the UK have Covid-19 and the symptom tracker app doesn’t tell us - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This data cannot be extrapolated to the UK population. The number of people with Covid-19 may be higher, lower, or the same as claimed.

claims.text: We have an expanding population.

claimReview.title: What’s driving our increasing population and household numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: 1,295 people died as a result of the Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s how many people reportedly died shortly after vaccination up to 2 June, not necessarily because of the vaccine. Because so many people are being vaccinated, we would expect some of them to die afterwards, by chance.

claims.text: Nearly 9 per cent of 16 to 24-year-olds had used Class A drugs in the past 12 months.

claimReview.title: Are more young people taking cocaine? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for England and Wales.

claims.text: About 46% of prisoners and 60% of those on short sentences re-offend within a year of release.

claimReview.title: How many prisoners re-offend within a year of release? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for England and Wales as of March 2014. The overall rate of proven re-offending has remained stable for the past decade.

claims.text: West Midlands Police agree that 17-year-old Adam Ali was “murdered” with a Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: Police have not said a West Midlands teen was "murdered" with a Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. Adam Ali was not vaccinated before he died and police are not treating his death as a criminal matter.

claims.text: The UK has made huge progress in cutting greenhouse gas emissions.

claimReview.title: UK greenhouse gas emissions: fast progress but not yet enough to meet future targets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has exceeded its own targets in cutting emissions compared to 1990 levels, and has made bigger cuts than other G7 countries. But this isn’t expected to be enough to meet future targets.

claims.text: Landmark Danish study shows face masks have no significant effect.

claimReview.title: Danish study on mask efficacy only tells us half the story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
A Danish study found the Covid-19 infection rate was lower among mask-wearers than non-mask wearers but not significantly so. 

However this is not proof that masks don’t have a significant effect, as the study didn’t look at whether mask-wearing protects others by stopping wearers from exhaling the virus.

claims.text: Argos is offering a chance to “win” Samsung microwaves for £1.78.

claimReview.title: Argos is not offering microwaves for £1.78 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Argos have told Full Fact that this is not a genuine page or post.

claims.text: Hundreds of GPs are asking patients to prove they need face-to-face appointments in a three-minute telephone call, before they see them.

claimReview.title: Will you have to prove you need to see your GP? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen evidence that GPs are asking patients to prove they need to see them over the telephone. Some people do have concerns about whether taking initial consultations over the phone provides the best quality of care, saves GPs time overall, or saves the NHS money.

claims.text: The vaccines have caused deaths and injuries.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA has determined a possible link between the AstraZeneca vaccine and a rare blood clot which has caused 72 deaths in the UK to 18 August 2021.

claims.text: Wearing protective gloves doesn’t prevent the spread of coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Official advice says handwashing is better at protecting against coronavirus than gloves - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. The World Health Organisation says that regular handwashing is the best way to stop the virus spreading.

claims.text: Per head, spending by local councils is up to 40% lower across regions outside of London.

claimReview.title: Councils in London spend more per head - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's correct.

claims.text: Boris Johnson said his party has “wiped out the national debt”.

claimReview.title: Fake Boris Johnson quote spreads on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence he said this.

claims.text: The Conservatives are giving a record £14 billion to schools.

claimReview.title: Is schools spending going to be at record levels? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Once you account for inflation the increase between 2019/20 and 2022/23 is £4.3 billion in England. This isn’t a record increase in terms of spending per pupil (which is the most meaningful measure).

claims.text: People are putting tape laced with fentanyl on car petrol caps. If you take the tape off with your bare hands it will kill you.

claimReview.title: No evidence people are trying to kill with fentanyl-laced tape on cars - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Full Fact could find no evidence that this is happening. Even if it was, briefly touching a piece of tape laced with fentanyl would not kill you.

claims.text: There are 32,000 jobs at risk in the steel industry.

claimReview.title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the number of people working in the whole steel industry in the UK in 2016. We don’t know with any certainty what the future holds for the steel industry.

claims.text: JustGiving has kept a large percentage of the funds raised by Captain Tom Moore for the NHS. Some posts say the platform has kept £2 million.

claimReview.title: JustGiving are not keeping £2 million commission from donations to Captain Tom Moore - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not right. JustGiving does charge processing fees and collects voluntary donations, but says more than 97% of money raised goes to charity. The platform has donated £100,000 to Captain Tom’s fundraiser.

claims.text: If we left the EU without an alternative trade deal in place then we’d still have a choice about whether to put tariffs on imports.

claimReview.title: Post-Brexit trade tariffs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. In general we’d have to apply the same tariffs to all our trading partners and keep them within limits agreed at the World Trade Organisation. It would be up to other countries, not us, to choose whether to charge tariffs on our exports.

claims.text: The NHS pays £4 billion annually in rent to private investors because of deals under Labour.

claimReview.title: Labour hospital and acute care PFI contracts in England cost £1.4 billion in 2017/18 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In 2017/18 hospital and acute sector PFIs in England that started under Labour cost £1.4 billion.

claims.text: There are nearly one million more disabled people in work since Disability Confident was launched in 2013.

claimReview.title: Counting Esther McVey’s record on employment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but this rise can’t be attributed to any one particular reason or policy.

claims.text: The UK government promised the Barnett Formula would remain but billions have been pledged to other parts of the UK, bypassing the formula, as part of political pacts with the DUP.

claimReview.title: The Barnett Formula isn’t set out in law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the case of the £1 billion for Northern Ireland the Barnett Formula didn’t apply because public spending in England didn’t change.

claims.text: National Insurance Contributions are being used to reduce the national debt.

claimReview.title: What happens to the money from National Insurance Contributions? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some are. This doesn’t mean anyone isn’t getting paid what they’re currently due in pensions or benefits—the UK government invests the NICs that don’t go towards paying pensions and benefits on reducing the national debt.

claims.text: In Wales, Track and Trace costs £32 per head.

claimReview.title: Labour MP contact tracing claim at PMQs out by factor of ten - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Welsh government has put £102 million into Test, Trace and Protect, which works out at £32 per person in Wales. It is unclear whether this funding is the total amount spent on contact tracing in Wales.

claims.text: The steel industry has been decimated over many years.

claimReview.title: 32,000 people work in the British steel industry - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of people employed in steel in the UK - not including steel processing - has fallen from 320,000 in 1971 to 24,000 in 2016.

claims.text: A probable new link has been found between the Pfizer jab and the heart condition myocarditis.

claimReview.title: Possible link between Pfizer second dose and mild heart inflammation in young men - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Researchers reporting to the health ministry in Israel have found a possible link between mild myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle) in young men and getting the second dose of the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.

claims.text: The UK poverty rate is 23.2%, higher than countries including Spain, Greece Italy and Portugal.

claimReview.title: The UK’s poverty rate is around average for the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This compares two different measures of poverty. By one measure the UK poverty rate is estimated to be 23.2%, but on the comparable measure in this case it is around 17%, roughly the EU average.

claims.text: Thérèse Coffey said “It is not my job to worry about people starving to death in the UK”.

claimReview.title: Thérèse Coffey did not say starving people were not her concern - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is a made-up quote.

claims.text: Nine in 10 major businesses in the UK have had cyber-attacks in the last year.
claims.claimant: Dido Harding, Chief Executive of TalkTalk Group, Radio 4 Today

claimReview.title: How many major businesses have experienced a cyber-attack? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure refers to businesses reporting having experienced some form of information security breach in the last year. The survey it's based on isn't representative of the frequency of cyber-attacks in all large businesses across the UK.

claims.text: More people are being caught carrying blades.

claimReview.title: Are more people being prosecuted for carrying knives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of offences involving possession of article with blade or point has been increasing in England and Wales since 2013/14.

claims.text: The fact a BBC journalist reported the collapse of World Trade Center 7 before it actually happened means 9/11 was a “scripted, actor based reality”.

claimReview.title: Error in BBC reporting doesn’t mean 9/11 was scripted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that a BBC journalist reported the collapse of World Trade Center 7 almost half an hour before it fell, as did a number of other news services. There is no evidence this was due to insider information or a “scripted” version of the terror attack.

claims.text: All Tesco meat is halal except pork produce.

claimReview.title: Not all Tesco meat is halal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not all Tesco meat is halal. Some stores do sell it though. No pork products are halal.

claims.text: More than 450 mosques have opened in London.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. There are probably around 477 mosques, Islamic centres, prayer rooms and halls for hire in London.

claims.text: 85% of people who test positive for Covid wore masks always or often.

claimReview.title: Viral video contains several false pandemic claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from a study that found a slightly higher proportion of people who tested negative wore masks, and were less likely to visit restaurants, where mask wearing is difficult.

claims.text: Pictures show Condoleezza Rice, Hilary Clinton and Barack Obama pictured with Osama Bin Laden.

claimReview.title: Osama Bin Laden pictures with US politicians are fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All three pictures are fake.

claims.text: Mobile roaming fees could return for Brits in the EU after Brexit after Theresa May confirms exit from bloc’s digital market.

claimReview.title: Mobile roaming fees could be back after Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. EU regulations mean we can’t currently be charged roaming fees within the EU. After Brexit, we'll no longer be subject to these regulations. It’s unclear if UK mobile companies will bring back roaming charges, nor if a UK-EU roaming regulation agreement can be reached.

claims.text: Poverty is being redefined to remove any reference to income.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: is poverty being redefined to remove any reference to income? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A bill going through Parliament contains plans to replace existing income indicators of child poverty with ones that focus on worklessness and educational attainment. The annual statistics on the income measures will still be published but they won't be the government's main poverty indicators.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines have caused thousands upon thousands of life changing adverse reactions.

claimReview.title: Viral video includes lots of false claims and half truths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Reports of possible events that have occurred around the time of vaccination are made to the MHRA’s Yellow Card scheme. Just because they’ve been reported does not mean that they have been proven to be caused by the vaccine.

claims.text: Vaccines contain graphene oxide.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines still don’t contain graphene oxide - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Covid-19 vaccines do not contain graphene oxide.

claims.text: Evidence is growing that Covid-19 vaccines may worsen the disease in some recipients because antibodies developed as a result of the jab can end up enhancing disease rather than protecting against infection.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence Covid-19 vaccines make the disease worse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Antibody dependant enhancement is a rare but genuine risk when it comes to creating new vaccines. There is good evidence that this does not occur with the current Covid-19 vaccines in use, from animal studies, large human trials, and real world data from people who have received the vaccine.

claims.text: The risk of a child dying of Covid-19 is around one in 3.5 million.

claimReview.title: The risk of dying from a Covid vaccine is lower than 1 in 31,000 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The risk of a child dying of Covid is very low, but this figure refers to the England and Wales death rate as of May last year, when more people had it so chances of getting ill were higher. Estimates suggest perhaps 1 in 100,000 children who catch Covid die of it, but, in the UK at least, there are very few infections so the risk will be lower.

claims.text: 25% of coronavirus deaths in Wales are in care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC based on figures from the Office for National Statistics.

claims.text: A man who assaulted his wife was spared jail because the judge didn’t consider her “vulnerable”.

claimReview.title: When are domestic violence victims not “vulnerable”? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The judge did mention that he didn’t consider the victim to be “particularly” vulnerable. Official sentencing guidelines required him to look into that as a possible aggravating factor in setting the length of the attacker’s sentence. It wasn’t relevant to his separate decision to suspend the sentence.
