claims.text: Sadiq Khan posed with a Sharia Zone leaflet.

claimReview.title: Sadiq Khan did not pose for photos with a Sharia zone leaflet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been edited. The original image didn’t feature Mr Khan or leaflets on Sharia zones.

claims.text: Grant Shapps said that people who are double vaccinated are more likely to get and carry Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Grant Shapps misspoke about double vaccinated people on BBC Breakfast - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Grant Shapps did say this. His office has explained that it was a simple mistake. He intended to say that people who are double vaccinated are much less likely to get and carry Covid-19.

claims.text: The government is cutting the number of hospital beds.

claimReview.title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is right, the number of overnight beds in the English NHS has fallen.

claims.text: We are on course to have a death toll this year in line with recent years.

claimReview.title: No, we are not on track for a normal number of deaths this year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Unless deaths decline sharply, the UK death toll is likely to be its highest in decades.

claims.text: Wind generates about 10% of the UK's power

claimReview.title: How much of our energy comes from wind? MPs disagree - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's right—it generated 10% of the UK's electricity in 2014/15, although the amount varied within the year.

claims.text: NHS Test and Trace has employed about 20,000 staff.

claimReview.title: NHS Test and Trace has not spent £37bn so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. In December it employed “over 50,000” people.

claims.text: The same image of an elderly woman being vaccinated has been used by the media to show a woman called Joan being vaccinated in Manchester and a woman called Susan getting vaccinated in South Africa.

claimReview.title: A satirical caption in a South African newspaper under a picture of a British woman getting the vaccine has caused confusion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture is of a woman called Joan Burgess being vaccinated in Manchester. The picture appeared in a South African newspaper with a joke caption in part of the paper which is usually satirical.

claims.text: The Institute for Fiscal Studies, National Audit Office, Education Policy Institute and Public Accounts Committee all agree that per-pupil spending in schools will be reduced in real terms over the next few years.

claimReview.title: Experts agree school funding is falling per-pupil - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: An orange has tested positive for Covid-19 using a lateral flow test.

claimReview.title: Oranges don’t test positive for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not accurate. The fruit appears to have broken the test, making it appear like a positive result. Lateral flow tests rarely give false positives, and are more likely to give false negatives.

claims.text: There are almost 11,800 more doctors than in 2010.

claimReview.title: Are there more doctors in the NHS than in 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly correct looking at doctors working in NHS hospitals and community health services in England.

claims.text: Deprived areas are facing the most significant council cuts.

claimReview.title: Are the most significant council budget cuts in deprived areas? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Councils that are most dependent on government grants—those which are poorest or in inner London—have seen their budgets reduced by more than other councils between 2009/10 and 2016/17.

claims.text: Leaving Euratom will not affect the UK’s ability to import medical radioisotopes - which are used to diagnose and treat certain kinds of cancer.

claimReview.title: Could leaving the European nuclear club put cancer patients at risk? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t certain, and will depend on what future arrangements are negotiated. The UK may find it harder to guarantee a supply after leaving.

claims.text: Police numbers fell under Boris Johnson as Mayor of London.

claimReview.title: Police numbers under Boris Johnson’s time as Mayor - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Police officer numbers were higher when Boris Johnson left office compared to when he entered office, but were lower since his first budget as Mayor.

claims.text: Cocaine use among young people is at its highest level for a decade

claimReview.title: Are more young people taking cocaine? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Cocaine use is at a nine-year high among 16-24 year olds in England & Wales. 6% had taken cocaine in the past year.

claims.text: Dandelion root is able to kill 98% of cancer cells within 48 hours.

claimReview.title: Dandelion root is not a proven cancer cure - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Laboratory studies using cancer cells have shown that dandelion root extract has anti-cancer effects, but this has not been proven in humans.

claims.text: There were 2,000 new social homes in 2014/15, compared to 12,000 social homes which were sold as part of the Right to Buy scheme.

claimReview.title: Are homes sold under Right to Buy being replaced? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figure are correct for social homes sold and being built by local authorities in England.

claims.text: Stop and search is achieving a higher arrest rate.

claimReview.title: Stop and search: higher arrest rate? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The arrest rate in England and Wales rose from 8% in 2009/10 to 17% in 2016/17. The number of stop and searches fell from 1.3 million to 300,000 between those years.

claims.text: As of 3 November, the UK’s coronavirus epidemic was escalating by the day.

claimReview.title: Why are media outlets reporting the Covid epidemic is escalating? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At this point, new infections were falling, but the total number of people with Covid-19 may still have been increasing.

claims.text: The Treasury forecast that dropping out of the European single market will cost the economy £66 billion and reduce GDP by 7.5%.

claimReview.title: Leaving the single market - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is confusing estimates for GDP with estimates for tax revenue. The Treasury does expect GDP to be 7.5% lower than it otherwise would have been after 15 years, if the UK relies on World Trade Organisation rules outside of the single market. But the £66 billion figure is for the resulting loss to public finances, not the economy, and it's the upper limit - £52 billion is the Treasury's best estimate.

claims.text: Polysorbate 80 and 20 are in vaccines and cause cancer in animals and are linked to autoimmune issues and infertility.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Tiny amounts of Polysorbate 80 is in a type of flu vaccine. There isn’t evidence ingesting it is linked to these issues in humans.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets free mobile phone calls.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim for expenses for the costs of running a constituency office, including telephone and mobile phone calls for parliamentary purposes.

claims.text: Support for Welsh independence was never more than 10%.

claimReview.title: Latest poll puts support for Welsh independence at 24% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A recent poll put support for Welsh independence at 24%.

claims.text: The UK government will be £290 million a week worse off because of leaving the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit means... borrowing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s what the Office for Budget Responsibility expect, but it’s a hugely uncertain figure and relies on assumptions about future immigration, productivity and inflation.

claims.text: Corporation tax rates have gone down since 2010 but the amount raised by this tax has increased to £56 billion, the highest ever recorded.

claimReview.title: Corporation tax: could we have raised more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that the rate has fallen, but the actual amount raised in 2016/17 was £50 billion. The tricky question is how these two things are related. The government’s own estimates suggest it might have collected more without having made changes to corporation tax, even though these estimates are quite uncertain.

claims.text: The head of Ofsted wants schools to discriminate on the basis of race when hiring teachers.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: Can white teachers be discriminated against? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sir Michael Wilshaw said that in some cases, he would hire an equally qualified person from an ethnic minority over another. But in law, this isn't 'discrimination'.

claims.text: 66 A&E and maternity wards have been closed.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know, as this information isn’t collected nationally. In 2014, there were reportedly plans to close or downgrade 66 in England, but while some have been, others have stayed open.

claims.text: Alcohol-based hand sanitiser can become heated when left in hot cars leading to flammable vapours being released, these can then ignite in normal air conditions and set fire to flammable components in the car.

claimReview.title: Alcohol-based hand sanitiser cannot catch fire, without a spark, just because it's in a hot car - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Alcohol-based hand sanitiser cannot catch fire at the temperatures found in cars without a spark.

claims.text: The Pfizer vaccine has a one in 17 mortality rate.

claimReview.title: Pfizer vaccine doesn’t have a 6% fatality rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Of those adverse event cases reported after vaccination with the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine which ended in death or recovery, this figure is the proportion which were fatal.

claims.text: Menachem Begin was a key organiser of the 1946 Irgun attack on the King David Hotel in Jerusalem.

claimReview.title: This is a real photo of Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Begin did order the attack.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us the right to vote on our laws. And a court to make sure that British people and businesses are fairly treated.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, remaining would mean UK citizens have a vote on legislators and to be heard in court (so does leaving).

claims.text: 97% of Labour activists back a "Remain alliance" election pact.

claimReview.title: Claim that 97% of Labour activists support remain alliance is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is based on a survey of supporters of a pro-remain Labour campaign group. It is not representative of all Labour activists.

claims.text: One in four doctors and one in six nurses is an immigrant.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The length of time it took to discover thalidomide’s dangers proves more time should be spent researching medicines, particularly Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Covid vaccines aren’t comparable to thalidomide scandal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Thalidomide underwent a very different research and regulation process to Covid-19 vaccines. There is no evidence so far that any of the Covid-19 vaccines in use in the UK are unsafe for pregnant people.

claims.text: Pets must be walked alone within 50m of your house.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t true. You can go further away from your house and walk them with members of your household as part of your daily exercise.

claims.text: People living in Labour councils pay on average £351 less council tax than those living in Tory councils.

claimReview.title: Do Labour councils cost you £350 less in council tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Technically correct for England in 2019/20, based on the average bill per eligible home, but this isn’t very meaningful. Many residents pay council tax to more than one body, so it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single council or party.

claims.text: Leave campaigners before the referendum weren’t consistent on whether Brexit meant leaving the customs union.

claimReview.title: What was promised about the customs union before the referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The customs union was rarely mentioned by Leave campaigners before the referendum. There were generally calls for the UK to have an independent trade policy, though messages about specific trading arrangements weren’t always consistent.

claims.text: A video of Bill Gates casts doubt on whether the Covid-19 vaccines work.

claimReview.title: We do know that Covid-19 vaccines work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It doesn’t. Bill Gates was speaking in July 2020, before the results of the vaccine trials were known.

claims.text: The formation of “non-neutralizing antibodies” can lead to an exaggerated immune reaction, especially when the person is confronted with the real, “wild” virus after vaccination. This so-called antibody-dependent amplification, ADE, has long been known from experiments with corona vaccines in cats.

claimReview.title: Claims about the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine ingredients lack evidence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence antibody-dependent amplification is an issue in humans with Covid-19, and the use of plasma therapy suggests that it is not.

claims.text: The government voted to allow water companies to pump sewage into rivers.

claimReview.title: Murky claims about sewage bill fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The amendment rejected by the government would have also allowed the pumping of sewage into rivers, but required it to be progressively reduced.

claims.text: Cuts to income tax will save the typical basic rate taxpayer £1,205 a year.

claimReview.title: Are we saving £1,205 a year in income tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on the increase in the tax-free personal allowance, from 2010/11 to 2019/20. But it doesn’t account for inflation. The figure drops to £940 once that’s factored in.

claims.text: You are not exempt from wearing a face covering unless you have a supporting letter from a doctor, and wearing the invisible disability exemption badge is illegal.

claimReview.title: You do not need a doctor’s letter to prove exemption from face coverings - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You do not need a doctor’s letter to prove exemption and you may choose, although are generally not required, to carry an exemption card. Wearing an exemption badge or carrying a card is not illegal.

claims.text: Labour party members voted to debate Palestine rather than Brexit and the NHS at the 2018 Labour Conference.

claimReview.title: Labour members did vote to debate Palestine over the NHS and Brexit at the 2018 party Conference - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, although Brexit was still debated due to being chosen for debate by Trade Unions. CLP members are usually encouraged to vote for options not chosen by the Unions.

claims.text: 64 million people took advantage of the ‘Eat Out to Help Out’ scheme.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence for how many people took part in ‘Eat Out To Help Out’ or later died from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Treasury said more than 100 million meals were served as part of the scheme. It’s likely many people took part more than once, meaning we can’t know the exact number of participants.

claims.text: The Track and Trace app cost £37 billion.

claimReview.title: NHS Covid-19 app is not the third most expensive project ever - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS Covid-19 app cost around £76 million in the first year. £37 billion is the total budget for NHS Test and Trace in its first two years.

claims.text: Wages have stopped rising.

claimReview.title: Evening Standard wrong to say wages aren’t rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Average employee wages are growing at 1.9% per year in real terms.

claims.text: If you need the police in a situation where you can’t speak, ring 999 and when they answer press 55. This tells them that you need help and they will dispatch police to you.

claimReview.title: The police won’t always be dispatched if you dial 55 during a 999 call - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you can’t talk during a 999 call, dialling 55 should route your call to the police. But they won’t necessarily send officers and they can’t always trace calls to an exact address.

claims.text: Deprived areas are facing the most significant cuts to adult social care budgets.

claimReview.title: Are the most significant council budget cuts in deprived areas? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Council spending on adult social care hasn’t reduced on average as steeply as for some other services, but the reductions have been highest in areas with the greatest need, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

claims.text: Two thirds of police forces are rated good or outstanding.

claimReview.title: How many police forces are rated good or outstanding? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct based on HMIC’s most recent report on police effectiveness. Of the 43 police forces in England and Wales one was found to be outstanding and 28 were good in 2016. That’s just over two thirds.

claims.text: Weight loss pills advertised on Facebook have been endorsed by judges on the US version of Dragons’ Den, Shark Tank.

claimReview.title: Facebook posts falsely advertise weight loss pills as endorsed by judges on US Dragons’ Den - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Shark Tank has never featured weight loss pills.

claims.text: On average, Labour councils charge you £93 more in band D than Conservative councils, and Liberal Democrat councils charge you £120 more.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson repeats misleading council tax comparison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour and Liberal Democrat councils have higher band D rates than Conservative councils, but this measure is misleading. Labour councils charge lower council tax on average than Conservative councils.

claims.text: £10 billion extra funding for the English NHS will pay for new seven-day services.

claimReview.title: Can a "seven-day NHS" be paid for? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government maintains this will happen, but experts doubt it’s possible without more money, as the original plans didn’t factor in the cost of seven-day services. It also needs the NHS to meet ambitious savings targets.

claims.text: People born poor will die nine years earlier than others.

claimReview.title: Life expectancy and poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is partially correct. Boys born in some of the poorest areas in the UK are expected to live nine years fewer than those in the very richest areas. For girls the figure is seven years.

claims.text: Help to Buy ISAs won’t help you with your mortgage deposit.

claimReview.title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Several banks have said that they will treat the bonus payments as part of the buyer’s savings when they apply for a mortgage, even though it won’t arrive in their bank account until after the sale is completed.

claims.text: The Taylor Review found that 58% of people working on zero hour contracts did not want more hours.

claimReview.title: How many people on zero hours contracts want more hours? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Incorrect, it was actually 68%, which refers to people on the contracts who’ve specified a view of their hours. It’s 57% if you include people who didn’t specify a view.
Newer official figures put the same figures at around 72% and 63% respectively.

claims.text: Under a more proportional voting system, UKIP would have around 100 seats.

claimReview.title: How many seats could UKIP have under a different voting system? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 80 seats is plausible, based on UKIP’s vote in 2015, although it depends on the voting system.

claims.text: In March 2020, the Home Office paid over £77,000 to an eyebrow threading company that was dissolved in 2018.

claimReview.title: Everything you need to know about the Home Office’s ‘eyebrow’ spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The Home Office has said the money was spent on PPE.

One of the companies paid, called “Beautiful Brows”, is dissolved. However, a website of the same name, which sells PPE, is operated by another company which is still active.

claims.text: 4,300 people die of diabetes every day.

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct.

claims.text: Just 2.9% of deaths were caused by Covid-19 in the first three months of 2020.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post is wrong on deaths in first three months of 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the first 12 weeks of 2020, less than 1% of deaths registered in England and Wales had Covid-19 on the death certificate, but the rate has since risen to more than 30% for some weeks in April.

claims.text: Dialling 55 during a 999 call will automatically dispatch the police to where you are.

claimReview.title: Dialling 55 during 999 call won’t automatically send police to your location - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you can’t talk during a 999 call, dialling 55 should route your call to the police. But they won’t necessarily send officers and they can’t always trace calls to an exact address.

claims.text: Diabetes is on the rise.

claimReview.title: Healthcheck: cancer, diabetes and mental health conditions on the rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of people living with a diagnosed case of diabetes has almost doubled since 1998, according to Diabetes UK. We’ve asked it for more information on its figures.

claims.text: Experts agree that… prices would rise

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on prices - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If we voted to leave the EU that could see prices rise in the short term due to the expectation that the value of the pound would fall. The longer term is more uncertain.

claims.text: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “The danger is that pupils will be overpromoted into jobs that are beyond their competence.”

claimReview.title: Gavin Williamson did not say pupils will be overpromoted into jobs that are beyond their competence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true and does not accurately reflect comments Mr Williamson made in The Daily Telegraph. This incorrect paraphrasing seems to have begun as a joke.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means the UK makes its own laws again.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
If we leave the EU with no deal, EU laws will no longer have power or jurisdiction over the UK (although all existing EU law will be copied over into UK law).

However the UK will still follow certain international rules and regulations, such as trading rules determined by the WTO and the European Convention of Human Rights.

claims.text: A senior judge has said that many of the people in the Calais "jungle" migrant camp aren't refugees, but want the UK's "economic benefits".

claimReview.title: "The judge who dared to tell the truth"? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One line in a recent judgment says "many are probably not refugees", but want to apply for asylum in the UK instead of France "due to perceived advantages". His judgment doesn't mention benefits.

claims.text: 2020 has had the 6th highest death rate in the past thirty years.

claimReview.title: Death rate back to early 2000s levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 2020 had the joint-11th highest death rate over the past three decades.

claims.text: Pensioners who have paid half a century’s worth of tax and national insurance are given £8,840 to live comfortably.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post compares the national living wage with the state pension - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the average amount per year that the bottom fifth of single pensioners by income were getting between 2015 and 2018, according to research by retirement finance company Just Group. The exact state pension depends on the individual.

claims.text: Nearly 90% of those convicted of wider child abuse offences and on the sex offenders register are white men.

claimReview.title: What do we know about the ethnicity of people involved in sexual offences against children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t much publicly available information on this. The data we do have shows a large majority of those convicted of sexual offences (no matter the age of the victim) are white.

claims.text: A girl called Alice was kidnapped when out walking with her family and authorities need help identifying the suspect from a video.

claimReview.title: Missing girl ‘news article’ is harvesting Facebook logins - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a scam webpage to harvest Facebook login details, which the site asks for to view the video of the “suspect”. This is not a genuine missing person case.

claims.text: 19 million people are at school.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of school pupils in the UK is around 10 million.

claims.text: 85% of schools are good and outstanding schools, vs 68% in 2010.

claimReview.title: Government resurfaces misleading claim about good or outstanding schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to England, and doesn’t acknowledge changes to inspection practices. A significant chunk of pupils are in schools that haven’t been inspected since 2010.

claims.text: Rio 2016 was the UK's best overseas Olympics.

claimReview.title: The Olympic Games, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The only times the UK has won more gold medals was in 1908 and 2012 when the games were held in London.

claims.text: In Wales you cannot drive to your place of exercise.

claimReview.title: It’s true that recent changes to lockdown rules are slightly different throughout the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct as of 11 May.

claims.text: One in five asylum seekers in the EU are from Syria.

claimReview.title: Are only one in five asylum seekers Syrian? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct for the EU asylum applications in spring 2015 (the latest figures available). But this was before a more recent surge in arrivals, and there is evidence to suggest that a high proportion of these people are from Syria.

claims.text: In London crime has risen five times faster than the rest of the country since Sadiq Khan became Mayor in 2016.

claimReview.title: Crime in London has risen less than the rest of England since 2016 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Recorded crime per person in London has increased by 18% over this period, less than the 31% increase across England overall. These statistics only count crime recorded by police, and it’s estimated that overall crime is decreasing.

claims.text: Only 6 per cent of UK firms export to the EU, yet all have to abide by EU regulations on their business

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: exporting firms - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are no official figures of how many UK businesses export to the EU. This estimate is justifiable and we do know that around 5% of VAT-registered businesses exported to their EU peers in 2014/15.

claims.text: The courts have said that the so-called 'bedroom tax' is illegal.

claimReview.title: The ruling on the 'bedroom tax' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The decision affects victims of domestic violence whose homes have 'panic spaces', and disabled children who need overnight carers. It doesn't spell the end of the policy in general and is likely to be appealed to the Supreme Court.

claims.text: A 10% rise in immigration leads to a 2% reduction in wages.

claimReview.title: Does a 10% rise in immigration lead to a 2% reduction in wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Bank of England found that a 10% increase in the proportion of foreign born workers in lower paid service jobs was associated with a near 2% fall in average pay for those jobs, when focusing on particular regions.

claims.text: There are over 13,300 more nurses on our wards since May 2010.

claimReview.title: Are there more nurses on our wards? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t substantiated by the available data. We don’t have figures specifically for the total number of nurses on hospital wards. The claim refers to figures just for nurses working in ‘general care’ with adults, which misses out some nurses in children’s and mental health services who also work on wards.

claims.text: If you call 999 in an emergency but can’t speak, press 55 and they can track where you are calling from using new technology.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that dialling 55 in a silent 999 call lets the police track your location - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you can’t talk during a 999 call, dialling 55 should route your call to the police. But it won’t automatically track your location, and it’s not always possible to pinpoint your exact location if calling from a mobile.

claims.text: Addicts and alcoholics cost the public £10 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: Do addicts and alcoholics cost the taxpayer £10 billion a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research estimated that public expenditure on people who are homeless, offenders, and/or drug misusers is roughly £10 billion a year in England. So it's not just an estimate of the cost of alcohol and drug addiction. The research describes that estimate as "indicative and not definitive", and says it's likely to be a conservative estimate.

claims.text: Sir David Attenborough said “words fail me” over the felling of a 300 year-old tree for an HS2 service road.

claimReview.title: No evidence Sir David Attenborough made viral comments about HS2 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence Sir David ever made these comments.

claims.text: The Pfizer and Moderna Covid-19 vaccines use lipid nanoparticles to deliver an mRNA load into cells.

claimReview.title: No evidence that nanoparticles in Covid-19 vaccines affect fertility - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Almost half of young offenders are from black or ethnic minorities.

claimReview.title: Young offenders from ethnic minorities - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct if you look at “young offenders” who end up with custodial sentences. 47% of young people responding to a survey of young offender institutions by HM Inspectorate of Prisons reported they were black, Asian or minority ethnic in 2015/16. Ministry of Justice figures paint a similar picture of all children in custody.

claims.text: The Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies said that 1 June was too soon to reopen schools.

claimReview.title: SAGE did not advise against reopening schools on 1 June - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. It was the Independent SAGE, a different group, who gave this advice.

claims.text: A new English language test has been introduced for nurses which means that some people who would otherwise have been able to practice can’t.

claimReview.title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: English language tests have been a requirement for nurses from outside of the EU since 2005. In January 2016 these were extended to include nurses from the EU/EEA. It’s been cited as one of a number of reasons, including Brexit, behind falling nursing recruitment.

claims.text: A speech by the Home Secretary Amber Rudd has been reported as a hate incident.

claimReview.title: Hate incidents aren’t the same as hate crimes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s true, but if someone has reported it to the police and given that reason then they have to record it as ‘hate incident’. They only record a ‘hate crime’ if they think something illegal has probably happened.

claims.text: Reports to the Yellow Card scheme suggest that the Covid vaccine from AstraZeneca is not safe.

claimReview.title: There is no evidence that people are dying from the Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The Yellow Card scheme has collected reports of adverse health events following vaccination, but none of the deaths or serious events so far appear to have been caused by it.

claims.text: Unemployment in Wales, at 4.1%, is the lowest in the UK.

claimReview.title: Unemployment in Wales is the lowest in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s the lowest of the four countries within the UK, but not the lowest of any region.

claims.text: Local NHS has been allocated £570 billion to fund the NHS Long Term Plan.

claimReview.title: Will local NHS services in England have £570 billion to spend over the next five years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over the next five years across England, CCGs’ budgets are expected to total around £570 billion in cash terms. Funding is set to increase by around £3 billion each year in real terms.

claims.text: The Conservatives plan to take on 6,000 more police officers in 12 months at a cost of £750 million.

claimReview.title: Don’t compare Labour and Conservative costings for police recruitment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This covers police salaries as well as any costs associated with recruitment and training.

claims.text: A judge refused to allow a child to live with her grandparents, instead of being adopted, because they were too old.

claimReview.title: The "too old to adopt their granddaughter" myth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn't correct. Age was mentioned in passing in the judge's written decision, but not as the main reason for it.

claims.text: 73% of people under 24 voted to remain.

claimReview.title: How did young people vote in the Brexit referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s a reasonable estimate for how many 18-24 year old voters voted Remain in the 2016 EU referendum, based on the results of polls and surveys. There are no official figures, so it’s impossible to say exactly what the true figure is.

claims.text: Flamingo egg yolks are pink.

claimReview.title: Flamingo egg yolks are not bright pink - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Like chicken eggs, flamingo eggs have yellow to red egg yolks.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation as of June 25th has said no asymptomatic testing.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The WHO said it only recommended asymptomatic testing for at-risk groups.

claims.text: Over 3 million UK jobs are linked to our exports to the EU - that’s one in every ten UK jobs.

claimReview.title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: jobs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estimates show around 3 million jobs are linked to our trade with other EU countries, but don’t tell us anything about the number of jobs linked to British membership of the EU. Nobody is forecasting that these 3 million jobs would be lost if we left the EU.

claims.text: The Guardian reported that an ambulance carrying an Insulate Britain protester was delayed in traffic caused by another protest.

claimReview.title: A ‘Guardian’ headline about the Insulate Britain protests is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It comes from a digitally altered screenshot with a fake headline.

claims.text: Flu is killing many more people than Covid-19 at the moment.

claimReview.title: Flu isn’t the underlying cause of death for more people than Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t evidence for this. Although we don’t have detailed data on recent deaths, there are almost certainly fewer deaths where flu is identified as the underlying cause compared to Covid-19.

claims.text: If Lord Kinnock, Lord Mandelson, or Lord Patten began to publicly criticise the EU, their pensions would be withdrawn.

claimReview.title: EU staff don’t lose their pensions for criticising the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: All three are ex-EU commissioners. None would lose their pension for criticising the EU.

claims.text: Delaying a decision about which runway to build costs the UK economy £6 million every day.

claimReview.title: Does delaying airport expansion cost us £6 million a day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Whether or not you agree that a delay in the decision is imposing unnecessary costs on the UK economy, this probably isn’t the best estimate of what those costs are. Any precise figure will be uncertain.

claims.text: Ursula von der Leyen is the new EU President.

claimReview.title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no such thing as an “EU president”. Ms von der Leyen has been nominated to be President of the European Commission, one of the EU’s three main institutions. This needs to be confirmed by a majority of MEPs.

claims.text: There are more teachers.

claimReview.title: Teachers with first class degrees - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’re not sure of the timeframe for this claim, but teacher numbers generally did increase between 2010 and 2015, although the number of secondary teachers fell.

claims.text: A photo shows an EU police force which is coming to the UK.

claimReview.title: There is no EU police force being rolled out in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo is of Peruvian police officers. There is no current policy for an EU police force.

claims.text: People were stabbed at protests in London over the weekend of 13 June.

claimReview.title: There were no stabbings reported at protests in London over the weekend - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The Met Police have said that there were no reported stabbings at the protests over the weekend.

claims.text: The Immensa lab, which may have given more than 43,000 inaccurate PCR test results, was fully accredited before being appointed by the government.

claimReview.title: Government hasn’t explained differing statements on lab accused of inaccurate Covid-19 results - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was originally stated by a government spokesperson, however it later emerged that it was untrue. The government told Full Fact that the lab was in the “early stages” of accreditation, but did not explain the discrepancy between the two statements.

claims.text: All of the Covid-19 variants have planned release dates.

claimReview.title: Covid variants weren’t planned - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They don’t. These claims come from a document that seems to be fake that has been circulating since July and been debunked numerous times.

claims.text: The "Stevens plan" for an extra £8bn into the NHS can help to fund better mental health services, among other things.

claimReview.title: There's only so much £8 billion will buy you in the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £8bn is the minimum amount required to keep services at current levels.  It is not extra money to pay for extra services.

claims.text: The last Labour government made 1.4 million homes habitable.

claimReview.title: Did Labour make 1.4 million “non-decent” homes fit to live in? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Between the introduction of Labour’s “Decent Homes Programme” in 2000 and 2009, an estimated 1.4 million “non-decent” social sector homes in England received work to make them habitable.

claims.text: People are getting paid £850 a week in benefits.

claimReview.title: It’s possible to receive financial support above the benefits cap, but this does not apply to the majority of households - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most people receiving universal credit or housing support receive less than this figure due to the benefits cap. Some can receive over the benefits cap, but most do not.

claims.text: Every five minutes, 70 children will be born in the UK, 20 to mothers not born here.

claimReview.title: One born every minute? How many migrants arrive in the UK and how many children do they have? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In 2016 the equivalent of around seven children were born every five minutes, of whom around two were born to mothers not born in the UK.

claims.text: Keir Starmer stopped Jimmy Savile being charged in 2009.

claimReview.title: Keir Starmer led the CPS when it did not charge Jimmy Savile, but he wasn’t the reviewing lawyer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Starmer was head of the CPS when the decision was made not to prosecute Savile but he was not the reviewing lawyer for the case. An official investigation commissioned later by Starmer criticised both prosecutors and police for their handling of the allegations.

claims.text: Charles Bronson has recently assaulted Ian Huntley in his prison cell.

claimReview.title: Charles Bronson has not attacked Ian Huntley - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The men are in different prisons.

claims.text: That’s more than the £3,087.96 a Universal Credit claimant gets each year.

claimReview.title: What extra expenses can MPs claim if they have children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £3,087 is the standard annual allowance for Universal Credit from October 2021 for someone aged under 25 who is single. Claimants with children receive more than this.

claims.text: Police are searching for a man and child after a member of the public reported the child telling the man “you’re not my dad”.

claimReview.title: Hunt for child who told man ‘you’re not my dad’ was false alarm - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct at the time of publication, but police have since confirmed that this was a false alarm. They’ve visited the child to confirm he is safe and well with his father and there is no ongoing search.

claims.text: Home tests for the new coronavirus will be available in days.

claimReview.title: Home Covid-19 tests will not be readily available to the public by the end of March - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was said by the director of the national infection service at Public Health England. However, medical experts and politicians have since said the new tests will not be ready so soon.

claims.text: If you are registered to vote in two places you are allowed to vote in both places during local elections.

claimReview.title: You can register to vote in two places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, provided that they are in separate local authorities.

claims.text: £1.8 billion of ‘new money’ has been announced for the NHS over the next five years.

claimReview.title: Money for the NHS: is it new or not? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £850 million has been announced for 20 hospitals over the next five years and £1 billion for the NHS in capital funding this year. The £1 billion is money that NHS trusts previously earned through a cost-cutting incentive scheme, but were then told not to spend. It is ‘new’ in the sense that the Treasury had not previously budgeted for them spending it.

claims.text: We have the highest female employment rate on record.

claimReview.title: Women in work: the female employment rate, company boards and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. A higher proportion of women aged 16-64 are in paid work than ever before, although the employment rate is still lower for women than for men.

claims.text: Anyone in Manchester with blood group O negative should go to the Royal Infirmary as they have run out of blood.

claimReview.title: The NHS is not asking people with type O negative blood to go to donate at Manchester Royal Infirmary - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: Pensioners have had free TV taken away.

claimReview.title: Prisoners don’t have to pay the TV licence whereas most pensioners will soon have to - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is partially correct. Free TV licences for all over 75s were due to end from June 2020 and this will be replaced by a scheme where only those over 75 who receive Pension Credit (or whose partner lives with them and receives Pension Credit) will not have to pay. Due to the Covid-19 pandemic the BBC has said this scheme will now begin from 1 August.

claims.text: Nine in 10 school-age girls are being sent explicit images.

claimReview.title: Nine in 10 girls did not say they’d been sent explicit images - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The evidence, which comes from an Ofsted survey, does not support this claim. It found that 88% of girls said this happens among young people—not that it had happened to them.

claims.text: The most serious violent and sexual offenders receive automatic early release from prison halfway through their sentence.

claimReview.title: More prisoners to be released two thirds of the way through sentence than halfway - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the default sentence (excluding those given life) though judges in England and Wales are already allowed to keep offenders in prison for two thirds of their sentence if they are considered dangerous.

claims.text: The weekly UK state pension is £141 compared to £304 in France, £513 in Spain and £507 in Germany.

claimReview.title: This comparison of pensions in different countries is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures for the UK, Spain and France are in the right ballpark in terms of the maximum available in each country, but differences between their pension systems means it’s not a fair comparison.

claims.text: Anxiety levels among young teenagers dropped during the coronavirus pandemic, a study has suggested.

claimReview.title: Claims of pandemic fall in child anxiety may not apply across the whole country - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is nothing wrong with the study, which surveyed year 9 students in the south west of England. But this data may not be representative of children across the country and in other age groups.

claims.text: The Prime Minister says the number of nurses is up by 3,000 since the last election, while a Labour MP says it's down by 2,500.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: How nurse numbers can be up as well as down - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends who you count, how you count them, and what time period you count from.

claims.text: Only a tiny proportion of rapes ever reach trial.

claimReview.title: Reported rapes that reach trial - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around one in ten rapes or attempted rapes reported to police in England and Wales are brought to trial. Research from 2013 estimated that between one in twenty and one in thirty rape cases end up at trial.

claims.text: More people died from suicide than from Covid-19 in August.

claimReview.title: This post comparing deaths in August is a guess - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no data on the number of deaths from suicide in August this year, as the cause of death needs to be confirmed by an inquest. The monthly average from 2018, the most recent year we have data for, was slightly higher than the number of Covid deaths in August 2020.

claims.text: The number of operations classed as urgent that have been cancelled twice have doubled since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of urgent operations in England cancelled for the second time or more for non-medical reasons more than doubled between 2011/12 and 2017/18.

claims.text: The climate change committee says that the Government is way off target with its climate change commitments and carbon targets.

claimReview.title: The UK is not on track to meet its carbon emissions targets for the next 15 years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is off target. In June 2018, the Committee on Climate Change said “the fact is that we’re off track to meet our own emissions targets in the 2020s and 2030s.”

claims.text: An image of a bright yellow fish with a trunk depicts an elephant fish.

claimReview.title: Viral image doesn’t show an elephant fish - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image appears to have been altered. The fish pictured is markedly different from recognised species of elephant fish.

claims.text: Almost three-quarters of first time buyers say paying upfront costs like stamp duty will be more of a challenge than paying for a mortgage deposit.

claimReview.title: Saving up for stamp duty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not quite what the poll said. 72% of potential first-time buyers said that paying for upfront costs like stamp duty and removals would be ‘difficult’. 69% said saving for a mortgage deposit would also be ‘difficult’. 34% said it would be ‘difficult’ to meet the monthly mortgage payments.

claims.text: The government claims it has capacity for 300,000 Covid-19 tests a day.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner’s testing numbers are not quite right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The official Coronavirus Dashboard has shown roughly this capacity figure for all tests in the UK (including antibody tests) in the past. It currently shows a daily diagnostic test capacity of around 240,000.

claims.text: The EU Court of Justice has decided that obese people are disabled, and so entitled to protection under employment law.

claimReview.title: Did the EU rule that obesity is a disability? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. The court said that an obese person can be considered disabled, if their ability to work is limited. In itself this isn't a major change.

claims.text: Men are less likely to develop breast cancer because antiperspirant deodorant is applied to the hair rather than directly on to the skin.

claimReview.title: The role of antiperspirant in causing breast cancer is not proven - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Men are less likely to develop breast cancer due to  differences in the amount and type of breast tissue in men. There are also important hormonal differences between men and women which relate to this.

claims.text: This image shows a heart-shaped honeycomb pattern which was made naturally by bees.

claimReview.title: This honeycomb pattern was made by bees, but it was no accident - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to come from a beekeeper who partly curated the pattern.

claims.text: A three-page trade agreement under Article 24 would be “enough to avoid delays at borders”.
claims.claimant: Iain Duncan Smith, David Campbell Bannerman, Martin Howe, Jon Moynihan, Rebecca Ryan

claimReview.title: GATT 24: new argument, same old problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This agreement would mean the UK and EU having different regulatory standards, and therefore checks on goods at the border.

claims.text: Mask-wearing causes people to contract bacterial pneumonia.

claimReview.title: Mask wearing doesn’t cause bacterial pneumonia - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this.

claims.text: There are more flu vaccines available than ever before.

claimReview.title: NHS: More beds, more doctors, and more flu vaccines? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In October, the Chief Medical Officer for England said that there were “more people eligible than ever before” for the flu vaccine this winter, and NHS England said it aimed to treat up to 21 million people. Public Health England doesn’t yet have complete figures on how many people received the vaccine this winter.

claims.text: 2016 saw the steepest fall in university applications for 30 years.

claimReview.title: Are university applications falling in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. In 2016 the number of applicants to UK universities fell slightly, but not by as much as they did in 2012, following the increase in tuition fees. The number of applications to UK universities (which doesn’t include applications made after the June application deadline) rose in 2016. The number of applicants for 2017 (reported after 15 January deadline) showed a fall of 5%. This is the second largest of three falls since 2002.

claims.text: Mass immigration has depressed wages, especially on the low skill level.

claimReview.title: What does immigration do to wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Studies find that immigration affects low-waged workers the most negatively. They disagree on whether it has been good or bad for wages overall but tend to show that the effect is small and also short-term.

claims.text: Spending on mental health went up by £575 million last year.

claimReview.title: NHS spending on mental health - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to the increase in spending by Clinical Commissioning Groups, but doesn’t account for inflation. Factoring that in the increase was around £368 million. It’s not a complete picture of mental health spending because other money is spent by the NHS on specialised mental health services. The figures on this aren’t regularly published.

claims.text: 98% of junior doctors voted in favour of strikes.

claimReview.title: Did 98% of junior doctors vote to strike? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 98% of junior doctors who are members of the British Medical Association (BMA) and who voted in the ballot said they would be prepared to strike. Not all junior doctors are members of the BMA, and not all members voted. Taken as a proportion of all junior doctors (including some not affected by the changes), roughly 46-52% voted to strike.

claims.text: Universal Credit will mean 200,000 more people will be in work when it’s fully rolled-out.

claimReview.title: 200,000 more people in work under Universal Credit? The government can’t know the answer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s according to the government’s own estimate, but it’s subject to significant doubt. It’s also currently unprovable: the National Audit Office says “the Department will never be able to measure whether Universal Credit actually leads to 200,000 more people in work”.

claims.text: Increasing numbers of vaccines are associated with increasing rates of autism.

claimReview.title: Autism prevalence is up but scientists have consistently found that vaccines don’t cause it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Dozens of scientific studies have shown there is no link between autism or autism spectrum disorders and vaccines.

claims.text: A person survived being struck twice in quick succession by lightning.

claimReview.title: It is unlikely this person got struck by lightning twice in quick succession - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The theoretical survival chances, lack of news coverage and elements of the video which seem edited make it very unlikely that this happened.

claims.text: Over the last ten years half a million fewer men than women have been accepted to university.

claimReview.title: Half a million fewer men accepted to university than women - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true for students living in the UK when they applied, for all students accepted to UK universities since 2007 the difference is a little over half a million.

claims.text: 103 NHS walk-in centres have closed or been downgraded since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know exactly, as this information isn’t collected centrally. Research from an NHS regulator and from campaign group 38 Degrees suggests more than 90 have been closed or downgraded.

claims.text: A Radox bath product contains the ingredient clary sage which can induce labour in pregnant women and should never be used during pregnancy, especially in the first and second trimester.

claimReview.title: Clary sage in Radox isn’t dangerous for pregnant women - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Office for Product Safety and Standards told us there’s no evidence that clary sage would be dangerous for pregnant women in the quantities found in bath products.

claims.text: Eight Oxford colleges are less than 1% black.

claimReview.title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for undergraduate students from the UK who took up their place between 2015 and 2017.

claims.text: A post on social media has claimed that if a deaf person asks you to remove your mask you are legally required to make an adjustment.

claimReview.title: You do not have to legally lower your mask for lip-readers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. You are allowed to lower or remove your mask to assist those who lip-read, but it is not a legal requirement.

claims.text: 128,000 children will not be in their own home at Christmas.

claimReview.title: How many children are homeless in England, Scotland and Wales? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This many children were estimated to be in temporary accommodation across Great Britain earlier this year.

claims.text: If I drank cordial and then take a test I would test positive because of the drink in my mouth.

claimReview.title: Pouring diluted cordial onto a Covid-19 test won’t give an accurate result - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Government guidance says you should wait 30 minutes after eating or drinking to take a test to reduce the risk of spoiling the test.

claims.text: Bald men are twice as likely to suffer from severe Covid-19.

claimReview.title: It’s not clear whether bald people get more ill with Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Being older raises the risk of severe Covid-19, but based on the research we have so far, it is not yet clear whether baldness itself has any effect.

claims.text: The Labour government lifted over a million pensioners and a million children out of poverty.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The exact level depends on the measure of poverty you use. Looking at absolute poverty the number of pensioner and children living in poverty both fell by well over a million. Meanwhile the number of pensioners living in relative poverty, after housing costs were accounted for, fell by over a million. The number of children in relative poverty fell by less than a million.

claims.text: Five different people’s Covid-19 swab tests are being sent off in one vial, so one positive test will contaminate the other four, giving five positives.

claimReview.title: Group swab Covid-19 tests do not return positives to people without the virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are currently some trials of pooling samples, meaning a few samples are tested together to save resources. If all come out negative, they don’t need to be re-tested, but if any are positive, individual samples are tested again.

claims.text: Up until 26 May 2021 there have been 888,196 adverse reactions to Covid-19 vaccines and 1,253 deaths where doctors have acknowledged that it is caused by the jab.

claimReview.title: Video in a car shares misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
These are the numbers of potential adverse reactions and deaths that happened around the time of vaccination, as reported by clinicians and members of the public to the MHRA Yellow Card scheme. 

This does not necessarily mean the vaccine caused that reaction or event.

claims.text: Four Oxford schoolgirls have started a petition to make lessons on climate change compulsory in schools.

claimReview.title: Setting the record straight on climate change in the school curriculum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The students’ petition recognises that climate change is already part of the science and geography curriculum in England. But they say that they have “barely learned about” it at school and want climate change to be a “core part” of the national curriculum.

claims.text: There is a Tory plan to raise the pension age to 75.

claimReview.title: Misleading claim about pension age continues to circulate online - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This policy was recommended in a report by the Centre for Social Justice think tank, which is chaired by Conservative MP Iain Duncan Smith. The Department for Work and Pensions told us it is not government policy to do this.

claims.text: London has no go areas.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is nowhere in London where the law doesn’t apply.

claims.text: The UKIP leader Paul Nuttall has said that he wants to privatise the NHS.

claimReview.title: UKIP and the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Nuttall has been critical of the NHS model of a publicly-owned healthcare provider in the past. He has since said that he thinks there could be more private sector involvement in the NHS. UKIP’s policy is still for an NHS that’s free at the point of use.

claims.text: Cuts to tax credits will cost low-paid working families £1,300 a year.

claimReview.title: Will changes to tax credits cost families £1,300 a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £1,300 is a "rough" estimate of the average reduction in income next year (2016/17).

claims.text: The vaccines haven’t been subject to medium or long term safety testing on humans.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccines have been tested on humans since mid-2020. If vaccines produce side effects, these are usually detectable in the short term.

claims.text: Deliveroo will have to recognise a union if over half the drivers in an area sign up to it.

claimReview.title: Deliveroo, unions and the ‘gig economy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s likely, but not completely guaranteed since the Central Arbitration Committee may decide that the drivers should hold a ballot on union representation anyway. The appointed panel would also have to decide that Deliveroo drivers are ‘workers’, not self-employed contractors.

claims.text: The return to universities could cause 50,000 deaths from Covid-19 without “strong controls”.

claimReview.title: Reopening universities will almost certainly not cause 50,000 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from a research paper that has not been peer-reviewed. It is based on several assumptions, including that every student gets infected, and nothing is done to stop it.

claims.text: Londoners are the “most likely” people in the country to search for teeth whitening treatments

claimReview.title: Claims about teeth whitening inquiries don’t add up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t appear to be true. All the results of this study show is that London had the highest volume of searches, but it does not tell us anything about likelihood to search for teeth whitening as the numbers aren’t adjusted for population.

claims.text: 5G millimeter waves could be absorbed by dermatologic cells acting like antennas, transferred to other cells and play the main role in producing Coronaviruses in biological cells.
claims.claimant: Journal of Biological Regulators and Homeostatic Agents

claimReview.title: A baseless paper that linked skin cells, 5G and coronavirus has been retracted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that this is the case, and lots of evidence that it isn’t. The journal that published the paper that claims this has now removed it from their website.

claims.text: Each Olympic medal for the UK cost £4.5 million in funding.

claimReview.title: The Olympic Games, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct for the London 2012 Olympics. At Rio each medal cost £5.1 million in funding.

claims.text: Tesco is giving away free TVs to people who share a Facebook post, or visit a link.

claimReview.title: A post offering free TVs from Tesco is a scam - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The post does not come from Tesco’s Facebook account. Tesco has told us that it does not offer rewards for liking, sharing or commenting on posts.

claims.text: Rail commuter fares are rising faster than wages.

claimReview.title: Fair fares? How much are season tickets increasing by? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Since Brexit, Britain has been able to strike new free trade deals with 70 countries worth over £760 billion.

claimReview.title: Express overstates Brexit trade deal value, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: £760 billion is the total value of bilateral trade with these countries, not the additional value of the trade deals. Many of these deals were rolled over from when the UK was a member of the EU.

claims.text: Mr Choudhury’s fine was paid out of his benefits.

claimReview.title: Two men did go to prison for throwing bacon at a mosque, while a man was fined for burning poppies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was reported at the time that Mr Choudhury received benefits and had a part-time job. We don’t know who paid the fine.

claims.text: From 21 July to 25 July the UK reported 426 Covid-19 deaths.

claimReview.title: You were more likely to catch Covid-19 in Spain than the UK in late July. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This figure is the number of deaths registered after a positive test, so will miss out some Covid-19 deaths.

claims.text: 57% oppose Theresa May's Brexit approach.

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 53%.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines are a mass clinical trial and won’t get to phase 3 trials until 2023.

claimReview.title: Video in a car shares misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The three Covid-19 vaccines currently in use in the UK have been through many stages of clinical trial and had phase 3 trial data published in peer reviewed journals. The phase 3 trials include long-term follow-up and have completion dates set for 2022 and 2023.

claims.text: Anti-inflammatories should be used to fight Covid-19.

claimReview.title: This post about Covid-19 and blood clotting conditions contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Anti-inflammatories such as ibuprofen may be useful in treating Covid-19 symptoms at home.

claims.text: Having the Covid-19 vaccine eats away at your immune system, and people vaccinated six or eight months ago are dying from the common cold.

claimReview.title: Funeral director’s viral claims about vaccinated people not based in fact - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence this is the case. The vaccines are effective at preventing severe disease from Covid-19.

claims.text: Beaches, parks and children’s playgrounds are closed.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Playgrounds are closed. Some parks have decided to close too, but no beaches have reported closing. People should follow social distancing measures.

claims.text: In the last eight years, Education Maintenance Allowance has been taken away.

claimReview.title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was removed in England at the end of the 2010/11 school year, and replaced by a new bursary scheme. Government research suggests the new scheme has lowered participation in further education among students previously eligible for EMA.

claims.text: The Royal Mail is part-owned by the German government.

claimReview.title: Who owns Britain’s trains, energy and postal service? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve not seen any information on who all of the Royal Mail’s shareholders are and have asked them for more information.

claims.text: Research from Israel suggests that the Pfizer vaccine is much less protective against Covid-19 than natural immunity from catching the disease.

claimReview.title: Immunity through Covid infection is much riskier than a vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research does say this. However, it also says that infected people are even better protected if they get vaccinated as well.

claims.text: 5G is harmful to humans.

claimReview.title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that 5G can harm people.

claims.text: Of the almost 1,800 deaths that occur on our roads annually, around 450 are pedestrians in incidents where motor vehicles are involved.

claimReview.title: How many cyclists are killed each year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Refers to figures for Britain in 2016.

claims.text: Diane Abbott said that Chairman Mao did more good than harm.

claimReview.title: Diane Abbott did say that Chairman Mao did more good than harm - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. During an episode of This Week in 2008 she said “I suppose that some people would judge that on balance Mao did more good than harm”.

claims.text: Under the current system, people on a work, study or family visa only pay a £400 surcharge to use the NHS.

claimReview.title: Claim that immigrants “only” pay £400 surcharge to use the NHS ignores their tax contributions - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the current level the international health surcharge is set at each year, but the taxes that people who come to work in the UK pay also goes towards things like the NHS.

claims.text: The manual for certain benefits is three times the size of War and Peace.

claimReview.title: War and Peace and benefits regulations - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is right on one measure. Guidance for officials on administering JSA and Income Support has three times as many pages as the novel’s first edition.

claims.text: The government have announced the end of hospital parking charges for patients.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s first interview of 2020: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In December it was announced that hospitals in England will have to provide free car parking to frequent hospital visitors, blue badge holders and at certain times to staff and parents of child patients.

claims.text: Children can’t get the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Children aren’t immune from the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Children can get Covid-19 but there have been relatively few cases in children and in general, their symptoms tend to be milder.

claims.text: The way to cure this is antibiotics, anti-inflammatories and anticoagulants.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Antibiotics do not directly treat Covid-19, which is caused by a virus. The anti-inflammatory ibuprofen is being trialled for use against Covid-19 and an anticoagulant has been used in some Covid-19 cases. Aspirin is not a specific cure.

claims.text: Ten thousand or more families have suffered “serious damage” as a result of getting a Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: MP makes unevidenced claims about vaccine damage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Again, there is no available data to substantiate this claim and no source was provided.

claims.text: Prime Minister Boris Johnson advocated for the UK to take Covid-19 “on the chin” and allow the disease to spread through the population.

claimReview.title: Here is the transcript of what Boris Johnson said on This Morning about the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Prime Minister said this was a theory on how to deal with the virus, but said it would be better if we take all the measures we can to reduce the burden on the NHS during the peak of the disease.

claims.text: You can make a substance that removes body hair by mixing one tablespoon of 2% iodine and one cup of baby oil.

claimReview.title: Mixing baby oil and iodine won’t remove body hair - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This won’t remove body hair.

claims.text: The UK has only granted asylum to 187 Syrian refugees through the Vulnerable Person Relocation scheme.

claimReview.title: How many Syrian refugees are there in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but not all Syrian refugees arrive in the UK through the scheme.

claims.text: There has been a 400% increase in hate crime within the LGBT+ community.

claimReview.title: Change in LGBT+ hate crime levels not as simple as Dawn Butler suggests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There are two sources of data on this type of hate crime. One estimates a 261% increase in hate crime on the basis of sexual orientation and transgender identity, and the other estimates a 40% decrease in hate crimes based on sexual orientation since around 2010. Neither measure is perfect.

claims.text: Migration is linked to 82% of population growth (between 2001 and 2016).

claimReview.title: Is 82% of population growth driven by migration? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: “Linked to” here combines an estimate of both net migration and children born to immigrant parents. This is likely to be on the right scale but too precise a figure, as it rests on a number of assumptions and uncertain data sources.

claims.text: 819 people were turned away across eight council areas during voter ID trials.

claimReview.title: Voter ID scheme: far more turned away than convicted of electoral fraud - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Across all ten trial areas in 2019, 1,968 people were turned away for not having the correct ID. Of those people, 740 did not return to vote.

claims.text: Fluoride is so toxic it is considered hazardous waste.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Fluoride is toxic at high concentrations, but these are much higher than the levels found in toothpaste and tap water.

claims.text: Six million workers are paid below the living wage.

claimReview.title: Six million jobs pay below the living wage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Last year six million jobs were paid below the living wage, but some people have more than one job. We've got hold of some new figures suggesting at least 5.4 million people were paid less than the living wage.

claims.text: There are 400,000 fewer children in poverty than there were in 2010.

claimReview.title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Main measures can be used to show anything from a fall of 100,000 to a rise of 500,000.

claims.text: A study found that 82% of people first encountered the term “cancel culture” in the past 12 months.

claimReview.title: Only a third of people first heard of the term ‘cancel culture’ in the past year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research actually shows that around a third of people first encountered the term in the past year. Almost half of the people surveyed said they had never heard it.

claims.text: Even when including those with pre-existing conditions, for the under 60s there is a 1 in 300,000 chance of death, for the over 60s there is a 99% survival rate and for the over 80s it’s still 90%.

claimReview.title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The death rate given for under 60s is definitely far too low. The survival rate for over-60s appears to be too high, while the survival rate for the over 80s is more plausible. It is impossible to calculate a true death rate because we do not know how many people have been infected.

claims.text: Transport for the North’s budget has been reduced by 40%.

claimReview.title: Is Transport for the North’s budget being reduced by 40%? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This much is being removed from Transport for the North’s core funding, though not from its total funding. It will be able to access some extra funding from other programmes to supplement its core funding.

claims.text: No vaccine has been tested to see if it causes cancer.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that any current vaccines cause cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the UK, all vaccines have to undergo a number of trials, usually over a period of years, to check if they cause any side effects.

claims.text: A picture shows an animal that threw itself into the water to escape the Amazon fires being rescued by a Brazilian soldier.

claimReview.title: This picture of a man swimming with a jaguar isn’t from the 2019 Amazon fires - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture was taken in 2016 and is of a jaguar which is one of the Brazilian army’s mascots. The image most likely shows the jaguar playing in the water with a soldier.

claims.text: Childhood diabetes in England and Wales is up 40% in four years.

claimReview.title: Is childhood type 2 diabetes up 40%? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is in the right ball park. Data from both the NHS and the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health show this scale of increase across similar time periods.

claims.text: Kary B Mullis invented the PCR test that’s being used as the Covid-19 test. He died suddenly in August 2019.

claimReview.title: The inventor of PCR never said it wasn’t designed to detect infectious diseases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He did invent PCR, which is a process used to test whether someone currently has Covid-19. He did die in August 2019.

claims.text: A YouGov poll predicts the Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn will lose his seat to the Liberal Democrats in the next election.

claimReview.title: YouGov did not predict that Jeremy Corbyn will lose his seat to the Lib Dems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. YouGov’s poll was a national survey based on a hypothetical scenario, not a conventional survey of voting intention. The results should not be used as a ‘forecast’, nor can they be reliably applied to any individual constituency.

claims.text: The USA is the largest investor in the UK economy.

claimReview.title: UK-US trading and investment: a special relationship - Full Fact
