claimReview.textualRating: Correct. US-based companies invested around £350 billion in the UK in 2017. That made it the top investor in the country.

claims.text: The IMF said the pound was overvalued before the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Was the pound overvalued before the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. Before the EU referendum, the IMF said that the pound was overvalued in 2015.

claims.text: 1.3 million children will benefit from the government’s u-turn on funding free school meals over the summer holidays.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson incorrect to say Keir Starmer is “completely wrong” about past trends in child poverty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, this is roughly how many children receive free school meals in England.

claims.text: Disadvantaged pupil attainment has risen, including among poor pupils from black, Asian and minority ethnic communities.
claims.claimant: Nicky Morgan MP, Secretary of State for Education

claimReview.title: Is the performance of disadvantaged pupils improving? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly yes, but there's not such a clear trend for the attainment gap.

claims.text: The vaccine manufacturers do not have liability.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 survival rate is less than 99.8% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid-19 vaccine manufacturers are immune to some, but not all, civil liability.

claims.text: A photo of a bicycle-like vehicle, with an attached bed for carrying patients, depicts the first ambulance service.

claimReview.title: Old photo of bed attached to bicycle is not the world’s first ambulance service - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo is from 1941 whereas (in the UK at least) ambulance services began forming during the 19th century.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, Northern Ireland is effectively annexed by the EU with border in the Irish sea between NI and the UK.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There will be checks on goods crossing from the rest of the UK into Northern Ireland, but Northern Ireland will remain part of the UK’s customs territory. What you deem to be annexing is really a matter of interpretation.

claims.text: The UK has close to the lowest cost healthcare in the world.

claimReview.title: The NHS: low cost healthcare? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Assuming this refers to spending on healthcare as a percentage of GDP, the UK spends more than the average of the 35 OECD countries, but less than most of the G7 countries. These kinds of comparisons will differ depending on what you classify as ‘healthcare’.

claims.text: The most vulnerable people claiming Employment and Support Allowance will continue to get extra money despite benefit cuts.

claimReview.title: ESA: "extra money" for some - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Those in the ESA support group will be getting more than other claimants, but the real value of the benefit will fall over time.

claims.text: An extension to the date of Brexit would cost £1 billion a month.

claimReview.title: It’s not true to say a Brexit extension would cost £1 billion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wrong. An extension of a few months would cost no more than leaving with a deal in October 2019, which is still the government’s publicly stated policy.

claims.text: The last labour government took 800,000 children out of poverty.

claimReview.title: Poverty: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, if you look at the number of children living in relative poverty and don’t include housing costs. There’s more than one measure of poverty.

claims.text: The amount of times drugs were found in prisons across England and Wales rose by 23% in one year. 20.4% of drug tests came back as positive.

claimReview.title: Violence and drugs in prison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, including tests for psychoactive substances like spice.

claims.text: We are selling more to our global partners - £13.6 billion - than to the EU.

claimReview.title: April’s trade figures fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that in April 2021 the UK exported more goods to non-EU countries (£13.6 billion) than to EU countries (£12.9 billion).

claims.text: Boris Johnson is taking £70 a week away from pensioners.

claimReview.title: Some pensioners will lose £70 a week, but Boris Johnson didn’t introduce the change - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some pensioners will lose £70 a week under reforms introduced in the 2007 Pensions Act. In May 2019 the number receiving this benefit was around 11,000.

claims.text: The average salary for nurses increased from £22,000 in 2010 to £25,000 in 2020.

claimReview.title: MPs salaries have grown faster than starting salaries of nurses, teachers and police officers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2010, a starting (not average) salary for a newly qualified nurse was £21,200; it is now £24,200. Factoring in inflation, this amounts to a 5% decrease.

claims.text: Water bills are up 40% since privatisation.

claimReview.title: Water rip-off? Are water bills up 40% since privatisation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in real terms in England and Wales between 1989 and 2014/15. Most of that rise happened between 1989 and 1995. Bills have fallen slightly in real terms since 2009/10.

claims.text: The Guardian said “Lib Dems winning and on the up after by-election victory” in August 2019.

claimReview.title: Lib Dem leaflet falsely attributes pro-Lib Dem quote to the Guardian - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is misleading. The quote is an edited version of the Guardian headline, which made clear that the words originally came from Jo Swinson, not the Guardian itself.

claims.text: The vaccine has been pushed through in record time.

claimReview.title: Luminescent enzymes not in Covid-19 vaccine and other myths debunked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, thanks to recent medical advances, new technologies and ample funding. The Covid-19 vaccines have been tested to the same high standards as all vaccines are.

claims.text: An image shows Nigel Farage wearing a gollywog badge.

claimReview.title: This image does not show Nigel Farage wearing a gollywog badge - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been edited to include the badge.

claims.text: Two UK police forces used the same photo to illustrate two different crimes.

claimReview.title: Two police forces did not use the same photo to illustrate two different lockdown crimes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The tweet from Cumbria Road Police is real, the image of a tweet from Police Scotland is fake.

claims.text: We spend £22 billion on social care.

claimReview.title: Health and social care: What do we spend? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct looking at public spending on adult social care across the UK in 2016/17. Around £10 billion was spent on children’s social care.

claims.text: The old EU-Japan trade deal was estimated to deliver a £2.6 billion boost to the UK economy.

claimReview.title: Is the UK's trade deal with Japan better than the EU's? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the estimate of annual GDP growth after 15 years, but it can’t be compared to the estimate for the UK-Japan deal because they used very different calculation methods.

claims.text: There were 700 deaths from cancer in Ireland in August.

claimReview.title: People did die of Covid-19 in Ireland in August - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know these figures yet as it is too soon after the fact. The figure for cancer seems realistic from past trends, as there were around 830 deaths caused by cancer in Ireland per month in Q1 of 2020.

claims.text: Only 5% of Northern Ireland’s GDP goes to Ireland.

claimReview.title: Irish border: how much trade? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct in terms of goods exports. But goods exports are not normally measured as a percentage of GDP. 33% of Northern Ireland’s goods exports went to the Republic in 2016.

claims.text: Labour have committed to hire 10,000 police officers at a cost of £3 billion.

claimReview.title: Don’t compare Labour and Conservative costings for police recruitment - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Labour costed this at £770 million over five years in 2017, though this only covers police salaries and so the actual cost of recruitment would be higher.

claims.text: Russia was the first country in the world to dissect Covid-19 corpses (going against WHO’s criminal orders of no autopsies.)

claimReview.title: Claims about Russia, Covid-19 and 5G are almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. Scientists in Wuhan, China performed post-mortems as early as 16 February 2020, while the first Covid-19 death in Russia wasn’t announced until March 2020.

claims.text: A girl called Ellie Morrad is missing.

claimReview.title: Fake missing child reports used to scam Facebook users - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: She is not. This is the latest in a long line of fake missing child reports posted on Facebook to scam people.

claims.text: Educational attainment in Scotland is at record levels.

claimReview.title: Is educational attainment in Scotland at record levels? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends on which measure you look at. 15 year olds’ performance in international exams is falling, but at the same time more pupils are leaving school with Higher qualifications..

claims.text: Vote Leave is accused of breaking electoral law.

claimReview.title: BBC Question Time get themselves in a mess over who broke electoral law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct it was fined £61,000 by the Electoral Commission for a number of offences.

claims.text: Three quarters of maternity units don’t have consultants present overnight during the week.

claimReview.title: Do we have enough maternity consultants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to a survey by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.

claims.text: Facebook has said sharing the Lord’s Prayer goes against their policies.

claimReview.title: The Lord’s Prayer is not banned from Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The post is based on an unsourced article from 2016.

claims.text: There are half a million more children in poverty since 2010.

claimReview.title: No single figure about child poverty tells the whole story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is what’s estimated to have happened to children in relative low income households, comparing 2010/11 to 2017/18. But this is one measure of several and the alternatives show smaller increases or even slight falls.

claims.text: Asylum seeker benefits cost the UK taxpayer £60 million per year.

claimReview.title: This viral post on benefits and tax avoidance is inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In 2019/20 the Home Office spent £470 million on providing accommodation and cash support to people seeking asylum.

claims.text: Extending the grace period for the proposed early closure of the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind to include projects with planning applications in place, could mean funding being given to a further 7.1 gigawatts of projects.

claimReview.title: The proposed Renewables Obligation cut off: how much onshore wind capacity loses out? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only 0.2 of the 7.1 gigawatts would be expected to qualify for the funding in the government's best estimate.

claims.text: Jose Mourinho was sacked as manager of Tottenham Hotspur after refusing to take training due to the European Super League announcement.

claimReview.title: Fake football quotes go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence he was sacked for this reason. This was claimed by a Twitter user who’s made false claims in the past.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines are killing many people according to data on the VAERS system.

claimReview.title: Some people have died after Covid-19 vaccination—not because of it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Reports on VAERS are not evidence that the vaccine caused these deaths. Data collected so far suggests that Covid vaccines are safe.

claims.text: It’s significantly more expensive to send a child to prison than it is to send them to Eton.

claimReview.title: Prison or Eton: which costs more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2016/17 the average annual price per place for children in custody ranged from £76,000 to £210,000. The full annual fee to send a child to Eton in 2018/19 is just over £40,000.

claims.text: The enacting of Section 1 of the European Union Withdrawal Act underlines that we are leaving the EU on October 31.

claimReview.title: The government has not just “set in stone” the repeal of the European Communities Act - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Exit day is currently set for 31 October but it could still be amended, under other sections of the Act, as has happened twice already. Enacting section 1 of the Act does not change this.

claims.text: It’s wrong to suggest Spain is in worse shape than the UK as the UK has a much higher Covid-19 death toll.

claimReview.title: You were more likely to catch Covid-19 in Spain than the UK in late July. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Looking at the number of cases is more relevant and Spain had many more new cases than the UK at the end of July.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines are in trials and are all experiments ending in 2023.

claimReview.title: WHO advice about asymptomatic transmission has changed since the start of the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Covid-19 vaccine trials have been published in peer-reviewed journals, but data collection is ongoing to allow several years of follow-up on patients.

claims.text: Just 15% of people who begin low-paid work in the UK will rise out of low pay during their working lives. This is the worst rate in the developed world.

claimReview.title: Sir Iain Duncan Smith is wrong to say that only 15% of people ever move above low pay - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is based on EU data from 2004-2011 showing the proportion of workers moving upwards from any skill level over four years, not in their lifetimes. The same data shows 35-40% of people rising out of low pay in the UK over a four-year period. The UK’s rate is low compared with other EU countries, but not the lowest.

claims.text: Poland, France and Germany have cheap travel and utilities subsidised by Europe.

claimReview.title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some of the EU budget is invested in transport and energy programmes. But it does not simply subsidise existing services for EU citizens. The UK is also a recipient of this funding.

claims.text: You are twice as likely to get into the University of Oxford as a white applicant (24%) than a black applicant (12%).

claimReview.title: Black and ethnic minority students at the University of Oxford - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for UK undergraduate applicants between 2015 and 2017.

claims.text: Greece has said it will collapse when we leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It has not.

claims.text: A new trial would allow over 31,000 women to perform their own smear tests.

claimReview.title: HPV testing kits are not smear tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is near impossible to perform your own smear test. This is referring to a self swab to test for Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). The two tests are not the same thing.

claims.text: There were more than 4,000 foreign criminals from other EU countries locked up in British jails last year.

claimReview.title: 4,000 EU prisoners in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is how many prisoners in England and Wales at the end of 2017 were citizens of other EU countries.

claims.text: PPE being exported from the UK to other countries could have been used here.

claimReview.title: Some PPE exported to the EU could have been used in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not necessarily as British standards might vary from other countries. However, some PPE that has been exported to the EU could have been used here as they met EU regulations, which are the same standards used in the UK.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, there is a transition period until 2021, extendable for years longer.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Under the current terms of the agreement, the transition period would end just before 2021 began. It could theoretically be extended by up to two years, provided that’s been settled by half way through 2020.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines don’t prevent infection or transmission of the disease.

claimReview.title: Facebook post makes misleading claims about Covid-19 passports and death rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Evidence shows vaccines have a significant effect on the infection rate of Covid and reduce transmission.

claims.text: Children are silent super-spreaders of coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t show that children are ‘silent super-spreaders’ of coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not proved by this study. It finds children have a high viral load, but offers no evidence on transmission.

claims.text: 40% of all day-to-day spending by the State now goes to the health sector

claimReview.title: Health doesn’t account for 40% of day-to-day public spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it doesn’t. This year, day-to-day spending on health is forecast to account for about 23% of all day-to-day public spending by the UK government.

claims.text: Scotland’s drug-related death rate is the highest in the EU.

claimReview.title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct if you compare Scotland to a league table of EU sovereign countries. This is based on a comparison of the drug-related death rate per million people aged 15 to 64 in 2015 and 2016.

claims.text: The government is providing not just the £8 billion of extra funding that the NHS requested, but £10 billion of extra funding.

claimReview.title: £10 billion or £4.5 billion: what's going on with NHS spending? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s £10 billion commitment isn’t all of what NHS leaders asked for, and isn’t as generous as it sounds.

claims.text: The chances of catching Covid-19 are 44 million to one.

claimReview.title: This viral post understates the risk of Covid-19 infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is a misreading of the claim that, at the end of August, 44 people per million were catching Covid-19 each day in England. 

This has slightly increased since then.

claims.text: The Covid-19 test is the vaccine and if you get tested you have been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: A Covid-19 vaccine is not being administered via Covid-19 nasal swab tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not the case. Vaccines have to go through many rounds of testing before they can be rolled out, and none have got to this stage yet in the UK. You must consent to have a vaccine in the UK.

claims.text: A photo shows an aerial drone display in Mexico City depicting a skull wearing a sombrero as part of celebrations for Día de los Muertos or Day of the Dead.

claimReview.title: Day of the Dead drone display of skull wearing sombrero didn’t happen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This didn’t happen. There’s no other evidence the event took place. The drone display is almost certainly a digital effect. The city in the photo isn’t Mexico City either—it was taken near Mount Fuji, Japan.

claims.text: NASA faked an image of Mars.

claimReview.title: NASA did not fake a picture of Mars - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a fake image, but NASA did not make it.

claims.text: The IFS found that real terms per pupil funding in 2020 will be over 50 per cent higher than it was in 2000.

claimReview.title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The IFS says: “The average level of spending per pupil by primary and secondary schools rose by around 5% per year in real terms during the 2000s and was then largely protected in real terms under the coalition government. Spending per pupil fell 4% in real terms between 2015–16 and 2017–18, but will be held constant in real terms up to 2019–20.”

claims.text: Theresa May once said “curbing the promotion of lesbianism in Merton's schools starts with girls having male role models in their lives.”

claimReview.title: There is no evidence to suggest Theresa May said this about lesbianism - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence she ever said this.

claims.text: Children and adults have the same chance of getting ill from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Testing positive for Covid-19 doesn’t necessarily mean you’ll get ill - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The ONS found, with a degree of uncertainty, that there was no evidence that the rate of infection differed by age group, but being infected doesn’t necessarily mean you become ill and display symptoms.

claims.text: The Conservatives have delivered a million homes in the last five years in England.

claimReview.title: The housing supply has increased by a million in the past five years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A million homes have been added to the housing supply over the past five years.

claims.text: 168 countries are members of the WTO.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. There are 164 full members of the WTO.

claims.text: The Brexit Secretary said this week he has done no analytical work to assess the economic impact of failing to reach a deal with the EU over trade arrangements after Brexit.

claimReview.title: Has the government assessed the economic impact of no Brexit deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Brexit Secretary said this week the government has not done any further forecasts of the economic impact of a ‘no deal’ situation since the EU referendum. He said the government needs to fully plan for failed negotiations (which he said it is in the process of doing) before it can make such a forecast.

claims.text: Most secondary schools use teachers not trained in their subject

claimReview.title: Do most secondary schools use non-specialist teachers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Two-thirds of people responding to a survey by a school and college leaders’ union said recruitment problems have led them to have subjects taught by non-specialists. We don’t know how representative that figure is of the experience of schools nationally. Official figures show that about one in six lessons in the key academic subjects in English secondary schools were being taught by teachers without a relevant post A level qualification in 2014. Around 24% of maths teachers and 21% of English teachers didn’t have a relevant post A level qualification in that year.

claims.text: Mersey Care NHS Foundation Trust have had five deaths related to Covid-19 and all patients that passed away had pre-existing conditions.

claimReview.title: Mersey Care has only had five Covid-19 deaths because it is not an acute trust - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, but Mersey Care NHS Foundation Trust provides mental health, addiction, learning disability and community health services, so is not expected to treat those seriously ill with Covid-19.

claims.text: An image shows Israelis dressing up as the burning Twin Towers for the Jewish holiday Purim.

claimReview.title: This picture of women ‘dressing up like 9/11’ was taken in the UK, not Israel - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The picture is of two students who wore the costumes for Halloween at a nightclub in Chester, England.

claims.text: More than 11,500 children have been admitted to English hospitals with malnutrition since 2015.

claimReview.title: Layla Moran’s child malnutrition figures are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The true figure is at least 2,112 lower, and will be much lower still if the same mistake was made with every hospital.

claims.text: British 75 year-olds knew the Luftwaffe

claimReview.title: These claims about people of certain ages remembering parts of World War Two are generally incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Unlikely. The last air raids on Britain were in 1944, the same year most 75 year-olds were born.

claims.text: Coronavirus isn’t dangerous as it can be killed by Dettol products.

claimReview.title: Dettol hasn’t tested its products against the new Wuhan coronavirus yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: How dangerous the novel coronavirus is doesn’t relate to whether disinfectants work against it. Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold. Dettol has said its products haven’t been tested against the new virus yet.

claims.text: Brazil produces 25% of the planet’s food.

claimReview.title: Brazil doesn’t produce 25% of the world’s food, as the UK’s trade envoy to the country claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears far too high. The most recent available data from the UN shows Brazil produces 10% of the world’s food by weight and 4% by value.

claims.text: The number of Britons drinking to harmful levels has fallen sharply.

claimReview.title: Booze telling the truth? Is Britain sobering up or not? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 21% of adults aged 16+ in England reported to an NHS Digital survey that they usually drank more than the recommended 14 units of alcohol a week in 2017. This level has been falling since at least 2012.

claims.text: Wages are rising at the fastest rate in a decade.

claimReview.title: Government uses bad measure of wage growth, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This ignores inflation which means it’s a bad measure to use. Average wages for employees in Great Britain grew around 2% over the last year in real terms, which isn’t the fastest in a decade.

claims.text: The NHS was rated the most efficient health service in the world by the Commonwealth Fund.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Wages are rising at the fastest pace in three years.

claimReview.title: Real wage growth is just above 0% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to regular pay, and doesn’t factor in inflation or peoples’ total pay. Total pay in Great Britain is growing in real-terms by 0.2% in the three months to July 2018, the joint fastest pace in 18 months.

claims.text: Over 200,000 nurses have resigned since 2010.

claimReview.title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This figure covers all nurses and health visitors who have left the NHS in England from 2010 to 2018, including those with an unknown reason for leaving as well as those who have retired or died in service. Overall the number of nurses working in the NHS is higher than in 2010.

claims.text: The overwhelming majority of people in hospital with Covid have not been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Anna Soubry was wrong to say that the ‘overwhelming majority’ of Covid-19 patients are unvaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not supported by the latest evidence, which shows that 46% of admissions in England in the four weeks up to 19 December were unvaccinated people.

claims.text: The Pfizer vaccine contains syncytin-1 which is vital for the formation of human placenta, so could lead to infertility.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence the Pfizer vaccine interferes with the placenta - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccine contains instructions on how to build a spike protein, a very small part of which resembles syncytin-1. Realistically, there is very little chance the vaccine would cause the body to attack syncytin or cause infertility.

claims.text: The Royal British Legion will not be selling poppies in certain areas to avoid upsetting “minorities”.

claimReview.title: Claims the Royal British Legion won’t sell poppies to avoid upsetting ‘minorities’ are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: New data from Israel shows the vaccinated account for nearly all serious cases and deaths.

claimReview.title: Israel’s travel policy doesn’t view vaccinated passengers as higher risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t been able to find the data from Israel. In the UK, many serious cases and deaths are among vaccinated people. However, this is because the vast majority of the population is vaccinated and vaccines aren’t 100% effective. Vaccinated people have a much lower risk of hospitalisation and death than unvaccinated people.

claims.text: Boris Johnson’s Brexit proposals would lead to the kind of hit to the economy experienced in the financial crash.

claimReview.title: This comparison between Brexit’s impact and the financial crisis is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an unfair comparison as it equates real drops in GDP and wages during the financial crisis to the loss of potential earnings over longer time periods as a result of Brexit.

claims.text: Muslims can’t use alcohol-based hand sanitiser as it is against their religion.

claimReview.title: Claims that Muslims caused Leicester’s Covid-19 outbreak are baseless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Many Muslims consider it permissible to use alcohol-based hand sanitisers. There has been no suggestion that sanitiser use contributed to the Leicester outbreak.

claims.text: More people are being prosecuted for carrying a blade.

claimReview.title: Are more people being prosecuted for carrying knives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. There was a 12% increase in the number of prosecutions for possession of an article with blade or point in England and Wales between 2016 and 2017, to just under 9,000. It’s been rising since at least 2013.

claims.text: There are eight million foreigners living in the UK.

claimReview.title: Those "eight million foreigners" living in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are an estimated eight million people who were born abroad living in the UK, although according to the census that was already the case in 2011.

claims.text: Three in 10 people who should be self-isolating aren’t doing so.

claimReview.title: Are 3 in 10 people failing to isolate? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t enough evidence for this claim, which simply takes the midpoint of the results of two different surveys about self-isolation.

claims.text: The number of EU nurses coming to the UK has fallen by 90% since the Brexit vote.

claimReview.title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of nurses and midwives from the EEA joining the Nursing and Midwifery Council’s register fell by 91% from 2015/16 to 2017/18.

claims.text: Picture of a gazelle looking calm while being killed shows a mother sacrificing herself to allow her children to get away. Taking the photo led the photographer to fall into a depression.

claimReview.title: Viral impala picture is not a maternal sacrifice - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an image of an impala. The photographer says this is “a completely ridiculous fake story” and the image actually shows cheetah young practicing their hunting.

claims.text: More under-18s are being prosecuted for selling cannabis while the number of those aged 18 or over prosecuted has fallen.

claimReview.title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, in England and Wales. The number of 10-17 year-olds prosecuted between 2012/13 and 2016/17 increased, while the number of adults fell. Despite this many more adults are still being prosecuted overall.

claims.text: A photo shows a 12kg rat in London.

claimReview.title: There was not a 12kg rat in London - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The photo makes the rat look deceptively big. It almost certainly weighed less than 3kg.

claims.text: The Treasury has said that leaving the EU could lead to a drop in tax revenue of £66 billion.

claimReview.title: "Leaked" analysis: would a Hard Brexit cost £66 billion? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures aren’t new. £66 billion is the top end of an estimate the Treasury published in April.

claims.text: BBC Question Time hired the son of a BBC producer to pose as a Brexit and Boris Johnson supporter.

claimReview.title: BBC Question Time did not hire the son of a producer to say pro-Brexit statements - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The man on the show was not Mr Burley’s son, and Burley does not work on Question Time. The claim originated from a spoof account.

claims.text: Further measures that cut UK corporation tax to 12.5%, matching Ireland, would cost the UK government £120 billion over the next five years.

claimReview.title: The cost of cutting corporation tax - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour has offered us estimates which suggest the direct effect would be about half that. These estimates aren’t complete as they don’t account for how companies will react to the change.

claims.text: New laws on workplace rights have come into effect.

claimReview.title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The government has made a statement to parliament saying they intend to introduce new laws to change workers’ rights. But these new rights haven’t been passed as law and so aren’t in effect.

claims.text: It is now illegal to park on pavements in Wales.

claimReview.title: You can still park on the pavement in Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Welsh government is planning to give councils more power to fine problem parkers from July next year, but doesn’t plan to pursue an outright ban.

claims.text: We’ve got the slowest growth in Europe.

claimReview.title: The pound has fallen in value since the Brexit vote - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK had the third-slowest year-on-year GDP growth in the EU, based on the latest figures for July-September 2017.

claims.text: MPs get free alcohol.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs cannot claim expenses for alcohol but can drink in parliamentary bars and restaurants which are effectively subsidised with public money.

claims.text: The number of people from disadvantaged backgrounds going to university has gone down.

claimReview.title: Young people's participation in higher education - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are a number of ways to measure what a ‘disadvantaged pupil’ is, but on all UCAS measures young students from disadvantaged groups in England are more likely to go to university now than any other year on record. The picture may be different for other types of students, such as mature students or part-time students.

claims.text: The National Audit Office said that schools face real term cuts of 8% by 2019/20.

claimReview.title: Schools will have less to spend per pupil by 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The National Audit Office said that although overall spending on schools will increase between 2014/15 and 2019/20, increasing pupil numbers and staff costs mean they will need to spend 8% less per pupil.

claims.text: If we Vote Leave... We will control our borders.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A vote to leave doesn’t necessarily mean we will control immigration. It depends on what the government chooses to do with immigration policy, and what arrangements it negotiates.

claims.text: The vaccine is experimental.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccines have passed the same safety tests and procedures any other vaccine would.

claims.text: Interest payments on the national debt cost the government £46 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Interest payments on the national debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s about right for 2015/16, although the government effectively paid some of that to itself because it went to the state-owned Bank of England. Ignoring these payments, the government spent around £33 billion on debt interest that year.

claims.text: Knife murders fell 14% due to increased stop and search operations in London.

claimReview.title: Knife crime at eight-year high - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Homicides involving a knife are down, and stop and searches in London for offensive weapons are up but there’s no evidence to support the idea that one is causing the other.

claims.text: The overwhelming majority of other EU countries have no steel industry to protect.

claimReview.title: Does most of the EU have no steel industry? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Seven EU countries produce more steel than the UK, including large economies like Germany, Italy, and France. The UK is responsible for 4% of the EU’s crude steel production.

claims.text: Knife crime has soared to a record high.

claimReview.title: Knife crime at eight-year high - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for England and Wales, though comparable data only goes back to 2011 and there are some data issues.

claims.text: A picture shows trees that have been cut down before 5G is launched.

claimReview.title: These trees weren’t cut down because of 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture is of felled trees in Serbia, as part of redevelopment works, which are due to be replaced by new trees. There’s no evidence this had anything to do with 5G.

claims.text: Ireland’s test and trace system costs £773,000.

claimReview.title: This comparison of the cost of the Irish and UK contact tracing systems is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is just the initial development cost of the contact tracing app, not the entire test and trace system.

claims.text: 33,000 people are employed by the European Commission, and 7,500 by the Parliament.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct, although that’s not all staff employed by the EU. The total administrative staff is around 60,000.

claims.text: Face masks are useless.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 can be fatal and tests for it aren’t rigged - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The guidance has changed throughout the pandemic, however current thinking is that face masks can play a useful role in preventing the spread of Covid-19.

claims.text: Stonehenge is a modern fake.

claimReview.title: Stonehenge wasn’t built in the 1950s - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No it isn’t. It’s between 4,500 and 5,000 years old.

claims.text: There are fewer doctors and nurses employed in mental health.

claimReview.title: Mental health staff in the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are around 5,000 fewer nurses specialising mental health between August 2010 and 2017. The number of fully trained doctors specialising in psychiatry and psychotherapy has also gone down by 105 over the same time, but if you count junior doctors the number has increased.

claims.text: The OECD has ranked the UK as the third highest for education funding.

claimReview.title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This includes private spending, so isn’t an accurate reflection of government funding.  In terms of public spending on education, as a percentage of GDP, the UK ranked joint-fourteenth out of 34 OECD countries that provided data in 2015. Education spending in the UK is devolved.

claims.text: They [migrants] also affect public services.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Impacts of immigration are likely to vary by local area. Immigrants may add to demand for and pressure on public services, but also contribute to financing and providing them.

claims.text: The flu jab contains thimerosal, which may have neurological effects, cause developmental deficits and has been known to cause seizures.

claimReview.title: Image on flu jab ingredients is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No current UK flu jabs contain thimerosal (known as thiomersal in the UK). It was removed from most UK jabs as a precaution, and doesn’t seem to build up in the human body and cause issues.

claims.text: 379,998 people are in prison.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The prison population of the UK was 92,500 in 2018.

claims.text: 100,000 children have not returned to school since the start of the pandemic.

claimReview.title: Figure of 100,000 children missing from school is out of date - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not a current figure, so we can’t use it to describe how many pupils have remained absent from school since the start of the pandemic. The Centre for Social Justice found 93,514 pupils missed more than 50% of school sessions between September to December 2020.

claims.text: Glyphosate causes cancer.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about glyphosate, vaccines and cancer are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Evidence on whether glyphosate causes cancer seems contradictory. Cancer Research UK told us that there is some evidence that people exposed to very high levels of it could have a slightly increased risk of certain types of cancer.

claims.text: Jeremy Corbyn wore a poppy pin that said: “lets forget”.

claimReview.title: Jeremy Corbyn did not wear a poppy pin that said “lets forget” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. An image of Mr Corbyn at PMQs has been edited to include said poppy.

claims.text: The UK parliament has 1458 members.

claimReview.title: These figures for the size of House Of Commons, House of Lords, and the EU parliament are all correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The combined total of the House of Commons and House of Lords is 1458 if you include recently announced Life Peers.

claims.text: One in five people lives in absolute poverty. Over 14 million people are living in absolute poverty.

claimReview.title: About one in five people live in absolute or relative poverty if their housing costs are included - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Around 13 million people are living in absolute poverty in the UK, after housing costs are taken into account—that’s one in five. 14 million people are living in relative poverty, after housing costs.

claims.text: You cannot catch Covid-19 from touching surfaces.

claimReview.title: Mask graphic contains a number of inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Respiratory droplets can land on surfaces and the virus in these droplets have been shown to remain viable for up to 72 hours on some surfaces.

claims.text: A video captured the BBC interrupting its programming to alert the UK to a nuclear attack.

claimReview.title: This video does not show a real nuclear attack alert - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The original video shown on the screen is not real. It was made “just for fun”.

claims.text: There are over 2,000 more people employed in talking therapies.

claimReview.title: Mental health: staff working in talking therapies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One estimate says at least 2,850 more people worked in IAPT services (a flagship talking therapy programme for those with anxiety and depression) from August 2012 to April 2015. This does not include other NHS talking therapies.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU means £50 billion more for the government to spend by 2024/25.

claimReview.title: £50 billion “remain bonus” figure is a reasonable estimate but highly uncertain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a fair assessment of the best available forecasts, comparing Remain to a Brexit deal scenario. But those forecasts themselves contain a high degree of uncertainty, so we shouldn’t treat £50 billion as definitive.

claims.text: The recovery rate from Covid-19 is 99.9% to 99.994%.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 recovery rate is not 99.9% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The recovery rate is far lower.

claims.text: Leaving a customs union isn't the same thing as setting up a border.

claimReview.title: Will leaving the EU customs union mean border checks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Leaving the EU customs union will involve some sort of border checks on goods entering Britain.

claims.text: Charles Bronson has attacked Thomas Hughes and taken him hostage in his prison cell.

claimReview.title: Charles Bronson has not taken the father of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes hostage in prison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. The two men are in different prisons.

claims.text: Health minister Nadine Dorries said nurses would understand and accept a 1% pay rise because they have husbands and partners bringing in salaries.

claimReview.title: Here’s exactly what Nadine Dorries said on Woman’s Hour about nurses’ salaries - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not exactly what she said, although she did refer to the husbands and partners of nurses in a discussion about the pay rise.

claims.text: 1,620 schools, most rated outstanding, haven’t been inspected for six years or more. 290 haven’t been inspected for more than a decade.

claimReview.title: Ofsted hasn’t inspected 300 schools for a decade or more - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 1,620 state schools in England, most of which were rated outstanding in their last inspection, have not been inspected for six years or more. Of these, 296 have not been inspected for between ten and eleven years.

claims.text: The governor of the Bank of England has said that 15 million jobs in the UK could be stolen by robots.

claimReview.title: Robots and the future of your job - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's one way of putting it. Mark Carney quoted an estimate that 15 million jobs in the UK could be automated over the next few decades. In the past, new technology has created new types of work and hasn't caused mass unemployment in the long run.

claims.text: An independent Scotland wouldn’t be forced to join the euro once it applied to rejoin the EU.

claimReview.title: It’s unclear whether an independent Scotland could be forced to join the euro as an EU member - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New member states are officially required to adopt the euro at some point unless they have negotiated specific opt-outs, but in practice it's unclear whether members would or could be forced to.

claims.text: If we leave the EU, we could introduce a points-based immigration system like Australia’s.

claimReview.title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. We're likely to need to leave the single market to do so.

claims.text: People from Caribbean countries such as Jamaica appear to be disproportionately targeted for deportation from the UK if they commit crimes.

claimReview.title: Higher deportation rates don’t necessarily demonstrate ‘disproportionate targeting’ of Jamaicans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data alone does not provide an entirely reliable ‘deportation rate’. Nor can it indicate the reasons why the deportation rate may vary. There may be many reasons why criminals from some countries are more likely to be deported than others.

claims.text: Parents are subsidising a new flagship "free" nursery scheme for three- and four-year-olds in England from their own pockets.

claimReview.title: Are parents paying for free nursery places? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 28% of childcare providers responding to a survey said that if they provided the new 30 hours of free childcare, there were additional costs on top for more hours, or other goods and services. We don’t know how representative this is of all childcare providers, and it’s based on a low response rate.

claims.text: Emmanuel Macron said the UK must take its share of migrants, 300,000 now immediately and up to 100,000 every year until the situation is resolved if it wants to remain in the EU.

claimReview.title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He hasn’t said this.

claims.text: SARS-CoV-2 has never been isolated, purified, sequenced, characterised or proven to exist.

claimReview.title: SARS-CoV-2 does exist - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The SARS-CoV-2 virus does exist and has been sequenced over a million times in the UK alone.

claims.text: Ireland owes 865 Billion.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Ireland’s national debt is worth €215 billion

claims.text: Poland has refused to allow mosques to be built until they can build a Christian church in Saudi Arabia.

claimReview.title: Poland has not refused to allow the building of mosques - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is not Polish government policy.

claims.text: Changes in government energy policy since 2015 may have added £120 a year to household bills.

claimReview.title: Renewable subsidy cuts might raise bills in the long term, but we don’t know by how much - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The confidence of energy investors has been shaken, according to the Energy and Climate Change Committee. If so this could raise household bills in the long term. But the specific £120 figure isn’t particularly credible.

claims.text: Conservative councils cost £341 more in council tax on average per household.

claimReview.title: Labour and Conservative council tax: who costs you more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t been able to replicate this calculation, and in general it’s difficult to attribute the cost of council tax to a single party.

claims.text: One in six A&E units in England are set to be closed or downgraded.

claimReview.title: How many A&Es are going to close? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are mostly speculative at present. Research has shown this many could be closed or downgraded based on their current plans. At the moment we only know for definite that about a quarter of these will be closed or downgraded.

claims.text: Nurses are spending entire shifts in A&E car parks because of ambulance delays.

claimReview.title: More ambulances are being delayed outside A&Es - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An unnamed nurse said this to ITV News, although we don’t know how widespread this is. One in six ambulances were delayed for over half an hour after arriving at A&Es in England in the first week of 2018.

claims.text: The EU is demanding that the UK pays a £39 billion divorce bill.

claimReview.title: Claims that a no deal Brexit “will cost us nothing” are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was jointly agreed by the UK and the EU. It covers the UK’s outstanding financial commitments and liabilities to the EU.

claims.text: Last winter, tens of thousands of sick patients waited on A&E trolleys.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were 196,000 waits of over four hours in accident and emergencies in England in the winter months of 2016/17. These figures are the closest we have to a count of people on trolleys, which isn’t specifically recorded.

claims.text: The Labour Party wouldn't have problems with the Irish backstop because it wants the whole of the United Kingdom to be in a permanent customs union with the EU.

claimReview.title: Does Labour's Brexit policy mean no Irish backstop? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour’s proposed Brexit policy may avoid a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic (removing the need for the Irish backstop) in theory. But it seems extremely unlikely that the EU would accept those proposals alongside everything else Labour wants from Brexit.

claims.text: Rail fares have risen by 25% since 2010.

claimReview.title: Please do not board this train: rail fare claims held at red signal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but refers to all rail fares rather than just regulated fares, as has been widely quoted.

claims.text: Closing the Renewables Obligation to onshore wind early will save households 30p a year.

claimReview.title: How much will closing the Renewables Obligation early save on your bills? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government's best estimate is that the early closure will cut the average household's electricity bill by 30p, but there's some uncertainty to this estimate.

claims.text: The UK wastes more food than any other country in Europe.

claimReview.title: Corbyn incorrectly says UK has worst recycling in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Data on food waste is not up to date. The latest data suggests the UK does not have the highest level of food waste per person.

claims.text: The SNP has delivered 52,600 homes for social rent.

claimReview.title: The state of social renting in Scotland - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is how many were completed between 2007/08 and 2017/18. This figure isn’t complete, as it doesn’t include homes for social rent that weren’t partially funded by the government.

claims.text: Experts agree that… [if we left Europe] there would be less money for public services like the NHS.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most economists seem to agree that leaving the EU would cost the UK economically. If that happened, the government would need to raise taxes, cut other things, or borrow to keep NHS spending at the same level.

claims.text: 94% of people in Wales don’t want independence.

claimReview.title: Welsh views on independence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: On average 6% of people in Wales said they wanted independence when presented with a range of options on how Wales should be governed. This is comparing polls which ask a consistent question over the last five years. Other polls have asked slightly different questions and found a higher proportion in favour of independence, but it’s always in the minority.

claims.text: Excess deaths over the past year have not been statistically higher than the average for previous years. The ONS shows that, in terms of deaths per 100,000 of population, since 1993 ten previous years have had higher rates than 2020.

claimReview.title: Several coronavirus claims made by MP in newspaper are inaccurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Excess deaths in 2020 were higher than the average over previous years. Eight years since 1993 have had higher death rates.

claims.text: Water cannon may be deployed today in London for a pro-Brexit march.

claimReview.title: No, water cannon will not be deployed at the pro-Brexit march - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. The Met Police do not own any water cannon and they are not currently authorised for use in England and Wales. Both the Met Police and the Mayor of London’s office confirmed they will not be using water cannon.

claims.text: Covid-19 is a deliberate hoax designed to promote the climate change agenda.

claimReview.title: David Icke makes false claim that vaccines are ‘gene therapy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misinterpretation of a book written in 2020 by the executive chairman of the World Economic Forum.

claims.text: An NHS doctor who spoke out about the lack of PPE on the BBC has been suspended.

claimReview.title: A doctor claims his contract was terminated after talking about PPE shortages to the press - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A doctor has told us his contract working at an NHS hospital was terminated because of comments he made to the BBC about a lack of PPE.

claims.text: 23% of parents of secondary pupils will insist their children wear masks when they return to school.

claimReview.title: Data doesn’t show parents will ‘insist’ on children wearing masks to school - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The survey question this claim is based on did not ask whether or not parents would “insist” children wore masks—only whether or not children would wear them.

claims.text: There are street prayers happening in London.

claimReview.title: Islam in London: factchecking the viral image - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are examples of Muslims praying outdoors, on streets, and pavements, in London.

claims.text: Dettol antiseptic spray says it kills coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Dettol hasn’t tested its products against the new Wuhan coronavirus yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is correct but that doesn’t refer to the new coronavirus (Covid-19) identified in Wuhan. Coronavirus is a large category of viruses that includes the common cold. Dettol has said its products haven’t been tested against the new virus yet.

claims.text: The reports of sexual offense in schools have almost trebled over four years, others say it has more than doubled.

claimReview.title: Reporting sexual offences in schools: an incomplete picture - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are correct but the figures are incomplete, so don’t show the full picture across the UK.

claims.text: 43% of health boards in England provide no specialised mental health service for new or expecting mothers.

claimReview.title: Is there a shortage of maternal mental health services? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was correct in 2014 and is still about right. Updated figures from the Maternal Mental Health Alliance show that 39% of Clinical Commissioning Groups have no community mental health services for pregnant or new mothers. 19% had services which met Royal College of Psychiatrists standards.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU means we have ample supplies of fresh fruit and medicine.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although it’s difficult to say how severe medicine and food shortages – if there are shortages - might be after Brexit.

claims.text: Public opinion is swinging in favour of having a second referendum on Brexit.

claimReview.title: Has public opinion swung in favour of a second EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is some polling evidence of a shift in public opinion towards another referendum, but different polls have given inconsistent results, and results can vary a lot depending on what question is asked.

claims.text: The starting salary for teachers increased from £21,600 in 2010 to £24,400 in 2020.

claimReview.title: MPs salaries have grown faster than starting salaries of nurses, teachers and police officers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. But after factoring in inflation, this amounts to a 6% pay fall.

claims.text: Messages encouraging users to upgrade to WhatsApp Gold should be ignored.

claimReview.title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. WhatsApp Gold does not exist, but there are numerous “WhatsApp Gold” scams which encourage people to download the fake app which may be harmful for their computer or mobile device.

claims.text: The Far East economy is “going gangbusters”.

claimReview.title: Comparing economic growth across the world - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The GDP of East Asia grew by 5.6% in real terms in 2017 and Southeast Asia grew by 5.3%, according to the IMF. It forecasts growth in East Asia to slow slightly in coming years.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines have the capacity to change your DNA.

claimReview.title: Influencer video full of untrue vaccine claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is untrue that Covid-19 vaccines, which include mRNA vaccines, have the capacity to affect your DNA. mRNA vaccines work by introducing a molecule into the body which instructs cells to build a disease-specific antigen. The antigen is then recognised by the immune system which produces antibodies to fight the real thing.

claims.text: Everybody is getting their news and information, and watching television on a tablet.

claimReview.title: How much shopping gets done online? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An Ofcom survey published in 2017 reported that 17% of UK adults reported getting news from internet or apps on a tablet, although Ofcom says this may be underestimated. Most adults get their news from television. An Ofcom commissioned survey found that of adults who used video on demand or TV catch-up services, 35% watch film and TV on a tablet. 83% use a TV.

claims.text: A survey found almost three quarters of voters believe social care should be a high priority for the government.

claimReview.title: Poll shows public thinks Brexit and NHS are most important issues facing the country - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, though the survey was of UK adults, not just voters.  The list of issues respondents were asked about was also far from comprehensive. Other polling shows Brexit and the NHS are the most important issues to the public overall.

claims.text: The flu killed 64,000 people in 2018.

claimReview.title: This figure for flu deaths is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 64,000 people died in January 2018 in England and Wales of all causes. Public Health England estimates that across the 2017/18 flu season there were around 22,000 deaths associated with flu in England.

claims.text: 39 people were murdered in one day in England.

claimReview.title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is likely untrue. We could find no evidence of a recent mass homicide, and on average two people die of homicide each day in England.

claims.text: Nicola Sturgeon is keeping the lockdown.

claimReview.title: Be wary of social media posts comparing fatality rates in confirmed Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were some slight changes to the lockdown rules from Monday 11 May but they remained much the same as before. They have since been relaxed further to allow meetings of people from two households.

claims.text: The emissions from private jets flying delegates to Glasgow for COP26 are equivalent to Scotland’s entire annual CO2 emissions.

claimReview.title: Emissions from COP26 private jets are far, far lower than Scotland’s annual CO2 output - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. A headline in the Sunday Mail claimed that the emissions from 400 private jets is equivalent to the annual carbon footprint of Scottish people. The article clarifies that this refers to 1,600 Scots, not the entire country, however this has been taken out of context in a number of cases.

claims.text: Vaccinated people are still being hospitalised and getting sick.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccines are not perfect. Some people who have been vaccinated do fall sick and die of Covid-19. But their risk of this is far lower than people who have not been vaccinated.

claims.text: A million families are dependent on food banks.

claimReview.title: Food banks, zero hours contracts and falling wages: are we worse off? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The most commonly used figures for food bank use come from the Trussell Trust. They show a million uses (not individual users) of food banks in 2013/14. The Trust isn't the only organisation running food banks, so we don't have a figure for the total number of people using food banks.

claims.text: All animals died in the vaccine’s clinical trials.

claimReview.title: Post makes misleading claims about Covid vaccines and animal trials - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Animals are usually euthanised as part of medical trials so scientists can examine their organs for signs of pathology. This does not mean they were killed by the vaccine.

claims.text: Criminals are sent to jail only after committing 55 offences.

claimReview.title: Context is needed in this article about offences committed prior to prison sentences - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is misleading. In prison sentences of less than six months, the average number of previous offences was 60 for females and 57 for males. This includes offences that have previously resulted in a prison sentence and the figures may count the same people more than once.

claims.text: The UK has lost 134 million miles of bus routes because private operators choose to make a profit and scrap the ones that don’t.

claimReview.title: Would free bus travel save young people £1,000 a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were 134 million fewer miles driven by buses in the UK in 2016/17 than in 2006/7. This was driven by a reduction in local authority funded bus miles.

claims.text: They signed a six month contract taking them to full qualification, six months earlier than they had anticipated.

claimReview.title: This is what has happened with student nurses who volunteered to work for the NHS early - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The contract they signed will depend on the trust they worked for. But some nurses may have been under the impression they would work for six months and some of the communication about the policy to nurses was ambiguous.

claims.text: Cutting corporation tax will boost the growth rate of the economy.

claimReview.title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s evidence this could happen over the long term, but it’s too limited and uncertain to put specific numbers on the effect. Cutting the tax is expected to cost more money than it raises through higher growth or investment.

claims.text: Police will now require written evidence of a medical exemption if people are to avoid a fine for not wearing a mask.

claimReview.title: Do you need to carry proof if you’re exempt from wearing a mask? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The rules have not changed, people with medical exemptions from wearing a mask are not legally required to carry an exemption card or badge. But the police union says officers may ask people for proof to enforce mask wearing laws.

claims.text: There are 10,000 more training places available for nurses.

claimReview.title: Nursing training places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This figure refers to the government’s ambition for additional places by 2020 on nursing, midwifery and allied health courses.

claims.text: Hate preacher Abu Qatada called for the death of soldiers and faced no action for his crimes.

claimReview.title: These claims about radical Muslim preachers and Tommy Robinson are mostly incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We could find no specific evidence Qatada called for the death of soldiers, though he has advocated terrorism. Qatada was extradited to Jordan for terrorism charges in 2013 after spells in and out of UK prisons. He was cleared of terrorism offences in Jordan.

claims.text: One in three dementia patients are forced to sell their homes.

claimReview.title: How many people with dementia have to sell their homes to pay for care? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A poll found that 16% of respondents who said they had friends or family with dementia also said that person had to sell their home to pay for care. But there are other drawbacks which mean the results are not reliable.

claims.text: Arrest rates at Notting Hill Carnival are almost identical to Glastonbury.

claimReview.title: Do Notting Hill Carnival and Glastonbury have similar crime rates? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures are not reliable enough to estimate the crime rate at either event.

claims.text: The £300m Track and Trace app has quietly been binned.

claimReview.title: Viral Facebook post on cost of “binned” test and trace app is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A Covid-19 track and trace app is on trial in Great Britain. The government trialled an app of its own design before changing track and using a Google/Apple designed system. The app had cost around £10.8m as of June.

claims.text: NASA just hired 24 theologians to assess how the world would react if we discovered alien life.

claimReview.title: NASA hasn’t ‘just’ hired 24 theologians to study future discovery of aliens - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NASA did fund a programme undertaken by 24 theologians to study how major religions would react to the discovery of alien life, but did not directly hire the academics. The NASA funding for the programme ended in 2017.

claims.text: Half of adults are now being paid by the state.

claimReview.title: Claims about who’s paid by the state aren’t very meaningful - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are too many ways to interpret this for any single answer to be meaningful.

claims.text: 69% of the public support onshore wind, which is the most popular renewable energy technology.

claimReview.title: What do Brits think about wind farms? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a survey where 70% of respondents stated they'd be happy to have a wind farm built in their local area. However, a DECC survey showed 65% of respondents supported onshore wind, which was less popular than solar power, wave and tidal power and offshore wind.

claims.text: State school pupils are less likely to reach top professions than pupils from private schools.

claimReview.title: Are state school pupils less likely to reach top jobs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Overall this is correct.

claims.text: Four in ten fathers will not see their children this Father’s Day.

claimReview.title: Did four in ten dads not see their children this Father’s Day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 37% of fathers who responded to a recent survey said that either they, or someone they knew, had ever experienced not seeing their children on Father's Day.

claims.text: We don’t know the Covid-19 vaccines are safe because the trial of them is still underway and won’t finish until 2023 so anyone getting the vaccine is being experimented on.

claimReview.title: People giving Covid-19 vaccines won’t be tried as war criminals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Multiple phases of trials have shown the approved vaccines to be safe and effective. Ongoing monitoring and further trials does not disprove this.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith has been awarded a knighthood for services to the country.

claimReview.title: This claim that 2,000 people have died waiting for benefits since a Universal Credit review was announced needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He has been knighted in the New Years Honours for political and public service.

claims.text: Jo Swinson called for a referendum on leaving or remaining in the EU in 2008.

claimReview.title: Jo Swinson said the Liberal Democrats supported an EU referendum in 2008 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, in 2008 she said this was the policy of the Liberal Democrats.

claims.text: Some of the foreign aid budget went on China’s film and museum industry last year.

claimReview.title: Is UK foreign aid funding filming in Beijing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, at least £440,000 of Overseas Development Aid was spent on Chinese film, TV and museum projects in 2016/17.

claims.text: A lot of the vaccine ingredients haven’t been tested for their efficacy.

claimReview.title: Influencer video full of untrue vaccine claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. Efficacy data has been published for all three Covid-19 vaccines approved for use in the UK.

claims.text: The junior doctors' strike will put 200 lives at risk.

claimReview.title: No evidence that junior doctors' strike will put 200 lives at risk - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This number is unsubstantiated, and we have questions about the assumption it appears to be based on.

claims.text: A facemask is not going to save you from a virus and they can cause pneumonia.

claimReview.title: False claims from funeral director about facemasks, vaccines and the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The guidance has changed throughout the pandemic, however current thinking is that face masks can play a useful role in preventing the spread of Covid-19. There is no evidence to suggest that they cause pneumonia.

claims.text: There are roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty this year. In 2000, there were roughly 14 million people living in relative poverty.

claimReview.title: How poverty rates are cherry-picked to score political points - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest government figures show 14.5 million people (22% of the population) living in relative low income households after housing costs in the UK. In 2000/01 it was 13 million across Great Britain (23% of the population).

claims.text: A medical alert says to stop the use of anti-inflammatories for pain or high temperatures.

claimReview.title: That ‘medical alert’ about severe Covid-19 cases in Cork due to anti-inflammatories is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This message is fake. Current advice from health authorities in the UK and Ireland say to continue taking previously prescribed medication, including anti-inflammatories unless told otherwise by a healthcare professional. The NHS says there is no strong evidence that taking ibuprofen can make Covid-19 worse, but advises people with symptoms to take paracetamol if they can.

claims.text: Official data shows twice as many people have died due to the Covid-19 vaccines in six months than people who have died of Covid-19 in 15 months.

claimReview.title: Vaccine deaths are not higher than Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is completely untrue, and is based on misleading conclusions drawn from official data. It only counts Covid-19 deaths in England with no underlying conditions, and misuses reports of deaths after Covid-19 vaccines where no causal link can be proven.

claims.text: Sixty percent of people in the UK asylum system entered the country illegally.

claimReview.title: Government asylum claims based on unpublished data - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s unclear whether this statistic is reliable because the Home Office has not published any details behind how it was calculated.

claims.text: You have until 23 June to opt out.

claimReview.title: The deadline for opting out of the NHS GP data collection has changed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This deadline has changed. It was 23 June when the data collection date was 1 July, but the collection date has now changed to 1 September. NHS Digital says you need to return the opt out form to your GP to be processed ahead of this date.

claims.text: The Supreme Court has ruled that the benefit cap is "right and fair".

claimReview.title: The Supreme Court didn't endorse the benefit cap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. The Supreme Court ruled that the benefit cap is legal, not that it's right or fair. The judgment can't be taken as an endorsement of this policy.

claims.text: The Pirbright has an office in Wuhan China.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can find no Pirbright office in Wuhan, China.

claims.text: There is a specific criminal offence of assaulting a police, immigration, or prison officer, but not of assaulting a doctor, nurse, or paramedic.

claimReview.title: Assaults on NHS staff - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but the maximum sentence for assaulting a police officer is no higher than that for assaulting anyone else, and sentencing rules say that assaults on public sector workers of all kinds should be treated especially seriously.

claims.text: Flu shots contain polysorbate 80, which has been linked to ovarian damage and infertility. It could induce liver failure.

claimReview.title: Image on flu jab ingredients is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At least one UK flu vaccine does contain polysorbate 80. There’s no evidence that the levels found in vaccines can damage fertility or the liver.

claims.text: Higher tuition fees haven’t put students from disadvantaged backgrounds off going to university.

claimReview.title: What’s been the impact of higher tuition fees on disadvantaged students going to university? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Higher tuition fees do not seem to have affected the longer term trend of increasing proportions of young disadvantaged students (and young students of all backgrounds) going to university. Mature student numbers have fluctuated. We don’t know if the numbers going to university would be higher if tuition fees hadn’t been increased.

claims.text: Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries.

claimReview.title: Why Sinn Féin MPs don’t get salaries - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Sinn Féin MPs and the party do receive other money for expenses.

claims.text: It’s possible to “seize” Edinburgh Castle using powers granted by Magna Carta.

claimReview.title: Magna Carta can’t be used to seize Edinburgh Castle - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is completely untrue. Magna Carta does not, and has never, been part of Scots law. The relevant clause only applies to 25 barons who lived in the 13th century, and was removed from the historic law a year after it was written.

claims.text: The EU has set a 15% overall target for UK energy consumption from renewable sources in 2020.

claimReview.title: The UK's renewable energy target - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK does have a 15% overall target. It also has a 10% target for renewables in transport energy consumption in 2020. The exact way in which the 15% target is met is up to the UK, so long as the 10% transport sub-target is met.

claims.text: When the UK leaves the EU we won’t be sending vast amounts of money to the EU every year.

claimReview.title: NHS England: £394 million more a week? - Full Fact
