claimReview.textualRating: Our net contribution to the EU budget is typically £9-10 billion a year. We will no longer contribute to it from 2021 onwards, but other costs and economic effects associated with leaving are expected to more than offset that saving.

claims.text: Youth unemployment is at historically low levels.

claimReview.title: Is youth unemployment at a historic low? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: At 12.5% youth unemployment is among the lowest it’s been since 2005.

claims.text: Vaccines contain the SV40 virus.

claimReview.title: There are no mouse brains in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was some concern in the 1960s that some viruses were contaminated with SV40. No vaccine has been found to contain it since 1963, and there’s no evidence it caused cancer as some claimed.

claims.text: Blue surgical masks are sprayed with PTFE, which is harmful to humans.

claimReview.title: PTFE in masks does not pose a health risk, unless you get it very hot - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some masks contain PTFE, but ordinary surgical masks are often made from other materials. PTFE is not generally harmful to humans.

claims.text: The pumps can now be filled with E10 fuel which will destroy old cars.

claimReview.title: No evidence government spreading fuel shortage rumours to sell surplus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: E10 fuel is intended to phase out standard E5 fuel and isn’t suitable for all older cars. However, super unleaded E5 fuel will still be available.

claims.text: The leader of the government’s independent review into building regulations and fire safety said she didn’t think it was her job to call for the banning of combustible materials in cladding.

claimReview.title: What has the leader of the fire safety review said about a cladding ban? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, she said she didn’t think it was her role to go into “the detail of individual regulations or the specifics of the guidance”. She welcomed the government’s consultation on a ban but has also raised concerns that a ban might “create a false sense of security”.

claims.text: Diabetes prescriptions are costing the NHS in England more than £1 billion a year, according to figures from NHS Digital.

claimReview.title: Do diabetes prescriptions cost £1 billion a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can’t know how much it actually costs the NHS. £1 billion was the net ingredient cost in 2017/18 of items for diabetes prescribed in England through NHS primary care settings. There is no available information on what discounts the NHS might receive or extra costs relating to dispensing.

claims.text: Until 12 March, the government’s advice said it was ‘very unlikely’ people in care homes will become infected.

claimReview.title: Government guidance withdrawn in March did say it was ‘very unlikely’ people in care homes would be infected with Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. Government guidance, withdrawn on 13 March, stated this twice.

claims.text: In the last eight years, spending cuts led to the closure of children’s centres.

claimReview.title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of children’s centres in England has fallen by around 500 from 2010 to 2017, and the number of Sure Start centres has fallen by around 1,200. Funding for Sure Start in England fell by 50% in real terms from 2010/11 to 2016/17.

claims.text: Women aren’t allowed to breastfeed babies in the House of Commons.

claimReview.title: Can MPs breastfeed in the House of Commons? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Breastfeeding is not allowed in the House of Commons chamber and committees, though it is allowed in other areas of the Palace of Westminster.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Godfrey Bloom video makes false claims about vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid-19 vaccines have been through a number of clinical trials which have shown their benefits “far outweigh any currently known side effects.”

claims.text: 5G millimeter waves could be absorbed by skin cells acting as antennas, transferred to other cells and play the main role in producing coronaviruses in biological cells.

claimReview.title: A retracted paper linking 5G and coronavirus with no evidence is doing the rounds on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is absolutely no evidence that this is the case. A paper presenting this theory (with no proof) has since been retracted.

claims.text: The IMF says that the UK will be the fastest-growing advanced economy in the world in 2016.

claimReview.title: The economic outlook: IMF or IFS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not correct. The IMF forecasts GDP growth of 1.8% for the UK in 2016, the 18th highest among the 39 countries it calls ‘advanced economies’.

claims.text: There is no tsunami, no cliff edge and no explosion in suicide figures.

claimReview.title: New data doesn’t definitively show zero increase in suicides across England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We cannot be sure about that from these early figures, as they only cover approximately one sixth of England.

claims.text: The nurses that Boris Johnson claimed saved his life are not registered in the UK.

claimReview.title: The nurses that treated Boris Johnson for coronavirus are real UK nurses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. We found both nurses on the register.

claims.text: Black Lives Matter Scotland have produced posters and stickers with phrases such as “Kill a white on sight” on them.

claimReview.title: Black Lives Matter Scotland say they did not produce “Kill a White On Sight” stickers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The group have denied the material came from them.

claims.text: The UK government spent £285 million building an airport on the island of Saint Helena that planes can't use.

claimReview.title: UK foreign aid, and an airport that never took off - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About £285 million was spent on a project to design, build, and operate an airport on the island of St Helena for ten years. But due to the extreme winds on the island commercial flights have been unable to run as planned.

claims.text: 5G can make you sick.

claimReview.title: £20 notes don’t have a secret message about 5G and coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that 5G can harm your health.

claims.text: Since 2001 Westminster has returned £447.5 billion to Scotland.

claimReview.title: England hasn’t ‘kept’ £450 billion of Scottish taxes since 2001 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is hard to say for certain. Since 2001/02 the Scottish government, local authorities and public corporations have spent £643 billion which was not retained in Scotland. Most of this would have come back from the UK government in the form of the block grant.

claims.text: Official International Red Cross records reveal the actual Concentration Camp total death during World War II toll was 271,301.

claimReview.title: Red Cross documents do not undermine official Holocaust death toll - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The documents managed by the International Committee of the Red Cross only recorded a fraction of the Holocaust death count. They do not in any way dispute the official death toll of six million.

claims.text: Options for post-Brexit trade deals with the EU will lead to GDP that’s between 2% and 8% lower.

claimReview.title: This image on the costs of Brexit is very misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on government analysis of 3 hypothetical deals, which explicitly can’t be used as economic forecasts and are very uncertain. According to the analysis GDP will continue to grow over the next fifteen years in each case, but more slowly than on existing OBR projections.

claims.text: The government spent £2.8 million protecting Donald Trump.

claimReview.title: How much of this meme on government spending is true? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was reportedly the extra cost to the Metropolitan Police for policing Donald Trump’s visit to London and Windsor (not including the protests). Since the tweet was written, the National Police Chiefs’ Council has said an “early estimate” of the total cost is nearly £18 million.

claims.text: The French ambassador to Afghanistan has left the country’s capital.

claimReview.title: French ambassador hasn’t left Kabul as Robert Peston claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The embassy has relocated to Kabul airport.

claims.text: Leaving the EU would cost the average UK household at least £850 a year, and potentially as much as £1,700, according to research released by the London School of Economics.

claimReview.title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: leaving - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures don’t tell you how much you or your family would lose, but they point in the same direction as most other economic analysis seems to.

claims.text: An image shows Muslims queueing to get into a mosque, standing closer than two metres apart, after the lockdown was announced.

claimReview.title: Photo circulating of busy mosque was taken before lockdown - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture was taken the Friday before lockdown measures were announced. Lockdown measures were announced on Monday 23 March, and included places of worship being told to close.

claims.text: Class sizes are soaring under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Class sizes under the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The average class size in English state primary schools has been increasing. It rose from 26.4 pupils in 2010 to 27.1 in 2016. In secondary schools, average class sizes have dropped from 20.5 to 20.4 in the same period.

claims.text: The number of nurses in the NHS has declined by 5,000 because of Brexit.

claimReview.title: Lib Dem claims about EU health workers and the NHS are generally true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that nursing and midwifery numbers have dropped by around 5,000 since the referendum, and Brexit is a likely factor driving at least some of this fall.

claims.text: Approximately 15% of people will pay back their entire student loan.

claimReview.title: About 17% of students are forecast to fully pay back their loans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to forecasts. Estimates from the Institute for Fiscal Studies in October last year show about 17% of graduates are forecast to fully repay their loans.

claims.text: A police car destroyed during protests in Bristol is a prop vehicle as the MOT has expired.

claimReview.title: Burnt-out police car in Bristol protests was not fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not the case. Police vehicles don’t need MOT registration.

claims.text: Golf can reduce the risk of early death.

claimReview.title: Research suggesting health benefits of golf could also suggest benefits of being rich - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Golfers identified in a study had a lower death rate than other over 65s but the research didn’t say golf was the reason why.

claims.text: Allegations of people pretending to be other people to steal their votes doubled nationally between 2014 and 2016.

claimReview.title: Has the government’s voter ID scheme been a success? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Allegations of personation at polling stations did double from 21 in 2014, to 45 in 2016. The UK statistics Authority said that isolating 2014 to 2016 is “not typical of the fuller time series”.  The number of allegations fell again to 28 in 2017 and there were 22 a year on average since 2010.

claims.text: Spending on the main disability benefits will increase over the course of this parliament.

claimReview.title: Is spending on disability benefits going up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending on Disability Living Allowance, Personal Independence Payments and Attendance Allowance (the ‘main disability benefits’ this claim is referring to) is expected to rise slightly over this parliament, after rising prices are taken into account. It won’t rise by as much as it has been in recent years.

claims.text: All cameras on the M1 and M25 went live recently, set at 72mph.

claimReview.title: These claims about speed cameras on the M1 and M25 aren’t true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Highways England says it is not aware of any changes on these roads. The normal speed limit on motorways and dual carriageways is up to 70mph although it may be lower at some points on these roads.

claims.text: A video shows migrants rioting in Denmark.

claimReview.title: This is not a video of “migrant hordes” attacking Danish police - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s actually from anti-government protests in Algeria.

claims.text: Some airlines are not allowing vaccinated passengers to fly.

claimReview.title: British Airways hasn’t told their pilots they don’t need Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence airlines are planning to ban vaccinated passengers, and no record of airlines meeting to discuss the possibility of this happening.

claims.text: England is easing the lockdown.

claimReview.title: Be wary of social media posts comparing fatality rates in confirmed Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were some slight changes to the lockdown rules from Wednesday 13 May but they remain much the same as before.

claims.text: 60% of all sales from Northern Ireland go to Great Britain.

claimReview.title: 60% of Northern Ireland’s exports go to the rest of the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in 2015.

claims.text: Just 13,844 people in England and Wales were infected with Covid-19 in 2020.

claimReview.title: Millions—not thousands—caught Covid last year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is close to the number of NOIDs notifications by doctors, but it is not the total number of infections. Almost 2.5 million people tested positive for Covid-19 in England and Wales last year.

claims.text: 4,300 more staff employed in mental health trusts since 2013.

claimReview.title: Mental health staff in the NHS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not how many mental health specialist staff there are. It is the increase in all staff in English trusts with over half their outpatient activity in mental health specialities. Some of the staff were effectively re-categorised into the mental health category during this time, rather than being newly hired.

claims.text: 93.3% of school leavers in Scotland are going into education, training or employment.

claimReview.title: Is educational attainment in Scotland at record levels? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to initial findings for 2015/16, although these may change slightly when the surveys are followed up later this year.

claims.text: Dominic Raab said he watched Peppa Pig with his parents when he was young, even though it first aired in May 2004, when he was 30.

claimReview.title: Dominic Raab didn’t say he watched Peppa Pig with his parents when he was young - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears to be a misquote from an interview where Mr Raab said he watched Peppa Pig with his children when they were younger.

claims.text: More than 40% of newly recruited nurses are leaving full-time employment within their first year.

claimReview.title: Are 40% of nurses leaving full-time work in their first year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 15% of NHS England nurses who began as full-time staff between May 2016 and May 2017 had left full-time work by May 2017.

claims.text: Nadine Dorries MP’s office said that although vaccines aren’t mandatory, if you choose not to have a Covid-19 vaccine, you will face short-term restrictions to prevent you infecting anyone else.

claimReview.title: Nadine Dorries says email from her office on vaccines does not reflect her views - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a genuine email sent from her office but according to the MP, it was not signed off by her and doesn’t reflect her view or government policy.

claims.text: The NHS was not “overwhelmed” during Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Letter to MHRA is filled with false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is somewhat subjective but there is lots of evidence indicating NHS trusts were under severe pressure during the peaks of Covid-19.

claims.text: Since the Conservatives came into government in 2010, they have delivered more affordable homes than Labour did in its last seven years in office.

claimReview.title: Affordable homes: comparing Labour and Conservative records - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 346,000 more affordable homes were added in the seven years to 2016/17, compared to 333,000 in the seven years before that. Since 2011/12, the kinds of affordable homes being built have been typically more expensive “affordable rented” homes.

claims.text: The EU has ordered organic farmers to treat sick animals with homeopathy in a new directive.

claimReview.title: The EU, homeopathy and Norwegian vets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU legislation promotes homeopathy in organic farming if it's an effective treatment. The law isn't particularly new, as a revised version of the claim makes clear.

claims.text: The UK is the only country in the EU whose health service is heavily dependent on foreign clinical staff.

claimReview.title: UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has one of the highest levels of foreign-born doctors and nurses in the EU, but it’s not the highest.

claims.text: On 30th January 1939 Adolf Hitler asked President von Hindenburg to dissolve parliament to stop politicians bypassing “the will of the people.”

claimReview.title: This post oversimplifies and confuses details about Hitler’s rise to power - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This incorrectly conflates multiple events in Hitler’s rise. Von Hindenburg dissolved parliament at Hitler’s request in 1933 in order to hold an election. We’ve seen no evidence that Hitler said dissolution was to bypass those trying to stop “the will of the people”.

claims.text: Poor oral health raises the risk of mental illness by a third.

claimReview.title: Study linking gum disease and mental health shows correlation not causation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A study found people with diagnosed gum disease were more likely to go on to develop a mental health condition, but did not say whether one factor caused the other, as suggested.

claims.text: The cladding used on Grenfell Tower has previously been banned in the USA.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The cladding used on Grenfell Tower is been banned on tall building in some parts of the USA.

claims.text: If we leave the EU on WTO terms, Article 24 of the World Trade Organisation would allow the UK and EU to maintain zero tariffs for up to 10 years while negotiating a new deal with the EU.

claimReview.title: Does WTO Article 24 allow us to have tariff-free trade with the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is very unlikely in practice. This refers to Article 24 of the WTO’s General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. It allows countries who are negotiating a free-trade area or customs union to have an interim agreement on trade tariffs for a period of (in most cases) up to ten years provided they have a “plan and schedule” agreed for concluding a final deal. It’s unlikely we could have such a “plan and schedule” in place with the EU before we leave.

claims.text: The number of school places in the country has expanded by 800,000 since 2010.

claimReview.title: 825,000 more English school places since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, they've increased by around 825,000 in primary and secondary schools in England since 2010.

claims.text: The vaccine will change your DNA.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Some of the coronavirus vaccines use mRNA, which instructs the body on how to build immune proteins called antibodies against SARS-Cov-2 (the virus that causes Covid-19). They do not change, or interact with your DNA.

claims.text: Gatherings of more than 30 people are illegal under the current Covid-19 guidelines.

claimReview.title: More than 30 people are allowed to protest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are some exceptions, including for protests which have been organised by a suitable body and undergone risk assessments.

claims.text: This is the first time the UK has finished above China in the medals table.

claimReview.title: The Olympic Games, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It's the first time since the Winter Olympics of 1980, China's first games, when the UK has finished above them in the table.

claims.text: A picture shows a person installing 5G wearing a hazmat radiation suit.

claimReview.title: This picture doesn’t show someone wearing a hazmat suit to install 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The person was probably not installing 5G, but wearing protective clothing to clean a 4G mobile phone tower.

claims.text: Jürgen Klopp said the European Super League is about “greed” and that he had demanded a meeting with the Liverpool owner.

claimReview.title: Fake football quotes go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This quote is made up, although Jürgen Klopp has expressed opposition to the idea of a Super League.

claims.text: 3.8 million people in work are living in poverty.

claimReview.title: Are most working age people in poverty also in work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the estimated number in relative poverty in 2014/15. Newer figures since put the figure slightly lower.

claims.text: 23 people in Norway died after getting the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: What you need to know about the claims 23 people died after getting the Covid-19 vaccine in Norway - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True as of 14 January, but we don’t know for certain that getting the vaccine was what caused these people’s deaths. There’s a possibility that side effects of these vaccines, such as nausea and fever, contributed to the deaths of these 23 elderly patients. As of 17 January there had been 33 such deaths.

claims.text: At the moment, Scotland gets more money from the UK government than it sends back.

claimReview.title: Scotland's public finances - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True in 2016, although it hasn’t always been the case.

claims.text: Tariffs on exporting lamb and sheep to the EU will be 40% in a no deal Brexit scenario.

claimReview.title: Lamb exports to Japan aren’t due to EU trade deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tariff level varies depending on which lamb or sheep product is being exported. But 40% is within that range.

claims.text: Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are cures for the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: We don’t yet know if anti-malaria drug chloroquine is a cure for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There aren’t yet peer-reviewed clinical studies to prove either drug is effective against the symptoms of, or can protect against, the new coronavirus. You should not take either unless you’re specifically prescribed them by a doctor.

claims.text: Spending on schools is being cut.

claimReview.title: School spending: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Spending per pupil is set to fall in real terms, by 8%, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

claims.text: The Australian government has removed documents describing the vaccines as a poison from their site as part of a cover-up.

claimReview.title: Australian government hasn’t admitted vaccines are a dangerous poison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. At the time of writing the documents referred to in the video were available in full on the government of Western Australia’s website.

claims.text: Police budgets are being cut.

claimReview.title: What's happened to police budgets? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Direct government grants to the police have been cut for the past five years. They will continue to fall over the next few years. Most local forces have the power to maintain their budgets if they raise the maximum amount they are allowed to.

claims.text: The cladding used on Grenfell Tower was chosen by Ed Miliband to meet EU climate change legislation.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about Grenfell Tower are wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Ed Miliband did not choose the cladding on Grenfell Tower. There is no evidence we’re aware of that environmental legislation was behind the choice of cladding material.

claims.text: There are fewer good schools in the Midlands and North of England compared to the South.

claimReview.title: Secondary schools in the South perform better than other parts of England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct according to Ofsted ratings. There’s a small North-South divide in the percentage of primary schools rated “good” or “outstanding”, and a significant one when it comes to secondary schools.

claims.text: 38% of infections outside of the home are caught in schools

claimReview.title: Fact-checking claims on coronavirus transmission in schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This data refers to the number of Covid-19 incidents reported by local health teams. It does not represent all non-domestic transmission and it is misleading to suggest this.

claims.text: One in three people aged 30 are going to live to 100.

claimReview.title: You’ve less than a one in three chance of reaching 100 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears to be an overestimate. The latest estimates from the   Office for National Statistics say that men aged 30 have a 12.5% (one in eight) chance of reaching 100, while women aged 30 have a 17.2% chance (one in six).

claims.text: Poverty has skyrocketed.

claimReview.title: Poverty hasn’t skyrocketed in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. A report from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation said that overall poverty rates have remained at about 22% over the last 15 years. However, some groups have seen increased rates of poverty, including children and pensioners.

claims.text: More people from deprived backgrounds are going to university than ever before.

claimReview.title: Social mobility and universities - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. In 2016 the proportion of 18 year-olds living in the most disadvantaged areas going to university was the highest on record for England, Scotland and Wales. It’s the second highest level it has ever been in Northern Ireland.

claims.text: Dental X-rays don’t work as a means of finding out a person’s age.

claimReview.title: Asylum seekers and dental age tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The British Dental Association describes them as “ineffective”, and there’s a large margin for error. The Home Office does accept voluntary tooth X-rays as evidence of age in an asylum application.

claims.text: A petition on change.org called for the White Cliffs of Dover to be renamed the Black Lives Matter Cliffs of Dover.

claimReview.title: This was a real petition calling for the White Cliffs of Dover to be renamed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was a real petition, which has been taken down from the site for breaching its community standards. It doesn’t seem to be connected to the official Black Lives Matter group in the UK.

claims.text: Profit margins of the big six energy companies hit their highest ever level.

claimReview.title: Energy companies profits at their highest level ever? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct if you look at the average. It was 4.5% in 2016, up from 1% in 2009 when these figures were first published. Looking at individual companies there is a lot of variation though.

claims.text: That change to mesh sizes has reduced fishermen’s income by 40%.

claimReview.title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is based on an unsourced quote reported by a Cornish news website. We don’t know how or if income has been affected yet as the regulation only changed on 1 July 2019.

claims.text: A picture showing people unwell on the streets of India shows the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

claimReview.title: New York Post’s use of old India gas leak picture causes confusion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This image was used in an article written by the New York Post about the Covid-19 pandemic. But it actually comes from a video taken in 2020 after a gas leak in Visakhapatnam, India.

claims.text: A vaccine for the coronavirus was being trialled in January 2020 days before the outbreak.

claimReview.title: The virus in this clinical study is not the coronavirus seen in China in 2019/2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The trial referenced was for a different type of coronavirus—Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS).

claims.text: Police engagement with communities isn’t happening.

claimReview.title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s evidence from the police watchdog that the capacity for crime prevention work has been declining but also evidence that it improved last year. The number of PCSOs decreased by 40% between March 2010 and March 2017.

claims.text: Just 10% of children’s books in the UK in 2019 had at least one character from a Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic background.

claimReview.title: A survey of diversity in children’s books is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure comes from flawed research and is not reliable. It’s also important to consider that many books in the survey did not have human characters.

claims.text: Labour's Shadow Cabinet is the most diverse in the British parliament's history.

claimReview.title: Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinets have been the most diverse ever - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. Currently 45% of the shadow cabinet are women and 13% are non-white. The highest-ever representation of women and ethnic minorities ever have been in previous shadow cabinets under Jeremy Corbyn.

claims.text: Jeremy Corbyn will cost every British worker £2,400 per year.

claimReview.title: Another flawed “cost of Corbyn” figure from the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is largely meaningless as the calculations and assumptions behind it have a number of flaws.

claims.text: Google has removed Churchill.

claimReview.title: Churchill’s photograph has not been removed from Google - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Churchill’s photograph did temporarily disappear from one part of Google’s search results last year. It was restored on 14 June 2020.

claims.text: A contract from the UK government says the MHRA is seeking an AI software tool to process the expected high volume of Covid-19 vaccine adverse drugs reactions to ensure no details from the adverse drugs reactions’ text are missed.

claimReview.title: The government plans to monitor potential adverse reactions to a Covid-19 vaccine, but that doesn’t mean it won’t be safe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, but monitoring any adverse reactions is a standard part of monitoring an approved drug or vaccine. Reported adverse reactions are not necessarily the same as side effects, and may have no connection to the vaccine.

claims.text: After leaving the EU, we will take back control of roughly £350 million per week.

claimReview.title: £350 million EU claim "a clear misuse of official statistics" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong, it’s more like £250 million a week. In any case the impact on the economy from changes to trade after leaving the EU is likely to be far bigger than savings from the UK’s membership fee.

claims.text: The WTO spends £0.15 billion per year on overhead costs.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the WTO’s total budget for 2019.

claims.text: Two siblings won the right to marry in the US.

claimReview.title: A brother and sister did not win the right to marry in the United States - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This did not happen. The story originally came from a satire website using pictures of a British couple who won the right to have a civil partnership instead of a marriage.

claims.text: For every £1 spent on legal aid, the state saves £6.

claimReview.title: How much money does legal aid save the country? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim has evolved down a chain of several different pieces of research and should be treated with caution. Academics say that we need more research about the savings that spending on legal aid can bring.

claims.text: The mRNA Covid-19 vaccines have not been tested on animals.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Both the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have been tested on animals.

claims.text: We do not know where Covid-19 places among causes of death because the data is not published.

claimReview.title: It's not true that data on causes of death isn't published - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The data is published monthly by the Office for National Statistics.

claims.text: If the new coronavirus gets into your mouth, drinking water or other liquids will wash them down through the oesophagus. Once they’re in the stomach, the acid will kill the virus. If you don't drink enough water more regularly, the virus can enter your windpipes and into the lungs.

claimReview.title: Holding your breath is not an indicator of whether you have the new coronavirus, and drinking water doesn’t protect against it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Drinking water does not prevent an infection and there have been cases where the virus has survived in the stomach and affected people’s intestines.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Drinking water does not prevent an infection.

claims.text: The UK has taken in only 216 Syrian refugees.
claims.claimant: George Eaton, New Statesman Political Editor

claimReview.title: Has the UK only taken in 216 Syrian refugees? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has taken in around 5,000 Syrian refugees. The 216 figure refers to an additional number resettled from around Syria under one particular scheme.

claims.text: Rigevidon is a cheap pill to prescribe.

claimReview.title: What are the possible side effects of the contraceptive pill Rigevidon? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is one of the cheaper combined contraceptive pills the NHS prescribes in England, at around £8 a year. In contrast, one of the most expensive pills costs around £63 a year.

claims.text: 49% think Theresa May should stand down.

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's of adults in Great Britain voting 'Leave' in the 2016 referendum, according to one survey. Among all adults in Great Britain, it's 42%.

claims.text: EU law overrules UK law. This stops the British public from being able to vote out the politicians who make our laws. EU judges have already overruled British laws on issues like counter-terrorism powers, immigration, VAT, and prisoner voting.

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: EU law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU law does override UK law. The EU court has made rulings to that effect on some, but not all, of these issues.

claims.text: Thousands of women are leaving the island of Ireland to have an abortion in Britain.

claimReview.title: How many women leave Northern Ireland to have an abortion in Britain? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Around 4,000 women living in Ireland and Northern Ireland came to England and Wales for an abortion in 2016. Seven women not resident in Scotland received an abortion in 2016, but we don’t know where they were from.

claims.text: Approximately 7% of men experienced domestic abuse in the year ending March 2020.

claimReview.title: About 3.6% of men have recently experienced domestic abuse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. The true figure was 3.6%.

claims.text: A 2018 OECD report on social mobility showed from 1997 to 2010 found the UK had the largest fall of any nation in immobility and biggest rise in social mobility.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are various measures in the OECD report. Looking at one of them, this is correct: the likelihood of someone still being in the poorest 20% of people in the UK after four years fell from 56% in the early 1990s to 45% in the early 2010s.

claims.text: A flyer recommending the Hollie Guard app is genuine.

claimReview.title: Police have recommended the Hollie Guard app - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Hollie Guard app is a genuine personal security app and has been recommended by police forces.

claims.text: Vaccinated people are dying from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Vaccines reduce the risk of death but don’t eliminate it altogether - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Covid-19 vaccines are very effective. But no vaccine is 100% effective and therefore there will be breakthrough cases.

claims.text: Period poverty has forced more than a quarter of females to miss work or school.

claimReview.title: Period poverty: how widespread is it? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Of those responding to the survey the figure seems to be closer to one in ten, but it’s unclear and we’ve asked for more information. The survey also wasn’t designed to be representative so it can’t tell us about the wider population.

claims.text: Care workers in the UK get a badge they have to buy.

claimReview.title: Many French care workers will get a tax-free bonus of up to £1,340 for working during the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The CARE badge was available to purchase in a minimum order of 100, and was supposed to be passed on to carers for free. The profits went to care-related causes. It’s unclear whether the badges can still be purchased.

claims.text: The big banks and multinationals might be lobbying to keep us in the EU, but small and medium-sized businesses feel differently

claimReview.title: Vote Leave "facts" leaflet: business opinion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There aren’t any representative surveys of business opinion generally that we’re aware of, but there is evidence that smaller businesses are more divided on the EU than larger businesses.

claims.text: The robbery rate shot up by 10% in a year - more than any of 12 other nations examined by the Home Office

claimReview.title: Robbery: Is the UK a “world leader”? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. The number of recorded robberies in England and Wales increased by 10% and the robbery rate by 9% between 2015 and 2016. That’s more than in any of the other 12 countries examined by Home Office analysis.

claims.text: Based on ONS data, immigration has put English house prices up by 20% over the last 25 years.

claimReview.title: Have house prices risen because of immigrants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s impossible to say for definite. Government analysis suggests immigration has pushed English house prices up by 20% but says it’s not meant to be a complete answer, and should be used with caution. There is no consensus across other research.

claims.text: The UK will be paying the Brexit divorce bill until 2064.

claimReview.title: Our Brexit divorce bill will probably be paid off by 2064 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The majority of these payments will be made by 2021.

claims.text: NHS spending is going to increase by 3.4% a year.

claimReview.title: The latest plans for NHS England spending outstrip both main parties’ manifesto pledges - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to the government’s latest plans to 2023/24 for the NHS in England. This is in real terms, taking inflation into account.

claims.text: A letter to The Times newspaper was signed by a Mr Martin Spiro. Records from the General Medical Council show that the only Martin Spiro registered died five years ago.

claimReview.title: Two doctors with same name cause Times letter confusion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are two Martin Spiros, as confirmed by the General Medical Council. One of them voluntarily removed themselves from the Council’s register in 1993. Their record was subsequently not uploaded when the register was digitised in 2005.

claims.text: 97% of schools who submitted data had children coming back in early June.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson overstates number of schools with returning students - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. 97% of schools who submitted data were open, but only about two thirds of them had children coming back.

claims.text: Less than 10% of engineers in the UK are female.

claimReview.title: 11% of UK engineers are women - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Official statistics show that in the second quarter of 2017 11% of engineers were women.

claims.text: The UK spends more than the average rich country on health services.

claimReview.title: Global health spending: how does the UK compare? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct if you compare the proportion of GDP health spending made up in the UK in 2014 with the OECD. This includes private spending and social care which aren’t always included in figures on health spending in the UK.

claims.text: UK fishing crews will see the price of fuel for their boats more than quadruple due to the removal of EU subsidies post-Brexit.

claimReview.title: Brexit hasn’t quadrupled the cost of fuel for fishing boats - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This has not come to pass. HMRC’s guidance on fuel duty for fishers has remained materially the same pre and post-Brexit.

claims.text: Police catch 11 year-olds being used to sell drugs.

claimReview.title: Cannabis kids: are more under-18s being prosecuted for supplying the drug? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve not seen the evidence for this, though other data on the number of young people prosecuted for drug offences suggests it’s possible.

claims.text: A whistleblower has described how Pfizer made up results about injuries and deaths during vaccine trials. This has been published in the British Medical Journal.

claimReview.title: Radio 4 programme featured Covid vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While it is true that the BMJ did publish an article about concerns raised by a whistleblower who was previously employed by a company running some of Pfizer’s Covid-19 trials, it did not include allegations that the company had made up results about deaths.

claims.text: The average length of time for staying in hospital has virtually halved since the year 2000.

claimReview.title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It hasn’t quite halved but it has fallen. The average length of stay overnight was eight days in 2000 and is about five days now.

claims.text: A UK government document is circulating promoting mandatory Covid-19 vaccination.

claimReview.title: The government is not proposing to make a Covid-19 vaccine mandatory - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Evidence submitted to a parliamentary committee by four academics argues that the government may want to consider making a Covid-19 vaccine mandatory. This is not being proposed by the government.

claims.text: McDonald’s is reopening in the UK from Monday 6 April.

claimReview.title: McDonald’s is not reopening on 6 April in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. McDonald’s has said its restaurants in the UK will remain closed.

claims.text: HMRC employs just 522 staff to tackle tens of billions of tax evasion by the super-rich.

claimReview.title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It employed around 500 staff in March 2017 to work with taxpayers with assets over £10m, and another 500 staff to investigate the tax affairs of taxpayers with assets over £1 million, or an income over £150,000 a year. In 2016, they were estimated to account for around £2bn in lost tax revenue.

claims.text: In the last eight years, the “Building schools for the future” project has been stopped.

claimReview.title: Sure Start, school building and tuition fees: the Conservative and Coalition record - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It was stopped in 2010 and replaced with a new scheme in 2011. The old scheme aimed to rebuild and refurbish all secondary schools in England. The new scheme is targeted at “school buildings in the worst condition across the country”.

claims.text: 51% of coronavirus deaths in Belgium are in care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct up to May.This was reported by the ECDC.

claims.text: University applications have fallen by 4%.

claimReview.title: Have university applicant numbers fallen in 2017? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of applicants through UCAS to UK higher education institutions has gone down by 4% compared to last year.

claims.text: There is pork in Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Neither the Pfizer, AstraZeneca, nor the Moderna vaccines contain any animal products.

claims.text: Three quarters of the Labour Party passed a vote of no confidence in Jeremy Corbyn as leader in 2016.

claimReview.title: Labour party confidence in Jeremy Corbyn - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Three quarters of Labour MPs did so. In the leadership challenge that followed Mr Corbyn won 61.8% of the vote (59% among Labour Party members).

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine might kill children who receive it.

claimReview.title: Children are more likely to die from Covid than vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not impossible, but the risk appears to be extremely small. We can find no evidence of a child dying as a result of a Covid-19 vaccine in the UK.

claims.text: The NHS spends £100 million on translators for 128 languages in five years.

claimReview.title: There isn’t good data on how much the NHS spends on translators - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A 2012 report based on FOIs found that NHS trusts (that responded) spent £23.3m on translation services in 2010/11. We don’t have recent or complete figures for how much the NHS has spent on translators because no one collects that information. We can’t find a reliable source for the 128 languages figure.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines contain graphene oxide.

claimReview.title: There is no graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA has told us that none of the Covid-19 vaccines in current use contain graphene oxide.

claims.text: The Nazis were socialists.

claimReview.title: The Nazis were not socialists - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While their name did include the word “socialist”, their policies and treatment of left-wing opponents show they were not socialists in any meaningful sense.

claims.text: 40% of grassroots music venues in London have shut in the past eight years.

claimReview.title: No longer partying all night - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A report for the Mayor of London found 35% fewer venues in 2015 than 2007. City Hall says it’s now 40%.

claims.text: Boris Johnson said this quote about Liverpudlians “seeing themselves whenever possible as victims”.

claimReview.title: Did Boris Johnson write this quote about Liverpudlians and Hillsborough? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Johnson was editor of that publication, but a different journalist has claimed responsibility for writing it.

claims.text: The so-called “Nigerian variant” of Covid-19 is twice as deadly as the dominant “Kent variant”.

claimReview.title: We don’t know if the ‘Nigerian variant’ is more deadly - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This reflects the number of deaths among the small number of cases from the “Nigerian variant” detected so far. At the time of writing there is not enough data to know whether this variant is more deadly or not.

claims.text: Cherie Blair is representing her.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence Shamima Begum has been flown back to the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: Under Labour, UK steel production and employment in the industry halved.

claimReview.title: Did UK steel production halve under Labour? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Yes, if you compare 1997 to 2010, when the economy was in a slump. Production has been, broadly, in decline for decades.

claims.text: 500 churches in London have closed.

claimReview.title: Don’t trust claims about the change in the number of churches and mosques in London - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from an estimate for the number of churches converted into homes between 2001 and 2006. Estimates indicate there was probably a net increase of around 800 church congregations between 2005 and 2015 in London.

claims.text: Serco received £37 billion of government money in contracts for NHS Test and Trace.

claimReview.title: The government did not give £37 billion to Serco - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The total value of contracts signed with Serco under the Test and Trace programme by the end of March 2021 was about £623 million. £37 billion was the total budget for the whole programme, not all of which was spent.

claims.text: 1.1 million Brexit postal ballots are missing or rejected.

claimReview.title: No postal votes from the EU referendum are recorded as “missing” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No votes from the referendum are recorded as “missing”. Close to one million postal ballots weren’t returned, which can be due to a variety of reasons. An additional 170,000 or so were returned on time but not counted—mostly due to problems with identifying the voter.

claims.text: There’s graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines which reassembles in the body and becomes a “supercomputer” or “superconductor”.

claimReview.title: mRNA vaccines aren’t gene editing and don’t alter your DNA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no graphene oxide in the Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: Masks do nothing.

claimReview.title: No evidence masks limit oxygen for children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Studies have shown that mask wearing can reduce the viral dose of Covid-19 someone might receive and can protect others if worn by someone with the virus.

claims.text: The Pirbright Institute has the main patent for coronavirus, which was granted by Serco.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Pirbright Institute’s coronavirus patent is not related to the virus causing the current outbreak, and we can find no evidence that it was granted by Serco.

claims.text: More people are getting advance payments on Universal Credit.

claimReview.title: Are more people being paid an advance on their Universal Credit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Advances made on the first payment of new Universal Credit claims increased from 30% of claims in May 2016 to 52% in July 2017.

claims.text: Nine of the ten most deprived council areas in this country have seen cuts that are almost three times the average of any other council.

claimReview.title: Have the most deprived councils seen the biggest reductions in funding? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures used in this analysis aren’t comparable over time in this way. But analysis by the National Audit Office shows that these ten councils have all had a greater proportion of their funding reduced than the percentage across all councils put together.

claims.text: £30 billion is lost to tax fraud.

claimReview.title: There’s no easy way to compare benefit and tax fraud. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2017/18 HMRC estimated the ‘tax gap’ (money that should have been collected in taxes but wasn’t) at around £35 billion per year. Not all of this is due to fraud.

claims.text: Daily Covid-19 deaths dropped to “just” seven on Saturday 10 April 2021.

claimReview.title: The weekend Covid-19 death figures need more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the number of deaths reported on Saturday, but may not reflect the actual number of people who died of Covid-19 that day due to lags in reporting at the weekend.

claims.text: The IFS said the new benefit cap “almost exclusively affects families with large numbers of children or very high rents or both.”

claimReview.title: The IFS and the benefit cap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The IFS said this about the benefit cap as it was introduced in 2015. It has said the new, lower cap will be less concentrated on households with lots of children and affect more people outside London where rents are lower.

claims.text: 800,000 people pay a higher tax rate than someone who earns £1m.

claimReview.title: Do you pay a higher tax rate than a millionaire? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some people do pay higher tax rates than those earning £1m, but only when their income rises between certain amounts. The estimate of 800,000 people affected only applies to relatively high earners, but marginal tax rates affect low earners too.

claims.text: Covid-19 can’t kill children.

claimReview.title: Children are more likely to die from Covid than vaccination - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. In England alone, 25 children had died as a result of a Covid-19 infection up to the end of February 2021.

claims.text: The government knew Covid-19 was no more dangerous than flu before lockdown and flu and Covid-19 are the same thing

claimReview.title: Trafalgar Square “Freedom Rally” speech littered with false claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a misunderstanding of the declassification of Covid-19 from a government list of high consequence infectious diseases. It does not mean Covid-19 is not dangerous. Covid-19 is not the same as flu.

claims.text: Scotland raises £25 billion a year in income tax.

claimReview.title: Scottish taxes don’t subsidise English spending - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. It raised £13 billion from income tax in 2020/21.

claims.text: The Treasury has backtracked on its stated original aim about Help to Buy ISAs

claimReview.title: Help to Buy ISAs: do they work and were they mis-sold? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t correct. The scheme was always intended to support the part of a house purchase that’s funded by the buyer, commonly known as a ‘deposit’ or ‘mortgage deposit’. The Treasury never said that it was meant to help with the initial exchange deposit that’s put down when contracts are exchanged.

claims.text: The Conservatives are planning to pass a Bill setting the threshold at which a referendum could pass. This would be 55% turnout, 60% in favour and two thirds of MPs agreeing to the referendum in the first place.

claimReview.title: A Bill to change referendum rules came from one Lord, not the government - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Such a Bill has been proposed, but not by the Conservative party officially or by the government. It was put forward as a Private Members’ Bill by a Conservative member of the House of Lords and has not yet been debated.

claims.text: Four million children live below the poverty line.

claimReview.title: Are four million children living in poverty? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for relative poverty in the UK, measured after housing costs in 2015/16. It’s a smaller number using other measures of poverty.

claims.text: One in four hospital beds will be occupied by diabetics by 2030.

claimReview.title: Express front page headline on diabetes is based on flawed research - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s difficult to know how many hospital beds will be occupied by diabetics in 2030, but the way in which this estimate was calculated is seriously flawed.

claims.text: Households are £900 worse off due to increased energy bills since 2010.

claimReview.title: Energy bills under the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's adding up the increase in average electricity and gas bills in each of the six years from 2010 to 2016 (adjusting for inflation) if energy use stayed the same over this time. It hasn't. The Committee on Climate Change has said that household bills in 2016 were lower than they were in 2008, due to reductions in energy use.

claims.text: The Conservative government is investing an extra £10 billion in the NHS, more than its leaders asked for.

claimReview.title: Is the government’s £10bn NHS funding commitment more than NHS leaders asked for? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s £10 billion commitment isn’t all of what NHS leaders asked for, and isn’t as generous as it sounds.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets free stationery.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim expenses for office stationery.

claims.text: Pepsi uses a flavouring made of aborted human foetal cells.

claimReview.title: Pepsi doesn’t use a flavouring made from aborted foetal cells - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The cells in question are not flavourings themselves but used in flavouring development. Regardless, Pepsi say their flavourings are not developed using these cells.

claims.text: A video shows a police officer being egged by children in Kent.

claimReview.title: Video of police officer egged by children is a prank - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not an assault of a real police officer. Kent police have no record of an assault. The video was shared by a prank account.

claims.text: A picture shows Remain supporters burning a Union Flag.

claimReview.title: This picture of Remain supporters burning a Union Flag is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been edited to add the burning flag.

claims.text: The EU has stopped the UK from having free ports.

claimReview.title: What’s a free port, and does the EU have them? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Free ports exist within the EU. The UK had free ports until 2012. However, EU law means free ports exist in a more limited form than elsewhere in the world.

claims.text: Photographs show many electric cars that were scrapped because their batteries were too expensive to replace.

claimReview.title: These cars were not abandoned because their batteries failed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. These cars were scrapped because they were part of the fleet of a French business that stopped trading.

claims.text: Real wages are falling.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner wrong on wage growth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Over the past few months, real wages are largely stable.

claims.text: The BBC lost £150 million a year because the licence fee didn’t cover iPlayer until 1 September 2016.

claimReview.title: The £150 million BBC licence fee loophole? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The BBC has said that it will make £150 million less in 2016/17 from licence fees than it had expected in 2011, which it attributes to fewer people owning TVs and more people watching programmes online. The BBC doesn’t publish these forecasts so nobody can assess the reliability of this claim.

claims.text: Any vaccine that needs to be stored and shipped at -80 degrees isn’t a vaccine. It’s a transfection agent, kept alive so it can infect your cells and transfer genetic material.

claimReview.title: The Pfizer Covid-19 candidate vaccine is not too cold to be called a vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One candidate RNA vaccine does have to be stored at close to this temperature. It is still a vaccine though, and other vaccines, such as the Ebola vaccine also had to be this cold. This RNA vaccine is in no way alive, although it does contain genetic material that can be read by human cells.

claims.text: Social housing has been decreasing over the last 30 years and has now been placed into the private rental market.

claimReview.title: Social housing stock has fallen over the last 30 years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The British social housing sector dramatically decreased between the early 1980s and the early 2010s. This was largely down to the introduction of Right to Buy and a drop in social house building.

claims.text: In England, contact tracing costs £1700 per head.

claimReview.title: Labour MP contact tracing claim at PMQs out by factor of ten - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a calculation which overestimates the cost by a factor of 10. £12 billion has been allocated to testing and tracing by the UK government, but this is not just for England and so cannot be compared to the costs specific to Wales.

claims.text: Leaving the EU would or could cut net migration by 100,000

claimReview.title: Would net migration fall by 100,000 if the UK left the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Nobody knows. It’s an unofficial “ball park figure” for one possible exit scenario and the prediction depends on assumptions which might or might not come true.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine is a trial drug.

claimReview.title: This Morning guest makes misleading claims on vaccine efficacy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research on the ongoing efficacy and safety of the vaccines will continue but data on key safety and efficacy aspects has been published and peer reviewed.

claims.text: Over 90% of the women who are pregnant and have Covid-19 vaccines in early pregnancy experience a miscarriage in the first 12 weeks.

claimReview.title: Miscarriage does not occur in 90% of vaccinated pregnant women - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t true. The MHRA says there is no sign to suggest the vaccines are causing miscarriages, and the NHS says there is no need to avoid getting pregnant after having the vaccines.

claims.text: 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped from making the crossing to the UK in the past year.

claimReview.title: We don't know that 100,000 illegal migrants have been stopped at the border - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data doesn't allow us to say this. This is an unofficial projection based on Home Office data and depends upon the assumption that foiled attempts to cross the border have continued at the same rate as in April to July this year for the rest of the year.

claims.text: Antibodies from a previous Covid-19 infection are probably equivalent to someone who has been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Doctor who challenged Sajid Javid made misleading claims about vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although natural immunity acquired through  Covid-19 infection does protect against subsequent infection, evidence shows that also being vaccinated can increase this protection dramatically. Vaccines also lower the risk of serious illness caused by an infection.

claims.text: 51% of people working for the NHS aren’t clinically qualified.

claimReview.title: Is half of the NHS not clinically qualified? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 51% of people working for the NHS are clinically qualified. Looking at it another way, that’s 53% of full-time equivalents.

claims.text: Recently introduced laws mean if you are told to self-isolate and do not, you will get a £1,000 pound fine administered by Serco.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true a law was recently introduced to fine those breaking isolation orders from Test and Trace. However, Serco does not administer these fines.

claims.text: A video shows protesters in London chanting “We’re racist and that’s the way we like it”.

claimReview.title: This video of protesters in London chanting “We’re racist and that’s the way we like it” is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Audio from a clip of racist Chelsea fans in Paris in 2015 has been added onto the video of the protests at the weekend.

claims.text: Last year, the Conservatives delivered the highest number of homes for almost 30 years.

claimReview.title: The housing supply has increased by a million in the past five years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Last year saw the biggest increase in the housing supply for thirty years.

claims.text: Theresa May negotiated the UK out of 100 EU justice and home affairs laws.

claimReview.title: Theresa May's EU negotiating experience - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is about right; David Cameron notified the EU of the decision to opt out of the laws, and Theresa May was involved in negotiations to opt back into 35 of them. But the right to opt out of the laws in the first place was negotiated by a previous government.

claims.text: Rashes are a symptom of the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: A rash is now listed as a possible symptom of the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A rash was not initially listed as a symptom of the new coronavirus. The World Health Organisation have now said it is a less common symptom.

claims.text: Recent UK and international data suggests that children are in fact as likely as adults to become infected and carry the virus.

claimReview.title: Claim by Independent SAGE about Covid-19 infections in children is based on unclear evidence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen reliable and consistent evidence that backs up this claim. Reviews of the literature to date suggest that children are less likely to become infected and carry the virus. More evidence from antibody studies is needed to quantify the exact transmission risk from children.

claims.text: The number of Covid hospitalisations is 0.5% of the level of cases.

claimReview.title: Allison Pearson tweets misleading stats about Covid hospital patients - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The statistics used to make this claim compare positive test results when tests were first taken versus current hospitalisation figures. Because of the time it may take for symptoms to develop before hospitalisation, this is a flawed calculation.

claims.text: The number of British children who need foster care has risen by 44% during the pandemic, children’s charity Barnardo’s has warned.

claimReview.title: Data from Barnardo’s doesn’t show the number of children needing foster care has grown 44% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Barnardo’s has seen a 44% rise in the number of referrals to its fostering services from councils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. 

But that doesn’t mean the number of children needing foster care has risen by 44%.

claims.text: The Conservatives’ poll lead has fallen following recent policy announcements on tax and spending.

claimReview.title: Little evidence the Conservatives’ poll lead is narrowing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s little evidence for this: this is comparing polls from two different companies which use different polling methods. Recent polls have generally shown Conservative leads approaching or exceeding 20 percentage points.

claims.text: The lockdown began on 16 March 2020, when Matt Hancock told the House of Commons that all unnecessary social contact should cease.

claimReview.title: When did lockdown begin in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Hancock did say this, but it was not until 23 March 2020 that Boris Johnson told the country that people ‘must’ stay at home and certain businesses must close. Government ministers have previously described this second date as the start of lockdown. There is no official government definition of ‘lockdown’.

claims.text: Sir Patrick Vallance said 60% of people currently in hospital with Covid-19 were double vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Double vaccinated people do not make up 60% of Covid-19 hospitalisations - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is correct that he said this during a government briefing, but later corrected his remarks on Twitter. He meant to say 60% of hospitalisations from Covid-19 are currently from unvaccinated people.

claims.text: The public thinks disruption caused by protests is “completely unacceptable” by a ratio of five to one.

claimReview.title: The public dislikes disruptive protests—but less than the Telegraph says - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a misleading way to read the data. The balance is more like three to one against “serious disruption”, and less strongly against “minor inconvenience”.

claims.text: The risk of dying after a Covid vaccination is 1 in 31,000.

claimReview.title: The risk of dying from a Covid vaccine is lower than 1 in 31,000 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. It is unclear where this figure comes from, but it is far too high. In the UK, around 50 deaths have been possibly linked to one of the vaccines, an incidence of 1 in 470,000.

claims.text: Lionel Messi signing with Paris Saint-Germain doubled the club’s Instagram followers from 19.8 million to 40.2 million in 24 hours.

claimReview.title: Messi didn’t double PSG’s Instagram followers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It didn’t. After his signing was announced, the club’s Instagram followers increased by about 3 million.

claims.text: Almost 300 people under 18 were flagged up last year under the Prevent Strategy because of concerns about the far right.

claimReview.title: Far right extremism: a growing problem? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct according to figures from the National Police Chiefs' Council. 1 in 7 under-18s referred were on far-right grounds.

claims.text: 24,641 die of heart disease every day.

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an underestimate for all cardiovascular disease deaths, but close to the daily figure of those who die from coronary heart disease specifically.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022 we become an EU state.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The treaty came into force in 2009, nothing is due to change in 2022. There are no developed plans for the creation of a single EU state.

claims.text: Donald Tusk’s grandfather was a German SS officer.

claimReview.title: Donald Tusk’s grandfather was not in the SS - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. His grandfather was Polish and was arrested by the Nazis in 1939. He was made a forced labourer, then imprisoned, and was then conscripted into the armed forces of Nazi Germany in 1944.

claims.text: There are 2 million illegal immigrants in the UK.

claimReview.title: There almost certainly aren’t as many as two million unauthorised immigrants in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is much higher than even the upper end of an estimate of how many people were in the UK in 2017 without a permit to be there.

claims.text: A&E four hour targets have been missed more than 10 million times since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Between 2010/11 and 2017/18, around 12 million A&E attendances in England took over four hours from arrival to admission, transfer or discharge.

claims.text: The UK is doing more Covid-19 tests than virtually any country in Europe.

claimReview.title: We still don’t know if the UK does the most Covid-19 tests in Europe - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK appears to be testing fewer people than in Russia. But there isn’t enough data on this to determine for sure where the UK places, and the UK’s data isn’t particularly comparable with other countries.

claims.text: Vaccines cause ME/CFS.

claimReview.title: There are no mouse brains in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Getting a vaccine may exacerbate ME/CFS symptoms in people who already have these illnesses, but there is no data from clinical trials on this.

claims.text: The UK oil and gas industry supports an estimated 375,000 jobs.

claimReview.title: How many jobs are supported by the UK's oil and gas industry? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 375,000 is the latest estimate of the total employment supported by the industry according to the industry itself.

claims.text: Life expectancy is going down.

claimReview.title: Living long and prospering? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Life expectancy isn’t falling overall, but its rate of increase has slowed down in recent years. In some local areas life expectancy has decreased in the last few years, although we can’t be sure all these local estimates are showing genuine changes.

claims.text: We already turn around 90% of tests within 48 hours.

claimReview.title: New data reveals PM’s testing speeds claims as wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Test times covering early June when the claim was made are only available for around half of antigen tests. That means we can’t say whether or not this is accurate.

claims.text: The number of UK part-time workers unable to find full-time work increased from an average of 680,000 under the last Labour government to 1.3m under Conservative-led governments.

claimReview.title: Are more people unable to get full-time work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s broadly correct, but the number of people overall who want more work is close to the lowest it has been in the last 25 years.

claims.text: NHS hospitals will require all women to show their passports before they receive maternity services.

claimReview.title: Passports for the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to one hospital in London rather than all hospitals in England and Wales. It’s in line with NHS guidelines on identifying foreign patients who might be required to pay for their treatment. The government is looking into whether identification checks could be rolled out more widely.

claims.text: According to the Lisbon Treaty, in 2022, there will be no more monarch.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about the EU aren’t true and have nothing to do with the Lisbon Treaty - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. There are no plans for the EU to remove the heads of state of its members.

claims.text: If the rate of infection in late June continues for nine months, the UK will experience 27,000 more deaths from Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Independent SAGE’s estimated death rate is too high - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is too high. This estimate was calculated using data on when deaths were reported, not when they happened. It also suggests an unrealistically high death rate, given the number of infections at the time.

claims.text: The country’s most senior judge has said that women shouldn’t be able to wear veils in criminal trials.

claimReview.title: Lord Neuberger on veils in court - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The head of the Supreme Court said that witnesses whose evidence is being challenged should have to remove a veil covering their face.

claims.text: People pay for tariffs set by the EU every time they shop—and the government collects the money and sends it to Brussels.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. A proportion of this money is then spent in the UK on EU-funded projects, though less than most other EU countries.

claims.text: The average worker is over £1,000 worse off today than they were in 2010.

claimReview.title: Angela Rayner wrong on wage growth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure compares wages for full-time employees between 2010 and 2020, not “today”. Other wage statistics show wages for all employees in July 2021 were worth about £1,480 more than in 2010 in real terms.

claims.text: Theresa May has broken a pledge to make shareholder votes on corporate pay binding.

claimReview.title: Executive pay: power to the shareholders? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proposals have been watered-down, so the pledges haven’t been met. The current proposals don’t provide for binding votes but do force more transparency on companies who have shareholder opposition.

claims.text: The UK is performing 240,000 Covid-19 tests a day.

claimReview.title: Lots of people are getting confused over testing figures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is close to both the highest figure for daily tests performed and current theoretical lab capacity. The number actually performed on most days in the latest data is slightly lower.

claims.text: The UK no longer has an NHS according to the WHO’s definition.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: Does the World Health Organisation think the UK no longer has an NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There has been privatisation of services according to the WHO’s definition, because more NHS care is run by private sector companies. But the WHO didn’t say this means there’s no longer an NHS.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines are not approved for use.

claimReview.title: Post makes misleading claims about Covid vaccines and animal trials - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. All three of the vaccines currently in use in the UK (Pfizer, AstraZeneca and Moderna) have been authorised for use. A fourth, Janssen has been authorised, but is not yet in use.

claims.text: The deaths of 131 care workers have involved Covid-19.

claimReview.title: We don’t know exactly how many NHS workers have died from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on data collected on deaths in England and Wales up to 20 April.

claims.text: Coronavirus pneumonia is a dry cough with no runny nose.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
