claimReview.textualRating: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some Covid-19 patients do get pneumonia, and one of the symptoms is a dry cough. A runny nose doesn’t rule out Covid-19.

claims.text: The number of police officers has dropped by 20,000 since 2010.

claimReview.title: Police officer numbers have fallen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of police officers has dropped by 19,000 since 2010.

claims.text: Every person who shares or comments on a Facebook post will receive a free Morrisons food box and voucher, collectively worth £50.

claimReview.title: ‘Free Morrisons food box’ offer is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Morrisons have confirmed the post is a scam, and have warned people not to interact with the post.

claims.text: TfL is part of a pilot whereby staff required to self-isolate can instead take daily Covid-19 tests at work.

claimReview.title: TfL is part of self-isolation pilot scheme - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: People are abandoning pets due to fears of Covid-19 transmission.

claimReview.title: The RSPCA has said that they are worried people will abandon pets because the economic effects of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The RSPCA says that lockdown saw lower numbers of abandoned pets, but that they fear the economic effects of the pandemic will lead to a rise.

claims.text: The Taliban survived the last 18 months with no vaccines, social distancing, PCR testing, masks or business closures to then recapture an entire country with no mass deaths amongst their population during the pandemic.

claimReview.title: What we know about the Taliban and Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear if any Taliban members have been vaccinated, though it’s reported they were allowing vaccinations to take place before the August takeover in areas they controlled. Pictures exist of Taliban fighters wearing masks. There have been confirmed cases of Covid-19 in Afghanistan.

claims.text: Two Pfizer doses are 99.96% effective.

claimReview.title: Pfizer vaccine effective, though not as effective as newspapers suggest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Pfizer vaccine has an efficacy rate of over 90%. The 99.96% figure is not an efficacy rate but the proportion of people vaccinated in Israel who did not later test positive for the virus.

claims.text: Osimertinib (the lung cancer medication) has been licensed in the EU for use since 2016.

claimReview.title: Conflicting claims about ‘new’ cancer drug thanks to Brexit are both misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Osimertinib has been authorised for use in the EU since 2016, but for use in later stage lung cancers. A sub body of the EMA has recently recommended that the medication be authorised for earlier use, but this has not yet been approved by the European Commission.

claims.text: The Lisbon treaty calls for EU member nations to be part of the euro by 2020.

claimReview.title: The UK won’t have to adopt the Euro by 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect.  The treaty aims for the euro becoming the currency of all member states of the Union but it isn’t time limited and the UK has an explicit opt-out.

claims.text: Only a handful of MPs turned up to debate a pay rise for health and social care workers.

claimReview.title: Why did few MPs attend a debate on health worker pay? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This debate related to a petition, and these debates are generally sparsely attended.

claims.text: If we Vote Leave… We will trade with Europe without handing over permanent control to people we cannot vote out […] If we Vote Leave… We will control our own economy and trade

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on trade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ll still trade with Europe if we leave the EU. That trade will be controlled by, and may be affected by, any agreement we reach with the EU.

claims.text: These unlicensed vaccines will be administered by non-medical staff, such as your employer.

claimReview.title: Unlicensed vaccines are not untested - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is consulting the public on whether to change the rules around who can administer certain vaccines, which may include some people who don’t normally administer them, including some who aren’t registered healthcare professionals. It does not specifically mention employers.

claims.text: Voters don’t support a version of Brexit that will cost jobs.

claimReview.title: Employment or immigration: which matters more? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s polling evidence going both ways.

claims.text: After nine years of a Conservative government, crime is up 30%.

claimReview.title: Viral post about Conservatives’ record in government gets lots of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There’s no perfect measure of crime, but best estimates suggest it has fallen in England and Wales between 2009/10 and 2018/19, under coalition and Conservative governments.

claims.text: The UK share of the vote in the EU Council of Ministers is 8%, down from 17% when we joined.

claimReview.title: British influence in the EU Council of Ministers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It has declined, but a new system based on population makes the UK's vote worth 13%. A lot of Council decisions are made by consensus after negotiation, so vote share doesn't neatly capture the UK's influence.

claims.text: Photos of Boris Johnson receiving his Covid-19 booster vaccine do not show him being vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson did receive his third Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Johnson was vaccinated, as can be seen in a video tweeted by the prime minister. A blue cap at the end of the needle is part of the injection device, not a safety cap.

claims.text: Labour is pushing Theresa May for the UK to have access to the Single Market after Brexit.

claimReview.title: What is Labour’s policy on the customs union and single market? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour says it wants to be outside of the single market after Brexit, but has tabled amendments calling on the government to seek “full access to the internal market of the European Union”. Labour suggests the issue of free movement would have to be negotiated in this scenario. It’s hard to judge how feasible this would be as a negotiating position, but it seems to fall foul of the EU’s red lines.

claims.text: In September 2021 there was a three-week period when renewables produced between 2% and 3% of the country’s electricity.

claimReview.title: Nigel Farage understates renewable energy generation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. During the first three weeks of September, wind, solar and hydroelectricity accounted for their lowest share of total electricity generation during the month, but it was still between 10% and 19% on average, each day.

claims.text: About 1% of the population is infected with Covid-19 today.

claimReview.title: The number of people dying right now is not the same as in any other year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to the most recent data, this is about right.

claims.text: Apprenticeship funding is being cut by 30-50%

claimReview.title: Apprenticeship funding: going up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Funding rates for many types of apprenticeship will fall under new rules, set to be introduced in May. Some popular apprenticeship schemes for 16-18 year olds could receive between 30% and 50% less funding for each apprentice, depending on their circumstances. At the same time, the total amount of funding available for all apprenticeships will increase.

claims.text: In January there were one million people in hospital who couldn’t leave because they had nowhere to go.

claimReview.title: Are there one million people in hospital with nowhere else to go? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve asked for the source of this claim, but it seems to be incorrect. In January there were 7,100 people in hospital at the end of the month who were medically fit to leave but hadn’t been discharged. Across the whole month there were 197,000 delayed days when patients fit to leave weren’t discharged.

claims.text: NHS hospitals have been hit with a 21% rise in business rates.

claimReview.title: NHS and private hospitals: who pays business rates? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s what was projected when changes to business rates came in last year. A more up to date estimate puts the 2019/20 bill at around 24% higher than in 2016/17.

claims.text: Surprisingly few people have died of flu or pneumonia in 2020 so far.

claimReview.title: The number of deaths from flu and pneumonia is about what you would expect this year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 2020’s flu and pneumonia death figures are low, but this post makes the fall seem much more extreme than it is, by comparing this year with the worst on record.

claims.text: Labour left a £38 billion black hole in the defence budget.

claimReview.title: Did Labour leave a £38 billion black hole in defence spending? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Ministry of Defence says this, but this hasn’t been fully substantiated in the evidence it has published.

claims.text: Article 61 of Magna Carta allows for lawful dissent and rebellion. It also means that businesses don’t have to close under Covid-19 regulations.

claimReview.title: “Article 61” of Magna Carta doesn’t allow you to ignore Covid-19 regulations - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is all incorrect. Clause 61 of the 1215 Magna Carta set out rules for 25 specific barons. It did not allow the general population to rebel, and it was also removed from subsequent versions of the document.

claims.text: 95% of new workers are foreigners.

claimReview.title: Foreigners working in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. These employment figures don’t tell us the number of new workers, only the overall change in employment. The claim also defines “foreigners” as all people born outside the UK, including those who are UK citizens. About 450,000 more people in the UK were employed in July-September 2016 than had been the year before, and roughly half of the increase was due to an increase in the number of non-British citizens.

claims.text: The UK has a trade surplus with America.

claimReview.title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The UK’s trade surplus with the USA was around £34 billion in the year to June 2017.

claims.text: The Queen takes 15% of the crown estate profit each year - around £60m.

claimReview.title: How does the royal family make money? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Historically the Queen received a grant from the government based on 15% of the income from the Crown Estate, but this has gone up to 25% to pay for refurbishments to Buckingham Palace. In 2019/20 this will equate to about £82 million.

claims.text: A survey from Samaritans said one in four people had suicidal thoughts during lockdown.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A survey done between March and May 2020 found that 1 in 10 people had suicidal thoughts.

claims.text: Profit on the Crown Estate over the last 10 years is enough to pay for the renovation of Buckingham Palace six times over.

claimReview.title: Paying for Buckingham Palace - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s about right.

claims.text: The Mental Health Act will be used to section people who refuse to have the Covid-19 vaccine so they can be forced to have it.

claimReview.title: The government is not proposing to make a Covid-19 vaccine mandatory - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is not proposing this. Four legal and ethics academics wrote to the government arguing that this may theoretically be possible.

claims.text: A vaccine for coronavirus was made in 2001.

claimReview.title: An image of a dog vaccine for a different coronavirus has gone viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The vaccine pictured is one for dogs for canine coronavirus. It does not protect against Covid-19 and is not for humans.

claims.text: The eight week interval between vaccine doses is designed to coincide with the immune system’s “reproductive system”, so that the second dose can hit the immune system while it’s down.

claimReview.title: There is no HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is a gap between vaccine doses because this has been shown to be more effective at protecting against Covid-19. White blood cells have a range of different life spans.

claims.text: Half of people in rural areas and many small businesses can’t get a decent broadband connection.

claimReview.title: Rural properties are much less likely to have good broadband connections - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s fair according to Ofcom’s definition of a good broadband connection. It says just under half of rural properties (around 1.5 million) and many smaller businesses can’t access a good speed.

claims.text: A vaccinated pilot died mid-flight, causing an emergency landing.

claimReview.title: Vaccinated pilot did not die mid-flight - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This appears to be based on a widely debunked claim that a pilot working for Delta Airlines died during a flight. There is no evidence this happened.

claims.text: In World War Two, when Londoners were asked to black out their homes at night, none complained or objected.

claimReview.title: It’s incorrect to say there was no resistance to safety measures around the Blitz - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. There are recorded instances of numerous objections to blackout and Blitz safety measures.

claims.text: The number of deaths from diabetes is up 86%, from prostate cancer is up 53%, from Parkinson’s is up 79%, from breast cancer is up 47% and from bowel cancer is up 46%.

claimReview.title: Non-Covid deaths in private homes are up, but have decreased elsewhere - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to the number of deaths in private homes registered in England between March and September this year compared to the five-year average. Across all locations, the numbers of deaths from some of these diseases are in line with historic averages.

claims.text: The government's plan to make vaccines a requirement for employment within the NHS cannot be enforced unless it is already written into the contract that you must take part in medical trials and accept unlicensed drugs.

claimReview.title: Vaccine requirement law for NHS staff in England could be enforced regardless of contracts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. If the new rule becomes law, employers would be required to enforce it, regardless of pre-existing contracts.

claims.text: The UK is already in the largest recession for 300 years.

claimReview.title: It’s not right that you’re more likely to drown than die of Covid-19 if you’re under 60 with no health problems - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Bank of England has suggested this could be correct.

claims.text: The number of patients waiting more than 12 hours in A&E is up 2,700% since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct (although not all patients will necessarily have been waiting in A&E). In 2011/12, 120 patients in England waited 12 hours between the decision to admit them to emergency admissions and their actual admission, compared to 3,500 in 2017/18.

claims.text: The UK government is skewing data collected in a public consultation on lockdown measures.

claimReview.title: A ‘government consultation’ isn’t skewing data on lockdowns - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no such government consultation on lockdown measures. The survey described is actually run by YouGov, which is not part of the UK government.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us the right to send people from other countries home if they can’t support themselves.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct (although so does leaving).

claims.text: At 16 we’re free from parental control, we can leave home, we can start a family, we can get married, we can start work, we can pay taxes, we can join the forces.

claimReview.title: How sweet is sixteen? Legal age limits in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although in some cases parental consent is still required for under-18s.

claims.text: 72% of free schools are located in areas with a shortage of places.

claimReview.title: Seven in ten free schools are in areas needing more school places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: DfE analysis shows 7 in 10 open free schools are (or 75% of open and approved free schools). Many of the schools won't be operating at full capacity yet.

claims.text: The Social Mobility Commission has said that social mobility is getting worse in Great Britain.

claimReview.title: What's happening to social mobility? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: There were 99 daily deaths from stroke in England in October.

claimReview.title: A comparison of daily deaths from Covid-19 and non-Covid causes is incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This seems to be based on figures from the British Heart Foundation. An estimation based on 2019 figures suggests a figure of 65 daily deaths.

claims.text: PCR tests for Covid-19 have a 100% false positive rate.

claimReview.title: Tests can detect the Covid-19 virus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The false positive rate of Covid-19 PCR tests in the UK is extremely low. The highest possible value is 0.08%.

claims.text: One million migrants are expected in the EU this year and 800,000 have already arrived.

claimReview.title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One million people will seek asylum in the EU in 2015, according to the OECD; around half of them may already have arrived. All these estimates are uncertain.

claims.text: Up to week 47 of 2020, there were only 511,883 deaths in England and Wales, 20,000 fewer than the number of deaths in 2019.

claimReview.title: False death figures go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Up to and including week 47 there were 542,463 deaths registered in England and Wales. Across the whole year there were 608,002 deaths registered, 77,000 more than in 2019.

claims.text: A quarter of Covid-19 deaths were not caused by the virus.
claims.claimant: Zero Tolerance Media UK Main Page

claimReview.title: Claims that a quarter of all Covid-19 deaths weren’t caused by the virus misinterpret the data - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true for deaths registered in England and Wales for the week ending 2 April 2021, not  the entire pandemic.

claims.text: The Tories just refused to support 6500 jobs and £1 billion for our economy by not guaranteeing that 3 new Royal Navy ships will be built in Britain.

claimReview.title: Did the Conservatives refuse to support 6500 British shipbuilding jobs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These numbers assume that if a British shipbuilder won the contract, they would exclusively use British labour and goods. That’s uncertain. The £1 billion estimate is unconfirmed.

claims.text: Two billion was announced for social care last year.

claimReview.title: Social care: what’s the situation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. This was money for the NHS in England and councils to “support social care providers and relieve pressure on the NHS locally” until 2019/20.

claims.text: CPR involves doing chest compressions only.

claimReview.title: NHS says you should perform rescue breaths on children who aren’t breathing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: UK guidance says CPR should involve, alongside chest compressions, rescue breaths on children in all cases (unless there is a good reason why this is not possible), and on adults if the person administering them is completely confident and the person who is unwell doesn’t have Covid-19.

claims.text: This new virus is not heat-resistant and will be killed by a temperature of just 26/27 degrees. It hates the Sun.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence for this. There’s evidence that similar viruses transmit less well in the heat, but many countries with reported Covid-19 cases are experiencing temperatures higher than this.

claims.text: MPs get free phone calls.

claimReview.title: What can MPs claim on expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim for phone calls in their constituency offices. MPs eligible for housing expenses can claim for work-related telephone calls at that home.

claims.text: A screenshot shows a tweet from radical preacher Anjem Choudary.

claimReview.title: These tweets are from an Anjem Choudary parody account - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This tweet actually comes from a parody account.

claims.text: Trussell Trust food bank use has increased by 52% in a year in areas where Universal Credit has been rolled out.

claimReview.title: Is Universal Credit driving people to food banks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to the Trust’s own research. It’s difficult to measure the extent that one is causing the other. There’s wider evidence that people have had problems during the rollout of Universal Credit and that some have been going to food banks as a result.

claims.text: The use of physical forms of punishment against children is falling in almost every Western country, in Scotland and in the rest of the UK.

claimReview.title: Are fewer parents smacking their children? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research we’ve seen only covers a limited number of rich countries, but the claim is correct as far as this shows.

claims.text: Monsanto just lost in court.

claimReview.title: Most of these claims about glyphosate, vaccines and cancer are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. US agricultural company Monsanto has lost three court cases in the last year linking the chemical glyphosate in its Roundup weed killer to cancer cases.

claims.text: Shops buy apples that are coated with wax.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, this replaces natural wax washed off after picking, but the new wax poses no health risk.

claims.text: Drinking a glass of water 30 minutes before a meal helps digestion.

claimReview.title: Drinking water at set times does not provide certain health benefits - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Drinking water can help digestion, but we’ve not seen evidence that specifically drinking water 30 minutes before eating helps more than drinking water at other times.

claims.text: Over 80% of vaccinated pregnant women in a US study experienced miscarriage.
claims.claimant: Science Public Health Policy and the Law

claimReview.title: Research does not show 80% of vaccinated pregnant women experienced miscarriage - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This figure was made in error and is being corrected. The true miscarriage rate in this study was around 13%, which is similar to the normal rate.

claims.text: Boris Johnson wrote that working class men are “likely to be drunk, criminal, aimless, feckless and hopeless” in The Spectator in 1995.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson did write that “blue collar” men are likely to be drunk, criminal, aimless, feckless and hopeless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. He specifically said “blue collar” men.

claims.text: A video shows Muslims in Birmingham attacking cars so they can break fast during Ramadan on a road.

claimReview.title: This video does not show Muslims in Birmingham attacking cars during Ramadan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video is actually of violence following a football match in Switzerland in 2018.

claims.text: Polling figures show that Theresa May’s Brexit approach is ‘pissing off most of the nation’.

claimReview.title: These poll figures are for leave voters - not "most of the nation" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers in the graphic refer to opinion among Leave voters only, not the public as a whole. Opinion of the progress of Brexit varies depending on what question is asked.

claims.text: The Red Cross says people vaccinated against Covid-19 cannot donate blood plasma because the vaccine wipes out antibodies.

claimReview.title: Red Cross hasn’t banned blood donation from vaccinated people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The American Red Cross has stopped accepting donations of plasma containing Covid-19 antibodies from anyone as it has enough supply. It says people who have been vaccinated against Covid-19 can still give blood.

claims.text: People with a terminal illness are being declared fit to work and told to apply for jobs.

claimReview.title: Can people with terminal illnesses be declared fit to work? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Examples of this happening have been reported by the media and charities, but it’s not supposed to. We don’t know how widespread this is.

claims.text: The population is living a lot longer.

claimReview.title: More people, more (NHS) problems? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Life expectancy is increasing.

claims.text: In England the fatality rate is 50% higher than Scotland, at 20.9%.

claimReview.title: Be wary of social media posts comparing fatality rates in confirmed Covid-19 cases - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The proportion of people with NHS-lab confirmed cases who have died so far is 50% higher in England than in Scotland.

claims.text: You can sign the Revoke Article 50 petition using any name you want.

claimReview.title: Is it possible to repeatedly sign a parliamentary petition using the same email address? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is possible to sign using a false name.

claims.text: Two thirds of knife offenders under 25 were black or minority ethnic.

claimReview.title: Are a majority of youth knife offenders minority ethnic? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In England and Wales 38% of knife possession offenders under 25s were non-white in 2017. It was two thirds in London.

claims.text: The FDA says that hand gel causes cancer.

claimReview.title: Hand gel safety alerts only apply to certain brands - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The FDA has said that some particular types or brands of hand gel contain harmful ingredients, some of which are linked to cancers. However, this does not mean that all hand gels are harmful. The FDA and NHS advise that if soap and water aren’t available, hand gel should be used.

claims.text: There were 70 deaths from alcohol in Ireland in August.

claimReview.title: People did die of Covid-19 in Ireland in August - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We could find no source for this figure. A 2013 average of 88 alcohol-related deaths a month in Ireland includes a number of different factors, such as the coroner mentioning alcohol dependency, certain alcohol-related diseases, and if they were an alcoholic.

claims.text: Penalty charge notices are usually issued by the police or councils, while parking charge notices are invoices issued by private companies.

claimReview.title: This advice on how to fight a parking ticket is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The 2016 EU referendum was the largest democratic exercise in the UK’s history.

claimReview.title: The EU referendum wasn’t quite the largest democratic exercise in UK history - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. More people voted in the 1992 general election. It also had a higher turnout rate, as did other elections in the 20th century.

claims.text: The “Colston Four” admitted to pulling down the statue of Edward Colston and dumping it in the river. Legally, that is criminal damage.

claimReview.title: Claims on ‘Colston Four’ case leave out key questions the jury had to answer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not how the law defines criminal damage. Part of the definition is that it is done without “lawful excuse”. The defendants argued they had an excuse.

claims.text: Nearly two-thirds of ‘child’ refugees who officials questioned about their real age were found to be adults.

claimReview.title: Age assessments for Calais asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Home Office has decided in two thirds of ‘age disputes’ that the asylum seeker involved was over 18. But there’s no definitive test for age, and this fact isn’t necessarily relevant to young people who have already been screened for age in Calais.

claims.text: The reason why there are more cases is because they are testing more people.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true more people are being tested than ever before, but we also know deaths and hospitalisations have increased.

claims.text: 620,000 people are in hospital.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no clear measurement of how many people are in hospital at one time, however, figures that give an indication are significantly lower than this.

claims.text: There were 13,000 knife attacks in London.

claimReview.title: Muslim knife attacker claim is unfounded and implausible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know what time period the claim refers to but there is data to show this at the time. The latest data shows the police recorded just under 15,000 knife attacks in London in 2018/19.

claims.text: 2.5 million more people went to A&E last year.

claimReview.title: A&E in England has never been busier - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Just over one million more people went to A&E last year compared to the year before. 2.5 million is only correct comparing back to 2010.

claims.text: Italy has become the first country in the world to conduct a post-mortem on a Covid-19 patient.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. China performed autopsies on Covid-19 patients before Italy had its first Covid-19 death.

claims.text: MPs receive expenses and an allowance for food and booze.

claimReview.title: MPs cannot claim for alcohol from expenses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs cannot claim expenses for alcohol. MPs do receive expenses and can claim up to £25 for food and non-alcoholic drinks per night if they stay outside their constituency or London area. Catering on the parliamentary estate is also effectively subsidised, but is not solely for MPs.

claims.text: The working week in France is 35 hours.

claimReview.title: UK taxpayers aren’t subsidising France’s 35-hour working week - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. A full working week in France is officially set at 35 hours. Many employees agree to work more than 35 hours per week—but they will be compensated for this, for example through additional holiday.

claims.text: Human rights aren’t devolved in Northern Ireland.

claimReview.title: Abortion, human rights, and devolution - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In general human rights are a devolved matter in Northern Ireland, but the Assembly and Northern Ireland Ministers are required to comply with the European Convention on Human Rights.

claims.text: Under Boris Johnson’s planned withdrawal agreement GDP per capita would fall by up to 7% in 10 years.

claimReview.title: Think tank did not say GDP per capita will fall by 7% under Boris Johnson’s deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This misreports an estimate by think tank UK in a Changing Europe. It estimated that, in one scenario, GDP per capita would be 7% lower after 10 years, compared to if the UK remained in the EU—not 7% lower than it is now.

claims.text: There are 18 million GP appointments a year for self-treatable conditions.

claimReview.title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a very rough figure based on uncertain and out of date data. It uses self-reported data from about 60 GPs on 5,000 appointments in 2015, and applies this to the total number of GP appointments in 2008.

claims.text: People who are in insecure work or on zero hours contracts are excluded from the government’s financial support for self-isolation.

claimReview.title: Zero hours workers not excluded from self-isolation payments - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These groups aren’t excluded from support but, like other workers, need to be on benefits or have a low income in order to be eligible.

claims.text: Migration to the UK has dropped following the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estimates including three months after the referendum suggest net migration has fallen since the previous year, although the change isn’t statistically significant. It’s too soon to say what effect the result has had on immigration.

claims.text: Ken Clarke, former Conservative Chancellor said he won’t vote for the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Ken Clarke did not say he won’t vote for the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Mr Clarke said he would not vote for the Conservatives if it campaigned as “some crazy right-wing nationalist organisation” but also said that “I don’t think that will be where we end up”.

claims.text: A banana has been chemically ripened if it is brown spotted with a green stalk and naturally ripened if the stalk is black.

claimReview.title: You can’t tell how a banana was ripened by looking at it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. There is no consistent way to visually tell “naturally” and “chemically” ripened bananas apart. Both can develop these characteristics.

claims.text: Thousands of people died within weeks of being found fit for work.

claimReview.title: Reporting on "fit for work" deaths isn't fit for purpose - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures show people who died within weeks of their claim ending, not being found fit for work. Many claims have ended because the claimant died

claims.text: The majority of Britons say the police have lost control of the streets.

claimReview.title: Do a majority of Britons say the police have lost control of the streets? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A poll of 2,000 people in Great Britain found that 57% agreed with this statement. The poll also found that 43% said their police force was excellent or good and a majority said they felt safe on their streets.

claims.text: You are going to die if you get tested for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Ipsos MORI isn’t trying to kill you with Covid tests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is false. There are no reports of anyone dying because of a Covid-19 test. It is important to get tested if you have symptoms.

claims.text: Illegal immigrants and refugees living in Britain get a weekly spouse allowance of £225.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no weekly spouse allowance for refugees. People staying in the UK illegally are not entitled to claim any benefits.

claims.text: The Duke of Cambridge said there are “too many people on earth”.

claimReview.title: Prince William is not leading a global depopulation agenda - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. While Prince William has, in the past, made comments about human populations in the context of wildlife conservation, Full Fact could find no record of him publicly saying there are “too many people on earth”.

claims.text: All English schoolchildren are taught geography until at least the age of 14 — many until 16 — and in geography they’re taught about climate change.

claimReview.title: Setting the record straight on climate change in the school curriculum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Climate change is also part of the science curriculum in England, which all children are taught up to the age of 16. Some students have recently said they’re not learning enough about climate change on the current curriculum.

claims.text: TV presenter Richard Madeley was rushed to hospital at 4am after receiving his booster vaccine.

claimReview.title: Richard Madeley had his Covid-19 booster over a month before hospital visit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that he was taken to hospital on 25 November, but he had his booster jab in early October and there’s no evidence his hospital visit was in any way linked.

claims.text: 81,000 people are being tested in the UK every day.

claimReview.title: Lots of people are getting confused over testing figures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure is too low, although we don’t know by how much. It refers to people “newly” tested in England only. People who have been tested before may not appear in this figure.

claims.text: Average pay has finally surpassed its pre-crisis peak.

claimReview.title: Whether wages have passed their pre-crisis level depends on whether you include bonuses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True, for average weekly earnings in GB, if you don’t count bonuses. Average weekly total earnings including bonuses is still below the pre-crisis peak.

claims.text: Teacher numbers rose by 50,000 between 1997 and 2010 and support staff by 200,000.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in England.

claims.text: A new YouGov poll shows 62% of people think that Brexit is a bad thing.

claimReview.title: Daily Mirror misrepresents research on public support for Brexit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The poll shows that 50% of GB adults think Britain was wrong to leave the EU, and a further 12% don’t know.

claims.text: There are more council houses that have been built in the last seven years than under the last Labour government.

claimReview.title: Have more council houses been built in the last seven years than under Labour? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is technically correct, but it ignores the major role of housing associations in the provision of social housing. Including homes built by local authorities and housing associations, Labour built more houses during their 13 years than in the 7 years since then, but built on average fewer houses per year.

claims.text: There were 922,000 adverse reactions as a result of the Covid-19 vaccines and it’s now closer to a million.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are reported reactions as of 2 June. We don’t know that they happened because of the vaccine, just that they happened shortly afterwards.

claims.text: Taking statins cuts the risk of dying of Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Study doesn’t prove that statins ‘cut’ the risk of dying from Covid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We do not know if this is true. A new scientific study found that people taking statins were less likely to die of Covid-19—but it did not find that the statins themselves cut the risk.

claims.text: Heathrow Airport is used by people getting off one plane and on another.

claimReview.title: Is Heathrow just for high flyers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An estimated 34% of flyers leaving Heathrow are on a connecting flight, far higher than any other London or UK airport included in the survey.

claims.text: People earning £80,000 are not in the top 5%. Doctors and lawyers make more than that.

claimReview.title: If you are earning £80,000 you are in the top 5% of income tax payers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: If you are earning over £80,000 you are in the top 5% of earners. The average salary of a doctor or a lawyer is substantially lower than that.

claims.text: Illegal immigrants or refugees living in Britain get a total yearly benefit of £29,900.

claimReview.title: Who gets more, pensioners or refugees? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Illegal immigrants cannot collect benefits, and refugees can on the same basis as UK nationals once their request for asylum is granted—but this figure is unusually high.

claims.text: The image in the post shows soldiers during World War Two.

claimReview.title: These claims about people of certain ages remembering parts of World War Two are generally incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image is from World War One. All of those who served in the conflict died some years before the Brexit vote.

claims.text: Central government funding to police forces will be cut by £330 million in real terms between 2015 and 2018.

claimReview.title: Police funding: up or down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct, totalling up central government grants to individual police forces and adjusting for inflation.

claims.text: The cost of 20 years in Afghanistan was only 59% of the cost of NHS Test and Trace.

claimReview.title: NHS Test and Trace has not spent as much as war in Afghanistan yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MoD estimates for the military costs of being in Afghanistan from 2002 onwards are around £27.7 billion. The total budget for Test and Trace for its first two years is £37 billion.

claims.text: Currys is selling a Dyson hair dryer for £1.78.

claimReview.title: Facebook offer to buy a Dyson hair dryer for £1.78 is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The offer is not real as confirmed by Currys.

claims.text: The NHS has been judged the best healthcare system in the world.

claimReview.title: Has the NHS been judged the best healthcare system in the world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It depends who you ask and what they’re judging to be important for a healthcare system. One report judged the UK’s healthcare the best of eleven rich countries, but other reports say the UK does much worse. None we’ve seen are specific to the NHS.

claims.text: German police can enter homes and forcibly vaccinate people.

claimReview.title: German police cannot vaccinate people by force - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true, and there is no evidence of this happening.

claims.text: It will cost the UK £378 billion to extend the transition period between the UK and the EU.

claimReview.title: Claim that extending the Brexit transition period could cost £380 billion is not credible - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This estimate is based on a one-sided analysis which doesn’t seem to factor in any economic benefit of retaining free trade with the EU during the transition period. Most studies suggest these benefits outweigh potential gains from trade agreements and deregulation after the transition period ends.

claims.text: Nurses have been using food banks.

claimReview.title: How many nurses are using foodbanks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Media reports show that at least some individual nurses and trainees have visited food banks. We don’t have solid evidence of the scale of use.

claims.text: European patent 3172319B1 is owned by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

claimReview.title: These patents are not for the new coronavirus or its vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not. The patent is owned by the UK-based Pirbright Institute, which receives some of its funding from the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

claims.text: UK public spending is expected to fall to US levels by 2019.

claimReview.title: UK public spending down to US levels by 2018/19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As a proportion of GDP, UK spending is forecast to be similar to the US by 2019. The summer 2015 Budget in the UK set this in motion.

claims.text: The new coronavirus does not settle in the air but is grounded so it is not transmitted by air.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The virus can spread via sneeze and cough droplets that can move a short distance through the air and into someone else’s system.

claims.text: More than a quarter of English adults are now obese.

claimReview.title: Are more people going into hospital for obesity related illnesses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 26% of adults were measured to be obese in a 2016 survey. This has been at roughly the same level since 2010.

claims.text: Under the last Labour government, we had the longest sustained period of investment in the NHS since it was founded.

claimReview.title: Satisfaction with the NHS peaked in 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour governments from 1997-2010 increased health spending by more each year on average than any party apart from the Conservatives between 1970 and 1974. The longest period of sustained increases in health spending since 1950 was from 1953-1969 under a number of different governments and political parties.

claims.text: Muslims who use living areas within their homes as a place of worship are exempt from paying council tax. This doesn’t apply to other religions.

claimReview.title: You can’t be exempt from council tax if your home is used as a place of worship - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct, they wouldn’t be exempt from council tax. Places of worship for all religions can be exempt from business rates, but only if they’re officially recognised as such. The principal use of the site has to be worship.

claims.text: NHS staff will get a pay rise of between 6.5% and 29%.

claimReview.title: NHS pay: what’s the deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Pay will rise for some staff by between 4.5% and 29% over the next three years. This includes the increases in salaries staff will get by progressing through their pay band over time, and pay rises would still occur without a new deal. It doesn’t cover doctors, dentists, or very senior managers.

claims.text: Masks don’t work.

claimReview.title: Mike Yeadon wrong again on lockdowns and face masks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Masks do work to reduce viral transmission.

claims.text: Washing glasses with soap will prevent lenses from fogging whilst wearing a mask.

claimReview.title: Washing your glasses with soap can help prevent fogging when wearing a mask - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. The soap disrupts the surface tension which causes the condensation or “fog”.

claims.text: Deaths after Covid-19 vaccines have overtaken the number of Covid-19 deaths in “healthy” people that occurred in 2020.

claimReview.title: Deaths from vaccines have not overtaken Covid-19 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is based on mismatched sets of data, which are misleadingly presented to draw false conclusions. The two figures used do not cover the same time period or same UK nations.

claims.text: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy.

claimReview.title: The EU has shrunk as a percentage of the world economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. The EU economy has grown in size, but the rest of the world economy has grown faster.

claims.text: Photos appearing to show Boris Johnson hosting a Christmas quiz from Number 10 Downing Street in 2020 show that the CCTV camera in the room has been covered with a big bag.

claimReview.title: Downing Street quiz picture doesn’t show bin bag over CCTV - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The object people are saying is a bin bag covering a security camera is actually part of the curtain.

claims.text: 93% of the world is not in the EU.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, looking at the world’s population. About 78% of the world’s economic output is estimated to be outside of the EU.

claims.text: Japan has banned Black Lives Matter apparel and demonstrations such as taking the knee or raising a fist.

claimReview.title: Japan hasn’t banned Olympic athletes from taking the knee - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that political, religious and racial protests are banned at Olympic sites and venues, but this applies to all such demonstrations, not just BLM. Japan did not make this decision—the rule has been in place for decades and is implemented by the International Olympic Committee.

claims.text: A picture claims to show a ‘hammerhead salamander’.

claimReview.title: This picture shows a model of an extinct amphibian - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture shows a model of a dipocaulus, sometimes called a hammerhead salamander, which is extinct.

claims.text: NHS funding is at record levels.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. NHS funding in the UK is at record levels, even adjusted for inflation.

claims.text: The government hasn’t balanced its books because debt is up from £1 trillion to £1.7 trillion.

claimReview.title: The UK public debt is rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The deficit is falling and debt is still rising.

claims.text: 65,000 deaths tested positive for coronavirus within 30 days of their death, so they could have died of a heart attack or a stroke or cancer, but it will go down as a Covid death.

claimReview.title: Viral influencer video full of false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some deaths unrelated to Covid-19 may happen within 28 days of a positive test but this makes very little difference to the figures. Up to the week ending 15 January, 85,321 deaths were registered in England and Wales with Covid-19 recorded as the underlying cause of death by a medical professional.

claims.text: A 5G test in the Netherlands resulted in the death of 297 birds.

claimReview.title: Hundreds of birds were found dead in the Netherlands but it had nothing to do with 5G - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Almost 300 starlings were found dead in a park in the Hague in October 2018. There were no 5G tests in The Hague in October 2018. Mass starling death is not unheard of.

claims.text: 70% of Conservative constituencies and 60% of Labour constituencies voted to Leave in the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Did a majority of Conservative and Labour constituencies vote to leave in the EU referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are roughly correct, although we don’t know for sure how many parliamentary seats voted – all we have are estimates.

claims.text: There is a 20 fold difference between the best and worst performing councils in terms of delayed transfer of care from hospital.

claimReview.title: Delayed transfers of care: does geography matter? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Based on the latest figures this looks to be about right. We’ve asked the Department of Health for its figures.

claims.text: People are getting poorer.

claimReview.title: Living long and prospering? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Looking at the overall population of the UK this is incorrect. Over the last 50 years people have been getting richer. But if you look at specific groups the picture changes. Young people in their 30s today have around half the household wealth of those born a decade earlier at the same age.

claims.text: Being in Europe means lower prices in UK shops, saving the average UK household over £350 a year. If we left Europe, your weekly shop could cost more.

claimReview.title: Stronger In "facts" leaflet: lower prices - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t the impact of being in the EU as such, but one estimate of the impact of the free trade deals the EU has negotiated—a saving of 1.27% for the average household. It’s difficult to say overall what the impact of being in the EU has had on prices in the UK.

claims.text: Boris Johnson said that an alert system for Covid-19 could involve detecting the infection in the water supply.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson mistakenly said that Covid-19 could be monitored through the water supply - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true that Boris Johnson said this, however, he misspoke according to his spokesperson. He was referring to a potential scheme that could detect genetic material from the virus in sewage: not in the water supply.

claims.text: According to Dr. Bill Osmunson, the amount of fluoride in an 8-ounce glass of fluoridated tap water is equivalent to the “pea-sized” amount needed to call the Poison Control Center, as recommended on the back of any fluoridated toothpaste.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the UK, you would need to brush your teeth four to six times a day with a ‘pea-sized amount’ of toothpaste, and swallow that toothpaste, to consume the same amount of fluoride as found in a litre of tap water with the maximum levels of fluoride allowed.

claims.text: A video appears to show a phone detecting a new “product” when placed near a man’s arm, suggesting he was implanted with an electronic device when vaccinated.

claimReview.title: Video of ‘QR code’ detected in arm is not evidence of vaccine microchips - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Vaccines do not contain microchips. This is not evidence of microchips being contained in vaccines.

claims.text: Iain Duncan Smith MP gets free accommodation.

claimReview.title: Not all of these claims about what MPs can claim in expenses are correct - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: MPs can claim expenses for rent on a second residence or hotel if their constituency is outside London, and if they don’t live in free accommodation, such as Downing Street. Iain Duncan Smith is a London MP, so can’t claim accommodation expenses.

claims.text: Boris Johnson said "we have wiped out the national debt".

claimReview.title: This quote attributed to Boris Johnson is not real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence he said this.

claims.text: The UK has the highest property taxes in the world.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have the highest rate of property tax in the world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK does raise more from property taxes overall than any other developed country, but this includes things like council tax. It doesn’t seem to have the highest stamp duty (or equivalent) in the world.

claims.text: A D-notice is currently blocking the UK media from reporting on Yellow Vest protests in France.

claimReview.title: There is no D-notice blocking reporting on Yellow Vest protests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no D-notice for the protests. D-notices (also known as DSMA-notices) are non-mandatory advice and guidance for the media regarding reporting on defence and security information. They do not cover specific incidents.

claims.text: 91 people died in the attack on the King David Hotel in 1946, including 28 British people.

claimReview.title: This is a real photo of Margaret Thatcher and Menachem Begin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Measles is at the top of the list of the MMR vaccine’s adverse reactions.

claimReview.title: Measles is not the “number one side effect” of the MMR vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Atypical measles is listed as one of the “adverse reactions” of the MMR vaccine used in the US and one of the UK brands (it is not “top” of these lists). That’s because people vaccinated with a certain brand of measles jab in the 60s and 70s were still able to get “atypical measles” if they were exposed to a certain measles strain. The other UK brand lists “atypical measles” as a “possible side effect” as some people who were given that MMR vaccine got atypical measles if they also got the old measles jab.

claims.text: The House of Commons was crowded for debates on MP expenses and pay, but much emptier for debates and votes on topics such as education for refugees and knife crime.

claimReview.title: Pictures of Parliament don’t tell the whole story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While we’ve not been able to verify all these images, at least one, claiming to show the house during a debate on expenses, is actually from a debate on higher education. There are a number of reasons MP attendance may be low in debates.

claims.text: Police funding has risen from £12.1bn in 2015/16 to £16.9bn in 2022/23.

claimReview.title: Priti Patel’s tweet on police funding doesn’t account for inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true in cash terms but fails to take into account inflation, meaning the actual increase in police spending is much lower.

claims.text: 7.7% of UK goods exports go to the EU.

claimReview.title: Claim that 7.7% of UK goods exports go to the EU is a big underestimate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 46% of UK goods exports go to the EU, according to the latest data for 2019. Those exports amount to 7.7% of GDP.

claims.text: Boris Johnson has the support of more than half of the public to deliver Brexit by any means, including suspending Parliament, according to a poll.

claimReview.title: The Telegraph’s poll figures on suspending parliament are misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The poll showed that 44%, not a majority, agreed with the statement. There are also other problems with the poll.

claims.text: Article Eight of the Human Rights Act sets out a right to private and family life and therefore is allowing asylum seekers to argue that because they have a cat or dog their deportation should be halted.

claimReview.title: No evidence asylum seekers have used pets to argue against deportation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We could find no evidence that this has ever been successfully put forward as a reason for an asylum seeker to be granted the right to remain in the UK. A similar claim made in 2011 by Theresa May was widely debunked at the time.

claims.text: The Conservatives have had only three female MPs represent their party at Prime Minister’s Questions since 1997.

claimReview.title: Women at the despatch box for Prime Minister’s Questions - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The same is true for Labour.

claims.text: Tesco is sacking 4,300 staff.

claimReview.title: No evidence Tesco is sacking 4,300 workers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence Tesco is sacking 4,300 staff. Tesco has confirmed this is not true.

claims.text: Beer sales at British pubs have risen after the vote to leave the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit and the great British pub - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The figures available mostly cover the period before the referendum, and show that pub sales actually fell, although overall beer sales rose.

claims.text: One picture of a teenage boy has been used to cover the deaths of three teenagers in three different countries

claimReview.title: A picture of one boy who died has been mistakenly used to cover stories on the deaths of two other boys - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The screenshots of news stories are real, but some were errors that have been taken out of context. The images were not widely used in the media. The photograph is of deceased Irish teenager Conor Wilmot who died in 2017.

claims.text: For every three victims of domestic abuse, two will be female, one will be male.

claimReview.title: Are a third of domestic abuse victims men? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Of those aged 16-74 who told the Crime Survey for England and Wales that they had experienced some form of domestic abuse since they were 16, a third were male and two thirds were female.

claims.text: The Royal British Legion will not be selling poppies in certain places this year due to “upset minorities”.

claimReview.title: The Royal British Legion is not stopping poppy sales in certain areas due to “upset minorities” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The Royal British Legion has routinely stated this is untrue.

claims.text: You can’t be a member of the European single market without being a member of the EU.

claimReview.title: Can you be in the single market without being an EU member? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s technically possible for a non-EU member to be in the single market but it requires accepting a lot of rules set by the EU.

claims.text: People who have a stroke at the weekend are 20% more likely to die than if it happened on a weekday.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: stroke patients and weekend deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Academic research backs that up, although it's difficult to say why. It's possible that people treated at the weekend are more seriously ill on average.

claims.text: People in work are using food banks.

claimReview.title: Are people in work using food banks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Around 15% of households surveyed when using Trussell Trust foodbanks between October and December 2016 included at least one person with some work or income from employment, according to a recent academic study. We don’t know about the people using food banks not run by the Trussell Trust.

claims.text: 14 million people are in poverty, which is a record high.

claimReview.title: Poverty hasn’t skyrocketed in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. In 2017/18, 14 million people were in poverty according to one definition. This was a fall on the previous year in terms of the number of people and percentage of the population.

claims.text: More than a third of Covid-19 deaths had diabetes.

claimReview.title: Daily Express diabetes and coronavirus deaths headline is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. NHS data shows that of Covid-19 patients who died in hospital in England just over a quarter had diabetes.

claims.text: Instagram blocks your posts to all but 7% of your followers.

claimReview.title: Instagram isn’t blocking posts to your followers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Instagram confirmed earlier this year that no changes had been made to feed rankings recently or since the claim first appeared two years ago.

claims.text: Capital gains tax has been cut

claimReview.title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The main rate has been cut. But overall, policy changes under the Conservatives and the Coalition have tended to push revenues up.

claims.text: 23% of people in Wales live in poverty

claimReview.title: Poverty in Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct using the relative measure of poverty after housing costs, and absolute poverty after housing costs is similar, estimated at 22%.

claims.text: There are 363 murderers in open prisons; 106 murderers have absconded from open prisons in the last 10 years; and there are 179 offenders in open prisons who've absconded before.

claimReview.title: Prisoners absconding: an open and shut case? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are correct but not up to date. As many as 122 murderers absconded from open prisons in the decade up to 2013/2014.

claims.text: Japanese-owned companies employ 140,000 people in the UK.

claimReview.title: Japanese-owned companies in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, according to estimates from the Japanese government, although we haven’t yet been able to look into these in detail as they aren’t published in English.

claims.text: The Labour party has more women MPs than all the other parties in the House of Commons combined.

claimReview.title: Women in the Commons - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct then and now. Following the 2017 election, 119 out of the 208 women MPs are Labour Party members.

claims.text: Up to a third of millennials face renting their entire lives.

claimReview.title: Will one third of millennials rent for their entire lives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a projection made by the Resolution Foundation. Their “pessimistic” UK scenario says 66% of families where the head of household was born from 1981-1995 will own their own home by 2060. Their “optimistic” scenario says 73% will.

claims.text: The EU has decided to increase the size of fisherman’s meshes.

claimReview.title: There’s no solid evidence to support this Brexit Party MEP’s claim about fishermen’s nets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU regulation has changed and there is now a minimum mesh size in certain areas. That came in place on 1 July 2019.

claims.text: Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland and Canada have slashed tariffs—their citizens are better off as a result, and their economies have thrived.

claimReview.title: Beer mat Brexit: do the facts stack up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Uncertain. This is a very broad claim, and it is hard to attribute the performance of any economy to one factor such as reducing tariffs.

claims.text: Admissions for obesity have more than doubled in the last four years.

claimReview.title: Are more people going into hospital for obesity related illnesses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Admissions with a primary diagnosis of obesity are at roughly the same level as they were in 2012/13, including those with a secondary diagnosis the figure has doubled since then. But a secondary diagnosis doesn’t necessarily mean this is why the patient was admitted.

claims.text: A BMJ article is proof that the use of PCR tests are a massive part of the problem.

claimReview.title: The BMJ didn’t say PCR tests are useless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The BMJ article illustrates some of the concerns around potentially using PCR testing for asymptomatic mass testing. This is not how PCR tests are generally being used in the UK.

claims.text: The EU referendum outcome is "on a knife edge".

claimReview.title: Is the EU referendum outcome "on a knife edge"? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is uncertain. While two polls have shown a narrow gap between the 'remain' and 'leave' camps, others have shown significant gaps between the two. Different methods give different results, with telephone polls showing 'remain' with a strong lead and online polls showing a more narrow gap.

claims.text: An image of Earth was pasted into a photo from the Apollo 17 space mission.

claimReview.title: NASA didn’t paste a picture of the Earth into photos from the moon - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true and is a misinterpretation of an effect linked to photo editing software.

claims.text: We have 100,000 vacancies in our NHS.

claimReview.title: Are there 100,000 vacancies in the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS Improvement says there were 97,000 vacancies in NHS trusts in England between October-December 2017. It’s based on management information and is not an official statistic, so should be treated with some caution. Many of these “vacancies” are currently filled by temporary staff.

claims.text: In England we use an estimated 8.5 billion plastic straws each year, according to government figures.

claimReview.title: How many plastic straws do we use? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on an old estimate from an environmental consultancy of how many straws the fast food industry in the whole of the UK uses each year. The government has since said it thinks this figure is wrong.

claims.text: Covid-19 clots the blood causing thrombosis, stopping blood flow and oxygenating the heart and lungs.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Severe Covid-19 can cause blood clotting problems and issues like this have been seen in Covid-19 patients, but this is not the only thing that can be fatal in patients.

claims.text: Figures show a “consistently higher” number of Covid-19 cases among vaccinated adults.

claimReview.title: Former MEP wrongly uses UK Covid-19 data - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on misleading information which cannot be used to measure the effectiveness of Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: Women are getting ahead of men in terms of pay before they become mothers.

claimReview.title: Age, motherhood and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve not seen clear evidence that women are getting ahead on average, even though women and men are paid more equitably in their 20s than later in life.

claims.text: Britain gives away £13 billion a year in foreign aid.

claimReview.title: The UK foreign aid budget: what did the government spend in 2017? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK spent £13.4 billion on foreign aid in 2016. Provisional figures for 2017 put the amount at just over £13.9 billion.

claims.text: One million primary school pupils are set to stay home on 1 June despite schools reopening.

claimReview.title: The figure of 1 million children not returning to school is uncertain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on survey results of around 1,000 senior teachers asked in early May what proportion of families would keep their children at home. The results were then applied to the estimated number of students in Early Years, Reception, Year 1 and Year 6.

claims.text: There were nearly 1,000 drug-related deaths in Scotland last year.

claimReview.title: Are drug related deaths in the UK the highest in the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, there were 934 registered in 2017.

claims.text: The Royal College of Midwives estimates that there is a shortage of 3,500 midwives in England.

claimReview.title: A shortage of midwives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It does. The RCM calculates this based on the number of births, the number of midwives, and a widely recognised formula for how many births each midwives can handle per year.

claims.text: A record number of people killed themselves in English and Welsh prisons in 2016.

claimReview.title: Record self-inflicted deaths in prisons - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct, going back to 1978. The rate of self-inflicted deaths per 1,000 prisoners is also close to a record high.

claims.text: Statistics show the gap in income inequality is narrowing.

claimReview.title: Income inequality - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: By several headline measures, disposable income inequality has gradually fallen in the past decade (not accounting for housing costs). It matters what measure you use and it's hard to judge the influence of recent governments.

claims.text: Many judges at the European Court of Human Rights aren't legally qualified, and are appointed politically.

claimReview.title: Human rights court: "pseudo-judges" or super judges? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: None of the judges at the Court are obviously unqualified based on their CVs, although they are voted in by a political body.

claims.text: A viral video called “Martinelli” will be shared on WhatsApp tomorrow. It will hack your phone if opened.

claimReview.title: WhatsApp Gold scams are real, but these other threats are made up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a hoax. There is no evidence the Martinelli video or virus exists.

claims.text: In 2014 Chuka Umunna tweeted to promise he wouldn’t join the Liberal Democrats.

claimReview.title: This supposed Chuka Umunna tweet doesn’t seem to be real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tweet in question seems to be fake, it isn’t formatted in the same way as Twitter was five years ago and we’ve found no evidence Mr Umunna ever tweeted this.

claims.text: Betting on online slot machines has increased by 25% during lockdown.

claimReview.title: Spending on online slot machines didn’t go up 25% in lockdown - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Betting on online slot machines fell during the lockdown but the number of players increased 25% between March 2019 and March 2020.

claims.text: From 23 March until the foreseeable future, Microsoft and Sony will shut down their gaming servers during UK school hours.

claimReview.title: Xbox and PlayStation servers are not being shut down during school hours - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Microsoft and Sony haven’t announced these measures.

claims.text: There were no psychiatric beds available overnight for NHS patients across England on Saturday 28 October 2017.

claimReview.title: Were no psychiatric beds available anywhere in England at the weekend? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how many beds were available as there are no published figures. NHS England says this is incorrect. Anecdotal evidence suggests there have been times when none of the correct type were available.

claims.text: The UK’s child literacy and numeracy rates consistently languish either at or near the bottom of every international table.

claimReview.title: Telegraph columnist wrongly claims literacy at the lowest level in UK history - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Various international league tables put the UK above the OECD average for literacy and numeracy.

claims.text: The available Covid-19 vaccines are a type of gene therapy.

claimReview.title: David Icke makes false claim that vaccines are ‘gene therapy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. None of the vaccines change genetic code or attempt to replace genes.

claims.text: The booster vaccines have 81 strands of foreign bacteria or eight strands of HIV in them.

claimReview.title: There is no HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA told Full Fact: “There is no bacteria or strands of HIV in the booster vaccines.”

claims.text: Each air strike in Syria will cost £508,000, enough to pay for up to 20 public sector workers.

claimReview.title: Air strikes: how many teachers and nurses could we pay for instead? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The £508,000 figure is a rough estimate, and estimating how many workers it would "pay for" is trickier than you might think.

claims.text: People convicted for carrying a blade are spending longer in prison.

claimReview.title: Are more people being prosecuted for carrying knives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The average custodial sentence for a knife or offensive weapon possession offence increased by 2.2 months between 2008 and 2017.

claims.text: The number of people who came to live in this country last year was the same as the population of Newcastle-upon-Tyne.

claimReview.title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not far off, assuming the claim is referring to net migration. The best estimate is that about 335,000 more people came to live in UK than left in the year leading up to June 2016. Only 293,000 people live in Newcastle-upon-Tyne.

claims.text: A firefighter’s salary is £29,345.

claimReview.title: How much do firefighters, paramedics and police officers earn? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was the salary of a competent firefighter in 2015. It’s now £32,244 outside of London.

claims.text: Up to 57,000 Commonwealth-born people who arrived in the UK before 1971 could lose their homes, jobs, benefits, NHS treatment, or be threatened with deportation.

claimReview.title: Windrush generation: what's the situation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the number of Commonwealth-born people living in the UK in 2017 who arrived before 1971, and self-report as not being a UK citizen. They have the right to remain in the UK indefinitely but some have recently had problems proving their eligibility. We don’t know how many have had such problems, and some who are UK citizens could also be affected.

claims.text: Poland has had no terror attacks.

claimReview.title: Does Poland’s migration policy explain its lack of terror attacks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Poland had no recorded terror attacks between 2012 and 2015 according to data from the Global Terrorism Database. There have been at least three terror attacks since.

claims.text: Aluminium in vaccines can cause Alzheimer’s disease.

claimReview.title: No evidence aluminium in vaccines causes Alzheimer's disease - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No link between Alzheimer’s disease and the small amount of aluminium found in some vaccines has been established.

claims.text: The national debt almost tripled under the last Labour government.

claimReview.title: Labour and Conservative records on the national debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in cash terms, but after adjusting for inflation it’s more like doubled than tripled. Public sector net debt, adjusted for inflation, rose by 125% between 1996/97 and 2009/10 – mostly after the recession that began in 2008.

claims.text: A woman claimed on Facebook to have inside information suggesting that the photo of a boy sleeping on a hospital floor was staged.

claimReview.title: There is no evidence to suggest the photo of a boy sleeping on a hospital floor was staged - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence the photo was staged. The hospital has confirmed that the incident happened. The woman has told the media she does not have information about the incident.

claims.text: 2% or 3% of lorries going through Dover aren’t going to the EU.

claimReview.title: Lorries at Dover - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen the evidence to confirm this. We were told the figures came from the Port of Dover authorities, who have previously given similar figures to parliamentary committees. They have so far been unable to confirm the figures, so we’ve asked for more information.

claims.text: Families will be £1,250 a year worse off in 2020 than they were in 2016, and that's because of Brexit.
