claimReview.title: This video does not show the final moments of the Ethiopian Airlines flight - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. It’s a video from 2016 of an Etihad flight that experienced severe turbulence but went on to land safely.

claims.text: Covid-19 and influenza statistics are being combined to make the numbers look worse.

claimReview.title: Flu and Covid-19 statistics are not being added together - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Statistics about the two diseases are being published separately in the same document. This has no effect on the numbers.

claims.text: Former New South Wales Premier Gladys Berejiklian has resigned after accepting $65m in bribes from AstraZeneca and Pfizer.

claimReview.title: No evidence New South Wales Premier resigned over bribes from Pfizer or AstraZeneca - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
While Ms Berejiklian has resigned following a corruption probe, it has nothing to do with bribes from Pfizer or AstraZeneca.

There is no evidence of bribery from either company.

claims.text: “Forcing” young women to have Covid-19 vaccines is “almost certain” to lead to increased stillbirths, miscarriages, disabled children and infertility.

claimReview.title: Richard Tice makes misleading claims about Covid-19 vaccines and fertility - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this. Yellow Card and VAERS reporting is cited as the source of this claim, but the data from these systems does not prove a link.

claims.text: The NHS Covid-19 vaccination card will be used to prove who has been vaccinated.

claimReview.title: The new vaccination card is not a ‘Covid passport’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The card contains a record of someone’s vaccination and a reminder of their second appointment date, but it does not contain secure personal information so it cannot prove who was vaccinated.

claims.text: These lipid nanoparticles may have adverse effects on fertility for both men and women.

claimReview.title: No evidence that nanoparticles in Covid-19 vaccines affect fertility - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Nanoparticles are a broad spectrum of different materials that only have their small size in common. There’s no evidence that the lipid nanoparticles in these vaccines will have any effect on fertility.

claims.text: The economy has grown by 73% under this Conservative government.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson gets his numbers muddled on economic growth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The economy grew 73% between 1990 and 2017, under both Labour and Conservative-led governments. The economy has grown by around 20% since the Conservatives took office in 2010.

claims.text: Vaccines have severed the link between Covid-19 infections and serious disease or death.

claimReview.title: Was Dawn Butler right about Boris Johnson ‘lying’ to Parliament? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Vaccinated people are much less likely to catch Covid-19, or get seriously ill or die from it, but the link between infections and deaths has not been removed completely.

claims.text: The UK has dropped to 14th in a world ranking for investment in renewable energy.

claimReview.title: Investment in renewables - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has fallen to 14th in a ranking for most attractive countries to invest in renewables. A different ranking put it at 4th in the world for actual spending in 2015.

claims.text: Covid-19 is being used to usher in Agenda 2030 which will enslave humanity.

claimReview.title: Agenda 2030 conspiracy just describes UN sustainability goals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Agenda 2030 is a set of goals set by the UN in 2015 that include ending hunger. There is no evidence that it’s a wider policy to harm humanity.

claims.text: Priti Patel spent £77,000 on eyebrows and other beauty products.

claimReview.title: Home Office denies £77,000 was spent on eyebrows and beauty products - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This sum was paid to a company selling eyebrow products and services, but the Home Office has said the money was spent on PPE. The company in question does also sell PPE.

claims.text: Electrolysis of tap water and distilled water shows that tap water contains something that is dumbing us down.

claimReview.title: Electrolysis video doesn’t prove tap water is dangerous - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cup of tap water going green doesn’t prove there’s anything untoward in it. The colour change is likely to be the metal electrodes of the device breaking down, which is only possible in non-distilled water.

claims.text: In children between 12 and 17 that had the Pfizer vaccine, there were 9,246 adverse reactions within a period of a month.

claimReview.title: The Pfizer vaccine, teenagers and myocarditis - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was how many reports were made up to July 2021, over more than six months, out of 8.9 million children who were vaccinated.

claims.text: Labour introduced the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order in 2005, which was criticised by the coroner’s report following the Lakanal House fire in 2009 criticised the order.

claimReview.title: Have concerns been raised in the past about key fire safety laws? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Concerns about the Fire Safety Order (introduced by the Labour government in 2005) were raised by the inquest into the Lakanal House fire. It was concerned that people carrying out fire risk assessments weren’t necessarily qualified enough and about the scope of the new rules.

claims.text: There are plans for an EU army.

claimReview.title: The hunt for an EU army - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU member countries work together on military matters, but the EU doesn't have its own military capabilities. At least a few European politicians do support the creation of an EU army, but that would need unanimous approval.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines in use in the UK are still in the experimental phase.

claimReview.title: A fake Metro cover shares false vaccine information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The vaccines have been approved for use following clinical trials.

claims.text: The two most recent PHE reports show no statistically significant excess all-cause mortality.

claimReview.title: There are excess deaths in England and these PHE reports don’t prove otherwise - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are excess deaths in England at the moment. The PHE reports used estimates that were distorted by the reporting lag over Christmas. PHE has already revised its findings for week 52 of 2020 and may revise its findings for week 53.

claims.text: Abortion is still a crime unless it’s approved by doctors.

claimReview.title: What would changing the law on abortion mean? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although prosecutions are very rare in practice.

claims.text: If you are in the UK and under coronavirus lockdown with an abusive partner dial 999, wait to be connected, press 55 & hang up.

claimReview.title: If you need the police but can’t talk, dial 999 from a mobile, then 55 when prompted and don’t hang up - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You will only be prompted to press 55 on a silent call from a mobile. And you should not hang up after typing 55. You should try and cough, tap the handset or whisper to communicate on an emergency call if possible.

claims.text: A single parent working on the minimum wage and already working full-time would need to work more than nine hours a week on top of that full-time job to earn back the £20 uplift and make up for the rise in National Insurance.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit: Do politicians' claims about working more hours add up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Again this will be true for some Universal Credit recipients, but can’t be applied to everyone.

claims.text: The NHS needs 4 billion a year, but it’s getting 1.6 billion and that figures is set to decrease.

claimReview.title: How much money does the NHS need and how much is it actually getting? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Experts have previously said that NHS England needed £4 billion in 2018/19. In the Autumn budget 2017 the government announced that it will receive £1.6 billion, or £1.9 billion if capital spending is included.

claims.text: The vaccines contain genetically modified organisms.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: True. Some of them, such as the AstraZeneca vaccine, do contain GMOs.

claims.text: The top 10 Commonwealth countries take 8% of UK exports.

claimReview.title: Trade with the Commonwealth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Since the Conservatives came to government, national debt has increased from £0.95 trillion to £2 trillion.

claimReview.title: What is the UK’s public debt? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. Over that period debt has risen from £1 trillion to £1.8 trillion.

claims.text: House building has fallen to its lowest level since the 1920s.

claimReview.title: House building: at its lowest level since the 1920s? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, although it’s been falling since the 1960s under different governments.

claims.text: MPs in the UK have awarded themselves a £10,000 bonus to cover ‘expenses’ during the Covid-19 crisis.

claimReview.title: Not all New Zealand MPs have been ordered to take a pay cut, and UK MPs have not awarded themselves a £10,000 bonus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. MPs’ pay is regulated by the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority, which has increased the amount MPs can claim in expenses for office and staff costs by £10,000 to cover additional costs needed to set up remote working.  MPs did not get to decide on this increase and  do not have to claim it.

claims.text: GDP will be between £39 billion and £158 billion less per year as a result of on several different options for post-Brexit trade deals with the EU.

claimReview.title: This image on the costs of Brexit is very misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on government analysis comparing 3 hypothetical deals to existing GDP projections, which explicitly can’t be used as economic forecasts and are very uncertain. Were they to be used anyway, these are figures for a 15 year period, not one year.

claims.text: The new UK-Japan trade deal will mean soy sauce imports from Japan will get cheaper.

claimReview.title: Soy sauce imports from Japan will not be cheaper next year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Tariffs on Japanese soy sauce will stay at 0%. Tariffs on soy sauce imports from some other countries may increase, but from others may decrease.

claims.text: A policeman’s salary is £30,901.

claimReview.title: How much do firefighters, paramedics and police officers earn? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This does not match any of the pay points on the scale for police constable’s pay. Police constable salaries range from between £21,654 and £41,130.

claims.text: The number of vegans in the UK has risen from half a million in 2016 to 3.5 million today.

claimReview.title: Are there 3.5 million vegans in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 3.5 million is almost certainly too high. The phrasing of the survey it’s based on means it could include people who were previously vegan but no longer are. The best available research we know of (from 2016) estimated 540,000 adults in Britain are vegan.

claims.text: Coronavirus may have been genetically engineered for “efficient spreading in the human population,” a bombshell new study has claimed.

claimReview.title: A study has not claimed the new coronavirus was ‘genetically engineered for efficient spread in humans’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong and the study does not claim the new coronavirus has been genetically engineered. It simply compares the genome sequence of SARS-CoV-2 with other coronaviruses, and suggests a reason why it might be spreading relatively efficiently.

claims.text: A “scary” picture of a child with Mickey and Minnie Mouse was taken at Disney World in the 1940s.

claimReview.title: ‘Scary’ Mickey Mouse picture wasn’t taken at 1940s Disney World - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture does appear to be a genuine vintage image of a child with Mickey and Minnie Mouse characters. But it was not taken at a Disney theme park in the 1940s, as the first—Disneyland—didn’t open until 1955.

claims.text: Immigration adds a city the size of Cardiff to the UK’s population every year.

claimReview.title: Net migration equals a city the size of Cardiff - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Net migration in the UK was 327,000 in the year to March. Cardiff has a population of 357,000. But this isn’t true every year. In 2014 net migration was 243,000.

claims.text: A woman has recently been filmed filling plastic bags full of petrol at an Esso forecourt in Tooting.

claimReview.title: Woman filling bags with petrol was not filmed in south London - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The video was published online two years ago and was filmed at a petrol station in Texas.

claims.text: Currently those without symptoms who test positive on a lateral flow are asked to order a PCR test and can only begin their isolation period when they receive the second result.

claimReview.title: Telegraph wrong to claim removing PCR requirement will shorten self-isolation period - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The self-isolation period starts when someone becomes symptomatic or, if they don’t become symptomatic, from when they took their first positive test, whether that was a lateral flow or PCR test.

claims.text: The proposal to introduce a points-based system would wreck the economy.

claimReview.title: What would an Australian-style immigration points system mean for the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Setting up a points-based system would likely involve leaving the single market, and most economists say that would have a negative impact on the economy.

claims.text: Per pupil spending is falling in real terms.

claimReview.title: Are there enough school places being created? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. It’s expected to fall in real terms over this parliament according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies and National Audit Office.

claims.text: London has the best schools in the country as a result of government spending.

claimReview.title: London schools outperform the rest of England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: London pupils outperform those in every other English region for getting good GCSEs, and experts say that a government-funded programme made a big contribution to this.

claims.text: In the UK, women earn less than men.

claimReview.title: Do women earn less than men in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true overall. The gender pay gap is 9.1% per hour for full time employees in the UK, or £1.32 per hour. It isn’t true just for part-time work or every individual age group, and the size of the gap varies across different types of job.

claims.text: 61% of the public would back Remain in a second referendum.

claimReview.title: Does 61% of the country now back Remain? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only true in polls that limit the choice to two options: remaining in the EU or leaving with the current deal. When other options are included, support is lower.

claims.text: This is an experimental injection, it hasn’t had phase three trials completed.

claimReview.title: Viral video includes lots of false claims and half truths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Analyses of data from phase three trials for all three Covid-19 vaccines authorised for use in the UK have been published in peer-reviewed studies in medical journals.

claims.text: Only 138,000 immigrants spoke no English at the last census, less than 0.3% of population.

claimReview.title: Immigrants learning English - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite correct. 138,000 people in the UK spoke no English at the last census, about 0.3% of the population. 118,000 of those people were born outside the UK, 20,000 inside.

claims.text: Over 92% of Southern services are running to time against the temporary weekday revised timetable.

claimReview.title: Are Southern trains running on time? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 92% of all Southern trains that had run by 8.30 am on Monday arrived at their destination within 5 minutes of their scheduled arrival time. By 4.30 pm, the same figure had fallen to 82%.

claims.text: If you count the ballot fraud in the US election, most pollsters clearly failed. If you don’t include the fraudulent ballots, most pollsters failed on a spectacular scale.

claimReview.title: Express opinion piece wrong to allege evidence of widespread voter fraud in US elections - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of widespread fraudulent ballots in the US election. It is correct that the predictions of many pollsters were found to be inaccurate.

claims.text: The Lancet says 6.5 million migrants have registered with GPs in the last 10 years.

claimReview.title: How many migrants have registered with GPs in the last decade? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: According to the ONS, that’s how many new GP registrations there were between 2007 and 2017 where the person’s previous address was abroad. But migrants who moved between homes in the UK may have been double counted and we don’t know how many were only here short-term.

claims.text: Indoor and outdoor air pollution claim at least 40,000 UK lives a year.

claimReview.title: How to interpret today's reports about air pollution - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estimates suggest that every year, the equivalent of 40,000 deaths in the UK are attributable to exposure to outdoor air pollution. Adding deaths attributable to indoor air pollution is thought to increase this figure, but it’s not known exactly by how much. This doesn’t mean that this number of people die prematurely every year because of air pollution, as it’s not the sole cause of deaths.

claims.text: People taking the vaccines have an 85% chance of survival.

claimReview.title: Video in a car shares misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The Covid-19 vaccines have a survival rate vastly higher than this.

claims.text: The rules of lockdown have changed. Households can no longer mix inside a residential property or garden. That means families should not visit another family at their home.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on lockdown rule changes are right for certain parts of England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for Greater Manchester and parts of Lancashire and West Yorkshire as of 31 July 2020.

claims.text: 400,000 women are sexually assaulted in the UK every year.

claimReview.title: Sexual violence and domestic abuse - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no way of knowing exactly. This figure is probably too low. The latest estimates say 533,000 women aged 16-59 were sexually assaulted in England and Wales in 2015/16.

claims.text: Being caught urinating in public could put you on the sex offenders register.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: does urinating in public put you on the sex offenders register? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Very unlikely. Being convicted of exposure requires an intention to be seen by others, and not everyone convicted of that offence has to register.

claims.text: The number of hospital beds fell by 25,000 in the last six years of the last Labour government.

claimReview.title: Who's cutting hospital bed numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, the number of overnight beds in the English NHS actually fell by slightly more—about 26,000—between 2003/04 and 2009/10.

claims.text: Dr Otto Warburg won the Nobel Prize for showing that cancer cannot survive in an alkaline, oxygen-rich environment, but thrives in an acidic, low oxygen environment.

claimReview.title: This post incorrectly claims everyone with cancer has a pH that is too acidic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect, he won for his discovery of the nature and mode of action of the respiratory enzyme.

claims.text: Between 95,000 and 135,000 school pupils did not return to school this term.

claimReview.title: Claim that up to 135,000 children have not returned to school needs more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is missing context. It is an estimate based on a snapshot of attendance on just one day in September 2021, and does not record persistent absence. The data we have can’t be used to reliably show the number of pupils that haven’t returned to school at all this term.

claims.text: New gender pay gap figures reveal 8 out of 10 firms pay men more.

claimReview.title: Gender pay gap: what do the new figures tell us? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: New rules mean all UK employers with 250+ employees have to report their gender pay gap. 10,000 employers responded, and 78% pay men more than women on average, based on median hourly earnings.

claims.text: All Covid-19 vaccines are experimental.

claimReview.title: Letter to MHRA is filled with false Covid-19 claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have repeatedly shown that Covid-19 vaccines are not experimental; they have been through sufficient safety and efficacy trials.

claims.text: If the UK leaves the EU, France and Germany’s economies will collapse.

claimReview.title: Viral post has flawed understanding of EU debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that this would be the case.

claims.text: The government will only open up extra housing for homeless people if the temperature is zero degrees for three days.

claimReview.title: What help is available for homeless people sleeping outside in cold weather? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A scheme like this exists in England where councils can choose to take emergency measures when the temperature is forecast to be at or below zero degrees Celsius for three days in a row.

claims.text: A video suggests US fact checking organisation PolitiFact endorsed a Fox News recording of Americans discussing health conditions that developed after receiving a Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: US fact checking site did not endorse a Fox News broadcast - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: PolitiFact did not endorse this video, nor does it vouch for its claims.

claims.text: Only 3,774 people under 65 have died of Covid in the UK.

claimReview.title: An Instagram post underestimates Covid-19 deaths among younger people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Up to the end of November 2021, 17,095 people under 65 died of Covid in England and Wales alone.

claims.text: The UK is the fifth richest country in the world.

claimReview.title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In terms of total GDP, it is the sixth- or ninth-richest, depending on which measure you use. In terms of GDP per capita, it is the 20th- or 27th-richest.

claims.text: A town with a voting population of less than 7,000 had 41,000 votes counted in a local election. This was then overturned by the High Court.

claimReview.title: A mistake did mean a town with a voting population of around 6,400 did have an election where 41,000 votes were counted - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true—a mistake in the local council elections led to this happening in Highworth, Wiltshire in May 2019.

claims.text: European patent 3172319B1 is a vaccine for the new coronavirus.

claimReview.title: These patents are not for the new coronavirus or its vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not. The patent relates to a vaccine for a virus which infects birds, which is another type of coronavirus.

claims.text: A photo shows a protest in Vienna, with the “vaccinated and unvaccinated standing together for what is right”.

claimReview.title: ‘Vienna protest picture’ actually old photo of Moscow - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photo was actually taken in Moscow in 1991.

claims.text: Mr Starmer explains in a clip why child grooming gangs weren’t prosecuted.

claimReview.title: This tweet misreports an interview with Keir Starmer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The clip is from an interview with Mr Starmer on changes to how police and prosecutors deal with victims of child sexual abuse, rather than a discussion of why specific gangs weren’t prosecuted.

claims.text: We spend more on national debt interest payments than we do on education, transport or the police.

claimReview.title: Interest payments on the national debt - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong on education: the government spends £84 billion on education compared to £33 billion on debt interest. Police and transport spending is lower.

claims.text: 47% of the population don’t earn enough money to bring in a wife or husband from outside the EU.

claimReview.title: You usually need to earn £18,600 a year to bring a non-EU partner to the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an old estimate for the proportion of British national employees who earned less than the £18,600 threshold. More recent estimates have put this at 41%, and it could be lower today. Non-British nationals who are settled in the UK can also bring in a partner if they meet the threshold.

claims.text: 82% of study participants who were prescribed statins or blood pressure pills were more likely to gain weight.

claimReview.title: Daily Mirror incorrectly reports the results of statins and blood pressure drugs study. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. A study found that the risk of becoming obese increased by 82% among participants who were prescribed statins or blood pressure drugs, not that 82% risked becoming obese. This study does not prove that these drugs caused the weight gain.

claims.text: The government has protected the schools budget.

claimReview.title: Schools funding: a manifesto breach? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was correct in the recent past, and in the near future in terms of the overall amount. But per-pupil funding once inflation is taken into account is set to fall over the next few years.

claims.text: Boris Johnson wrote in 2013 that the EU is “better placed to strike trade deals with the US, or China, than the UK on its own. More generally, there is a risk that leaving the EU will be globally interpreted as a narrow, xenophobic, backward-looking thing to do.”

claimReview.title: This Boris Johnson quote has been edited and taken out of context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These words are taken from a 2013 Telegraph article by Mr Johnson, but have been edited and taken out of context. He says these arguments are “untested” and also makes points in favour of leaving the EU.

claims.text: The number of votes held in the nine months since the general election is lower than after every election won by David Cameron and Tony Blair.

claimReview.title: Fewer votes in parliament: Aye or no? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, based on data from Public Whip. There has been a higher average turnout of MPs to vote since the 2017 election, compared to past elections.

claims.text: 28 countries are members of the EU.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: A photo shows thousands of Europeans fleeing to North Africa during the Second World War.

claimReview.title: Picture of refugees on ship isn’t from WWII - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The picture was actually taken in 1991, and shows Albanian people boarding a ship bound for Italy after the collapse of the Communist regime.

claims.text: The EU referendum was “advisory” only.

claimReview.title: Was the EU referendum “advisory”? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The referendum wasn’t legally binding, but there’s plenty of scope for argument about whether politicians should feel obliged to implement the result anyway.

claims.text: We pay about £350 million a week to the EU budget.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK pays around £250 million a week to the EU, not £350 million.

claims.text: US patent number 20120251502 is for Ebola.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This application number was for a strain of the Ebola virus but the application has now been abandoned. The virus was not created by those who filed the patent.

claims.text: Death rates are lower than previous years which proves Covid-19 hasn’t killed or is killing anyone.

claimReview.title: A fall in death rates doesn’t prove Covid-19 isn’t killing anyone - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While death rates in England have fallen to their lowest levels since 2001, Covid-19 caused one of the biggest spikes in death rates of the past 20 years. Although rates have dropped since last year, people are still dying from Covid-19.

claims.text: The minimum wage should be £18 an hour, because in 1999 one hour’s pay at minimum wage could buy you 72 Freddos, but in 2017 it could only buy you 30 Freddos.

claimReview.title: The price of Freddos has risen five times faster than inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Actually, you could have got 36 Freddos in 1999. More broadly, Freddos are not a good measure of inflation. The price of Freddos rose about five times faster than inflation from 1999 to 2017, but the minimum wage also rose above inflation in that period.

claims.text: A video apparently shows a wind turbine shattering and collapsing during high winds.

claimReview.title: This video doesn’t show an actual wind turbine exploding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video is a digital animation which was not meant to be interpreted as real.

claims.text: Four in ten fathers will not see their children this Father’s Day due to separation and family breakdown.

claimReview.title: Did four in ten dads not see their children this Father’s Day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Respondents were not asked why they or someone they knew did not see their children on Father’s Day. So it’s incorrect to assume all of these cases are due to separation and family breakdown.

claims.text: US-Patent 8835624 is for the H1N1 virus.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The patent with this number was for a strand of DNA that binds to the H1N1 virus, not the virus itself.

claims.text: Firms bidding for government contracts are being asked if they back Brexit.

claimReview.title: Do companies bidding for government contracts have to back Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are two examples so far of companies tendering for digital work with the Department for International Trade being asked, as part of the selection criteria for the job, to show that they are “committed to the best possible outcome for the United Kingdom following its departure from the European Union”. The government says that’s not the same as firms being asked if they “back Brexit”.

claims.text: Record numbers of young people are going to university, including more people from disadvantaged backgrounds.

claimReview.title: More young people are going to university - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly correct at the time, and now correct on all measures. Some figures produced by government statisticians showed a slight dip in the proportion of disadvantaged students attending university when the claim was made. Newer data now suggests that this was temporary and that the longer term picture is one of generally increasing numbers.

claims.text: The Labour Party plans to increase the basic rate of income tax to 25% to pay for social care for older people.

claimReview.title: Are the Conservatives right about Labour’s tax plans? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Labour hasn’t announced any plans to increase the basic rate of income tax. It’s said that it won’t raise income taxes for those earning less than £80,000. We’ve asked the Conservatives for more information.

claims.text: Theresa May has agreed a £39 billion Brexit bill with the EU.

claimReview.title: This claim about the UK's EU contribution is correct, but meaningless - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK government has agreed to a Brexit bill in principle, though an exact amount hasn’t been confirmed. The latest estimates suggest it will be around £35-39 billion.

claims.text: If you see someone trick or treating carrying a blue pumpkin, it could be a sign they’re autistic.

claimReview.title: Blue trick or treating pumpkin buckets are not official symbols for the autistic community - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The blue pumpkins are not an official campaign, but have been embraced by some people (mostly, it seems in America).

claims.text: Britain is the third largest military power in the world.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have the world’s third most powerful military? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A think tank ranked the UK third in the world for “military might” based on judgements about countries’ defence spending, nuclear power, infrastructure, personnel and readiness. But this isn’t the only way to measure military strength and a number of others rank the UK slightly lower.

claims.text: MPs are not following workplace Covid guidance such as wearing masks.

claimReview.title: This is what the guidelines are for social distancing in parliament. - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid guidance for MPs attending parliament does not involve wearing masks, but does include 2 metre distancing and limits on attendance.

claims.text: Former housing minister, Gavin Barwell, failed to give the go-ahead to a safety review, despite it having been delayed for years.

claimReview.title: Fire safety regulations: has the government delayed reviewing them? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A review of the fire safety part of building regulations was recommended to the government in 2013. The government said it would conduct a review and publish updated regulations in 2016/17. The regulations remain unchanged. The government says the work is ongoing.

claims.text: EU airports are punishing Britain for Brexit with long queues caused by tougher security checks.

claimReview.title: European airport delays—is Brexit to blame? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The stricter EU border controls were proposed six months before the EU referendum in December 2015 and came into force in April 2017. The controls affect all passengers entering and leaving the European border-free Schengen area, not just UK citizens.

claims.text: The EU has exported 41.6 million vaccines so far, 10 million of which were to the UK.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccine exports and the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is how many vaccines manufacturers in EU member states have exported.

claims.text: There has been a decade of efficiency savings in the NHS.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There have been a number of efficiency initiatives over the years. Trusts have been increasing their efficiency since at least 2008/09, according to official analysis.

claims.text: On existing trends, it will take 50 years for 50% of Queen’s Counsel to be female.

claimReview.title: Barristers and diversity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on the change over the last year, but that doesn’t tell us much about what exactly will happen over 50. That said, the essence of the point is correct: gender parity is a long way off.

claims.text: 20 hospitals declared a ‘black alert’ on 11 January.

claimReview.title: How many hospital black alerts were there this week? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's according to media reports, which say that 23 hospital trusts in England have reached the highest level on the NHS’s system for saying whether they are under pressure, or are otherwise under serious strain. The Department of Health doesn't use the term 'black alert'.

claims.text: Research shows that only 11% of people self-isolate when asked to do so by NHS Test and Trace.

claimReview.title: Why are people not self-isolating? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for those who were close contacts of people who had tested positive. A survey in the summer found that only 11% of these people stayed in their homes for the full period required.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation says that the coronavirus that causes Covid-19 is not infectious.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The World Health Organisation says that the coronavirus that causes Covid-19 is infectious.

claims.text: These images show a recently discovered new planet.

claimReview.title: A “new” pink and blue planet is not real (sadly) - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are computer-generated images, not photographs of a planet.

claims.text: This photograph shows the smallest bird in the world.

claimReview.title: A photo of a tiny bird actually shows a tiny sculpture - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This is a photograph of a miniature artwork, not a real bird. It is a sculpture of a robin.

claims.text: Doctors have concerns about the mRNA vaccine’s long term effect on fertility.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The NHS recommends that pregnant women get vaccinated, and there is no evidence the vaccines affect fertility.

claims.text: It took 51 days for the UK to go from announcing its first Covid-19 death to 20,319.

claimReview.title: Figure comparing arena capacity to Covid-19 deaths needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The first patient who died having tested positive for Covid-19 was announced on 5 March. The total deaths was 20,319 on 24 April.

claims.text: There are 1.5 million British people employed in businesses owned by EU citizens in the UK.

claimReview.title: UK jobs and EU-owned businesses - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2014, about 1.6 million people were employed by businesses that were EU-owned, or by businesses whose parent company was EU-owned. We don’t know how many of these employees were British.

claims.text: There are around 9,000 people living in the Calais migrant camp. In June there were around 4,480.

claimReview.title: Counting the number of migrants in the Calais ‘jungle’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The official estimate is that there are around 6,900 people in the camp, though local charities have counted around 9,100. Charities have suggested that different counting methods and migrants’ reluctance to speak to authorities may be behind the difference.

claims.text: A film from 1956 predicted the Covid-19 pandemic

claimReview.title: A video claiming to be from 1956 did not predict Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video is not from 1956, it’s from February 2020.

claims.text: The World Health Organisation changed the definition of what a pandemic is and removed conditions such as cases of serious illness or death.

claimReview.title: False claims from funeral director about facemasks, vaccines and the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There has been ongoing debate about a change in the text used on a WHO website regarding pandemic influenza in 2009. Covid-19 was declared the world’s first coronavirus pandemic in 2020, based on factors such as “alarming levels of spread and severity”.

claims.text: 312 Conservative MPs voted against forcing rented homes to be made fit for human habitation. No Labour, Liberal Democrat or SNP MPs voted against it.

claimReview.title: Did MPs vote against forcing homes to be made fit to live in? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is roughly correct—it was 309 Conservative MPs rather than 312. There are other regulations which compel landlords to deal with serious health and safety hazards, which weren’t voted on here.

claims.text: Already there is a mountain of evidence, direct and circumstantial, of widespread ballot fraud.

claimReview.title: Express opinion piece wrong to allege evidence of widespread voter fraud in US elections - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of widespread ballot fraud.

claims.text: There are many more deaths from heart attacks, strokes and aneurysms than usually seen, as a direct result of thrombosis embolisms. Clots used to be rare but now they’re common.

claimReview.title: Funeral director’s viral claims about vaccinated people not based in fact - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest data for England and Wales shows that diseases to do with blood flow in the brain, such as strokes and aneurysms caused by clots are actually down compared to the five year average.

claims.text: The British public believe that 7% of the UK population has died from Coronavirus, a number 100 times higher than the recorded-death reality.

claimReview.title: Why this poll gives a misleading view on how many people the public think Covid-19 has killed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This uses a mean average which isn’t appropriate in this context. Using the median, the average Brit thought that 1% of the GB population had died of Covid-19.

claims.text: 12% of the electorate voted for no deal in the 2019 EU parliamentary elections, not one third of the country.

claimReview.title: Did one third of voters support a no deal Brexit at the EU elections? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One third of votes cast were for parties that support a no deal Brexit. But as turnout was 37%, this amounts to 13% of eligible voters voting for a party that supports no deal. Not all people who voted for no deal-supporting parties necessarily prefer a no deal Brexit themselves, though.

claims.text: Scotland gets 20% more per head because of money that comes from England under the Barnett formula.

claimReview.title: Scotland spends 20% more per head on public services than England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s correct that spending on public services in Scotland is 20% higher per head than in England. But this money comes from the block grant from the UK Treasury, rather than from England specifically. An increasing proportion of the Scottish government’s budget also comes from taxes it raises.

claims.text: Roaming charges in Europe are lower because of the EU.
claims.claimant: Will Straw, Britain Stronger in Europe

claimReview.title: The EU has reduced roaming charges - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU has put a cap on the amount you can be charged for using your phone abroad, and prices have fallen. Networks won't generally be able to charge roaming fees at all from 2017.

claims.text: Lockdowns never slow transmission.

claimReview.title: Mike Yeadon wrong again on lockdowns and face masks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. They do slow transmission.

claims.text: The government knew before the Covid-19 vaccines roll-out that they would kill and maim and issued a tender for a surveillance system to monitor deaths.

claimReview.title: Viral video includes lots of false claims and half truths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This may refer to either an artificial intelligence contract the government awarded to monitor adverse drug events or the Yellow Card scheme which was established in 1964. 

In either case both are intended to ensure drug safety, and reports of adverse events are not necessarily linked to the Covid-19 vaccines.

claims.text: 21 million people in Britain are retired.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know for certain but a maximum of around 11.8 million people in the UK are retired.

claims.text: Cancer is on the rise.

claimReview.title: Healthcheck: cancer, diabetes and mental health conditions on the rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There were around 300,000 diagnoses of cancer in England in 2016—excluding non-melanoma skin cancers—compared to around 250,000 a decade before. The age-standardised incidence rate has risen for women and fallen for men in that time.

claims.text: An image shows a woman making an offensive gesture to Jeremy Corbyn.

claimReview.title: This picture doesn’t show a woman making an offensive gesture at Jeremy Corbyn - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image has been edited, the original shows the woman not being hostile.

claims.text: No one voted for Ursula von der Leyen.

claimReview.title: Was the new President of the European Commission democratically elected? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Ms von der Leyen was nominated to be President of the European Commission by the European Council. Her nomination does need to be approved by a majority of MEPs in the EU parliament (who were voted for in May).

claims.text: Many immigrants who speak no English arrived in the UK as grandparents.

claimReview.title: Immigrants learning English - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that older immigrants make up a disproportionate number of those who have no English, although they’re still in a minority. About 25% of migrants who can’t speak any English arrived after they turned 50.

claims.text: This Conservative government introduced parity of esteem for mental health services in the NHS.

claimReview.title: What is parity of esteem? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government wants to achieve equality between the physical and mental health services provided to people, but it’s not there yet. The Coalition and Conservative government both introduced commitments to parity of esteem in legislation and official documents. The idea has been talked about for decades.

claims.text: The government has “sneaked through” an amendment to legislation governing Personal Independence Payments.

claimReview.title: Amendments to PIP legislation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government didn’t formally consult the Social Security Advisory Committee, which it’s normally supposed to refer to on changes to social security regulations. But the government can do this if it’s a matter of urgency, which it claims was the case here.

claims.text: Jeff Rothschild said that to “finalise a new world order” we need a “3rd world war to exterminate 90% of the global population”.

claimReview.title: No evidence that Jeff Rothschild ever called for WW3 to bring about a ‘new world order’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that Mr Rothschild has ever said this. The quote has been circulating for many years, and has been fact checked many times.

claims.text: The Covid vaccine is an RNA vaccine. This will actually change your DNA.

claimReview.title: RNA Covid-19 vaccines will not change your DNA - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some of the Covid-19 vaccine candidates are RNA vaccines. These don’t alter your DNA, they comprise of mRNA that gives the body instructions on how to make the proteins on the surface of the virus.

claims.text: The proportion of the NHS budget spent on private providers rose much more quickly under the last Labour government than it has since then.

claimReview.title: How much more is the NHS spending on private providers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is overstating the available figures, which only show spending since 2006/07. The growth rate is similar under both governments, and is higher under Labour counting its spending up to 2010/11.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us the right to keep control of our borders and stay out of the Schengen agreement on free movement.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Remaining would allow us to carry out border checks but the UK couldn’t opt out of free movement—EU citizens would continue having the right to freely move to and work in the UK.

claims.text: The UK is spending more on foreign aid than the Home Office.

claimReview.title: Overseas aid after the Autumn Statement - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is likely to be the case within a few years, although exact comparisons are tricky. Last year the Home Office spent more than was devoted to overseas aid, but aid spending is due to increase a lot.

claims.text: The new coronavirus is 400-500 micro and for this reason wide enough to be stopped by masks.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The virus is 50-200 nanometres wide, and a mask, although sometimes necessary, won’t guarantee that you don’t get Covid-19.

claims.text: One in nine UK workers are migrants.

claimReview.title: Are one in nine UK workers migrants? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About one in nine UK workers were estimated to be foreign nationals in 2016.

claims.text: The number of Britons getting citizenship of another EU country has doubled.

claimReview.title: UK citizens getting citizenship of another EU country - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, between 2015 and 2016.

claims.text: The new daily allowance for peers in the House of Lords is £323.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit monthly allowance is more than House of Lords daily allowance – for now - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct as of April 2020.

claims.text: The BBC altered the headline on the front page of a Scottish newspaper.

claimReview.title: The BBC didn’t edit the headline of a Scottish newspaper - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The Herald changed its front page headline. The BBC first reported the original headline and later reported the changed headline.

claims.text: Theresa May claimed expenses for her full gas bill and full cell phone bills.

claimReview.title: Parliamentary expenses: is this meme about Theresa May correct? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Between 2005 and 2008 Mrs May made a number of office expense claims for sim-card hire and the purchase of a mobile phone. She also made claims for utilities bills on her second home.

claims.text: Human rights laws and court judgments cost the UK billions, or alternatively, millions.

claimReview.title: Counting the cost of human rights law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The direct cost to the state of European Court of Human Rights judgments has been several million pounds in the past 15 years. Claims in the billions rely on doing effective calculations for the wider cost to the UK, which is impossible.

claims.text: A Covid-19 vaccine will kill more people than the virus.

claimReview.title: Baseless claims about vaccine safety go viral on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this claim. There have been no reports of deaths attributed to Covid-19 vaccines in any trials. Vaccines are rigorously safety tested before they are rolled out.

claims.text: Doctors and scientists are recommending people not to take the vaccine.

claimReview.title: Inaccurate Covid vaccine ‘Q&A’: fact checked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Far more doctors and scientists are recommending people to take the vaccine than to not take it.

claims.text: A video suggests the Kabul airport footage of people running alongside a plane is faked as the people aren’t being blown over.

claimReview.title: No evidence Kabul airport video is faked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence the footage is faked.

claims.text: These images are all from Black Lives Matter protests in London last weekend.

claimReview.title: Half of these images of injured police officers are not from recent Black Lives Matter protests - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Three of the images are from last weekend’s protests, the others are from protests in the UK dating back to 2016.

claims.text: In the EU at least 83m people (27%) suffer from mental health problems.

claimReview.title: About 27% of Europeans are likely to experience a mental health problem in a year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research agrees that 27% of Europeans experience at least one mental disorder in a year. Population growth means it's probably over 120m people by now.

claims.text: Vaccines don’t stop you getting Covid-19 or spreading it.

claimReview.title: There is evidence vaccines reduce risk of Covid-19 illness - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Pfizer and AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines reduce your chances of getting sick with Covid-19. There’s some limited evidence the Pfizer vaccine may stop you being infected with Covid-19 at all.

claims.text: A video seems to claim starch is harmful.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, starch is a naturally occurring carbohydrate and forms part of our everyday diet.

claims.text: Tap water can return a positive lateral flow test result for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Tap water can’t test positive for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Putting tap water on a lateral flow test will break it. Claims that water has tested positive have no basis in fact, because the test is used incorrectly.

claims.text: British old age pensioners get £106 a week.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A full British state pension is worth £125.95 or £164.35 a week before top-ups (depending on when you were born).

claims.text: The Tories have scrapped Labour's policy to cap class sizes at 30 pupils.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: Has the cap on infant class sizes been scrapped? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cap hasn't been scrapped, but there has been a three-fold increase in oversized classes under the Coalition.

claims.text: The UK’s pension age is going up.

claimReview.title: Polish pensions are not directly subsidised by the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, the state pension age in the UK is rising from 65 to 66 for both men and women between March 2019 and October 2020. It will then rise again, from 66 to 67, between 2026 and 2028, and then from 67 to 68 between 2044 and 2046.

claims.text: More people have died this year through stabbings or shooting, and more young men.

claimReview.title: Have more people died in stabbings and shootings this year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have exact figures for this year yet. The closest data we have is for homicides involving stabbings in London until the end of last year and those involving stabbings or shootings across the whole of England and Wales in 2016/17. These show increases in the past year or two and more young male victims.

claims.text: Legislation has been signed which sets in stone the repeal of the European Communities Act.

claimReview.title: The government has not just “set in stone” the repeal of the European Communities Act - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has brought into force Section 1 of the EU (Withdrawal) Act (passed in 2018), which states that the European Communities Act is repealed on “exit day”. In practice, repeal of the European Communities Act is no more “set in stone” now than it was in the spring.

claims.text: Viruses can’t exist outside of computer animations.

claimReview.title: Covid virus variants are real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is completely untrue. Knowledge about viruses has existed since the late 19th Century, and are known to cause many human illnesses including the common cold, smallpox and herpes.

claims.text: 10,000 EU staff have left the NHS because they don’t feel they are needed or wanted any more.

claimReview.title: NHS staff from the EU: one year on from the referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 10,000 EU staff did leave the NHS in the year following the referendum vote (excluding those working in GP surgeries), but we don’t have information about why any of these staff left. This continues a rising trend in the last few years.

claims.text: Jodie Foster said that attacking the rich was “self-defense”.

claimReview.title: No evidence Jodie Foster said that attacking the rich was ‘self-defence’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There is no evidence that Ms Foster has ever said this.

claims.text: Asylum seekers in the UK get somewhere to live, a cash allowance or both.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, but only if they are “homeless or don’t have money to buy food”.

claims.text: More disabled people have entered the workplace during this government.

claimReview.title: Disabled people in work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 3.5 million disabled people are in employment, compared to 2.9 million in 2013. The employment rate for disabled people has also increased from 44% to 49%.

claims.text: There has been a 10% funding cut in real terms in sixth form and further education.

claimReview.title: Are sixth forms and further education colleges better funded? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Spending for 16-19 year olds in sixth forms and colleges fell by 10% between 2010/11 and 2014/15, after accounting for inflation, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

claims.text: Humans kill 1,300 fellow humans every day.

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct if just considering homicides and not including war or terrorism.

claims.text: 19 Liberal Democrat MPs refused to support a motion to stop privatisation of the NHS.

claimReview.title: It’s misleading to claim the Lib Dems refused to support an end to NHS privatisation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The motion in question would not have stopped privatisation in the NHS, nor would it have necessarily repealed the Health and Social Care Act.

claims.text: Last year the UK took in 558,000 people from developed countries alone.

claimReview.title: How many migrants are coming to Europe and the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 558,000 people is the total number of foreign nationals that moved to the UK in 2014, not just asylum seekers, and not just people from developed countries.

claims.text: A photograph has been taken of a giant rat.

claimReview.title: A surprisingly large rat is really just surprisingly close - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The photograph appears to be an illusion, which makes the rat look larger using forced perspective.

claims.text: The 1939 Cancer Act makes researching cancer cures illegal.

claimReview.title: The Cancer Act doesn’t ban the researching of cancer cures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. It makes advertising cancer cures or treatments illegal unless it’s to certain groups, mainly those involved in the medical profession. It doesn’t mention research at all.

claims.text: One in five patients delay going to the dentist because they can’t afford to see one - meaning 100,000 end up in hospital with preventable problems with their teeth.

claimReview.title: Labour draws unsubstantiated link between dental costs and hospital admissions - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not possible to connect all these cases directly to people not being able to afford dental care. The “one in five” figure is also a decade old and we don’t have newer figures.

claims.text: From September the rules for securing loads on HGVs are changing and a certain way of securing loads will become illegal.

claimReview.title: HGV securing point rules aren’t changing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: Increasing council tax to pay for social care is four times more useful in wealthy areas compared to more deprived ones.

claimReview.title: How much can councils raise to pay for social care? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was roughly 3.5 times the difference between the council which could raise the most to pay for social care by increasing council tax and the council which would raise the least per over 65 year old.

claims.text: These images of text messages claiming to be from Royal Mail, asking for a payment to deliver a parcel, seem to be scams.

claimReview.title: Beware of scam texts claiming to be from Royal Mail - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The messages are almost certainly scams.

claims.text: Tulsa County's first positive Covid-19 case has recovered. This individual has had two negative tests, which is the indicator of recovery.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, this patient has recovered according to official Tulsa County sources. Two negative tests is one of three official indicators of recovery among people with Covid-19 (who showed symptoms).

claims.text: The Pfizer vaccine trial was underpowered to detect rare side effects or efficacy.

claimReview.title: Critical report on BBC Newsround story is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true the study was underpowered to detect rare adverse effects although this limitation is typical of studies of its type. Rare adverse effects which were recorded were unrelated to the vaccine. The data in the trial also clearly shows far fewer children who had a vaccine subsequently contracted Covid-19.

claims.text: More FTSE 100 board directors are women than ever before.

claimReview.title: Women in work: the female employment rate, company boards and the gender pay gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The proportion seems to have fallen fractionally in the months leading up to March 2017, although that’s nothing compared to the large year-on-year increases that came previously. Slightly over a quarter of FTSE 100 board members are women, so we’re still some way off equal representation on company boards.

claims.text: All Japanese citizens who have received their Covid-19 vaccine are not permitted to give blood.

claimReview.title: Ian Brown wrong to claim Japan refuses blood from anyone who’s been vaccinated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Japanese Red Cross guidelines state anyone who has received a vaccine must only wait 48 hours before they can give blood.

claims.text: In 2018, the UK contributed £11 billion to the EU and received EU funding of £6 billion.

claimReview.title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Data is not yet available for 2018. In 2017, the UK paid roughly £12 billion into the EU budget and received around £5.5 billion back in spending from the EU.

claims.text: In June 2017 Conservative MPs voted against a pay rise for nurses.

claimReview.title: Claim that Conservatives voted against a nurse pay rise needs some context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
In June 2017 Conservative MPs voted against a Queen’s speech amendment calling on them to lift a cap on public sector pay rises, but later that year went on to lift the cap anyway. 

In 2018/19 nurse pay rose by more than the previous cap of 1%, but in some cases will still only have stayed at the same level in real terms.

claims.text: 80% of children are not being tested for coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Why school testing data doesn’t tell the whole story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on data which only includes tests reported, not the number of tests done. It’s impossible to say what proportion of children in England are being tested for Covid-19.

claims.text: Staying in the single market & customs union would not cover services.

claimReview.title: Brexit department makes misleading claim on Brexit options - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A necessary condition for being a member of the single market is accepting rules on the free movement of services across the single market.

claims.text: 21 people were dying daily of Covid-19 in October in England.

claimReview.title: A comparison of daily deaths from Covid-19 and non-Covid causes is incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. At the time the claim was made, the number of deaths reported of people who had tested positive for Covid-19 and died within 28 days was 169.

claims.text: Former Labour government minister Shahid Malik said it was his desire for Labour’s Muslim MPs to take over parliament and the country and replace British Christian culture with Sharia law.

claimReview.title: Former Labour minister didn’t call for Sharia law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The quotes are made up.

claims.text: Obesity costs the economy £27 billion a year.

claimReview.title: What does obesity cost the economy? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the best estimate we’ve got of the total cost of obesity and being overweight to the NHS and the economy. But it’s based on analysis that’s over a decade old and there’s a lot of uncertainty to the numbers.

claims.text: Lateral flow tests show a positive result with things like cola and orange juice.

claimReview.title: Soft drinks shouldn’t be ‘tested’ with lateral flow tests and asymptomatic transmission is not ‘quackery’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is inaccurate. While testing food stuffs can return what appears to be a positive result, this is a misuse of the test and returns an invalid result.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccines have killed 3,362 people in less than four months.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines haven’t caused 3,362 deaths in America - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the number of deaths that were reported in individuals in the US who recently had a Covid-19 vaccine, but there’s no proof they were caused by the vaccine.

claims.text: Covid-19 case numbers are highest in countries with high vaccination rates, showing that vaccines increase case numbers.

claimReview.title: Vaccines don’t cause Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Vaccines reduce the risk of getting Covid-19. This analysis is not proof of anything, though it is plausible that vaccination leads people to socialise more and so cases increase as a result.

claims.text: The statistics which show that 7,810 more doctors are working in the NHS than a year ago include thousands of medical students who are not qualified.

claimReview.title: The number of doctors working for the NHS in England has increased in the past year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The statistics include some final year students who could register as a doctor earlier than normal, due to the Covid-19 pandemic. This doesn’t mean they are “not qualified”.

claims.text: Scientists find sniffing rosemary can increase memory by 75%.

claimReview.title: No evidence that smell of rosemary boosts memory by 75% - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no record of a 75% boost beyond a quote in the Daily Mail. One of the study’s authors has since said it was actually 7.5%.

claims.text: Violent assaults on police officers have risen by a third in just four years.

claimReview.title: Are assaults on police officers rising? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The way data is collected was changed in 2017, so it isn’t possible to compare current rates with what they were four years ago. But assaults on officers that resulted in injuries rose by 27% in 2018/19 compared to 2017/18.

claims.text: The coordinates of the Great Pyramid of Giza is 29.9792458°N

claimReview.title: The Great Pyramid’s location isn’t as spooky as this post makes out - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only one coordinate, giving its latitude but not its longitude. It is also only one of many lines of latitude that pass through the pyramid.

claims.text: Less than half of the migrants entering Europe are from Syria.

claimReview.title: Just under half of migrants and asylum seekers who've crossed into Europe are Syrian - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to the United Nations. 48% of migrants and asylum seekers arriving in Europe by sea since January 2015 have been Syrian.

claims.text: One in four girls or women are in period poverty and are unable to afford sanitary products.

claimReview.title: Period poverty: how widespread is it? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 27% of women asked by a survey in England, Scotland and Wales said this was the case. But the survey wasn’t designed to be representative so it can’t tell us about the wider population. Other representative surveys have found the number is around one in ten.

claims.text: There are 480,000 young people who are hidden from the unemployment figures.

claimReview.title: Is youth unemployment down 40%? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This seems to come from a misunderstanding of a report looking at the number of young people who are out of work, and not claiming benefits or being supported by job centres. These young people still appear in the unemployment figures, although they will not appear in the claimant count figures of people claiming benefits.

claims.text: There is a £20bn ‘black hole’ in the EU’s finances, which will cost the UK an extra £2.4bn after the referendum.

claimReview.title: Is there a "£20bn black hole" in the EU's finances? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: By December 2014, the EU owed £19.4bn in payments agreed in the past to support poorer regions. The UK won’t be forced to make additional payments outside of its regular contributions.

claims.text: Under Boris Johnson’s tenure as Mayor of London, the murder rate was cut by 50%.

claimReview.title: What happened to violent crime in London since 2008? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Roughly correct. We only have figures for homicides, which include more than just murders. The homicide rate halved between 2007 and 2014, before ticking back up slightly.

claims.text: A picture shows a giant Nubian mummy found in North America.

claimReview.title: Picture of ‘giant mummy’ is a case of forced perspective - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture shows a normal sized mummy that was found in the Canary Islands.

claims.text: 21 million people in China have died of coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Mobile phone cancellations in China don’t prove that 21 million have died of Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim is based on the fall in the number of Chinese mobile phone subscriptions and shouldn’t be trusted.

claims.text: The OECD says that fiscal sustainability in the UK has improved.

claimReview.title: UK economy; what was the OECD's verdict? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Last year, half a million children went for three days’ emergency food supplies.

claimReview.title: Did 500,000 children need emergency food supplies last year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures refer to the number of three day emergency food supplies given out to children by the Trussell Trust, not the number of children receiving those supplies. 437,000 three day emergency food supplies were given to children between April 2016 and March 2017.

claims.text: Covid vaccines contain aborted babies.

claimReview.title: A post about coronavirus vaccines gets facts about their safety, ingredients, and legality wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Human-derived cells have been used in the manufacture of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine, but they are filtered out of the final product. They are replicas of a cell derived from a foetus in the 1970s. They are not used in the manufacture of other vaccines, such as Pfizer’s.

claims.text: Total travel and accommodation costs for SNP MPs were £79,852 in the last 12 months.

claimReview.title: These figures on MP expenses are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This most likely refers to 2017/18 when SNP MPs’ travel and accommodation expenses totalled £1.3 million, or £37,000 on average per MP.

claims.text: Fee-paying schools ‘save the taxpayer £20 billion’.

claimReview.title: Front-page error from the Times about how much private schools save taxpayers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. A report estimated that educating privately-schooled children in state schools would cost £3.5 billion per year.

claims.text: There was no breach of the Ministerial Code.

claimReview.title: Was Michael Gove right about court ruling over bias in contracts? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Cabinet Office has said there will be no investigation into whether there was a breach as Michael Gove was not personally involved in the awarding of the contract.

claims.text: Track and Trace is costing UK taxpayers £37 billion.

claimReview.title: NHS Test and Trace cost £13.5 billion in its first year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is the service’s budget for the first two years. In its first year, it spent £13.5 billion.

claims.text: A picture shows George Soros as an SS officer.

claimReview.title: George Soros was not a Nazi SS officer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The picture is of Oskar Gröning, the so-called “bookkeeper of Auschwitz”, and not Mr Soros.

claims.text: The government will fall short of its ambition to recover £500 million a year from overseas patients next year.

claimReview.title: How much can we charge people from overseas to use the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has an ambition to recover £500 million a year by 2017/18 from overseas patients not eligible for free NHS treatment in England. But it has estimated that the NHS will actually charge about £346 million that year.

claims.text: It will take longer to get from Wakefield to London using HS2 than it does today.

claimReview.title: HS2: is it faster? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Today a journey from Leeds to London takes around two hours. Using HS2 and going via Leeds, the journey could be around 25 minutes faster, though this doesn’t account for the time taken to change trains and board HS2, and compares current train times with the fastest possible estimates for HS2.

claims.text: In the UK on 1 July 2021, 66% had had their first vaccination, 49% had had their second, and there were 27,989 new cases of Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Vaccines have not caused daily cases to increase - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for the percentage of the UK population that had been vaccinated and how many new cases were reported on that date.

claims.text: If you think you’re having a heart attack, coughing repeatedly and vigorously could help you.

claimReview.title: Don’t attempt ‘cough CPR’ if you think you’re having a heart attack - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This should not be attempted. If you think you or someone else is having a heart attack you should call 999 immediately.

claims.text: More than 30,000 children aged between 10 and 15 now say that they are in gangs.

claimReview.title: How many children are in gangs? The data’s not good enough to know - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know the exact number, and it’s difficult to get an accurate measure of this. In 2013/14, a survey found 0.9% of 10-15 year olds in England and Wales said they were in a street gang, which implies around 30,000 children in England, but this should not be taken as exact.

claims.text: The Football Association gets £30 million a year in public money.

claimReview.title: Does the Football Association get £30 million a year in public money? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to the Football Association itself.

claims.text: The percentage of judges that are female hasn't changed much in the past year.

claimReview.title: Diversity among judges: a mixed picture - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Overall, there has been an increase from 25% in 2015 to 28% in 2016. But it's correct that there hasn't been any change in female representation among the most senior judges in the past year.

claims.text: 1 in 2.5 people will get cancer.

claimReview.title: This viral post understates the risk of Covid-19 infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. Cancer Research estimates that 1 in 2 people will get cancer in their lifetime.

claims.text: The hardest hit by austerity have obviously been the most vulnerable in society.

claimReview.title: Has austerity hit the most vulnerable the hardest? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's correct according to various analyses of tax and benefit policies. But the poorest UK households have also seen their post-tax incomes rise faster than any other group since 2010.

claims.text: Home video footage shows that no planes were used in the 9/11 terror attacks on the World Trade Center.

claimReview.title: 9/11 video doesn’t prove plane didn’t hit South Tower - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The video only shows the impact from one angle, obscuring the second plane completely. There is ample evidence planes were used in the 9/11 attacks, including many videos showing a plane hitting the South Tower.

claims.text: Funding for schools is down by 8% in real terms.

claimReview.title: Government school spending figures: correct but misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The IFS says spending per pupil in England fell by 8% in real terms from 2009/10 to 2017/18, and will be held constant from 2017/18 to 2019/20.

claims.text: Buses have been cut by nearly half.

claimReview.title: Public spending on buses not down by half in a decade - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is referring to a report which found that local authority spending in England and Wales on bus services had fallen by 45% from 2010/11 to 2017/18 (without adjusting for inflation). But this ignores a larger chunk of government spending which goes directly to commercial bus companies. That fell by 19% across England (excluding London) between 2009/10 and 2018/19.

claims.text: Snakes kill 137 people every day

claimReview.title: It’s true these things kill more people each day than Covid-19 has so far - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is an underestimate. Snakes kill around 378 people per day.

claims.text: The Conservatives have overseen the deepest cuts to post-16 education ever.

claimReview.title: 16-19 education saw the largest fall in education spending over the last Parliament - Full Fact
