claimReview.textualRating: Last Parliament saw spending on 16-19 education fall by 4% a year (after inflation). This contrasts with an increase of 8% a year on average between 1998 and 2009, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies (we don't have comparable data before then).

claims.text: A letter from a consultant at a hospital in Surrey claims that hospitals are empty and that there is no pandemic.

claimReview.title: This letter claiming to be from a doctor in Surrey is full of errors - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There are numerous inconsistencies in the letter which suggest it is not from someone working at a hospital in Surrey.

claims.text: 1,800 more patients are seen within the four hour A&E standard every single day compared to 2010.

claimReview.title: A&E waiting times: are they getting longer? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, comparing attendances in 2009/10 with 2016/17. More people are also waiting more than four hours. As a proportion of all attendances fewer patients are seen within four hours.

claims.text: The country wants no deal.

claimReview.title: Does the public want no deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some polls show no deal as the most preferred Brexit option. Others show remaining. It all depends which options respondents are surveyed about and how the question is asked.

claims.text: We have a trade deficit in the region of 65 to 70 billion annually with the EU.

claimReview.title: Trade with America: are we getting a good deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The trade deficit with the EU was about £80 billion in the year to June 2017.

claims.text: A text message claiming to come from a GP practice warning about high local Covid-19 levels is false and a scam.

claimReview.title: This text from a GP is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The GP practice has confirmed that it did send the text message and it is not a hoax.

claims.text: The coordinates of the Great Pyramid of Giza and the speed of light in metres per second are the same and this could be more than coincidence

claimReview.title: The Great Pyramid’s location isn’t as spooky as this post makes out - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: One line of latitude passing through the pyramid contains the same numbers as the speed of light in a vacuum, but there are around 20,000 other lines of latitude passing through the pyramid, so you have to choose the number deliberately to make it look like a coincidence.

claims.text: Scotland doesn’t have the power to recognise countries.

claimReview.title: Can Scotland recognise Catalonia as an independent state? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, foreign affairs are a reserved matter.

claims.text: Millions of people have been injured by the vaccines.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a common misunderstanding of the Yellow Card monitoring system. Suspected adverse events reported through the system are not proven side effects.

claims.text: Matt Hancock said the death toll rose by 111 in one day, the lowest since lockdown began, but it actually rose by 556.

claimReview.title: The government updated total Covid-19 death data with April and May deaths confirmed by non-NHS labs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The death toll was 111 on 1 June, but an extra 445 deaths were added to the cumulative death toll between 31 May and 1 June because of previously unreported deaths in England from April and May.

claims.text: Students from a deprived background in Scotland are half as likely to go to university as those from England.

claimReview.title: Comparisons between disadvantaged English and Scottish students are tricky - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is probably a reasonable claim, though the comparison is a bit tricky. It also doesn’t account for the substantial amount of higher education provided by further education colleges in Scotland.

claims.text:
Boris Johnson’s mother, Charlotte Johnson Wahl described him as an idiot with no
common sense” and said she hoped “he never goes into politics. He'd be a disaster.”

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s mum did not call him ‘an idiot with no common sense’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mrs Johnson Wahl never said this. It is almost identical to another quote, attributed to Donald Trump’s mother, which was also debunked.

claims.text: At the beginning of 2020 there were 4.3 million children growing up in poverty.

claimReview.title: Poverty is not the same as food insecurity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to data on relative poverty after housing costs. Other measures of poverty would show different figures.

claims.text: There are four young people with no underlying illnesses in an intensive care unit in Cork due to Covid-19, who had all been taking anti-inflammatory drugs.

claimReview.title: That ‘medical alert’ about severe Covid-19 cases in Cork due to anti-inflammatories is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It has been denied by the clinical lead of Ireland’s public health service and the whole message branded ‘misinformation’.

claims.text: British old age pensioners get a weekly spouse allowance of £25 a week.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A state pensioner may get an “Adult Dependency Increase” worth up to £68.35 a week if they have a partner who is financially dependent on them. They must have claimed before 2010 and it will no longer be paid from April 2020.

claims.text: Covid-19 barely mutated before vaccines were rolled out.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 mutated long before mass vaccine roll-outs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. All four variants of concern, designated as such by the World Health Organisation, were identified before mass public vaccination programmes began.

claims.text: There are more teachers in English schools now than in 2010.

claimReview.title: The number of teachers in English schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct, although the number of pupils has also increased. The number of primary school teachers has risen, masking a fall in the number of secondary teachers.

claims.text: According to NHS England figures, the number of people whose death certificates show death from only coronavirus, i.e. no pre-existing condition, is 1,265.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is the underlying cause of death for most people who die with it - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the correct number of Covid-19 deaths (but only among hospital patients) where no pre-existing condition was reported, up to 26 May. But this data isn’t the deaths “only” from coronavirus and doesn’t tell us what the underlying cause of death was. Covid-19 death was determined by a positive test result or where Covid-19 was mentioned on the death certificate.

claims.text: From 1997-2010 Labour sold off the majority of NHS hospital buildings to private investors.

claimReview.title: Labour hospital and acute care PFI contracts in England cost £1.4 billion in 2017/18 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. We don’t know exactly what proportion of hospitals are funded by PFI contracts, but it’s a minority.

claims.text: Italy disobeyed world health law from the WHO saying not to carry out autopsies on Covid-19 patients.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The WHO never said autopsies couldn’t take place.

claims.text: The employment rate has never been higher.

claimReview.title: Unemployment is at a 10-year low - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct according to figures available since the 1970s.

claims.text: The number of people waiting more than four hours in A&E has gone up by 557% since 2010.

claimReview.title: A&E waiting times: are they getting longer? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s not quite correct.  The number of attendances where patients waited more than four hours in A&E has gone up 334% since 2010. The 557% is referring to patients with an admission approved who are waiting to be admitted.

claims.text: Jeremy Corbyn has already accepted that there is going to be a run on the pound in the event of a Labour government.

claimReview.title: Does Labour expect a run on the pound? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour has not accepted this. But some party members do want to “scenario-plan” for how they would deal with this issue in government.

claims.text: The 2015 Conservative manifesto committed the party to staying in the EU single market.

claimReview.title: The Conservative manifesto on the single market - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The manifesto does say, “We are clear about what we want from Europe. We say: yes to the Single Market.” The manifesto also promises a referendum on EU membership, although staying in the EU and leaving its single market can be two different things.

claims.text: An image of Neil Armstrong’s space boots do not match an image of his footprints on the moon.

claimReview.title: The boots Neil Armstrong wore on the moon do match the footprints he left there - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Neil Armstrong wore moon boots over the spacesuit in the picture when he walked on the moon. These moon boots do match pictures of his and Buzz Aldrin’s footprints.

claims.text: There are nearly 5,000 more nurses and midwives now than there were in 2010.

claimReview.title: The number of doctors and nurses in NHS England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t a fair comparison. The most recent comparable figures show the increase was more than that: about 6,000 more FTE nurses, health visitors and midwives between September 2010 and 2016.

claims.text: An Israeli study found that natural immunity was better at protecting people from Covid-19 than the vaccine.

claimReview.title: Radio 4 programme featured Covid vaccine misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: An Israeli research paper did find that immunity from prior infection may be more effective at protecting a patient from Covid-19 than vaccination. However, the study also found that a combination of natural immunity and vaccine-induced immunity was even more effective.

claims.text: There is a very long list of people urging the Prime Minister to pause Universal Credit, including the Citizens Advice, the Trussell Trust, John Major and two dozen Conservative back benchers.

claimReview.title: Is there a long list of people urging a pause on Universal Credit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Citizens Advice and Trussell Trust have issued press releases calling for a pause, and John Major has recommended a review. The number of Conservative MPs calling for a pause is based on reports in the Telegraph.

claims.text: An extra £1 billion will be invested on mental health spending by 2021.

claimReview.title: Unanswered questions on “extra £1 billion” for mental health - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS England says it has committed to spending this much extra on mental health services in 2020/21 from its existing budget, over and above what is spent at the moment. If this is the whole rise in mental health spending in England over the next five years, then the spending will rise more slowly than on other parts of the NHS. If it isn’t, then we’re no closer to knowing how much will be spent on mental health.

claims.text: Analysis by the Children’s Society has found that more than 1 million children living in poverty would miss out on a free school meal because of the cliff edge.

claimReview.title: Free school meals and Universal Credit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from a rough estimate of how many children could receive free school meals under the new income threshold, compared to the number of children living in poverty. It is not a calculation of how many will miss out compared to the old benefit-linked system.

claims.text: In Scottish education, bright children from poor areas are two years behind their better-off peers.

claimReview.title: The attainment gap in Scotland’s schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 15 year-olds from poorer families in Scotland were found to be roughly 2-3 years behind their better off peers in recent research comparing performance in science, maths and reading. That’s one of many ways to measure the attainment gap, so this answer isn’t definitive.

claims.text: Vaccinated people are “transmitting artificial intelligence synthetic ‘affliction’ to the unvaccinated” with multiple effects including menstruation/fertility issues.

claimReview.title: There’s no AI in vaccines creating fertility problems in unvaccinated people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is completely wrong. Covid-19 vaccines do not contain artificial intelligence, affect fertility or transmit anything to unvaccinated people.

claims.text: Genetically modified yeast, animal, bacterial and viral DNA in vaccines can be incorporated into the recipient’s DNA causing unknown genetic mutations.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Modified DNA can be used in the production of some vaccines, but is very unlikely to end up in the final product. Even if it did, there’s no evidence it can cause mutations.

claims.text: There are now more people in work than there were before the pandemic began.

claimReview.title: Numbers ‘in work’ not yet back to pre-pandemic levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite. There are more payrolled employees, but the total number of people in paid work, including the self-employed, is below the level seen just prior to the pandemic.

claims.text: Tri(n) butylphosphate is in vaccines and is potentially damaging to the kidneys and the nervous system.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We can find no evidence of this being used in vaccines in the UK.

claims.text: An extension to Brexit would cost the UK £1 billion a month

claimReview.title: Would an extension to Brexit cost £1 billion a month? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only compared to a no deal exit in which the UK refuses to pay the “divorce bill”, and it doesn’t include payments back from the EU to the UK. If we leave with a deal, any extension up to the end of 2020 will not cost us extra, as the agreed financial settlement already includes these payments.

claims.text: Only 11% of people who need to self-isolate are being contacted.

claimReview.title: Why are people not self-isolating? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. We do not have a precise figure for this. Official statistics show that the proportion of known contacts being reached is much higher.

claims.text: There are a record 6,000 more doctors and a record 12,000 more nurses than a year ago

claimReview.title: Increase in doctors and nurses does not include Covid-19 returners - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, according to workforce statistics published by NHS Digital for March 2020. It does not include returners or trainees who joined the workforce during the Covid-19 pandemic.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines will change your DNA.

claimReview.title: Luminescent enzymes not in Covid-19 vaccine and other myths debunked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: They won’t.

claims.text: You must wear gloves to go to the supermarket.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct. No guidance on gloves has been issued for supermarkets.

claims.text: Wales has 11% of the UK railway track and gets 1% of investment.

claimReview.title: How much rail investment goes to Wales? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wales has about 11% of the rail network in England and Wales. Research suggests it gets 1% of only a subset of investment spending. When you consider other investment spending, Wales gets a higher share.

claims.text: It is illegal to drive in pyjamas in the UK.

claimReview.title: It is not illegal to drive with pyjamas on in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is not. The article this claim is based on is an April Fool’s joke.

claims.text: The UK government has licensed £4.7bn of arms to Saudi Arabia since the Yemen war started.

claimReview.title: The UK has licensed at least £4.7bn of arms exports to Saudi Arabia since the start of the Yemen War - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK has licensed at least £4.7bn of arms exports to Saudi Arabia and £860m to its coalition partners. These don’t include all licences but also not all licences result in goods ultimately being exported.

claims.text: Drinking a mixture of milk and cough syrup is poisonous.

claimReview.title: No, milk doesn’t make a poison when mixed with cough syrup - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False.

claims.text: Only 6,000 asylum seekers have been relocated from Italy and Greece to other EU countries under a scheme meant to relocate 160,000 people.

claimReview.title: How is the EU doing on refugee relocation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The target is now for up to 100,000 people to be relocated from Italy and Greece by September 2017, although fewer than that may qualify.

claims.text: That translates to £135 million a week.

claimReview.title: The government’s education funding figures need context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: School funding in England will be £135 million a week higher by 2022/23, not throughout the three years. After adjusting for inflation, this amounts to £82.7 million a week.

claims.text: You can check whether honey has been diluted with sugar syrup by washing it in water to reveal a honeycomb pattern and the honey’s genetic memory.

claimReview.title: These food facts are mostly incorrect or misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, honey does not have a genetic memory.

claims.text: In March 2018 close to 50,000 people were in receipt of these kind of benefits.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, 46,700 were in receipt of either asylum support or were failed asylum seekers receiving support because they were destitute. More recent figures show that total was around 47,500 in September 2018.

claims.text: Membership of the single market has led to wage suppression over the last 12 years.

claimReview.title: What’s the link between membership of the single market and lower wages? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen evidence to prove that membership of the single market suppressed wages in the last 12 years.

claims.text: One in ten nursing posts are vacant.

claimReview.title: NHS video, factchecked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, according to the Royal College of Nursing.

claims.text: Two authors predicted the coronavirus decades before the outbreak.

claimReview.title: Here’s what the books that “predicted” the Covid-19 coronavirus actually say - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A 1980s sci-fi novel describes a disease called “Wuhan-400” that bears little similarity to the new Wuhan coronavirus. A book of “prophecies about the end of the world” written in 2008 predicted that a pneumonia-like illness would spread across the world in the year 2020.

claims.text: The Chinese have built a railway station in nine hours.

claimReview.title: China didn’t build a new railway station in nine hours - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t quite right. The nine-hour construction project in Longyan was to upgrade an existing station by adding a new section of track connecting existing lines, not to build an entire new station.

claims.text: An image shows Arminas Pileckas, a 15 year-old student in Sweden stabbed and killed after protecting a girl in his class who was being sexually harassed by a 14 year-old Syrian refugee. Neither the Syrian boy nor his parents face any charges.

claimReview.title: This boy in Sweden was killed but the motive is unclear - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image does show Arminas Pileckas, a 15 year-old Lithuanian student in Sweden who was fatally stabbed while at school by a 14 year-old boy from Syria in January 2016. The motive is unclear. The boy wasn’t prosecuted as he was below the age of criminal responsibility in Sweden.

claims.text: We import flowers from Kenya under WTO rules.

claimReview.title: No, Kenya doesn’t export flowers to the EU on WTO terms - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Kenya-EU trade is governed by a trade agreement that supersedes WTO rules and removes tariffs on the import of Kenyan flowers to the EU.

claims.text: Tetanus is an anaerobic bacteria meaning it can't survive in oxygenated environments and because blood has oxygen in it, if the wound bled, there is no risk of tetanus.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on tetanus jabs gets a lot wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Although the bacteria requires anaerobic conditions, the spores can survive in many different environments for a long time and therefore it is incorrect to say that a wound that bleeds eliminates any risk of tetanus.

claims.text: Cleveland Clinic developed a Covid-19 test that gives results in hours, not days.

claimReview.title: Good news coronavirus list needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. The clinic announced that it is able to speed up Covid-19 testing after developing the ability to test on-site, but it had not developed a new test.

claims.text: The number of frontline prison officers has fallen over the last year.

claimReview.title: The number of frontline prison officers is falling - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. There has been a fall of a few hundred officers, with the exact number depending on how you define the frontline.

claims.text: EU membership adds up to £91bn a year to the UK economy

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study behind this claim estimated that being in the EU benefits the UK between £73-91 billion a year. These are very precise figures for a very uncertain impact.

claims.text: The number of new Covid-19 cases each day is roughly doubling every week.

claimReview.title: How quickly is the outbreak growing? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This comes from the faster end of a range of estimates.

claims.text: If the EU parliamentary election results happened at a general election under first past the post, the Brexit party would have a majority of over 240 seats.

claimReview.title: Would the Brexit party win a majority of 240 seats at a general election? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is reasonable based on the best available estimates—but it’s very unlikely that these results would be replicated at a general election. EU election results can’t be used as a proxy for how people would vote in a general election.

claims.text: The number of children "up for adoption" has fallen.

claimReview.title: Fall in the number of children being placed for adoption - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of children granted a placement order - one of the first steps before a child can be adopted - has fallen by 24% in the last year in England. The number of completed adoptions has continued to rise, but at a slower rate.

claims.text: Home ownership is at its lowest level in a generation.
claims.claimant: John Healey MP, Shadow Minister for Housing and Planning

claimReview.title: Home ownership: the lowest in a generation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct, taking a "generation" as around 30 years. The proportion of households owning their own home is at its lowest since 1984.

claims.text: The UK's deficit is one of the highest in the developed world.

claimReview.title: Is the UK's deficit one of the highest in the developed world? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UK's deficit is one of the highest among developed countries in the OECD, although it's difficult to get comparable figures that are all up-to-date for different countries.

claims.text: When Ireland cut its corporation tax rate, their GDP went up.

claimReview.title: Would a corporation tax cut more than pay for itself, as Jeremy Hunt suggests? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, recent estimates suggest the Irish economy grew by over 25% in 2015 due to companies relocating, although the impact on the underlying economy was considered more limited.

claims.text: A fully qualified nurse’s starting salary has not increased since 2010 when it was £22,000.

claimReview.title: Pay rises: how much do nurses, the police, teachers and MPs get paid? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures don’t take account of inflation. In 2018 prices, it was £25,000 a year in 2010, and in 2018 it’s £23,000.

claims.text: Only hundreds, not thousands, of people have died of Covid without any other pre-existing condition mentioned on their death certificate.

claimReview.title: Lord Sumption made several errors about Covid on Today - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. There were 15,883 deaths recorded with no pre-existing condition in England and Wales alone, up to the end of March 2021.

claims.text: CCTV footage depicts a woman’s drink being spiked at a bar. She begins to feel dizzy and is led out by the two men who are thought to have spiked her.

claimReview.title: CCTV showing woman’s drink being spiked is a dramatisation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The footage isn’t real. It’s a staged performance set up by a social media influencer.

claims.text: The American economy is growing fast.

claimReview.title: Comparing economic growth across the world - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: US GDP grew 2.3% in real terms in 2017, according to the IMF. That’s faster than the UK but slower than the EU. The IMF expects US growth to slow slightly in the coming years.

claims.text: The Prime Minister may not have had Covid-19 and when he was admitted to hospital staff were asked to sign the Official Secrets Act and two who refused were dismissed.

claimReview.title: False posts that suggest Boris Johnson didn’t have Covid-19 are based on a blog post now labelled as satire - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. It is based on a satirical blog post.

claims.text: For every £1 we put into the EU, we get back almost £10 in lower prices, more jobs and more investment.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on the economy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: To compare the single membership fee that we pay into the EU to an estimate for many elements of the financial benefits that we might get from the EU is comparing apples to a basket of vegetables. The estimate for our financial benefit uses a precise figure for a very uncertain impact.

claims.text: There were five deaths within 28 days of a positive Covid-19 test in the UK.

claimReview.title: 1,102 people haven’t died ‘of’ the Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct for at least one day in early May.

claims.text: One in four people is hooked on prescription drugs.

claimReview.title: We can’t say how many people are ‘hooked on’ prescription drugs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Research by Public Health England into the prescribing of five specific types of drug found there wasn’t enough evidence to say how many people were addicted. One in four adults in England received a prescription for at least one of the drug types they looked at in 2017/18.

claims.text: You’re just as likely to be hit in your home by a plane falling out of the sky.

claimReview.title: The chance of being killed by a cow and other AstraZeneca vaccine risk comparisons explained - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This probability appears to have been calculated by an academic in the US in 1997 so won’t accurately represent the risk to a UK citizen in 2021.

claims.text: Spain’s Health Ministry said that the SARS-CoV-2 virus has never been isolated.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 virus has been isolated many times in Spain—and elsewhere - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Spain’s Health Ministry said that it did not have its own samples of the virus, or a register of labs that culture them. The virus has in fact been isolated many times.

claims.text: 91p per person per day has been spent on Brexit since 2016.

claimReview.title: This viral post about the costs of Brexit gets a lot of things wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This seems to be derived from an estimate that the Brexit vote reduced UK GDP growth by £66 billion in two and a half years. That is not the same as money spent on Brexit, and it is an estimate based on modelling, not a definitive sum.

claims.text: Theresa May said sex offenders including paedophiles should be allowed to adopt.

claimReview.title: Theresa May didn’t say paedophiles should be allowed to adopt children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: She never said this. An academic wrote an article saying this when Theresa May was Home Secretary.

claims.text: High levels of EU immigration mean the government hasn't been able to cut net migration to the tens of thousands

claimReview.title: Is EU immigration to blame for missing the net migration target? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Net migration from other EU countries isn't the only reason the government hasn't met its net migration target.

claims.text: Official NHS data to 16 July shows there were 1,379 Covid-19 deaths in which there were no pre-existing conditions.

claimReview.title: Misleading claims on pre-existing conditions and Covid-19 deaths go viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That is how many people without pre-existing conditions died in hospitals in England having had Covid-19, as of 16 July.

claims.text: Hitler fluoridated the water in the concentration camps to sedate the prisoners.

claimReview.title: Not all these claims about fluoride are accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this.

claims.text: A picture shows the aftermath of climate strikers in Hyde Park in London on 20 September.

claimReview.title: This old photo of rubbish in Hyde Park isn’t from a climate protest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The picture shows litter left following an event in Hyde Park in April 2019 promoting the legalisation of cannabis use.

claims.text: 72% of the goods that leave Belfast port come to Great Britain.

claimReview.title: Trade across the Irish Sea - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claim hasn’t been substantiated and we’ve not seen wider evidence for this. In 2016, 85% of goods which left Belfast port went to the UK, measured by their weight. 56% of all Northern Irish goods sold beyond its borders went to Great Britain, based on the value of those goods.

claims.text: Chevening is funded by a charity.

claimReview.title: Chevening isn’t 'taxpayer-funded' in the usual sense - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not entirely clear. Chevening is funded by a public trust that is not registered with the Charity Commission, but that doesn’t mean it’s not a charity and it operates like one in many ways.

claims.text: The antibiotics gentamicin sulfate and polymyxin b are in vaccines and can cause allergic reactions ranging from mild to life-threatening.

claimReview.title: This image about vaccine ingredients is extremely misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Traces of these antibiotics can end up in certain vaccines, but would only cause a reaction in someone severely allergic.

claims.text: EU nationals have fallen as a percentage of those joining the NHS.

claimReview.title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU nationals made up 8% of new staff (whose nationality was known) joining the NHS in England in the year to June 2018. That compares to 11% in the year to June 2016. It’s possible that the number in June 2016 was unusually high.

claims.text: 50% of mental health problems are established by age 14 and 75% by age 24.

claimReview.title: What age do mental health conditions develop at? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was the finding of an American study that interviewed people to diagnose mental health conditions and asked them about when their condition began. The study’s authors said the findings were likely to be “conservative” and that some people might not remember when their condition started correctly.

claims.text: More than 80% of UK councils have failed to take in any refugees since 2015.

claimReview.title: Where are the UK's refugees? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in terms of the flagship scheme for resettling Syrian refugees, although the figures don’t cover the past four months. Many more councils have accepted asylum seekers through the regular asylum system.

claims.text: Drinking warm water is effective for all viruses. Try not to drink liquids with ice.

claimReview.title: Viral posts sharing symptoms and treatments for Covid-19 contain false information - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can protect you from viruses.

claimReview.title: Viral post about someone’s uncle’s coronavirus advice is not all it’s cracked up to be - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can either protect you from or cure diseases caused by viruses.

claimReview.title: List of symptoms and how to prevent the new coronavirus contains inaccuracies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that the temperature of liquids consumed can either protect you from or cure diseases caused by viruses.

claims.text: One in five claimants that have been sanctioned became homeless as a result of it, according to one study.

claimReview.title: Welfare sanctions and homelessness - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is missing an important caveat. Researchers found that one fifth of people surveyed who had used homelessness services had lost their home because of sanctions. The proportion of all people who are sanctioned who become homeless is probably smaller.

claims.text: Suicide is killing more people than Covid-19 in September 2021.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is almost certainly killing more people than suicide - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is almost certainly untrue. We do not yet have exact numbers for either cause of death, but the evidence we have on 16 September 2021 suggests that Covid deaths are probably several times higher.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us a vote on how government spends our money.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, remaining would mean UK citizens vote on legislators who pass government budgets (so does leaving).

claims.text: House prices have quadrupled since 1990, but average income has only risen by half.

claimReview.title: House price growth has outstripped income growth—but not by much - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not correct, because the income figure is inflation-adjusted, but the house price figure isn’t. In cash terms, income has tripled in this time.

claims.text: Employment is falling.

claimReview.title: Evening Standard wrong to say wages aren’t rising - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The number of people in employment fell slightly between April 2019 and July 2019, though the employment rate is still at close to record highs.

claims.text: Emmanuel Macron said the UK must pay in full the costs involved for all other member states for Brexit, currently 39 billion euros if it wants to remain in the EU.

claimReview.title: Emmanuel Macron hasn’t said the UK must join the Euro if it wants to remain in the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He hasn’t said this. Under the terms of the Brexit withdrawal agreement, we’ll pay the EU an estimated £39 billion “divorce bill” for outstanding commitments and liabilities. If we remain in the EU, we would pay our membership fee each year which would cover all these things.

claims.text: British Airways have released a statement telling their pilots that they do not need to have a Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: British Airways hasn’t told their pilots they don’t need Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: British Airways has confirmed it has not released any statement regarding Covid-19 vaccines to their pilots.

claims.text: Spending on NHS Scotland has gone up by £4 billion to £13 billion.

claimReview.title: NHS Scotland: how much is being spent? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the planned increase in day-to-day spending on health in Scotland between 2006/07 and 2018/19. It doesn’t account for inflation though, once that is added the increase is £2 billion.

claims.text: Health Education England have said they can no longer afford to honour this agreement and many will be pulled out of full time paid work early.

claimReview.title: This is what has happened with student nurses who volunteered to work for the NHS early - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Health Education England has said that student nurses who volunteered to work will be paid until 31 July, or until September if they haven’t yet completed the hours they need to qualify as nurses.

claims.text: Jean Monnet said a European superstate should be created without the understanding of European people.

claimReview.title: MP tweets inaccurate quote from quotes website - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This quote doesn’t seem to come from Monnet, but originated in a 1997 book when the author summarised what he thought Monnet’s intentions were in developing the precursor to the EU.

claims.text: Self-employed people will only pay more tax after this budget if they have taxable profits over £32,000, once you take every change to tax and welfare policies into account.

claimReview.title: Taxes, national insurance and the self-employed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’re not sure what analysis this is based on and we’ve asked for the source.

claims.text: Young people are in record levels of debt.

claimReview.title: Young people in record levels of debt? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t have enough information to say if debt levels of all young people—including those who don’t go to university—are at record levels. The average debt of university graduates is the highest it has been.

claims.text: Test and Trace is costing £22 billion.

claimReview.title: Putting outsourced contact tracing spend in context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The 2020/21 budget for Test and Trace in England is £22 billion, but only £4 billion was spent by the end of October 2020. Most of this is spending on testing, rather than tracing.

claims.text: Thousands of doctors and nurses will lose their jobs for being unvaccinated.

claimReview.title: Too early to say whether unvaccinated doctors or nurses will lose jobs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A public consultation is due to launch on whether to make vaccination mandatory for healthcare workers, but we don’t know the outcome yet.

claims.text: In 2017/18, thirteen current Lib Dem MPs claimed expenses worth between £103,709.34 and £210,245.50 each.

claimReview.title: How much do Lib Dem MPs claim in expenses? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers are in the right ballpark, although some are out by a few thousand pounds. This includes MPs’ staffing costs. The average claim by Lib Dem MPs was roughly the same as the average claim for all MPs that year.

claims.text: Sky News said there were 2 million people at the People’s Vote march on Saturday 19 October.

claimReview.title: No evidence that People’s Vote march had over two million people - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We’ve seen no evidence it said this. It reported the figure as “hundreds of thousands”.

claims.text: 125,000 care home staff have been tested for Covid-19.

claimReview.title: The government says 125,000 workers in care settings and 118,000 care home residents have been tested for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Department for Health and Social Care has confirmed 125,000 staff in care settings have been tested since the start of the pandemic.

claims.text: A vaccine for the new coronavirus has been created by US scientists and will be ready to use from next Sunday.

claimReview.title: US scientists have not created a vaccine for the new coronavirus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Whilst there are vaccines in development, it will likely be more than 18 months before they are ready to use. The image and videos accompanying the post are related to Covid-19 diagnostic tests, not vaccines.

claims.text: Alcohol deaths in England at record high after 6% rise in a year.

claimReview.title: Booze telling the truth? Is Britain sobering up or not? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, in terms of deaths that are a direct result of alcohol misuse. However, the number of alcohol-specific deaths per 100,000 people has remained virtually the same over the last ten years.

claims.text: Only one terrorism suspect in the UK out of 2,000 is under a curfew.

claimReview.title: How many terrorism suspects are under curfew? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is true, but not new. 

Going back several years, there have only been a few Terrorism Prevention and Investigation Measures restricting the activity of terrorism suspects in force at any given time – sometimes none. 

The estimate that there are 2,000 “terrorism suspects” is not official, but does seem to come from people who know about the issue.

claims.text: The average distance travelled to a Covid-19 test centre is now 5.8 miles, down from 6.4 miles last week.

claimReview.title: Data on how far people travel to get a Covid-19 test isn’t all that useful - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This distance is one-way, measured as the crow flies and does not include people who turn down a test based on distance.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU allows us to stay out of the Euro.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct (although so does leaving).

claims.text: The average age of a Conservative Party member is 72.

claimReview.title: How old is the average Conservative Party member? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s almost impossible to know exactly. Recent academic research suggests that 57 is probably the best estimate.

claims.text: In the past year, employment in the constituency of Aldridge-Brownhills has gone up by 88,000.

claimReview.title: Unemployment is at a 10-year low - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s wrong. About 39,000 people were employed there from July 2015 to June 2016 - about 4,500 more than the previous year.

claims.text: Between 1995 and 2011, EU immigrants contributed £8.8 billion more than they gained.

claimReview.title: More context is needed for these “facts about immigration” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s an estimate from a 2013 study. There are lots of ways to calculate economic impact of immigration and no single correct answer to that question.

claims.text: Income inequality is falling.

claimReview.title: Is income inequality falling? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest (pre-pandemic) official figures show it was rising or broadly stable. Recent analysis suggests it fell during the pandemic but is rising again following the removal of income support.

claims.text: Covid-19 vaccines don’t meet the legal definition of a vaccine.

claimReview.title: Influencer video full of untrue vaccine claims - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is unclear what legal definition is being referred to, but Covid-19 vaccines meet the legal criteria for medicinal products.

claims.text: Asymptomatic Covid-19 doesn’t exist.

claimReview.title: David Icke makes false claim that vaccines are ‘gene therapy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Asymptomatic transmission of Covid-19 does exist and has been shown to be an important factor in how the disease spreads. The number of overall asymptomatic cases however has been debated.

claims.text: Raising starting salaries for teachers to £30,000 will put them among the most competitive in the graduate labour market.

claimReview.title: £30,000 would be a high graduate salary for most new teachers in England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is fair. £30,000 would put graduate teachers among the top quarter of graduate earners in England.

claims.text: You are 2.5 times more likely to apply to university if you are wealthy than if you are disadvantaged in England. The same figure is 3.5 times in Scotland.

claimReview.title: What is the gap in university applications for the most and least advantaged in Scotland? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect if you are looking at university application rates but pretty much correct for 2016 university entry rates (both focused on 18 year olds). Some care needs to be taken over these comparisons because of differences between higher education data in Scotland and England.

claims.text: Government direct subsidy of the railways is around £5 billion per year, an increase of over 200% since privatisation.

claimReview.title: How much does the government subsidise the railways by? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. The five year average to 2017/18 was about three times more than the five years to 1991/92, before privatisation. Large projects like HS2 and Crossrail have affected this amount.

claims.text: The EU has put up trade barriers with African countries.

claimReview.title: Most African countries can export goods to the EU tariff free - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The majority of African countries have no tariffs on exports to the EU, although a handful do face some tariffs.

claims.text: Pubs and restaurants caused less than three per cent of coronavirus infections in the week before the 10pm curfew, official data shows.

claimReview.title: It’s wrong to say that only 3% of Covid-19 cases are caused by restaurants and pubs - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
This is a misreading of data which only covers outbreaks and clusters where more than one person has or is suspected to have a respiratory infection. 

This data does not necessarily confirm where a new case was picked up.

claims.text: There is a decrease in the amount of saline in the second vaccine dose compared to the first and an increase in the levels of harmful ingredients.

claimReview.title: There is no HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The MHRA told Full Fact that  there is “no difference in composition between first and second doses”.

claims.text: The EU puts a 30% tariff on cocoa from Africa.

claimReview.title: The EU doesn’t have a 30% tariff on African cocoa imports - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The maximum tariff on processed cocoa is 9.6%. The vast majority of African countries can export all cocoa products to the EU tariff-free due to various schemes they’re part of.

claims.text: Covid-19 is no worse than a bad flu season.

claimReview.title: London Mayor candidate wrong to claim Covid-19 pandemic is no worse than a flu season - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a flawed comparison, as the number of deaths from Covid-19 far exceeds the number of deaths from flu in a given season, despite the much stricter controls in place.

claims.text: A vial for the Oxford vaccine existed in March 2020.

claimReview.title: This picture of a vaccine vial from March 2020 is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. The vaccine has been in development since January and in trials since March 2020.

claims.text: You shouldn’t be visiting countries on the amber list for holidays.

claimReview.title: Govt advice differs for travel to some amber list islands - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government’s advice says people shouldn’t make non-essential journeys to amber list countries, but there are some exceptions for certain islands.

claims.text: The flu shot contains hydrocortisone, which may cause bone weakness, adrenal fatigue, weight gain and diabetes.

claimReview.title: Image on flu jab ingredients is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Two UK flu vaccines are made using hydrocortisone, so there may be traces of it in the final product. The problems listed here are potentially side effects of taking actual hydrocortisone tablets over the long term.

claims.text: Since fracking recommenced in Lancashire there have been 17 earthquakes in nine days.

claimReview.title: Is fracking causing earthquakes? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
There were 18 earthquakes, but they’re very small, and earthquakes of this scale happen thousands of times in the UK each year. 

Fracking inherently tends to cause small earthquakes, but has occasionally been indirectly linked with larger ones as well.

claims.text: The vaccines aren’t safe during or prior to pregnancy.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims that you cannot refuse the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Approximately 200,000 women across the US and England reported that they were or could be pregnant at the time of vaccination with no serious safety concerns regarding maternal or fetal outcomes. 

The Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists says that the vaccine “is considered to be safe and effective at any stage of pregnancy”.

claims.text: Suicides have virtually doubled since lockdown.

claimReview.title: Sun wrong to claim lockdown doubled suicide rates - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is very little evidence for this. What evidence we have shows no increase in suicides after the first lockdown.

claims.text: Violent incidents rose to 31,025, up 16%, of which 9,003 were on staff, which is up by a quarter in the year to March 2018.

claimReview.title: Violence and drugs in prison - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Assaults on staff were up a quarter from around 7,160 to 9,000.

claims.text: Fibres from face masks and test swabs are evidence of parasites.

claimReview.title: Fibres from masks and swabs aren’t 'Morgellons' - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. There is nothing sinister about these fibres.

claims.text: After leaving the EU, the UK will be able to abolish VAT on energy bills.

claimReview.title: NHS, EU funding and VAT: possible effects of leaving the EU - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU rules mean we cannot reduce VAT on household energy any lower than the 5% that’s currently charged. If the UK left, it would be possible to reduce VAT on household fuel below this rate.

claims.text: 74 people a day were stopped from entering the UK illegally between 2010 and 2015.

claimReview.title: Do 74 people try to enter the UK illegally every day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 75 attempts a day were prevented on average, but that doesn’t mean 75 individual people.

claims.text: If you arrive from the beaches of Northern France today you get a TV licence for free, along with a house to watch it in.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that migrants get a free TV licence - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to migrants arriving in the UK across the English Channel, and is not correct. Migrants are expected to pay for their own TV licence, and their accommodation can include hostels and bed and breakfasts.

claims.text: Four million people are employed by the government.

claimReview.title: The figures in this post give an inaccurate view of Britain - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 5.4 million people were recorded as working in the public sector across the UK in September 2019, of which 3.2 million are employed by central government.

claims.text: Social care has been slashed by £7.7 billion since 2010.

claimReview.title: Claim about social care spending and nurse numbers needs more context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This figure refers to the savings councils in England report having had to make since 2010 on adult social care spending—through things like efficiency measures, renegotiating contracts, innovation, reducing and stopping services. It’s not the amount their budgets were reduced by, which have fallen by much less.

claims.text: Home Office figures suggest new immigration rules will mean a reduction in unskilled EU migration of 90,000.

claimReview.title: Unpublished Home Office target needs explaining - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number of unskilled EU migrants coming to work in the UK is already less than 90,000, so the government cannot cut it by 90,000 with changes to immigration rules.

claims.text: The European Commission is setting up an EU army to protect the borders.

claimReview.title: A new EU border agency, or an EU army? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to Commission proposals for a new border agency with increased powers, including the ability to operate in a country despite its objections. Most, if not all, of its border guards would be provided by member countries. The UK isn't covered by this plan.

claims.text: The BBC is increasing the licence fee by £3.

claimReview.title: The government sets the licence fee, not the BBC - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The licence fee is increasing by £3 a year but it is the government and not the BBC which sets the fee.

claims.text: The current Covid vaccines are obsolete as they do not cover the new variants.

claimReview.title: Conservative Woman article falsely claims vaccines don’t work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. All the vaccines mentioned have shown efficacy against the main Covid-19 variants, albeit to varying degrees.

claims.text: There are 52,000 nurses in training.

claimReview.title: What’s happening to nursing numbers? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Department of Health says this figure comes from Health Education England. We’ve asked them for more information.

claims.text: Around 16% of the working age adult population has a disability.

claimReview.title: How many people have a disability? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is broadly correct but slightly too low. An estimated 19% of working age adults have a disability, using the Equality Act definition.

claims.text: Young people tend to be lower paid, in insecure work and spend more of their income on travel.

claimReview.title: Would free bus travel save young people £1,000 a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Younger workers tend to earn less and a bigger proportion of gig workers are young than in more traditional forms of employment. Compared to all households, younger ones spend slightly more on public transport.

claims.text: Rife machines can cure over 5,000 diseases including all cancers, infections and more.

claimReview.title: No evidence Rife machines can cure all cancers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There isn’t sufficient evidence to back up this claim. Cancer Research UK says that “there is no reliable evidence to use it as a treatment for cancer”.

claims.text: Net migration was around 160,000 in 2009/10 and now it’s at record high levels of 380,000.

claimReview.title: Net migration is at a record high, but it's not 380,000 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The figures are wrong, but it’s correct to say that net migration is currently the highest estimate on record. Net migration was 336,000 in the latest set of figures, which count the year to June 2015. In 2009/10 it was thought to be around 205,000-240,000. An earlier set of estimates for 2009 (now revised) put the net migration figure closer to 160,000.

claims.text: Cannabis use causes a quarter of psychosis cases.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: does cannabis cause a quarter of psychosis cases? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's not what the research shows. High-potency cannabis (or skunk) is linked to 24% of cases in South London, but that's not representative of the rest of the country.

claims.text: New legislation has been introduced to change laws on workplace rights.

claimReview.title: Government proposes new zero hour contract legislation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has made a statement to parliament saying they intend to introduce new laws to change workers’ rights. The exact wording of the proposed law hasn’t been published yet.

claims.text: After it broke a contract with Samsung, Argos is now selling microwaves for £1.78.

claimReview.title: Argos isn’t selling microwaves for £1.78 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Neither the offer nor the claim about Samsung are genuine, as confirmed by Argos.

claims.text: Under the last government, social welfare cases receiving legal aid fell from 470,000 to 53,000.
claims.claimant: Lord Falconer, Shadow Secretary of State for Justice

claimReview.title: Far fewer social welfare cases get legal aid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures are correct. Cases about community care, debt, employment, housing and welfare benefits that got publicly funded legal advice and assistance fell 89% from 2009/10 to 2013/14.

claims.text: If you are registered to vote in two places you are only allowed to vote in one location in national elections but can choose which at the last minute.

claimReview.title: You can register to vote in two places - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Hate crimes spiked by 41%, following the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: Hate crime and the EU referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Yes, the number of hate crimes recorded by the police in July 2016 was 41% higher in July 2016 than in July 2015. There was a sharp increase immediately after the EU referendum.

claims.text: A post suggests that if masks work, it doesn't matter if other people aren't wearing them as long as you are.

claimReview.title: Protecting others is a reason to wear a facemask - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Masks can sometimes play a role in protecting the wearer, but another important action of mask wearing is to reduce the release of infected particles from an infected wearer. This ‘source control’ effect can help to protect others.

claims.text: Net migration to the UK has fallen by 49,000 to 273,000.

claimReview.title: Too soon to say if EU referendum has led to genuine falls in immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Estimates show this for the 12 months leading to September 2016. The changes aren’t statistically significant so we can’t say for sure, but may well be showing a genuine fall.

claims.text: Myocarditis has been listed on Covid-19 vaccine labels in Japan as a potential side effect.

claimReview.title: Japan has never enforced a Covid-19 vaccine mandate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true. However, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare says the chances of contracting it are “extremely rare”.

claims.text: An image from NASA shows the Northern Lights from space.

claimReview.title: This isn’t a real image of the Northern Lights from space - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This particular image is a computer generation, not a real photo, although many real photos of the Northern Lights taken from space exist.

claims.text: A British soldier was attacked by a Muslim gang that hates the armed forces.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that this man was attacked because he’s in the armed forces - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A member of the armed forces was hit by a car outside a nightclub in West Yorkshire, sustaining serious injuries. The police and the judge sentencing his attacker have both said there is no evidence that the attack was politically motivated. The judge said Mr Adams-Mitchell was not the intended victim of the attack.

claims.text: One in 14 adults was abused as a child in England and Wales.

claimReview.title: The scale of abuse during childhood: how much do we know? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to sexual abuse and is roughly correct according to estimates from the Crime Survey.

claims.text: Boris Johnson’s address on 4 January was filmed before 8pm and not live as claimed, and you can tell from the time on his watch.

claimReview.title: The time on Boris Johnson’s watch does not prove his televised address wasn’t live - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: His watch showed it was 8pm and the address was live.

claims.text: The EU budget will be up 6.9% in 2016, throwing off the Prime Minister's promise to have secured a 3% cut.

claimReview.title: The EU budget has its limits - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU budget spending commitments will be lower in 2016 than in 2015, and the 3% cut referred to by the Prime Minister was to spending limits over seven years, not spending in any particular year.

claims.text: Vaccines are ineffective.

claimReview.title: Former MEP wrongly uses UK Covid-19 data - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t true. Data in recent months shows vaccination lowers the risk of testing positive for Covid-19 and for having an infection with symptoms.

claims.text: The UK would pay 62% more into the EU budget than it gets back in spending by 2022 if it stays in the EU.

claimReview.title: This post about EU budget contributions is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This can’t be known, because we don’t yet know what the EU budget will look like for 2021-27, and it is being planned on the assumption that the UK is not a part of it.

claims.text: US patent 10130701 is for coronavirus.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This number is not a patent for the new Wuhan virus, Covid-19. It’s a patent for a weakened version of a virus in the same family as Covid-19, a family which includes the common cold and SARS.

claims.text: A record number of Britons are now in work.

claimReview.title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Around 32 million people are in work, the highest since records began. Around 76% of all adults aged 16-64 are in work.

claims.text: A video shows Matt Hancock saying the WHO told him there is no evidence for asymptomatic transmission of Covid-19.

claimReview.title: WHO advice about asymptomatic transmission has changed since the start of the pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He did say this, when talking about how the advice over time changed. It is now known that asymptomatic transmission is a factor in the spread of Covid-19.

claims.text: An MP’s salary is £74,000.

claimReview.title: How much do firefighters, paramedics and police officers earn? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was an MP’s salary in 2016/17. It is now £81,932.

claims.text: Corporation tax has been cut

claimReview.title: Tax cuts: corporation tax, inheritance, capital gains and the bank levy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The rate of corporation tax has been cut step-by-step since 2010. That’s been partly but not completely offset by a reduction in allowances and efforts to tackle tax avoidance.

claims.text: Spending on social care is down 8% since 2010.

claimReview.title: NHS viral image factcheck - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies last year said that between 2009/10 and 2016/17, councils’ spending on adult social care in England fell 8% in real terms. Newer analysis says that it fell by 6% over the same period. We’ve asked it for more information.

claims.text: The Great Train Robbery robbers served at least 30 years.

claimReview.title: Claim about the Kray Twins and great train robbers’ prison releases are false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Several of those involved in the Great Train Robbery were sentenced to 30 years in prison. But none that we’re aware of served the whole 30 years for that crime.

claims.text: The budget in Scotland has been continually cut by Westminster.

claimReview.title: Has the Scottish Government budget increased or decreased since 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s been cut, but not every year. It fell between 2010-11 and 2013-14 any way you look at it. Since then it’s risen or stayed the same, depending what you include.

claims.text: Covid-19 has never been isolated in a laboratory. It has never been proven to exist.

claimReview.title: Video in a car shares misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Covid-19 is the disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. This virus has been isolated in laboratories many times.

claims.text: 1.7 million people in Britain today are unemployed.

claimReview.title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, as of July-September 2016. Although the figure hasn’t been adjusted to take into account the time of year, and by historic standards that’s a fairly low level of unemployment.

claims.text: Taxpayers will pick up a £2 million security bill for Eugenie’s wedding.

claimReview.title: The Princess and the PCs: What will policing Princess Eugenie’s wedding cost? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This hasn’t been confirmed, but seems in the right ballpark based on reported costs for previous weddings.

claims.text: If you collect a parcel at the Post Office you need a driving licence or a passport.

claimReview.title: You don’t usually need photo ID to pick up a parcel - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: You don’t need photographic ID to pick up a parcel from the Post Office but you do need some form of ID.

claims.text: Clouds don’t move in NASA footage of Earth rotating. This is further proof of a cloud map, used across a number of NASA images.

claimReview.title: NASA didn’t paste a picture of the Earth into photos from the moon - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video used to make this point is not fast enough for us to perceive the movement of clouds. Movement can be seen in faster versions of the video.

claims.text: Consuming certain plants will stop women from getting pregnant.

claimReview.title: These plants won’t stop you getting pregnant, and some could cause you harm - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: None of these are effective forms of birth control, and some can even cause harm to women.

claims.text: A new police officer in 2010 has seen a real-terms increase in pay of 32%.

claimReview.title: Have some police officers had a 32% pay rise? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct given the pay progression this officer would have received if continually in post, but this increase is unlikely to reflect the experience of most officers today.

claims.text: Cucumber kills cancer cells.

claimReview.title: There’s no evidence that eating cucumbers stops lung cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence that eating cucumbers has any effect on treating lung cancer.

claims.text: The deficit in Scotland is three times that of the UK as a whole.

claimReview.title: How big is Scotland’s deficit compared to the UK as a whole? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct as a proportion of GDP, whether or not revenue from the North Sea is included.  In monetary terms, the UK deficit is larger.

claims.text: An image from Parliament shows that no Labour MPs turned up to a debate about the NHS.

claimReview.title: A nearly empty House of Commons may not be a sign that no one cares - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image appears to be real, but it comes from an adjournment debate. It is common for MPs (of all parties) to not attend adjournment debates, because they do not involve voting on decisions.

claims.text: Elephant tusks and rhino horns are being dyed pink to stop poachers killing these animals.

claimReview.title: The images in this post about the rhino horn and ivory trade have been digitally altered but the scheme is real - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This claims refers to a real scheme to deter poachers, but dyeing rhino horns does not lead to the bright exterior as the picture suggests—the pictures have been doctored. This scheme has only been used on rhinos, not elephants.

claims.text: Leaving the customs union and single market will cost every person in Scotland £1,600.

claimReview.title: Claim that Brexit will cost every Scot £1,600 is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This comes from a dated estimate of how much less Scottish GDP will grow by 2030 in such a scenario, compared to remaining in the EU. It doesn’t represent a cash loss, but is how much smaller Scottish GDP would be per person compared to remaining in the EU.

claims.text: The prison population has doubled in 25 years.

claimReview.title: The rising prison population - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It almost has, from 45,000 at the start of the 1990s to around 86,000 today in England and Wales. Prisons have been overcrowded almost constantly for the last two decades.

claims.text: The Covid-19 vaccine will cause infertility in younger men.

claimReview.title: There isn’t pork in Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no reason to believe this. If anything, vaccination may help protect any effect on fertility caused by the virus itself.

claims.text: 23.5 million people in England haven’t had a single dose of Covid-19 vaccine.

claimReview.title: How many people in England are unvaccinated? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. This is based on flawed maths and is too high. There are two estimates for the true figure, depending on which population estimate you use, but both are considerably lower.

claims.text: The government has told your GP to hand over your health data, including sexual and mental health data to third parties for payment.

claimReview.title: The deadline for opting out of the NHS GP data collection has changed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS Digital will start collecting GP data which will include information of this nature, though it will be pseudonymised. NHS Digital says it charges organisations for its services processing and delivering the data.

claims.text: The rollout of liaison therapy may have contributed to a 6% fall in suicide rates.

claimReview.title: Mental health crisis care - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This fall did happen but the link can’t be proved. Experts say liaison services can play a role in reducing suicides, but there’s no way to prove the extent to which one caused the other, and the rates tend to fluctuate from year to year anyway.

claims.text: There's no evidence there is a Covid-19 virus. The illusion of it has been manifested by using a fake test and fraudulent death certificates.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is real and not a government euthanasia policy - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Covid-19 is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. This has been proven using laboratory testing and seen through medical imaging.

Covid-19 tests can accurately detect current or recent Covid-19 infection, and the cause of death on a death certificate is recorded by a doctor. There’s no evidence that these have been falsified.

claims.text: The UK population is 61.6 million, of whom 194,000 are refugees.

claimReview.title: Ask Full Fact: how many refugees are in the UK population? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The latest estimate of the UK population was 64.6 million, as of 2014. The UN's latest estimate suggests that there were 117,000 refugees living in the UK that year.

claims.text: Five out of six EU immigrants have indefinite leave to remain in the UK, or will have by the time the UK leaves the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit: which EU citizens will have the right to stay in the UK? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not fully substantiated by the evidence and will depend on the arrangements we make upon leaving the EU. Whatever happens, EU citizens are not going to be forced to leave en masse.

claims.text: Symptoms of Covid-19 include nausea, hair loss, bone marrow damage.

claimReview.title: These claims about the new coronavirus and 5G are unfounded - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Symptoms have been reported as including fever, coughing and shortness of breath.

claims.text: The Treasury loses £40 billion each year due to tax evasion and avoidance by the super-rich and the corporate elite.

claimReview.title: Does the Treasury lose £40 billion each year to the super-rich? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s a long way off from HMRC’s estimates, although there’s necessarily a lot of uncertainty here.

claims.text: Luc Montagnier has said all vaccinated people will die within two years.

claimReview.title: No evidence Nobel Laureate said vaccinated people will die in two years - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence he said this.

claims.text: Deaths rose by 650 above average during the UK heatwave

claimReview.title: How many deaths from this summer’s heatwave? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for 23 June to 13 July this year in England and Wales. The increase has been higher in previous years, and we won’t have a full picture until better statistics come out later in the year.  High temperatures have been linked to more deaths in the past.

claims.text: Council homes are being sold off without being replaced.

claimReview.title: Council house replacements - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Only one in six council houses sold under Right to Buy are being replaced. Overall there are fewer homes available for “social rent” or equivalent in the social housing sector. There are increasing numbers available for higher “affordable rents”.

claims.text: Our railways cost 40% more to run than others in Europe.

claimReview.title: Britain's privatised rail: 40% too expensive? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Research carried out for the government has shown a 40% cost-efficiency gap between Britain and four European nations. But it's now quite dead.

claims.text: The net migration target could only have been met if immigration of non-EU citizens was cut.

claimReview.title: The net migration target was never likely to have been met - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. Significant reductions to non-EU immigration will have been needed given the government can’t control the volume of EU immigration. But non-EU levels are now roughly what they were back in 2010, so the target is far from being met.

claims.text: 60% of our trade is through EU trade agreements.

claimReview.title: Over half of UK exports were via EU trade agreements in 2016 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In 2016, around 54% of UK exports went to states with which the EU had a full or provisional trade agreement (including EU member states).

claims.text: Professor Dr Tasuku Honjo, caused a sensation today in the media by saying that the corona virus is not natural.

claimReview.title: A Nobel Prize-winning immunologist has not said coronavirus is manmade, as claimed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Professor Honjo has denied saying this and there is no evidence that he ever did.

claims.text: Child poverty rose by half a million under the Coalition government.

claimReview.title: Child poverty—it's up but it's also down - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's true of one measure—absolute poverty is up from 2009/10. But relative poverty is down.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means we wouldn’t have to pay a £39 billion divorce bill to the EU.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
Under the withdrawal deal we have to pay the EU an estimated bill of £39 billion. 

With no deal, it’s uncertain how much of that we’d have to pay, if anything.

claims.text: The UK government no longer considers Covid-19 to be a “high consequence infectious disease”.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 may not be a “high consequence infectious disease”, but it is a real emergency - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, because it no longer meets the criteria for an HCID. This doesn’t mean that it is no longer considered dangerous.

claims.text: Putting a doctor through medical school “costs the taxpayer” £230,000.

claimReview.title: The cost of training a doctor - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s wrong. About £64,300 of that comes in student loans, most of which the government gets back. The rest comes in grants for tuition, living costs and clinical placements.

claims.text: A photo shows a diesel generator and says there are patio heaters going at full blast in the bar area, at an Extinction Rebellion protest.

claimReview.title: This is not a diesel generator at an Extinction Rebellion protest - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This photo was taken at an American music festival.

claims.text: 400,000 more children are in absolute poverty under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Are 400,000 more children in absolute poverty since 2010? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The exact change in child poverty under the Conservatives depends on the year you compare from, but none of the absolute measures shows this. Relative child poverty was estimated to have risen by 400,000 between 2010/11 and 2015/16—both including and excluding housing costs.

claims.text: The salary of a newly qualified nurse was £22,000 in 2010 and the same in 2018.

claimReview.title: This tweet on public sector pay doesn’t factor in inflation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This doesn’t take into account inflation. In 2018 prices, a fully qualified nurse’s starting salary was £24,900 in 2010 and £23,000 in 2018.

claims.text: The government has committed to keep meeting the target of spending 2% of GDP on defence.

claimReview.title: Government defence spending is 2% of GDP - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In October 2017, the Defence Secretary described 2% as the “minimum NATO commitment” and said “we should aim to do better still”.

claims.text: You are not being given an option to refuse the vaccines.

claimReview.title: Video falsely claims that you cannot refuse the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. Consent must be obtained before the vaccines are given and people with ‘capacity’ have the right to refuse. There are special procedures to follow regarding individuals who do not have capacity to make this decision.

claims.text: EU law controls UK migration policy.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on immigration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: EU law means the UK can’t control the number of EU citizens coming to the country, but we can perform border checks and refuse entry to certain people.
