claims.text: A city centre fight was filmed in Luton as pubs re-opened in April 2021.

claimReview.title: Street fight was not filmed when lockdown eased in England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video was actually taken in the Netherlands last year, ahead of a football match.

claims.text: Nearly half of the aid sent to Syria came from the US and UK compared to 1% or less for other countries such as Saudi Arabia and Japan.

claimReview.title: Humanitarian aid to Syria in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That was correct of one of the UN's funds. Taking the two main funds together the UK and US made up 38% of funding, and Japan gave just under 3%.

claims.text: A WD-40 ad from the 1960s is filled with sexual innuendo.

claimReview.title: WD-40 did not say it “makes screwing a pleasure” - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t a real ad. It was created as a joke.

claims.text: A photo of Hyde Park Corner shows protestors at an anti-lockdown march on 24 April 2021.

claimReview.title: Photo of 2018 anti-Brexit march mislabelled as showing 2021 anti-lockdown march - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. It shows protestors at an anti-Brexit march in October 2018.

claims.text: This was spent on each employee only contacting two people each.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to an average figure part-way through the contract and includes workers who were not employed by Serco.

claims.text: DWP employs 4,045 to tackle benefit fraud.

claimReview.title: Do benefit fraud investigators outnumber super-rich tax inspectors 8:1? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It employs around 4,000 full-time equivalent staff to deal with benefit fraud, as of October 2017. Of these, 1,900 are directly involved in investigations.  An estimated £2 billion in benefits were fraudulently claimed in 2017/18, according to the government.

claims.text: NHS 111 has directed triple the number of people to GPs and A&E in 2014 compared to 2013.

claimReview.title: Factcheck: NHS 111 isn't referring triple the number of patients to GPs and A&Es - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Referrals have doubled in that time, but so have calls. That's partly due to the service being rolled out fully in 2013.

claims.text: Under the Geneva Convention refugees should seek refuge in the first safe country they come to.

claimReview.title: Do refugees have to stay in the first safe country they reach? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The UN Refugee Convention does not make this requirement of refugees, and UK case law supports this interpretation.  Refugees can legitimately make a claim for asylum in the UK after passing through other “safe” countries.

claims.text: Tesco wasted 119 million meals last year.

claimReview.title: Did Tesco waste 119 million meals last year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is true, if you define a meal as 0.5kg of food. It’s likely to equal a very small proportion of the food wasted by Tesco’s customers or across its supply chain.

claims.text: The wealthiest are paying more and more tax.

claimReview.title: What do the wealthiest pay in tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no one-line answer: it depends on who you define as the wealthiest.

claims.text: According to a University of Bristol study, mask-wearing by large numbers of people can reduce the R rate by 0.25.

claimReview.title: New study estimates mask wearing could cut R number by 25%, not 0.25 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The study estimated that if everyone in a given population wore a mask it could lead to a median reduction of the R number of 25%, not a flat reduction of 0.25.

claims.text: All the rest of the world trades with the EU under World Trade Organisation rules.

claimReview.title: The EU's other trade agreements - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. The EU has finalised 48 trade agreements with other countries of various kinds, beyond World Trade Organisation rules.

claims.text: There are 5,000 fewer mental health nurses since 2010.

claimReview.title: Are mental health nurse numbers down? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct looking just at mental health nurses and excluding those who work in learning disabilities. NHS Digital, which publishes the figures, uses a broader definition of mental health nurse that includes both groups. Looking at both of these the number of nurses has decreased by around 7,000 since 2010.

claims.text: Trade deals agreed with 70 countries are collectively worth £766 billion, a major boost to Britain’s economy.

claimReview.title: Express vastly overstates impact of UK trade deals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This £766 billion figure refers to the total value of trade between the UK and countries it has agreed trade deals with—not the value that they add. Most of these deals were rolled over from when the UK was an EU member.

claims.text: All EU members have to adopt the Euro after 2020.

claimReview.title: EU member countries don’t all have to join the Euro by 2020 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The UK and Denmark have opt-outs so don’t have to join the Euro. The seven countries without an opt-out and not already in the Euro are supposed to join it, but only once they meet certain conditions. There is currently no time limit on this process.

claims.text: More than a third of babies are born to foreign parents.

claimReview.title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About a third of babies in England and Wales have at least one parent born outside the UK. You probably wouldn’t call all those parents ‘foreign’.

claims.text: Joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) has the potential to boost GDP by up to £20 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Express overstates Brexit trade deal value, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on government modelling which assumes the US also joins the bloc, which it has indicated it will not do, at least at the moment.

claims.text: The government has restored the nurses’ bursary.

claimReview.title: Was Dawn Butler right about Boris Johnson ‘lying’ to Parliament? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government has reintroduced a non-repayable grant for all student nurses. However, student nurses must continue to pay their own tuition fees, without the contribution they received when the old bursary applied.

claims.text: NHS England head Simon Stevens has said the government’s spending commitments are a “clear acceptance of our argument” and that their case for funding has been “heard and actively supported”.

claimReview.title: The government has misquoted the head of NHS England on spending plans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government is misquoting Mr Stevens. He has welcomed the fact that the money has been ‘frontloaded’ so that more is spent in earlier years and previously said the NHS’s requests are being heard in the context of public spending constraints. He has since commented that it would be a “stretch” to say the NHS is getting all of what it asked for.

claims.text: Asylum seekers are often here illegally.

claimReview.title: We factchecked a viral video on asylum seekers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is legal to apply for asylum in the UK. You can’t be penalised if applying for asylum if you entered or are in the country illegally.

claims.text: The government orchestrated the fuel panic to sell off soon-to-expire fuel stocks built up during the pandemic.

claimReview.title: No evidence government spreading fuel shortage rumours to sell surplus - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this. There wasn’t a build up of fuel stocks during the pandemic. Supply fell to meet reduced demand.

claims.text: At the 2019 Labour conference, Palestinian flags filled the hall.

claimReview.title: These claims about the 2019 Labour conference are incorrect - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This happened at the 2018 conference.

claims.text: Reported crime is rising under the Conservatives.

claimReview.title: Is crime up under the Conservatives? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Crimes recorded by the police have been rising since 2014, but that's partly down to changes in recording practices. Crime in England and Wales is falling over the long term according to the more reliable Crime Survey.

claims.text: 1,295 died of a stroke in England in one day.

claimReview.title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is likely not true. Stroke death figures in England are closer to 65 people daily.

claims.text: The Covid-19 pandemic was planned and was facilitated by the use of false positive PCR tests.

claimReview.title: Viral video includes lots of false claims and half truths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have repeatedly debunked the conspiracy that the pandemic was a planned operation and PCR tests have a high rate of accuracy.

claims.text: Coronavirus stays on fabric for 9 hours, so washing clothes or being exposed to the sun for two hours meets the purpose of killing it.

claimReview.title: Coronavirus graphics you may have been sent on WhatsApp are not actually from Unicef - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how long the virus can survive on fabric. There isn’t evidence that it can transmit from fabrics to people, though soiled clothing from Covid-19 patients should be washed normally.

claims.text: Vaccines prevent transmission of the Delta variant of Covid-19 for only eight weeks.

claimReview.title: Doctor who challenged Sajid Javid made misleading claims about vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s difficult to measure the effect of vaccines on transmission, but available evidence suggests it’s longer than eight weeks and boosters are likely to increase that protection.

claims.text: The budget deficit has fallen by two thirds since 2009/10, just before the Coalition came into power.

claimReview.title: Best laid plans... for reducing the deficit - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That's correct.

claims.text: There are now more nurses from the European Union going home than coming to the UK.

claimReview.title: Where have all the (EU) nurses gone? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: In the year to September 2017 the number of nurses from the EU leaving the NHS in England outweighed those joining it for the first time in at least five years. We don’t know if they left the UK or what jobs they went on to do.

claims.text: The risk of transmitting Covid-19 from an unmasked person to an unmasked person is 90%. From an unmasked person to a masked person it is 30%. From a masked person to an unmasked person it is 5%. From a masked person to a masked person it is 1.5%.

claimReview.title: Figures in viral mask graphic aren’t substantiated - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: While evidence supports wearing masks to reduce the transmission of Covid-19, these figures are unsubstantiated.

claims.text: In Wales you cannot sit in the park on a bench.

claimReview.title: It’s true that recent changes to lockdown rules are slightly different throughout the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: When the Facebook post the claim is from was shared the Welsh government said you shouldn’t spend a prolonged period on a park bench. This guidance has now changed slightly and says it’s okay to be out for a walk in a park and to stop to sit down so long as you spend most of the time out of the house exercising.

claims.text: Dominic Raab posted and then deleted a tweet describing Scotland as a region of England.

claimReview.title: This supposed Dominic Raab tweet seems to be an old fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The tweet seems to be a fake. There is no evidence Mr Raab ever tweeted this, he has denied he ever did and it was covered widely as a fake by the media over a year ago when it first surfaced.

claims.text: According to the vaccine manufacturer’s own vaccine package insert, measles is the number one side effect of the MMR.

claimReview.title: Measles is not the “number one side effect” of the MMR vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. “Atypical measles” is mentioned as an adverse reaction (which is not the same as a side effect) of the MMR vaccine used in the US and one of the UK MMR vaccines. People given a certain type of measles jab in the 1960s and 70s could get “atypical measles” if they were exposed to a certain measles strain afterwards. The other UK MMR vaccine brand lists “atypical measles” as a “possible side effect” as some people who were given the MMR got atypical measles if they also got the old measles jab.

claims.text: Germany’s second biggest export market is China.

claimReview.title: Trading places: Who are the UK and Germany’s biggest trade partners? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. In 2017 France was Germany’s second largest export market, and China was third.

claims.text: The ‘Indian variant’ hasn’t affected the countries between India and the UK.

claimReview.title: The so-called ‘Indian variants’ have been found in lots of countries - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The B1.617 variants have been found across many continents, and many countries ‘between India and the UK’.

claims.text: The vaccine is being made by MIT which is a deep state cabal company.

claimReview.title: Luminescent enzymes not in Covid-19 vaccine and other myths debunked - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: None of the vaccines are being made by MIT, which is a highly-respected university.

claims.text: All posts on Facebook are about to be made public.

claimReview.title: Facebook is not suddenly sharing private posts - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is an old rumour that has been spread many times before.

claims.text: Conservative-led changes to corporation tax, inheritance tax, capital gains tax and the bank levy will lose the government £70 billion between April 2016 and April 2022.

claimReview.title: Have the Conservatives brought in £70 billion worth of tax cuts? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The individual figures stand up to a degree of scrutiny, but this claim gives a limited picture of how these taxes have changed overall.

claims.text: Buy to let landlords get £6bn in subsidies from the government.

claimReview.title: What landlords are getting from the government - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s not clear where this figure is from. In any case, the rules on tax relief for landlords have recently changed, so the amount claimed by landlords is likely to change too.

claims.text: The Duke of Cambridge presides over the UN’s Agenda 21, a global depopulation plan.

claimReview.title: Prince William is not leading a global depopulation agenda - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The UN’s Agenda 21 is a sustainable development plan, published in 1992 and not a global depopulation plan. Regardless, Prince William doesn’t preside over it.

claims.text: Your name, as registered at birth, is a fictional legal entity which you can choose whether or not to use. Obligations such as attending court are optional if you disregard what is described as the fictional legal entity.

claimReview.title: Video makes misleading claims about birth certificates and the law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These beliefs have previously failed as a defence in UK courts. All births in England, Wales and Northern Ireland must be registered within 42 days of the child being born. In Scotland a birth must be registered within 21 days.

claims.text: If we leave the EU, fuel bills will be lower.
claims.claimant: Michael Gove, Boris Johnson and Gisela Stuart

claimReview.title: What could happen to VAT and energy prices if we leave the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Leaving aside the wider economic impacts of leaving the EU, if we vote to leave the government could choose to remove the 5% VAT rate on fuel as Vote Leave has suggested. Having the power to do this doesn’t necessarily mean energy bills will be lower if we leave.

claims.text: Universal Credit has got 200,000 people into work.

claimReview.title: Universal Credit has not got 200,000 people into work - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This was the government’s estimate of what Universal Credit would do by 2024/5. It may not be reliable, and can never be measured properly.

claims.text: Ivermectin can cure Covid-19 in 48 hours.

claimReview.title: Viral video spreads misinformation about ethylene oxide and Ivermectin - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A study looking at Ivermectin’s impact on the SARS-CoV-2 virus in cells in the lab found it dramatically reduced the amount of viral RNA in cells within 48 hours, which doesn’t mean it can do the same in people. Both the Department of Health and Social Care and the WHO have said there is not sufficient evidence to prove the efficacy of Ivermectin as a cure for Covid-19, and its use remains controversial.

claims.text: Individual EU countries could veto a deal on the UK leaving the EU.

claimReview.title: Who can veto a Brexit deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Individual countries can’t veto a treaty governing the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, but could veto a treaty establishing Britain’s new relationship with the EU.

claims.text: A company called Omicron Nanotechnology Limited exists and has something to do with the pandemic.

claimReview.title: Dissolved Omicron nanotechnology company has nothing to do with Covid-19 variant - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There was a (now-dissolved) company registered on Companies House with this name. It has nothing to do with the Covid-19 variant of the same name, except they are both named after the Greek letter omicron.

claims.text: The average wait for hospital inpatient care fell from over 13 weeks to four weeks between 1997 and 2009.

claimReview.title: Labour's record on inequality and social mobility: 1997 to 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for England.

claims.text: The government’s tax take has been roughly between 34% and 38% of GDP since the 1970s and is set to rise to 38%.

claimReview.title: Historically high levels of tax? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These figures seem to refer to all government income, not just taxes. On that basis it’s broadly correct, although income has been more than 40% of GDP at points.

claims.text: Dr Anthony Fauci has said that Covid-19 vaccines don’t protect against Covid or death.

claimReview.title: Dr Fauci did not ‘admit’ Covid-19 vaccines aren’t working - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He didn’t. He actually said that evidence from Israel had shown that immunity against Covid-19, hospitalisation from it, and to a certain extent deaths from it, appeared to decrease over time.

claims.text: There have been about 1,500 deaths in police custody since 1990, and about one third of those who died were from black and minority ethnic backgrounds.

claimReview.title: Deaths of BAME people in police custody - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: About a tenth of identified deaths in police custody were people from black and minority ethnic backgrounds. This is based on figures from the charity INQUEST, which has identified 1563 deaths in total during or following police contact in England and Wales since 1990

claims.text: The UK is now capable of producing 80% of our own PPE.

claimReview.title: Boris Johnson’s PPE figures don’t tell the whole story - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a snapshot figure from a year ago, and doesn’t include gloves which make up around 45% of the UK’s PPE demand.

claims.text: Five helicopters are going to spray the air with disinfectant overnight in order to combat the new coronavirus

claimReview.title: There is no plan to combat the new coronavirus with helicopters spraying disinfectant - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a false rumour that has spread all over the world.

claims.text: All Commonwealth countries take 9% of UK exports.

claimReview.title: Trade with the Commonwealth - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: The government’s pledge to halve the disability employment gap won’t be met for 50 years.

claimReview.title: The disability employment gap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The gap isn’t currently falling fast enough to meet the government’s pledge, but the idea it’s 50 years away is more rhetorical than factual.

claims.text: The number of EU nationals leaving the NHS jumped by 14% in 2017.

claimReview.title: EU staff in the NHS: what has happened since the referendum? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct for staff in England, comparing the number who left in 2016 with the number who left in 2017.

claims.text: Everything is closed except supermarkets, pharmacies and petrol stations.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Other shops, including pet shops, dry cleaners and Post Offices can remain open.

claims.text: Poorer children are less likely to get into grammar schools.

claimReview.title: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Poorer children are less likely to go to grammar schools even if they are high achievers. It’s not certain if this is because poorer children are less likely to apply, or less likely to get in, or a bit of both.

claims.text: Visits to a GP or A&E for self-treatable conditions cost the NHS £850 million a year.

claimReview.title: Could 18 million GP appointments be seen by pharmacists? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We have limited evidence on the number of self-treatable appointments, so any cost estimate is fairly rough. How much could be saved by avoiding these appointments depends on whether the number of staff or buildings used could be reduced as a result.

claims.text: There are 350,000 homeless British people.

claimReview.title: This viral image on immigration and homelessness has a fundamental flaw - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The charity Shelter calculated that an estimated 320,000 people in Great Britain were homeless at the start of 2018. We don’t know what proportion were UK citizens but they certainly weren’t all British.

claims.text: Masks increase the risk of bacteria and illness.

claimReview.title: No evidence masks limit oxygen for children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s true that masks can pick up bacteria, but there’s no evidence that this can contribute to an increased risk of illness, if worn normally.

claims.text: Ian Austin, former Labour MP has said he won’t vote for Labour.

claimReview.title: Ken Clarke did not say he won’t vote for the Conservatives - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. He also asked Labour voters to vote for the Conservatives.

claims.text: In response to the New Zealand mosque attacks, Islamists have burned down a Christian church in Pakistan.

claimReview.title: This video doesn't show a church in Pakistan being burned in retaliation for the New Zealand attacks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The video used as evidence for this statement shows an attack on a church in Egypt in 2013.

claims.text: You must queue in single file and one meter apart.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: No advice on queuing has been issued, but the government recommends people stay two metres apart.

claims.text: Leaving the EU would cause billions of pounds worth of damage to the NHS budget each year.

claimReview.title: Would leaving the EU cost the NHS? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Most economists predict that leaving the EU would harm economic growth and be an overall cost to the government’s budget. Whether this affects spending on the NHS would be depend on future political decisions.

claims.text: Serco and Qinetiq are owned by the monarchy.

claimReview.title: This video makes a number of inaccurate claims about the Covid-19 pandemic - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true.

claims.text: In a day, Italy sent home more than 14,000 patients after treating them with Aspirin and Apronax.

claimReview.title: Facebook post about Italy, coronavirus and 5G is almost all false - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Italian Medicines Agency doesn’t mention aspirin or apronax in its list drugs used to treat Covid-19 outside of clinical trials. And there’s no record of a day when 14,000 people were sent home from hospital in Italy.

claims.text: Nearly half the population thinks the reason people lost their jobs in the pandemic was due to their own underperformance.

claimReview.title: Guardian report on public opinion about job losses needs context - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A survey found 47% of the population think job performance is an important factor in recent job losses, not necessarily the main reason.

claims.text: One third of private rented homes don't meet basic health and safety standards.

claimReview.title: The state of private rented homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Close to a third of private rented properties don't meet the official Decent Homes Standard, but health and safety is only one possible reason a home can fail that. A sixth of private rental homes failed minimum health and safety standards in 2013.

claims.text: Tennis pro Serena Williams wrote a post saying she is “sick of COVID-19” and sick of “black vs. white”.

claimReview.title: This Facebook post isn’t by tennis player Serena Williams - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect, the post was shared by someone also called Serena Williams, but not the tennis player.

claims.text: New rules mean that men accused of rape must prove that the woman consented to sex.

claimReview.title: Men accused of rape don't have to "prove that a woman said Yes" - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The advice for police and prosecutors doesn't change the law. The state almost always has to prove lack of consent, and lack of a reasonable belief that there was.

claims.text: Greenhouse gas emissions fell by 15% between 2010 and 2014, one of the biggest reductions in a single parliament.

claimReview.title: UK carbon emissions are falling - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s right.

claims.text: The £350 million a week we pay to the EU budget is the same as the cost of building a new NHS hospital every week or hiring 600,000 nurses.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on our EU membership fee - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We send £250 million not £350 million. That could pay for an NHS hospital but at the moment £85 million of it is spent in the UK paying for things like farmers and poorer areas, so we would have to cut that spending first.

claims.text: Rapper DMX had a Covid-19 vaccine days before he died of a heart attack.

claimReview.title: No evidence rapper DMX had Covid-19 vaccine before his death - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s no evidence DMX had a Covid-19 vaccine just before his heart attack and no evidence that Covid-19 vaccines cause heart attacks.

claims.text: The Conservatives nearly doubled the debt from £950 billion to £1.8 trillion.

claimReview.title: Fake Boris Johnson quote spreads on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Broadly correct. Government debt currently stands at just below £1.8 trillion, which is 81% of GDP. In May 2010 when the Conservatives came to office, it was worth just over £1 trillion or 64% of GDP.

claims.text: The number of police officer could be the lowest since the 1970s following funding cuts.

claimReview.title: Police numbers: back to the 1970s? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The cuts have yet to be announced and we don't know how they'd affect officer numbers. A cut of 14,000 officers would mean the lowest number since the 1970s.

claims.text: Understaffing in hospitals at weekends is responsible for 11,000 deaths according to research.

claimReview.title: No evidence 11,000 NHS weekend deaths are caused by understaffing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The research doesn't say this. It did find 11,000 excess deaths but says to assume these are avoidable "would be rash and misleading".

claims.text: Disadvantaged children who go to grammar school progress twice as fast than their better-off peers.

claimReview.title: Do poor grammar schools pupils make twice as much progress? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s the finding of one study, from 2004. The relatively few poor children who attend grammar schools seem to progress more than wealthier children, but those in the schools around them perform worse.

claims.text: The Conservatives haven’t put a figure on their proposed cap on adult social care costs.

claimReview.title: Will there be a cap on social care costs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government hasn’t said what the proposed cap on adult social care costs in England might look like. It will be included in a consultation after the election.

claims.text: Membership of the Comprehensive and Progressive Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) will mean tariffs are slashed on 99.9% of UK exports.

claimReview.title: Express overstates Brexit trade deal value, again - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: 85.4% of UK exports are already eligible for tariff-free access to the bloc. Joining the CPTPP would increase this to 99.9% of goods.

claims.text: A chicken welfare association has paused hen adoptions because people were buying them for food.

claimReview.title: An adoption centre did pause adoptions of rabbits for fear they’d be used as food, but there’s no evidence it’s widespread - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is true the British Hen Welfare trust has paused adoptions until the Covid-19 situation improves, but it is not clear why. The RSPCA said it hasn’t received any reports of these animals being killed for food.

claims.text: The recent deaths of four British Airways pilots could be linked to the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: British Airways hasn’t told their pilots they don’t need Covid-19 vaccine - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence that the deaths were linked in any way, and no information has been provided about their vaccination status.

claims.text: The unemployment rate is the lowest it’s been for over a decade.

claimReview.title: Unemployment is at a 10-year low - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: Data will be linked to your NHS number, date of birth and postcode.

claimReview.title: The deadline for opting out of the NHS GP data collection has changed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: NHS Digital will convert these details into codes to pseudonymise the data, which it says means no one will be able to directly identify you from the data without also having the key that links each patient to their codes.

claims.text: The total number of murders in London, even excluding victims of terrorism, has risen by 38% since 2014.

claimReview.title: Has the number of murders in London overtaken New York? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mostly correct. The number of homicides (not just murders) increased from 84 in 2014 to 116 in 2017. Over a longer period, the number of homicides in London has remained at around 100 per year.

claims.text: The UK’s “underground population” grew by 327,000 between 2010 and 2015.

claimReview.title: Do 74 people try to enter the UK illegally every day? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how many people entered the UK without being detected.

claims.text: Pfizer has changed the formulation of its Covid-19 vaccine for children aged five to 11 to include an ingredient used to stabilise heart attack patients.

claimReview.title: Claims about changes to Pfizer vaccine for children miss important details - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The FDA recently approved the inclusion of tromethamine in paediatric doses of Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine. It was included to extend the vaccine’s shelf life, and is not currently used in the UK. It is used to treat a condition which may result from illness following a heart attack.

claims.text: Councils are making it a criminal offence to be poor.

claimReview.title: Is it a crime to be poor? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s considerably more complicated than that. Councils and police are often responding to perceived anti-social behaviour from rough sleepers rather than poverty or homelessness in itself, but to address it they do use powers that can, directly or indirectly, lead to a criminal penalty.

claims.text: There are no biohazard bins used for PPE such as masks and gloves.

claimReview.title: Government advise special precautions for disposing of infectious PPE - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Clinical waste bins aren’t advised for most people, though they are in some settings like hospitals. There are also guidelines in place to make contamination from infected PPE less likely, and disposal safer.

claims.text: Drinking two glasses of water after waking up helps activate internal organs.

claimReview.title: Drinking water at set times does not provide certain health benefits - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this.

claims.text: New analysis shows that the UK will be £135 billion richer with no deal.

claimReview.title: Old claim about Brexit economic boost resurfaces - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The analysis in question is two years old, and claims that GDP would grow by £135 billion if the UK unilaterally removed all barriers to international trade after Brexit. The analysis has been criticised by other economists, especially for its argument that the UK would not face new non-tariff barriers to trade with the EU in this scenario.

claims.text: Fewer people have died from Covid-19 in the past 40 days than one day of cancer deaths.

claimReview.title: Daily cancer deaths not higher than those from Covid during last 40 days - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The data used when the claim was made actually shows the number of people over a 40 day period who died of Covid-19 was higher than the average daily cancer death rate.

claims.text: 15,000 passengers are arriving into the UK daily at the moment.

claimReview.title: The government hasn’t provided evidence for its claim that 15,000 arrive per day into the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government hasn’t yet provided any evidence to back this up, and the Home Office has said it does not recognise the figure and that in their view it is wrong.

claims.text: Since 2010 a million more households are stuck renting from a private landlord. More than 11 million people rent from a private landlord and many of them are at the sharp end of the housing crisis.

claimReview.title: There are 11 million people in the private rented sector - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The numbers on the scale of private renting are accurate.

claims.text: Israel, Singapore, India, Hong Kong and the U.S. trade with the EU under WTO terms.

claimReview.title: Who trades with the EU under WTO rules? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Israel has a trade agreement with the EU. Also, while Singapore currently trades with the EU under WTO terms, it has reached a trade agreement with the EU that now needs approval by the European Parliament and Council.

claims.text: BBC Children in Need has given Black Lives Matter £10 million.

claimReview.title: Children in Need is not donating £10 million to Black Lives Matter - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Children in Need has pledged £10 million over ten years to benefit young black people in the UK. The money is not specifically going to Black Lives Matter.

claims.text: The Pfizer vaccine is 99% graphene oxide.

claimReview.title: The Pfizer vaccine isn’t 99% graphene oxide - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. The MHRA has told Full Fact that this is ‘completely incorrect’.

claims.text: Wages are lower today than they were ten years ago.

claimReview.title: Have wages fallen in the past ten years? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Yes, the official headline measure of median weekly wages for full time workers is lower than ten years ago.

claims.text: Coronavirus is as deadly as the flu.

claimReview.title: Vaccine rap battle full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Without vaccination, evidence shows that Covid-19 has a higher fatality rate than the flu. Restrictions such as lockdowns, which are not implemented for the flu, also suppressed the number of deaths.

claims.text: Government data shows 460 deaths and 243,612 injuries from Covid-19 vaccines in the UK.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 vaccines haven’t caused 460 deaths - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. Deaths and other 'injuries' may occur after someone has had a vaccine, but this does not mean they were caused by the vaccine.

claims.text: UKHSA data shows that the Covid-19 vaccines are negatively effective.

claimReview.title: The Covid-19 vaccines don’t have ‘negative efficacy’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. This data cannot be used to estimate vaccine effectiveness. Other estimates from the UKHSA show that the Covid-19 vaccines are effective.

claims.text: In 2016, 18,477 cyclists were injured in road accidents, including 3,499 who were killed or seriously injured.

claimReview.title: How many cyclists are killed each year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for Britain. The 18,477 figure includes deaths, of which there were 102.

claims.text: There are more than 850,000 registered sex offenders in the UK.

claimReview.title: There are far fewer than 850,000 registered sex offenders in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. A Freedom of Information request, published in May 2021, showed there were 95,844 people on the sex offenders register in England and Wales.

claims.text: The number of NHS overnight beds has fallen by a fifth over the last decade.

claimReview.title: The number of NHS hospital beds has fallen - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The number has fallen, but we don’t know by how far. The bed count included more things a decade ago, so this claim isn’t based on a fair comparison.

claims.text: 98% of world trade is conducted through the WTO.

claimReview.title: It's not correct that 98% of world trade is done via the WTO - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: WTO members are responsible for 98% of world trade, but it’s misleading to say all of this trade is done “through” the WTO. Estimates suggest around three quarters of trade is done on WTO terms (not including trade between EU countries). Instead, many WTO member trade with each other via separate trade agreements.

claims.text: A video shows Shamima Begum, who left the UK for Syria in 2015, beheading someone.

claimReview.title: This video does not show Shamima Begum beheading someone in Syria - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The video is not of Ms Begum. The rest of the video shows that it’s a different and much younger person.

claims.text: Nicola Sturgeon has banned the Union Jack from British government buildings and replaced it with the EU flag.

claimReview.title: Nicola Sturgeon has not banned the Union Flag from Scottish government buildings - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Union Flag has not been banned from Scottish government buildings. It is still flown on Remembrance Day as has always been the case. However, it’s true that in 2021, Nicola Sturgeon instructed that the European flag be flown daily, except for on specific flag dates.

claims.text: The vote on whether to accept the Committee on Standards’ report into Owen Paterson and its recommendation to suspend him from Parliament was a free vote.

claimReview.title: BBC presenter corrects false claim about Owen Paterson vote - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: False. It was a three-line whip.

claims.text: The police budget has been protected since 2015.

claimReview.title: Police budgets, numbers and community policing - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The England and Wales police budget has been protected since 2015 with increased local taxation making up for reductions in central government funding. If local taxation for the police is maximised in future, police funding overall will be protected.

claims.text: A no deal Brexit means the UK will not be part of the planned “United States of Europe”.

claimReview.title: What does a “WTO rules” Brexit look like? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As this is not EU policy it’s misleading to say a no deal Brexit would mean the UK would be able to avoid this “plan”.

claims.text: Chevening is taxpayer-funded.

claimReview.title: Chevening isn’t 'taxpayer-funded' in the usual sense - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It isn’t in the conventional sense—Chevening is paid for by a trust. But that trust is exempt from paying income tax and appears to have received at least some public money in the past.

claims.text: Over one million vulnerable people are unable to look after themselves due to reductions in spending on social care.

claimReview.title: Are there one million older people unable to look after themselves? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Analysis by Age UK found that there were 1.2 million over 65s who experienced difficulty with basic tasks such as eating and washing.

claims.text: 700,000 people died homeless on our streets last year.

claimReview.title: 726 homeless people are estimated to have died in England and Wales in 2018 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. 726 people are estimated to have died in England and Wales in 2018 who were either sleeping rough or in emergency accommodation at the time of their death or shortly before.

claims.text: Reported victims of needle spiking have tested positive for HIV.

claimReview.title: Spiking: Very rare to contract HIV through used needle - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It is extremely rare for HIV to be contracted via an unsterilised needle. In the UK it is recommended that people wait six weeks after possible exposure to test for HIV. A test a few days after exposure  would not accurately determine whether someone has been infected and would need to be repeated several weeks later. For many of the recent reports, this time span has not elapsed.

claims.text: Following the economic crash private sector wages were hit more quickly, harder and for longer than the public sector.

claimReview.title: Was the private sector hit hardest by the recession? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s correct. Private sector wages dropped much more rapidly than public sector wages during the recession. They then began recovering as public sector wages slowed. In recent years the gap between the two has narrowed again.

claims.text: A photo of two emaciated men strongly implies they were British soldiers.

claimReview.title: Post suggests American WW2 prisoners were British soldiers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is a famous photograph of two American civilians after the liberation of a Japanese POW camp in 1945.

claims.text: Around 40% of students at universities such as Oxford went to private school. 7% of the population go to private school.

claimReview.title: Social mobility and universities - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, around 44% of young, full-time Oxford undergraduate students in 2015/16 had gone to an independent school. Around 7% of all English school pupils went to an independent school in 2017.

claims.text: There has been a 0.5% year on year increase in the dropout rate of students since the introduction of £9,000 fees in 2012.

claimReview.title: 6% of young first-time students drop out of university after their first year - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, but not far off. This is the percentage point change over two years rather than yearly. It grew from a 5.7% dropout rate in 2012 to 6.2% in 2014. We don’t know how much this is linked with the increase in fees.

claims.text: The Conservatives introduced employment tribunal fees that stop workers from getting justice when treated unfairly.

claimReview.title: Fees for employment tribunals - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Coalition government introduced these fees, which can be repaid if cases are successful, but seem to have led to a big fall in number of people using employment tribunals.

claims.text: The number of British-born workers has fallen.

claimReview.title: Reports on employment figures are accurate, but not the whole picture - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The estimates suggest this happened, but it’s uncertain. The changes in the ONS’ best estimates weren’t big enough for us to be sure there was any real change.

claims.text: A Facebook post has claimed Chris Whitty received £40 million in funding from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation.

claimReview.title: Chris Whitty did not personally receive millions of pounds from the Bill & Melinda Gates foundation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Professor Whitty was working at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine when they received a large grant, $40 million of which went to a group of malaria research bodies of which he was Director and Principal Investigator.

claims.text: John Major prorogued parliament in 1997 to delay a report into Conservative MPs taking bribes.

claimReview.title: John Major did prorogue parliament for three weeks in 1997 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Major’s prorogation in 1997 had the effect of delaying a report into Conservative MPs taking bribes until after the 1997 election, whether or not that was his intention.

claims.text: Introducing an ‘opt-out’ system of organ donation in England could allow as many as 700 more lives to be saved a year.

claimReview.title: Could ‘opt-out’ organ donation save 700 lives a year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the government’s ambition but it’s based on very uncertain estimates, which in turn rely on a lot of assumptions. There is currently little evidence for how much changing the consent system actually improves transplant rates, if at all.

claims.text: Figures from the Office for National Statistics say you’re 32,000 times more likely to die of Covid if you’ve not been double jabbed.

claimReview.title: Unvaccinated people aren’t 32,000 times more likely to die from Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating:
The ONS report actually said that the age-adjusted risk of deaths involving Covid-19 was 32 times greater in unvaccinated people than in fully vaccinated individuals—not 32,000. 


In addition, the ONS and OSR have been clear that the 32 times greater figure changes over time due to a number of different factors, and this figure should not be used to measure vaccine effectiveness. 


The Jeremy Vine show has since tweeted to say that the statement was incorrect.

claims.text: Tackling global threats like terrorism and climate change — with global threats that don't stop at borders, strength in numbers through the EU keeps UK families safer and protects our future

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Stronger In on EU collaboration - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The EU has worked on these issues. Whether working as a group rather than individually keeps the UK safer is a matter of judgement.

claims.text: 40,000 primary age children were taught in classes of 36 or more in England in 2016.

claimReview.title: Primary class sizes in England and Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: A British old age pensioner gets a yearly benefit of £6,000.

claimReview.title: Viral image about pensioners and refugees is wrong on every single number - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A full British state pension is worth up to £6,500 or £8,500 per year. Pensioners may also qualify for top-ups, partner support, and additional benefits.

claims.text: The government promised to recruit an extra 5,000 GPs by 2020.

claimReview.title: Is the NHS recruiting enough new GPs? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct.

claims.text: £1 billion has been taken out of youth services.

claimReview.title: Spending on services for young people in England has fallen since 2010 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct in England. This is a 73% reduction in local authorities’ spending on youth services in England between 2010/11 and 2019/20. The wider budget for children and young people has fallen by about £1.4 billion or by 13%.

claims.text: The government's roadmap to ease Covid-19 restrictions will be set out in 5 phases.

claimReview.title: Facebook post on Ireland’s plans for exiting lockdown goes viral - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the plan from the Irish government.

claims.text: Article 42 of the Magna Carta 'enshrines' the right to free movement at home and across borders in peacetime.

claimReview.title: “Article 42” of Magna Carta only existed for a short time - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Wrong. This provision existed in 1215 but it's not part of the most recently signed Magna Carta or modern law.

claims.text: More female and black and minority ethnic lawyers were appointed to the senior rank of Queen’s Counsel in 2016/17 than ever before.

claimReview.title: Barristers and diversity - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, if you add both groups together. Looking at each category individually, there have been more female, and more black and ethnic minority, QCs appointed in previous years.

claims.text: Upskirting is not illegal because there is no specific crime covering the act.

claimReview.title: Upskirting: what’s the legal situation? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Upskirting offenders have been prosecuted under existing laws but there is criticism these don’t go far enough. A new bill would specify upskirting as a criminal act if passed.

claims.text: A BBC News report showed an actor pretending to be ill with Covid-19.

claimReview.title: A Covid-19 patient on BBC News is not a ‘crisis actor’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The man was a genuine Covid-19 patient, who subsequently added the phrase “crisis actor” to his Instagram profile as a joke.

claims.text: The proportion of babies born to foreign parents has risen from a quarter in 2008 to a third in 2015.

claimReview.title: A third of babies have at least one parent born outside the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The rise was less dramatic than that, and you probably wouldn’t call all those parents ‘foreign’. In England and Wales, the proportion of children who have at least one parent registered as born outside the UK rose slowly each year from about 30% in 2008 to about 33% in 2015.

claims.text: The £1.9 billion the government has spent on preparing for no deal so far could pay the salaries of around 85,000 nurses, 50,000 secondary school teachers or 49,000 police constables.

claimReview.title: What’s the cost of preparing for Brexit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The government hasn’t said how much of the government’s additional Brexit funding is going to no deal preparations specifically. That would pay the salaries of roughly this many staff, but it doesn’t tell us anything useful as these workers would cost more to employ than their salaries alone.

claims.text: Emma Tustin, convicted of the murder of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes, has been hospitalised after inmates forced her to eat 79 packets of salt.

claimReview.title: Reports Emma Tustin was hospitalised after inmates force fed her salt are not true - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Sodexo, which runs the prison where Tustin is serving her sentence, says there is no truth to the claim.

claims.text: Under the government’s new immigration rules anyone earning less than £25,600 is regarded as an unskilled worker.

claimReview.title: Most of these NHS jobs are classed as “skilled” under new immigration rules - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. All workers applying for the skilled worker visa must have a salary of at least £20,480, and if it is below £25,600 they must also fulfil other criteria to gain a visa. Jobs are not classed by the government as “skilled” depending on salary.

claims.text: A Facebook post shows a screengrab from a government website with a list of reported deaths and side effects caused by the Covid-19 vaccines.

claimReview.title: Screenshot of website about Covid-19 vaccine side effects is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The image in this post is mocked-up and does not actually appear on the site, though it uses figures which do appear there.

claims.text: From October 2019 the BBC will add permanent Arabic subtitles to EastEnders, to help refugees and other migrants refugees settle in.

claimReview.title: Middle-EastEnders? No, the BBC isn’t adding Arabic subtitles to its flagship soap - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t correct, the story comes from a satirical news website.

claims.text: 14 million people are living in poverty.

claimReview.title: Claim about UK wealth and poverty is flawed - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct for the UK in 2017/18, according to the main measure of relative poverty used in the UK.

claims.text: The UK has spent 100 million on security at Calais in the last three years.

claimReview.title: How much is the UK spending on security at Calais? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We haven’t seen evidence to confirm this. It's from a news report apparently based on an unpublished government briefing to journalists. An agreement on Thursday now means the figure is closer to £150m and covers others French ports as well.

claims.text: Home ownership is on the rise.

claimReview.title: Is home ownership on the up? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct over the last year in England. The proportion of homes owned by the occupier increased by 0.5 percentage points between 2016 and 2017.  This follows year on year falls since 2004.

claims.text: ATTC VR-84 is a patent for Zika virus that comes from the Rockefeller Foundation.

claimReview.title: Viral image about patents for viruses is misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is the name of a certain strain of Zika virus, which was first isolated in the 1940s in a lab funded by the Rockefeller Foundation. This strain was not patented.

claims.text: City of London Police and Martin Lewis are warning people about a scam involving banks and mobile networks.

claimReview.title: Martin Lewis and City of London Police have not warned about a scam involving banks and mobile networks - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. They have not been warning about this specific scam.

claims.text: We’re spending record levels on our NHS—£149 billion a year.

claimReview.title: Health and social care: What do we spend? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s how much public spending on health across the UK came to in 2016/17. Most, but not all of this money goes to the NHS.

claims.text: Royal Mail has instructed staff to step away from customers when making deliveries, and if necessary to sign for items on their behalf.

claimReview.title: Postal workers have been told to keep their distance when delivering parcels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct. Royal Mail confirmed that this is their policy.

claims.text: 10 of the UK’s Supreme Court judges voted to remain, and Lord Wilson voted to leave.

claimReview.title: No evidence for how Supreme Court judges voted in EU referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: We don’t know how any of the Supreme Court judges voted.

claims.text: A professor in New South Wales Australia, has said under oath that the Covid-19 vaccines are not vaccines.

claimReview.title: An Australian professor didn’t say Covid-19 vaccines aren’t vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The professor specified that the Covid-19 vaccines used in Australia are not “live vaccines” but did refer to them as vaccines.

claims.text: Just short of 100% of all the electricity Scotland uses is from renewable sources.

claimReview.title: Scotland’s electricity consumption isn’t 100% renewable - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Scotland produces renewable electricity equivalent to its annual consumption, but some of this is exported, meaning it uses significant amounts of non-renewable electricity as well. In 2020, 56% of the electricity consumed in Scotland came from renewable sources.

claims.text: A new law to speed up the installation of 5G technology was quietly passed on March 23.

claimReview.title: The 5G And Beyond Act is not a British law - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This law was passed in the US, not the UK, after going through Congress for a year. It’s intended to ensure the security of 5G infrastructure, not to speed up the installation.

claims.text: We spent just over £1 trillion bailing out the banks after the financial crisis.

claimReview.title: £1 trillion was not spent on bailing out banks during the financial crisis - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, the total government spend was £137 billion. Most of this has been paid back and around £27 billion is still outstanding. Around £1 trillion worth of financial guarantees were provided to investors—but these were promises designed to restore confidence in the banks, not cash for spending.

claims.text: 600,000 people aged 18-24 are unemployed.

claimReview.title: Immigration and unemployment in the UK - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: That’s wrong, as of July-September 2016. About 520,000 people aged 18-24 were unemployed that summer. Taking the time of year into account, the ‘seasonally adjusted’ estimate was about 473,000.

claims.text: Asymptomatic transmission of Covid-19 is a hoax.

claimReview.title: Covid-19 victims cannot be cremated against their wishes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. While studies have shown a wide range of results on how common asymptomatic transmission is, there is clear evidence that it has contributed significantly to the spread of the virus.

claims.text: Two men were sentenced to eight months in prison for throwing bacon at a mosque.

claimReview.title: Two men did go to prison for throwing bacon at a mosque, while a man was fined for burning poppies - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mateusz Pawlikowski and Piotr Czak-Zukowski were both sentenced to two eight-month sentences, to run concurrently, for criminal damage and a racial/religious public order offence after verbally abusing and throwing bacon at a worshipper in a mosque.

claims.text: More foreigners have jobs than before the EU referendum.

claimReview.title: What’s happened to employment since the vote to leave the EU? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, the number of people born outside the UK in employment has increased over the past two years.

claims.text: Japan has a larger and older population, and a higher population density, than the UK.

claimReview.title: Far more people have died of Covid-19 in the UK than in Japan - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are all correct.

claims.text: There are 11,500 more doctors now than there were in 2010.

claimReview.title: The number of doctors and nurses in NHS England - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This isn’t a fair comparison. The most recent comparable figures show the increase was less than that: about 9,000 more FTE doctors between September 2010 and 2016.

claims.text: A Labour poster featuring Diane Abbott said “Labour will put black and ethnic minority families first to preserve a diverse nation”.

claimReview.title: This Diane Abbott poster is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The poster is not real, and never appeared anywhere on a billboard. The photo is a mock-up.

claims.text: The Vote Leave campaign includes three completely untrue claims on its EU referendum leaflet: Turkey becoming a member, an EU army and the £350 million a week cost of membership.

claimReview.title: False claims about false claims about the EU referendum - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The claim about the cost of membership is not true, because we don’t pay that much. The claims about the other two things have been overstated, but they can’t be ruled out as completely untrue.

claims.text: Construction of the Channel Tunnel cost £16 billion in today’s prices.

claimReview.title: We can’t say if Test and Trace has cost more than the Channel Tunnel—yet - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is complicated, and hard to be sure about. We’ve seen some estimates that are higher, and others that are lower.

claims.text: Masks limit oxygen intake.

claimReview.title: No evidence masks limit oxygen for children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence to support this.

claims.text: The ‘P’ on the photo page of passports stands for “pauper” or “peasant”.

claimReview.title: No, the ‘P’ on your passport does not stand for ‘peasant’ - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The ‘P’ actually indicates that it is a machine readable passport.

claims.text: Bill Gates’ polio vaccine permanently disabled 47,000 children in India.

claimReview.title: The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation wasn’t kicked out of India - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is based on a paper which claims that the polio vaccine increases the incidence of paralysis caused by things that aren’t polio. This is far from certain.

claims.text: Under the new withdrawal agreement, Boris Johnson agreed to a 'level playing field' meaning the UK will follow many EU laws making us uncompetitive and restricting our future trade.

claimReview.title: We fact checked this viral image on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The level playing field is in the political declaration part of the deal which isn’t legally binding, and the UK hasn’t yet made firm or specific commitments to following EU standards. Northern Ireland will remain aligned to some EU single market rules.

claims.text: The Conservatives’ ambition is a state pension age of 75.

claimReview.title: John McDonnell repeats misleading claim about Conservative pension age plans - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was recommended in a report by the Centre for Social Justice think tank. There’s no indication that it’s Conservative party policy.

claims.text: Mercury is used as a preservative in vaccines and is not safe.

claimReview.title: The mercury-based chemical found in some UK vaccines is not dangerous - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A mercury based chemical (and not the same one that can build up in the body after ingesting infected fish) is present in some non-standard UK vaccines. But it is not harmful in those amounts.

claims.text: If a man takes a pregnancy test and gets a positive result, it means he most likely has testicular cancer.

claimReview.title: You shouldn’t rely on a pregnancy test to tell you whether you have testicular cancer - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Some people with testicular cancer can get a positive result on a pregnancy test. But it is not a conclusive way of diagnosing yourself, and if you have any symptoms you should go to a doctor.

claims.text: A picture of Jeremy Corbyn with a man reproduced on the MailOnline website claiming to show him on 26 May 2020, is actually from 2016.

claimReview.title: No, the Mail didn’t use an old photo of Jeremy Corbyn to claim he wasn’t social distancing on his birthday - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This picture was not taken in 2016, it seems to have been taken on 26 May 2020 as reported.

claims.text: A video shows overcrowding in St Mary’s Hospital, London and Covid-19 patients lying on the floor in corridors.

claimReview.title: This video supposedly showing Covid-19 patients at St Mary’s Hospital, London was actually filmed in Madrid - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect, the clip is actually two videos filmed in hospitals in Madrid in mid-March.

claims.text: Covid-19 does not kill 99.99% of us.

claimReview.title: Baseless claims about vaccine safety go viral on Facebook - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. It is estimated that Covid-19 has a fatality rate of around 0.5%-1% globally, though could be slightly higher in countries with older populations.

claims.text: Lateral flow tests show a positive result with drinks including lemonade, Coca Cola and Fanta.

claimReview.title: Lemonade and Fanta don’t test positive for Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is inaccurate. Testing soft drinks can return what appears to be a positive result, but this is a misuse of the test and returns an invalid result.

claims.text: Only 1.6% of Irish exports go to Northern Ireland.

claimReview.title: Irish border: how much trade? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, for goods exports in 2017.

claims.text: Fewer than 300 children have been hospitalised with Covid-19 in England since the pandemic began and all but around 20 had underlying health issues.

claimReview.title: Daily Mail understates the risks of Covid-19 to children - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. These appear to be the figures for intensive care admissions, not hospital admissions. They also do not include admissions with PIMS-TS. In total, there were 7,050 hospital admissions of children under 18 up to the end of February 2021, 3,181 involving children without underlying health conditions.

claims.text: Wearing a mask can cause hypercapnia, by making you breathe in too much carbon dioxide.

claimReview.title: Ordinary face masks are not harmful - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. Wearing a mask is safe for most people. There may be rare instances of harm involving  tight-fitting N95 or FFP2 masks.

claims.text: The index of economic need, underpinning prioritisation for the “Levelling Up Fund” has been transparently published by MHCLG.

claimReview.title: Details missing on levelling up funding - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: A list of local authority areas grouped prioritised according to economic need has been published. But no real detail as to how that was calculated has been published

claims.text: PCR tests should not be used to diagnose Covid-19.

claimReview.title: Social media video makes false claims about Covid-19 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: PCR tests are the gold standard way to test for Covid-19, and are very effective.

claims.text: 250,000 pieces of extremist material have been taken down from the Internet since February 2010.

claimReview.title: Removing extremist online material - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: As of 21 December 2016, 249,091 pieces of extremist content have been taken down by the Counter Terrorism Internet Referral Unit, according to official figures.

claims.text: A branch of Extinction Rebellion tweeted in support of a flyer saying “Corona is the cure. Humans are the disease.”.

claimReview.title: Anyone can make an Extinction Rebellion sticker - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Extinction Rebellion says they are not affiliated with the Twitter account.

claims.text: 800 Sure Start children’s centres have been closed in England since 2010.

claimReview.title: Not so sure of Sure Start figures - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is only part of the story. There are over 1,000 fewer Sure Start centres, but only 300 fewer children’s centres overall. Around 700 sites still operate but no longer meet the official definition of a Sure Start centre.

claims.text: About 500 lions have been released on the streets of Russia to stop people going out during the coronavirus pandemic.

claimReview.title: Russia has not unleashed 500 lions to stop people going outdoors - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. The Russian government has yet to announce a widespread lockdown of any kind in Russia. The image of the lion is from South Africa in 2016.

claims.text: We pay for the NHS with taxes.

claimReview.title: How is the NHS funded? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The NHS in England is funded mostly through general taxation and National Insurance contributions. A much smaller proportion is collected through patient charges, for things like prescriptions and dentistry.

claims.text: The population is projected to grow to 74 million, another 10 million by 2039.

claimReview.title: More people, more (NHS) problems? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Not quite, the population is projected to rise to 72.5 million by 2039, an increase of 7 million compared to 2016.

claims.text: Remaining in the EU gives us the right to prevent Turkey joining the EU.

claimReview.title: Brexit: What’s a “Germany plus” deal? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct—each EU member has a veto on other countries joining the EU.

claims.text: The Scottish onshore economy is as strong as the UK’s generally.

claimReview.title: Comparing Scottish and UK growth rates - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There’s more than one way to look at this. The UK’s economy has been growing faster than Scotland’s recently, according to official estimates.

claims.text: 21% of coronavirus deaths in England are in care facilities.

claimReview.title: It’s not true that 58% of Covid-19 deaths in Scotland were in care homes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct up to May. This was reported by the ECDC based on figures from the Office for National Statistics.

claims.text: 3.4% of patients waited more than 12 hours in Wales compared with 1.3% in England.

claimReview.title: A&E performance: England v Wales - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. That’s the percentage of A&E patients who spent more than 12 hours in A&E, from arrival to departure in 2016/17.

claims.text: There are more people in work in the UK than for many years.

claimReview.title: Does the UK have lower unemployment than the Eurozone? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct. 32 million people are in employment, which is a near record level, as is the employment rate at 75%.

claims.text: When asked about getting a good Brexit deal on Good Morning Britain Mr Starmer was unable to answer.

claimReview.title: This video has been edited to make Keir Starmer appear confused at the end - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is untrue. In the original video, Mr Starmer answers promptly. His reaction in this video has been edited.

claims.text: Independent experts from the Committee on Climate Change have said that a new runway at Heathrow can be delivered within the targets for greenhouse gas emissions.

claimReview.title: Heathrow airport emissions targets - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The Committee called on the government to publish a strategy for how emissions targets would be achieved, in light of planned expansion at Heathrow. It has also provided specific advice on how this could be done.

claims.text: This image shows a mother snorting drugs in front of her child.

claimReview.title: This is not a picture of a mum snorting drugs in front of a child - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: It’s a joke photo taken by a comedian.

claims.text: This video shows accurate footage of Keir Starmer’s reaction to being questioned on Brexit.

claimReview.title: This footage of Keir Starmer being interviewed on Good Morning Britain was edited before being posted by the Conservative party - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. The footage has been edited to make it seem as though Mr Starmer does not respond.

claims.text: Violent crime is at record levels.

claimReview.title: Violent crime is not at record levels - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect. Several reliable sources indicate that overall violent crime in England and Wales is far lower now than it was in the 1990s. Police figures show violent crimes at their highest recorded level, but these are unreliable.

claims.text: White, working-class boys are less likely than other groups to go on to university.

claimReview.title: Are white, working class boys the least likely to go to university? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct for England, using research for university joiners in 2010 and 2011 and looking at the least well-off students.

claims.text: 50,000 retail jobs were axed in the first half of this year.

claimReview.title: How many retail jobs have been lost this year? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This refers to businesses in all sectors who publicly announced job losses. Over the long term the number of UK retail jobs appear stable, but jobs in other sectors are growing.

claims.text: Al Gore said that the ice caps would melt by 2014.

claimReview.title: There wasn’t more polar ice “than ever” in 2015 - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: He didn’t say this, although he did suggest that sea ice in the Arctic might be gone during summer months by that year. Sea ice isn’t the only ice in the polar ice caps.

claims.text: There are 1,012 rapists and 343 killers on the run.

claimReview.title: How many suspects are wanted by police? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: These are not convicted rapists or killers. This is the number of records on the Police National Computer relating to people wanted in relation to these crimes in England and Wales, as of August last year. Not all wanted suspects will be on the database and some who are there could be counted twice.

claims.text: The OBR expects real household disposable incomes to be 2.8% higher in 2020/21 than they are at the moment.

claimReview.title: Brexit and household incomes - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Incorrect.

claims.text: Labour’s spending plans would cost £1.2 trillion over five years.

claimReview.title: There are serious problems with the Conservatives’ claim that Labour would spend £1.2 trillion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Labour hasn’t published its 2019 manifesto yet, so nobody knows. This is largely based on Labour’s previous policy announcements. Many of the figures behind this estimate are uncertain or based on flawed assumptions.

claims.text: The animals in the Covid-19 vaccine trials had a 100% death rate.

claimReview.title: There is no HIV in the Covid-19 vaccines - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Experts told Full Fact that animals in this type of trial are normally euthanised and that if animals had died due to the vaccine, human trials would have been halted.

claims.text: 1,852 people died in one day in England from a heart attack.

claimReview.title: These figures for non-Covid deaths aren’t accurate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is likely not true. About 49 people a day die in England of a heart attack.

claims.text: There is no link between the severity of a Covid-19 infection and the chances of suffering “long Covid” afterwards

claimReview.title: Matt Hancock got the evidence about long Covid wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect, based on the data Mr Hancock mentioned, which suggests that people who suffer from “long Covid” had more symptoms when they were infected, and were more likely to have visited hospital.

claims.text: Poland has a no-migrants policy.

claimReview.title: Does Poland’s migration policy explain its lack of terror attacks? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Poland doesn’t have a “no-migrants” policy but has very few foreign-born residents compared to other European countries.

claims.text: The Covid-19 pandemic is caused by radiation

claimReview.title: Covid-19 is an infectious disease, and a video claiming it isn’t is wrong - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is not true. It is caused by a virus.

claims.text: MPs’ salaries rose from £66,000 in 2010 to £79,500 in 2020.

claimReview.title: MPs salaries have grown faster than starting salaries of nurses, teachers and police officers - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is correct.  Factoring in inflation MP pay has increased by 2%.

claims.text: You are not allowed to go for a walk or bike ride to get fresh air.

claimReview.title: Viral list of UK lockdown rules is not right - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is wrong. You can walk or cycle as part of your daily exercise.

claims.text: The vaccines contain polysorbate 80 and that is known to cause fertility issues.

claimReview.title: Video of man reporting Covid-19 crimes to police is full of misinformation - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The AstraZeneca vaccine does contain small amounts of this additive, which is also used in food. There is no evidence that it causes fertility issues in humans at the levels used in food and vaccines.

claims.text: Chuka Umunna has suggested a possible coup against Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson, and wrote “It’s a fact the no-deal Brexit is the best possible outcome for the party”.

claimReview.title: An article about leaked Lib Dem emails is fake - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This is incorrect. Mr Umunna has not done either of these things, and the claim comes from edited images masquerading as a genuine Guardian news article.

claims.text: There are now 28 member states of the EU, the most recent being Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia.

claimReview.title: EU Referendum Voting Guide: Vote Leave on EU expansion - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Correct, there are now 28 member states of the EU.

claims.text: Troponins (proteins released into the bloodstream after myocardial injury) are 10 to 100 times higher after vaccine-acquired myocarditis.

claimReview.title: Evidence suggests myocarditis risk after Covid-19 vaccination is lower compared to Covid infection - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this. Troponin levels may be as high or even higher after myocarditis acquired by a Covid infection than acquired following vaccination.

claims.text: The government is using an arcane loophole to bypass the House of Commons to force through changes to maintenance grants for students.

claimReview.title: Are changes to maintenance grants being made through an arcane loophole? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: The way in which proposals are being introduced isn't unusual. The debate is over whether the government should have made the time for MPs to debate the changes in the chamber of the House of Commons following opposition from the Labour Party.

claims.text: Dominic Raab said that Covid-19 tests have a 93% false positive rate.

claimReview.title: Dominic Raab did not say Covid-19 tests have a 93% false positive rate - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: Mr Raab appears to have mis-spoken. He was talking about the success rate of detecting Covid-19 when people arrive at airports. Evidence suggests that false positives are rare in the most common Covid-19 tests.

claims.text: There will be between 700,000 and 2,800,000 fewer jobs as a result of several different options for post-Brexit trade deals with the EU.

claimReview.title: This image on the costs of Brexit is very misleading - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence for this in the report cited by the claimant, nor elsewhere.

claims.text: 98% of NHS trusts are in deficit.

claimReview.title: How many NHS trusts are in deficit? - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: This was roughly correct for acute trusts in the third quarter of 2015/16. But by the end of 2015/16 it was 65% of all NHS trusts, of which 75% were acute trusts (hospitals).

claims.text: Deaths among children between September to October may have been caused by myocarditis or pericarditis (inflammatory heart conditions which have been reported as a side effect of vaccination).

claimReview.title: No evidence linking deaths among children to vaccine rollout - Full Fact
claimReview.textualRating: There is no evidence of this. The MHRA says it has not identified an increased risk of myocarditis and pericarditis among under 18s. Incidences of myocarditis and pericarditis have been rare and “typically mild”.
